0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20602/homepage_large.4c1a1b88.jpg|Metamodern Sounds in Country Music|32293.0|Sturgill Simpson|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['High Top Mountain']|2014-05-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:46.009919|"

Sturgill Simpson saw Jesus juggle flames and met the devil in Seattle
column2: or so he sings on “Turtles All the Way Down”
column3: the opening track on his second solo album. Just when you think he’s slinging the same Biblical imagery Johnny Cash foretold on “The Man Comes Around”
column4: Simpson adds that he “Met Buddha yet another time/ And he showed me a glowing light within.” Rather than parrot the same Christian ideology that most country musicians consider integral to the genre
column5: this Kentucky-born singer-songwriter is a quester
column6: intrigued by the metaphysics of spiritual experience and wondering aloud if the Bible and a handful of 'shrooms will lead you to the same religious epiphany. This isn’t country music to put on when you want to stare at your hand for three hours—well
column7: it is
column8: but it’s more than that.

column1: Simpson’s true subject isn’t the “reptile aliens made of light” who “cut you open and pull out all your pain
column2: ” although that’s a great line for a country song. Instead
column3: he’s much more preoccupied on “Turtles” and throughout the nine songs that follow
column4: with a much more earthly and everyday emotion: “Love’s the only thing that ever saved my life.” Perhaps it’s because his steely voice turns surprisingly tender when he sings that line
column5: or perhaps because his Mellotron player provides a bed of strings as nebulous as the Milky Way—but somehow Simpson pulls it off without sounding pretentious
column6: schmaltzy
column7: or dangerous.

column1: With a sharp mind to match that Hag burr of a voice
column2: Simpson not only owns the best name in current country music but comprehends the genre as a vehicle for big
column3: unwieldy ideas about human consciousness and the nature of life. He got Pope portraitist Jason Seiler to do the cover art
column4: and Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are thanked in the liner notes. Nashville rarely sounds so trippy as it does on Metamodern Sounds in Country Music
column5: whose title alludes to Ray Charles by way of Seth Abramson. It’s heady stuff
column6: and potentially insufferable
column7: too
column8: if Simpson wasn’t able to keep everything down to earth. He favors clear melodies
column9: careful structures
column10: and riffs that draw on Nashville and Bakersfield traditions without sounding revivalist. Nothing else on Metamodern is quite so bold or quite so dense as “Turtles All the Way Down”
column11: but Simpson comes across as a man deeply dissatisfied with the easy answers country music typically passes along as wisdom.

column1: As “Long White Line” dissipates into a blast of spacey distortion
column2: Laur Joamets’ slide guitar sounds like a spacecraft taking off
column3: but the song itself is tightly structured and moored to some dusty honkytonk on Planet Earth. Only on the penultimate track does he really blast into the cosmos: “It Ain’t All Flowers” begins as a stark self-reckoning at the bathroom mirror
column4: then dissolves into a bizarre sci-fi jam full of backwards guitars
column5: parallel-universe synths
column6: and fragmented drum beats. Immediately after that song fades
column7: Simpson launches into the hidden bonus track
column8: “Pan Bowl”
column9: which drops us back in some remote Kentucky holler. It’s the most traditionally nostalgic moment on Metamodern Sounds
column10: full of soft-focus memories of four generations of Simpsons
column11: and the acoustic austerity only underscores sharpness of the songcraft and the vividness of the details. He may be a big thinker
column12: but when it comes to the primacy of the song in country music
column13: Simpson is a traditionalist. There are no extraneous sounds or ideas here
column14: nothing that’s not battened down to a carefully structured set of lyrics and melodies.

column1: As a result
column2: the best moment here may be the most unlikely: a cover of the 1988 post-New Wave hit “The Promise” by When in Rome. Simpson slows it down to a crawl
column3: yet this isn’t one of those reinterpretations that purports to find deeper meaning through a more tasteful “Mad World” reimagining. The melody is tricky
column4: especially divorced from that familiar piano line
column5: but Simpson delivers it with gentle stalwartness
column6:
testifying powerfully to the magnitude of love. The Mellotron string section swoops in to add some earthly drama to an emotion that might just explain the entire universe. 

"|19386.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19386-sturgill-simpson-metamodern-sounds-in-country-music/|7.7|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20573/homepage_large.3df6d4d5.jpg|II|31088.0|Moon B|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Peoples Potential Unlimited']|2014-05-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:46.509593|"

It’s fitting that Sussegad
column2: the first 12” offering from Moon B
column3: was pressed onto wax whose swirl of black and gray resembled smoke. The Atlanta-based producer (also known as Wes Gray) makes music that has qualities similar to that peculiar element: the music obfuscates its origins
column4: has an untenable aspect to its sound and
column5: well
column6: it sounds better when you’re smoking something on a basement couch
column7: at once digging the beat while similarly forgetting just what it is you’re listening to.

column1: Gray’s debut album was released on the Washington
column2: D.C. imprint Peoples Potential Unlimited in 2012 without much in the way of cover art
column3: or even song titles. Much like the other releases on that imprint
column4: Moon B’s music favors miasma over certainty
column5: avoiding easy genre characterization while also drawing on distinct musical tropes of the early 1980s. Much like his fellow labelmate Benedek
column6: the music that Moon B releases is made from a mix of hardware
column7: drum machines and samples of cheap 12”s that might never get ID’d by anyone beyond the most obscure of DJs.

column1: In some ways
column2: Moon B’s new album
column3: II
column4: is a step up: the production is a little crisper
column5: the tracks have titles
column6: and there’s actually sleeve art
column7: in this case a peculiar painting of an African-American man standing in the middle of the road at night
column8: a chicken in one hand
column9: his other raised in a fist. Not much is expanded upon beyond that
column10: though
column11: and while the music itself has grown trickier
column12: it hasn’t ranged far from what he laid down on his first singles.

column1: Opener “Gulls” begins with the sound of eerie analog keyboards from Music has the Right to Children-era Boards of Canada before canned handclaps take over
column2: the track meandering into such disparate zones as synth-funk
column3: '80s B-boy soundtracks
column4: and smooth jazz without ever quite landing in one: pop and lock to it
column5: or else just chill until the track dissolves back into white noise. The album standout is also the track with the best title: “Stank Tartare.” The synth bass is queasy and deep and slightly warped
column6: as if originating from an obscure funk tape left on the dashboardone summer afternoon. “Green Sky” has the kind of stiff yet rubberbanding rhythm to it that connects the dots between Kraftwerk and Whodini.

column1: Funk
column2: soul
column3: boogie
column4: jazz
column5: R&B
column6: electro
column7: New Age
column8: even touches of house music: all sorts of familiar yet unmoored sounds emerge from Moon B’s haze
column9: and nothing remains in focus for long. When some tracks begin
column10: it already seems like they have the potential to take divergent paths
column11: from a thumping house track or else a woozy early garage house instrumental—or
column12: if it's Moon B's wish
column13: a narrow path between the two.

column1: Yet
column2: in touching on all these genres and running them through all sorts of samplers and drum machines (among the listed equipment used: Kawai K1
column3: ESQ-1
column4: Roland Alpha Juno 1
column5: Yamaha DX21
column6: Korg Microsampler
column7: Tascam 424)
column8: there’s one thing curiously absent from the above list of genres: hip-hop. His working methods are not dissimilar from any post-Dilla hip-hop producers
column9: but Moon B presents a parallel world in which hip-hop never happened
column10: where the beats are dope but not dope enough where someone would drop rhymes atop them. I wonder how these tracks might change with someone else on them
column11: but for now
column12: the music produces an uncanny feeling
column13:
like the presence of smoke but no real fire. 

"|19357.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19357-moon-b-ii/|6.9|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20548/homepage_large.f8f1e8f8.jpg|Xscape|2237.0|Michael Jackson|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2014-05-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:47.051432|"

Michael Jackson has released more new music in the five years since his death than in the 12 years before it. Jackson was a perfectionist about his music
column2: and he recorded many more songs than he ever released. That means that there's a lot of unreleased material in his archives; Michael appeared in 2010
column3: and now we've got this strange
column4: underfed
column5: vaguely horrid eight-song record
column6: inexplicably named after the group that had a hit with ""Just Kickin' It"". It's a set of outtakes and misfires that Jackson recorded in the 20th century
column7: freshly ""re-produced"" by L.A. Reid
column8: Timbaland
column9: and others to sound as if he'd just shown up to make a new record in a contemporary style.

column1: That
column2: it should be noted
column3: is a trick that's been tried before with Jackson's music. When Motown overdubbed and remixed some of his decade-old factory seconds in 1984
column4: it yielded the Farewell My Summer Love album
column5: whose packaging briefly fooled a few people into thinking it was the follow-up to Thriller. It's true that the new versions sound more modern and souped-up than the originals (which you also get if you buy the ""deluxe edition"" of Xscape)
column6: but their producers don't have enough distance from Jackson's presence to reframe his voice the way that
column7: say
column8: Junkie XL's remix of ""A Little Less Conversation"" reframed Elvis Presley's.

column1: It doesn't help that the outtakes they're dealing with are several tiers below the stuff that ended up on Jackson's later albums—maybe the estate is trying to parcel out the best material over time
column2: maybe it doesn't get any better than this. ""A Place with No Name"" is Jackson's rewrite of America's two-chord wonder ""A Horse with No Name""
column3: which is a bad enough idea on its own; Stargate
column4: who produced the new version
column5: replace the signature guitar riff with a sugary electroswing arrangement
column6: but it doesn't help. Most of these tracks are Jackson hiccuping and eee-hee-ing on autopilot through underdeveloped semi-tunes; both Grace Jones and MC Lyte beat him to the title ""Slave to the Rhythm"" with much better songs. (The version here is not the one with Justin Bieber that leaked a while back.)

column1: Jackson liked to present himself as pop's eternally youthful Peter Pan. In truth
column2: he was more its <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rabbit
column3: _Run"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Rabbit Angstrom
column4: forever re-enacting his moment of moonwalking glory from a position of ever-increasing bitterness. Defensive
column5: brittle songs like Xscape's title track (""don't you try to tell me what is right for me!"") don't look good on anyone. The most embarrassing song here
column6: though
column7: is ""Do You Know Where Your Children Are""
column8: a Dangerous outtake that apparently never got finished. (If Jackson knew what the bridge's lyrics were going to be
column9: he wasn't letting on in the recording studio.) It's a finger-jabbing harangue about a 12-year-old runaway who's ""tired of stepdaddy using her/ Saying that he'll buy her things while sexually abusing her"" and ends up hooking on Sunset Boulevard. As courageously stand-taking as it was for Jackson to indicate that he opposed child abuse
column10: it might not have been wise for his estate to release a song in which he's getting all sanctimonious about that particular topic. (The shred-by-numbers guitar solo that ends the new version doesn't do the song any favors either.)

column1: The one keeper on Xscape is its opener
column2: ""Love Never Felt So Good""
column3: which is also its oldest song—it dates from 1983 or so—and the one that's been in circulation the longest: written by Jackson and Paul Anka
column4: it initially surfaced on a 1984 Johnny Mathis album. It's got the best Jackson vocal here
column5: too. The original take
column6: which is mostly just his voice
column7: fingersnaps and a piano
column8: showcases the kind of  gravity-defying singing-for-pleasure that we barely heard from him in the post-Thriller era. The deluxe version of Xscape appends a Timbaland-produced remix of ""Love Never Felt So Good"" on which Justin Timberlake sings along with the old tape
column9: featuring disco flourishes borrowed from Jackson's ""Working Day and Night"". It sounds pleasantly like an echo of good Michael Jackson
column10:
but the fact that sampling an even earlier Jackson song makes it sound more contemporary says something about how wrongheaded this entire project is. 

"|19333.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19333-michael-jackson-xscape/|4.1|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20438/homepage_large.2c096a47.jpg|Easy Pain|5106.0|Young Widows|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2014-05-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:47.618086|"

Young Widows were born into a web of foregone antecedents and genre tags. When the Kentucky trio emerged in 2006
column2: they were
column3: as their name suggested
column4: survivors of a dead act
column5: the twisting-and-scraping
column6: post-hardcore band Breather Resist. That previous group’s musical skeleton stuck with Young Widows
column7: especially for their hurdling tantrum of a debut
column8: Settle Down City. That album presented a coiled mix of hardcore acrobatics and Jesus Lizard menace
column9: a Breather Resist continuation with less screaming and more variety. Young Widows didn’t discard that framework so much as build on top of it: Increasingly
column10: with 2008’s Old Wounds and 2011’s In and Out of Youth and Lightness
column11: they used the heaviness of their past as a foundation for a flexible stylistic composite—noise-rock against shoegaze against hardcore
column12: math-rock against post-rock against a little industrial. With polar dynamics
column13: lower tempos and a generally softer approach
column14: Lightness took the variety to surprising extremes
column15: issuing an apology of sorts for the mutilating abrasion of the trio’s past.

column1: But Easy Pain
column2: Young Widows’ fourth album
column3: swings the balance back toward belligerence and volume
column4: and the wallop doesn’t arrive in the manner you might expect. Of Young Widows’ four albums
column5: Easy Pain is the hardest to track and trace and the best overall. These eight tracks push quickly past pleasant and perfunctory intros (vestiges of the last record’s rather moody approach) to arrive at relentless
column6: loaded
column7: loud rock songs. The rhythm section lands mostly like fists on a shaky table
column8: and the guitars aim to fill every corner of the room with distortion and echo
column9: as plangent riffs are given a wide berth. “Gift of Failure” opens with a soft bit of kaleidoscopic electric guitar
column10: refracted and repeated through effects. But when the drums arrive
column11: the only direction the trio aims for the next four minutes is forwards. Tense and tired
column12: Evan Patterson struggles against an almost barbaric rumble to deliver the tale of a blind man blessed and cursed with his condition: “Nothing to see that hasn’t been seen for days
column13: he manages
column14: his voice slipping between a scream and a sigh that barely worms through the distortion. For a band initially known for snap-back song structures and zipping tempos
column15: Easy Pain presents a lumbering
column16: unleashed beast—not at all stupid or simplified
column17: just deliberate.

column1: But the reason these songs work so well isn't just because of their volume and muscle. More than their predecessors
column2: these Young Widows tunes refute the validity of the reductive descriptors that have always trailed the trio
column3: from post-hardcore to noise rock to misanthropic Midwestern indie. Easy Pain denies that these things are distinguishable at all
column4: that one strain can function without another. The slurred speak-sing of Patterson during “Bird Feeder” suggests Nick Cave backed by a power trio out to overwhelm him
column5: but there’s a roaring slide guitar solo at the song’s center and delirious stop-time lunges near the end. Those pieces make unlikely counterparts
column6: but they make “Bird Feeder” a seamless and compelling brute. “Godman” recalls one of those old hardcore nods
column7: drugged on Coil and sent shrieking into the busy streets.

column1: There’s no better illustration of this mix—and maybe no better song in Young Widows’ catalogue—than the diabolical “Kerosene Girl.” The guitar and bass are down-tuned and dense
column2: their march as thick as a bit of primo sludge metal. Through the din
column3: though
column4: Patterson webs a slender
column5: agile melody
column6: his little riff suggesting the lurid garage rock of the Swami stable. But the real esprit comes in the unexpected drum part—a daunting
column7: four-on-the-floor stomp that fights across the song’s length to not collapse on itself. It’s
column8: of all things
column9: danceable. Patterson admitted recently that he lifted the beat from Hamilton Bohannon’s “Dance Your Ass Off
column10: ” a swivel-and-clap 1976 disco cut about a party that refuses to let go of the night. “Kerosene Girl” even takes a sly
column11: sinister turn on that idea
column12: detailing the evening of a misanthrope so awkward he follows a woman home and burns down her house
column13: rather than simply speak to her on the dance floor. Such depravity winds through much of Easy Pain
column14: a record where people burn alive
column15: vultures pluck at the not-quite-dead and original sin brands already-leathered skin. There’s anxiety in Patterson’s voice
column16: sure
column17: an unease that suggests this music is always being made at the lip of an abyss. But these lyrics read like death metal
column18: where victims are mocked and a tension between distinct wills powers an often-mortal conflict.

column1: As members of Breather Resist and Young Widows
column2: bassist Nick Thieneman and singer and guitarist Patterson have played together for a dozen years. It’s surprising and inspiring that
column3: even now
column4: they’re still moving not just ahead but into their own space
column5: too
column6: a singular approach that feels definitively like Young Widows. Easy Pain is the closest they’ve ever come—so much so
column7: in fact
column8: that the record sags briefly toward the end from its own weighted consistency. But on the whole
column9: Easy Pain is athletic and aggressive like the old material
column10: dramatic and adventurous like the new goods. At last
column11: Young Widows sound less like a string of hyphenates and histories and more like their own demented
column12:
delightful selves.

"|19233.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19233-young-widows-easy-pain/|7.9|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20436/homepage_large.bf126008.jpg|Sincerely Yours|31412.0|Iamsu!|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['HBK Gang']|2014-05-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:48.151412|"

DJ Mustard has the hits to rightfully claim ratchet music's crown
column2: but Richmond rapper/producer Iamsu! has equally pushed the minimalist Cali sound to the masses. A founding member of Bay Area collective Heartbreak Gang
column3: he produced Loverance's “Up!” and contributed to Sage the Gemini’s viral-turned-Top 40 hit “Gas Pedal”. His nasal smooth-talking has factored in West Coast rap’s return to the mainstream
column4: and his debut LP
column5: Sincerely Yours
column6:
is Su’s opportunity to move forward through the doors he's already opened.

Sincerely Yours picks up where Su’s Kilt mixtape series left off
column7: with the young Bay Area rapper looking for a deeper niche beyond weekend party-soundtracking tracks. The album opens wistfully
column8: with Su quoting Pimp C's verse on Jay Z’s “Big Pimpin’”
column9: but his interpolation of “Everybody wanna ball
column10: holla at broads at the mall” is bashful
column11: a deviation from Pimp C's snarl. Later
column12: on “Girls”
column13: he waxes on taking his dream girl on dates that involve smoking weed and hanging out with his parents. Su’s everyman persona situates afield of Los Angeles’ gangster revivalist YG
column14:
as his music possesses an insular quality that places him outside of rap's larger-than-life personas.

Iamsu!'s numerous guest verses typically find him ready to turn up at any function
column15: but Sincerely Yours finds him turning down at every opportunity. “Only That Real”
column16: produced by HBK member P-Lo
column17: could fit on any ratchet mix from the last few years with its moody synths and vicious stomp
column18: but appearances by a bored-sounding 2 Chainz and Sage the Gemini dull this potential hit. Though Su has appeared and produced some big crossover singles
column19: Sincerely Yours is a bit too blunted
column20: as a majority of the album floats in its own haze. “What You ‘Bout"" offers a nice slap to the record's drowsy consciousness
column21: momentum that the album could use more of.

column1: As a whole
column2: Sincerely Yours maintains a tepid pace; the record's more thrilling moments are undercut by perfunctory rapping and weak track sequencing. After an unnecessary interlude
column3: there's a string of energetic posse cuts that feature HBK members Kool John and Skipper (“Back on Your Mind”) and Bay Area legends Too $hort and E-40 (“T.W.D.Y.”)
column4: but on an album that often gets too comfortable in its own relaxed mood
column5: Sincerely Yours could use more rappers with outspoken personas to act as a foil for Su.

column1: Iamsu! remains a distant figure on Sincerely Yours
column2: but there's a charm in the constant amazement he expresses regarding his success thus far. Furthermore
column3: his ruminations on unrequited love lack expected bitterness
column4: as he instead seeks to understand his complicated feelings. “Ascension” starts with Su pumping himself up by running down all of the things that he’s accomplished over the last few years
column5: but then comes “Runaway”
column6: a distorted back-and-forth with a former lover that ends with him singing
column7: “I thought you loved me.”

column1: These are not insurmountable struggles
column2: but other rappers have found universal appeal with far less relatable issues. “Problems” finds Su putting on the backpack of a conscious rapper
column3: trying to weave his own issues with the problems of black people in America. The sentiment is nice
column4: but he doesn't the passion in his voice to sell a track of such a weight. Su might not have the highest aspirations
column5:
but minor dreams can still compel a listener; Sincerely Yours just needed to find better modes of expression.

"|19230.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19230-iamsu-sincerely-yours/|6.0|David Turner

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20476/homepage_large.33167c69.jpg|Hour of the Dawn|29201.0|La Sera|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hardly Art']|2014-05-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:48.695809|"

Where Vivian Girls’ rough edges and droning harmonies suggested mystery
column2: Katy Goodman’s La Sera has to this point made no such attempt at obfuscation: Here was the Vivian Girls bassist
column3: here’s what was on her mind when she wasn’t with her bandmates. But Vivian Girls are no more
column4: meaning Goodman’s instincts have run in a less solitary direction for Hour of the Dawn
column5: La Sera’s third album. ""I wanted the new La Sera record to sound like Lesley Gore fronting Black Flag
column6: Goodman says in the album’s press material. ""I didn't want it to be another record of me sad
column7: alone in my room. I wanted to have fun playing music and writing songs with a band.""

column1: How fun it is when album opener “Losing to the Dark” strikes that aggressive pose
column2: the guitars pinballing off the walls as Goodman snarls about a boy who doesn’t seem to need her until he’s too drunk to take care of himself. “What a shame it must be to have to be in love with me
column3: ” she sings
column4: both heartbroken and spiteful. Not that she’s suddenly gone mean. Hour of the Dawn is largely made up of romantic songs carried to their open-hearted potential by Goodman’s high
column5: floating voice. She’s in love with people and with memories
column6: from summer’s promise to the town that used to be filled with her friends. An album that could be sad based on the lyric sheet is stuffed with delirious fret runs
column7: muscular drum fills
column8: sunny guitars soaked with reverb. Vivian Girls’ girl group harmonies were usually cloaked behind a curtain of feedback. Here
column9: Goodman stands in front of the band
column10: her voice shining like a lighthouse on the shore.

column1: The Lesley Gore-fronting-Black Flag comparison is apt
column2: since you could imagine the tougher directions the music would lean toward were Goodman’s instincts for melancholy and tenderness not there to soften the impact. The resulting sound is closer to Best Coast with more focus on the jamming. “Kiss This Town Away” leans into surf rock and a country singer’s sense of lament; the nimble picking of the title track builds to a triumphant outro even as she expresses unease about whether a new day will really bring something better. “10 Headed Goat Wizard” is straight-up Beatlesesque pop
column3: like something you’d hear at the end of an episode of “Mad Men” and not even realize it was anachronistic.

column1: The moments where she lets the band get heavier are interesting: “Control” chants like the flip side of Pink Floyd’s “Another Brick in the Wall Pt. 2” while “Storm’s End” groans like its title
column2: which is possibly a “Game of Thrones” reference (which Goodman has talked about in interviews) but probably doesn’t need to be read into beyond that. (Or does it? Okay
column3: it doesn’t.) That’s when Goodman takes steps toward establishing herself beyond what she’s known for
column4: which is personable if not always easy to distinguish from itself. Hour of the Dawn sounds like a summer record
column5: meant to be played when emotions are high and the sun is out. Most importantly
column6:
it shows what she’s capable of when the shine has worn off.

"|19268.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19268-la-sera-hour-of-the-dawn/|7.1|Jeremy Gordon

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20549/homepage_large.2d9e1cbd.jpg|Membrane Pop|32267.0|Sculpture|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer'
column3: the Brooklyn label Software has become a reliable home for a certain kind of electronic music: Brainy but with a dumb sense of humor
column4: influenced by dance and ambient music without actually functioning like either
column5: searching and pretty without ever feeling grandiose—the kind of soundscape you can take on a walk to the bodega. The label's cofounder and figurehead
column6: Oneohtrix Point Never
column7: has the aspect of a regular dude and peddles his music as such: High art for daily use.

column1: Enter Dan Hayhurst and Reuben Sutherland
column2: whose Software debut as Sculpture
column3: Membrane Pop
column4: plays like theme music for a cartoon parents might catch out of the corner of their eye and momentarily worry about what their children are being exposed to. Its beats are blocky and intricate
column5: its textures rubbery and its melodic lines rendered as simply as ringtones. It's music in a tradition that reaches back to Jean-Jacques Perrey and Gershon Kingsley
column6: whose compositions were painstaking efforts of tape-splicing and synthesizer manipulation that ended up with names like ""Barnyard in Orbit"". More recently
column7: it's a course followed by people like Aphex Twin and Black Dice's Eric Copeland: artists for whom silliness is an earnest endeavor.

column1: Pop is an aspirational title
column2: sometimes accurate and sometimes a little misleading. The concept
column3: presumably
column4: is music where immediacy and catchiness will transcend whatever weirdness gets in its way. Tracks like ""Hackle Scam Populator"" and ""Symbolic Molecule"" do this; tracks like ""5 Seconds in the Future is a You Made of Pure Thought"" are still playful but much more abstract. Generally
column5: it's the friendlier side of the record that feels more interesting because it has higher stakes: How
column6: it wonders
column7: can you make music that will register to most listeners as avant-garde while still retaining the approachability and charm of something less precious? Pop's harsher moments have their own ingenious little logic but ironically
column8: the more difficult the album gets the more familiar it feels.

column1: Sculpture bill themselves as an ""opto-musical agglomeration

One reason why the two have endured (and still kicking on a major label

column8:
multi-layered chorus.

column1: The possibilities for stylistic crossovers have especially been numerous in the South

column1: Suffolk

column1: On a few tracks

The beat on “Frankie Lymon” fuses a moire pattern of anxious trap triplets to a sweeping widescreen melody that'd sound great as a transcendent peak of a DJ set. ""Frankie Lymon"" is topped by an unshakably catchy hook by Que of “OG Bobby Johnson” fame; Que compares himself to tragic R&B pioneer Frankie Lymon and brags about being unable to feel love

column5: garishly neon-streaked keyboards

column8: by extension

column10:

Depending on which 20th-anniversary thinkpiece pops up in your Twitter feed at any given moment
column2: Britpop was either a prideful display of national unity that provided the triumphant soundtrack to a post-Thatcher England

column5: we can all agree on one positive outcome of the Blur-vs.-Oasis arms race: It injected Creation Records with enough cash for the label to roll the dice on Welsh wackaloons the Super Furry Animals
column6: the rare rock band of the era that was more interested in exploring the future (and all the toxic mobile-phone radiation that comes with it) than repackaging the past. And while they never approached tabloid-level
column7: supermodel-shagging celebrity status
column8: their steady success in the U.K. over the past decade-and-a-half has afforded frontman Gruff Rhys the means to indulge his various whims—which are never in short supply.

column1: Rhys’ capacious curiosity is given even greater room to roam with his latest solo project—the operative word being “project
column2: ” in the studious high-school-class-presentation sense. Its roots lie in Rhys’ recent discovery that he's a descendent of John Evans
column3: a Welsh explorer who
column4: in the 1790s
column5: embarked on a solo voyage through America to locate the Mandan
column6: an obscure tribe of Welsh-speaking Indians linked to a 12th-century Welsh prince named Madoc (who
column7: as legend has it
column8: touched down on our continent a good 300 years before Columbus). But rather than just update his Ancestry.com page and call it a day
column9: Rhys booked a tour along the same path his forefather traversed. This wasn’t your standard-issue solo-acoustic campaign
column10: but a multimedia PowerPoint presentation—booked into art galleries and lecture halls—chronicling Evans’ journey
column11: interspersed with new songs inspired by it. Given that Evans died long before the invention of the camera
column12: and no paintings of the man exist
column13: Super Furry Animals’ go-to artist Pete Fowler built a puppet version of his imagined likeness to serve as Rhys’ onstage second banana and travel companion. Because that’s how Gruff Rhys rolls.

column1: The tour is chronicled in Rhys’ new documentary with co-director Dylan Goch
column2: American Interior
column3: which is currently making the rounds on the festival circuit. But for those not in the vicinity of a screening
column4: there’s this namesake 13-song companion album
column5: which provides a vivid retelling of the story even in the absence of visuals. “100 Unread Messages” essentially serves the same function as the Raiders of the Lost Ark-style dot-to-dot maps that plot Evans’ trek in the film
column6: detailing his initial arrival in Philadelphia
column7: en route to St. Louis and up the Missouri River
column8: and then down to his final resting place in New Orleans. But even this straight-forward travelogue is infused with Rhys’ ever-peculiar musings: As he explains in the film
column9: the song is told from the perspective of someone who’s been trying to email John Evans repeatedly but
column10: for obvious reasons
column11: receives no reply
column12: thereby transforming the biography of an historical figure into a comment on the mind-warping effects of internet addiction. And the track’s countrified Krautrock stomp—supplied by excommunicated Flaming Lips drummer and fellow Native-American enthusiast Kliph Scurlock—is far more robust and widescreen-scaled than the modest
column13: folk-oriented music Rhys has thus far released under his own name
column14: positioning American Interior as the Rhys solo release that’s most in tune with the Super Furry Animals’ manic genre-blurring
column15: retro-futurist mandate.

column1: Really
column2: if this had been released as the first SFA album in five years
column3: no fan would complain
column4: as it encompasses several of the band’s signature modes: the ace-in-the-hole ’70s soft-rock throwbacks (“The Last Conquistador”)
column5: the nursery-rhyme funk jams with impossible-to-pronounce hooks (“Allweddellau Allweddol”)
column6: the multi-sectional
column7: pedal-steeled prog-pop opuses (“Year of the Dog” and its instrumental-coda counterpart “Tiger’s Tale”). And by fortuitous fuzzy logic
column8: the hair-raising
column9: string-swept cavalry charge “Iolo” works as both a nod to the Welsh poet that backed out of Evans’ expedition at the last minute
column10: and a sonic manifestation of Drake’s phonetically related philosophy. But the Evans narrative provides an emotional throughline that connects and grounds this stylistically free-ranging collection—for all his apparent eccentricity
column11: Rhys has always been an exceptional balladeer
column12: and poignant
column13: piano-bound turns like “Walk Into the Wilderness” feel all the more affecting in the light of the real hardship that inspired it.

column1: But Rhys’ affinity for John Evans clearly goes beyond mere blood relations—for Rhys
column2: Evans was the original Welsh punk
column3: who pursued his vision despite the ridicule
column4: incarceration
column5: and isolating loneliness inherent to the mission. And like so many of the punk icons we lionize today
column6: Evans may have been considered a failure in his lifetime (spoiler alert: his story does not end happily)
column7: but his work proved highly influential to those that followed: historians claim his hand-drawn maps of the American northwest were crucial to Lewis and Clark’s landmark maiden expedition to the left coast in the early 19th century. With American Interior
column8: Rhys not only follows in Evans’ footsteps but
column9: in his own way
column10: helps fulfill his original mission: If
column11: years from now
column12: social anthropologists note an unusually high concentration of Super Furry Animals fans along the Missouri
column13:
we’ll know why.

Damon McMahon’s work as Amen Dunes has been a process of expansion. The confined
column2: loner vibe of his 2009 debut DIA sounded like it was made in a cabin in the woods—which it was—but it also hinted at wider vistas McMahon might someday explore. That promise was realized on 2011’s Through Donkey Jaw
column3: as he extended his sonic palette while retaining his introspective bent. Love is an even grander step forward

column5: classic-leaning songs he’s written.

column1: This also means that Love
column2: in line with its broad title
column3: is less unique than previous Amen Dunes efforts. There are more obvious reference points here—the solitary creep of Syd Barrett
column4: the slow croak of Will Oldham
column5: the bittersweet swing of David Kilgour
column6: and the patient twang of Wooden Wand. But the decreased individuality actually makes the music stronger. McMahon is so open to (and adept at) simple melodies and turns of phrase that he’s bound to evoke lots of other good music along the way
column7: as if he’s tapping into something more elemental.

column1: Besides

column4: he sings better and more ambitiously than ever. Each song rises and falls with the elastic stretch of his voice

column1: That searching approach is reflected in McMahon’s wondering lyrics
column2: which step toward a horizon that keeps receding. Though McMahon’s musings are often in the first person
column3: he’s filled with uncertainty
column4: fascinated and confused by the self and what he can know about it. He darts around the subject and skirts obvious meaning
column5: recalling the way Oldham bent tangents on the latest Bonnie “Prince” Billy album. Even when McMahon hits on some answers
column6: as in the bluntly-titled “I Know Myself”
column7: he still questions and doubles back
column8: over meditative acoustic strums that suggest his journey won’t end
column9: and shouldn’t.

column1: Still
column2: when all of McMahon’s seeking comes together
column3: the results can feel like the pot of gold at the end of a rainbow. Two examples stand out: the loping “Lonely Richard” marches forward with one tempo and little chord variation
column4: yet McMahon makes it sound like he's scaling a mountain
column5: to the point where a chorus as objectively banal as “have yourself a good time” becomes bracingly profound. That’s topped only by “Lilac in Hand”
column6: whose stoned lilt should by all rights sound lackadaiscal

column8: black & white video). Building an expanding universe with just a few tools: it might not be a new trick
column9:
but it’s one McMahon continues to perfect with Amen Dunes.

Spanish duo Teitanblood have never cared much for niceties
column2: preferring to lambast their hapless listeners with walls of horrific noise. Death
column3: their second full-length is a bitter pill to swallow. Their sound is ugly and intense; it’s not all black metal
column4: and though some of the more warped moments sound like someone’s left a copy of Incantation's Onward to Golgotha outside in acid rain
column5: it’s not entirely death metal
column6: either. Instead
column7: it's a weaponized hybrid of the two genres
column8: as the majority of the band's guitar work remains an impenetrable mass
column9: a near-constant stream of wild
column10: squealing leads and solos come howling out from beneath the murk. Their technique illustrates just how much Teitanblood owes to thrash metal’s frantic ferocity. As has been his custom since the band’s inception in 2003 (save for their first demo
column11: which featured current Proclamation guitarist Usurper of Eternal Condemnation and Inverted Crucifixion)
column12: NSK handles bass
column13: guitar
column14: and vocals. He’s had over a decade to perfect that balance
column15: and it shows. There's a cold-blooded method to his madness.

column1: The powerful rhythm section is the weighty altar upon which Teitanblood consecrate their rituals. The drums never let up for a moment; J's movements are so focused and intense that he often seems on the verge of spontaneous combustion. NSK carries the majority of the weight
column2: but it must be noted that J’s heavy lifting fuels the album’s beating black heart.

column1: Death itself comes in many forms
column2: and Teitanblood seem to enjoy illustrating a smattering of examples on Death. “Cadaver Synod” erupts with an atomic blast
column3: “Silence of the Great Martyrs” bursts into crackling flames
column4: and dread sounds of the Rapture usher in the lengthy “Sleeping Throats of the Antichrist”
column5: which builds into a towering inferno of lawless darkness bookended by moments of eerie atmosphere. The album stretches well past seventy minutes
column6: smoldering and suffocating in equal measure. It’s a lot to stomach
column7: and a sure dealbreaker for the passing curious. Teitanblood is not for everyone.

column1: The flames sink into embers as Death rides out slowly. “Silence of the Great Martyrs” reverts back to heretical grace
column2: its dark ambiance backed by chimes
column3: foreboding synth
column4: and a chorus of liturgical chanting. The album fades out
column5: but the impact it makes lingers. As much as Death possesses noisy
column6: “anti-musical” characteristics
column7: there's a studied musicality concealed within the fracas. NSK may scorn studio shine or melodic pandering
column8: but he knows how to write a song. What’s more
column9: he knows how to do so in a manner that leaves listeners dazed and wondering what they’ve just witnessed. Therein lies the genius of Death: it’s a complete homage to extremity and regression
column10: yet it pushes boundaries that lesser bands never thought to look for. Teitanblood grimly bring order to chaos
column11: and with Death
column12:
have surpassed themselves once more.

Swans were hardly the first 1980s underground-rock fixtures to resurface in the new millennium
column3: and they’re not the only ones who've resisted the nostalgic trappings of reunion tours to make a respectable showing as a rebooted recording act. But they are the rare band of their vintage who seem less concerned with living up to or building upon a past legacy than establishing a completely different one. In retrospect
column4: the 14 years that elapsed between 1996’s Soundtracks for the Blind and 2010’s My Father Will Guide Me Up a Rope to the Sky were less a break-up-induced hiatus than a gestation period. The bigger
column5: brawnier Swans that Michael Gira has assembled in its wake (complete with a strapping
column6: bare-chested gong-smasher named Thor) are beholden neither to the primordial
column7: industrialized sludge of the band’s infamous ’80s catalogue nor the post-goth serenity of their ’90s work. Instead
column8: they’ve perfected a new means of transforming grostequerie into grandeur and vice versa.

column1: With 2012’s astonishingly colossal The Seer
column2: Swans pulled off the unlikeliest of coups: A record that
column3: over its six sides and two-hour-plus running time
column4: was seemingly designed to test the commitment of the band’s most ardent followers yet
column5: amazingly
column6: expanded their audience to an unprecedented degree. (This summer
column7: Swans are even playing the odd free festival date in outdoor public squares
column8: which could conceivably earn them a few new fans in the grandparents-and-strollers demographic.) But while Swans have always been the last band to pander to audience expectations
column9: Gira nonetheless seems aware that anticipation for a new Swans album has arguably never been greater. And so he’s responded in the best way possible: by producing a record that
column10: in structure and scale
column11: is every bit The Seer’s equal
column12: yet possessed by a peculiar energy and spirit that proves all the more alluring in its dark majesty.

column1: The relationship between the two albums can essentially be gauged by their respective album covers. Though there’s a similarity in composition
column2: To Be Kind’s artwork trades The Seer’s dark shadows for a bright mustard tone
column3: and the central feral-dog figure for cute baby faces (as rendered in a series of six by L.A. painter Bob Biggs)
column4: suggesting a more approachable ethos at play. But as any new parent can tell you
column5: an infant is as volatile and destructive a creature as the wildest of field animals and
column6: likewise
column7: the John Congleton-produced To Be Kind boasts a more focused attack—with a preminum on taut
column8: throbbing grooves and blackened blues—that initially tricks you into thinking it's more accessible than its predecessor. (Hey
column9: there's even a song named in honour of Kirsten Dunst.) Yet it’s ultimately accessible in the same way a prison gate is accessible—getting in is relatively easy; getting out unscathed is an entirely different story. Upon hearing the introductory Cajun-funk strut of “A Little God in My Hands”
column10: I initially worried that Swans were crossing over into the sort of campy
column11: Southern-fried creepiness you’d hear on the soundtrack to an episode of ""True Blood"". But after that destabilizing blast of brass and synapse-frying synth beam appears out of nowhere at the 90 second mark
column12: “A Little God in My Hands” carries on as if infected by a virus; it tries to keep its cool
column13: but the once-sprightly rhythmic bounce is now ridden with a nervous tension
column14: while the encroaching chorus of dead-eyed female voices transform the song into a mutant-zombie version of its former self. On To Be Kind
column15: this is what constitutes a lead single.

column1: Close observers of Swans will notice that seven of the 10 songs here were previewed in some form on last year’s limited-edition concert album/demos collection Not Here/Not Now (whose sales funded the new album’s production). But most have since been subjected to dramatic embellishment or rearrangement. Not Here/Not Now’s tense
column2: acoustic-strummed closing sketch “Screen Shot” has been recast as To Be Kind’s louche
column3: slow-boiling “Yoo Doo Right”-styled opener and
column4: in the process
column5: illuminates the great contradiction at the core of the 21st-century Swans sound: as their sonic vocabulary has grown more elaborate and texturally detailed
column6: Gira’s sense of melody has turned all the more minimalist and mantric. Thirty years ago on the deadpan dirge
column7: “Job”
column8: Gira sang from the perspective of the world’s most bored axe murderer (“Cut off the arms/ Cut off the legs/ Cut off the head/ Get rid of the body”) as a metaphor for soul-destroying
column9: day-to-day workplace drudgery; on “Screen Shot
column10: ” he more eagerly sings of a different sort of dismemberment  (“No touch/ No loss/ No hands/ No sin”)
column11: of purging urges—and the body parts used to indulge them—as way to achieve a state of spiritual purity.

column1: The ensuing songs on To Be Kind present variations on this theme—of unleashing an outsized sound to find an inner peace
column2: and reclaiming one's innocence by way of insolence. But
column3: of course
column4: this being a Swans record
column5: salvation never comes easy. When
column6: amid the “Dirt”-covered funereal march of “I’m Just a Little Boy” Gira pleads
column7: “I need loooooooooooove
column8: ” he’s answered by a Greek chorus of devious
column9: derisive laughter. (Of all the terrible
column10: humiliating experiences detailed in Swans songs over the years
column11: that moment just might count as the cruelest.) And if the 34-minute centerpiece “Bring the Sun”/“Toussaint L’Ouverture” initially summons our planet’s primary life-source with all the trance-inducing elation and desperation of a remote-island pagan sect praying to their gods for a bountiful harvest
column12: its more sinister second act—wherein Gira maniacally howls the name of the titular 18th-century Haitian revolutionary while drowning in a swamp of dub spewage—transforms the track into an after-hours seance gone wrong.

column1: As it plays out
column2: To Be Kind starts to resemble a cult procession unto itself
column3: a mesmerizing spectacle of an omnipotent band whose sound continues to expand in scope and ranks swell in size. Much like The Seer
column4: To Be Kind sees a formidable and evermore prominent coterie of female vocalists—from the insurgent Cold Specks to reigning freak-scene queen St. Vincent to avant-rock veteran Little Annie—falling under Swans’ sway. And rather than provide a calming counterpoint to Gira’s stentorian croon
column5: their voices ultimately serve the album’s hypnotic force. From the teeth-gnashing ferocity of “Oxygen” to the calamitous
column6: battering-rammed climax of “She Loves Us!”
column7: To Be Kind adheres to a policy of transcendence by any means necessary
column8: even if it means repeatedly bashing you in the face with a mallet until you’re seeing stars and colors.

column1: On the hymn-like title-track closer
column2: Gira solemnly repeats the words “to be kind” as both an aspirational self-help slogan and a tacit acknowledgement that
column3: given all the diabolically orchestrated malevolence we’ve been subjected to over the preceding 112 minutes
column4: he hasn’t always done the best job of heeding his own advice. But as the song violently erupts into one final
column5: sustained surge of tectonic-plate-shifting discord
column6: the moment proves to be as affirming as it is unsettling. “People always consider us to be very dour and depressing
column7: but fuck that shit
column8:
” Gira told Pitchfork’s Brandon Stosuy in 2012. “The goal is ecstasy.” And what makes To Be Kind so compelling is how that goal seems both fully realized yet forever out of reach at the same time.

column11: no plan. “We dove into different worlds

column13: and during the recording process she wandered around the band’s longtime hometown of Gothenberg in winter while listening to Janet Jackson.

column1: This wintry mix of fresh and familiar suffuses Nabuma Rubberband
column2: which opens as if Nagano stepped inside from one of these walks with “Twenty Foreplay” stuck in her head and started writing before her fingers uncramped from the cold. The intermittent thuds throughout “Mirror” depart noticeably from the magnetic rhythms of 2011's Ritual Union
column3: hinting at the album's changing focus. Though their very first release
column4: 2006’s Twice
column5: showcased Nagano’s voice with spacious
column6: somber piano chords
column7: she said in another interview that Little Dragon felt self-conscious about writing “slow jams”. It took them another three years to arrive at the Prince-indebted funky freakouts of 2009's Machine Dreams
column8: as well as the beat-focused collaborations with SBTRKT
column9: Gorillaz
column10: and Dave Sitek’s Maximum Balloon project that followed.

column1: Little Dragon's continued to explore the dichotomy between dance music and downtempo since
column2: and when Nagano doesn’t stick too closely to one or the other on Nabuma Rubberband
column3: the results are more adventurous than on the catchy but slightly underwhelming Ritual Union. There's a Japanese game show-styled interlude (“Lurad”)
column4: string accents by the Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra (“Nabuma Rubberbands”
column5: “Pink Cloud”)
column6: and “Killing Me”
column7: which coats Machine Dreams’ synthesizer freestyles in grimy noise. It’s nice to know Little Dragon can still pull off the same rhythmic variations and textural contrasts that made their earlier output such a rewarding listen
column8: even if it doesn’t always go smoothly: just when they settle into a groove on the ominous
column9: glittering “Only One”
column10: the song whiplashes to a close with an industrial beat that sounds tacked on.

column1: Nabuma Rubberband's slow jams are perfectly sexy
column2: but they lack originality. Even after repeated listens
column3: the album's velvety sequence of “Pretty Girls”
column4: “Underbart”
column5: and “Cat Rider” fail to leave a lasting impression. Nagano’s beguilingly smoky voice has also lost a little bit of its allure
column6: and when Little Dragon foray into already well-trod territory—there’s even a song called “Paris”
column7: complete with breathy French lyrics—they invariably disappoint. It’s great the band was able to find a throughline between the comfortable and the experimental this time around
column8:
but on Nabuma Rubberband they let go of a little too much of themselves in the process.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20473/homepage_large.2ddbafd6.jpg|Changing Light|2788.0|Mirah|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Absolute Magnitude']|2014-05-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:57.912575|"

Mirah launched her career at the end of the 1990s in Olympia
column2: Washington
column3: and while she no longer lives there
column4: the city's twin legacies of riot grrl and twee pop still faintly cling to her sound. Her downy voice is equally appealing whether set in growly rock music or glitteringly ornate folk
column5: the poles that her new album Changing Light often switches between. But more than Bikini Kill or Beat Happening
column6: she recalls a certain Pacific Northwest band that she came up alongside. Specifically
column7: Mirah's lyric writing resembles the Decemberists' Colin Meloy if he sang from his diaphragm instead of his nose
column8: and likewise she's too poised for the chancy idioms of punk and twee. Instead
column9: she makes her albums into their own magical islands where nothing too chaotic gets in—or out.

column1: It's been five years since Mirah's last LP
column2: the gentle and enveloping (a)spera
column3: where the music evoked seashell fragments glinting in a shallow tide. Changing Light reflects a marked sonic shift from polish to grit. ""I will go to the desert
column4: Mirah sings on opening track ""Goat Shepherd""
column5: and the arid invocation lingers even through the verdant ballads. In theme and sound
column6: this is a relatively stripped down music of desperation and exile. Gouged with desert rock tropes
column7: the album inverts (a)spera’s blue-hued fluidity
column8: built instead on a rugged bedrock of shadowy black and scorched orange timbres. Distorted electric guitars snarl and bite
column9: drums slap and rattle in your chest
column10: basses plunge like canyons. Even as the brass on ""No Direction Home"" glowers like Mahler
column11: a rattlesnake shaker sneaks the desert in. Mirah unfolds a characteristically lovely but slow-stepping vocal melody
column12: a mannered pace that makes her songs sound more alike than they are until you spend considerable time with them.

column1: Mingled with these tougher
column2: grainier sounds
column3: Changing Light has plenty of torchy art music based on gossamer acoustic strains
column4: such as the folky ""Fleet Foot Ghost"". There are shades of '80s pop ballads on ""Turned the Heat Off""
column5: the first Mirah song to even remotely bring Belinda Carlisle to mind
column6: and slinky album highlight ""Oxen Hope""
column7: where a light slick of vocoder seems to unfasten some restraint in the singer
column8: who turns in an unusually limber performance. But the synth-tom rolls buried deep in the mix
column9: like someone falling down a staircase inside herself
column10: remind us that a quiet catastrophe is underway.

column1: Uprooting herself after a breakup
column2: Mirah wrote these songs while living an itinerant existence over the last few years. Still
column3: she picked up collaborators as she ran—Deerhoof drummer Greg Saunier
column4: a well-matched Mary Timony
column5: Mount Moriah's Heather McEntire
column6: and Emily Wells. The music is topped with generally flattering arrangements by Seattle composer Jherek Bischoff
column7: whose strings slice so high and thin they're like cuts you barely feel until the blood starts flowing.

column1: Mirah's sister Emily Zeitlyn co-wrote ""LC""
column2: an aptly dusky and prayerful homage
column3: complete with second-person confessional tone
column4: to the breakup survival kit that Leonard Cohen's music provides. But the topic has begun to wear a bit thin
column5: because as Mirah sings on ""No Direction Home""
column6: ""This is a sorrow everyone knows."" You can only hear about other people's breakups for so long before sympathy turns into a desire to talk about something else
column7: especially when the resulting pain is described in such wrought
column8: high
column9: distancing language.

column1: Mirah's slightly clinical approach to songwriting makes this ostensibly personal album revealing only in comparison to her often guarded prior ones. For all its emotional charge
column2: Changing Light barely feels more intimate than Share This Place
column3: her multimedia concept album inspired by a French entomologist—in fact
column4: she writes more comfortably and warmly about the insect kingdom than the human one. Here
column5: she continues to seem a little beyond our reach
column6: hidden behind the hedgerows of manicured arrangements and an imperturbable singing style. Even in the wide-open conceptual deserts with collaborators in tow
column7: Mirah's music is somehow still an island: enticing
column8:
but always receding as we approach.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20474/homepage_large.1b0d3f6e.jpg|Bermuda Waterfall|31231.0|Sean Nicholas Savage|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Arbutus']|2014-05-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:58.628369|"

Sean Nicholas Savage wrote most of Bermuda Waterfall
column2: his 11th studio album since 2008
column3: when traveling while ""Trying to describe my most potent dreams related to my most potent life experiences."" This is mostly a fancy way of saying he’s a songwriter
column4: but Savage has a memorable way of describing the sights of an otherwise common life. A sun is not a sun
column5: but ""a five billion year old fire""; a broken relationship is not a broken relationship
column6: but an ""empire of hate."" It’s only been a year since his last album
column7: Other Life
column8: and Savage is still singing about the same themes of loneliness and love. But he’s breathed life into his homespun arrangements and learned to dive deeper into himself to recover rarer conclusions
column9: justifying his prolificness.

column1: There’s a soft rock bent to Savage's sound: the drums are unconfrontational
column2: the guitars soft and Spanish-inflected. Savage’s voice is worn out yet piercing
column3: as though a thousand miles couldn’t keep him from getting through. He puts his whole self into the swelling refrain on ""Heartless""
column4: pleading the title of ""Please Set Me Free"" while singing from inside what sounds like a rainstorm. The interplay between the fullness of the arrangements and Savage’s often despairing presence provides a viewpoint as to where his imagination takes him on those lonely nights. When he sings ""You come naturally to me"" to a lover on the lighter-than-air ""Naturally""
column5: he might as well be talking about his own ability to execute his ideas.

column1: Similar to fellow Canadian and former labelmate Majical Cloudz
column2: there’s a directness to Savage's approach that threatens to become uncomfortable. The ability to reconcile immense expressions of sadness and guilt with awareness is rare—he dives into himself without getting lost—and the songs on Bermuda Waterfall are beautiful and yearning. At the same time
column3: his musical style occasionally toes the line between ""cool lounge"" and ""chintzy infomercial
column4: and as Savage continues to interpret small moments as small failures
column5: it's hard not to tire of the constant introspection.

column1: It's important to keep in mind
column2: then
column3: that Savage's viewpoint is a byproduct of isolation
column4: where one analyzes every experience in search of deeper subtext while avoiding the risk of sounding like a loon when you explain it to someone else. But rather than loitering in solitude
column5: Savage is reaching out his hand: Bermuda Waterfall was written for his friends
column6: whom he memorializes on ""Hangin On"" for being so thoughtful as to wonder when he might be coming to a party. That's the type of inconsequential
column7: commonplace interaction that sometimes means the world to an individual
column8:
and Savage’s ability to locate an oasis of connection in a desert of heartbreak is what makes Bermuda Waterfall endearing rather than irritating.

column3: Finnish experimental cooperative Kemialliset Ystävät have mesmerized and puzzled listeners with a varied string of CD
column4: LP
column5: cassette
column6: and digital releases. The obscure enclave led by Jan Anderzén specializes in pieces carefully assembled from samples and snippets of improvisations. Woven into these tapestries are rough-hewn scraps of melody that blur the distinction between acoustic and electronic sound; it’s often impossible to differentiate a synth lead from a shrill reed instrument
column7: or a grainy field recording from an overblown drum machine. When it becomes futile to attempt to catalog the source material
column8: Kemialliset’s songs come across as uninterrupted streams of raw
column9: constantly unfolding texture—as willfully dizzying and deceptive in their syntax as a film montage.

column1: More so than on any previous release
column2: Alas Rattoisaa Virtaa
column3: the group’s latest full-length
column4: finds them working primarily with identifiably electronic sounds. The sonic palette and approach are reminiscent of collagists such as Ground Zero and Black Dice
column5: where free-floating noise objects coalesce into loose
column6: slushy grooves and fall out of them just as quickly. Here
column7: Anderzén and company sometimes indulge in full-on synth-scapes without their usual balance of hand-drum loops
column8: harmonized Scandinavian bagpipes
column9: or guitar blasts. “Roiske Ruudukolla”
column10: a pointillistic exercise for MIDI orchestral instruments
column11: Jean-Michel Jarre arpeggiators
column12: and wordless vocals phased out into digital gravel
column13: is particularly surprising. The aesthetic is not far off the avant-Muzak pastiches of James Ferraro. When put up against the recorder and balalaika trimmings of earlier KY albums (see 2002’s Kellari Juniversumi)
column14: the contrast is staggering.

column1: Kemialliset’s approach to layering incongruous and damaged sound artifacts is uncompromising
column2: but the music is never outright abrasive. Even the chunkiest sine waves are pacified by a bit of reverb or ambience. The clever sequencing also contributes to the record's relative smoothness
column3: or at least helps blunt some rough edges. Anderzén expertly masks cuts and fades
column4: creating form out of chaos like a young
column5: circuit-bending Teo Macero. “Vettä Yarahille”
column6: in particular
column7: is remarkably sutured
column8: morphing from skeletal
column9: handclap-driven R&B into a denouement of birdsong and voices speaking in tongues (think the “Cloven Theater” of the Sun City Girls).

column1: Despite these diplomatic gestures toward establishing unity and balance
column2: Alas Rattoisaa Virtaa is never a passive listen. If we dare to nod our head to a muted Terry Riley-like melodic loop
column3: some far-off siren or blockade of detuned synths always disturbs the idyll. Dialectic and disruption aren't ornamental techniques for Kemialliset—they're the central organizational principles of the group's music
column4:
keeping the project from becoming too scattered and less deserving of our undivided attention.

About 10 years ago
column2: already well into a flourishing career
column3: Sean Michael Daley decided to start moving the furniture around inside of his music. The bluster and self-evisceration of the early records Daley (aka Slug) made with producer Ant as Atmosphere suddenly bored him
column4: so he set it aside and started penning compassionate character sketches while Ant warmed and loosened up their sound with live instruments. The results strayed from rap towards gently rambling spoken-word territory
column5: but miraculously
column6: the duo didn't lose their audience: 2008's resonant When Life Gives You Lemons You Paint That Shit Gold sold the most of any Atmosphere release and marked an unlikely new chapter in an already-unlikely career.

column1: Southsiders extends the ""quietly durable"" phase of the Minneapolis duo's lifespan. The 2011 album The Family Sign
column2: which featured the upraised fist of Daley's newborn second child on its cover
column3: told stories that were close to his home while not being strictly about him—there were upsetting and finely detailed narratives of spousal abuse and breakups
column4: but few first-person pronouns. Southsiders dials in closer: opening track ""Camera Thief"" finds him in his kitchen with his children. ""I still kick it with angels
column5: the only difference is/ Instead of the bar
column6: I'm at my kitchen table
column7: he raps. The line obliquely references ""Angelface""
column8: a track from 2005's landmark You Can't Imagine How Much Fun We're Having that detailed tour conquests with self-loathing and relish. It establishes the creative challenge of Southsiders. Daley has two children
column9: a kitchen table
column10: and a domestic existence of sorts
column11: and he's trying to figure out how to make an Atmosphere record about that.

column1: The awkward
column2: uninspired construction of that line hints at the creeping problem: Contentment is damnably hard to write about. For most of us
column3: contentment is a gift
column4: a welcome reason to rev down the whirring of our mental engines. We analyze our bad feelings because we're trying to figure out how to banish them
column5: but we simply enjoy our good feelings. Daley is smart and self-aware enough to diagnose this problem on ""Camera Thief"": ""I don't need my defensiveness/ I keep to myself
column6: my family and friendships/ I got enough people I could disappoint/ If you disagree
column7: I think you missed the point
column8: he raps
column9: defensively. But pointing to the problem doesn't dissolve it
column10: and when he follows up with """"Now pull up a chair/ Let me tell you about the last few years
column11: it's hard to muster a lot of excitement.

column1: More distressingly
column2: a spare tire of flab has developed around Slug's usually chisel-sharp writing.  ""Gotta be a model civilian/ And get your name printed on a bottle full of pills
column3: and/ Spill your guts into a Dixie cup/ Give no fucks
column4: kiss no butts
column5: from ""The World Might Not Live Through the Night""
column6: is a stretch that would never have made it onto an earlier Atmosphere record. ""If everybody on the comet agreed/ We could set the clock to whenever we wanted it to be"" is a nice sentiment
column7: but not a terribly incisive thought
column8: and when he throws it out on the gently bumping ""Fortunate
column9: it's hard not to flinch a little bit.

column1: But even working at half-capacity
column2: Daley hits some powerful nerve clusters. On ""Arthur's Song
column3: there are freeze-in-place images to savor like ""Train tracks underneath the faceless moon"" and some of his trademark writerly details: ""Been a few years since the last cigarette
column4: but if you put your finger inside the flask
column5: it's still wet."" ""Time flew/ Like it's designed to do""
column6: from ""Star-Shaped Heart
column7: has a lovely
column8: jewel-like simplicity.

column1: There are a few moments where Slug revisits earlier versions of himself. On the curiously titled single ""Kanye West""
column2: he revisits some well-trod codependency-addiction territory (""She said she want somebody she could take care of/ And right then is when we paired up"")
column3: and on the title track he throws out goofy battle raps (""Show me a player who's mad at this/ And I'll show you a hater and a masochist"") like it's still 2005. The pinched fury of that era is long gone from Slug's voice
column4: and the song feels downright affectionate
column5: like a high-school picture
column6: a fond look back at his ""Whoever put out album must've needed write-offs"" era.   They foreground the album's lack of focus: For the first time in Atmosphere's long career
column7: the stakes feel low
column8: and Southsiders feels both pleasant and noncommittal
column9:
like it isn't even convinced of its own right to exist.

""We On 1""
column2: the title track to DJ Rashad's most recent EP
column3: is the first time his voice has been heard on record since his passing last month. His vocals are chopped up and slurred
column4: juxtaposing screw's lean-fueled stupor with the frantic
column5: slippery agility of footwork: ""Robitussin
column6: pink surrrp/ Robitussin
column7: pink surrrp/ Promethazine promethazine (we on one)"". The utterances hold a strange weight now
column8: especially following the speculation that the juke and footwork icon might have died of a drug overdose following misleading police reports (the drug paraphernalia those reports extraneously mentioned was said to be marijuana-related); regardless
column9: the attempts to gain closure and clear the air over Rashad's death have cast a pall over the concurrent release of this new EP.

column1: In an alternate universe
column2: We On 1 provides four tracks' worth of proof that Rashad's 2013 breakthrough Double Cup was just the beginning of his next leap forward
column3: rather than an inadvertent eulogy or an object of what-could-have-been speculation. As it stands
column4: it's a concentrated jolt of wide-ranging takes on an already down-for-whatever sound
column5: with Rashad finding countless vantage points to throw odd asides and funny mutations into the 160-BPM barrage of digital percussion. The beats are expectedly heavy-hitting and distinct even at their densest
column6: rumbling with crisp
column7: open-space fidelity that finds nuance in subwoofer-stressing bass and generations-old 808 claps.

column1: ""We On 1"" is a trunk-rattler that groans under its own weight and lets its beats push through the drone
column2: sawn-off versions of booming-system throbs impenetrable as solid steel but buckling and waving like gelatin. When that heavy growl is peppered with Rashad's characteristic stagger-rhythm snares
column3: the bass rumble starts shaping more distinctly into a bassline
column4: as one-note and insistent as the style demands but unified into something even bigger than its already hulking frame. Rashad pulled off a smart trick by taking this frenetic blueprint and using its supercharged tempo to swing between trebly
column5: claustrophobic AK-47 percussion and the wide-open
column6: two-ton glide of that low-end assault. (Get a load of the ""Aja"" drop
column7: too.)

column1: Two other tracks feature Rashad's longtime friend and frequent co-producer DJ Spinn. The beat of the '80s ghettohouse nod ""Come on Girl"" metamorphizes from insistently one-two bass jabs to fast-clacking snare rolls to flat-out drum'n'bass breaks to breath-snatching fusions of all three. It's so relentless that even the looped shout of ""pop that pussy!"" nearly gets lost in the flood. The woozy sing-song-laced ""Do It Again"" (also featuring Teklife member and ""Way I Feel""/""Drums Please"" collaborator DJ Manny) initially comes across as light
column2: a gently blissed-out female vocal providing the gradually-forming repetition of the titular hook
column3: washed in lawn-sprinkler hi-hats and boosted by warm
column4: weighty bass hits. But its smooth build into breakneck snare-bass buildups and breakdowns
column5: laced with Southern-tinged molly-rap signifiers and ""Fuck me"" whispers
column6: turns the track into a bristling juxtaposition of anticipatory calm and fevered motion.

column1: Considering that Rashad's sound finds the intersection of emotional swells
column2: nostalgic happiness
column3: and shivering catharsis
column4: EP closer ""Somethin 'Bout the Things U Do"" (featuring veteran ghetto house/juke innovator Gant-Man) is We On 1's inarguable standout. A footwork reassembly of Chaka Khan's instantly recognizable ""I Feel for You""
column5: those iconic David Frank synthesizer hits and Stevie Wonder harmonica riffs are tweaked into a frantic fast-forward caricature that subsequently stretches
column6: loops
column7: and hammers home every last truncated syllable out of Khan's voice into a monomaniacal burst of joyous abandon that ricochets off the retrofitted footwork rhythms.

column1: We may not be finished talking about DJ Rashad's legacy yet. Hopefully
column2: there'll be far more to come
column3: both from his own vaults and from the Teklife collective. As long as there are artists out there who are willing and able to take his lead
column4: to find a way to make ribcage-collapsing bass and deep soul work in tandem
column5: to work all the angles of every kick and rattle to make that 160 BPM upend any efforts to straitjacket it
column6:
Rashad will be with us.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20570/homepage_large.19617f0d.jpg|Youth Culture Forever|30616.0|PAWS|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Cat']|2014-05-09 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:01.717239|"

There’s a scene in Cartoon Network’s ""Adventure Time""—a cartoon that embodies the intersection of interests between seven-year olds and stoners—where the main character
column2: Finn
column3: is frustrated by the old people who tell him he’s too young to know what he’s doing. Undeterred
column4: he yells ""Youth culture forever!"" as he runs away to try something new. You might consider this when listening to Youth Culture Forever
column5: the sophomore album from Scottish trio PAWS that comes here to both praise and bury youth. Like contemporaries Yuck and Tony Molina
column6: you can pinpoint PAWS’ 90s alt rock influences from a mile away—there’s a bit of Mascis
column7: Malkmus
column8: Cuomo
column9: and the like. But while they spend time recounting the well-worn experiences of being young—the drunkenness
column10: the heartbreak
column11: the drunken heartbreak—they also push aside foolish things in favor of sober observations
column12: giving them gravitas beyond their years.

column1: ""Erreur Humaine"" is a loud-quiet-loud meditation on what feels like the futility of humanity when dealing with a collapsed relationship; when Philip Taylor sings ""Just 22 and I feel like I'm through
column2: he’s a world away from Taylor Swift’s ebullient take on that age milemark. Taylor might remind you of Titus Andronicus’ Patrick Stickles
column3: another guitar hero who’s made a career out of turning feelings of self-loathing into anthems. What ails Taylor are situations that can’t be grappled with until they emerge: dead friends
column4: imploded confidence
column5: hometowns that don’t evoke any fond feelings when you find yourself walking through the streets. A song on 2012's Cokefloat!
column6: ""Catherine 1956""
column7: paid tribute to a deceased parent; Youth Culture Forever's ""Alone"" and ""YCF"" are performed as stripped-down dirges at imaginary funerals for friends and states of mind. As Taylor proclaims
column8: ""I’ll have my youth culture forever
column9: you know he knows he won’t.

column1: PAWS have also beefed up their sound since Cokefloat!
column2: which was regarded as a lo-fi record; on Youth Culture Forever
column3: the rhythm section rumbles outward and the guitars are thick and present. ""Great Bear"" sounds like the animal namechecked in its title
column4: while ""War Cry"" shakes and sears like an active volcano for nearly 12 minutes
column5: spewing monolithic guitar lines and layers of feedback. The record is largely composed of uptempo singalongs filled with wistful feelings and perfectly timed ""whoa oh"" harmonies that they’ve picked up from pop-punk. Another element from that genre PAWS have picked up is that it’s more fun to sound happy about how sad you are
column6: as Taylor chants lines like ""Sometimes we were forced to accept defeat"" as communal bummers.

column1: Youth Culture Forever’s uptempo songs also factor as some of its weakest moments. ""Narcissist"" castigates someone who can’t stop talking about how hard his life is
column2: and since it's possible that Taylor could be making himself a target here
column3: it's essentially three uninteresting minutes of a singer checking his own privilege. Then there’s ""Someone New""
column4: which wins points for honesty but overcommits with its thrashing whine.  If Youth Culture Forever runs the risk of alienating listeners who aren’t particularly interested in what young people have to say about anything
column5: though
column6:
it’s a mark of the album’s endearing success that PAWS don’t seem to care.

"|19354.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19354-paws-youth-culture-forever/|7.2|Jeremy Gordon

When he’s not singing woozy pop songs about the worries of parenthood and the trials of adulthood
column2: Mike Adams hosts a talk show in Bloomington
column3: Indiana. It began in what looks like somebody’s basement
column4: with a cheery co-host and a laugh track with quote marks around it
column5: but has since become a live event with an actual audience replacing the “studio audience”. As funny and bizarre as it can be

column1: Adams is a goofball in the best sense
