column3: and that extends to the music he makes as Mike Adams at His Honest Weight. When he plays with his band
column4: he cavorts across the stage
column5: holding the mic close to his chest and waving a finger in the air to emphasize certain lyrical passages. Recently
column6: he and his band played a live show dressed as priests
column7: complete with clerical collars and crucifix medallions. Part crooner and part pop star
column8: Adams projects an outsize persona from the stage
column9: which he then punctures with his between-song banter. Somehow he manages to come across as both ironic and deeply sincere
column10: goofing on the conventions of pop music (he made this video
column11: after all) even as he embraces them as a means of communicating some deep pain.

column1: His songs aren’t dark
column2: but they are heavy. “I’m Worried”
column3: the first single from Adams’ second album
column4: <i>Best of Boiler Room Classics
column5: was written about the concerns he faced while his newborn son underwent multiple open-heart surgeries. Thankfully neither dour nor blandly life affirming
column6: the song evokes those endless moments of abject worry
column7: with a long
column8: tense instrumental interlude conveying the hand-wringing boredom of a waiting room. Presumably
column9: music assuaged Adams’ fatherly fears: He sneaks in a quote from the Cure’s “Just Like Heaven
column10: ” as though singing an old favorite to himself: “Show me show me show me how you do that trick/ That keeps you calm.” If the theme is harrowing
column11: the tone is anything but: the music is jangly and lush
column12: with pinpricks of guitar jabbing against his vocals that somehow keeps the melody bobbing and buoyant.

column1: Adams’ sense of humor shows through in the exaggerated hooks that pepper Boiler Room Classics. Songs like “Be Free
column2: Live Well” rush excitedly into towering
column3: tumbling choruses
column4: while slower numbers like the brooding “A Woman Is the New Man” and “Don’t Want It
column5: Don’t Get It” follow clean melodic lines
column6: like Bacharach at his most ruminative. On closer “Good Thing Going
column7: ” he sounds uncannily like Brian Wilson; on “The Fingers You Know
column8: ” like the Byrds. He and his band work with a musical palette that is both broad and specific
column9: blurring the distinctions between Nuggets-era rockers
column10: Midwestern power pop
column11: late-night lounge
column12: and ‘80s synth-pop.

column1: Adams is not necessarily concerned with integrating these various styles into something wholly new. Rather
column2: he’s projecting an identity through musical cues
column3: speaking through the shared language of pop. If his touchstones were too obscure or inside-jokey—if they weren’t so much fun—it might sound like he’s only playing to his record collection. Instead
column4: Boiler Room Classics is shot through with deep nostalgia and an even deeper melancholy
column5: as though Adams’ true subject is the fleeting nature of happiness
column6: the impermanence of family and friends. Or
column7: as he sings on one of the album’s sunniest hooks: “We’ve got a good thing going/ So we better get going
column8:
before the good thing goes.”

GoldLink is a 20-year-old rapper with a name that recalls a securities firm (he used be to be Gold Link James
column2: but dropped the surname to avoid any Trinidad James comparisons) and a sound all his own. Brightly colored
column3: hyper
column4: and upbeat
column5: the Virginia native's music draws openly from genres that street rap usually has no time for: bachata
column6: go-go
column7: classic house. When Diddy's Revolt.TV asked him to describe his style
column8: he responded thoughtfully: ""Rick James meets Justin Timberlake (*NSYNC days) with Backstreet Boys and a little D12 and Tupac."" GoldLink is a unique creature in rap right now and he knows it.

column1: He doesn't have much music to his name yet—The God Complex
column2: his debut mixtape
column3: is only 26 minutes and nine tracks long. Prior to that
column4: there were six songs on his Soundcloud. But his sound is distinct and unusual enough to have snagged the attention of local tastemakers: Peter Parker
column5: nighttime DJ at D.C. urban radio station WPGC
column6: named him one of the DMV's artists to watch last year
column7: and several of those early songs of his have surpassed 100k plays on Soundcloud. He's struck a nerve
column8: even if no one knows exactly where that nerve is just yet.

column1: There is a lot of information to parse on The God Complex
column2: all of it happening at once. The BPMs are nearly twice as fast as current street rap allows
column3: and glitzy house synths flutter everywhere. Louie Lastic
column4: one of GoldLink's main collaborators and an architect of the sound that they've dubbed ""Future Bounce""
column5: handles most of the production here; the resulting sound is wet and lubricious—there is a lot of audible licking and jiggling
column6: both in the lyrics and the music.  The Ronnie Foster sample behind A Tribe Called Quest's ""Electric Relaxation"" peeks out furtively behind strobe lights and '90s R&B keyboards on ""Bedtime Story"". A slowed-down playback of Britney Spears' ""Toxic"" surfaces near the end of ""How It's Done"". You can imagine Azealia Banks wishing she'd corralled production from this crew.

column1: And yet
column2: GoldLink tramples through the music
column3: his rhymes as hard as a shoulder check. This is one of the most fascinating pieces of GoldLink's sound—he skips through the minefield separating rap's ideas of ""hard"" and ""soft"". On ""Bedtime Story""
column4: he calls out wearers of tight jeans and waves box-cutters at us. On ""Hip-Hop (Interlude)"" he reminisces about ""masturbating to them porno flicks my brother gave me"" and ""popping guns"" at age 11. His voice is high
column5: hyper
column6: and excitable
column7: no one's idea of a tough-guy stereotype
column8: but he keeps one foot firmly planted in street rap and the other in the club
column9: tangling all the music's reference points and intentions like kite strings. The surfaces of his music are slick and slippery
column10: and gaining purchase on what he's doing is like trying to hug a dolphin.

column1: This confusion
column2: and the endorphins it loosens
column3: is presumably why people have been losing their shit about GoldLink. His music doesn't just make you hold two opposing ideas in your mind--it opens twelve tabs in one browser window.  On ""Planet Paradise""
column4: he raps in triple-time
column5: allowing a single pinhole gulp of air to open between ""everyday we pray to-"" and ""God"" in the exact same place every time. His mind moves at a thousand miles an hour
column6:
as does the music. Nine tracks is more than enough to digest for now.

column4: Lily Allen released a single called ""Sheezus""
column5: from her new album of the same name. She begins the song in a weary murmur
column6: announcing that
column7: after five years away
column8: she's ready to step back into the spotlight and endure all the ""embarrassing"" comparisons she will receive to other female pop stars. Then
column9: in the chorus
column10: she all but invites these comparisons by name-checking some artists she seems to perceive as her contemporaries: ""Riri isn't scared of Katy Perry's Roaring/ Queen B's gone back to the drawing/ Lorde smells blood
column11: yeah she's about to slay you/ Kid ain't one to fuck with when she's only on her debut.""

column1: ""Sheezus"" is a maddeningly catchy
column2: deeply puzzling song. Is she paying homage to these women? Is she making fun of them? Maybe a little bit of both? (And while we're asking the unanswerable: Why is she dressed like a Na'vi from Avatar in the song's video?) Maybe Allen wants ""Sheezus"" to be read as a critique of the ruthlessly combative
column3: Who-Wore-It-Better? pageant that our culture creates for female celebrities—though at the same time
column4: she admits that part of her desires that rigged game's flashy prize. ""Give me the crown
column5: bitch
column6: she snaps a little too convincingly at the end of the chorus
column7: ""I wanna be Sheezus.""

column1: All things considered
column2: the Lorde reference is particularly loaded. Nearly a decade ago
column3: Allen was the promising and precociously literate pop insurgent who was ""only on her debut."" That record was 2006's enduringly charming <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9221-alright-still/"">Alright
column4: Still—a personable blast of witty
column5: hip-hop-informed pop that featured lively character sketches of famous family members
column6: eccentric London townies
column7: and shitty ex-boyfriends. It sold millions and made her a star
column8: particularly in her home country. Allen became a fixture on the London club scene and an acid-tongued presence in the British media; she took a brief and well-publicized break from drinking after telling Elton John to ""fuck off"" on national TV.

column1: Her second record
column2: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/12662-its-not-me-its-you/""><i>It's Not Me
column3: It's You
column4: was as shimmery and sharp as a shattered mirror
column5: critiquing the vapidity of fame (""The Fear"") and the ways in which the deck is stacked against outspoken women who dare to outlive their ingénue phase (""22""
column6: a song about the Rock-Forever-21-But-Just-Turned-30 set
column7: now feels like a bleak sequel to Taylor Swift's hit of the same name). Though the tabloids charted Allen's every affair
column8: her most passionate love/hate relationship seemed to be with her own notoriety. (A telling detail that almost every profile of her dutifully noted: After she was arrested in 2007 for attacking a photographer
column9: she blew up a copy of the police citation and hung it in her foyer.)

column1: Clearly
column2: Allen possesses a terrific flair for irony. But there's a fine line between using irony to make a cutting point and using it as a protective coating to hide the fact that you're not sure exactly what you're trying to say. Allen was once a master of the former
column3: but Sheezus too often finds her drifting perilously in the latter territory. Even before she was disowning her underperforming singles as ""docile pop rubbish"" on Twitter a few weeks ago
column4: we got a taste of this back-pedaling and double-speak on the album’s lead-off single ""Hard Out Here""
column5: which fashioned itself a critique of music industry sexism but
column6: to some listeners
column7: sent an unfortunate mixed message. ""I don't have to shake my ass for you
column8: cuz I've got a brain
column9: Allen sang
column10: as though the two were mutually exclusive; behind her
column11: a group of black women shook their asses at the camera. When the video was accused of being racist
column12: Allen clarified
column13: ""If I could dance like the ladies can
column14: it would have been my arse on your screens."" All of this confusion only muddled her original point
column15: and made you wonder if the song had as much brain power as Allen advertised.

column1: Allen was one of the first high-profile artists to cultivate a fanbase via the internet; she posted demos on Myspace in advance of Alright
column2: Still
column3: and later became known for writing confessional posts on her blog. But the controversy that ""Hard Out Here"" generated seemed like a barometer of how much the internet has changed in a few short years—especially when it comes to talking (or making music) about feminism. As the writer Michelle Goldberg described in a recent cover story for The Nation
column4: it can sometimes feel on Twitter like there is a radical SWAT team that would rather jump on anyone who Does Feminism Wrong (see also: the ""Is Beyoncé A Feminist?"" Thinkpiece Fatigue of 2014) than allow people to express ""well intentioned"" but ""imperfect"" opinions. Because she is making some valid points about double standards in the music industry
column5: some might find it tempting to consider Allen a victim of this kind of hand-wringing. But in the end
column6: Sheezus fails on much less ambiguous grounds.

column1: There's nothing particularly wrong with the way the album sounds: It's a sleek and bubbly
column2: if somewhat indistinct
column3: pop record. It's not easy to write songs that are as catchy as they are verbose
column4: but Allen and her frequent collaborator
column5: producer Greg Kurstin
column6: have not lost the light
column7: agile touch they showcased on the best of It's Not Me. ""L8 CMMR"" is cheeky summertime pop
column8: and the Sugababes-sweet ""Air Balloon"" is infectious enough that I can almost forgive Allen
column9: lyrically
column10: for making the same joke as that stupid Bavaria Radler commercial with Elvis and Kurt Cobain. (Almost.) The record's most satisfyingly on-point moment
column11: though
column12: is ""URL Badman""
column13: a satirical send-up of spiteful internet commenters. Allen sings it in the voice of a parents'-basement-dwelling ""London white boy repping ATL"" who says things like
column14: ""I don't troll
column15: I make statements."" Even though he spends his days spouting Wordpress vitriol at famous women who will never fuck him
column16: he wants us to know that deep down he's really just a sensitive guy
column17: ""like Drake.""

column1: If only this record could put its money where its delightfully dirty mouth is. But too often
column2: there's a tone of scolding
column3: mean-spirited superiority about Sheezus that
column4: after a few spins
column5: makes you wonder why Allen thinks she’s so different from that blogosphere hater. The feather-light R&B number ""Insincerely Yours"" is bogged down by cheap shots and Twitter-beef petulance: ""I don't give a fuck about the Delevingne
column6: that Rita girl
column7: about Jourdan Dunn… I don't give a fuck about your Instagram
column8: about your lovely house or your ugly kids."" Allen's venomous tongue was previously effective when it spewed at unidentified love interests or impersonal cultural institutions like ""society"" or The Sun and The Mirror
column9: but
column10: as on “Sheezus”
column11: she runs into trouble as soon as she starts naming names. Not only will “Insincerely Yours” age about as well as the Fred Durst diss in ""The Real Slim Shady""
column12: but less forgivably
column13: it contradicts the record’s overall message. How can Allen not see that she's playing into the very catfight narrative that
column14: four songs previous
column15: she was supposedly trying to end?

column1: Even as Allen takes both serious and “ironic” jabs at her contemporaries
column2: she seems plenty interested in borrowing from their sounds and sensibilities. “Our Time” is her obligatory stab at a YOLO-anthem
column3: a “We Can’t Stop” in everything but name and cutting-edge production. There’s also a particularly noxious song called ""Silver Spoon""
column4: the main argument of which scans as
column5: “Fuck off
column6: I grew up slightly less rich than you think I did.” Although it aims for empathy across class lines
column7: it just comes off as defensive. Furthermore
column8: although Allen’s records have always been stylistic hodgepodges
column9: Sheezus doesn’t flow as fluidly as her last two. When things get a little weary after the mandatory ballad about not wanting to be famous anymore
column10: cue ""As Long As I Got You""
column11: which is...a zydeco song?

column1: “The game is changing
column2: ” Allen sings on “Sheezus”. “Can’t just come back
column3: jump on the mic and do the same thing.” There is something poignant and disarmingly honest about this song—very few artists pull back the curtain on the kind of fears and anxieties she’s acknowledging here. And while Allen’s right—the game is changing—there are plenty of reasons to feel more hopeful about the future than she does. Katy Perry’s “Roar” wasn’t a catty snipe at anybody’s Instagram
column4: but instead a primal battle cry of female self-empowerment. Yes
column5: Beyoncé did go back to the drawing board—and she returned to completely reinvent the album as a relevant format in 2014 and prove that brains and ass-shaking can coexist and the world shall continue to turn. And in the short amount of time she’s been on the scene
column6: Lorde has not only spoken out against the music industry’s sexism but also cultivated a powerful sense of solidarity with other young female pop stars. Even in the context of a joke
column7: the word “diva” feels applicable to her least of all. She is not the girl who wants to “slay” her “rivals”
column8: but befriend and root for them instead.

column1: So “Sheezus” is based on a false conceit. Nobody’s vying for the title of Top Diva in 2014 because—and this is the great and exciting thing about women in pop music right now—there’s enough room at the table for all different kinds of femininities
column2: sexualities
column3: races
column4: body types
column5: and sounds. (It ain’t perfect
column6: of course
column7: but progress is being made.) Sheezus has a few good points and some admirable intentions
column8: but too often it misses the point. In the end
column9:
Allen only fans the flames she says she wants to extinguish.

TANHÂ is a collaboration by Japanese artists Arµ-2 and Lee. On each track
column2: mangled samples are fused into colorful masses that convulse for a couple minutes and then humbly fade away. The album belongs to a strand of meta-music that takes the surplus of recorded media as both backdrop and subject. The Books

column5: and their name is insolubly linked to the concept of forging obscure narratives from audiovisual errata
column6: drawing as much attention to the medium as the message.

column1: TANHÂ updates the Books' approach for contemporary times; its disturbances are contextualized by stuttering streams and nested browser windows instead of crackling vinyl and faltering radio waves. The pitch-bent vocal fragments are grounded
column2: however distantly
column3: in hip-hop rather than folk. If the Books evoked waking up to the sound of a possessed radio
column4: TANHÂ is like falling asleep while multiple Pandora stations play at once on a lagging connection
column5: dreamlike narratives emerging from the clash of clipping signals.

column1: Digital sampling is a much less arcane art these days

column3: a keystroke instantly familiar to any Mac user

column6: concentrated doses of emotion
column7: and a sweet melodic sense that softens the aggressively choppy rhythms—the latter of which can also sound refreshingly delicate at times
column8: like pebbles rolling through a reverberant cave. Rap
column9: fusty standards
column10: spoken dialogue
column11: and zany sound effects roil through deconstructed beats and cottony melodies
column12: streaked with traces of Japanese folk
column13: classical and ambient music. The bright
column14: gulping electronics recall fellow Japanese artist Radicalfashion
column15: while twinkling piano themes evoke the contemplative moods of Akira Kosemura.

column1: Lee has claimed a J Dilla influence
column2: but that soulful lope is nowhere in evidence. Hip-hop shows up in prismatic fragments—an MC's disembodied ""Hey""s punching through the cinematic trip-hop of ""aśrava""
column3: or samples from Fat Joe's ""Firewater"" twisted into paperclip shapes to fasten together the high-contrast cuts of ""sen"". The boldest tracks have either a more cartoonish or sentimental feel. The former is epitomized by ""sankha^ra^""

column5: and ""muditā""
column6: where dreamy pianos and synths mix with braying Woody Woodpecker-like laughter to forge a beguiling blend of sweetness and madness. The sentimental aspect comes to the fore in “dukkha”
column7: which revolves around Nat King Cole's ""For Sentimental Reasons""
column8: and ""三""

column1: ""dukkha"" lands with a schmaltzy jolt of familiarity

column4: which makes them seem more based on tenets of design than music—like something you’d hear at an art installation. So the aforementioned two songs are key

column1: There's a thin stretch near the end of TANHÂ where several tracks linger without standing out
column2: but the album rallies for a strong finish with the songful ""mantra"" and the closing title track

it makes for an arresting view of the present in idiosyncratic hands such as these.

Like Todd Terje
column3: Mark Evetts rode into the spotlight in the mid-2000s on the strength of his bedroom edits. His re-works of disco and forgotten R&B album cuts (see the Damita Jo-era Janet Jackson remix “RnB Drunkie”
column4: which became enough of a hit to demand several re-pressings) gained him enough traction to found his own label
column5: MERC. Sparkling tracks like his slow-burning workout of Womack & Womack’s “Baby I’m Scared of You”
column6: and a fabulous
column7: freewheeling Labelle re-edit he called ""Sunshadow” were eventually compiled on Mark E Works 2005 -2009 Selected Tracks & Edits.

column1: Evetts’ attitude towards edits has always been fairly utilitarian
column2: so it’s no surprise that his interests have slowly shifted to original composition. Stone Breaker
column3: his 2011 debut for Spectral Sound
column4: was a satisfying sampler of woozy house; its monumental centerpiece
column5: “Got to Get Me There”
column6: proved as blissfully meandering as the best of his early work. Product of Industry is initially a less inviting record—though it incorporates some of the same tightly-wound
column7: slowly morphing loops found in his re-works
column8: it has its share of methodical
column9: energy-sapping tracks. Taken as a larger statement
column10: it paints Evetts as an artist who’s grown increasingly insular over the course of his career.

column1: Evetts is a native of Wolverhampton and has lived in the larger English industrial center of Birmingham since 1995. Product of Industry could properly be called a “concept album
column2: ” but that concept is fairly nebulous
column3: really more of a shifting mood bolstered by a set of musical connotations. Tracks like “Persia” and the perplexingly heavy-footed “Eganix” plod along with the dull robotic energy of machinery operators
column4: their thick
column5: leaden drums sounding like clanging pipes
column6: or feet treading on sawdust.

column1: The album tries to convey the dark side of industrialization: boredom
column2: hopelessness
column3: depression
column4: and pollution all find a musical corollary at some point. Evetts often tweaks and re-tweaks interlocking parts until a given track stretches well past the seven minute mark; the album is over an hour long
column5: but in the midst of that monotony
column6: there are moments of specific intimacy. “Smoke”
column7: with its impossibly deep voice growling ""Yea…uh huh
column8: ” seems to mimic the minute
column9: enveloping distraction of a cigarette
column10: eventually adding a hint anxiety before finally petering out. Back to reality
column11: then.

column1: “Bog Dance”
column2: one of the most aggressive cuts
column3: is also among the most entrancing
column4: as a series of chain-link synthesizer lines whirr upwards to towering heights. It highlights Evetts' feel for structure with interlocking parts that escalate in urgency even as they continually return to the same ground
column5: following the same tension-and-release patterns he once sutured into otherwise affable disco tracks. But despite Evetts’ abundance of ideas
column6: there are stretches that feel like dead air. “Being Hiding”
column7: featuring a vocal by Bing Ji Ling of the Phenomenal Handclap Band
column8: comes off as a too-literal singer/songwriter take on the album’s underlying ideas
column9: overburdened with lines like “Every day there’s a 9 to 5/ Yet we still don’t know just when it ends.”

column1: Evetts is an old hand at house music’s relentless 4/4 beat
column2: ambient washes
column3: and slightly dissonant chords. When these details spool out at a methodical rate
column4: they create a unique feeling somewhere between melancholy and slightly buzzed euphoria
column5: the best example being the remarkable nine-minute closing track
column6: “Leaving Osaka”. You could interpret Product of Industry’s sometimes severe tone an expression of the real world's slow encroachment onto the dance floor
column7: but “Leaving Osaka” makes it sound like a further displacement of reality
column8:
as if enduring the tedium opens the door to some weird new bliss.

An upright bass-playing torch singer? The gist of Nat Baldwin’s music is more interesting than his membership in Dirty Projectors
column2: the selling point his name has most often generated for much of the last decade. But by himself
column3: or with any number of high-caliber collaborators
column4: Baldwin is a singer/songwriter who employs his upright bass in much the same way as most people stuck to that tag use a piano
column5: a guitar
column6: or even a cello—to form the musical foundation for tense
column7: impressionistic tunes. His fluttering
column8: agile voice
column9: capable of falsetto crests and valley-deep dives
column10: only adds to the intrigue.

column1: As distinct as Baldwin’s approach seems
column2: though
column3: his music has typically fit into predictable indie songwriter circles. The movement of his voice
column4: for instance
column5: recalls that of lead Projector Dave Longstreth
column6: particularly given how Baldwin condenses and stretches syllables during wild rhythmic runs. His light timbre suggests both Andrew Bird and Owen Pallett. In the past
column7: however

column1: But on his latest
column2: In the Hollows
column3: Baldwin falls far into a quagmire of the expected
column4: not only with vocals that take no new chances but also with a cast of collaborators that
column5: however accomplished
column6: scans like a cliché. Otto Hauser
column7: for instance

column9: but his résumé of appearances—Vetiver
column10: Devendra Banhart
column11: Marissa Nadler
column12: Vashti Bunyan—suggests that Baldwin is trying to pigeonhole himself stylistically. And then there’s the three-piece string section

column15: Bon Iver
column16: Grizzly Bear
column17: and Arcade Fire. Their contributions to In the Hollows sound wonderful

column19: high definition in a proper Rhode Island studio. But this quintet ultimately feels flat and safe

column1: If you were to read the liner notes for In the Hollows without actually listening to the record
column2: you might assume that the music is fraught with worry

column4: after all

column6: a period that often pits the trainee against his or her own human frailty.) “Light a match to erase a lifetime leading here
column7: ” Baldwin offers during “Knockout”
column8: a song that pits eternal perseverance against the fact that few things last very long at all. And on paper
column9: “Cosmos Pose” is a sharp
column10: short examination of the torture we endure to approach some arbitrary idea of perfection: “Sweat it out to make the weight/ Needles stuck in every vein.”

column1: But on tape
column2: “Knockout” is practically buoyant
column3: the grimace of the bowed bass and slapped drums lifting into a kind of hollow comfort. Cloying strings extend beneath Baldwin’s vocal
column4: pulling tight like a safety net—which he clearly needs
column5: since he sings the word “fucked” with the hesitation of a teenager cursing in front of parents for the first time. “Cosmos Pose” aims for high drama
column6: with Hauser’s percussion responding to the foreboding call of the bass. Still
column7: Baldwin seems to shrink from the weight of his own words
column8: his voice tempered and tame even as the words he sings reveal crisis after crisis.

column1: Time and again
column2: the arrangements and performances here seem to treat their subject matter like familial black sheep
column3: shuddering at the anxieties they propose. “Half My Life” is borne of a nightmare and mid-life despair
column4: but it’s as affable as a Disney score. “The End of the Night”
column5: one of two solo numbers here
column6: sets itself up as the record’s soul-baring centerpiece. But even as Baldwin sings “I don’t know if it’s weakness or strength/ Just know that I need something to go for
column7: ” his diction is overly precise and polished

column1: In the Hollows never feels lived-in
column2: or more generously
column3: part of the reality Baldwin has found and written into these songs. The exception comes with the title cut
column4: the record’s biggest production and the most anomalous and audacious pop anthem of Baldwin’s career. Its words are
column5: again
column6: loaded with feelings—namely
column7: the sense that all the enthusiasms and experiences we collect are simply sideshows during our own march to oblivion—as Baldwin lets his voice break only to pull it together
column8: the strings tracking beneath him like a nervous heartbeat. “Even strides mark my path for the first and last time
column9: ” Baldwin sings
column10: his tone a wonderful mess. In this moment of honest
column11: human admission
column12: he flashes above the quotidian company that this record keeps. It’s a riveting flash of inspiration—too brief to renew the album
column13: yes
column14:
but good enough to reiterate that the upright bass-playing torch singer remains more than a mere sideman.

Sleaford Mods are the type of band that force you to have an opinion on them within about five seconds of hearing their music. There are no half-measures
column2: no stylistic arcs
column3: no organic steps taken
column4: no time at all to let it sink in and decide if this is something you might like. They’re a duo from Grantham in England
column5: a place most famous for being the birthplace of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Singer Jason Williamson speed-talks bile while Andrew Fearn provides coarse backing tracks
column6: which barely get beyond cheap plastic keyboard presets. They’ve already released a ton of music
column7: most of which got nowhere
column8: until last year’s Austerity Dogs
column9: which gained rolling acclaim as a treatise on the State of Things in contemporary England. It might sound unlikely
column10: but a man who frequently references toilet habits in songs has become one of the most sharp and funny chroniclers of his country's widespread slump into disillusionment.

column1: Williamson has had a few attempts at getting somewhere in music before. “I used to be in bands
column2: fuckin’ hated it” is the slogan on Sleaford Mods’ Bandcamp page. They’re a band of inherent contradiction
column3: neither coming from the English town of Sleaford nor being mods
column4: although Williamson’s appearance bears traces of a mod past. Instead
column5: Divide and Exit is about as punk as punk gets in 2014. Williamson sounds charged
column6: wired
column7: determined to make one last go of things
column8: simultaneously expressing his frustration at the helplessness of it all and finding his words taking him somewhere beyond his current predicament—a juxtaposition that could have fascinating implications for this band’s future. Sleaford Mods are playing sell-out shows in the UK
column9: gaining blanket acclaim everywhere. Their next album
column10: post audience expansion
column11: should be interesting
column12: especially as Williamson drops enough music industry references into his songs to suggest he’s got an astute grasp on how its machinations work.

column1: Sleaford Mods songs follow a simple formula
column2: repeated 14 times on Divide and Exit. Fearn triggers his economical music
column3: allowing it to repeat until close
column4: while Williamson gets lost in a blizzard of words
column5: sometimes to the point of tripping over himself (on “Smithy”
column6: about fashion designer Paul Smith
column7: on this album). Profanity
column8: jokes
column9: and commentary come thick and fast
column10: with Williamson often sounding like he’s in an argument with himself
column11: or addressing someone whose identity forms around his words as the song progresses. There are cultural references that will mean nothing to many people outside the UK
column12: most prominently on “Tiswas”
column13: named after a kids’ TV show (""Tiswas"") that ran from the mid 1970s to the early 80s. It barely matters because what makes Sleaford Mods work is a universal expression of exasperation
column14: of finding yourself in a position where your ideals are trampled on so hard every day that it feels like society barely has a place for you.

column1: Even the jokes and puns Williamson scatters through his songs form a particular function if you can dig past them as surface level chatter. They’re so poor
column2: so lacking in laughs
column3: that they resemble the kind of forced-grin jollity people put on when they’re at an absolute low
column4: scrambling around for something
column5: anything
column6: to get them through the day. He hops from that kind of thinking to scathing critique in a heartbeat
column7: calling out people who talk in fake regional accents on “Livable Shit” and then lambasting pointless nationalist loyalty in the same song (“St. George’s flag twat
column8: ” he growls). You can almost feel Williamson’s skin prickling in the places he goes to in these songs
column9: some of which are outlined in unrelentingly grim terms. On “A Little Ditty” he rants about “gnarly coke-death faces
column10: death death death
column11: nine to a cubicle.” Of course
column12: after such disturbingly lucid thinking
column13: the song ends with a voice saying: “That was shit that end bit
column14: mate.”

column1: Some of the acts regularly mentioned in the same breath as Sleaford Mods include the Streets
column2: the Fall
column3: and English punk-poet John Cooper Clarke. There are traces of those artists here
column4: but only dim ones in the overall picture. Instead
column5: Sleaford Mods are tapping into a feeling the UK has traditionally found a more expressive home for in mediums other than music. Williamson has declared an admiration for the kitchen sink drama of Alan Sillitoe’s Saturday Night and Sunday Morning
column6: and his ceaseless depiction of a life marred by petty violence
column7: discontent
column8: and resentment resembles the work of filmmaker Alan Clarke
column9: whose Scum and Made in Britain are chilling depictions of societal outcasts whose lives are caught in utter stasis. There’s a similar conviction to those works here—it’s difficult to imagine anyone else being able to pull off a line like “the state is no longer your voice” on “Under The Plastic And N.C.T.”
column10: so convincing is the tenor in Williamson’s voice.

column1: The crude nature of this music as a mode of overall expression
column2: whether it’s in the unrelenting use of swearing or in Fearn’s cloddish rhythms
column3: might be the most powerful tool this band has at its disposal
column4: particularly in terms of making a connection to a bigger audience. Turner Prize winning artist Jeremy Deller recently exhibited pictures drawn by prisoners of the Iraq war
column5: which depict the chief architects of the conflict
column6: including Tony Blair and former UN weapons inspector Dr. David Kelly. The works are raw and technically poor
column7: but the bitterness and hatred they express is overwhelming
column8: illustrating how base feeling
column9: when expressed with such belief
column10: can overcome any window dressing put up around it. Where Sleaford Mods take their wonderfully foul-mouthed antagonism from here is anyone’s guess
column11: but it scarcely matters when they’re so vividly depicting the now. Williamson’s been through a lot
column12:
and he knows the zeitgeist when he sees it. A recent tweet from Sleaford Mods succinctly sums up both the position they find themselves in and the feeling they reflect in their music: “This is our time.”

On Cerulean
column3: Baths’ 2010 debut LP
column4: songs sounded splintered
column5: shot through with percussive interruptions that were unwieldy yet ear-catching. These arrangements made Will Wiesenfeld
column6: then loosely associated with Los Angeles’ Low End Theory scene
column7: stand out in a company of seemingly likeminded beat-heads. Since then
column8: his output has become deceptively simple

column10: and Baths' latest EP
column11: Ocean Death
column12: hits you in the head with enormous
column13: blunt impact.

column1: Following Will Wiesenfeld’s most recent record
column2: last year's Obsidian
column3: the EP showcases the singer’s continued focus on mortality and heartbreak. He approaches each subject with the misdirection of an experienced comedian: death is discussed with morbid joy
column4: and heartbreak is met with anger instead of sadness or self-pity. Wiesenfeld’s songwriting remains evocative as ever
column5: and while Ocean Death lacks the thematic cohesion of its predecessor
column6: it’s another beguiling offering from a singer and beatmaker who continues to evolve into a singular artist.

column1: At points
column2: Ocean Death takes cues from dance music
column3: evoking '90s dub techno while slowing things down and revealing a darkly humorous streak. The title track at once resembles Vincent Floyd and early Four Tet; it's a whirring
column4: humming paean to death that sounds eerily ceremonial. A baroque atmosphere lingers throughout the EP
column5: even as Wiesenfeld's subject and sound shifts track-by-track. Wiesenfeld's an admirer of Björk and Kate Bush
column6: artists whose surface approachability offers passageway into complicated songs; on Ocean Death
column7: he’s working in a similar way
column8: adding static prickles to represent a growing contempt for a lover on “Yawn” and burnishing the otherwise dour “Voyeur” with what sounds like harp strings.

column1: Obsidian was informed by Wiesenfeld’s battle with a deadly strain of E. coli
column2: and its lyrics were both gruesome and vulnerable in a way that bred a unique intimacy. For the majority of Ocean Death
column3: he's moved away from the pain and venom that he expressed so vehemently last time. Compare Obsidian's “Earth Death” to the EP’s title track: where “Earth Death” described the fear of a person trapped in his own dying body
column4: “Ocean Death” is gleeful
column5: as Wiesenfeld takes on the role of the ocean
column6: asking for someone to be sacrificed to him. It's a fitting image on a release where Wiesenfeld widens his scope.

column1: There are still hints of Wiesenfeld's scorched-earth songwriting. The cruelest couplet here
column2: on “Yawn”
column3: masterfully combines the mundane and the vicious: “Your steady breath when you’re reading/ I think about our love and its lack of meaning.” Wiesenfeld’s sharp sense of humor pokes through elsewhere
column4: especially in the coy attitude on “Fade White
column5: ” which finds him coaxing a companion to join him in the embrace of nonexistence.

column1: Ocean Death scan as less personal than Wiesenfeld’s earlier work
column2: but the more generalized approach suits the music's expanse. He no longer seems obsessed with his own death: the perspective here suggests a broader apocalypse
column3: and in that sense
column4: the EP represents something larger than anything Wiesenfeld's done previously. Dark and painful at points
column5:
Ocean Death is still filled with wonder at the largeness of the world and the awesome power of endings.

Notions of place and displacement feature strongly in the works of Fatima Al Qadiri. Her clearly realized Desert Strike EP
column2: which was based around the experience of playing a videogame based around Operation Desert Storm—an event she lived through as a child growing up in Kuwait—and Asiatisch arrives with a new cloud of conceptual thought hovering over it. Now based in Brooklyn
column3: Al Qadiri uses her debut full-length as a lens to refract the skewed manner in which Asian motifs have sunk into Western pop culture. She calls it a “virtual road trip through ‘imagined China
column4: ’” a country she has never visited
column5: but has extensively experienced through a barrage of appropriated thoughts
column6: images
column7: and sounds. It’s set to a musical backing so bare it feels like someone scooped out most of the contents and dumped them out
column8: providing an intriguing counterpoint to the dense flood of thought the record carries on its back.

column1: The ideas surrounding Desert Strike were inspired by the rapid bastardization of other cultural experiences by the West
column2: dealing with a particular form of accelerated baton-handing that effectively transforms horror into fun in rapid time. Asiatisch—its title taken from the German word for Asian—broadcasts from a similar space
column3: only with a stronger sense of remove at work. In a sense
column4: it’s a forebear for how the West will dilute something like the first Gulf War 40 or 50 years from now
column5: slowly contorting it and shaping it until it becomes something few who were actually there will have experienced. If Desert Strike was about feeling an immediate sense of personal remove
column6: Asiatisch observes the long-term effects of societal remove
column7: where great blocks of culture are siphoned off then progressively diluted until they have as much significance as an empty Coke can.

column1: The tiny sub-genre of sinogrime—essentially the sound of London producers briefly looking East for inspiration circa 2002-3—has been vaunted as an influence on this record
column2: although Al Qadiri admits she wasn’t familiar with the style until after this album was finished. Still
column3: there are ties
column4: although most sinogrime efforts were denser in structure than these songs. Sometimes there’s little more than a crisp trap snare and a bass welt or two; often there are glassy
column5: MIDI-indebted synth lines padding away. “Jade Stars” sounds like a sci-fi Vangelis fantasy ripped straight out of Blade Runner
column6: while “Wudang” features music so hollow it perfectly reflects the sunken feeling of binging on low culture for too long. Journalist Dan Hancox described sinogrime as a sub-genre “that barely ever existed”
column7: which is fitting because Al Qadiri also makes music that barely exists
column8: to the point where the gaps between notes almost become the songs themselves.

column1: The best tracks further dilute culture in themselves
column2: acting like real-time examples of the disintegration Al Qadiri is interested in. “Shanzhai” is titled after the word used to describe pirated goods produced by Chinese companies
column3: which she turns into a cover of Sinead O’Connor’s version of “Nothing Compares 2 U” (itself a cover)
column4: using a vocal she describes as a “nonsense version” of the song sent to her by friends. It’s only a political record in a faint sense
column5: making few overt statements outside of “Dragon Tattoo”
column6: which observes Disney's racist co-opting of Asian culture by borrowing lines from “We Are Siamese” from Lady and the Tramp. Certainly it’s not always so easy to trace Al Qadiri’s intentions
column7: and the largely dynamic-free range she operates in can grate at times. But the immaculate emptiness is
column8: in a sense
column9: Asiatisch’s masterstroke
column10:
helping bolster the pervading sense of dislocation of being exposed to a society that’s been fed through the photocopier one too many times.

There’s a tendency in American culture to use foreign punk bands to gain insight to another nation’s political and emotional tenor
column2: and that’s just not gonna work with Sweden’s Makthaverskan. Though a reaction to what they considered to be a conformist
column3: “happy and cute” indie scene in Gothenburg
column4: II is an interior and personal record of constricted scope
column5: occurring entirely within Maja Milner: in her blood
column6: in her head
column7: in her body
column8: in her room. Beyond that
column9: who knows what else is going on in the world—but that’s the whole point of II
column10: a record of unhinged beauty that can be wrested from longing and anger. At times it feels threatening enough to render all other concerns inconsequential.

column1: The cramped confines of II are indicative of its attitude
column2: a desire to get the fuck away from somewhere
column3: whether it’s a torturous relationship
column4: a mental straightjacket
column5: or a shitty mood. For the most part

column7: melodic post-punk

column9: its punk ethos and intensity make it all feel like a crying fit so physically severe that you’re actually sore afterwards.

column1: Makthaverskan try to soar with makeshift wings on II
column2: and more often than not
column3: the results are charming rather than awkward. Glistening guitar leads occasionally stumble upon a bum note
column4: drums get lost in swirl of reverb if they let up the intensity. Regardless
column5: it’s rare to hear a singer who can flat-out project like Milner—the leaps of faith she takes before hitting the skyscraping notes that punctuate the daring introductory duo of “Antabus” and “Asleep” are captivating to the point where sometimes it seems like she’s only utilizing a small fraction of her powers. But as with the rest of her band
column6: Milner is less compelling on songs that require a bit more finesse; when “Drömland” drops the 100
column8: 000th “Be My Baby” drum intro and “Something More” runs through facile midtempo
column9: mid-career Cure
column10: it comes off as strangely sheepish. Consequently
column11: there are points where Milner’s voices gets a bit too piercing amidst the unbalanced mix—it’s the effect of cleaning your ear with a Q-Tip and going in a little too far.

column1: But then again
column2: II takes on the form of what happens to people who’ve gone a little too far putting themselves out there—the “never again” visceral reaction one has after getting screwed by their vulnerability. (It's worth noting that “Antabus” is named after a drug which elicits a violent reaction in alcoholics when they relapse.) While little of II’s vitriol is lost in translation
column3: there is no English equivalent for the band name: “The woman with the power” is as close as we can get.

column1: And yet
column2: Milner’s lyrics can be categorized into three stages of trying to recapture that power rather than owning it: ""Don’t go""
column3: ""Please come back""
column4: and ""Fuck you
column5: leave"". At times
column6: the latter is literally what it comes down to: there’s no real chorus to “Antabus”
column7: just a refrain of “I don’t know what to say/ So fuck you!/ Fuck you!” Fittingly
column8: “No Mercy” is even more direct<b>
column9: as Milner yells
column10: “Fuck you for fucking me when I was 17...You never loved me/You wanted to own me."" The fine and crucial semantic distinctions of “fuck” apparently cross the language barrier and throughout II
column11: there isn’t much romantic love
column12: just the romanticization of young lust and teen angst. Those are part of the same continuum
column13: though and when II taps into its eternal power
column14: the cries from Milner’s bedroom nothing short of universal.

column6: while closer ""And No Stress"" is proof that even with a basis of familiar

The final track on Maria Minerva's third full-length
column2: <i>Histrionic
column3: shares its title with exiled Estonian writer Karl Ristikivi's 1953 novel Hingede Öö (""Night of Souls""). Here’s a representative quote from the book: ""I almost have the feeling that I am writing about someone very remote from myself
column4: someone I hardly know and whose life story I am only familiar with by hearsay. Someone who has gone far away
column5: so that I can no longer meet him to ask how it really was."" Ristikivi’s narrator describes a condition of exile that’s less geographical than it is existential

Think of this meditation on alienation and loss of self as a sort of epigraph to Maria Juur’s (Minerva’s real name) latest effort. Having moved from her own native Estonia to Brooklyn before writing and recording Histrionic
column7: it’s perhaps natural that she would find connection in their mutual disconnectedness.

column9: maybe

column8: ""You don't have to say you love me

column5: seems flawed and unsatisfying. She then tries to find solace in who she originally was
column6: but finds that impossible to recapture as well. In most ways Histrionic is Maria Juur’s most self-assured and cohesive work—she moves from song to song with purpose—but by the end of the record I felt like I knew her even less than when I began listening to it. Her alienation is contagious that way. And while I appreciate and perhaps even identify more strongly with Histrionic's less formed songs
column7: Juur's resistance to conformity often sounds like a resistance to passion. Commitment is overrated
column8:
but feeling isn't.

Merrill Garbus started recording music as tUnE-yArDs while working as a babysitter on Martha's Vineyard
column3: an island off the coast of Massachusetts. Funny things happen to solitary people in quiet places. You talk to yourself. You expand to fit the space. You realize ""you"" might be more than one person. Midway through her 2009 debut
column4: BiRd-BrAiNs
column5: Garbus tells a deadbeat lover she no longer needs him because she can always get pregnant with birds
column6: which comes as terrific news. Her backup singers—a bevy of voices that seem to have fluttered out of a 1930s dish-soap ad—agree
column7: which makes sense because they are also Merrill Garbus.

column1: Her music has always been playful but extremely confident. The product of a liberal liberal-arts education
column2: she has worked as a puppeteer and is often photographed wearing facepaint. At the height of the Occupy movement
column3: she lead audiences from the theater into the street
column4: guerrilla-style
column5: and her music embodies an activist's urgency
column6: filled with sounds that elbow their way to the front in order to be heard. She's an introvert's nightmare
column7: and all she wants is for you to open your heart and sing.

column1: Her third album
column2: Nikki Nack
column3: is more reserved than 2011's w h o k i l l
column4: which isn't saying much. There are still songs that sound like playgrounds full of street kids ricocheting off each other like bumper cars. There are still nursery rhymes about body dysmorphia and white liberal guilt set to what sounds like Coke-bottle percussion from the undiscovered country. But there are also songs like ""Time of Dark"" and ""Look Around""
column5: where Garbus seems to have made a conscious choice to slow down
column6: and in slowing down
column7: lets us see the muscle in her stride. tUnE-yArDs now sound less like buskers outside the neighborhood co-op than some blues-jazz combo from the near-future
column8: severed from the traditions of the music but still somehow in touch with its spirit. (Two of the songs here were produced by Malay
column9: who also worked on Frank Ocean's Channel Orange
column10: and whatever Garbus lacks in marketing appeal to the alt-R&B crowd she makes up for by actually having a powerful voice.)

column1: Subtlety has never been at play for Garbus
column2: who tends to tackle her subject matter like a child after a robotic mole at a carnival game. ""I come from the land of slaves/ Let's go Redskins
column3: let's go Braves!"" she wails on ""Real Thing"". Her world is made up of broad irony and clashing patterns—one whose conflicts are obvious but painfully irresolvable. Earlier
column4: on ""Water Fountain""
column5: there's this vignette: ""I saved up all my pennies and I gave them to this special guy/ When he had enough of them he bought himself a cherry pie/ He gave me a dollar
column6: a blood-soaked dollar/ I cannot get the spot out but it's okay
column7: it still works at the store."" The imagery is violent but the delivery is sweet—then
column8: you remember the cherry pie
column9: red as blood. The most startling moment on w h o k i l l was when Garbus  fantasized about making love to a cop who arrested her brother
column10: then confesses how liberated she feels by violence as the band breaks into an ecstatic calypso.

column1: Nate Brenner reprises his w h o k i l l role here as a bassist
column2: synth player
column3: and co-writer
column4: and the album also features contributions from Roomful of Teeth
column5: a Grammy-winning vocal group who
column6: like Garbus
column7: enjoy doing things with their voices that most people would not classify as singing. But even as Garbus opens up tUnE-yArDs to other collaborators
column8: her albums still appear to be the work of a solitary kid in a basement
column9: jerry-rigging her own fun with the help of imaginary friends. It is private music
column10: splattered outward.

column1: Like Dirty Projectors and St. Vincent
column2: Garbus is an artist who lives with weird but flirts with normal. Gone is the chipper ukulele of w h o k i l l and BiRd-BrAiNs; Nikki Nack signifies maturity while still allowing room for Garbus to do zany things like scat-sing ""One two three o'clock/ Four o'clock
column3: walk and walk and talk and talk and walk and talk and then/ Five
column4: six
column5: seven—seven—seven—heaven—heaven—take me again"" for 90 seconds straight on full tilt. In moments when Garbus does calm down
column6:
she does it with the grace and certainty of an archer drawing back her bow—less a concession than a show of power.

When the Horrors pick lead singles
column4: they don’t bury the lede. Their eight-minute krautrock half-marathon “Sea Within a Sea” boasted affiliations with Portishead’s Geoff Barrow
column5: acclaimed video director Chris Cunningham
column6: and former the Jesus & Mary Chain bassist Douglas Hart. It left no doubt that 2009's Primary Colours intended to erase the memory of the “psychotic sounds for freaks and weirdos” that typified their shlocky shock-goth debut Strange House; two years later
column7: “Still Life” was an obvious tell of the John Hughes-in-IMAX
column8: cloudgazing reveries to come on Skying.

column1: So it goes
column2: then
column3: with ""I See You""
column4: the first glimpse of their fourth LP Luminous: you could spend all seven-and-a-half minutes of thinking of adjectives to describe this dazzling moonshot and still not come up with anything better than “luminous.” But the title of the song is even more telling
column5: considering its likeness to Skying’s second single
column6: “I Can See Through You”
column7: highlighting the biggest obstacle Luminous faces; it's at turns utterly breathtaking and vaguely familiar
column8: but in the end it just sorta sounds like Skying.

column1: The similarities between old and new are disappointing if you value how the Horrors have made radical transformations from album to album. But in the longview
column2: they’ve always been driven by the same instincts and ambitions: regardless of whether they were invoking the Cramps
column3: Can
column4: or the Cure
column5: this is spot-the-reference record collector rock
column6: and Luminous is the first time they haven’t completely ditched the vinyl from their last time out. It’s an incremental move towards the edge of the '90s
column7: where the band slips inside this Hacienda
column8: coloring with sunlight and glowsticks rather than pretty in pink pastels.

column1: Luminous opens with about three minutes of anticipatory electronic murmuring
column2: bongos
column3: and birdcall before “Chasing Shadows” turns on the klieg lights and lets the beat drop for a crowd of thousands who will completely lose their shit. The gleaming acoustic guitar strums that open “First Day of Spring” could’ve been pickpocketed from Happy Mondays during their 24-hour party stupor. This is still music meant for the biggest crowd possible
column4: only now the Horrors sound more suited for the festival grounds rather than a hockey arena.

column1: Still
column2: the Horrors aren’t Madchester purists like Jagwar Ma
column3: or Cut Copy circa Free Your Mind. There’s too much composure in this hardworking
column4: stylized music—the jeans are still black and skinny instead of baggy. It’s Screamadelica dosed on trustworthy hallucinogens
column5: or Pills 'n' Thrills & Bellyaches if we're talking about smooth
column6: green gelcaps rather than hairspray-tasting E tablets. Or
column7: think of the Stone Roses
column8: the outlier of that scene in that they always just seemed like a rock band dabbling in club sounds
column9: utilizing extended guitar codas and the occasional mechanistic thump in the place of actual groove.

column1: In other words
column2: Luminous is Skying with faster tempos
column3: which might only qualify as dance music at ca. 2000 ""Britpop nights"" at American bars
column4: the setting that the Horrors truly belong in. They’re a throwback to the post-Radiohead
column5: studio-nerd likes of Doves or Elbow
column6: acts that attracted Yanks looking towards the UK because those bands seemed more interested in guitar pedals and electronic trickery. It’s easy enough to say Luminous sounds like a million bucks
column7: but that’s not really a figure of speech—just about every moment here gives you an opportunity to itemize the recording budget
column8: from whatever gets the bass on “Jealous Sun” to sound like a steamroller to the battery of guitar pedals that achieve the streaking comet sound of “Mine and Yours” and the quasar swirl of “Falling Star”.

column1: And yet you wonder just how much the actual people in the Horrors have invested themselves in all of this; they come off like a band that wants to play for a stadium full of people that still don’t know the first thing about them. As with Skying
column2: it’s a high compliment to say Luminous is a giant bowl of assorted
column3: premium ear candy
column4: and it’s about as nourishing
column5: which maybe is the point. Faris Badwan’s vocals are perfectly situated within his imperious surroundings—half drama king
column6: half complacent plutocrat—and his lyrics can read like nonsense
column7: sounding like grand proclamations before dissipating completely the moment he moves on to the next thought. Whether it’s the hint of a bizarre love triangle on “Change Your Mind” or seemingly stern repetitions like “So now you know/ Turn away”
column8: nothing really seems like that big of a deal.  They have have mastered their sound and vision
column9: and hopefully they can grow to recognize their heart and soul
column10:
too.

Even by the standards of alt-rap eccentrics
column2: Antwon’s pretty damn protean: a former hardcore kid brought up on boom-bap and pop singers who’ll readily name his new favorite thrash bands after compiling a list of the best Cocteau Twins songs. The San Jose rapper’s unorthodox backstory easily situates him within the broader
column3: border-crossing movement that
column4: thanks to peers like Le1f
column5: Big Baby Ghandi
column6: and Cities Aviv
column7: seeps steadily into hip- hop’s consciousness. “Post-internet” labels aside
column8: it’s easy to see why his two most recent mix tapes
column9: End of Earth and In Dark Denim
column10: were received with enthusiasm: combining vaporwave synths
column11: Death-Grips-style compression
column12: and Biggie worship into a cohesive rap song is hard enough
column13: and tougher still when sex jams are one of your main specialties. Somehow
column14: Antwon pulled it off. On his new album
column15: Heavy Hearted in Doldrums
column16: the rapper constructs his boldest collection yet
column17: grounded in improved production and his characteristic schoolboy wit.

column1: If the album’s mildly redundant title and its po-faced track list don’t make it clear enough
column2: Antwon’s grown sulkier since we last saw him. From the shadowy posturing of “Cold Tears”—this album’s closest thing to a banger—to the molasses-thick
column3: melancholic  “Don’t Care”
column4: Heavy Hearted in Doldrums is often mired in sorrow. But the sadness is ultimately powerless before the rapper’s insatiable libido. In spite of his laments on “Loser” (“I used to have a heart/ It once was filled with love”)
column5: Antwon continues to approach sex with the bushy-tailed perspective of a teenager who’s just been handed his driver’s license. “She bust seven times
column6: made a nigga feel great!” he crows on “Break Yo' Back”
column7: a boast he supports throughout the album with his many
column8: many references to oral sex. Wacky erotic banter remains his biggest strength
column9: fueled by a warmhearted
column10: sex-positive spirit that recalls fellow horn dog Danny Brown
column11: or perhaps
column12: a kinkier Biz Markie. Even when he’s being a creep (“As long as your Dad don’t care/ I’ma run my fingers through your baby hairs”) or indulging his bad habit of running a phrase like “bust in threes” into the ground
column13: you’ve got to admire his originality
column14: not to mention his gusto. At the very least
column15: he’s leagues above the majority of his guests
column16: whose contributions to this album range from tight (Lil Ugly Mane’s crossfaded musings on “Rain Song”) to irremediably tepid (Wiki’s shrill
column17: stilted verse on ""No Metro Nome”).

column1: Heavy Hearted in Doldrums has been billed as Antwon’s first proper “album”
column2: a distinction that translates into some much-needed upgrades in production. Most notably
column3: there’s none of the dodgy mixing that rendered portions of In Dark Denim downright unlistenable. After the cramped sonics of the past
column4: even the first few seconds of the Sean Kemp-produced
column5: “Rain Song” feel overwhelming: a sudden onslaught of ambient nature sounds
column6: cavernous chorals
column7: and somber violins before the bongo beat comes creeping in. When Antwon finally comes in over the primal beat
column8: his voice doesn’t have to fight for space
column9: so even a stale hook like “She’s got me up all night doing that rain dance” gets a vital dose of immediacy.

column1: That’s not to say the mix is immaculate. It suffers from a serious dearth of bass
column2: and frequently overemphasizes their weaker aspects
column3: like the cheap synths that drive  “Mr. Intercontinental”. “KLF ELF”
column4: the worst offender in this regard
column5: includes a refreshingly ribald guest verse from Das Racist’s Heems that packs in a reference to Olivia Benson from “Law and Order: SVU”
column6: but it’s hard to appreciate the rapper’s wit when he’s muffled by Pictureplane’s blaring calisthenics jams. Were this another run-of-the-mill mixtape
column7: these flaws could easily be overlooked. But considering the fact that Heavy Hearted in Doldrums was funded by a clothing company that charges upwards of 50 bucks for a faux-distressed t-shirt
column8: one would think there’d be fewer duds.

column1: Last summer
column2: Antwon crossed paths with Deafheaven guitarist Kerry McCoy for a washed-out remix of In Dark Denim’s title track
column3: hinting at a possible new scheme through which his two selves
column4: Crusthead and Biz Markie .gif incarnate
column5: could be joined in anguish. Instead of putting these new configurations to the test
column6: Heavy Hearted in Doldrums tinkers with the made-in-the-‘90s blueprint he’s been using from the start
column7: with solid and safe results. That framework suits the rapper just fine
column8: but listening to this album
column9:
you can’t help but wish for his dirty genius to fester into something fiercer.

In spite of their best efforts
column2: Young Magic managed to distinguish themselves from their peers in 2012. Considering the nondescript name
column3: the album title of their debut Melt
column4: and its smeared cover art
column5: the duo of Isaac Emmanuel and Melati Malay appeared hellbent on confirming presumptions of them as another post-chillwave purveyor of amorphous
column6: watercolor synth-and-sample ambience. Most of Melt turned out to be just that
column7: except all that all tidal ebb and flow crested into huge
column8: crashing singles “Night in the Ocean” and “You With Air”— the latter of which got a high-profile boost when Purity Ring interpolated it into “Grandloves” later that year on their hit LP Shrines. Their most accessible songs were the ones that made people take interest
column9: and you'd think that wouldn't be lost on the duo. But on their new album Breathing Statues
column10: they’re every bit as intent on blending in with the surrounding scenery instead of standing out. This time
column11: they’re far more successful.

column1: As with Melt
column2: the intercontinental incubation period of Breathing Statues is the main talking point—before finishing the album in New York
column3: Young Magic recorded in places such as Morocco
column4: France
column5: and New Zealand. And yet
column6: regardless of the passport stamps and frequent flier mileage the Aussie/Indonesian duo accumulated
column7: Breathing Statues could've come from just about any MPC-masher who spent the past two years living in the Twittersphere. Similar to hundreds of likeminded acts with hazy sonics
column8: hazy boundaries between “producer” and “band
column9: ” and a desire to still operate under the tag of “indie
column10: ” Young Magic’s taken a decidedly darker
column11: more coldly minimal tack since 2012—lurching bass
column12: ice-grilled snares

column1: But there's never a sense of the artistic process

column3: or internal inspiration that went into Breathing Statues. The band's new tricks resemble updated software—patches being dragged and clicked onto a horizontal timeline. The woofer-blowing bass judder that opens “Cobra” makes for an intriguing start
column4: but then Young Magic let the figure carry the entire four minutes by itself. A similar effect happens with “Foxglove”
column5: which features the kind of vacuum-packed
column6: freeze-dried synth tones that lets you know they’ve shared their colleagues' fixation on the idea of listening to Sade
column7: or most likely
column8: Rhye—but there’s no heat being generated underneath. Meanwhile
column9: the screwed moans of “Mythnomer” are the only reminder that Emmanuel sorta-kinda rapped on Melt
column10: and subsequently Breathing Statues could've used anything on that questionable element's level of generating tension with Malay’s airy
column11: anonymous breath-sing.

column1: Nothing here bears the strain of overzealous ambition
column2: there are no flubbed notes
column3: unseemly textures
column4: unfortunate lyrical ideas; everything positive or negative about Breathing Statues is simply too ephemeral to make a fuss about. It's an album of which the main purpose is to take up space
column5: whether it’s in a retail setting

column7: or as news fodder for content-hungry websites and as raw materials for their friends to remix. Even if I can’t imagine anyone outside those realms being excited about Breathing Statues

it completely justifies its existence as a record that aspires to exist as content.

If you’re going to talk about Wold
column3: you’re probably not going to speak of melodies. For more than a decade
column4: the deliberately enigmatic
column5: incredibly abrasive project has cloaked black metal beats and screams and maniacal guitar playing in a dynamic web of harsh noise and electronic contortion. At first
column6: the result might sound slipshod and spontaneous
column7: the result of an anti-production that captures performances of proper
column8: discrete songs and turns them into messy
column9: unidentifiable jumbles. But Wold’s best work is the product of fastidious and hostile arrangement
column10: where those layers of song and manipulation move in forever-unsettled patterns. Finding the tune or even the rhyme and reason within a Wold cut suggests watching a ghost emerge from the fog: The eyes strain against an inscrutable background and slowly spot unexpected shapes
column11: while the brain constantly second-guesses the detective work. It’s this daunting game—and Wold’s power over it—that makes the project’s albums so compelling
column12: not the refrains.

column1: But the centerpiece of Postsocial
column2: Wold’s seventh album and second since the act relocated from Saskatchewan to Rhode Island
column3: is actually an identifiable hook. Surrounded on all sides by chirping and choking noise near the start of “Five Points
column4: ” Wold leader Fortress Crookedjaw shouts the title itself 10 times (or rather
column5: in two sets of five times
column6: he might prefer). In the willfully obscure world of Wold
column7: it is an absolutely lucid proclamation
column8: decipherable even without the aid of a lyric sheet. During the next 10 minutes
column9: Wold pushes ahead with usual ferocity. A thrashing guitar riff fights against the blanket of static beneath it
column10: and Crookedjaw’s increasingly beleaguered bleat soon battles them both. The tumult rises so that
column11: by the six-minute mark
column12: his words have become mostly indecipherable ruminations on and symbolic explorations of Masonic structures
column13: an extension of the content from their 2012 masterpiece Freermasonry. But when Crookedjaw returns to the refrain
column14: he again powers through the melee with two more sets of five proclamations—“Five points/five points…”—after the song’s verses. He peaks above his own machine’s power. Yes
column15: “Five Points” is a squall of explosive sound and sustained noise
column16: but it’s also a song with a perceptible chorus-verse-chorus-verse-chorus structure
column17: so long as you’re willing to peer through the fog to find it.

column1: “Five Points” might sound like a pretty wretched formula for a pop tune—bury everything until all that remains is some phantom of a refrain—but in all of Wold’s output
column2: it is perhaps the clearest illustration of the finesse that empties into this incorrigible belligerence. In fact
column3: the bulk of Postsocial pulls back the electrostatic drapes a bit more than its predecessors
column4: allowing the cores beneath the clamor to resonate a bit more readily. Opener “Throwing Star
column5: ” for instance
column6: suggests a violent hardcore romp played by a boombox that’s been sealed inside a plastic barrel and tossed down a metallic staircase. But get past the bedlam
column7: and listen to the levels shift. “Throwing Star” feels alternately like a no-low-end void and
column8: in spots
column9: like a recording session where the only fully functional microphone was attached to the bass amplifier.

column1: Such amoeboid acoustics are Wold’s best trick. “Spiral Star Inversion” might seem to follow a less-identifiable path
column2: as there are no rhythms underpinning it and no refrains anchoring it; instead
column3: Crookedjaw divides five stanzas of a prurient poem about ghoulish copulation across 14 minutes
column4: making it the longest piece in Wold’s oeuvre. It straddles the divide between being brutal and beautiful
column5: and the latter word is rarely associated with Wold. It’s still unforgiving music
column6: laced with electronic samples that suggest metal scraped and stabbed against metal and crackling with a static that seems to come from a cesspool of Rice Krispies wired with contact microphones (think the Dead C at their most vile) but a gigantic two-tone pulse lingers just beneath the mess
column7: glowing like the more radiant music of Tim Hecker. The track is a wonderland of control
column8: a series of musical mirages nested inside one another
column9: testing the borders between punishment and relaxation.

column1: With Wold
column2: all of these qualities or components—beauty
column3: hooks
column4: refrains
column5: rhythms—are necessarily relative. Though moments on both Freermasonry and Postsocial offer more points of entry into their cloaked
column6: claustrophobic universe than previous records
column7: Wold remains some of the moment’s most brittle and confrontational fare. And there’s an absurdist foundation beneath it all
column8: of course
column9: with interpretations of secret Masonic rites hurled against a barely buttressed oblivion by someone who calls himself Fortress Crookedjaw. Not unlike those Masons
column10: though
column11: there is endless intrigue just past the surface
column12: as Wold continues to raise more questions than their music would ever dare to answer. Even when the hook stands out against the din
column13: as it does at the middle of Postsocial
column14: Wold delivers a disorienting mix of power and poise
column15:
thickly veiled and wonderfully bewildering.

If you’re unsure of why Lykke Li named her third album I Never Learn
column3: the last four songs leave nothing to the imagination: “Love Me Like I’m Not Made of Stone”
column4: “Never Gonna Love Again”
column5: “Heart of Steel”
column6: “Sleeping Alone”. The titles alone feel like disclaimers—are you willing to live life on these terms? It's worth noting
column7: then
column8: that Lykke Li moved over 5
column9: 400 miles from her native Sweden to Los Angeles at the age of 28 after the most painful breakup of her life. It hardly matters that almost none of us will experience anything like that; what is important is that many of us have endured the kind of heartbreak that made it feel like your old self is halfway across the planet. But if you’ve ever just secretly hoped your life could inspire such romantic ideals of romantic failure
column10: wish fulfillment doesn’t come more potent than I Never Learn.

column1: I Never Learn is both spartan and expansive; it's Li’s most ambitious and shortest album
column2: at nine songs and 33 minutes. This is widescreen drama meant to hit with direct and precise impact
column3: so the operative term for advance singles “No Rest For the Wicked” and “Love Me Like I’m Not Made of Stone” has been “Spector-esque.” It's a fair comparison
column4: as Li plays a winner-take-all game of “He loves me
column5: he loves me not” accompanied by a host of string players and drums that beat and thump like a flawed human heart. Li relies on classic emotive archetypes as well—excepting “I Will Always Love You”
column6: torch songs don’t get much more literal than “Never Gonna Love Again”
column7: and as with most of I Never Learn
column8: its incapacitating sense of impending emptiness is closer in spirit to “I Have Nothing”.

column1: The power ballads are just what the tag implies: ballads that require an enormous amount of exertion and are about power itself
column2: whether it’s helplessly putting in the hands of another (“Love Me Like I’m Not Made of Stone”)
column3: taking ownership of your culpability (“No Rest For the Wicked”)
column4: or watching it disappear in a moment of passion (“Gunshot”). Rather than evoking a specific decade of music
column5: though
column6: Li approaches this style of songwriting as musical theater that should be created by something other than a proper band—either by professionals just off-screen
column7: or some kind of studio magic.

column1: I Never Learn utilizes the simplest tools of confessional songwriting: uneasily strummed acoustic guitars and resonant piano chords enlarged for texture and dramatic flair
column2: like they’re appearing from behind a just-raised curtain
column3: or from a radio as you sing to yourself. Thanks to the cavernous production
column4: the enduring mental image of I Never Learn isn’t Li slumping over a glass of whiskey
column5: but rather letting fresh wounds breathe
column6: soundchecking alone in an empty arena.

column1: Note the word “arena”
column2: because even if these are stark
column3: personal songs

column7: dead serious
column8: striking cover shot of I Never Learn isn’t fronting on you; Li hangs around David Lynch
column9: collaborates with A$AP Rocky and admires Beyoncé
column10: Drake
column11: and Rihanna
column12: all of whom commingle celebrity and artistry to serve as avatars
column13: people through whom we can imagine how our idealized selves might sing
column14: dress
column15: fuck
column16: or hurt.

column1: Li is not a tabloid fixture nor a force of nature
column2: and I Never Learn takes advantage of that by emphasizing the rawness of her lower registers and utilizing negative space to keep things from getting too far out of proportion. At times
column3: the record resembles a pocket version of Adele’s eternal 21. Yes
column4: “Love Me Not I’m Not Made of Stone” does American teenagers a disservice by showing up a couple weeks late for prom season
column5: but right when Li chokes on the line
column6: “Even though it….hurts
column7: ” she negates any idea of this being makeout music; it’s more like getting told ""let's be friends"" in the middle of a slow dance.

column1: The artillery-riddled
column2: burnished metal of “Gunshot” was helmed by Greg Kurstin
column3: best known as a collaborator of P!nk
column4: Kelly Clarkson and Katy Perry—but he’s also the guy who produced Tegan & Sara’s Heartthrob
column5: another record that commingled teenaged emotions with adult situations and vice versa while nudging a beloved
column6: modest act in a way that led to a polished
column7: radio-ready album that reflected their real-life popularity.

column1: “Gunshot” is I Never Learn’s fist-pumping climax and a total outlier

column3: his trademark
column4: treble-harshed reverb making each lovelorn lullaby sound like it’s smeared with Li's own tears and ruined makeup. That lends a crucial
column5: tactile reality in Li's sadness
column6: since very few of her lyrics are going to remind people of things their significant others have actually said to them—“Every time the rain falls
column7: think of me.”  “Baby wait a lifetime before you find somebody new”
column8: “Every time I pay the price for a heart that can’t be broken.” Maybe you've thought these things
column9: and hearing them out in the open ensures I Never Learn isn’t an admission of defeat; there’s an unspoken uplift to be had

column11: whereas the gospel choir does the same with “Heart of Steel”
column12: either taunts or acceptance of a fate where grand

column14:
but I Never Learn is for the times when heartbreak is so life-affirming that you want to share the feeling with the world.
