Brian Eno is rarely idle. In 1996 he published a book titled A Year With Swollen Appendices
column2: which detailed his extraordinary life over a 12-month span. Even his quiet days
column3: it seems
column4: have some sense of purpose to them. For the book's September 25 entry<i>
column5: he doesn’t do much at all
column6: aside from noting two phone calls that came through: one from David Bowie
column7: the other from Paul McCartney. Although much has surely changed since then
column8: his workrate hasn’t dipped
column9: and the albums keep coming. His latest
column10: Someday World
column11: is a collaboration with Underworld’s Karl Hyde
column12: and
column13: like much of Eno’s recent output
column14: it’s released by Warp. Eno hasn't exactly given this album the hard sell
column15: instead presenting it as a collection of half-thoughts he tried to salvage after browsing through a stray hard drive one afternoon. “I had a big collection of 'beginnings' sitting around waiting for something to galvanise them into life
column16: to make them more than just 'experiments
column17: '"" he said in advance of the album's release.

column1: So Someday World may not be built on the most exciting premise
column2: but even Eno’s malformed thoughts are usually worth a look
column3: or a listen
column4: or a read
column5: depending on which medium he’s currently working in. Here
column6: he brings in a group of collaborators alongside Hyde
column7: including familiar accomplices (Roxy Music’s Andy Mackay
column8: Coldplay’s Will Champion)
column9: a family member (his daughter
column10: Darla Eno)
column11: and a co-producer in his early twenties (Fred Gibson). It sounds expensive
column12: in the way that Eno’s production for Coldplay or U2 often does
column13: although with less obvious ambition beyond being an outlet for a group of people to work in ways they perhaps haven’t before. There’s form and structure
column14: although whether it was always there or devised after the fact is difficult to discern. As Someday World progresses
column15: it gradually falls into that bracket of projects that were probably much more fun to record than they are to listen to.

column1: Eno talked about how we are “deep in the grid period of making music” in reference to computer-based composition in 2010
column2: and that's the place this album is rigidly stuck in. There’s no looseness here
column3: very little space to move around in. The mode is largely set to “pop” throughout
column4: but only in the sense that Eno and Hyde are reaching for catchy
column5: polished rhythms. Strangely
column6: for someone so reticent to expand on his past
column7: it’s a resolutely backward looking work by Eno’s standards. Everything feels a little old
column8: including the jungle-lite drums (“Daddy’s Car”)
column9: nods to '90s electronica (“When I Built This World”)
column10: and the creeping fear of Blur’s 13 (“Mother of a Dog”).

column1: It doesn’t help that Hyde sounds particularly uninspired
column2: only finding function on the obvious standout tracks (“Daddy’s Car”
column3: “Who Rings the Bell”). The deliberate strain in his voice grates by the time track nine comes around
column4: sounding like years of coasting through unremarkable Underworld albums like Barking has taken its toll. It may have been difficult for Hyde to find a way in here—the precision-tooled arrangements don’t often open up much room for him
column5: leaving him stranded somewhere above the music but never fully immersed in it. He’s more observer than participant
column6: letting a watching-the-world-go-by glassiness settle in as his vocals take a distinct back seat to the studio trickery.

column1: The record runs out of steam around “Witness”
column2: where a deadpan Miss Kittin-style female vocal is threaded over the top. (Thankfully
column3: it exits just as the ghosts of electroclash’s past are whipping at Eno and Hyde's ankles.) Someday World is well arranged
column4: meticulously produced
column5: even catchy at times. But there’s an overriding sense of aimlessness
column6: of people just dropping by the studio and breezing into the songs before wafting off to a more important appointment. For an Eno work
column7:
it’s disappointingly lacking in direction.

column3: Fujiya & Miyagi seemed fresh and cool. Stitching together lush synths and rigid
column4: springy beat programs with thin golden wires of electric guitar
column5: they made electro-pop feel metropolitan
column6: dislocated and somewhat detached from human affairs—qualities embodied in David Best's aloof vocals and the smoothly machined forms they nestled into. Their music descended from 1970s German experimentalism at a time when krautrock hadn't yet become a common influence in indie music.

column1: If Fujiya & Miyagi started out ahead of a trend curve
column2: they sounded increasingly commonplace over the intervening years
column3: and at this point they’re the ones rushing to catch up. On new album Artificial Sweeteners
column4: they inject their mannered krautrock with an energizing dose of techno
column5: a shift ostensibly executed to propel them into contemporary relevance. The shift is immediately noticeable on opening track ""Flaws""
column6: where a melting haze of kosmische ambiance and a rounded
column7: lockstep bass that could have come from any of their albums accelerates towards a thrumming dance arpeggio that could only have come from this one. It's a neat
column8: good-humored way for the band to spoof its own trajectory.

column1: Throughout the record
column2: Fujiya & Miyagi prove adept at fitting together sequences at higher BPMs
column3: twiddling knobs
column4: triggering gates
column5: and tailoring filters to make the music dynamically slingshot around tight corners. But none of that saves the record from feeling rather stale—even anonymous—in a musical climate that's currently awash in such stuff. The productions can be deft and exciting
column6: with a wide variety of timbres smartly meshed to distinguish the otherwise cookie-cutter tracks.

column1: But the vocal performances are flat and tiresome
column2: offering a wan surface for emotional connection—which is problematic now that the music has leaned away from sculptural forms and toward a more kinetic
column3: direct
column4: and engaging style. Best seemingly aims for louche in his delivery but stops short at toneless and
column5: at times
column6: downright silly
column7: with faux-dramatic whispers as the rare source of variation in his gray mutterings. The band excels when the singer gets out of its way
column8: as on ""Rayleigh Scattering""
column9: a tensely scudding mini-odyssey that lofts and dips on powerful bass currents
column10: where the lead synth melody is more eloquent than the cipher-like lyrics that resemble Matthew Dear doing Dr. Seuss.

column1: The slit-eyed vocals
column2: dance beats
column3: and funk guitars of Artificial Sweeteners bear a strong resemblance to !!!
column4: another band that started off fresh but then got stale as the culture it was once at the vanguard of caught up with and
column5: eventually
column6: lapped it. Similarly
column7: Fujiya & Miyagi have skill as producers but
column8: at this point
column9: they don't have much to say. Artificial Sweeteners certainly isn't a terrible album
column10: and it does the trick if you're just looking for a quick pick-me-up
column11:
but it leaves a bland aftertaste.

Jason Quever has been writing and recording as Papercuts for well over a decade at this point
column4: fleshing out his take on the last 50 years of oft-dreamy
column5: pillow-soft pop-rock. His gaze spans from the Velvet Underground to contemporaries like Grizzly Bear and Beach House—the latter’s guitarist
column6: Alex Scally
column7: is an occasional collaborator—and he filters the sounds of these groups using his voice
column8: a woolly and versatile instrument that moves from breathy melancholy to a lapsed choirboy falsetto with ease. Quever’s new full-length
column9: Life Among the Savages
column10: places a spotlight on his skills as a producer and arranger playing with several new variations on his warm
column11: woodsy music.

column1: From a production standpoint
column2: Life Among the Savages sounds consistently strong
column3: even when songs swell to accommodate Quever's dense arrangements. The album was mostly recorded in his San Francisco home studio
column4: so comfort and familiarity clearly informs its bright sound. The record is an easy
column5: pleasant listen
column6: but it's not particularly compelling as a whole
column7: occasionally falling into a pattern of contented stuffiness. Quever can't always cut through the light fog of his arrangements with his gentle
column8: fuzzy vocal takes
column9: so he has to rely on the strength of his melodies and arrangements to keep songs from turning soporific.

column1: After a baroque opening third
column2: the record starts to wake up on ""Staring at the Bright Lights""
column3: where Quever lays down a distant
column4: ringing guitar line that corrodes and sparks as the song unfolds. The song sounds a little like the luminous
column5: spacious guitar pop of Deerhunter guitarist Lockett Pundt's Lotus Plaza project
column6: a welcome change from the album's more uptight moments. Strong guitar leads factor in Life Among the Savages' finest moments: the dusty
column7: late-1960s ramble of ""Family Portrait""
column8: the knotty patterns of ""Psychic Friends"".

column1: Just as Quever's music consciously roots itself in time-honored pop and folk traditions
column2: his lyrics are imbued with a similar sense of setting: he makes note of times and places—""Psychic Friends"" finds him cataloging memories against the backdrop of a chilly winter equinox—and uses natural imagery well
column3: like the wilderness detailing of ""Afterlife Blues."" There's also a palpable sadness often hanging around Quever's writing
column4: an off-kilter sense of dread; on tracks like ""New Body"" and ""Family Portrait
column5: that sense works against the songs' musical lightness
column6:
creating intriguing tension. That valuable tension is just another expression of the truth that lurks in the background throughout Life Among the Savages: Quever realizes his true potential when he eschews easy comfort and warmth to introduce elements that are a little more challenging.

As the story goes
column2: Wussy formed in Cincinnati in 2001 when former Ass Ponys frontman Chuck Cleaver wanted to play some solo shows but was too scared to play material on his own
column3: so he recruited Lisa Walker to sing and play guitar with him. It worked so well they kept it up and began writing songs together
column4: eventually forming a full band with Mark Messerly (bass) and Joe Klug (Wussy’s second drummer). For Attica!
column5: Wussy also brought pedal-steel player and former Ass Pony John Erhardt into the fold.

column1: Wussy is quintessentially Midwestern. It’s hard to imagine their sincere
column2: blue-collar
column3: decidedly untrendy songs coming from either coast. The band doesn’t hesitate to borrow some alt-country sounds from Cleaver’s days in the Ass Ponys
column4: but even with that pedal steel there’s nothing Southern about Wussy. They sound like a band from the early- to mid-’90s
column5: but they’re not overly grungy
column6: and you can’t really fold them in with much of the college rock from that decade
column7: either. There are big hooks
column8: drones
column9: acoustic instruments
column10: mellotron
column11:
fuzz. Wussy is familiar yet wonderfully uncategorizable. It’s the sound you’d hope would result from a grizzly stonemason now in his mid-’50s recruiting a woman almost 20 years younger to not just accompany but co-lead a band of fellow Ohioans who love rock that pops.

Buckeye
column12: a compilation released on UK label Damnably in 2012
column13: collected 17 of Wussy’s greatest hits that never were from previous albums. It’s a good place to start for newbies
column14: but Attica! is a perfectly fine entry point
column15: as well; Walker and Cleaver get an equal shake on just about every release. It’s surprisingly rare to hear arguments about who’s the greater or preferred Wussy warbler. Walker’s range and clarity would win in a reality show sing-off
column16: but the two voices have a lot in common. They share a rumpled desperation that somehow never sounds resigned
column17:
kicking hard enough to keep ever-encroaching despair from taking over completely.

Attica!—Wussy’s fifth album of new material if you don’t count 2011’s Funeral Dress II
column18: an acoustic reworking of 2005 debut Funeral Dress—is a nostalgic record
column19: and not just because of that vaguely ’90s sound. It’s an album about growing up and remembering and
column20: of course
column21: the relationships that accompany those remembrances. (It seems worth noting that Cleaver and Walker were in a long-term
column22: tempestuous romantic relationship in the not too distant past.) The album showcases everything Wussy is good at
column23:
particularly the band’s portrayal of their fractured homeland. You can see it vividly in the broken-down Pontiacs and frozen lakes and women too poor to take the pill and street drinking and house fires started by cigarettes.

If a song title like “Rainbows and Butterflies” brings to mind Owl City or Lisa Frank
column25: which deconstruct slightly as they go
column27: providing a dark backdrop to Cleaver’s couplets that start off troubling (“I’m gonna kill you…”) and resolve as lovey-dovey promises (“...with goodness and light”). It’s something Wussy does all over Attica!
column28: and what they’ve always done. Cleaver and Walker like to set up a lyric in a way you think you know where it’s going right before it goes somewhere else entirely. “I’m not the monster that I once was/ 20 years ago I was more beautiful than I am today
column29: ” they sing in unison on anthemic closing track “Beautiful.” (The song’s two-chord progression bears a strong resemblance to “Little Paper Birds
column30:
” leadoff track on Wussy’s self-titled 2009 album.) The refrain repeats until you start to realize what’s beautiful to Wussy and what’s not.

Even with a minute-long instrumental outro
column32: ending before the 4:30 mark. Wussy songs tend to be that way—compact packages with maximum singability and staying power squeezed into minimal space. Sometimes the songs can feel too tight
column33: if that’s even a thing. When I saw Wussy play “Beautiful” at last year’s Nelsonville Music Festival
column34: they stretched out the ending until the seams frayed; the mantra-like chorus
column35: drone-fuzz guitars and strummed bass erupted like a lost Yo La Tengo outtake. Perhaps “Beautiful” was destined to be more taut when put to tape
column36:
but there’s some unspent potential energy in the Attica! version’s coda.

Walker pays homage to the Who in first track “Teenage Wasteland""
column37: a pop song that rivals its namesake. She references “Baba O’Riley” and the band’s legendarily explosive Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour performance (“When the kick of the drum went off like artillery fire”)
column38: but it’s less about classic-rock head nods and double entendres and more about capturing what it’s like to be a kid and finding a band you connect with on the deepest level imaginable. “Do you remember the moment you finally did something about it? When the kick of the drum lined up with the beat of your heart?” Walker asks at the top of the song. Then
column39: at the end of the song—sounding as if she can’t contain the exhilaration—she describes the feeling in more detail: “For one short breath it sounds like the world is ending
column40: exploding in space and beginning again so far away.” It’s the moment that turns suffering into transcendence because someone else feels the way you do
column41: and that person felt compelled to translate it into music. I’d argue that’s what we’re looking for most of the time when we listen to music—that band or album or song or even a few notes that make us marvel and proclaim
column43:
“Your misery sounds so much like ours.” At Wussy’s best—and Attica! is pretty close to that—they’re capable of doing for us what Pete and Roger and Keith and John did for them.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20504/homepage_large.661d1953.jpg|A Letter Home|4693.0|Neil Young|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Third Man']|2014-05-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:38:15.605076|"

Neil Young has spent the past few months making moves on something he's been passionately preaching about for a while now: studio-quality audio made accessible to the masses. From the looks of things
column2: Pono seems to be the most practical application of Young's audio purism to date. He's been a loud critic of the mp3 and digital audio degradation for years
column3: and he's embraced expensive and clunky listening formats to ensure that listeners are getting the best possible sound quality. His public persona in recent months has been that of ""expert audio purist""—decrying ""underwater listening"" behind a desk
column4: driving record executive Mo Ostin around to show off the capabilities of his new format
column5: and so forth.

column1: So what's the first album Young puts out after raising $6.2 million for Pono on Kickstarter? A sepia-toned long-player with a sound that would sit comfortably next to late 1920s Jimmie Rodgers or Carter Family records. In fact
column2: the sonic quality of Young's latest
column3: A Letter Home
column4: might be a little worse than its spiritual forebears: Young joined Jack White at his Third Man HQ in Nashville
column5: where he posted up in a 1940s phone-booth-size studio with limited resources—his acoustic guitar
column6: a harmonica
column7: a piano
column8: and White—to record a handful of covers direct to vinyl. It's pretty much the sonic opposite of
column9: say
column10: his early collaborations with Jack Nitzsche. You can hear the continuous scrape of the grooves
column11: pops
column12: and momentary warps—tiny flaw after tiny flaw. Vintage-sounding and created using White's toys
column13: it has all the appearance of a record featuring the guy who encased Paramount's archives in an oak cabinet and gussied up old Charley Patton records.

column1: Young introduces the album with a letter to his dead mother
column2: telling her that she should talk to his dad (his parents divorced in 1961)
column3: asking her to relay a message to his late bandmate Ben Keith
column4: and telling her about how the public turns on <a href=""http://www.algore.com/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Al
column5: the weatherman. It's a sweet
column6: absurd bit of business that vaguely recalls his sense of humor from Human Highway
column7: and it frames the album as a care package to the afterworld
column8: with songs and messages sounding like they're being transmitted via string-connected aluminum cans. This context renders his subsequent performance of Phil Ochs' ""Changes"" heart-wrenching. His voice is quiet
column9: his guitar is strummed tenderly
column10: the song he sings is about aging and loss. ""Your tears will be trembling
column11: now we're somewhere else
column12: one last cup of wine we'll pour/ And I'll kiss you one more time
column13: and leave you on the rolling river shores of changes."" At one point in the song
column14: he misses a chord change
column15: which makes the performance feel incredibly human. After all
column16: this is Neil Young
column17: who's got an entire discography of impeccably recorded material. Those small flubs are like scratched out words on a page
column18: and they make the record feel much more intimate.

column1: For an album recorded primitively inside a Nashville box
column2: there are some stunning performances on A Letter Home. The strongest moments on the album are the most delicate ones
column3: which shouldn't come as a surprise for anyone who's spent any time with ""Ambulance Blues"" or Live at Canterbury House. The restrained material is also better suited for this recording format. His stripped down readings of Gordon Lightfoot's ""If You Could Read My Mind"" and ""Early Morning Rain"" pares both songs back to their essentials—beautifully delivered acoustic rambles about being a long way from home and a pained look back at a relationship. On one of his two duets with White
column4: a version of the Everly Brothers' ""I Wonder if I Care as Much"" that closes the album
column5: their voices sound completely gorgeous together and neither White nor Young showboats. It's a loving
column6: simple
column7: well-done tribute.

column1: Occasionally
column2: though
column3: the recording quality distracts from the album's content. Young's cover of Tim Hardin's ""Reason to Believe"" is partially blown by warped sound to the point where the original version sounds more assertive and fully realized than Neil's cover. Occasionally
column4: Young will blow the harmonica too hard and temporarily mar every other sound; elsewhere
column5: he covers songs that flat-out sound bad in the audio format they're presented in. ""Since I Met You Baby"" is an unessential
column6: bleary version of Ivory Joe Hunter's velvet R&B original
column7: while ""My Hometown""
column8: removed from the production of Born in the U.S.A.
column9: is repetitive and a bad fit for Young's voice. The cover of ""On the Road Again"" is just a slapdash mess; White's vocals somehow sound abrasive
column10: and similar to the Springsteen cover
column11: Neil's voice just isn't well-suited to tackle Willie Nelson's register.

column1: Young said the songs he picked to cover were ""songs that I love
column2: songs that changed my life
column3: and said behind the archaic recording quality was some ""beautiful music"". There's nothing more beautiful or potentially life-changing on A Letter Home than his take on Bert Jansch's ""Needle of Death"". It's a gorgeous
column4: heartbreaking song about a heroin overdose—it's devastating and beautiful coming from Young
column5: a longtime Jansch disciple who also lost friends to the needle (and wrote some of his best songs about it).

column1: There's a video of Young performing the song
column2: and at the end
column3: White comes up and says
column4: ""That sounded good."" Young replies
column5: ""That's a heavy song."" He wasn't focused on how it sounded—he was thinking about what he was singing. In that way
column6: A Letter Home doesn't contradict his work on Pono. Both projects
column7: different as they are
column8: stem from his deep love for the material. If anything
column9:
the crackling whistle that introduces ""Needle of Death"" speaks much more strongly to the life-changing power of music than any extra-musical project ever could.

Calgary songwriter Chad VanGaalen has a complicated relationship with beauty. In 2011
column3: he made what I thought was one of the loveliest indie-rock records of the year
column4: but I had a lot of trouble convincing other people of that fact
column5: because he decided to call the damn thing Diaper Island. (Its most tender ballad? Well that would be ""Shave My Pussy""
column6: of course.) As a visual artist
column7: VanGaalen dabbles in various mediums; he's made animated videos
column8: fantastical figurines and a conceptual piece that was
column9: according to a press release
column10: ""a literal piece of shit in a hot dog bun."" Recently
column11: he began posting on his Instagram whimsical drawings he had etched into snow: Here is a cute dinosaur
column12: a tugboat
column13: and what appears to be a self-portrait. It was only after I'd admired a couple of them that I realized they were made out of pee.

column1: But if everything VanGaalen touches seems to have a repellant
column2: piss-pungent weirdness about it
column3: that's kind of a ruse—his records of jangly junkyard-pop are warm
column4: inviting
column5: and surprisingly easy to love. His latest
column6: Shrink Dust
column7: is possibly his best
column8: and certainly his most confident. These songs are gentle
column9: sad
column10: and just bizarre enough. (There's a streak of Cronenberg-ian body horror throughout
column11: and it begins playfully unsettling image: ""Cut off both my hands and threw them in the sand/ Watch them swim away from me like a pair of bloody crabs"".) VanGaalen's called Shrink Dust his country record because it's his first where he makes use of a recently acquired pedal steel
column12: but some of the quieter songs also feature the lonely-cricket chirps of a mouth bow that remind me of Leonard Cohen's Songs from a Room. Like that record
column13: Shrink Dust has a slow
column14: steady trot—like an eccentric stranger rolling into town on horseback
column15: bemused but also made lonely by the vivid visions in his head.

column1: VanGaalen records by himself at home
column2: in a space that's equal parts garage studio and wacky inventor's laboratory. He creates a lot of his own instruments from scratch: a two-person thumb piano; a narrow
column3: portable harp; an analog drum machine that is dotted with Legos and looks more like a middle school science fair project than a rock instrument. Triggered by foot pedals or whirring by themselves with built-in motors
column4: most of these jerry-rigged contraptions are designed to help VanGaalen act in the studio as a one-man band
column5: but they also give his songs a homemade feel. Like all of his records (including the two he produced for the great
column6: defunct Calgary art-rockers Women)
column7: Shrink Dust is full of varied
column8: ramshackle textures. Spacey lead-off single ""Where Are You?"" rumbles like rickety spaceship
column9: its hollered title lyric echoing and warping through an unfamiliar atmosphere on its way back to earth. A gorgeous and languid love song in the vein of Diaper Island's ""Sara""
column10: ""Lila"" sounds like a crooner's ballad dissolving in a murky pond
column11: with all the scummy creatures popping up to harmonize with VanGaalen on the surprisingly stirring chorus.

column1: ""I started out just experimenting with more… sound-scapey
column2: ambient sort of experimental music
column3: VanGaalen said in an interview a few years ago. ""The songs weren't really what I was concentrating on."" Since his 2004 debut Infiniheart
column4: though
column5: VanGaalen has moved towards uniting those ""song"" and ""soundscape"" tendencies with increasing seamlessness. For all its cosmic-cowboy vibes
column6: Shrink Dust contains some of the catchiest and most assured hooks he's written yet—many of which are just a single word or phrase (""Evil""
column7: ""Monster""
column8: ""Lila"") that's been taffy-pulled into a graceful and memorable melody. Occasionally
column9: as on the rather aimless ""Weird Love""
column10: things get a little too plainspoken and laid back
column11: but the psych-pop tune ""Leaning on Bells"" wakes up the back half of the record with a satisfying jolt of electricity.

column1: In the middle of Shrink Dust
column2: there's an upbeat folk-pop song called ""Monster""
column3: which describes in vivid detail a Gregor Samsa/Teen Wolf-esque metamorphosis of man into beast: The singer suddenly sprouts quills
column4: his skin turns ""scaly and yellowish brown""
column5: his fingers wither away only to be replaced by claws. It's one of the creepiest-ever conceits for a jangly pop song
column6: but there's also something cool—and quintessentially Chad VanGaalen—about it. It's like watching one of his surreal claymation creatures
column7: odd drawings
column8: or Frankenstein-esque instruments come together in real time. Chad VanGaalen's world is weird
column9: but never just for weird's sake—his creations spring from deep inside the singular
column10: twisted mind of their creator
column11:
and Shrink Dust is the closest we've come yet to getting inside his head.

"|19226.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19226-chad-vangaalen-shrink-dust/|7.8|Lindsay Zoladz

Of all the obscure indie-rock bands to surface during the 1990s
column3: few were as curious or as obscure as Silkworm. Formed in the late 80s in Missoula
column4: Montana
column5: when some of its members were still teenagers
column6: the band relocated to Seattle just in time for the marketing bonanza known as grunge
column7: an invented genre that still somehow couldn't stretch to contain them. Like a lot their peers—including Pavement
column8: Archers of Loaf
column9: and a half-dozen other artists cresting on Matador or Merge in the 1990s—Silkworm sounded like musicians reared on classic rock as filtered through 80s hardcore and bands like Dinosaur Jr. or Sebadoh
column10: who had turned the extroversion of rock'n'roll into something jagged and secret. And yet for however straightforward their influences were
column11: something about Silkworm always seemed bent.

column1: Libertine
column2: their third album
column3: was recorded by the band's longtime engineer Steve Albini at a studio called Pachyderm
column4: where Albini had recorded Nirvana's In Utero a year earlier. The music on it is rough-cut and powerful
column5: like a cinder block rendered in sound. Verses start halfway through songs; performances feel glaringly first-take; solos explode without precedence or warning
column6: like a joke told out of context. Despite having two guitar players at the time
column7: there are several minutes on Libertine where nobody is playing guitar at all. What were they doing instead? Low-key Montanans that they were
column8: Silkworm never saw fit to explain their choices
column9: if they were even choices to begin with.

column1: Some bands thrive on confronting their audiences
column2: others on comforting or reassuring them. Silkworm did neither. Their songs are stoic without being standoffish and good-natured without ever seeming eager to please. ""Couldn't you wait?/ You were funny to a fault/ Went too heavy on the salt
column3: Midyett sings on ""Couldn't You Wait""
column4: a portrait of someone whose deepest flaw is their need to be liked. For a band whose music often sounded spare and turned-down
column5: Silkworm never seemed depressing so much as allergic to sentiment entirely.

column1: Libertine was their last album with Joel Phelps
column2: who
column3: along with Andy Cohen and Tim Midyett (formerly Midgett)
column4: was one of the band's principal songwriters. As a writer
column5: Phelps is more emotionally determined than his bandmates
column6: who tend to keep things closer to the vest. Hearing songs like ""A Tunnel"" next to ""Couldn't You Wait"" is like juxtaposing a bare-all diary entry with a found photograph: Both are intimate
column7: but only one retains the kind of mystery that brings you back to it a second and third time.

column1: Like a lot of Silkworm's catalog
column2: Libertine is a series of unconventional decisions made with conventional tools. I don't like all the music on it
column3: but am inspired by their commitment to avoiding the obvious. Over the course of the 1990s
column4: they toured with Pavement at the height of their powers
column5: bouncing from El Recordo Records to the indie evergreen Matador to Touch & Go
column6: shaping their sound into something more linear and familiar—more redolent of their Cheap Trick influences than their post-punk ones. But even their later albums have a bite and opacity to them that kept the band at the fringes
column7: beloved by few but ignored by most. My entrée into them was Lifestyle
column8: which I bought in 2000 during my freshman year in college on the blind recommendation of a friend who said Silkworm was a great band. It had just come out. When my friend and I listened to it
column9: he decided that the songs I liked were corny
column10: and I decided that the ones he liked were cold. Both of us had a point.

column1: In some ways
column2: the band's music was overshadowed by the story of why they stopped making it
column3: when in mid-2005 a suicidal woman crashed her convertible into the back of a car stopped at a light in Skokie
column4: Illinois
column5: killing three people
column6: including Michael Dahlquist
column7: their drummer. Neither Cohen nor Midyett seriously considered continuing.

column1: Libertine comes reissued and remastered with bonus material that includes the band's session with Seattle DJ Marco Collins in 1995
column2: which is a nice opportunity to hear Andy Cohen play an even longer guitar solo on Libertine's ""Grotto of Miracles""
column3: though my guess is that most people interested in hearing this album will be divided into two camps: Longtime Silkworm fans who already know this material
column4: and people who have never heard Silkworm at all. For both
column5: there's a documentary about the band called Couldn't You Wait?
column6: released last year. It moves at a decent pace
column7: without too much drama
column8: chasing moments of indifference with flashes of tenderness
column9:
portraying a group of musicians in a way that feels nuanced but unpretentious—not unlike a Silkworm song.

'Anthology Recordings']|2014-05-02 00:00:00|1981|2016-06-11 16:38:17.763022|"

The first wave of UK punk defined itself by its nihilism
column3: scorched-earth deconstructionist aesthetic
column4: and a dystopian drive that
column5: in retrospect
column6: seemed like the only sane response to life in the shadow of perpetual nuclear detente. The movement's power to shock came from its willing embrace of an oblivion-lust that most people shoved in the back of their subconscious. The flipside to these self-destructive tendencies was a generative urge that punks in their quest to offend usually kept under wraps
column7: and which often expressed itself an affinity for reggae.

column1: It's easy to understand why punks would admire reggae artists: around the time of UK punk's first emergence they were at the peak of their influence
column2: apocalyptically revolutionary and so passionate for deconstruction that
column3: on dub plates
column4: the songs often seemed to dismantle themselves from the inside out. But unlike punk
column5: reggae had an ultimately utopian vision of burning down Babylon so that Zion could rise in the ashes
column6: and the radically new sounds that reggae artists were generating was a crucial part of that vision.

column1: So after UK punk’s first wave had crashed
column2: the participants who were smart enough to realize the limited confines of the genre had turned to reggae for inspiration. Adrian Sherwood
column3: a dub scene honcho who’d eventually go on to play an influential role in the industrial movement
column4: assembled some of the more committed of them that had established themselves in the burgeoning post-punk scene—including the Slits’ Ari Up
column5: Public Image Ltd.’s Keith Levene
column6: and the Pop Group’s Bruce Smith—into a revolving-door dub group called the New Age Steppers that released a handful of records together in the early '80s
column7: as well as one in 2012. For 1981's Threat to Creation
column8: Sherwood took his ambition (and his svengali-like tendencies) up a notch by combining that collective with another one that recorded for his weighty On-U Sound label
column9: Creation Rebel
column10: which had started its existence as the backing group for mystical dub pioneer Prince Far I.

column1: The record that came out of their meeting is astoundingly heavy. Details about the genesis of Threat to Creation are sparse
column2: and the meager liner notes provided by Mexican Summer’s new archival imprint
column3: Anthology Recordings
column4: don't help; the liners do list three drummers and three bassists
column5: which speaks to how Threat to Creation is centrally focused on rhythm. Sherwood was in legitimate competition with dub pioneers like Lee “Scratch” Perry to produce the most earth-tremblingly massive drum/bass combos
column6: and the record presents those instruments with little else to provide long periods of uninterrupted low-end bliss.

column1: The way Sherwood chopped up
column2: processed
column3: and reassembled Creation Rebel and New Age Steppers’ rhythmic components hints at the more extreme cut-and-paste techniques that dance music and hip-hop would acquire after samplers came on the market a few years later. Other elements on Threat to Creation were treated even more radically
column4: diced and delayed to near-total abstraction. Here and there you can identify particular sounds
column5: like Ari Up’s quirkily dissonant piano lines and bits of skritchy
column6: treble-blasted guitar; other sounds are more mysterious
column7: like the wobbly tones that bubble up in the mix and a sound cluster on the title track that’s been run enough flanger to make the original signal impossible to pick out. Sherwood takes particular pleasure in experimenting with the human voice: a wordless vocal part drenched in sharp echo on the title track suggests both preverbal primitivism and technological advancement at the same time
column8: while “Eugenic Device” reduces the singer’s role to an aching groan.

column1: Just how far out Sherwood and his crew got on Threat to Creation becomes clearer when they start messing around with other people’s songs. The twitchy
column2: paranoid “Last Sane Dream”
column3: the album’s most post-punk-indebted cut
column4: is a take on “Devious Woman” by reggae crooner Bim Sherman
column5: while the snippets of vocal melody that come in during the very last seconds of the apocalyptic “Ethos Design” reveal that the tune’s a radically reworked version of the Abyssinians roots reggae hymn “Satta Massagana”.

column1: If dub was a competition to see who could do the most berzerk things to musical recordings and still have them scan as music
column2: Sherwood’s work set a new standard
column3: so it’s hard to believe that Threat to Creation has been relegated to esoteric status. (This is the first time the record's been officially released in the U.S.) Despite its obscurity
column4: Threat to Creation is an important record
column5: and not just for the historical value of the post-punk supergroup that came together to make it
column6: or the fact that the record carries roots in Sherwood’s future ventures in electronic music. It’s a sublime listening experience and a profound statement about the power of experimentation
column7:
and over twenty years after the fact it still sounds shockingly new.

One of the first things I learned about Davey Harms
column2: who records and performs as Mincemeat or Tenspeed
column3: is that he doesn’t use “real” instruments. His big
column4: scruffy beats are made solely with feedback loops that he coaxes from pedals and mixers. It’s an interesting detail: how does he make such bold
column5: floor-shaking rhythms that way?. But Harms’ music
column6: a psychedelic pound that sounds as much like noise
column7: metal
column8: and rock as it does dance
column9: is fascinating whether or not you’re aware of his unique method.

column1: Waiting for Surfin’ Bird
column2: the first release on which Harms uses conventional electronic instruments such as synths and sequencers
column3: is proof that his magic isn’t dependent on his tools. Despite the shift
column4: Harms’ beats still hammer away as gritty fuzz piles up around them
column5: and he’s still obsessed with grinding a single rhythm into your skull like a trepanner’s drill
column6: until it produces the kind of epiphanies intended by mantras. In other words
column7: it still sounds like Harms is DJing for a dancefloor in his head
column8: with the bouncing bodies replaced by firing neurons.

column1: If there’s a noticeable difference between Waiting for Surfin’ Bird and previous Mincemeat or Tenspeed records
column2: it’s that the music is slightly clearer now
column3: a little sharper
column4: more spacious. But this could just as easily be due to recording techniques as instrumentation. Either way
column5: the variance doesn’t detract an iota from the roller-coaster thrill of Harms’ sonic journeys. He acknowledges the change himself immediately and self-deprecatingly
column6: titling the opening track “Normal Techno Jam”. This music isn't exactly abnormal-sounding
column7: but the frenzied
column8: warped edge Harms gives to every sound makes it singularly demented
column9: and exhilaratingly fun.

column1: Despite working within minimalist structures
column2: Harms makes everything sound unpredictably deranged
column3: which gives the album variety. Each track features a sturdy beat that rarely wavers in terms of BPM
column4: deriving momentum instead through texture and volume. So while the frantic “Spirou” might sound like a drum machine that won’t turn off
column5: it also cycles through a wealth of timbral changes
column6: timed with a precision that belies its rough
column7: bleeding cacophony. This also means that more restrained tracks still brim with tension. “Scarfin' Boards” is probably the most reserved Mincemeat or Tenspeed piece to date
column8: yet its tiny clicks and submerged rumbles feel ready to snap at any moment.

column1: It might’ve been easy for Harms to give up on that formula
column2: and stop putting so much work and energy into his music. After his excellent 2010 album Strange Gods on Zum
column3: he ended up releasing his last record for free via the Free Music Archive. But he’s since found another sympathetic label to support him: Decoherence
column4: whose owner MP Lockwood himself makes noisy beat-oriented music as Radio Shock. Which is fortunate
column5: because it’s tough to imagine the music of Mincemeat or Tenspeed actually stopping. There’s a drive to Harms’ repetitive beats that feels infinite
column6: even eternal
column7:
and so Waiting for Surfin’ Bird will likely echo in your brain long after the album is over.

To the outside observer
column2: Chairlift’s Caroline Polachek had an identity crisis over the last year. She was playing secret shows and debuting new material under increasingly inventive
column3: singer-songwriterly pseudonyms: Kimsin Kreft
column4: Theora Vorbis (an A/V pun)
column5: and most fancifully
column6: Ramona Lisa
column7: the name under which she’s presented her solo debut
column8: Arcadia. Chairlift’s sophomore LP
column9: 2012's Something
column10: possessed some excellent singles
column11: and the Polachek-written “No Angel” ended up on Beyoncé's recent self-titled album
column12: but despite all this upward momentum
column13: Arcadia is a quiet curiosity
column14: a quirky side project that’s mostly a labor of love.

column1: Arcadia was composed and recorded entirely on tour and on laptop with MIDI instruments
column2: but the music’s not too recognizably lo-fi or idiosyncratic
column3: especially when compared to some of Chairlift’s past work. There are reprises and recurring motifs that lend Arcadia a conceptual coherence
column4: but Polachek’s songwriting is as broad as it is pared-down. The record works in two modes: for more abstract material like “Hissing Pipes at Dawn (They're Playing Our Song)”
column5: which is
column6: yes
column7: a impressionistic sound-painting of hissing pipes at dawn
column8: there are tracks like “Lady’s Got Gills” and “Backwards and Upwards
column9: ” which resemble Chairlift album cuts that were allowed to melt around their chorus sections.

column1: Despite their meandering tendencies
column2: the songs on Arcadia sound neither tossed-off nor incomplete
column3: and are surprisingly sticky at times. “Backwards and Upwards” is a driftier sequel to Something’s “I Belong in Your Arms” as an insistent organ hook and bass burble are paired with love-dazed vocals; “Lady’s Got Gills” is as playful as its title suggests
column4: its synthesized instruments scattered through the busy beat like stones.  These moments are where Polachek’s sense of humor comes through: “Getaway Ride” is a charming bit about arson and fanciful theft
column5: and you can hear little deadpan nudges and winks in Polachek's delivery. Arcadia's introspective cuts are mostly effective as well
column6: particularly the pastel waltz “Dominic
column7: ” which comes and goes as drowsily as the “perfect disaster” of a fling described in the song. Like much of Arcadia
column8: ""Dominic"" is “pastoral” in the sense that it uses nature—fields
column9: pale mornings-after—as an incidental backdrop for stories that tend toward the small and personal.

column1: Arcadia tends to lean instrumental and abstract
column2: interspersed with field recordings that were inspired by Polachek’s traveling through Rome and wanting to recreate what she saw out the windows. The results are warm and almost meditative: synth pads that evoke sunbeams
column3: choral multitracking that sounds like General MIDI voice patches. There are referents for this
column4: some expected and some not; Polachek is an avowed fan of cult singer-songwriter Virginia Astley—specifically
column5: of Hope in a Darkened Heart
column6: her collaboration with Japan’s David Sylvian and Ryuichi Sakamoto—as well as Japanese artist Mishio Ogawa
column7: and their watercolor art-pop is a clear
column8: audible influence.

column1: But Arcadia evokes other artists' work
column2: too
column3: from ambitious composers like Julia Holter or Lucrecia Dalt
column4: to more workaday ambient artists like Sleepthief in his less trip-hop moments
column5: to Miriam Stockley (who coincidentally has her own “Arcadia”)
column6: to any number of bedroom-produced singer/songwriters. The album is an interesting
column7: almost peculiarly personal mix of sounds
column8: one that almost seems underdeveloped and unlikely to win Polachek any new fans. As an outlet for Polachek’s songwriting
column9: though
column10:
it suggests there's more interesting work yet to come from her.

"|19287.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19287-ramona-lisa-arcadia/|6.8|Katherine St. Asaph

'Electronic']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Island']|2014-05-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:19.260708|"

Like Josephine Baker nearly 50 years before her
column3: it was when Jamaican-born Grace Jones left New York City and went to Paris in 1970 that she went from being mere Wilhelmina Agency model to international cause célèbre. Towering at nearly six feet
column4: with an obsidian skin tone and facial features like flint rather than flesh
column5: Grace Jones and her androgynous looks made her a sensation in the fashion world. She stalked the runways for Yves St. Laurent and Kenzo Takada
column6: roomed with Jessica Lange and Jerry Hall
column7: served as muse for photographers like Helmut Newton and appeared on the covers of Elle and Vogue.

column1: Fashion world conquered
column2: Jones then returned to NYC
column3: habituated Studio 54 (sometimes in nothing more than her birthday suit)
column4: and conquered disco
column5: recording three albums with the man who invented the very notion of the form
column6: Tom Moulton. Jones’ choice of covers on those albums ran the gamut from dreck like “Send in the Clowns” to a stunning rendition of Edith Piaf’s “La Vie En Rose
column7: ” her flat monotone speak-singing voice atop a flamboyant overly-dramatic backdrop that veered often into camp. When the disco backlash began in earnest
column8: Jones set her sights on a new realm to conquer: new wave.

column2: Grace Jones decamped to Compass Point Studios in Nassau
column3: Bahamas where she worked with producers Alex Sadkin and Island Records’ president Chris Blackwell
column4: as well as a crack team of session musicians rooted by the rhythmic reggae force of Sly & Robbie. (This group would eventually be dubbed Compass Point All Stars
column5: supplying island grooves for everyone from Robert Palmer to Tom Tom Club to Black Uhuru.) Across three critical and commercial hit albums spanning from 1980’s Warm Leatherette through 1982’s Living My Life --with the expanded reissue of 1981’s Nightclubbing as her pinnacle-- Jones reinvented herself
column6: while also altering the face of modern pop.

column1: Fashion
column2: art
column3: and music all converged in the form of Mrs. Jones and looking out at the 21<sup>st</sup> century musical landscape
column4: it’s easy to see her influence: Lady Gaga
column5: Rihanna
column6: Nicki Minaj
column7: M.I.A.
column8: Grimes
column9: FKA twigs
column10: and more. Beyond that
column11: there’s an entire subset of alternative music that draws on the template set by Jones and her Nassau backing band: Massive Attack
column12: Todd Terje
column13: Gorillaz
column14: Hot Chip
column15: and LCD Soundsystem all emulate those rubbery yet taut grooves of Sly & Robbie and cohorts
column16: a hybrid that amalgamated rock
column17: funk
column18: post-punk
column19: pop and reggae. So curiously strong was Grace Jones’s influence on pop culture of the early '80s that not only did she pioneer the androgynous look in fashion (as styled by Jones’s then-beau Jean-Paul Goude)
column20: she was even able to turn her chiseled bodyguard boy toy into an action star. It's but one of many examples of Jones' singular existence in pop culture (who else nearing retirement age could command a stage with the likes of both Lil’ Kim and Luciano Pavarotti
column21: or perform for the Queen's Diamond Jubilee while hula-hooping?).

column1: On the album’s opener
column2: a cover of Flash and the Pan’s “Walking in the Rain”
column3: Jones growls in her contralto about “Feeling like a woman/ Looking like a man.” Noirish
column4: foreboding
column5: sounding rain-slicked
column6: the beat crafted by Sly Dunbar with percussionist Uzziah (Sticky) Thompson is undeniable across its four minutes. But it’s on the second disc
column7: where many of the album tracks' running times are extended towards the sublime
column8: that the now seven-minute song soars even higher. It also doubles as a showcase for keyboard wizard and the Nassau band’s secret weapon
column9: Wally Badarou
column10: a classically-trained synth session man who’s C.V. includes M’s “Pop Music” and Level 42’s “Something About You.” Badarou's extended solo evokes a tone not unlike Miles Davis' muted trumpet: gorgeous
column11: weightless
column12: it's as brooding and wistful as a midnight walk in the rain can be. On Grace Jones’s take on the tango “I’ve Seen That Face Before (Libertango)
column13: ” Badarou mimics both Argentinean tango master Astor Piazzolla’s bandoneon and that eerie organ tone of “Runaway”.

column1: But of course
column2: Grace Jones is the star here. Five of the original album’s nine songs are covers
column3: though rather than fealty to the source material
column4: Jones sounds as if she’s shredding the songbook with her bare teeth. She treats each cover not as a singer tackling a song
column5: but as an actor inhabiting the skin of a role. She sneers the Police’s “Demolition Man” as if she's a villainess leveling a hospital
column6: inverting the gender and notions of sexual dominance in her lascivious take on Bill Withers’ “Use Me.” Dubbing out the zombiefied pacing of “Nightclubbing”
column7: Jones intones Iggy Pop’s lines with the detachment of a dominatrix contemplating her cat o’nine tails
column8: while a previously unreleased cover of Tubeway Army’s “Me! I Disconnect From You” sets it in a sleek reggae setting.

column1: Another bonus track is labeled “Peanut Butter
column2: ” which some disco fans will recognize as the title of another Sly & Robbie & Wally track (as remixed by Larry Levan)
column3: made for Gwen Guthrie on her 1985 mini-album Padlock. But here
column4: “Peanut Butter” is the beat that Grace Jones turned into her Top 10 single and Paradise Garage anthem
column5: “Pull Up to the Bumper.” Originally deemed “too R&B” by Chris Blackwell
column6: Jones finally got her hands on the pistoning riddim and turned it into one of the most profane singles in pop/dance music history. Long black limousines
column7: commands to “pull up” and coos of “let me lubricate it” make it one of the finest parallel parking metaphors for butt-fucking. At a time wherein a song about a ""gigantic"" interracial lover can soundtrack a tech giant's new promotional ad campaign
column8:
one hopes that soon a car company will do the same for Grace Jones' most wanton pop moment on a record that further cemented her iconic status in pop culture.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20512/homepage_large.76853513.jpg|That's Harakiri|31976.0|Sd Laika|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tri Angle']|2014-05-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:19.860064|"

It seems like there should be a little more perplexing mystery to Sd Laika than there actually is: Peter Runge is basically a guy from Milwaukee with a low-key social media presence and enough of a distinct game plan to wind up on the same label as Forest Swords and Evian Christ. But Runge's music possesses an unnerving sense of man-machine fusion that sends viscera burbling out your speakers—the kind of glitched-out muck that leaves a permanent stain on everything in hearable radius and makes one thankful that you can't actually smell music. It's gruesomely tactile
column2: dank stuff
column3: the kind of keyboard gut-ripping that primarily resembles grime in the ""Crime scene clean-up"" sense of the word.

column1: Two years ago
column2: Runge put out the Unknown Vectors EP
column3: which took the more abrasive qualities of grime and bass music
column4: sharpened their edges to the border of discomfort
column5: and kicked their surefooted steps out from beneath them to leave their rhythms scrambling. Since then
column6: he's only pushed that discomfort further
column7: something that his new LP That's Harakiri brings to deeper fruition. There's some real agitation on this thing—beats that rattle like a loose drive belt
column8: ambient percussion that sounds sourced from the static left after Earth's last radio transmission
column9: gurgling drones on some ""all glory to the Hypnotoad"" shit—and there's no real accessible way into it.

column1: The sick stuff's enough to shake off the unwary
column2: and the opening one-two of ""Peace"" and ""Great God Pan"" put the most difficult aspects of Runge's music right up front. The former's a scrambled broadcast that pits trebly squeaks of inside-out digital strings against heaving meat-slab synth
column3: resembling less a beat than a creeping caustic ooze. The latter track throws out the pastoral flute-tootling its title might imply in favor of glo-fi catatonia; there's analog hisses that give off enough neon heat to leave blisters
column4: while a machine shop's worth of misfiring pistons plays percussion. While there are signs of order to grab on to—the straightforward 808 boom-clap beat that marches through closer ""Percressing
column5: or the batterram 4/4 kicks that churn through the loud-yet-minimalist ""Remote Heaven""—the sense of short-circuit disorder is never far away
column6: which gives That's Harakiri the feel of pulling order through chaos. Noise interference is ramped up
column7: as are counterintuitive rhythms and ugly chords
column8: only to tie them all together into an unexpected sort of cohesion.

column1: The mutated-grime signifiers give his songs a bit of grounding; there are these juddering Wiley-style Eski beats and bleeps in ""I Don't"" and ""You Were Wrong"" that move a little funny because they've lost a few toes to frostbite. And the pulse really does get insistently catchy once you've given in to the havoc: for all the moaning buzzes and Tesla-coil sparks that scorch its surface
column2: ""Meshes"" also has a remarkably supple and intricate chattering beat down beneath that could goe toe-to-toe with your favorite Major Lazer cut for ass-shaking potential. There's a sense here that Runge is reacting to the clockwork sleekness and futurist warmth of Grime 2.0 and Night Slugs/Fade to Mind bass music with deliberate violence—not out of hostility
column3: just a fascination with what happens when all those parts start malfunctioning. In the case of That's Harakiri
column4:
that malfunction just turns out to be another kind of fine working order.

Nashville guitarist and composer William Tyler’s new 12” Lost Colony marks a significant departure from his two solo albums
column2: both of which were collections of sparely orchestrated
column3: virtuoso guitar instrumentals. His debut
column4: 2010’s Behold the Spirit
column5: was a workbook’s worth of tricky exercises in rapid-fire fingerpicking
column6: cluttered harmonies
column7: and expansive open tunings. With the help of song titles like “Terrace of the Leper King” and “The Cult of the Peacock Angel”
column8: the comparisons to John Fahey rolled in. On his follow-up
column9: Impossible Truth
column10: Tyler rebelled modestly against that designation
column11: peppering the album with bristlier psych-Americana pieces for electric guitar and drones. Now
column12: across Lost Colony’s three tracks
column13: the guitarist seeks to capture a completely different musical atmosphere: that of a standard-issue rock band playing live in a room.

column1: The main attraction on the EP is the first track
column2: the 13-minute “Whole New Dude"". It's essentially two movements punctuated by a recurring string of overdriven electric guitar chords which conjure up the image of hurtling towards a Midwestern skyline on an open
column3: mildly potholed highway. The interest of the track is mostly in the changing rhythmic emphases of Tyler’s finger-picking against Jamin Orrall’s unwavering
column4: muscular drumbeat. Tyler switches between a few basic riffs
column5: which he plays in a cyclical progression like a regimented Indian raga. Though it’s extraordinarily involved playing
column6: the band runs the arrangement down like they do it a few times every day
column7: and the ritualistic nature of their performance gives the song a compellingly static
column8: meditative quality.

column1: The EP’s second track
column2: “We Can't Go Home Again”
column3: is also on Impossible Truth. There
column4: it's an acoustic guitar solo redolent of the English folk scene of the late 1960s/early 1970s
column5: building in intensity as Tyler adds increasingly detailed ornamentations and internal melodies. Lost Colony’s full-band retake sounds more like a jangly Big Star instrumental augmented by steel guitar swells. It's easy to see why Tyler decided that this version was worth a separate release—the arrangement transforms the character of the song entirely
column6: but it also doesn’t add anything to it. Instead
column7: the full-throttle treatment obscures some of the finer points of the guitar playing and reduces the piece’s dynamic range. If the original was a beacon of clarity after Impossible Truth’s comparatively sludgy first half
column8: it feels inconsequential on Lost Colony
column9: an intermission between two pieces with more inventive musical aims.

column1: The second of these is an odd
column2: playful cover of “Karusell”
column3: a model kraut-shuffle from Neu! founder Michael Rother’s 1977 album Flammende Herzen. The appeal of Rother’s original is its compressed
column4: streamlined flatness—the modesty of the grainy synth
column5: lightly chugging rhythm guitar
column6: and dry
column7: muted drumkit. But the ornate details count in Tyler's version. The ping-ponging delay and fuzz on the guitar build up until the band fades out still blaring
column8: the ""carousel"" spinning out of control in a way that the original never does.

column1: On the whole
column2: Tyler’s move toward a full ensemble feels inspired. It is gratifying to see such a gifted artist broadening his palette to accommodate new influences. If Lost Colony is a testing ground for ideas for a new full-length ensemble effort
column3:
it's an auspicious beginning. But it remains to be seen whether an entire album of kraut-country—Tyler has hinted at the idea—or even a record without solo guitar will play to his well-tested strengths for subtlety and complexity.

David Eugene Edwards has never been an easy fit for many record labels. Through the 1990s
column3: with the brooding folk-rock act 16 Horsepower
column4: and with the stoic solo reflections of Wovenhand over the last decade
column5: he’s bounced among various American imprints—from the majors in the mid-’90s to weirdo outpost Alternative Tentacles
column6: from the once-edgy and now-erstwhile Jetset to the Christian encampment Sounds Familyre. The movement stems
column7: at least in part
column8: from Edwards’ deliberate genre aggregation. Throughout his career
column9: he’s mixed gospel and bluegrass
column10: rocking both punk and gothic on a forever-sliding scale.

column1: The most challenging element about Edwards’ place within the industry and with his potential audience
column2: however
column3: is his Christianity
column4: which anchors the music he makes. His fire-and-brimstone religion
column5: cast often in a King James Version non-vernacular
column6: examines his faith and the way it can survive in a world of human error. It’s neither the cute stuff of former labelmates Sufjan Stevens and Danielson
column7: nor does it possess the path-affirming promises of contemporary gospel; it’s brooding
column8: soul-scraping stuff
column9: like Michael Gira attempting to turn the other cheek.

column1: Given the consistent religious content of Edwards’ music
column2: you might find it surprising that Wovenhand’s seventh album

column4: arrives under the aegis of Deathwish
column5: the label co-founded by Converge frontman Jacob Bannon. Deathwish has been a diverse label for more than a decade
column6: releasing the aberrant punk of Integrity
column7: the electronic creep of Cold Cave
column8: and the fetching post-hardcore of Touché Amoré. Now
column9: Christian neo-folk
column10: sung in a loamy baritone by a 46-year-old from Colorado's found a home on the label as well.

column1: Refractory Obdurate is Edwards’ “heavy record”
column2: with tumescent electric guitars and unforgiving drums
column3: howled lines and massive codas. The album finally makes good on the post-punk and metal influences that have forever lingered at the edges of Wovenhand’s output. “Field of Hedon” lashes open like Sonic Youth in their concision-focused heyday. The remarkable anthem “Good Shepherd” feels like pop-punk
column4: simply slowed and strengthen by the import of its own in excelsis proclamation. The saturated guitars that open “Hiss” even form a black metal feint. These fortified settings afford Edwards an urgency that his songs haven’t had in a decade. “This darkness does not want me/ It refuses to hold me
column5: ” he offers during the chorus of “Masonic Youth
column6: ” the newfound electricity actually dispatching with despair. It’s primal and powerful music
column7: loaded and loud enough to demand that you—Christian or no—at least consider his case.

column1: Edwards’ religion isn’t just central to the music he makes; in many respects
column2: his religion—or at least his very cerebral and personal exploration of it—is the music he makes. “That’s the lens through which I see everything. It’s not something I just use to use
column3: ” he told his hometown newspaper four years ago. “I don’t know anything else.” His lyrics are lined with deep-reading references to scripture and the history that surrounds it; these 10 new tracks
column4: for instance
column5: mention the contested temptress Salome
column6: use an euphemism for Satan to crack a joke
column7: and speak of travelers from ancient Biblical lands as though they’re a stranger you’ve just met on the street.

column1: Faith frames Edwards’ quest for justice and redemption
column2: too
column3: ideals he sees distorted by non-believers and self-proclaimed Christians alike. Refractory Obdurate often reads like an attempt to find and defend righteousness in a landscape that he believes is deadest on destroying it
column4: and Edwards delivers all this with Pentecostal conviction
column5: his voice decisive and stentorian
column6: like a preacher gathering converts at a small-town
column7: big-tent revival. Above the searing guitars of “King David
column8: ” he yells “Have you not read the story?” He pauses midsentence
column9: a minister taking a moment to glare at and tacitly question ever member of his gathered congregation.

column1: But Refractory Obdurate feels bigger than any belief system. In fact
column2: despite its name
column3: which essentially pairs two synonyms for the word stubborn
column4: there is a remarkable
column5: underlying plasticity at work here. Edwards backs the nascent electric surges with the same polyglot approach he’s embraced for two decades. “Obdurate Obscura” pairs Indian rhythms with Tuvan throat-singing
column6: Arabic oud melodies and a smoldering background hum. “Salome” is a tempestuous epic
column7: with a web of a half-dozen electric guitars and crisscrossed vocals shaping a foreboding thicket of sound. But Wovenhand’s progressions suggest a well-worn stack of West African records
column8: and the bursts of gang vocals betray an interest in the kind of old American work songs Alan Lomax collected. Edwards and his supporting trio haven’t simply plugged in and turned up; rather
column9: they’ve simply expanded the scope and shifted the balance of everything that’s long made Wovenhand’s music interesting. In the process
column10: the re-energized Edwards is as good as he’s been years.

column1: Edwards works through these songs with archaic words such as “doth” and religious references so specific that you’ll need to set aside some research time in order to parse the lyrical pieces. But he refers to his god as benevolent and beautiful
column2: a passive leader who only enacts vengeance upon the wicked
column3: those who “free the guilty for a bribe.” Edwards’ music is incredibly personal

column5: really
column6: our history. He sees a world at fault and wants to find ways to remedy it
column7: or at least to reconcile his hopes with reality. “This landscape is a thorn
column8: from Tubal-Cain down to me
column9: ” Edwards sings at one point
column10: invoking the Genesis character often credited with forging the first instruments of war. The world is a birthright of troubles

column12:
and these songs—now given the wonderful gumption of an electric edge—are simply his ways of dealing with them.

One of these days there'll be the definitive retrospective written about how Kelis somehow managed both a solid run of great songs and an impenetrable run of rotten luck. We're 15 years out from the cult-hit success of Kaleidoscope and “Caught Out There""

Every few years it seems like she's had to find a new voice and a new audience to go with it.

column1: In that respect
column2: even a move like getting Dave Sitek to produce your album on a label best known for Amon Tobin isn't excessively out-of-nowhere. The chameleonic nature of Kelis' voice and her versatility in sonic roles ranging from vintage Neptunes to Raphael Saadiq to David Guetta is her biggest strength
column3: one that's sustained her throughout a career filled with unfair perceptions of her as a producer's plug-in. Sitek
column4: meanwhile

column6: the big-in-Europe star rerooted to the Harlem of her youth and reconciling it with the art-school upbringing that made her one of pop's likeliest indie-crossover candidates.

column1: And it should've gone so much better. Food shows Kelis in unusual form—ragged
column2: raspy
column3: somewhere between exhausted from effort and deep in reflection. It's definitely not the tough
column4: coyly defiant

column6: though there are still flashes of it for emphasis. At its best

column9: the deeper-than-deep long-distance yearning in Labi Siffre cover/Tunde Adebimpe duet “Bless the Telephone""
column10: and the maternal lessons-learned wisdom in “Hooch” (which slyly invokes an epochal line from her ex Nas: “Like your daddy said
column11: the world is yours/ So let it flow naturally”). Even if it's a hard sell going to some of the hooks a few too many times—especially when they're as lyrically noncommittal as the placeholder-quality “Gimme what I want/ Gimme what I need/ I'm beggin' you please/ I'm down on my knees” refrain of “Friday Fish Fry”—it's striking to hear a voice you thought might've been familiar over the previous five albums given a new rendition.

column1: If the occasional lapses in songwriting are forgivable

column3: strange rasp of hers is subsumed under layers of Sitek studio trickery: pushed back by horn sections when it should be riffing off them

column7: Tunde
column8: and an acoustic guitar all meshing together in a way just as striking as her younger self careening through Pharrell's digital Tilt-a-Whirl. For most of the remainder of Food

It’s probably difficult to imagine if you weren’t there
column2: but Endless Summer
column3: the 2001 album by Christian Fennesz on the Mego label
column4: seemed like a pretty big deal at the time. I’m not positive it was a big deal because back then it wasn’t so easy to measure these things; you couldn’t add up YouTube plays or look on the Hype Machine or measure Facebook Likes to see how music was getting around. Instead
column5: you pretty much had to rely on the conversations you were having and the reactions you were seeing among those people. And Endless Summer
column6: an album of abstract but pretty electronic music on a label better known for releasing abstract and—well
column7: if not ugly
column8: then at least difficult electronic music—seemed to get around. It became the template for a type of record that has become familiar: the go-to album of electronic music for people who don’t necessarily listen to a lot of electronic music.

column1: In the years since
column2: Fennesz has made a lot of records (and he even reissued Endless Summer)
column3: but he’s only released two proper full-lengths that weren’t either collaborations or created to soundtrack another medium. Both 2004’s Venice and 2008’s Black Sea were quintessential Fennesz—heavily processed guitar
column4: quaking drones
column5: shoegaze-informed clouds of distortion—but they took his sound in darker directions with increased density. While the records expanded Fennesz’s sound in intriguing and satisfying ways
column6: they never had that lightning-in-a-bottle moment of Endless Summer. It was a new millennium and we were just starting to understand the ability of using a laptop computer to make music sound new
column7: and here was a record that took the wistful sounds of the California dream and refracted them through silicon. It was the sound of a moment.

column1: For his new record
column2: Fennesz has returned to both the label and the style that provided that 2001 breakthrough. Even if Bécs hadn’t been positioned as an Endless Summer sequel
column3: the connection to the earlier work would have been clear. Rather than serving as texture
column4: the strummed guitars play changes to accompany melodies. The drones and fractured processing are twinkly and bright
column5: instead of dour and foreboding. Once again
column6: Fennesz proves a master of this approach. The acoustic strumming in “Static Kings” sounds impossibly delicate and naïve next to the swirly vortex of the drone accompanying it; the deep organ pedals of “Pallas Athene” bring to mind a vast expanse that stretches to the horizon; the harshness of the distortion on the title track walks a tightrope between oceanic envelopment and repellant destruction. The closing “Paroles” brings it back full circle with possibly the most naked acoustic playing to appear on a Fennesz record
column7: as processing seems to cling to random notes like a burr before being flicked off with the next note. The sense of composition and sound design is strong
column8: and these tracks complement each other and make a coherent whole even if no two sound the same.

column1: The relative warmth and light here gives the music a nostalgic cast
column2: which was at the heart of what made Endless Summer so memorable
column3: but Bécs also possesses an added layer that doesn’t necessarily work in its favor. Fennesz once illuminated the beauty of a digitally scrambled memory
column4: but Bécs is a memory of a digitally scrambled memory. So while there’s something appealingly meta about returning to a sound that was so suggestive of experimental electronic music 13 years ago
column5: there’s also just the slightest hint of surrender in the proposition. If electronic music in this vein is generally expected to push things forward
column6: resurrecting a style from over a decade ago makes you wonder about motivation. But that’s an analytical judgement rather than an aesthetic one
column7:
because the music on Bécs is often gorgeous.

column2: prog rock and regal folk suggested late-night drives in the fall

column5: as McBean delivered exclamatory anthems about love

column4: steely guitars

column2: where it comes from
column3: how many gallons one can manage
column4: how it gave her AIDS
column5: how she now gets it from bears

column7: of course

column1: The trouble isn’t that McBean thought it best to include a rap verse on Get Back
column2: or even that the only woman to appear on this album sets herself up as an automatic punchline. (J Mascis plays guitar on Get Back—can he rap about dicks

column4: the rap's presence isn’t that surprising

column5: too. He posits that 1987
column6: when he would have been a late teenager
column7: was “The second summer of love”
column8: referencing the joy of doing dirty deeds along the kid-cruising strip of his midsize Canadian hometown. And he praises those old pals who persevered when the mayhem went bad: “I could understand how you’d rather split than take my hand

column1: The sentiments are there

column9: there’s the overwhelming sense that McBean is mining the past for comfort in the uncertain present. “North Hollywood Microwaves”

column2: ” or at least without its rapped appendix. Doesn’t it seem unfair

column1: But Get Back still finds McBean trying to tap into something risky and surprising
column2: even if the results are the sometimes-egregious misstep of a mid-40s rock musician obsessed with the letdown of aging. Still
column3:
the adventure—bear semen notwithstanding—makes me want to stick around long enough to give McBean at least one more chance for a road trip.

One of Thomas Moen Hermansen’s greatest strengths seems to be a well-managed lack of discipline. This isn’t to imply that he’s some kind of slacker; Prins Thomas III is the third solo LP he’s put out since 2010
column2: on top of the knee-high stack of singles
column3: remixes
column4: and DJ mixes that he’s released over the past decade. (Not to mention the couple of well-regarded albums he’s recorded with Hans-Peter Lindstrøm). But the texture of his music suggests that he’s not working according to any overarching plan or formula
column5: simply letting his creations wander where they please
column6: without enforcing any rules to ruin the fun. Unlike the majority of artists who embrace this kind of lenient creative philosophy
column7: his work doesn’t turn out terminally self-indulgent or a blob of undifferentiated sonic mush.

column1: Hermansen—better known as Prins Thomas—is a prime mover in “space disco
column2: ” an amalgamation of disco
column3: electro
column4: krautrock
column5: and pop that feels as casually assembled as one of his albums. Space disco is about as much goofy fun as the name suggests
column6: and its existence is a low-key but intensely effective rebuttal to the self-seriousness that dance music has a habit of falling victim to on a predictably regular basis.

column1: In his liner notes Hermansen insists that there’s “no space disco” on III
column2: and that the album similarly has “no great concept
column3: no specific theme
column4: no scheme
column5: no plan.” Pedantic space disco fans
column6: if there are such a thing
column7: can debate whether the music technically qualifies or not. But the style’s essential playfulness is still here
column8: as well as the right amount of unabashedly screwy synth tones and cowbells
column9: even if it’s overall an even more relaxed experience than most of Hermansen’s past work.

column1: III isn’t an emphatically dancey record; it’s more like space disco’s chill-out room equivalent. Disco’s presence in the mix has been muted
column2: or at least reined in
column3: and in many places it’s overshadowed by ambient music
column4: which has always hovered in the periphery of Hermansen’s influences
column5: and which he indulges in here to an unprecedented extent. His most thorough embrace of the style comes on “Luftspeiling""
column6: a drumless 13-minute-long synthesizer excursion that’s much more entertaining than that description suggests. It begins with a chunky major-key synth arpeggio that he layers with spacey pads and burbling
column7: slightly acid-y leads
column8: as well as a sprawlingly delayed looping guitar figure
column9: returning to an unadorned arpeggio every time things cross a very low threshold of excitement. The results bring to mind Kraftwerk
column10: but some extremely mellowed-out alternate-universe version of the group that got really into benzos and balearic music. (Even the song’s title
column11: the Norwegian word for heat mirages
column12: literally “air mirroring
column13: ” evokes a more blissfully psychedelic image of the Autobahn.)

column1: But Hermansen’s split from the microgenre he’s most closely linked to isn’t as absolute as his notes suggest. The album opens with “Hans Majestet""
column2: which boasts a burbling synth bass
column3: a chugging drumbeat
column4: and a sweeping melody that makes it sound like the theme song from a straight to video action movie from the VHS era. It closes 10 songs later with “Åpne Slusa”
column5: which piles together manic high-pitched strings
column6: clanging cowbell
column7: bouncing sub-bass
column8: and a house beat that could have come from the style’s earliest days. In between there’s a lot of stuff that’s just as danceable
column9:
only in a more abstract way. Hermansen hasn’t given up on the party; he’s just moved it someplace further out.
