column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20449/homepage_large.ca5e1651.jpg|Loose Power|31109.0|Survival Knife|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Glacial Pace']|2014-04-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:23.999969|"

One of the creepiest things about the late Unwound was when singer/guitarist Justin Trosper—perhaps possessed by some perverse sense of pop loyalty—would stop either mumbling or screaming just long enough to sing pretty. His voice itself isn’t the most attractive sound imaginable. At best it’s a utilitarian moan
column2: a means to a purgative end. But that struggle between abuse and euphony could be
column3: at times
column4: unsettlingly sweet. Loose Power
column5: the debut album by Trosper’s new band
column6: Survival Knife
column7: is not a traditional pop-rock record by anyone’s definition. But it is the closest he’s ever come to making anything remotely like one
column8: and that overt love of the classics adds a wholesome swagger to an otherwise gnarled clutch of rock songs.

column1: Trosper isn’t the only Unwound alumnus in Survival Knife. Unwound’s original drummer
column2: Brandt Sandeno—who only appears on that group’s earliest material
column3: recently collected as Kid Is Gone—has rejoined Trosper
column4: only this time partnering up on guitar. Bassist Meg Cunningham and drummer Kris Cunningham round out the roster
column5: and it’s telling that Trosper has amassed a full quartet this time
column6: as opposed to the gaunt trio that was Unwound. Instead of being a shambling wreck of anemic noise
column7: Loose Power is a well-fed
column8: red-blooded specimen. And a tuneful one. The unapologetically catchy choruses of “Divine Mob” and “Fell Runner” positively soar
column9: even as the sparring riffs of Trosper and Sandeno refuse to play nice. Pouring post-punk choppiness into stomping hooks
column10: “Gold Widow” leaves just enough room for Trosper’s newfound sneering croon. Not to mention a tangle of metallic guitar harmony that nests neatly inside a thunderous Black Sabbath vibe.

column1: At seven songs
column2: Loose Power seems at first glance like a brief album. But two songs
column3: “Cut the Quick” and “Heaven Has No Eyes”
column4: exceed eight minutes each—and it’s here that Survival Knife sinks closer toward the brooding Unwound mood of old. In particular
column5: the sparse
column6: dissonant jangle that opens “Cut the Quick” could have come straight out of Unwound’s Fake Train or New Plastic Ideas
column7: only here it thickens into a chugging confessional that concludes with—of all things—a distinctly Zeppelin-esque acoustic coda. “Heaven Has No Eyes”
column8: on the other hand
column9: doesn’t make the best use of its playing time
column10: opting instead to limp along on a contorted prog-punk jam that takes far to long to reach its destination.

column1: That jam
column2: though
column3: is telling. Trosper has never hid his love for vintage Black Flag—he once served time in a side project called Young Ginns—and that worship of Greg Ginn’s alternately needling and plodding hard-rock/hardcore hybrid is the subtext to almost every squealing chunk of Loose Power. “Roman Fever” borrows a telltale
column4: descending lick from Black Flag’s “Drinking and Driving”; “Loose Power” overcomes Trosper’s biggest lyrical flop (“My twin towers/ Your twin towers”) by melding the cocksure conventionality of Black Flag’s most catchy and accessible album
column5: Loose Nut
column6: with the bluesy
column7: serpentine proto-punk of the Stooges’ Raw Power. Summing up Loose Power as a shotgun marriage between Black Flag’s Loose Nut and the Stooges’ Raw Power might be way too tidy. Still
column8: it’s hard not to. And it doesn’t detract from the fact that Trosper has found a fascinating new way forward: one that mangles then mingles his punk and classic-rock influences while melodically subverting his own accomplishments in Unwound. It ain’t exactly pretty
column9:
but it’s a little less ugly.

"|19243.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19243-survival-knife-loose-power/|7.2|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20454/homepage_large.c2abfa7b.jpg|More Than Any Other Day|32221.0|Ought|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2014-04-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:24.586329|"

Ought are a band from Montreal on Constellation Records
column2: which is both the most obvious and most misleading thing you can say about them. For one
column3: they’re not actually Montreal natives
column4: or even Canadians—their collective passports list birthplaces as far-flung as New Hampshire
column5: New Jersey
column6: Oregon
column7: and Australia. Furthermore
column8: their tetchy
column9: talkative brand of art-punk makes them anomalies on a Constellation roster that
column10: from the foundational releases of Godspeed You! Black Emperor to current franchise players like Colin Stetson
column11: has mostly favored the abstract over the elemental. But this outsider’s vantage is precisely what makes Ought’s debut album
column12: More Than Any Other Day
column13: so endearing and electrifying. It’s an anxious
column14: distressed record to be sure—brimming with feelings of disaffection and dislocation—but it presents itself as such simply to show you how that nervous energy can be put to more positive
column15: constructive use.

column1: As legend has it
column2: Ought came together at McGill University in 2012 during the “Printemps Erable”—i.e.
column3: the “Maple Spring
column4: ” when a push by the Quebec government to increase tuition fees across the province by 75 per cent prompted thousands of students to walk out of the classroom and into the streets for mass protests and school boycotts that lasted into the fall. For the members of Ought
column5: it was an especially eye-opening experience
column6: both as an immersion into Quebec’s proud tradition of civil unrest
column7: and the celebratory
column8: often musical form it can assume: the most enduring image of the 2012 movement is the sight of students and supporters dancing through neighbourhoods
column9: banging on pots and pans in percussive protest. (A snippet of such a gathering can be heard in the dying moments of “Mladic” on Godspeed’s 2012 comeback release
column10: <i>Allelujah! Don’t Bend
column11: Ascend!)

column1: Now
column2: More Than Any Other Day contains absolutely no songs about Quebecois education policy or the rising cost of living for undergrads. However
column3: over its eight tracks
column4: Ought strive to recapture and inspire that same sense of anarchic abandon they witnessed on the streets on Montreal in 2012. To that end
column5: they couldn’t have chosen a more emblematic album cover—not because
column6: as some have pointed out
column7: its image of hands clasped in a show of solidarity bears an uncanny resemblance to another debut album from an idealistic rock band
column8: but because
column9: as the liner notes reveal
column10: that photo was found discarded atop a dumpster. Accordingly
column11: More Than Other Day is Ought’s effort to ensure that the basic tenets of passion and commitment don’t get tossed aside amid a culture of instant gratification and distraction
column12: and remind their hashtag activist generation of how it really feels to feel. This is a manifesto to write more manifestos.

column1: And as singer/guitarist Tim Beeler convincingly illustrates throughout the record
column2: the process of reconnecting with your inner iconoclast can be more potent than any drug. In the standout
column3: Marquee Moon-lit ballad “Habit”
column4: the addiction in question is to the act of expression itself
column5: and the liberating/empowering sensation of getting something off your chest (even if the strung-out
column6: string-screeched coda nods to a song about a different sort of habit). The almost-title-track “Today More Than Any Other Day” puts that transformative theory into even more explicit action: over a slowcore trickle
column7: a dejected Beeler mutters the dispiriting line “we’re sinking deeper”—but then repeats those words over and over as the song accelerates until his ennui is reborn as exhilaration. And as the song hits its joyously frantic stride
column8: even the prospect of going grocery shopping is elevated to a near-religious experience: “Today more than other day/ I am prepared/ To make the decision/ Between 2 per cent and whole milk
column9: ” Beeler shares
column10: fully aware that the concept of choice in a late-capitalist economy is an inherently flawed one. But for him
column11: even such small victories can provide one with the motivation to achieve much greater ones.

column1: With his sardonic
column2: conversational style and ticking-time-bomb outbursts
column3: Beeler belongs to a lineage of brainiac-maniacs that span the likes of David Byrne and the Violent Femmes’ Gordan Gano to modern-day rant-rockers like Parquet Courts and Protomartyr. Likewise
column4: the band’s sound encompasses myriad eras and permutations of proto- and post-punk: Velvet Underground drones (via the omnipersent hum of keyboardist Matt May)
column5: Feelies speed-jangle
column6: daydreamy Sonic Youthian sprawl. And with the gritty grooves of “Pleasant Heart” and “Around Again”
column7: bassist Ben Stidworthy and drummer Tim Keen display an amazingly deft
column8: Fugazi-like facility with injecting a little funk into their punk without turning it into punk-funk.

column1: But more so than any identifiable influence
column2: More Than Any Other Day is ultimately defined by its unsettled
column3: restless spirit; this is an album that treats panic attacks and adrenalized ecstasy as two sides of the same pounding heart
column4: with its simultaneous transmissions of joy and fear
column5: discipline and chaos
column6: comedy and tragedy. As Beeler spells it out in the album’s thrillingly combustible closer
column7: “Gemini”: “I retain the right to be disgusted by life/ I retain the right to be in love with everything in sight.” Though born of a highly politicized protest movement
column8:
Ought aren’t telling you what to do with your life. They just want to make sure you live it.

"|19248.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19248-ought-more-than-any-other-day/|8.4|Stuart Berman

There were dozens of fairly high-profile
column2: 90s-indebted indie rock records released in 2013
column3: and Yuck’s Glow & Behold was no better or worse than the majority. It was
column4: however
column5: judged on a different rubric
column6: one where the standards were lower and yet the grading curve somehow far more strict: while most new bands are shown leniency if they aren’t exactly challenging No Pocky for Kitty
column7: Painful
column8: or You’re Living All Over Me
column9: Yuck was in a tougher spot of competing with a superior version of themselves that no longer existed. Daniel Blumberg wrote the majority of Yuck’s excellent self-titled debut and when he left the band
column10: he took most of its underdog snarl
column11: bite
column12: and sadness with him. With that in mind
column13: the quick turnaround for the Southern Skies EP is a smart bit of damage control. It’s also a weirdly risky maneuver
column14: because it’s simply an addendum to Glow & Behold that makes it clear
column15: “this is Yuck now
column16: ” and the one from 2011 ain’t coming back.

column1: That point is emphasized by opener “Athena”
column2: a song which has no precedent in Yuck’s catalog. But since this is still Yuck
column3: it has a lot of precedent from two decades prior
column4: the sort of quasi-ballad that could sneak its way into the middle of a Bob Mould project. Its brassy
column5: bright acoustic strums and gelatinous shoegaze guitars waltz in a manner similar to “The Slim” without the caustic rage or “Panama City Motel” without the longing. But the lush guitar layering certainly sounds nice
column6: and Yuck’s increasingly hi-fi production is the one thing it can claim as an improvement over their earlier iteration.

column1: Otherwise
column2: Southern Skies is a continuation of Glow & Behold in establishing just how little of an impression Yuck can leave during otherwise competent songs. During the midtempo jangler “Set in Motion”
column3: you can spend four minutes mentally ticking off college-rock reference points and finish without finding a distinguishing characteristic. That carries over to Southern Skies’ sole uptempo number
column4: which coasts on a breezy fuzz riff in the manner of “Georgia” or “Get Away” without channeling either of those songs’ desperation or keening hooks. And it’s called—no joke—“Another One”. An EP of this nature should at the very least point towards Yuck’s future direction and to its credit
column5: the closing title track shows the trio modernizing their sound. But this is only incremental progress that takes Yuck to the very beginning of the 21st century
column6: as the full-stop
column7: punctuated clipping during its main acoustic pattern instantly recalls Madonna’s “Don’t Tell Me”
column8: while its drum machine pitter-pat hearkens back to any number of peripherally related electro-alt singles.

column1: Even if Yuck’s influences are some of the most commonplace in indie rock
column2: that’s not the issue with Southern Skies. Hell
column3: you can kinda sound like the Gin Blossoms or Goo Goo Dolls in 2014
column4: and if you do it with enough passion and hooks
column5: it can be goddamn revelatory. As with Glow & Behold
column6: absolutely nothing sounds like it’s at stake during Southern Skies—Max Bloom’s vocals
column7: melodies
column8: and lyrics build and resolve in the most predictable and comforting way imaginable
column9: the way a data entry temp fills out an Excel spreadsheet without much incentive to do better than good enough. Call Southern Skies “workmanlike” if you will
column10:
just remember the sort of work most cubicle dwellers do nowadays and how they go about their business.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20453/homepage_large.0c3d509e.jpg|Flashbacks and Dream Sequences: The Story of the Moles|32220.0|The Moles|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fire']|2014-04-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:25.618915|"

For the purpose of this compilation
column2: “The Moles” refers to two distinct but related projects. The first is a Sydney-based band fronted by Richard Davies that was active for a short time in the late ‘80s and early ‘90s. The second is the solo project Davies launched shortly after that band broke up. The first Moles brought a uniquely fraught and cinematic sensibility to the Oceanian indie pop tradition honed by bands like the Bats and the Chills. The second Moles built psychedelic chamber-pop collages whose rich arrangements seemed perpetually at odds with the inescapable sense of isolation and bareness they evoked. This comprehensive reissue collects the complete works of both Moles
column3: reserving one LP for each incarnation’s sole album-length release and appending the rest of the first Moles’ output on CD.

column1: Notably
column2: this is the first time that the original sequence of the Moles’ first mini-album Untune the Sky has been preserved for a US release. (The original CD reissue on Flydaddy offered a well-sequenced hodgepodge of album and non-album tracks.) Restored to its intended sequence
column3: Untune the Sky feels like an almost uncanny portent of the great American “lo-fi” bands that would come to prominence in the years after its release. Opener “Wires” kicks off with a persistent bagpipe drone and just-out-of-tune guitar part that would be right at home on Guided by Voices’ Alien Lanes
column4: and its just-pre-chorus build feels like the spiritual cousin of Pavement’s classic album opener “Summer Babe”. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">“Bury Me Happy
column5: ” which was wisely tapped to open the prior US reissue
column6: could be an early Clean single right down to its near-cartoonish organ tone.

column1: The greatest differentiator between the work of the Moles and that of their contemporaries
column2: though
column3: is Davies himself. As a presence
column4: there is something deeply and beguilingly inscrutable about him
column5: a purposeful blankness that betrays an enormous amount of weight and depth behind it
column6: and oozes both vulnerability and vitriol when it breaks and cracks. Davies’ voice rings out plainly at what sounds like the top of his comfortable range
column7: straining over the noise of his bandmates in a kind of frustrated half-triumph that suits these songs perfectly. “This Is a Happy Garden” and “Lonely Hearts Get What They Deserve”
column8: two wrenching standouts from the Tendrils and Paracetamol EP
column9: find the band learning to move with the nuances of Davies’ voice
column10: making ample room for its most stark and unnerving moments
column11: and elevating its subtle rises and swells.

column1: The crown jewel of the first Moles’ catalog
column2: and of this collection generally
column3: may very well be the title track from the band’s final EP. “What’s The New Mary Jane” is ostensibly an attempt to write the lost Beatles song of the same name
column4: and its roundness and rumble feel like a glorious
column5: exaggerated misremembering of that band’s sonics. Its chorus is an almost overwhelmingly indulgent crescendo of layered vocal harmonies and swelling guitar chords. A top-notch remastering job is particularly appreciated here
column6: but it’s frustrating that so many of the Moles’ most well-produced songs were not included on the vinyl in such a comprehensive set.

column1: In the wake of recording their very best material
column2: the first Moles traveled to the UK
column3: recorded a Peel session
column4: and broke up soon after learning that their manager had run off with the 900 pound fee. Davies moved to New York and
column5: with his former bandmates’ blessing
column6: kept the Moles name for a solo project accompanied by a small cast of supporting players. But the most immediately striking change between projects is found in the one of the few things they share: Davies’ voice The rawness and barely-contained urgency that Davies brought to the first Moles is noticeably absent from Instinct
column7: replaced by a clenched and hyper-controlled style that Davies would continue to explore throughout his career. In Davies’ own words
column8: Instinct was meant to be “a Polaroid of being far away from home
column9: ” and it is an almost uncomfortably dry and claustrophobic record. At times
column10: Davies wraps himself up so tightly that it’s hard to take much away from these songs. But on more spacious tracks like “Cars for King's Cross”
column11: which sounds exactly like a solitary walk through the snow
column12: Davies successfully telegraphs a very particular and exquisite type of loneliness.

column1: In many ways
column2: Instinct is best understood as a gestational version of the magnificent orchestral pop that Davies would go on to make with singer/songwriter/arranger Eric Matthews as Cardinal. Matthews
column3: as with the first Moles at their best
column4: was able to turn Davies’ hints into full-on flourishes
column5: rendered on Cardinal’s beloved eponymous LP in glorious technicolor hi-fi. But the Moles—both Moles—were decidedly weirder projects
column6:
harder to put in any one aesthetic bucket. It is this very specificity that makes these records so profoundly meaningful to those who have been won over by their distinct but related charms.

If you've heard an Ex-Cult record before
column2: the sound of Midnight Passenger shouldn't come as a surprise. The Memphis band's newest 10 songs don't offer a particularly significant step away from the sound they had established on their singles and 2012 self-titled debut. The Memphis band still create songs with plenty of momentum
column3: two guitars
column4: and their lyrics generally lean ""dark"" or ""bleak."" Often
column5: this band occupy the middle spot between hardcore (frontman Chris Shaw was in Memphis hardcore outfit Vile Nation) and arid psychedelia (à la Destruction Unit).

column1: But there's a shift here that makes Midnight Passenger a markedly superior album to their first one: The production opens up the band's sound exponentially. Nothing's remotely muffled
column2: so the guitars jump out a little faster
column3: and Shaw's voice is given more of a spotlight. It's an album with a well-crafted universe—Following the bruising
column4: muscle-headed intimidation of opener ""Shattered Circle"" is ""Ties You Up""
column5: and while it still features these prominent reverberating guitar stabs
column6: it's a song that feels restrained. The percussion is given space
column7: the strums are more concise
column8: and the brief pauses lend an added punch to the contrastingly aggro chorus. It's also a song that shows how this band can take nihilistic lyrics about death
column9: blood
column10: and shootings and make them symbols for emotionally relatable sentiments. ""Ties You Up"" isn't about literally tying somebody up: ""You can't keep pretending that all your scars are mine
column11: / when you should be dreaming of your next disguise
column12: sings Shaw. He's seemingly addressing a joiner—a person who keeps assuming false identities instead of establishing their own voice.

column1: On ""Not a Threat""
column2: they acknowledge what it means to be an outcast. ""No one's ever gonna get your mood
column3: / but that's not why they hate you
column4: yawps Shaw. Naturally
column5: this is stated with aggression
column6: but this is the band empathizing with outcasts and loners. It's like a Memphis punk equivalent of X-Men comics. Ex-Cult never deliver flowery ""be proud of who you are and never give up on your dreams"" lyrics—everything's dark and tersely worded—but at least there are flashes of understanding or commiseration. That's why it feels like a missed opportunity when other songs pack empty sentiments: ""I'm the voice from the sewer
column7: go the title track's seething vocals. Hollow intimidation is probably the least interesting component of Midnight Passenger
column8: especially when you consider that Shaw's voice in a sewer isn't even a fraction as terrifying as demented clown Tim Curry's.

column1: There are stretches of the album that feel long-winded and threaten to breeze past entirely. ""Catholic Entries"" has some excellent studies in texture
column2: like the scratch of strings which persists in the back of the song's mix. But it's a song that feels like it's in limbo and either needs to beef up the percussion even more or fully commit to heady spaciness. There's a line in the song about ""the future of nothing""
column3: which is thematically appropriate for a more spare track
column4: but it doesn't mean the song needs to persistently spin in place. It's all the more frustrating because it's just three songs removed from ""Sid Visions""
column5: which offers the perfect formula for breaking that exact kind of monotony. Following a full minute of airy
column6: haunting guitar work
column7: which threatens to remain wispily inert
column8: they kick into gear. The track picks up speed and volume
column9: and when Shaw barks the words ""She's dead! She's dead!""
column10: the album suddenly feels vital and electric.

column1: On Midnight Passenger
column2: Ex-Cult prove that their best results come along when they forgo the quiet in favor of something more brazen. There's a sweetness to the melody of ""Lights Out Club"" (similar in tone to Thee Oh Sees' ""No Spell"")
column3: but it's cut with the occasional crusty
column4: blurting low-end. This album has a couple murky stretches in tow
column5: but considering they also have several satisfying experiments with texture
column6:
the missed opportunities are just hiccups between psychedelia-steeped victories.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20521/homepage_large.00cebfb8.jpg|The Honeymoon Workbook|32258.0|Good Willsmith|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Umor Rex']|2014-04-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:26.585193|"

Chicago trio Good Willsmith formed in 2012
column2: and The Honeymoon Workbook is their first widely-released LP. But it’s not really a debut: in the past two years
column3: they’ve made a slew of fascinating small-run releases
column4: all of which saw them steadily growing their sound into something both recognizable and capable of surprise. The semi-public woodshedding culminates on The Honeymoon Workbook
column5: as the group pours many of the ideas and strengths they’ve developed into one continuous 41-minute suite.

column1: The details behind the work are familiar: three 20-somethings using synths
column2: pedals
column3: and loop stations to make drifting
column4: abstract music. The scenario makes it tempting to slot Good Willsmith in with other post-Emeralds outfits melding noise
column5: drone
column6: and new age. But the distinct shape of The Honeymoon Workbook deserves to be assessed on its own terms. It’s a shape that derives partially from method: the group semi-composed a set using some planned cues and graphical scores
column7: honed it during a 2013 tour
column8: then executed it in one live recording session without any subsequent edits or multi-tracking.

column1: As a result
column2: The Honeymoon Workbook stirs up the space between controlled narrative and open possibility. On “& my body to breath” a fuzzy pulse frames the sorts of tone waves and vocal moans that Double Leopards once perfected. Reliably-rhythmic synths melt into haze on “Taking too long to text
column3: ” recalling the easy ascension of Beaches and Canyons-era Black Dice. Some tropes emerge that in other hands could sound stale
column4: like the rippling
column5: Terry Riley-like bleep of “Now—shower put on all black”
column6: or the dramatic voice samples sprinkled throughout. But Good Willsmith breathes new life into such familiar sounds
column7: giving them a sense of purpose
column8: as if every piece is completing a puzzle or unlocking a new one.

column1: That drive is part of a simple
column2: effective tactic: continual forward motion. There are no pauses on The Honeymoon Workbook
column3: even though it’s presented as seven discrete tracks—a division that’s not simply convenient indexing. Each section has its own arc that builds on the previous and sets up its successor. They’re like lines in a poem
column4: which is perhaps why their titles sound like verse fragments: “I told you to get up and it just happened”
column5: “What you think is crazy isn’t”
column6: “If anything happens to me
column7: my password is Lady Lass”. The latter finds Good Willsmith at their most transcendent
column8: turning columns of air
column9: thatches of disembodied hums
column10: and radio-preacher bites into a unified chorus of friendly strangers.

column1: That description might sound forbidding
column2: but one of the most impressive things about The Honeymoon Workbook is how welcoming
column3: even comfortable it sounds. The group’s name—a half-joking pormanteau of Good Will Hunting and Will Smith—is meant as self-defense; as member Max Allison explained to me recently
column4: “if [people] can't get past the name
column5: they're probably not going to have patience to endure the sounds.” It’s an admirable idea
column6: but probably an unneccesary one. Because while The Honeymoon Workbook doesn’t hold back
column7:
it never feels like Good Willsmith are engaged in a battle. They sound less interested in conjuring sonic spirits through conflict than through communication and concentration.

Blur singer Damon Albarn has had 20 years of practice perfecting a certain kind of song. It’s a sad song but comfortable in its sadness
column2: the kind of song that might make might you stop in a crowded bar and remember that even beautiful things come to an end. It is grand
column3: but rumpled and a little isolated
column4: too. It has quieter places to be. For someone who has performed in front of a crowd of 200
column5: 000 people
column6: Damon Albarn never seems to be far from his next nap.

column1: Blur has been on and off hiatus since 2003. Since then
column2: Albarn has made 12 albums
column3: including four with the downturned pop collage project Gorillaz
column4: who came on like an afterthought and ended up selling millions of records anyway. He has co-written two film soundtracks and two operas. He has collaborated with folk musicians in Mali and the Democratic Republic of Congo
column5: and with the rigorously buttoned-up English composer Michael Nyman. He has also partnered in a label called Honest Jon’s that specializes in curiosities like London is the Place for Me
column6: a four-volume set of Calypso
column7: jazz
column8: and highlife. He is your dog-eared friend who never seems to be doing much and yet gets more done than anyone.

column1: All the Albarns appear on Everyday Robots. It is sleepy music
column2: with the looseness of reggae and the bittersweet grace of gospel and soul. It connects the globetrotting Albarn to the fashionably moody one who sang Blur songs like ""Badhead"" and ""This Is a Low"" and ""Tender""
column3: without Blur’s reluctant grandeur. Most of its songs are anchored by drum-machine heartbeats down low and plinking acoustic sounds up top
column4: with a big warm hole in the middle. (Robots was produced by both Albarn and XL Recordings owner Richard Russell
column5: who Albarn has previously worked with on Gil Scott-Heron's I'm New Here and Bobby Womack's The Bravest Man in the Universe
column6: albums with a similarly old-soul quality.)

column1: Albarn is famous whether he cares about fame or not
column2: but has tended to set his own name to the side. Robots is actually the first time an album has been credited to Damon Albarn and Damon Albarn alone. There he is on the cover
column3: sitting in the middle of an indefinite gray space
column4: hanging his head and smirking at some private joke
column5: the boy who refuses to look at the camera even when it’s time for his close up.

column1: Robots relishes in alienation
column2: and specifically in the way technology facilitates it. Cultural concerns like this are important but can feel pedantic when turned into art. Parts of Robots—the lyrics of “Lonely Press Play” and the title track
column3: for example—are obvious statements made in obvious ways
column4: right-on but one-dimensional
column5: melancholy rendered melancholically.

column1: More interesting is when Albarn manages to graze the side of his subject matter in a way that knocks it into place. Robots starts with a sample from the British comedian Lord Buckley talking about the explorer Alvar Nuñez Cabeza de Vaca: “They didn’t know where they was goin’ but they knew where they was wasn’t it.” Removed from its literal context the line becomes a comment about society writ large. “Mr. Tembo”
column2: a sweet
column3: upbeat song Albarn originally sang for a baby elephant he met in Tanzania
column4: keeps returning to the refrain
column5: “It’s where he is now but it wasn’t what he planned”—a reminder that unfortunate circumstances are less important than how you deal with them. The album’s best songs
column6: “Photographs (You Are Taking Now)” and “You and Me”
column7: mention Albarn’s hot-button topics but set them to the side
column8: frames about other kinds of stories more than the stories themselves.

column1: Albarn has often been compared to English writers like Ray Davies but has always seemed more like Paul Simon
column2: a heavy-hearted and moody person who nevertheless manages to bring a room together. A lot of pressure rests on an album like this but it would seem out of character for him to rise to it. Robots is decidedly lowercase music
column3:
more a piece of his puzzle than a picture on its own. 

"|19280.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19280-damon-albarn-everyday-robots/|7.0|Mike Powell

Jenn Wasner was a little worried about reinventing herself on Wye Oak’s fourth album
column3: Shriek. ""There is more at stake than whether my feelings get hurt or not
column4: she said in an interview earlier this year
column5: addressing how fans would receive the Baltimore/Portland-based duo’s decision to replace her guitar with synthesizers. ""We've been touring in this band
column6: making a living off of it since Civilian
column7: and we are very fortunate that that has been the case
column8: but we're both very aware that it could totally go away.”

column1: She had some reason to be concerned. Wye Oak has been beloved
column2: especially since 2011's excellent Civilian
column3: for the charged interplay between Wasner’s formidable axe-wielding and band mate Andy Stack’s immense
column4: intense drumming. Up until that point
column5: the singer had kept her love of the instrumental and structural aspects of pop and R&B sequestered from her main outfit
column6: seeking other artistic outlets in dancefloor-ready odes to Robyn as Flock of Dimes and last year’s gauzy
column7: Mariah Carey-indebted bauble Dungeonesse
column8: the self-titled album she wrote with Baltimore-based musical polymath Jon Ehrens.

column1: While Flock of Dimes had been ongoing to an extent
column2: Wasner started Dungeonesse to escape a creative funk she had fallen into following Wye Oak’s constant touring behind Civilian. After Stack moved from the East Coast to Portland
column3: she stared down another mental block
column4: this time specifically around the guitar
column5: before realizing she could just hang up the damn thing and make music inspired by her first musical loves as a child of the '90s. That’s when Wasner “sort of fell to the ground in relief and excitement.”

column1: That’s also where the album begins. After a light pitter-patter of synths like raindrops on her bedroom window
column2: Wasner sings
column3: “This morning
column4: I woke up on the floor
column5: thinking ‘I have never dreamed before.’” This chimerical quality suffuses Shriek
column6: as if Wasner still can’t believe she can make the kind of music she has always loved without shunting it into a side project for fear of sacrificing Wye Oak’s identity. But don’t let the soft lighting fool you: Wasner’s bass (Stack now handles melody in addition to keys and percussion) reverberates with nearly the same tension as her six-string
column7: fortifying songs like “The Tower” and “Glory” with a stiff
column8: funky backbone. Even though the latter’s synthesizer solo leaves something to be desired after Wye Oak’s guitar freak outs—nothing on Shriek sends all-over chills quite like The Knot’s “For Prayer” or equally bruising ""Take It In""—Wasner’s instrument carves a viscerally satisfying groove into the air.

column1: Her voice also takes up more space on this record
column2: going deeper and flitting over Stack’s melodies with such abandon it’s as if she might float away. Comparatively
column3: her vocals on Wye Oak’s earlier material come out wispy and flat
column4: crunched by the massive noises emitting from her guitar. Even on “Paradise”
column5: with its familiar squalls of feedback in the background and pummeling drums
column6: she sings more confidently and with a broader range.

column1: That specific song makes me long for the old Wye Oak
column2: actually
column3: like thinking you see an old friend on the street that turns out to be a total stranger. Even though no band owes their audience music they don’t want to make anymore
column4: it’s still a little sad reading Wasner in 2009 talk about how much she needs her guitar. “I know it’s cliche
column5: ” she said
column6: “but I love it. I would go crazy without it.” Many fans will probably feel the same way—I doubt their new live setup will wrench me apart with the same visceral impact as their Civilian tour—but even the most steadfast relationships change
column7: and it’s clear Wasner has moved on. As she should: the way she was feeling
column8: if the next Wye Oak album were made the same as the last
column9: it wouldn't sound as effortless
column10: and she wouldn't sound as sure of herself. So we'll have to get used to it
column11: and while we're at it
column12:
maybe we can enjoy ourselves as much as she did.

Край (Krai) is Olga Bell's fond tribute to backwaters
column2: to half-forgotten towns.  In Russian
column3: the album title means ""edge"" or ""limit""
column4: referring to the areas away from cities and cultural centers where you can walk into a kitchen and find your grandparents' culture still very much alive. Bell's album

column7: where heated conversations you can't quite follow take place in a language you no longer quite remember.

column4: chamber music
column5: and avant-garde rock music.

column2: thrilling noises where it's difficult to know
column3: exactly
column4: what is going on at any given moment. Vibraphones and glockenspiel melt into synthesizers
column5: and Bell's vocals dip
column6: moan
column7: and smear into lower registers with the help of pitch-shifting software. You can imagine you're hearing some of the Knife's last album in the blur
column8: Holly Herndon's work with the sound of human breath caught in a digital blender
column9: or an artfully curdled
column10: Cubist take on Bell's current band.

column1: Bell scored the album for a colorful menagerie of instruments; cello
column2: mallet percussion
column3: guitar
column4: electric bass
column5: and more sample and more crawl across its surface. The instruments sound suspended on some steep dunking line between past and present that Bell's located—new sounds plunge into the deep and come up old
column6: and old sounds become freshly strange. The synth on ""Stavropol Krai"" strongly resembles a wailing clarinet; on ""Krasnoyarsk Krai""
column7: the vibes and glockenspiel tinkle in a minor key above a throbbing cello and Bell's ghostly
column8: pitched-down vocals. A chiming electric guitar picks up the figure the vibes were playing and carries them around
column9: dropping them all over the surface of the music like pulverized glass.

column1: Bell's voice
column2: spread across in various octaves
column3: plays the role of every single townsperson of every krai in her memory. Her multitracked vocals spread out to every corner of the mix. Many of the lyrics
column4: translated into English
column5: probe the feeling of being forgotten or left behind: ""God's too high for us/Moscow's far too distant
column6: she laments on ""Primorsky Krai"". ""Kransnador Krai"" tells the story of a Cossack warrior riding home on an old path: ""Ancestral glory is gone/ New people are here/ Not a pleasant thought."" The ""blinking township lights"" on ""Krasnoyarsk Krai"" are
column7: implicitly
column8: seen from a distance—and distance is what Bell is working to close on Край (Krai). Her mesmerizing
column9: eventful
column10:
and strange album brings these remote voices close enough to feel their breath in our ears.

Melancholia isn’t exactly a lost album in William Basinski’s canon
column2: but it’s one that’s easily overlooked. In 2003 he was releasing an abundance of music
column3: including further volumes of his Disintegration Loops. This record was released in that year as well
column4: and listening to it now
column5: over 10 years after it originally surfaced
column6: it feels like a natural successor to his best-known work. The mechanics behind it are similar; Basinski returned to the same source material used for The Disintegration Loops—a series of tape loops he’d made in the 1980s—to again discover a rich sound world in the degraded patterns that emerged.

column1: Basinski was working in microscopic detail on these pieces
column2: essentially using a method that picked at infinitesimal pieces of sound to see where they would lead him. Something that ties it to The Disintegration Loops
column3: aside from the core operating principle
column4: is the way he uses small movements to express larger feelings. If his preceding work was overwhelmingly about death
column5: Melancholia sees hope approaching in its aftermath. It’s an album split into tracks
column6: although it’s almost impossible to regard it as such
column7: especially as it’s easy to pin a narrative on it when tiny pin-pricks of light rip through the surface in its backend.

column1: This reissue of Melancholia
column2: gorgeously packaged on high quality vinyl by the always interesting Temporary Residence
column3: goes some way to advancing its reputation. It’s the type of record that deserves this kind of treatment in order to get the most out of it
column4: making it easier to sink into the feelings of concern
column5: threat
column6: faith
column7: and belief that are suggested as Basinski delicately plods through this world. The arcing piano motifs are reminiscent of Harold Budd’s collaboration with Brian Eno on The Plateaux of Mirror—an album released in the same decade as Basinski’s source material
column8: and one that shares its sense of dysphoria morphing into optimism.

column1: Occasionally Melancholia drops like a lead weight
column2: with darker transmissions emerging just as set patterns threaten to take hold. “Melancholia XIII” is the most effective of these; sequenced as the penultimate track to the album
column3: it works as a subtle reminder of the ills in Basinski’s world
column4: even if he does appear to be on a slow
column5: upward trajectory during everything that surrounds the track. “Melancholia VII” is an earlier downturn in mood
column6: highlighting how well he suggests struggle in his work—here
column7: it feels like the ghostly loops are last gasp remnants of some dying planet
column8: struggling to make one final broadcast before the darkness overwhelms.

column1: Something this album toys with occasionally is a wistful
column2: almost folky kind of ambience. On “Melancholia IX” Basinski gets tangled up in the kind of atmosphere that lutist Jozef Van Wissem occasionally inhabits
column3: where the sense of sadness is underpinned by a rustic air
column4: giving it the feel of a place that’s centuries old. It’s a key reason why Basinski’s work can resonate so hard—the tools he uses may be modern
column5: but the feeling he foments in his work is positively ancient. It makes the slow movement through Melancholia instantly relatable on a very human
column6: almost primordial level
column7:
like looking at an old cave painting and realizing how much of it reflects our current identity.

Jacques Greene makes house music for lovers. His latest release
column3: Phantom Vibrate

column6: though

column10: Marriage
column11: & Divorce

column1: Montreal’s Greene has always had a feel for R&B
column2: whether it’s dropping Mya’s “Ponytail” in DJ sets or wistfully reimagining Ciara’s remix of “Deuces” on his track “Another Girl”. With Phantom Vibrate

column4: “No Excuse”

column6: Sister"")

column8: ascendant synths
column9: and intermittent sweeps of bells.

column1: The emotional swell of “No Excuse”
column2: the A-side
column3: towers over the rest of the release. ""Feel What” and “Night Tracking” have a willowy
column4: less emphatic texture than “No Excuse”
column5: but Greene has proven to have a strong grasp on how varied house music can embody the emotional weight of R&B. “Feel What” is a nimble collage of varied tempos
column6: the vocal sample blending into the hodgepodge of skittering
column7: revved
column8: and staticky synths. On paper that sounds like a nightmare drafted on Ableton
column9: but with Greene as the technician
column10: it’s seamlessly meditative. “Night Tracking” is the closest to classic house and the EP’s quietest cut. It almost seems to fight with itself at points
column11: different grooves trying to be the most dominant on the track
column12: intertwining and acquiescing with tranquil aggression before zipping into silence.

column1: Had “No Excuse” been the closer
column2: it would have given the short collection a more substantial climax. Instead
column3: the EP’s downward tonal slope plays out an emotional arc of a blossoming romance into its ultimate dissolution
column4: down to the wielding of vocal samples. What’s clear and unruffled at the beginning becomes absent toward the end. Greene has done robust heartbreak before with last year’s ebulliently elastic “On Your Side” featuring the aforementioned How to Dress Well singing about loving desperation. Even when that song’s lonely lyrics are gutting
column5: the beat never feels vacant. With Phantom Vibrate
column6: Greene breaks it down further
column7: separating feelings into their own parts
column8:
narrating with sound how you get from allure to familiarity to the void.

column3: the reunited Pixies released their first new album in 23 years. Titled Indie Cindy
column4: the record collects material from three EPs released over the past few months. Two of these EPs have been reviewed by Pitchfork
column5: and both received exceptionally low marks. In the interest of avoiding redundancy with another standalone review of this material

column1: The great anecdote about the Pixies is that they formed when a college dropout going by the name Black Francis put out an ad for a female bass player who liked both the punk band Hüsker Dü and the folk trio Peter
column2: Paul
column3: and Mary.

column1: The Venn diagram here would be tight. Hüsker Dü made noisy
column2: bleeding-heart records for the underground label SST; Peter
column3: Paul and Mary sang ""Puff
column4: the Magic Dragon"". Francis got only one response
column5: from a woman named Kim Deal. She had never played the bass before but presumably saw in his ad some sly humor and the spark of liberated thinking that lies behind a bad idea.

column1: Crucially
column2: the Pixies weren't from New York or Los Angeles
column3: or even Chicago
column4: but Boston: a famous place but fiercely provincial
column5: with all the reticence of small-town New England and almost no cosmopolitan sheen. We can always depend on Boston for more sports and software engineers. Early on
column6: Francis—a comic-book kid raised in an evangelical church—talked about the band's music with all the pretense of someone fixing toilets or laying shingle. ""You want to be different from other people
column7: sure
column8: so you throw in as many arbitrary things as possible
column9: he told the writer Simon Reynolds shortly after their 1988 debut
column10: Surfer Rosa. A few minutes later
column11: the band's drummer
column12: David Lovering
column13: interrupted to describe a video he'd seen of ""people shooting eggs out of their ass
column14: right across the room into another guy's mouth.""

column1: The band's songs were about Old Testament Christianity
column2: UFOs and white women who crave sex with big black men—fixations that in certain contexts can turn ordinary people into outcasts. Francis liked the surrealist movies of Luis Buñuel and David Lynch circa Eraserhead
column3: which use violence not as a real-world dynamic but a metaphor for the roiling inner worlds we can cover up but never quite control. On a Surfer Rosa song called ""Cactus""
column4: he begs a woman to cut herself up on a cactus and send him the bloody dress in the mail. For the Pixies
column5: this passes as a ballad. In general they remain solid evidence for the theory that the darkest and most violent thinking is done by the quiet kids next door.

column1: In March 1987
column2: the band went into a warehouse studio called Fort Apache and worked for three days straight
column3: producing 18 songs. The project cost a thousand dollars
column4: including printing
column5: tapes
column6: and beer. Eight of these songs were released as Come on Pilgrim on 4AD
column7: an English label that had built a reputation selling
column8: moody
column9: vague bands like Dead Can Dance and the Cocteau Twins but by 1987 had also released some Bulgarian choral music
column10: the number-one dance-pop song ""Pump up the Volume""
column11: and an album by their first American signing
column12: the Throwing Muses. More recently
column13: they've released albums by Deerhunter and Ariel Pink
column14: and in general remain a safe home for uncommon art.

column1: Pilgrim is 20 minutes long and more of a hint at what the band could do than anything else. Two of its best songs (""Caribou"" and ""Vamos"") ended up being re-recorded in more muscular forms; another (""Nimrod's Son"") unfortunately wasn't. The other songs from the Fort Apache sessions—which came to be called ""The Purple Tape""—ended up scattered throughout the Pixies catalog
column2: also in stronger versions. As much as the band changed and refined their sound over time
column3: they seemed almost romantically attached to a big-bang concept of their own music
column4: like a person who measures every relationship against that first love.

column1: Surfer Rosa is highly combustible music
column2: but slapstick
column3: too. Many of its songs feel half-finished or regurgitated in half-digested form
column4: with verses that run on longer than they ordinarily might
column5: choruses that repeat odd numbers of times instead of even ones
column6: and abrupt shifts in tone and volume. Francis was less of a rock singer than a grotesque impression of one
column7: too angry and too tender
column8: a pantomime of extremes. He sounds new but seems to come from an old place
column9: like an obscure bog predator with alien-looking adaptations.

column1: But for all their radical ideas
column2: the Pixies depended on convention—without it
column3: they would have nothing to pick apart. Like Devo or Pere Ubu before them
column4: they were an art-rock band steeped in the 1950s and early 60s
column5: a period of music before rock was considered art. Their songs feed back to surf
column6: boogie
column7: doo-wop and early R&B more easily than anything post-Beatles. The notion that they were changing the shape of alternative rock seemed like a nice bonus but immaterial. In an anecdote from the sessions for the band's 1988 album
column8: Doolittle

column1: Doolittle is their most famous album and for understandable reasons. It's more even keel than Surfer Rosa and better mannered

column3: forgoing the harsh live sound of Steve Albini for the lush
column4: almost folksy one of Gil Norton
column5: who had had previously worked with marshmallows like Echo and the Bunnymen. Its songs take aim at the big things important art is sometimes supposed to: good and evil

column7: Bible stories

column9: which in the late 1980s had the same conversational weight and place as ""climate change""; ""Gouge Away"" flirts with Catholicism. ""Hey"" is practically their ""Like a Prayer

column1: It's in Doolittle's margins—the faux-hillbilly cackling of ""Mr. Grieves
column2: ""There Goes My Gun"" and ""Dead""—that the album becomes what it really is. At heart

In 2005 the ever-revolving lineup of Thee Silver Mt. Zion briefly settled and released “Hang On to Each Other” as part of Horses in the Sky. Taking the “campfire song” descriptor quite literally
column2: the band recorded the track around a campfire
column3: which can be heard crackling away in the background. It’s mostly a vocal piece
column4: aside from the rasping harmonium planted firmly in the distance. Thee Silver Mt. Zion loosely compartmentalized sections of Horses in the Sky when writing notes on the record
column5: with “Hang On to Each Other” bracketed in the “love songs” portion. The original has an earthy
column6: agrarian texture to it—a feeling eradicated on these two new versions of the track
column7: which are about as close as this band will presumably ever come to producing a club banger. “The chords to that tune are like house music chords
column8: ” they claim
column9: explaining the desire to suddenly get their arpeggiator on.

column1: Something that’s clear from the outset of the first version of the song
column2: retitled “Any Fucking Thing You Love”
column3: is that this isn’t some jokey dalliance with dance music. Nor is it coming from a place of naivety. “Most important thing = No irony
column4: ” they write. “Because we love that kind of music
column5: and impromptu dance parties
column6: too.” It’s an unabashedly nostalgic work based around zigzagging analog synth patterns and an ancient drum machine
column7: topped off by a euphoric club diva vocal from Ariel Engle of AroarA. Both versions of the song exceed 10 minutes
column8: but there’s a feel for pacing that stops it from toppling into overkill. There’s nothing here that suggests Thee Silver Mt. Zion have an affinity for current developments in this field—if anything
column9: it closely resembles the point where bands such as Primal Scream laid down their guitars circa 1990 and headed out onto the dancefloor
column10: albeit with an overriding feeling that this is a more temporary arrangement.

column1: The better of the two versions is “Birds Toss Precious Flowers”
column2: mainly because it has a darker
column3: nastier edge to it. Here
column4: Thee Silver Mt. Zion get close to filtering their familiar sound through an overtly electronic template. The keyboards are firmly set to distress when the song begins
column5: but a more tender underbelly emerges as it progresses
column6: edging toward that part of clubland that’s less about nihilistic “losing yourself” thrills and more about getting in touch with feelings. Engle’s vocal makes more sense here
column7: often dipping close to melancholy as analog sounds grind and pulse behind her. If “Any Fucking Thing You Love” is their “Loaded”
column8: “Birds Toss Precious Flowers” is their XTRMNTR
column9: bringing with it a huge industrial grind that suggests some of the visceral oppression of Thee Silver Mt. Zion tracks like “Take Away These Early Grave Blues” from last year’s Fuck Off Get Free We Pour Light on Everything.

column1: There are usually channels of optimistic thought that surface in Thee Silver Mt. Zion records
column2: as Pitchfork’s Stuart Berman noted in his review of Fuck Off Get Free. In a sense this release isn’t so different in mood from their other work
column3: bringing in equal shades of light and dark
column4: and seeing hope amid all the dreams tossed carelessly to the roadside. It’s just that the tools used here are very different
column5: to the point where it’s easy to feel like you’ve been transported to an alien place. Something Hang On to Each Other demonstrates
column6: perhaps unwittingly
column7: is how hard it is for musicians to let go of the core ideas that guide them
column8: even when branching out in this manner. Still
column9: there’s a strange comfort in seeing this band work this way
column10:
bringing their strong sense of dynamics into a different sphere in a move that’s both bold and—a word not often associated with Thee Silver Mt. Zion—fun.

column2: R&B has mutated as much as any genre in music

column4: or we could look at Beyoncé’s newest album
column5: which more or less encapsulates the zeitgeist: dance club beats
column6: disco revival
column7: smeared atmospherics
column8: stuttering bedroom production
column9: Drake
column10: and Frank Ocean. The world Boykins returns to looks much different than the one he left.

column1: But Boykins is an active participant in changing the rules of R&B
column2: too. In 2012
column3: he released a collaborative album with a New York multimedia artist named MeLo-X
column4: who describes himself as a “sonic creator.” Titled Zulu Guru
column5: the record filters Boykins neo-soul classicism through the glitchy motherboard of Flying Lotus. With Love Apparatus
column6: which is billed as his second solo album
column7: Boykins teams up with Machinedrum
column8: a polyglot electronic producer whose own beats shift like a man trying to wiggle his way out of handcuffs.

column1: Boykins tabbing a junkyard instrumentalist like Machinedrum as his producer is left-field and interesting
column2: and emphasizes his willingness to further break down whatever barriers may still exist between R&B and the rest of music. But the pairing is better than a mere thought experiment: Love Apparatus is a warm
column3: dreamy album that easily allows you to get lost in its glow.

column1: It’s a quality of Boykins’ music that has carried over from his debut
column2: which would have sounded right at home soundtracking a bossa nova club. But what’s impressive is that Boykins and Machinedrum have managed to maintain that atmosphere while distinctly digitizing his music. Now
column3: you are eased into zoning out not by acoustic guitar strums and shakers
column4: but by soft synth pads
column5: misting keyboards and bass that feels like it burbles. This is the slow melting of neo-soul
column6: as practiced similarly by newjacks (Toro Y Moi
column7: Frank Ocean) and old heads (Om’Mas Keith
column8: Bilal).

column1: As such
column2: Boykins’ songwriting is not exactly one of Love Apparatus’ selling points. When the album is at it’s worst
column3: Boykins moves songs along like a car with a booted wheel. These are
column4: uncoincidentally
column5: often the tracks that up the tempo: the stilted “B4 the Night is Thru""
column6: or “Tell Me""
column7: or the amelodic “Live in Me.""  The best tracks are the dewdrops suspended in midair: the soothing opener “GreyScale
column8: ” “Show Me Who You Are” and its muted horns and “I Wish""
column9: a longing track that would be equally at home on his debut or an early Robin Thicke album.

column1: There is one song on the delightfully free-floating Love Apparatus that does hold weight
column2: though. Wedged into the middle of the album is “4 U 2 B Free""
column3: a sweeping track that in the hands of another songwriter might become a song like Coldplay’s “Lost!” It is out of step with the album
column4: but its chorus also describes its new age-y appeal: “I’m lost in the world/ Lost in the world
column5:
made for you to be free.”

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20485/homepage_large.09e4cf21.jpg|Drop|5758.0|Thee Oh Sees|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Castle Face']|2014-04-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:33.909084|"

Well
column2: that didn’t take long. As it turns out
column3: the only thing Thee Oh Sees do more expediently than release new music is hiatuses. Less than five months after frontman John Dwyer told a hometown audience at San Francisco’s Great American Music Hall that they wouldn’t be seeing the band in action for a while
column4: Thee Oh Sees have reemerged with their eighth full-length record in six years (to say nothing of a 7"" and split-EP stream that that presumably puts as great a strain on America’s vinyl pressing plants as Record Store Day). And despite the significant developments in Dwyer’s life so far this year—like moving to L.A. and reuniting his early 2000s scuzz-rock combo the Coachwhips at SXSW—Drop turns out to be the next logical step in the progression undertaken on 2013’s Floating Coffin and 2012’s Putrifiers II
column5: further reconciling Thee Oh Sees once-oppositional motorik-punk pummel and psychedelic-pop whimsy into a feel-good fuzz-rock groove. If Dwyer's morning-after clarification of his onstage address didn't already defuse the uncertainty surrounding the Thee Oh Sees' future
column6: the steady-as-she-goes nature of Drop renders the hiatus announcement a total blip non-event in the band's trajectory.

column1: If anything
column2: the increasingly refined
column3: texturally detailed nature of their recent recordings—not to mention a way-lighter touring itinerary than usual—suggests that Thee Oh Sees weren’t so much pondering a break-up as a Beatles-circa-’66 shake-up
column4: easing up on the relentless road show in favour of a more considered approach in the studio. Accordingly
column5: the songs on Drop aren’t so much tailored to the band’s notoriously blitzkrieged
column6: crowd-swarmed concerts as the all-night after-party. That’s not to suggest it’s an especially mellow record; the noise and chaos linger
column7: but Dwyer and co. are in less of a hurry to unleash it
column8: preferring to patiently zone out rather than freak out.

column1: Coming on like the come-down successors to Putrifiers II rave-up “Lupine Dominus”
column2: the early double-shot of “Encrypted Bounce” and “Savage Victory” counts as two of the band’s most entrancing tracks to date: the former distills the serrated psychedelia of Pink Floyd’s “Interstellar Overdrive” and airtight groove of Can’s “Mother Sky” into Nuggets-sized dimensions
column3: while the latter taps into the same spectral spirit as the Rolling Stones’ ace acid-rock oddity “2000 Light Years From Home”. But even though such familiar record-collector reference points abound on Drop
column4: the mischievous melodies and funhouse-mirrored guitar contortions render the results unmistakably Oh Sees. After introducing itself with a mellontroned refrain uncannily similar to Aerosmith’s “Dream On” (not that there’s anything wrong with that)
column5: “The King’s Noise” shows Dwyer to be as in thrall to the early-’70s canon of Bowie
column6: Bolan
column7: and Lennon as peers like Ty Segall and The Smith Westerns—though
column8: unlike them
column9: he punctuates each verse line of faux-Brit diction with a destabilizing Yes-like arpeggio. And despite its titular allusion to every brostepper’s favorite sound
column10: “Drop” actually splits the difference between the Who’s maximum R&B and the Stooges’ Raw Power. (However
column11: the Kinksian “Camera”—with its admission that “life is a camera and I cannot get near ya”—could very well be Dwyer’s dismissive comment on selfies.)

column1: If Drop ultimately ranks a notch below its immediate predecessors in Thee Oh Sees’ discography
column2: it’s for a couple of tracks that stick out as frivolous filler
column3: like the repetitious
column4: nursery-rhymed paisley pop of “Put Some Reverb on My Brother” and the drifting
column5: synth-washed decadanse of “Transparent World”. But as per recent Thee Oh Sees tradition
column6: the album comes to a peaceful balladic conclusion with the unabashedly Beatlesque “The Lens”
column7: though in this case
column8: it feels less like a strategic antidote to the anarchy that preceded it than a natural manifestation of Drop’s stress-free spirit. And yet
column9: just when the song introduces a baroque harpsichord flourish grafted from the mid-section of “In My Life”
column10: it comes to a swift conclusion
column11: as if the band were embarrassed by this uncharacteristic indulgence. It just goes to show that
column12: even at their most relaxed and reverential
column13: Thee Oh Sees’ feisty
column14:
impulsive essence still cuts through loud and clear.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20443/homepage_large.5b90c01c.jpg|Flemish Altruism|2.0|A Minor Forest|['Rock'
column3: the A Minor Forest song “Bill’s Mom Likes to Fuck”—a high point of the post-rock group’s 1996 debut album
column4: Flemish Altruism—was swiped from an inside joke that had circulated for years among the punk kids of Rapid City
column5: South Dakota. A Minor Forest wasn’t from Rapid City; they hailed from far-off San Francisco. But the band toured extensively throughout the country during its 90s-spanning existence
column6: playing many of the same DIY venues that hosted the burgeoning post-hardcore and emo bands of that decade. If there’s one thing that brings people together
column7: it’s cruel humor—and A Minor Forest
column8: brooding and abrasive as well as downright delicate
column9: knew a good joke when they heard it.

column1: Flemish Altruism was reissued on vinyl for this year’s Record Store Day
column2: alongside A Minor Forest’s other studio album
column3: 1998’s Inindependence. The rollout has been humble one
column4: and it can’t help but be compared to Slint’s deservedly lavish Spiderland box set this month. Slint blazed trails with its dour
column5: eerie ominousness; A Minor Forest
column6: on the other hand
column7: neither innovated nor intimidated. That doesn’t make Flemish Altruism any less tense. The shadow of Slint—as well of Slint’s slower
column8: icier cousin
column9: Codeine—loom large over A Minor Forest’s distended syllables and dangling chords. The group had been honing that sound on singles and EPs since 1994
column10: but Flemish Altruism tracks like “…But the Pants Stay On” and “Jacking Off George Lucas” groped for a new vocabulary out of the fragments laying around after post-rock’s early-90s Big Bang. What resulted was pidgin Slint—but in that process of restructuring
column11: A Minor Forest came damn close to inventing post-post-rock
column12: where the subgenre’s self-seriousness was wrestled with until it laughed
column13: gasped
column14: and collapsed.

column1: Steve Albini and Bob Weston produced Flemish Altruism
column2: and the nerve-tightening cello they’d previously captured on Nirvana’s In Utero feels almost deliberately evoked on the album’s most arresting song
column3: “Perform the Critical Straw Transfer”. Singer/guitarist Erik Hoversten opens it with a deadpan punch line: “Guess you really lucked out…” he begins
column4: his numb voice trailing off as bassist John Trevor Benson screams bestially yet faintly in the background
column5: “…on this one.” Sarcasm never sounded so black. Beneath them
column6: cellist Dominique Davison saws with quiet strength
column7: as if mocking and apologizing at the same time. The screaming gets pushed to the fore on thoroughly non-dainty “Dainty Jack and His Amazing Technicolor Cloth Jacket”
column8: an erratic spasm of dissonance that shows an affinity for San Diego screamo (A Minor Forest had previously recorded with Matt Anderson of Heroin)
column9: only broken up here and there with squibs of pinpoint jazziness. The balance is struck almost perfectly on “Bill’s Mom Likes to Fuck”
column10: a 10-minute noise-cycle of mood swings
column11: red herrings
column12: and curdled blood.

column1: The wiseass
column2: scattershot racket of Flemish Altruism settles into a more predictable groove on Inindependence. Concise and controlled by comparison
column3: A Minor Forest’s second and final album (not including their 1999 singles-and-EPs collection
column4: …<i>So
column5: Were They in Some Sort of Fight?) drags more algebra into the rhythm and more calculation into the off-kilter melody. It wouldn’t be fair to say the band had begun to take itself either more or less seriously—but the music is more serious
column6: and even the song titles are less crass. If “Erik’s Budding Romance” is to be taken at face value
column7: that relationship flip-flopped randomly and often between coy
column8: candlelit dinners and table-flipping eruptions of lust. Drummer Andee Connors
column9: an unsung hero of his instrument and era
column10: is in top form
column11: coaxing every shade of texture
column12: dynamic
column13: and emotion out of the kit. There are honest
column14: unabashed hooks on the deliciously brief (that is
column15: under four minutes) centerpiece
column16: “…It’s Salmon!!!”
column17: as well as in “Michael Anthony”
column18: which skips a sweet melody across a minefield of disjointed changes and chords. At the same time
column19: the album’s 18-minute monster “The Smell of Hot” never fully jells; as A Minor Forest’s recording career drew to a halt
column20: patience-testing jams occupied one extreme of their spectrum
column21: while a hint of pleasing pop teased at the other.

column1: A Minor Forest’s legacy is not a towering one. Most notably
column2: Hoversten went on to play with Pinback
column3: where he was able to indulge his love of angular melody much more avidly. The band never seemed to want to make bold statements
column4: and it always punctured whatever atmosphere it crafted with wiry self-deprecation and perverse wit. When A Minor Forest reunited in 2013 after a 15-year hiatus
column5: Hoversten said in a radio interview
column6: “[This reunion is] sort of like
column7: take an outfit you wore 15 years ago
column8: then put it on today. Clearly you liked it at one point
column9: but it’s not exactly the outfit you would have chosen today. That being said
column10: it’s not like I’m being asked to put on a clown suit.” Despite their crank titles and in-jokes
column11: A Minor Forest was never a funny band. But they had fun
column12: and that fun seeped into their music. And that makes Flemish Altruism and Inindependence two of the most endlessly rewarding albums of the 90s post-rock boom
column13:
if never the most monolithic.

""These books and bars and this honesty
column2: they're all I've got
column3: James Snyder concedes halfway through ""Get Lost""
column4: the third of four heartbreakers from Beach Slang's debut EP Who Would Ever Want Anything So Broken? Snyder—a self-admitted ""slave to fucking up""—spends most of Broken couching his confessions in a certain romance: ""We're just some dumb kids getting wasted and knowing we're alive
column5: he sings on ""Kids."" When the so-called ""accidents
column6: whores
column7: and wrecks"" that populate Broken aren't screeching it out with the cops
column8: they're drinking down or snorting up anything they can get ahold of. Yet
column9: when Snyder insists ""the kids are still alright
column10: he's onto something.

column1: And Snyder knows a thing or two about ""the kids"": before Beach Slang
column2: he spent the better part of the last 20 years co-fronting much-loved Bethlehem
column3: Penn.
column4: punkers Weston. To a certain stripe of east-coast pop-punk fan
column5: the Philadelphia-based Beach Slang must look something like a supergroup; Snyder's joined by Ex-Friends drummer JP Flexner and NONA bassist Ed McNulty. Between their pop-punk pedigree and their SPF-spackled moniker
column6: you wouldn't be wrong to go into Broken expecting a little sunshine. But Beach Slang's got something stormier on offer: four self-described ""sweaty prayers"" set to hard-charging drums and heartbleed guitars.

column1: ""I watched your palm hug your guitar—it buzzes like a bomb
column2: Snyder remembers most of the way through ""Get Lost"". There's a careening
column3: about-to-explode urgency of the guitars on Who Would Ever Want Anything So Broken? that's every bit as crucial to these songs' emotional heft as Snyder's lyrics. Everywhere you turn
column4: breathless rhythms crash headlong into blaring
column5: yearning leads
column6: a perfectly outsized complement to the widescreen
column7: fucked-up-and-loving-it sentiments. What this sound lacks in subtlety
column8: it more than makes up in desperation
column9: and that tug between those darting leads and Snyder's whispered-in-your-ear vocalese is electrifying. ""I gave you taste
column10: and a spine
column11: Snyder sings on ""Filthy Luck"". The music drops out just in time for Snyder to stage-whisper his kiss-off: ""And I hope you drown."" The guitars charge back in a second later
column12: the perfect punctuation to his seething passion.

column1: While it's tempting to try to position the wild-eyed desperation in Beach Slang's music somewhere between the fuckup glory of the Replacements and the finely tuned angst of Jawbreaker
column2: there's a considerably less cred-compatible touchpoint towering above the rest: the Goo Goo Dolls. Believe it or not
column3: the hardscrabble Buffalo rockers turned adult-contempo mainstays are all over Broken; not so much the soggy ""Black Ballon""-era ballad-slinging Dolls
column4: but the scrappy pre-""Iris"" Goos of ""Naked"" or ""Only One"". The longing lead guitars
column5: Snyder's closed-miced confessionals
column6: those everything-is-riding-on-this-moment stakes? Textbook Rzeznik. Despite the current onslaught of 90s revivalism
column7: few bands seemed less primed for cool-kid revivalism than the Goo Goo Dolls. But chasing coolness seems to be just about the last thing on Beach Slang's mind. They're an earnest bunch
column8: and the things they sing about—outsized romances
column9: youthful abandon
column10: feeling pretty good about feeling pretty bad—deserve the kind of big
column11: heartrending
column12: leave-it-all-out-there drama this surging alterna-pop only amplifies. And
column13: between you and me
column14: ""Long Way Down"" still bangs.

column1: Broken is tantalizingly brief: four songs
column2: 10 minutes
column3: and barely a wasted breath. Still
column4: it's not without its flaws: you'd need to consult the dental records to tell the ripcord melodies of ""Filthy Luck"" and ""Kids"" apart
column5: while the limp harmonies that pepper ""Get Lost"" don't quite generate the same kind of heat as the three songs that surround it. But even when their nuts-and-bolts songwriting concerns falter
column6: their passion rarely does: these songs feel like they bounded out of these guys fully formed
column7: brash and urgent and very much alive. The people in Snyder's songs aren't always so good to themselves
column8: but Snyder's awfully good to them: he celebrates their flaws
column9: toasts their smallest successes
column10: holds back their hair after another rough night. It may stick pretty close to the down-and-out
column11: but Broken's a fairly life-affirming record; these people aren't perfect
column12: but they've got time to figure it out. For now
column13: they're accruing scars
column14: gathering stories
column15:
and getting by with a little help from their fucked-up friends.

"|19261.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19261-beach-slang-who-would-ever-want-anything-so-broken-ep/|7.4|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20394/homepage_large.ccc2ada7.jpg|Nordraum|32190.0|Old Wainds|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Negative Existence']|2014-04-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:35.691617|"

We haven’t heard from Old Wainds since 2008
column2: but the Murmansk-based trio remains one of Russia’s greatest musical exports. The port city of Murmansk lies far beyond the Arctic Circle
column3: closer to Finland and Norway than anything else. Its unforgiving climate and overall isolation seems like a perfect breeding ground for raw black metal
column4: and given these frozen surroundings
column5: it’s not difficult to see why Old Wainds’ music has more in common with old-school Scandinavian black metal than much of what their countrymen are currently playing. The band’s approach is thrashy and melodic in equal measure
column6: livening up the tremolo-picked grimness of dyed-in-the-wool Northern European black metal
column7: even as they pay tribute to it. The sound is dynamic
column8: atmospheric
column9: and above all
column10: addictive.

column1: Nordraum
column2: Old Wainds’ fourth album since they formed in 1995
column3: is genuinely catchy and surprisingly listenable; it’s graced with an understated production that lets the ugliness seep through. While earlier material was harsher and more one dimensional
column4: Nordraum remains unrelenting and abrasive without sacrificing finesse. They've managed to stay true to the formula they’ve spent nearly two decades refining. Which isn’t to say it’s the most original record you’ll hear this year: Old Wainds remain the antithesis of trendy or progressive.

column1: The band’s lyrical themes and aesthetic values run far closer to the old traditions
column2: as well
column3: focusing heavily on the Arctic
column4: astrology
column5: and bleakly picturesque depictions of gleaming snow and black moss. Where so many other Russian black metal bands choose to preach hatred and right wing ideology
column6: Old Wainds concern themselves with Slavic mythology
column7: heathenism
column8: and nature. It’s jarring to acknowledge that in their native metal scene the band’s apolitical status is the exception
column9: not the rule
column10: but it’s important to remember that in some places
column11: black metal is still dangerous. (Look up Russia’s Blazebirth Hall collective for ample proof of that.)

column1: Nordraum is their first full-length album to feature English song titles
column2: and save for a 1996 demo and 2003 split with Nav
column3: their only foray into the language. This gives those of us who are ignorant of their native tongue a small
column4: rare glimpse into the band’s inner workings. Despite their far-out titles
column5: songs like “Insane Stellar Race” and “Refracting the Light” owe more to Darkthrone than Roky Erickson
column6: with the violent outpouring of “As Spilled Blood They Sprout” echoing more to the Finnish masters.

column1: There are a few wrinkles. Mini-epic “Stoneweaver” is a marked divergence from the rest of the album with its depressive tempo and pretty guitar work. (The other long song
column2: “Inquiring of Secrecies”
column3: is a straightforward blaster that trips and crawls halfway through.) And “Ascension” opens the album with a few second of ominous synth before Old Wainds unchain the wolves and plunge into the fray. When they do punch in
column4: bassist Kholdogor’s vocals go far beyond the categorical “agonized rasp.” He wheezes painfully
column5: gasping for air like he’s drowning in bile. It’s more desperate than forceful
column6: and finds him sink behind the chiming tremolo like a wounded beast. The guitar work from Morok is sound; it’s not terribly innovative
column7: but it is impassioned
column8: and almost joyous.

column1: This is not a happy album by any stretch of the imagination
column2: but the band’s enthusiasm for the material is apparent. One gets the impression they’ve been champing at the bit to bring these tunes into the world
column3: and have gone about their business with gusto. Eternal “session drummer” Izbor anchors the recording with flair
column4: slipping in more than a few clever ideas amidst his furious assault on the kit. Thanks to his breakneck pace
column5: Nordraum itself flies by so fast that several of the songs blur into one another
column6: and a certain homogenous quality emerges. When all is said and done
column7: it's an excellent slab of traditional-minded black metal with an ear for songwriting. You’ve probably heard it all before
column8: but for those who wish the 2000s had never happened
column9:
it should do the trick.
