column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20493/homepage_large.6de49b79.jpg|Doss EP|32234.0|Doss|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Acéphale']|2014-04-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:36.339473|"

As often happens with new electronic artists
column2: the first two songs from Doss were remixes. At the end of 2012
column3: she released a reworking of How to Dress Well's ""& It Was U"" that darkened the original's empty-warehouse swing
column4: smearing it with a claustrophobia that paired well with the remix's jungle-soaked vibes. A few months later
column5: her remix of Wildarms' ""Full Hearts"" operated in the same nocturnal space as its predecessor but was less portentous—it crossed the finish line with something that resembled catharsis if not straight-up joy.

column1: And then last month ""The Way I Feel"" arrived
column2: the first completely original track from the recent Acéphale signee. What it shares with her earlier remixes is a foundation that leans toward the jungle/drum'n'bass end of the spectrum as well as a reverence for the sounds of early-to-mid 1990s dance music. But ""The Way I Feel""
column3: along with the rest of Doss' self-titled debut EP
column4: is a lot dreamier than either of the remixes that preceded it. The EP maintains a similar sense of propulsion but with a markedly lighter touch
column5: its four tracks gliding effortlessly through the air rather than driving their way through viscous material. The blissed-out Lite-Brite melodicism of trance music can also be heard
column6: except here it's removed from its big-tent origins and retrofitted for a more intimate setting.

column1: ""I don't care about anyone"" Doss sings in a hushed whisper on ""Softpretty""
column2: which swirls with a jubilance seemingly at odds with this sentiment until you realize that it's not lament but rather a timestamp—there might not be a special someone in her life at this very moment
column3: but the yearning in her voice belies a hope that at some point that don't becomes a didn't. ""Here Tonight"" slows things down to a trip-hoppier tempo before unleashing its percussive downpour just past the track's midpoint. It's the heaviest track on the EP
column4: but even here its throbbing low-end is tempered by pastel-colored melodic lines that curl up and into the sky.

column1: ""Extended Mix""
column2: which closes out the EP
column3: stands out for its breathless precision
column4: matching anthemic house chords to a stomp that evokes the sensation that things could careen out of control at any time. It's an evocative end to an EP that mines older sounds not for nostalgia's sake but for thematic material
column5: embracing the fact that euphoria and melancholy are usually jumbled together and probably impossible to separate into pure strains. Her music has been described as ""the true sound of tomorrow""
column6: and based on the evidence here
column7:
I'm almost certain that the irony of tomorrow sounding an awful lot like yesterday is not lost on Doss.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20451/homepage_large.02f0ab38.jpg|Journey On: Collected Singles|26175.0|Songs: Ohia|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2014-04-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:36.972698|"

The fortunes of Secretly Canadian have always been tightly intertwined with those of Jason Molina. In the 1990s
column2: a group of friends in Bloomington
column3: Indiana
column4: heard his debut 7"" for Will Oldham’s Palace Records
column5: fell under the spell of that careening voice
column6: and drove all the way to New York City to sign him. While not the fledgling label’s first release—SC001 is a reissue by North Dakota band June Panic—Molina was Secretly Canadian’s charter signing and would prove to be a franchise artist. Throughout his 15-year career
column7: he built up a formidable catalog first as Songs: Ohia and later as Magnolia Electric Co.
column8: and the label has treated his music with great affection
column9: reverence
column10: and purpose
column11: especially on 2007’s Sojourner
column12: which collected stray Magnolia Electric Co. recordings in a wooden box. After Molina’s sad passing last year following a long battle with alcoholism
column13: Secretly Canadian began reissuing his back catalog
column14: obscure releases and popular albums alike.

column1: The latest posthumous package is Journey On: Collected Singles
column2: which gathers nine of Molina’s first 7"" singles
column3: including that first Palace release
column4: a few one-offs
column5: and his sides of splits with Oneida
column6: Scout Niblett
column7: and Glen Hansard. The vinyl comes in a canvas box with a CD
column8: a wooden turntable adapter emblazoned with his crowssbow insignia
column9: and a booklet with liner notes by Chicago writer Erin Osmon. It’s a handsome set
column10: of course
column11: and essentially a prequel to Sojourner—right down to the pinstriped record sleeves. If Magnolia Electric Co. was specifically an album-oriented project
column12: one that fed into his fascination with Neil Young and other classic rock acts
column13: then Journey On repositions Songs: Ohia as a singles act
column14: one best served by the strictures and confines of the 7"" format. This is not entirely true
column15: of course. Songs: Ohia’s spectral folk music inspired a number of excellent albums during the late 1990s and early 2000s
column16: including its self-titled debut full-length and 1999’s Axxess & Ace.

column1: As Osmon writes
column2: the 7"" medium was chosen as much for its financial benefits as for its aesthetic appeal: “The goal of the 7”? To burn brightly
column3: to share and inspire via a portable format that artists could afford to self-produce and ship and fan kids with shallow pockets could afford to buy at basement shows and ramschackle all-ages joints.” At this stage in his career
column4: it was a good format for Molina
column5: and Journey On reconnects him with this particular DIY scene
column6: even if the collection might outprice such origins. His first release
column7: “Boys
column8: ” was pressed onto a flexidisc for Wingnut magazine
column9: which credited the song to “unknown artist” even as the front cover promised a “giant interview with the cryptic author of ‘Songs: Ohia.’” Nearly twenty years later “Boys” appeared on a flexidisc in Wingnut magazine
column10: it’s hard to imagine how music this mysterious would have originally emerged
column11: or how Molina and others cultivated that sense of shadowy enigma.

column1: “Cryptic” is a perfect description of Molina’s approach to music
column2: as these aren’t songs so much as they are ghost stories
column3: possessed of a campfire intimacy and austere accompaniment. Most feature Molina alone with his guitar
column4: occasionally with the distant patter of drums to suture the melodies together. Jennie Benford
column5: of Jim & Jennie and the Pinetops
column6: occasionally stops by for company
column7: her voice adding a compassionate counterpart to his. Even when Molina plays with a full backing band (sometimes featuring his label founders)
column8: the music sounds skeletal
column9: intimate
column10: hushed
column11: tortured. “Haunted” is a cliché for this style of music
column12: yet there does seem to be some kind of hellhound on his trail; the world presses heavy on these songs. “It’s not just evil that stalks the American sky
column13: ” he sings on “The Gray Tower.” “It’s not just bad luck
column14: it’s just what can happen.” What’s beyond evil? Nothing
column15: and that nothing is much more frightening.

column1: The 7"" format also allowed Molina the freedom to entertain new lyrical and musical concepts without having to fit the results into a longer work or worry about how they compliment other such experiments. Journey On rambles from the lo-fi dirge of “Boys” to the more polished acoustic picking and strumming of “Black Link to Fire Link”
column2: yet he also understood the importance of silence to these songs. The most dramatic moments are when the instruments fall away to leave only his only his voice and the hesitant strums of his electric guitar. On “Keep It Steady
column3: ” the quiet between notes and syllables might even be louder than those notes and syllables.

column1: A few of these songs would not be constrained by the 7"" format. “How to Be Perfect Men”
column2: for example
column3: appeared on 1999’s Axxess & Ace
column4: and “Lioness” anchored 2000’s The Lioness. The emphasis on format
column5: however
column6: means that we can hear these songs in a slightly different context
column7: and “Lioness” in particular resonates with much greater intensity here. The album version sounds like a rock song
column8: with barbed guitar licks and an insistent tempo that underscores the chorus: “You can’t get here fast enough!” By contrast
column9: the Journey On rendition turns the song into a duet
column10: with Benford presumably voicing the title character. The pace plods
column11: as though the moment before consummation is the most vivid aspect of such all-consuming lust. “Whether you save me
column12: whether you savage me
column13: I want my last look to be the moon in your eyes
column14: ” Molina sings
column15: without flinching. It’s impossible to tell which would be preferable
column16: and that ambiguity ranks the song among Molina’s most illuminating recorded moments.

column1: That’s why it’s crucial to listen to these eighteen songs on vinyl. The CD plays like a long
column2: meandering album that gently dulls some of the most intense moments here. To fully grasp these harrowing songs
column3: it’s necessarily to play a side
column4: then flip the record; to unsleeve and resleeve the vinyl between spins; to slip the adapter on and off the spindle; to consider each song individually. This is not a new way to hear Molina–in fact
column5: it’s actually the oldest way to experience his music. Yet
column6:
the process of playing these 7"" singles makes these songs burn more brightly.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20450/homepage_large.7069568a.jpg|P.T.S.D. (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder)|5333.0|Pharoahe Monch|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['W.A.R. Media']|2014-04-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:37.652317|"

Yes
column2: there are plenty of good reasons to assume that an album called <i>P.T.S.D.
column3: that's a metaphor about dealing with the music industry from a veteran rapper's rapper
column4: would be an unbearable missive from the land of butthurt MCs. Pharoahe Monch is a perennial critical favorite and industry underdog who emerged
column5: as half of the group Organized Konfusion
column6: dropping complex multisyllabic rhymes about nebulous geopolitical threats all the way back in 1991
column7: before that was a thing. He is literally who people are talking about when they talk about thoughtful MCs whose rhymes go over audiences' heads
column8: which means he's also more or less the godfather of what's evolved into one of rap's most reliably insufferable styles. On top of that
column9: he's a poster child for the way early '00s record label disorganization completely undercut the careers of a certain set of artists
column10: since it took seven years for him to get out a follow-up to his pugnacious
column11: widely admired 1999 solo debut Internal Affairs.

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: you'll be forgiven for assuming that Pharoahe Monch's new album might just be a mouthpiece for all the concerns of cargo-shorted rap conservatives everywhere. It even opens with a loose sci-fi framing device that seems like a particularly bad omen: Pharoahe Monch has entered “Recollection”
column4: a facility that extracts the memories of traumatic experiences from his brain
column5: and the album will show those memories as they are extracted. But other than a few initial flashes of concern about whether we
column6: as a population
column7: are staying woke enough (“I ask: Are we comatose or unconscious?”)
column8: what follows is
column9: for the most part
column10: Pharoahe creating some of the more emotionally incisive and grounded music of his career. The promised music industry angle is thankfully more or less absent.

column1: The theme that the album returns to most reliably is instead the psychological effects of various traumas
column2: especially the kind that come from living in dangerous and impoverished circumstances—a topic that
column3: despite being the subtext in a lot of rap music
column4: doesn't tend to get addressed explicitly very much in any form of media. On “Lose My Mind”
column5: Pharoahe refers to flashbacks prompted by police sirens and bluntly points out the challenge in the way that this environment is handled: “My family customs were not accustomed to dealing with mental health/it was more or less an issue for white families with wealth.” Elsewhere he touches on the mind-dulling effects of anti-depressants
column6: as well as his own struggles with severe asthma and self-doubt about his career. The album's best song
column7: the soulful
column8: detailed “Broken Again”
column9: is delivered from the point of view of a heroin addict losing his place in society.

column1: The hungry energy that defined Pharoahe when he was younger isn't quite as strong
column2: but there's still a kind of intensity and occasional recklessness that makes him far more interesting than the bulk of currently en vogue young lyrical revivalists. “REM”
column3: a collaboration with the Roots' Black Thought
column4: may be a total boilerplate rap banger with its hook about being “crack music
column5: ” but it's also full of a kind of bravado—including a great bit about Pharoahe growing into a giant so he can pick up the rapper Ma$e and use him as a club to attack other rappers—that's refreshingly old school. The production mostly follows the cheesy
column6: guitar-tinged template seemingly beloved of aging lyricists
column7: but there are a few welcome curveballs
column8: like Quelle Chris's squelching
column9: frenetic beat for “Scream” and Pharoahe's own fascinating contribution
column10: “Heroin Addict”
column11: a tangled spoken-word interlude that could pass for a Gil Scott-Heron outtake.

column1: At the same time
column2: Pharoahe's insatiable desire to craft clever rhymes has always fostered a weakness for corniness
column3: and even the best songs on P.T.S.D. are weighed down with clunkers. He's frequently distracted by wordplay
column4: and other times he comes across like a high school teacher trying to be hip. When things do get really conscious
column5: like on “Eht Dnarg Noisulli”
column6: the result is painfully unsubtle
column7: yielding nonsense like “17
column8: 000 times a day the human eye blinks/ making us even more subjectible to the hijinks.” Stabs at targets like rappers ""making pussy music” on “Bad M.F.” just feel out of touch.

column1: While he might have been able to crack the Hot 100 in 1999
column2: Pharoahe Monch is now about as far from mainstream rap's center as possible. It's hard to imagine ever being compelled to play many of the songs on P.T.S.D. for someone else. But the fundamental lack of coolness here shouldn't do anything to deter fans of Pharoahe Monch or even newcomers who aren't quite sure what they're getting into: It's a rich album that continues to play into the rapper's long-running strengths while taking a more personal
column3: emotional look at the kinds of issues he's traditionally addressed with more inflammatory missives. What Pharoahe Monch is doing may not be as vitally important as it once was
column4:
but it still can feel surprisingly vital.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20441/homepage_large.24907c00.jpg|Ashes to Ashes|32211.0|Final Conflict|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Tankcrimes']|2014-04-23 00:00:00|1987|2016-06-11 16:38:39.039917|"

On any given weekend in the 1980’s
column2: a hardcore turf war threatened to swallow Fenders Ballroom whole. In this cramped shrine
column3: tucked away inside Long Beach’s historic Lafayette hotel
column4: hordes of young people moshed en masse to the likes of Black Flag and Agent Orange. The music was pulverizing
column5: to be sure
column6: but there was much more danger to be found simply by looking around the room. The Suicidals
column7: the South Bay Skins
column8: FFF
column9: Circle One: according to those who were there
column10: these and other rival punk gangs were known to sulk about the space
column11: doling out bloody noses and beat-downs as they saw fit. Muggings and stabbings were not uncommon
column12: nor was the prospect of going to see Bad Brains only to get your brains bashed out.

column1: And yet
column2: even as violence threatened to tear the place apart
column3: the true fury and fervor of Los Angeles' punk scene resided
column4: ironically enough
column5: in the music of peacenik bands like Final Conflict
column6: who were among the first to successfully augment the crude power of hardcore with sleek
column7: sophisticated musicianship. Formed by guitarist and principal songwriter Jeff Harp in 1983
column8: the Long Beach quartet enlisted elements of thrash
column9: black metal
column10: and d-beat to lend their minute-long manifestoes an essential
column11: acrid urgency. In 1987
column12: they released their pulverizing debut album
column13: Ashes to Ashes—a venom-soaked takedown of the Reagan years
column14: as well as one of the decade's best crossover releases. Since its original pressing by Pusmort
column15: the album has seen three more reissues
column16: including one from Relapse.  Now
column17: with Tankcrimes' Record Store Day reissue
column18: Ashes to Ashes returns for its fifth lap around the ring
column19: just as sprightly and scowling as when it loped into our lives over a quarter-century ago.

column1: During the height of the Orange County hardcore scene
column2: bands' lists of influencers typically included their fellow Californians
column3: along with NYC acts like Reagan Youth  Final Conflict's palette
column4: on the other hand
column5: combined the fever-pitch intensity of  UK crust-punk pioneers like Discharge and Amebix with the grizzled black metal of Crucifix. The ramped-up intensity and increased emphasis on technically-proficient solos enabled the band to carve out a newer
column6: more brutal niche from the existing framework
column7: lying somewhere between thrash's reptile-brain party mode and the tempered rage of heavy metal.

column1: Jack Control's robust remaster creates some much-needed space
column2: allowing Harp's toothed guitars to mingle alongside Warren Renfrow's nimble bass riffs
column3: rather than overwhelm them. Dave Phillip's drumming sounds more hot-blooded this time around
column4: too
column5: firing off snare hits into the abyss at the start of ""Apocalypse Now!"" and striking a throttling gallop on ""Crucifixion"". Control places Ron Martinez's vocal track lowest in the mix
column6: so that at any given point
column7: he's yowling from between his bandmates' slabs of sound like a trapped and wounded beast. These contrasts distinguish Ashes to Ashes as a work determined to distance itself from its more unilateral-sounding peers
column8: providing enough smatterings of depth and texture to please even the most punk-a-phobic eardrums. It's a hardcore album
column9: all right
column10: but between Control's ear-friendly Mix and Harp's penchant for turbo-charged
column11: hooky refrains on songs like ""Abolish Police"" and ""Constant Fear
column12: there's enough pop appeal here to lure  in the Tony Hawk Pro Skater Soundtrack fanatics.

column1: As the cover art suggests
column2: the hand of the doomsday clock sits dangerously close to midnight for the entirety of Ashes to Ashes. Corrupt cops
column3: rainforest-gutting corporations
column4: the Reagan administration
column5: the atomic bomb: disturbing images abound on the record
column6: often sketched in excruciating detail. On “Constant Fear”
column7: Martinez describes man’s annihilation by nuclear warhead through the sensuous image of “smoldering flesh underneath crumbling structures.” Elsewhere
column8: “Abolish Police” and  “Self-Righteous Pigs” plaster the walls with grotesques of authority figures “playing hero” with civilian lives. The band even takes part in a little aural graffiti for the album’s closer
column9: tearing down a sample of Reagan on the campaign trail with an instrumental sucker-punch.

column1: A single listen of the included 1985 demo of the album (even more blistered and rabid than the studio version) sufficiently proves that even a quarter-century after its release
column2: Ashes to Ashes continues to burn with a ferocity of which few hardcore albums can boast. There's no doubt that Final Conflict's rage has matured somewhat the passage of time (Trash Talk they ain't)
column3: but it's comforting to know that the white-hot fury of the band's Fenders Ballroom gigs hasn't retreated an inch. Long after the demise of L.A.'s infamous punk gangs
column4:
the poetic violence of Final Conflict's debut hits hardest of all.

"|19236.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19236-final-conflict-ashes-to-ashes/|7.8|Zoe Camp

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20481/homepage_large.62177ea2.jpg|Weird Drift|31066.0|Heterotic|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2014-04-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:40.291084|"

Half the fun of listening to Heterotic’s Weird Drift is trying to pin down exactly what kind of record it is. On their second album together
column2: Planet Mu founder Mike Paradinas (aka µ-Ziq) and his wife Lara Rix-Martin flirt with a dozen or more styles and subgenres without settling on any particular one for very long. The opening track
column3: “Self Importance
column4: ” with its pulsating arpeggios and reverb-y synth strings
column5: oscillates between 1980s acid house and '80s horror movie soundtrack vibes; from there
column6: they make their way through gothy ambience
column7: funky electro-pop
column8: and sleek techno.

column1: Despite Weird Drift's genre-busting ambitions
column2: the album feels humble and unpretentious. Paradinas has been making music for so long and in so many different styles that he has very little left to prove to anyone
column3: so there’s nothing ostentatious or show-offy about the record’s genre excursions. And although Rix-Martin doesn’t have as many credits under her belt as her husband
column4: her work curating his 2013 retrospective anthology Somerset Avenue Tracks (1992-1995) showed a refined
column5: understated taste and an intuitive ear. They seem like smoothly synergistic collaborators
column6: and even at its most adventurous Weird Drift still has a comfortably casual air.

column1: There are a few beautiful moments where that casual energy manifests beyond a series of pop references. “Rain” nails a specifically airy
column2: chilly sound with an effortlessness that countless British pop-R&B bands in the late '80s would have killed for
column3: while “Lumber” balances a distorted rap beat and layers of ethereal vocals in a compellingly crooked way
column4: resembling a new twist on trip-hop transmitted through a low-fi pirate radio frequency. Quasi-dub cut “Foghorn” interrupts a the album’s generally well-mannered mood with a resinous reggae bass line and blaring
column5: Inception-style low brass that drift blissfully through clouds of Detroit techno synths and Funkadelic-style acid-rock solos.

column1: Heterotic's easygoing experimentation provides one of Weird Drift’s strongest aspects
column2: but it also works to the duo's disadvantage. The album’s peripatetic stylistic wandering takes it to interesting places
column3: but it also lacks a cohesive aesthetic identity--it
column4: well
column5: drifts. When Paradinas and Rix-Martin head in a pop-focused direction
column6: it sounds great in the moment but the hooks aren’t sharp enough to stick around afterwards. Largely
column7: the album doesn’t possess much in the way of gravity or edge.

column1: The album finally finds the focus that it needs on the last song
column2: “Empires”
column3: which is ironically the record's sole moment where it also enters clichéd territory. A piano twinkles over slow-changing chords and a gently thumping kick drum
column4: elements that skirt banality when paired with the inspirational mood conjured up by the arrangement's gently rising and falling action. The song sounds like something from a soundtrack for a feel-good sports movie
column5:
but it resonates in a way that the rest of Weird Drift fails to.

"|19273.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19273-heterotic-weird-drift/|6.8|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20461/homepage_large.cd5fcb99.jpg|Boring Ecstasy: The Bedroom Pop of Orchid Tapes|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Orchid Tapes']|2014-04-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:41.055652|"

When the artists releasing music through Brooklyn-based label Orchid Tapes talk about the imprint
column2: it sounds like they are describing a support group instead of a business. “It’s the idea that anything good enough
column3: no matter how much publicity or fans the artist has gathered
column4: deserves love and attention
column5: ” said Infinity Crush's Caroline White in a recent interview. “It feels like a bunch of friends.” Boring Ecstasy: The Bedroom Pop of Orchid Tapes serves as a strong introduction to this tight-knit community
column6: and highlights what makes it stand out during a time when anyone with Internet access can conceivably start a label.

column1: A devotion to intimacy and earnestness unites the musicians on Orchid Tapes
column2: and those qualities have been part of the label’s DNA since Warren Hildebrand
column3: who's also behind the dreamy Foxes in Fiction project
column4: founded Orchid Tapes in 2010. Initially
column5: he created it as a way to release his debut album Swung From the Branches in a physical format)
column6: but soon Hildebrand connected with other bedroom-based artists via Myspace. Since then
column7: his label's released music from the likes of Coma Cinema and Ricky Eat Acid
column8: whose Three Love Songs served as their first vinyl release earlier this year.

column1: Ricky Eat Acid kicks off Boring Ecstasy with “Can You See It’s Bloom”
column2: a woozy ambient-pop track that is one of two instrumental songs here. The other
column3: Los Angeles producer Meishi Smile’s “Sincerity”
column4: bookends the compilation on a fluttery
column5: bittersweet note. The collection never settles for one particular style
column6: instead letting each artist construct their own world without having to worry what’s happening around them
column7: so the back-porch strumming of Alex G’s “Cards” co-exists peacefully with the drum-machine jitters of Julia Brown’s “Without You”.

column1: The thread that ties many of Boring Ecstasy's contributors together is a neck-breathing closeness. Hildebrand’s contribution as Foxes in Fiction
column2: “Rearrange”
column3: slowly builds up from washes of guitar
column4: but even as the music ebbs and flows
column5: his words float through. Wisconsin-born
column6: Berlin-based artist Yohuna delivers one of Boring Ecstasy’s most memorable cuts with the slow-burning “Badges
column7: ” which mixes synthesizers with her stretched-out vocals to create something radiating warmth.

column1: There are missteps: Euphoria Again’s “Change” is one of the most stripped-down numbers here
column2: but it lags
column3: while The Sweater I Gave You’s “Nobody’s Baby” is too cluttered
column4: taking away from the Oregon project’s usual charm. Daniel Abary’s Four Visions makes the noisier approach work better on “Hazy Past”
column5: an appropriately fuzz-tinged song prone to moments of clatter that constantly shifts instead of succumbing to tedium. Infinity Crush’s “Spoiled” is nothing more than White’s singing and some guitar
column6: but she delivers both with unblinking directness
column7: punctuated by self-targeted lines like “I feel like shit/ We know
column8: get over it.”

column1: “Spoiled’s” lyrics touch on the other important aesthetic pillar of the artists affiliated with Orchid Tapes: they aren’t shy about baring their feelings
column2: so Boring Ecstasy focuses on love gained and lost
column3: usually against the backdrop of everyday happenings. “What’s the point of the leaves changing color/ I can’t watch them change with you
column4: ” Julia Brown’s Sam Ray sings on ""Without You""
column5: the words out of step with the music surrounding it
column6: underlining the desperation contained within. “The overall idea that we try to go for is releasing music by people who are really dedicated and put a lot of themselves into their music and don't try to follow any passing Internet trends or anything

Much of the intrigue surrounding Future’s debut album Pluto fixated on the voice: raw and emotive
column4: possessed of both a forlorn R&B Lothario’s despondency and the gruff yawp of a drug-runner celebrating a sold out batch
column5: and shellacked in a thick
column6: forbidding coat of Auto-Tune and reverb. Coupled with a penchant for interstellar iconography
column7: the vocal modification frequently attracted science fiction descriptors
column8: portraits of the artist as a moody machine. But Pluto’s most gripping cuts (“Turn on the Lights”
column9: “You Deserve It”) took flight by scaling back the mods to focus on the unnerving frailty of a singer unafraid to skim around and across the break in his voice. Even in moments where Pluto’s vocals were heavily processed
column10: the most captivating quality was the humanity poking through. So let’s set aside this robot business.

column1: Pluto’s greatest success was opening new avenues in Future’s songwriting. At the time
column2: his calling card was the trap house shouter: 2011–12 mixtape highlights “Tony Montana”
column3: “Magic”
column4: and “Same Damn Time” delivered dopeboy truisms via battering ram. Pluto collected those cuts for good measure
column5: but otherwise it dispensed with the tough guy shit
column6: reintroducing Future as a lovelorn hook man. As with Kanye’s 808s & Heartbreak
column7: the transition from rapping to singing was smoothed out by a T-painian dollop of purposefully overdriven pitch correcting tech and confessional emotionalism. The gambit worked
column8: but the album was a touch too reliant on its crutches in retrospect. After a protracted streak of hijacking Top 40 smashes like “U.O.E.N.O.” and “Bugatti”
column9: spitballing weirdness out on mixtapes
column10: and farming his more saccharine ideas out to pure singers from Justin Bieber and Miley Cyrus to Rihanna and his fiance Ciara
column11: Future finally returns with his second proper full-length
column12: Honest.

column1: Future’s got a notably greater command of his instrument two years on from Pluto
column2: and to that end
column3: much of the Auto-Tune and reverb that occasionally gave the first album’s vocals the distance of a radio transmission have been scrubbed. The training wheels are off. Fight songs like “My Momma” and “Covered N Money” draw their intensity from the quirky sound of a voice giving out screaming the titular choruses
column4: a trick perfected on the searing pre-album street single “SH!T”. Flubbed notes are left in for character rather than squeegeed out by computers
column5: but there’s less of those than ever because writing for and performing alongside other singers has worked wonders for Future’s range. The rousing upper register chorus for “Blood
column6: Sweat
column7: Tears” and the slick falsetto hook on “Honest” wouldn’t have worked with his voice before. “Never Satisfied” refuses to let Drake do the heavy lifting as Future confidently soars past the Toronto MC’s introspective vocalizing in between choruses. And where guests were once employed to secure a measure of credibility
column8: now they hover in Future’s orbit: Drake gets faded out mid-chorus on the two-minute “Never Satisfied”
column9: and even when Kanye parks the Kardashian roadshow in back of “I Won”
column10: he sticks to the script.

column1: Honest relinquishes Pluto’s romantic tendencies as well
column2: retaining a personal bent without resorting to pining for affection to achieve it. In a recent interview with Pitchfork
column3: Future said flatly
column4: “There are no love songs on this album
column5: ” although mid-album stunners “I Won” and “I Be U” teem with pride and excitement about meeting the mate he yearned for on “Turn Out the Lights”. Otherwise
column6: Honest prefers to buck expectations by sneering through the slow jams. Deep cut “Special” is all somber strummed guitars and taunts for an ex who couldn’t handle the fame. (“You ain’t even tryin’ to be special.”) The title track uses a sedate piano-filled production from DJ Spinz and Metro Boomin to coolly revel in newfound wealth and status in a wan
column7: sad deadpan. (“I’m a rock star for life
column8: I’m just being honest.”) Honest is consistently moneyed and aspirational in all the places you might’ve previously expected sap.

column1: Future’s eagerness to escape his old tics and methods also means moving away from trap. There’s still room for grisly
column2: gothic stompers from a murderer’s row of 808 architects from Nard & B to Sonny Digital and 808 Mafia
column3: but Honest’s production is expansive. “Look Ahead” outfits a sample of Amadou and Mariam’s Santigold-assisted “Dougou Badia” with kicks
column4: claps
column5: and guitars for a powerhouse opening argument for Future’s growth. Fresh off a year of platinum hits
column6: frequent collaborator Mike WiLL Made It has gotten weird: he approximates Noah “40” Shebib’s pulsating bass and muted drums on “Never Satisfied” and affixes rattling low end to the gritty
column7: almost atonal synths of “Move That Dope” like a Southern rap Trent Reznor. The album closes with “Blood
column8: Sweat
column9: Tears”
column10: a sermon about the fruits of perseverance delivered over martial drums and wrenching strings specifically designed
column11: it would seem
column12: to blow the lid off arenas.

column1: The searching stream of mixtapes and loosies that followed Pluto appeared to many to signify a struggle to maintain footing in an industry notorious for feeding on Atlanta rap sensations and casting them aside once the hits dry up. But Honest surges with the self-assurance of an artist finally coming into his own. The bruisers are icepick sharp
column2: the ballads restlessly toy with convention
column3: and Future’s heightened ease with both makes Pluto look like a transitional album in retrospect
column4: the dress rehearsal for this
column5:
the actual takeover.

Has anyone ever accused David Lynch of making background music? It seems unlikely—sound design is such an integral part of his filmmaking that it usually says as much as the images. That’s why it was apt that the soundtrack for his early film Eraserhead merely presented unedited stretches of the movie’s audio. Those excerpts contain enough information
column3: moods
column4: and atmosphere to create meaning on their own
column5: without needing any help from pictures.

column1: The Air Is on Fire is trickier
column2: because the sound Lynch made for it literally is background music. It played on two floors of a Paris gallery during a 2007 exhibition of Lynch’s visual art. While I imagine Lynch and sound editor Dean Hurley didn’t intend their work as background—they’ve called it an “interactive soundscape”—the setting gave them less control over the marriage of sound and image than film offers. Few visitors would hear the exact same thing while looking at any given piece of art
column3: and whether any would absorb the entire 41-minute soundtrack in real time was out of Lynch’s hands. Those factors increase the range of effects the piece could have—practically to infinity—but they also increase the chances that it would be experienced as sonic wallpaper.

column1: You might guess that such indeterminancy wouldn’t deter Lynch from packing as much narrative and emotional density into The Air Is on Fire as he does in his films
column2: and you’d be right. In fact
column3: though I would’ve loved to see the original installation
column4: I’m glad my first encounter with this was as one continuous piece divorced from imagery. Because there’s more than enough going on inside it to capture attention and encourage focused listening. There are literal events—knocks
column5: wind
column6: footsteps
column7: thunder—that suggest plot points
column8: and tangible atmospheres that set scenes. It may be cliche to call instrumental music “cinematic
column9: ” but The Air Is on Fire clearly has the sequential
column10: impressionistic effect of film. It’s a movie projected into the head through the ears.

column1: Part of what makes it so cinematic is the way it balances the narrative and the abstract
column2: much like Lynch’s films. There are clear steps and turns
column3: obvious moves forward and significant retreats. But there are also moments of pure texture
column4: in which creating an indefinite feeling is more important than painting a specific picture. There are points in between
column5: too
column6: and those are the most fascinating: a section that sounds like a slowed-down show tune underwater
column7: a rumble that could either be the echo of a cave or the ghosts of human voices
column8: a dramatic turn that’s like a symphonic string section shot into space. As all these elements melt into one uniterrupted stream
column9: it’s easy to enjoy as sonic drift
column10: as a dark river to float down. But focus your ears a bit and more profound
column11: moving moments emerge.

column1: How Lynch and Hurley compare in those moments to musicians more seasoned at this kind of music is a tough question. I’m sure much of what they do here has been done by others; the blackened caves of Demdike Stare and the Haxan Cloak come to mind immediately. But really
column2: Lynch has developed as deep a sonic vocabulary as anyone - he’s just done it through an audiovisual medium rather than a purely aural one. And besides
column3: it doesn't sound like he was worried about breaking ground here. Even at its densest
column4: The Air Is on Fire is pretty simple sonically
column5: which gives it a universal tone. It’s not about cutting-edge techniques or never-heard-before concoctions. It’s about using sound to tell a wordless story and evoke undefined emotions. On those counts
column6:
it succeeds thoroughly.

Almost every song on Loom
column2: Fear of Men’s full-length debut
column3: includes a reference to water. The narrator in these songs risks being consumed
column4: overwhelmed
column5: sunk like a stone
column6: or washed away completely. The drowned romanticism of the band’s lyrics (“I tried my best to destroy you but the waves/ Keep overflowing me/ Washing me out ‘till I’m empty”) is reflected in their music as well—a kind of delicate
column7: twilight indie pop swirl that belies the heady darkness that seems to always be simmering just underneath. At first listen
column8: Loom plays like an appropriately wistful dream pop cousin to Young Marble Giants or the Marine Girls (or something resembling Camera Obscura’s awkward stepsister). But underneath all the jingle-jangling guitars and twee musical meanderings
column9: Fear of Men are quietly seething—a prim librarian who just happens to carry a warm switchblade in her book bag.

column1: Fear of Men is essentially the work of two mindful British art students: Jessica Weiss (guitarist and vocalist) and Daniel Falvey (guitarist). Taking their name from a rare anxiety disorder (“androphobia” is an abnormal and persistent fear of men)
column2: the band set about making songs that took on mortality
column3: mental illness
column4: and loneliness and set them against a melodic backdrop of Smiths-like guitars. The fruits of the band’s early efforts were collected into an aptly named 2013 collection called Early Fragments
column5: a release that showcased the band’s ability to marry the beautiful with the slyly profane. It’s a concept the band pushes even further on Loom. When Weiss sings “Lie alone until the dark takes it all/ Without a body
column6: I am free to dissolve
column7: ” it’s a fitting descriptor of the band’s aesthetic: Personal melancholy and romantic dread loom large
column8: while an ever-present ocean of ambiguously deep feelings threatens to wash everything away.

column1: Musically
column2: Loom is a nice step forward. “Green Sea” and “Seer”—both of which appeared previously on Fragments—sound bigger and bolder here
column3: each benefiting from more assured production. The record’s best songs—“Inside” and “Descent” among them—balance the record’s darkest lyrical sentiments against it’s brightest melodies
column4: which generally proves to be Fear of Men’s neatest trick. Though the band’s committed DIY aesthetic is admirable—they employ a strict hands-on approach to everything
column5: from the production of the music to the album art to the band’s videos—the music might be better served by the help of an outside producer. This is far and away a more sanguine listening experience than anything the band has recorded before
column6: but even with the addition of a full-time drummer (Michael Miles) and a live bassist (Becky Wilkie)
column7: the rhythm section can’t deliver the kind of punch the material demands. And the album’s shimmery sameness (and turgid melancholy) eventually starts to feel a bit rote.

column1: When the band does cut loose
column2: as they do on the sublime “America”
column3: the albums’s best track
column4: you get a sense where they might go next. The song veers from gentle strummer and escapist fantasy to something resembling heaviness
column5: with diaphanous guitar lines momentarily giving way to a bit of roiling feedback and what sounds like a tiny little amp being mercilessly overdriven. It’s a rare moment of abandon. Fear of Men are likely never going to shred riotously
column6: blow up their gear
column7:
or even raise their voices to anything resembling a scream—they simply aren’t that kind of band—but here’s hoping that all that well-considered vitriol in Weiss’ lyrics might eventually bleed over into their music.

When Death’s meager
column2: forgotten discography from the 70s began to be unearthed in 2009
column3: it made sense to peg the group as proto-punk. In fact
column4: the first Death collection
column5: …For the Whole World to See
column6: went out of its way to reinforce this image. Here were a trio of African-American brothers from Detroit who—before the Ramones had released a record—laid down a lean
column7: ferocious form of rock'n'roll. But even that initial anthology of songs
column8: as carefully as it was curated

column10: Mental

column1: The selling of Death as a proto-punk band certainly helped the long-lost group catch the attention of modern listeners
column2: especially now that they’ve reformed (minus their late leader
column3: guitarist David Hackney). But with their third archival release
column4: Death III
column5: it’s become even clearer that Death had much more than spit and snarl up their sleeves. “North Street” pulses and pounces
column6: but it does so fluidly—and with a bluesy lasciviousness that’s more Thin Lizzy than the Stooges. That aggression carries over into “Restlessness”
column7: a pummeling confessional that melds the homegrown chops of David
column8: bassist-vocalist Bobby Hackney
column9: and drummer Dannis Hackney into a smoothly pneumatic machine. And while the drumless demos “Introduction by David” and “Free” show off little more than searing tones and promising ideas
column10: they’re not significantly sketchier than the studio tracks “Yes He’s Coming”
column11: with its tinges of echoing
column12: off-kilter gospel
column13: and “Open Road”
column14: an awkward
column15: start-stop speed-waltz that highlights Death at their least together and coherent. Death always reached for something just beyond their collective talent
column16: and that’s both the strength and weakness of these recordings—and a reflection of David’s lifelong
column17: and ultimately frustrated
column18: quest toward a spiritual ideal.

column1: The 2013 documentary A Band Called Death simultaneously reinforces and undermines the image of Death as punk godfathers. Even as the word “punk” gets bandied loosely about in the film
column2: some of David’s gentlest compositions
column3: “We Are Only People” and “We’re Gonna Make It”
column4: are featured prominently in the soundtrack. Death III includes both those songs: “We Are Only People” is a spacious guitar meditation that starts out sounding like an interlude off a Hendrix bootleg before morphing into a sprawl of raw yet progressive funk
column5: something Earth
column6: Wind & Fire might have made in the 70s if they’d been a stripped-down
column7: lo-fi garage band. “We’re Gonna Make It” hails from 1992
column8: when the brothers briefly reunited; sweetly clunky
column9: it’s a nugget of uplifting pop-rock—with an almost countrified undertone—that’s poignant because of its corniness
column10: not despite it.

column1: When you take into account the Hackneys’ full body of work—from their R&B outfit that existed before Death
column2: RockFire Funk Express
column3: to their Christian-rock outfit that existed after Death
column4: the 4th Movement—it becomes clear that the “punk” tag they’ve been saddled with is as inaccurate as it is limiting. Even defining punk in its broadest terms
column5: as an ethic rather than an aesthetic
column6: doesn’t cover what Death was truly about. They were in many ways uncompromising—but as Death III shows
column7: they were just as happy to make sweet
column8: pleasing music in the hopes of reaching a larger audience. That conflict of sound and approach
column9: a symptom of the group’s internal tensions as musicians and as siblings
column10: makes these songs both more soulful and tougher to cram in a pigeonhole. The best thing about Death III is that it finally unravels the narrative set up by their previous two albums: that Death was a punk band
column11: one that in some way may have even helped invent punk. It’s an absurd notion
column12: and one that sells short what the Hackney Brothers actually accomplished. The truth is much messier
column13:
and much more beautiful.

London-based electronic artist and self-taught pianist Tourist
column3: whose real name is William Phillips
column4: first surfaced on Myspace in 2010 as Little Loud. He had a baby-faced selfie profile picture and a few tracks to his name: an 80s-tinged Balearic remix of Ariel Pink’s “Round and Round”
column5: an Acéphale-commissioned rework of Memory Tapes’ “Bicycle”
column6: and another version of HEALTH’s “Nice Girls” as part of a companion remix album to their Disco2. His remixes were pretty standard—add a 4/4 beat and chopped-up vocals to any song
column7: sit back
column8: and watch it go to number one on Hype Machine—but an artistic sensibility
column9: however indefinable
column10: began to emerge.

column2: Phillips released his first EP under the new moniker Tourist: Placid Acid
column3: four songs of sun-dazed beats and melodies that shifted and sparkled like the equatorial sun on a calm sea. It was a pleasant debut
column4: if not very distinctive from other blissed-out jams with cutesy names
column5: like Slow Magic’s “Corvette Cassette”
column6: which made similar Soundcloud rounds the year before. Six months later
column7: Phillips changed approaches with a remix of Sharon Van Etten’s chronicle of a panic attack
column8: “We Are Fine”. He replaced Van Etten’s ukulele with throbbing
column9: haunted synths and skittering percussion
column10: hinting at a developing emotional and musical complexity that in turn foreshadowed Tourist’s 2013 Tonight EP.

column1: “You know a Venn diagram
column2: Phillips told Billboard earlier this year. ""My left circle would be electronic music and the right circle would be emotions
column3: atmosphere
column4: honesty.” It’s not the most unique thought—you’d be hard-pressed to find an artist
column5: electronic or otherwise
column6: claiming not to care about those things—but the idea gets at something he started doing very well in the beginning of last year. There’s a newfound sense of longing and urgency in the minor chords and driving pulse of an elegant banger like “Never Stop”
column7: which undoubtedly helped get him signed to Disclosure’s Method label last summer. Tourist then released a string of higher-profile indie remixes (Haim
column8: Chvrches
column9: Sam Smith) in the lead-up to his Patterns EP
column10: which was steadily pushed back from a December release date to give Tourist more time to reinvent himself on the tour circuit as well.

column1: The most immediately noticeable difference between the Disclosure-affiliated Tourist and the Tourist formerly known as Little Loud is guest vocalists. Album closer “I Can’t Keep Up” features singer and occasional saxophonist Will Heard
column2: who most notably appeared on Klangkarussell’s soulful UK hit “Sonnentanz”. With Tourist at the helm
column3: Heard takes a darker turn
column4: asking
column5: “Won’t somebody give a fuck?” as the producer ramps up tension with a quickening pulse that rockets to 130 BPM before just as suddenly slowing down again. “I refuse to fall
column6: ” Heard sings
column7: the last word echoing as if he’s already tumbling into the abyss. The title track
column8: which opens with scattershot ping-pong synths straight out of SBTRKT’s playbook
column9: is led by Lianne La Havas. Phillips doesn’t seem to know quite what to do with her here
column10: supplementing her buttery voice with a background chorus that’s ultimately more distracting than anthemic.

column1: “Trust in You” eases into Patterns with cascading vocal samples and judicious xylophones
column2: its clickety-split backing track setting the EP’s overall urgent tone that finds full expression in “Together”
column3: Tourist’s most ambitious effort to date. His first release after signing to Method (and Patterns’ lead single) is something of a coming-out party
column4: Phillips busting through any preconceived notions of him as an artist with a hi-NRG gallop riding the irresistibly universal refrain “We should be together.” It’s masterfully crafted
column5: from the restrained fade-in and exhausted fade-out to the arpeggiated synths that take it to the bridge
column6: quietly bow out
column7: and then resurface for the final sprint to the finish line.

column1: For the first time
column2: it sounds like Tourist has something to lose: in that same interview with Billboard
column3: he said
column4: “There’s something dangerous about getting big because you make your success on certain defining records.” With “Together”—and Patterns in general
column5:
which sets a promising tone for Tourist's continued artistic development—he may have found that record.

On a spitting grey evening last week
column4: I went to Rough Trade's new record store in Williamsburg to see what's being called an ""interactive gallery exhibition"" in honor of LCD Soundsystem. It showcased a small shrine to the band—replete with candles
column5: flowers
column6: and an empty bottle of Jameson—alongside some framed photos
column7: a flat screen TV playing the 2012 documentary Shut Up and Play the Hits on mute
column8: and a glitchy projection of random home-movie style footage of the group. There were also five portable Numark turntables set up
column9: each spinning one of the discs from the box-set chronicle of their 2011 finale
column10: The Long Goodbye: LCD Soundsystem Live at Madison Square Garden. The whole white-walled room felt like a well-intentioned relic—a cheap museum piece that barely hinted at the too-recent memories it was designed to revive. The same could be said of the entire Rough Trade store
column11: which has all of the hallmarks of Tower Records of yore—plenty of space
column12: high retail prices
column13: huge promo posters—but now with an added level of desperate nostalgia. The visit left me a bit dulled—experiencing the halfhearted fossilization of your youth will do that. But something less soul-shattering stuck with me
column14: too.

column1: Stamped onto the wall above the LCD shrine were little hand-written love notes to the band by fans who had previously stopped by the space. Some were weird (""James
column2: I once rubbed your back at a ramen restaurant
column3: it was so creepy and so awesome"")
column4: some gushed (""James Murphy is my David Bowie"")
column5: and some were all too real (""Thanks for making me realize that it was OK that I hadn't achieved my goals by the age of 25""). More than anything else in the room
column6: those scrawled bits of Sharpie resonated
column7: and they reminded me of the crowd noise that hums underneath much of The Long Goodbye's 187 minutes. That last LCD show was as much of a party as a concert
column8: an extended celebration of goodwill
column9: good taste
column10: and the fact that something so relentlessly sharp and gracious could reach such a rarified place within the culture. It was also really long. Which made sense. LCD Soundsystem were not a greatest hits band. They were band for completists
column11: by completists. This is one reason why The Long Goodbye is such an apt punctuation. It is a largely unedited document of everything this band had to offer: the laughs
column12: the tears
column13: the disco
column14: the rock
column15: the cowbell
column16: the deep cuts. And if you were to listen to this five-disc set front-to-back on a turntable
column17: you'd need to flip or change the record a total of nine times—a very serious commitment in today's stream of endless one-click playlists.

column1: Speaking of vinyl
column2: it is no coincidence that this item is originally seeing life as one of those Record Store Day specials. Along with its superfan collectibility
column3: the box's presentation is spare
column4: monochrome
column5: and elegant
column6: and Murphy tweaked the audio with needles and grooves in mind. ""We're totally not making a CD of this or anything
column7: because it's not 1997
column8: he quips on a tiny square download card. And while The Long Goodbye will get a digital release next month
column9: he stresses that ""it's really mixed for vinyl."" Having heard both the WAV files and LPs
column10: I can report that the overall experience is indeed different. While the computer version retains more clarity
column11: the sound on the records gives into the live-wire atmosphere of the actual show—the low tones in particular are noticeably fatter
column12: gloriously smudging into everything else. Along with Pat Mahoney's tireless drumming
column13: Tyler Pope's bass provides a rubbery rhythmic backbone from which the rest of the band is allowed to explode. Murphy was smart to highlight this controlled chaos in this mix
column14: because it offers a distinct
column15: refreshing contrast to LCD's studio records
column16: which are often marked by deadpan dryness along with a watchmaker's attention to detail. Live
column17: though
column18: Murphy and his crew are more excitable and woolier—it's where the frontman can get out of his own self-conscious mind for few hours and get lost in the beats and emotions around him. This feeling is contagious.

column1: And it's found all across The Long Goodbye. Song of the Century contender ""All My Friends"" benefits from edging perilously close to breaking apart at the seams
column2: its smile-to-cry ratio more perfect than ever; ""Time to Get Away"" speeds up and morphs from something slinky into a monolith of funk; ""Daft Punk Is Playing at My House"" turns into a giddy rush of imagined robots and punk rock synths; Murphy ditches his early stuffed-nose Mark E. Smith affectations as ""Movement"" reminds you that LCD Soundsystem are a better straight-up punk band than almost any other straight-up punk band; 45:33's ""You Can't Hide (Shame on You)""
column3: with singer/comedian Reggie Watts on pitch-perfect guest vocals

column5: a TV show that could easily be subtitled ""New York

column9: and in many ways ""Louie"" has taken on the affably-fucked-white-guy baton Murphy left behind more than any band. And just as ""Louie"" can hit deep emotional chords within an unlikely milieu of strange sex

column11: and fart jokes

column13: trying to make the beats pump harder because they're always one step closer to the big goodbye. This set highlights that fleeting fleshiness—the paradox of creating something timeless while thousands of people run out of time together.

column10: an elite coffee blend
column11: and a <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/51741-watch-james-murphy-in-conversation-about-the-soundsystem-he-designed-with-soulwax/"">50
column12: 000-watt custom sound system—hasn't tried to match the impact of LCD in any sense
column13: it's managed to stay true to the LCD ethos by remaining singular and impassioned; while you or I may not get the same high from sipping a perfect cup of coffee as we do from listening to ""All My Friends"" for the thousandth time

column17:
we can still come home to this.

The Voyager probes
column2: launched within less than a month of each other in 1977
column3: were pushed into space at a time when optimism about exploring the universe was still on a relentless upswing. In 2014 you’re just as likely to read about NASA budget cuts as you are about the upcoming wave of space tourism. Now
column4: it seems
column5: the limitations of our galaxy have been embraced
column6: perhaps as a way to deal with the crushing reality that there might not be much out there after all. Those forthcoming suborbital flights
column7: aimed at non-astronauts
column8: barely go anywhere at all
column9: which speaks volumes for how much the dream of widespread space exploration has been reined in. Space Project is a compilation album released for Record Store Day that links back to the Voyager era
column10: taking recordings made by Voyager I and II of “electromagnetic radiation fluctuations in the magnetosphere of the planets
column11: moons
column12: and large asteroids
column13: ” which have been handed over to a variety of artists to construct music around.

column1: As an overall work it’s easy to trace a hint of nostalgia that runs through this record
column2: framing it as a return to the wide-eyed view of space that purposefully ignores the workaday nature of current developments. As such
column3: the lineup mostly feels appropriate
column4: with Youth Lagoon’s sci-fi blues represented
column5: and Jason Pierce (recording as the Spiritualized Mississippi Space Program) working up his narcotized astronaut persona. The drone-like Voyager recordings are largely inconsequential and often hard to detect—maybe that rumbling sound at the beginning and end of Porcelain Raft’s pretty ambient instrumental “Giove” is one of them; perhaps that gentle hum that underpins the quietly menacing “Moonlet” by Zomes is from some distant planet. It doesn’t matter too much
column6: although it does appear that the crude base material these artists were given has worked to unify Space Project in a way that most compilations can’t reach.

column1: The default mode most of the musicians operate in here is firmly set to “sad
column2: reflective”—as you might expect from a cursory glance at the artists involved. But thought and care has clearly gone into the sequencing
column3: which is another thing that sets it apart from similar ventures. So it goes from the Cocteaus-like lullaby of the Holydrug Couple’s “Amphitrites Lost”
column4: through a piano-bar-at-the-end-of-the-world lament (Blues Control’s “Blues Danube”)
column5: and ends with a couple of typically pristine DFA affiliated acts (Benoit & Sergio and Larry Gus). It’s impressive how the bridges between worlds never feel like a stretch—it can effortlessly get to Gus’s itchy “Sphere of lo (for Georg Cantor)” from the elegance of Beach House’s minimal “Saturn Song”
column6: which is positioned just a handful of songs before. The Beach House track works around a Major Tom-esque lyric about being “out on my own”
column7: adding to the overall tone of space race nostalgia.

column1: Despite having a satisfying arc that gently bends through it
column2: there are a few moments where Space Project doesn’t solidify as a whole. Jesu’s “Song of Earth” sounds like something they could have written in their sleep
column3: while Anna Meredith’s “Miranda” is slightly too imposing
column4: working better as a standalone piece that takes hard
column5: overlapping electronics and builds them to a dizzy crescendo. Such is the nature of the multi-artist compilation album—largely an imperfect concept that makes you to sift through the bad in order to get to the good
column6: and to criticize it for being that way feels like a particularly pointless exercise. Still
column7: this one works better than most
column8: not necessarily because of the source material that was a requisite to entry
column9: but more because the concept clearly triggered some kind of sentimental reflex in most of the artists involved. This might be a last gasp for space age retro-nostalgia before that concept begins to feel retro in itself; if so
column10:
it’s a decent way to go out.

column1: <div>As Kool A.D.
column2: Victor Vazquez is a rapper whose best lines are often other rappers' best lines
column3: repurposed
column4: or nonsense that sticks in your head because its fun to say. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">He raps like a very talented
column5: very spacey member of a cipher
column6: always on the verge of losing the thread of his freestyle but never particularly worried about it. His style is culled from relatively obvious influences
column7: including Cam’ron’s internal rhymes and joy in language and Lil B’s daring absurdity.

column1: His new record
column2: Word O.K.
column3: is an album of post-modern rap
column4: a self-conscious
column5: fourth-wall-breaking word collage that parodies hip-hop’s grand narratives even as it gleefully fulfills them. After deconstructing rap on his 2012-2013 “Bus Route” tapes
column6: which were short bursts of Bay Area-influenced conceptual experimentation and genre cuts
column7: the new album is a sign that Vazquez is returning to Das Racist's own knotty style.  The songs here are longer
column8: more difficult to characterize
column9: than his recent work; he's not claiming to be a series of arbitrarily chosen celebrities anymore or mumbling stream-of-consciousness lyrics over guitar licks. The ambition showcased on Word O.K. makes for a more fluid project than anything that Vazquez has come out with since 2012's The Palm Wine Drinkard
column10: but it also dials down the enigmatic quality of his recent work. He had once committed to the “anything goes” sensibility of his music
column11: but now Vasquez is hedging his bets
column12: unsure of whether or not to shoulder the mantle of contributing seriously to the genre he so clearly loves.

column1: Vasquez's love of rap and wordplay
column2: if nothing else
column3: is what comes through strongest on Word O.K.: as he says early on
column4: he “Speaks the English language/ That's the slang I learned to bang with/ If I came from Denmark then I’d probably freak the Danish.”  It’d be hard to come up with another rapper who takes such simple joy in rhyme
column5: and Vazquez remains a pure pleasure to hear flipping words
column6: even as he mocks his own ability to do so.  Several times throughout the record he throws shade at his own rapping
column7: noting his semi-amateur status (‘“Sometimes I get paid to record…other times I do it for free”) and lack of concrete subject matter (“This is just me bullshittin
column8: I ain't got shit to say”).  Most of the tension on the record comes from the difference between that attitude and sentiments like the one on “Naughty by Nature”
column9: on which Vazquez claims to “Just want to write real raps/ Like
column10: tell ‘em how you feel raps
column11: before undermining himself again by describing a boatload of other jokey types of raps that he’d like to write.

column1: Throwing this many words at a canvas typically makes for interesting material
column2: and on Word O.K. Vasquez occasionally says something interesting. On the seven-minute exploration “Life and Time”
column3: he talks about the pain that comes with seeing misery in the world
column4: shrugging “What can one man do?” before self-correcting: “I don’t know
column5: probably a lot.” It’s a thought-provoking questioning of the artist’s priorities. Unfortunately
column6: as with so many other similar sentiments on this record
column7: there’s no follow-through
column8: as the train of thought is abandoned as soon as it arrives.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Word O.K. is held together by longtime collaborator Amaze 88's beats
column3: as well as production from Mike Finito and Toro Y Moi's Chaz Bundick; the latter's throwback hip-hop contributions to “The Front”
column4: especially
column5: helps the song stand apart as one of the record's most diverting cuts. For his part
column6: Amaze comes through
column7: as his blissed-out West Coast loops on “Open Letter
column8: ” “Life and Time”
column9: and the title track provide firm foundations for Vazquez's random blocks of thought.

column1: Word O.K. is compelling art
column2: but it's also weightless
column3: shifting
column4: defiant music that rejects the listener’s ability to gain something from it. Since he's cloaked his more serious self in an armor of dense wordplay
column5: it’s difficult to determine whether Vasquez has a goal other than throwing words on wax and seeing what sticks
column6:
a method that shields him from his own seriousness and prevents him from further exploring bigger ideas.

Floor were never very settled. In the first dozen years of the Miami band’s existence
column2: they burned through a dozen members. They swapped out rhythm sections and shifted between trio and quartet lineups
column3: as though their thick but quick mix of sludge metal and pop structures cracked the will of any new additions. As legend has it
column4: that’s one of the reasons guitarists Steve Brooks and Anthony Vialon drastically dropped the tunings of their instruments. Who needs a fourth wheel when you’ve got 12 strings tuned to the introductory letters of the alphabet? It’s a probable cause of their single-and-split-prone output
column5: too. Between 1992 and 2004
column6: the band released more than a dozen short shots but only one full-length
column7: a self-titled 2002 stomper that was fine but never quite captured the band’s intensity and addictiveness. It would take Brooks’ post-Floor crew
column8: Torche
column9: to do that—particularly on their 2008 album Meanderthal and its irrepressible Songs for Singles chaser.

column1: When Floor reunited in 2010
column2: then
column3: it seemed safe to assume that the jumpstarted band would be a short-lived nostalgia trip. In 2009
column4: Robotic Empire had released a gargantuan box set collecting Floor’s entire scattered discography; it came loaded with 10 LPs
column5: a single
column6: and eight CDs. The next year
column7: Floor played several shows
column8: including bills in which they’d shift drummers so as to offer timeline-correct renditions of early material. For the next three years
column9: Floor continued to tour sporadically. But the entire idea seemed noncommittal. Brooks was busy with Torche
column10: after all
column11: as their mix of Jawbox hooks and Eyehategod volume had found unlikely crossover reception. As late as 2012
column12: he confirmed the spare-time aspect in an interview: “I consider it a side project at the moment. If I have the time to focus on new Floor material
column13: it will happen. In the meantime
column14: we play shows from time to time for fun.”

column1: But the same trio that made that 2002 album has returned with Oblation
column2: only Floor’s second LP in more than two decades. Brooks and Vialon still wield those earth-roar guitars
column3: and drummer Henry Wilson shifts capably between punchy up-tempo bursts and browbeating-and-slow doom-pop. Oblation is
column4: at the very least
column5: the best of both Floor albums. It’s more dynamic than its predecessor
column6: relative to volume and variety
column7: and Kurt Ballou’s work behind the mixing board gives Oblation the kind of depth that Floor forever lacked on tape. Brooks makes some compelling lyrical choices
column8: including his tale of Don Quixote’s sidekick horse during the racing “Rocinante” and the man-on-man/love-hate-love lunge “New Man”.

column1: There are some surprising structures here
column2: too. Brooks harmonizes perfectly with Wilson’s girlfriend
column3: Melissa Friedman
column4: during the laidback “Homegoings and Transitions”
column5: a tune she wrote. And though Floor kept things dense and compact during their heyday (7"" singles end quickly
column6: after all)
column7: the trio nears the eight-minute mark for “Sign of Aeth”. They cycle through a sliding
column8: smoky preamble and creep through some very moody blues; the guitars peel away from one another in oddly psychedelic patterns
column9: as though the drugs suddenly work for Floor in very different ways. And on closer “Forever Still”
column10: Brooks calms his generally exclamatory voice
column11: delivering every verse in a multi-tracked monotone. He subtly curves the words into one of the record’s best melodies.

column1: As its name implies
column2: however
column3: Oblation often feels like a curtsy to Floor’s own legacy
column4: an attempt to fortify the influence and ideal of the band’s sludge-pop. The down-tuned tumult begins to turn into a gauntlet of drudgery
column5: where structures and sounds string into blurs. Though they’re exciting in isolation
column6: great tunes like “War Party”
column7: “Sister Sophia”
column8: and “Find Away” begin to register as redundant. Instability once fueled Floor; they’ve now recorded two albums (albeit separated by more than a decade) with the same lineup
column9: and the consistency can start to scan like a rut. But that’s almost always the trouble with reunion records
column10: isn’t it
column11: especially for bands whose signature sound has become a calling card for successors? The unfamiliar might hear Oblation and assume that these three dudes are very big Torche fans. However illogical that may be
column12: there’s a grain of truth to the joke: Brooks relaunched an old band that
column13: more often than not
column14: sounds like a working model of his more popular current one.

column1: Though Oblation feels unnecessary now
column2: it may prove to be a requisite transition for Floor
column3: a recapitulation of the back catalog that clears the way for something more. There are glimmers here not only of the band that they were but also suggestions of what they could become
column4: whether it’s the ecstatic
column5: feedback-inducing instrumentalists of “The Quill” or the downcast pop-rock renderers of “Forever Still”. In this way
column6: the record recalls Corrosion of Conformity’s self-titled 2012 return
column7: released by the similarly important Candlelight. That album reunited the trio responsible for the band’s pivotal 1985 album Animosity after years of similar retrospective shows. By quickly summarizing most everything the band had ever done in a new set of songs
column8: Corrosion of Conformity worked in much the same way as Oblation. Both albums suggested that these units
column9: despite the turbulent past of the brand
column10: had more to give. “Begin tomorrow/ Be above it/ Why change at all?” Brooks sings on the opening title track
column11: his voice lost in the deep-space echo that’s now so emblematic of Torche. Well
column12: because we
column13: like you
column14:
have been here before.

column1: The Way and Color is stuffed with chugging synthesizers
column2: gristly bass lines
column3: braying horns
column4: and high harmonies layered into multi-movement suites that sometimes feel like they’ve been crafted out of the ashes of a handful of songs. Despite the commotion

column2: and the songs on The Way and Color address a similar kind of sinewy
column3: sometimes sinister sexuality where bodies don't quite know what to do with each other. But their attempt to slink around doesn’t carry the same comfort level; it sometimes sounds as though the band
column4: while playing
column5: is repeating a mantra of “Be cool
column6: be cool” inside their heads
column7: infusing everything with a level of stiffness. There’s a song called “Toi Toi Toi” that borrows its title from the opera
column8: where “toi toi toi” is said in the same way as “break a leg.” The Liebersons come from opera stock: their late father
