Long live the singers who never intended to be singers; they're the ones that make you feel like there are still new ideas under the sun. Life Without Buildings were a short-lived
column3: mathy art-rock band from Glasgow fronted by a painter/sometimes-spoken-word poet named Sue Tompkins
column4: who ended up in a band almost by accident and sang like a kindergarten playground bully reciting her older sibling's copy of Horses from memory. No one since has sounded quite like Life Without Buildings
column5: and to even try would miss the point. Their music valued invention
column6: risk
column7: wonder
column8: imagination
column9: and—perhaps above all other virtues—fun. And like very few bands
column10: they were smart enough to walk away as soon as the fun stopped. ""When the band began of course none of us really thought anyone would be interested
column11: so there wasn't anything at stake
column12: guitarist Robert Johnston recalled about a decade after their amicable break-up. ""For Sue
column13: I think it turned from a laugh into being a commitment she'd never signed up for."" Lucky for us
column14: though
column15: that laugh was caught and forever immortalized on tape.

column1: Released on Rough Trade's Tugboat imprint in 2001
column2: Any Other City is Life Without Buildings' only proper record. (There's also the very good live album
column3: Live at the Annandale
column4: which was released in 2007
column5: a few years after the band broke up.) It came out to mild hype but has grown to be a cult favorite in the years since
column6: its reputation all the more storied and elusive because the CD went out of print and it has never been available on vinyl in the U.S. until now. That the band has yet to capitalize on the reunion show/deluxe-reissue trend keeps with the lack of careerist tendencies that defined its entire run. There's a story that
column7: in 2001 at what would end up being the Strokes' first-ever headlining show in London
column8: Life Without Buildings got bumped down to a supporting act at the last minute. Even if it's apocryphal
column9: I suspect this tale gets repeated by fans so often because it cements LWB's underdog status—their indifference about jumping through the hoops that would have made them the Next Big Thing and the inability of most people to appreciate them in their time. Reviews of Any Other City were either breathless raves or pans that questioned the sanity of anyone who could listen to it in full. ""I remember one [review] that said only mad people could like us
column10: drummer Will Bradley said years later. ""I was happy with that. Not long afterwards
column11: we seemed to get a lot of guys coming to our gigs with fresh head wounds
column12: like unstitched lobotomy scars.""

column1: The most distinct (or to those who prefer the safety of convention
column2: the ""maddest"") part of Life Without Buildings' sound is Tompkins' singing
column3: which lands somewhere between scatting
column4: talking
column5: and speaking in tongues. ""No details
column6: but I'm gonna persuade you!"" she insists with electric charisma in the record's first seconds
column7: and opening-line mission statements do not get much truer than that; all you'll want to do for the next 45 minutes is follow her blindly
column8: even when you don't know where the hell she's headed. To Tompkins
column9: language is bubblegum—something exhilaratingly sugary to chomp
column10: crack
column11: and stretch between her fingers. In that opening song
column12: ""P.S. Exclusive""
column13: she repeats the phrase ""the right stuff"" 44 times
column14: but it's too dynamic to ever grow repetitive; it's almost like she's playing a game with herself to see all the different ways she can pronounce it.

column1: Tompkins' lyrics often resemble collages. Familiar words are stammered
column2: stuttered
column3: and chopped up until they sound disorienting and strange—which is a sensibility that carries over to the visual art she's been making since she left the band. (A line from the program of one of her recent gallery shows could easily double as a description of a Life Without Buildings song: ""Through her typed and spoken works she represents snatches of material gleaned from the everyday
column4: distorting meaning by metering their arrangement and delivery."") She delights in found phrases
column5: homophones
column6: and the serendipity misunderstanding. In fan favorite ""The Leanover""
column7: she chants ""If I lose ya
column8: if I lose ya
column9: if I lose ya in the street"" enough for it to start sounding like ""if Illusion Street."" Or something else entirely. On the song's entry on SongMeanings.net
column10: there is a long comment written by someone who was once convinced that she was saying ""a Fallujan street"" and that the song was about the Iraq War. Although this theory has been debunked
column11: I have no doubt that this poetic misunderstanding would delight Sue Tompkins.

column1: For all its art-rock leanings
column2: Any Other City never feels too self-indulgent. A lot of this has to do with the interplay between Tompkins' freewheeling style and the dependable (though wonderfully crooked) backbone provided by Johnston
column3: Bradley
column4: and bassist Chris Evans. Inspired by Pittsburgh math-rock heroes Don Caballero
column5: Life Without Buildings were first an instrumental band before they convinced their art-school friend Tompkins to meld her spoken-word poetry with their antic
column6: skittering sound. (Even the band itself is a kind of collage.) Sometimes the disconnect in their sensibilities is a little too wide (the tonal palette of ""Young Offenders""
column7: the most overtly Don Caballero-esque
column8: is a bit too dull for Tompkins' bold
column9: primary-color exclamations)
column10: but more often it creates a novel and unique energy. One of the band's signature songs is ""New Town""
column11: in which Johnston's quiet
column12: steadily chugging riff and Bradley's muted beat suddenly explode alongside Tompkins' vocals in the chorus. ""Looking in your eyes/ I'm looking in your eyes!"" she shouts
column13: as combative as she is jubilant
column14: issuing these words like a challenge for everybody else to look
column15: live
column16: and love a little bit more emphatically.

column1: The reissue mostly leaves the original record to speak for itself. The only extra included here is a 7"" containing the more ramshackle original versions of ""The Leanover"" and ""New Town""
column2: which are interesting because they let you hear Tompkins working out phrasings and pronunciations she'd sharpen on the record. When Any Other City came out
column3: most people assumed her vocals were heavily improvised
column4: but as the spot-on renditions replicated on Live at the Annandale Hotel proved
column5: they're actually carefully metered and display an extraordinary sense of rhythm. Life Without Buildings were most impressive—and influential—in the way they balanced sheer technical skill with a sense of ecstatic playfulness
column6: which is a sensibility carried on after them by bands like Ponytail
column7: Perfect Pussy
column8: Marnie Stern
column9: Los Campesinos!
column10: and more. Hopefully this reissue will add more names to that list.

column1: It's hard to talk about Tompkins' vocals without using the word ""childlike""
column2: which is too often an annoying cliché people use to infantilize female vocalists and refrain from taking them seriously. (Many of the 2001 pans of Any Other City are tainted with sexism; in one baffling comparison
column3: an NME reviewer faulted Tompkins for not sounding like Whitney Houston.) Here
column4: though
column5: it's apt. This record is all about the wild wisdom of youth; here are four musicians who have managed to recreate that sense of wonder and invention and play that most people (and
column6: let’s face it
column7: bands) lose when they get older. “Look around!” Tompkins insists. “Just information in the leaves
column8: in the leaves
column9: in the leaves!” The phrasing is a little awkward

Many band members have joined and departed Spiritualized over the years—not always in the best of circumstances. A few were cohots from Jason Pierce’s days in Spacemen 3 (Will Carruthers
column2: Mark Refoy
column3: Jon Mattock); one is a former lover who inspired some of Pierce’s material (Kate Radley); and others such as Ray Dickaty (Moonshake)
column4: Thighpaulsandra (Julian Cope)
column5: and John Coxon (Spring Heel Jack) were notable for their work elsewhere. John Colpitts
column6: aka Kid Millions from Oneida
column7: came on board in the band’s recent history
column8: although it’s not yet clear if he’s passing through or is a permanent fixture in the lineup. Either way
column9: he’s clearly formed a firm bond with Pierce
column10: helping bring Spiritualized to a tiny Brooklyn venue that he’s been a fundamental part of over the years
column11: and taking time out of the tour to promote Sweet Heart Sweet Light to perform an improv set with the singer at Le Poisson Rouge in New York in September 2013.

column1: This release
column2: a limited edition Record Store Day pressing that spreads four songs over a 12"" and an accompanying 7""
column3: documents the show. It bridges the pair’s dueling fondness for minimalism and chaos
column4: with the last two Oneida albums
column5: Absolute II and A List of the Burning Mountains
column6: useful as reference points for where Millions found a point of intersection for those tendencies. Pierce’s experiments with breaking free of song structure have been similarly inspired—the 2006 album Guitar Loops is an underrated record in his canon—but here both he and Millions find a space to operate in that’s only fleetingly similar to their output elsewhere. Opener “Misha” initially works as a piece that provides space for them to feel each other out
column7: with Pierce gently tapping out repeating piano motifs before switching to guitar. The sense of anticipation and control is key
column8: with the the duo beautifully building to nowhere in particular
column9: sometimes letting a looseness take hold of the playing
column10: at other times coming close to something resembling structure.

column1: If there’s a harmony to “Misha”
column2: it’s not a place Pierce and Millions return to much for the remainder of this performance. Mostly they sound like warring factions
column3: actively agitating one another. At one point during “New York” Pierce fires off a squall of guitar laced in fuzz
column4: only for Millions to respond with a barrage of drumming that resembles a heap of scaffolding collapsing into the sidewalk. At those points Pierce’s guitar playing sometimes resembles Neil Young’s work when he’s firmly in the abstract—Young’s 1991 album Arc
column5: a collation of feedback and guitar noise gathered from live recordings
column6: largely thought to be inspired by his then-touring partners Sonic Youth—is a useful comparison piece for the places Pierce lands in here. When he reaches for chaos in Spiritualized it’s usually more dense than this. If the breakdown section of “Cop Shoot Cop” is like the apocalypse violently raining down on you
column7: this record’s “London” is a slow
column8: unconscious crawl into oblivion.

column1: The circular motions Pierce experimented with on Guitar Loops are reflected on “Han”
column2: which is built around a robo-loop that the two use as a focal point to extract a maelstrom of noise from one another. It’s the point where Pierce feels at his most free
column3: clouding Millions in billows of wah-wah guitar
column4: steering in waves of calm via husks of light feedback
column5: and throwing in power chords to close it out in an exalted state. Something that elevates this recording is the sense of release that flows throughout
column6: no doubt caused by it being the work of two musicians locked into the touring cycle
column7: playing the same songs night after night. Here
column8: Pierce and Millions step out of the machine for a while and simply let rip. Pierce is at his best when he’s unleashing personal demons—there’s a reason the post-Radley songs on Ladies and Gentlemen We Are Floating in Space are by far his band’s most popular material. His need to offload surfaces again here
column9:
manifesting itself in wonderfully deformed ways.

When thinking back on the early careers of Kendrick Lamar

presenting an assured artist in the lineage of the South's great thinking-man's MCs.

But the ability

column10: to be understood immediately eludes TDE's newest artist SZA
column11: the first woman and R&B singer to sign to the label. Her debut album Z plays out like a fractured memory you struggle to piece together fully: there are shards of clarity
column12: but only that. Of course

column14: but Z is not the sort of mysteriously seductive record that reveals itself over time. Instead
column15: it has walls that are tough

making for an unnecessarily frustrating listen that too often feels guarded.

It is clear that SZA knows precisely what she wants her music to sound like: Z is essentially a chillwave album
column19: every song resting softly on a bed of gauzy keyboard tones as muffled guitar figures and teetering drum patterns float by like dust in the sunlight. The results sound less weird than that description implies

but Z is deeply flawed.

Z's biggest problem is that
column24: despite choosing a sound that is soft and somnolent

column26: but her voice gets lost. In a literal sense
column27: it can be hard to hear her: on tracks like ""Warm Winds""
column30: her vocals are as ethereal as the beat

column32: Z does not reveal the answers to these questions

column1: The album opens up when SZA does

column3: I swear"" on ""Ur""

column9: SZA comes from an identifiable

and hopefully she'll harness it on whatever comes next.

His artwork is peppered with everything from Ninja Turtles to the type of hyperreal photo-illustrations (see above) found on recent Night Slugs releases. While it contains plenty of references

The confident breeziness of ""If Loving U"" moves in and out of a piano house breakdown; the tart lightness of opener ""A Face Only Another Could Love"" rolls out the red carpet for Yahoo's ballsiest bassline. The stuttering ""Summer Jorts"" is the sound of the Go! Team's cheerleading

Plague Vendor’s brand of punk rock is Californian
column2: though not in the sense that their debut Free to Eat conjures visions of Los Angeles’ variegated urban sprawl
column3: or the countercultural aggression Berkeley

column5: few of which are consistent with each other but all aligning to create a theoretical Golden State: the guitars are situated somewhere between the beach and the garage
column6: and there's ""surf's up"" tremolo riffing played with the berzerker energy that powers the Bay Area. It's pop too

column8: Epitaph. That covers a lot of ground geographically and stylistically

column1: The band's a quartet in their early 20s from Whittier
column2: an exurb about 20 miles outside of Los Angeles that truly earns a reputation as ""conservative""—it gave us George Allen and Richard Nixon. It's the kind of stultifying
column3: relatively comfortable place that drives a lot of bored kids to the dark arts and Plague Vendor dabble in all kinds of gothic aesthetics—there's Brandon Blaine's possessed vocals
column4: the eyeliner-streaked anthems of early AFI
column5: and the Mexican folklore from which they get their name. But Plague Vendor are more interested in creating their own aura—even more so than the song on Free to Eat that bears their own name
column6: single “Breakdance on Broken Glass” is a statement of purpose
column7: indulging in “Immigrant Song” and “We’re An American Band”-style mythmaking (“Your daughters love our style/ Every slaughter ends with a smile”). If “voodoo-punk” is a real subgenre
column8: Free to Eat is trying to be a definitive document.

column1: Free to Eat is a blast

column3: only outside the frame because he’s lunging out of it. He deadpans like Mark E. Smith over bucking
column4: neck-snapping riffs on “Black Sap Scriptures” and a minute later
column5: manages a Jack White yawp on “Cursed Love
column6: Hexed Lust”
column7: bedeviled and agitated over the wiles of a preacher’s daughter—at least until the double-time thrash where he scat-raps like Anthony Kiedis with his sock on fire. It’s certainly cartoonish and caricatured
column8: but the carnality is welcome; there hasn’t been much space for sex in punk of late
column9: carnal drives either eliminated by scolding stoics or used as a platform to spark academic and political debate.

column1: While Blaine’s imagination is given plenty of space to roam
column2: Plague Vendor’s framework is small —small town
column3: small
column4: cramped shows
column5: small
column6: cramped album. Free to Eat’s ten tracks clock in at about 18 minutes
column7: most of which are tied up in the aforementioned highlights; the balance is given to one-minute
column8: fast-twitch exertions which don’t leave much of an impression beyond being samplers for their live show. Still
column9: it’s all fun and all hooks
column10: the latter in a literal sense—the musical elements are entirely sharp and metallic
column11: with guitars that sound like they’re emitting steel shavings
column12: jangly tambourine and a piercing
column13: inhuman shriek in the beginning of “My Tongue is So Treacherous.”

column1: As referential as Free To Eat can be on its own

column7:
Plague Vendor could end up somewhere even more strange and exciting next time out.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20363/homepage_large.4fbc5c5a.jpg|Quack|28340.0|Duck Sauce|['Pop/R&B'
column3: Duck Sauce are not fucking around. Armand Van Helden and A-Trak have spent a large part of this decade acting as big-box dance music's merry pranksters
column4: following their clown-nosed muses to the most illogically comical endpoints. In their music videos
column5: the duo have acted as whistle-prone barbers
column6: drank each other's milkshakes
column7: and become literal dickheads; after bringing their bomber jacket-befitted inflatable mascot to New York City's Governor's Ball festival in 2012
column8: they set their creation floating down the East River during the following year's installment of the festival—just for laughs.

column1: While introducing Duck Sauce's loopy entry in BBC's Essential Mix series
column2: Armand Van Helden described the originals-heavy portion of the two-hour mix as ""songs we tried shopping to George Michael
column3: Celine Dion
column4: Billy Joel
column5: and were all declined""; loaded with stoner-friendly sampledelia
column6: the end result resembled something the Avalanches would've whipped up if they binged on breakfast burritos and after-hours basic cable.

column1: ""There’s nothing serious about Duck Sauce—nothing
column2: said A-Trak (real name Alain Macklovitch) when I interviewed him and Van Helden earlier this year. The project has indeed come across as a lackadaisical concern for the two veteran producers
column3: releasing roughly a single a year over the past six years and devoting the rest of their shared effort to crowd-pleasing live performances on the festival circuit. The pair liken their biggest hit to date
column4: the giddily repetitive ""Barbra Streisand""
column5: to the Champs' ""Tequila Song""—""Just a riff and a word""—and to this point Duck Sauce have come across as a novelty concern
column6: a singles project that excels at penetrating the zeitgeist.

column1: Which is fine; dance music thrives as a singles-focused culture
column2: and even with the current micro-boom in artist-focused albums as a byproduct of the EDM money pit
column3: smart money was not on the guys with the inflatable duck releasing a satisfying full-length. So the punchline to Duck Sauce's greatest prank yet is that they've gone ahead and done exactly that. Quack
column4: Duck Sauce's proper debut
column5: is reverential to the music of A-Trak and Van Helden's past—disco's ecstatic glide
column6: house music's hedonistic heartbeat
column7: the good-natured irreverence of classic hip-hop—while sounding totally refreshing amongst its contemporaries. The closest thing here to what some would refer to as ""EDM"" is the squeaky Dutch house of ""It's You""
column8: which rests its central melody on
column9: of all things
column10: a sped-up sample of a goddamn doo-wop song.

column1: If Daft Punk's Random Access Memories found the robots paying tribute to the music that shaped their lives
column2: then Quack is Duck Sauce paying tribute to Daft Punk themselves
column3: along with other French Touch luminaries like Alan Braxe
column4: Fred Falke
column5: and Etienne de Crécy. A-Trak and Van Helden liberally apply the glowing synths and filter-heavy textures of those Gallic auteurs throughout Quack
column6: the entire thing brushed with the type of stupid-smart goofiness not seen since Fatboy Slim's big-beat heyday. Bemoan festival-ready dance music as you wish
column7: but the genre's greatest malady in 2014 is that many of its practitioners sound like they're trying too hard to have fun; Duck Sauce bring the party without breaking a sweat.

column1: Expertly playing to its creators' strengths—Van Helden's ability to hardwire hip-hop breaks and house motifs
column2: A-Trak's turntablist skill and crate-digging know-how—Quack operates at one intense speed and never lets up
column3: from the heavy thump that kicks open ""Chariots of the Gods"" to ""Time Waits for No-One""'s stadium-minded '80s rock fixations. Subtlety is non-existent. The secret to Quack's success
column4: then
column5: is how loud it isn't: the record is mastered with finesse
column6: an impressive studio sheen that wraps even the most hard-hitting of A-Trak and Van Helden's creations in a down comforter. Disco-pop auteurs Chromeo pitch in on various tasks throughout the album—vocalist Dave Macklovitch
column7: brother of Alain
column8: sings lead on ""Everyone"" under the goofball alias Teddy Toothpick—and Quack frequently bears the type of big-money studio wizardry that the perpetually underestimated Chromeo are known for.

column1: At 54 minutes long
column2: Quack isn't completely user-friendly as a front-to-back listening experience (shave two minutes off of every song and you'd have a tighter album that nonetheless would lose its functionality as a collection of DJ tools) but A-Trak and Van Helden deploy a few tricks to avoid inducing listener fatigue. Once or twice
column3: they veer close to repetition for repetition's sake—the vocal drops and cyclical strings of ""Charlie Chazz & Rappin Ralph"" wear out their welcome halfway into the tune's five-minute length—but elsewhere they exhibit an impressive sense of patience. Leaning hard on samples from THP Orchestra's ""Good to Me""
column4: the hook on ""Goody Two Shoes"" is almost impossibly indulgent to the point where it risks inducing diabetic shock; Duck Sauce know this
column5: tempering the song's initial burst with a placid midsection of hand drums and lazer synths before bringing back the chorus in a way that triggers an intoxicating release. Even ""Barbra Streisand""
column6: placed in the midst of Quack's world-beating final third
column7: ebbs and flows with added flourishes (check the steel drum-sounding tones less than a minute in) to avoid reaching peak monotonousness.

column1: The other ace up Quack's sleeve is its skits. I know
column2: I know—skits on albums are rarely funny
column3: and their success more often than not relies on the listener's sense of humor
column4: and everyone's definition of what's ""funny"" is as specific as snowflake architecture. Regardless
column5: A-Trak and Van Helden
column6: along with a cast of wiseguys that range from viral comedian the Fat Jew to Lord Sear from radio DJs Stretch & Bobbito's classic NYC hip-hop show
column7: are pretty good at busting your gut
column8: providing that your gut has a high tolerance for quacking noises and jokes about smelly underwear. They send up comparison-obsessed music nerds (""It’s sort of Mel Gibson meets ancient aliens"")
column9: Spanish-language radio shows
column10: and Wu-Tang Clan's classic torture skit from ""Method Man""
column11: the latter in which a pitched-down A-Trak and Van Helden promise to ""Take you to a yoga ashram and shit
column12: in fuckin’ Toronto.""

column1: A few skits on Quack (the Fat Jew's prank phone call to a Chinese restaurant at the end of ""Ring Me""
column2: the club-and-concert-calendar radio-promo spoof tacked on to ""NRG"") will undoubtedly trigger nostalgic reactions from anyone who's spent the majority of their lives in the tri-state area that surrounds New York City
column3: and that's the point. A-Trak and Van Helden are both NYC denizens—the latter's legacy is practically cemented as one of many who shaped and added vibrancy to the city's dance culture—and even if they don't quite hit the heights of the A-Trak-name-checked influence of Beastie Boys' Paul's Boutique (how could they
column4: let alone anyone?)
column5: they've created a hedonistic
column6: piston-pumping album that bears as much relation to the urban hustle-and-bustle as it does to festival crowds' surging
column7: ecstatic mindsets
column8:
a love letter to NYC that sounds good just about anywhere you're likely to hear it.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20445/homepage_large.7139793d.jpg|Under the Skin OST|23356.0|Mica Levi|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Milan']|2014-04-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:53.264079|"

The character Scarlett Johansson plays in Under the Skin is a blank-eyed cipher
column2: a predator without apparent motivation. There is no horror more visceral than the horror of the impersonal
column3: so it makes sense that Mica Levi
column4: composing the film's score
column5: would turn to the master of elemental horror:György Ligeti
column6: whose ability to gather masses of semitones into translucent wisps without a center made The Shining
column7: which relied heavily on his work Lontano
column8: the scariest movie ever made. (Watch that film with the music off
column9: I still maintain
column10: and it becomes a particularly caustic domestic comedy.)

column1: The score opens with a locust plague of dry tremolos
column2: the strings pressing down until the sound has reached a roar. It's a sound with tremendous menace and weight. From there
column3: the roar shrinks into a whine
column4: and enters a hazy nexus between digitally processed and live sound. It's an indeterminacy Levi worked hard to cultivate: ""We were looking at the natural sound of an instrument to try and find something identifiably human in it
column5: then slowing things down or changing the pitch of it to make it feel uncomfortable
column6: she told The Guardian. Insectile
column7: near-vocal sounds erupt across the tense
column8: arid space of ""Lipstick to Void
column9: evoking either the Knife's berserker Shaking the Habitual or the processed strings from Britney Spears' ""Toxic"". It's an appropriate cross-section for the film
column10: which veers between menace and sexuality and brilliantly cross-wires high-brain and low-groin impulses.

column1: That hovering dust-cloud of strings
column2: which Levi referred to as ""like a beehive"" in her and Under the Skin director Jonathan Glazer's recent Pitchfork interview
column3: pops up repeatedly throughout the score with minor additions and tweaks representing the journey of Johansson's character: in ""Meat to Maths""
column4: there are clanging bell-like sounds behind it
column5: while in ""Mirror to Vortex"" it's half-submerged in the amplified sound of its own echo. In the context of the film
column6: these additions feel like the messiness of lived experience muddying Johansson's template
column7: the imprint of the lives she begins to grapple with as her time on Earth extends. The hollow knock of a single drum
column8: like a single dragging foot
column9: is another repeating theme
column10: giving the score a reiterative
column11: hesitant quality. Inasmuch as you can be invited into Johansson's character's head in Under the Skin
column12: the music does the heavy lifting. The score has the feel of a thought process
column13: albeit one conducted by a being you have no genetic relation to.

column1: The music unfolds as deliberately and as unconsciously as the dreamlike film itself. Levi drops in an arching
column2: three-pitch motif at various points
column3: one that lingers on its highest pitch the longest
column4: like a hanging doubt. In ""Lonely Void""
column5: this figure is colored in briefly by a furtive patch of tonal harmony
column6: a startling appearance of warmth that scrubs itself out as quickly but leaves a powerful impression. There are other brief hints of tenderness
column7: particularly in the unearthly pairing of ""Bedroom"" and ""Love""
column8: which lifts the score entirely free from anxiety and into something exalted and sorrowful. Here
column9: Levi's work comes closer to Vangelis than to Ligeti
column10: and completes the film's mysterious arc. Levi's commitment to the film's themes is all-consuming
column11: and the score is so tightly woven into the film's DNA that it is difficult to detach and experience as an album. However
column12:
the gorgeousness of the quavering synths on ""Love"" ask nothing of you than to be enjoyed.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20488/homepage_large.b5593b90.jpg|Ghetto Cuisine|28818.0|DaVinci|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2014-04-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:53.869537|"

It's not always easy for musicians to hop between genres while still being taken seriously
column2: so credit is due to Wavves' Nathan Williams
column3: who has made four instrumental mixtapes with his brother Kynan as Sweet Valley without arousing ire. February's So Serene mixtape
column4: in particular
column5: was an intriguing mash-up of off-kilter psychedlia
column6: dance
column7: and instrumental rap. Veteran Fillmore rapper DaVinci clearly hears something in Sweet Valley's music that transcends novelty status
column8: as he's collaborated with them on their latest mixtape
column9: Ghetto Cuisine. The new record is a glossy
column10: practiced-sounding project where the rapper sounds refreshed
column11: relaxed
column12: and jolted out of his comfort zone
column13: an interesting deviation in DaVinci's relatively somber discography.

column1: DaVinci has always been a consistent artist
column2: focusing more on low-key reflections of life in a tough neighborhood than belly laughs on wax. The Fillmore-repping “In My City
column3: ” a standout on 2012’s The MOEna Lisa
column4: is a proud
column5: detail-laden portrait of a man on his home turf
column6: and even his relatively lighthearted collaboration with Huntsville producers Block Beattaz “Nothin’ Finna Stop Me” showcased a gruff undertone. It’s refreshing
column7: then
column8: to hear DaVinci abandon that side of his personality on Ghetto Cuisine cuts like “Hello Stranger
column9: ” a starry
column10: chipmunk-soul-powered sex jam where he reveals himself as an understanding
column11: communicative
column12: and hilarious lover while Sweet Valley provide some cringeworthy punchlines in the form of a crude sound effect. On the no-nonsense gangster cut “Paper Blood”
column13: you can hear the rapper chuckling in the midst of the threatening chorus
column14: while “Cheap Thrills” divulges the ethos of the record with a characteristically straightforward approach: “We ain’t come to hurt nobody
column15: ” DaVinci croons. “We tryna have a good time.”

column1: As for Sweet Valley
column2: they do plenty by not trying to do too much: the boilerplate
column3: funk and soul-laced
column4: Bay Area-indebted beats they provide are a great vehicle for DaVinci’s lighter side.  Their production style here isn't terribly progressive
column5: but the Williams brothers aren't completely risk-averse
column6: either: “Work Hard” sweetens the pot with a sped-up version of Barbara Lewis’s “Baby I’m Yours” before dropping the sample out for the majority of the song
column7: giving a real kick to an otherwise superb storytelling track. “I Got That Line” with its revolving door of drum kicks and punctuated sound effects complementing sing-song DaVinci verses
column8: features the kind of left-field decisions that makes you wish Sweet Valley were a little more daring throughout the record.

column1: But keeping it (somewhat) conservative is a smart choice on this first full-length collaboration between Sweet Valley and DaVinci. There’s a good chance that dedicated Wavves fans have never heard of DaVinci
column2: who is still very much an underground rapper
column3: so he has room to demonstrate plenty of times on Ghetto Cuisine that he’s someone worth caring about
column4: giving off an all-inclusive pride on ""I Got That Line"" and elsewhere that
column5: genre shift be damned
column6:
makes those unfamiliar with the rapper's work feel right at home.

On last year's Water on Mars
column3: Purling Hiss cleared most of the murk that helped define some of Mike Polizze's earlier solo recordings. Instead of sounding like a guitar savant trapped inside an AM radio
column4: Polizze and his band were dishing out tracks that could have conceivably found placement on rock'n'roll radio
column5: with partial credit going to production from the War on Drugs' Adam Granduciel and engineer Jeff Ziegler. The record was proof that Polizze didn't have to hide behind the veil of his home-recorded low fidelity
column6: and more importantly it depicted what the band's live incarnation was capable of.

column1: Still
column2: the album's improved fidelity didn't lessen the power of his early recordings
column3: since Purling Hiss' early records still stand as the project's most powerful work so far. Drag City's unearthing some of that early work by reissuing Dizzy Polizzy
column4: a collection of material that originally came out as a limited-run
column5: tour-only cassette back in 2011. Polizze largely recorded these songs by himself between 2004 and 2009
column6: and the record debunks the myth that he's merely a guitar shredder
column7: highlighting what he's capable of as a songwriter.

column1: Though ""Millions of Colors"" dips into proggy psychedelics
column2: most of the tracks on Dizzy are folk songs. ""She Don't Mind"" is an acoustic campfire jam for slackers
column3: as Polizze sings ""Sittin' around in the same old town"" while following a rambling groove and bending a few bluesy guitar flourishes. ""The Earth Creature"" clears some of the fuzz off Public Service Announcement's ""Beautiful Earth Creature""
column4: revealing the song's gorgeous harmonies and mandolin lines. By pitch-shifting his vocals down
column5: muting his acoustic strums
column6: and falling into a stomping trudge when the chorus hits
column7: ""On the Last Day"" slathers some darkness on a beautifully melancholic song about heartache.

column1: The muddy fidelity of these recordings isn't distracting
column2: as Polizze often manages to buoy some of his best guitar solos above the din. Sometimes
column3: whether intentionally or not
column4: the production becomes a crutch. Since ""Digh High"" takes a couple of minutes to kick into gear
column5: the washy production and warped hiccups are all there is to keep listeners interested. More often
column6: though
column7: the fuzzy atmosphere is the perfect companion for these songs. The acoustic ballad ""Sifting Through My Hands"" seems to emanate from a tin can on the opposite end of the room
column8: accentuating Polizze's hoarse
column9: pained vocals
column10: and when the guitar solo hits
column11: it's muffled but nonetheless feels stark and dramatic.

column1: In addition to Dizzy Polizzy
column2: Permanent recently repressed Polizze's self-titled debut as Purling Hiss from 2009. Compared to Dizzy Polizzy
column3: Purling Hiss is a monster of blown-out
column4: shredding
column5: heavy psych music that consistently locks into a satisfying groove. (Fans of Earthless
column6: take note.) Everything is smothered by blaring electric guitars
column7: and it's just as well. A few of these tracks go well beyond the nine-minute mark
column8: which allows Polizze to go long with some of his best solos to date. The LP ends with ""Sound of Montage""
column9: a trepidatious 90-second nugget with tribal drums and a humming monotone that suggests a quiet end to Purling Hiss—that is
column10: until Polizze rips through the same brazen melody he established on album cut ""Montage Mountain"".

column1: Purling Hiss paints Polizze as a Philadelphia guitar hero who uses his prowess to craft heavy psych odysseys through murky territory
column2: while Dizzy Polizzy casts him as a folkie outsider with some devastating songs in tow. He's cleaned up nice since
column3: but these early recordings prove that even when he was working with lower fidelity
column4:
Polizze was writing some of the most exciting and affecting songs of his life.

"|19184.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19184-purling-hiss-dizzy-polizzy-purling-hiss/|7.5|Evan Minsker
