0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18273/homepage_large.37b2f302.jpg|Box Set|1535.0|For Against|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2014-04-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:54.843509|"

It’s easy to assume that American underground didn't grasp the definining characteristics of  post-punk until the 21st century
column2: but the truth is more complicated than that. Ohio's Vertical Slit covered Joy Division’s “I Remember Nothing” in 1980
column3: Steve Albini became obsessed with the fierce tension of the Comsat Angels before founding Big Black
column4: and SoCal bootstrappers the Abecedarians released their 1985 debut single
column5: the majestic ""Smiling Monarchs""
column6: on Factory Records. Appreciation for the sub-genre in the U.S. was alive and well in the '80s
column7: and Jeffrey Runnings
column8: the sole and constant member of Lincoln
column9: Neb.'s For Against
column10: was one of its strongest champions.

column1: To say that For Against has a cult following is an understatement
column2: so it’s a pleasure that Captured Tracks has reissued the band's first three albums. It’s not the full sweep of their career by any means
column3: but this overview of the original lineup's work—Runnings
column4: guitarist Harry Dingman and drummer Gregory Hill—clarifies why the band inspired passion in their listeners. If they had gained a tenth of the attention Interpol attracted
column5: it would have been a wonderful world.

column1: 1987's Echelons was For Against's debut LP
column2: and its opening track “Shine” captures a blend of sudden-soar sonics and mixed feelings that would become the group’s hallmark. Runnings' vocals occasionally sound tentative
column3: but everything else is in place. Dingman’s guitar underpins Runnings’ verses with focused breaks and melodic lines
column4: and Hill’s drums burst and stomp more forcefully even as he never steamrolls the overall performances. Hill’s elegant drumming
column5: showcased excellently on the title track to 1990's In the Marshes 10""
column6: is an essential element in highlighting For Against's strengths
column7: but Runnings and Dingman's tightly wound partnership served as the band's true core.

column1: The versatile Runnings was able to slash with a deep cut
column2: set a calmly propulsive mood
column3: or just crackle with energy
column4: with vocal abilities that resembled a lost choirboy; Dingman
column5: meanwhile
column6: leaned hard on his digital delay pedals
column7: incorporating the psychedelic
column8: shimmering flow of his contemporaries. In the Marshes consists of demos recorded a year after For Against's 1985 debut single “Autocrat”
column9: sequenced beautifully from the nervous pulse and skitter of opening track “Tibet”
column10: offset by Runnings’s soft wordless chanting and beautifully queasy guitar; elsewhere
column11: the slow burn build of “Amnesia” rivals South London post-punkers the Sound’s fierce “Missiles”.

column1: 1988's December is the strongest collection to come from this iteration of For Against. Vocally
column2: Runnings is mixed up front along with his other band members
column3: resulting in a sound that's bold and brash without being overbearing. Heard in the context of their underground (and major-label) rock contemporaries
column4: December sounds singular: clean
column5: clear
column6: and ruminative rather than chest-beating. Songs like “They Said” and “Clandestine High Holy” are anthems for people who hate anthems
column7: while the title track excels in executing tightly wound
column8: serenely beautiful tension.

column1: After December
column2: For Against's original lineup fractured: Dingman and Hill went on to form the Millions while Runnings continued with a new lineup of For Against throughout the last two decades
column3: sounding out of sync than ever with whatever trends came along.  Dingman rejoined the band last decade
column4: and albums like 2008's Shade Side Sunny Side and the following year's Never Been proved that the band could still produce some truly beautiful
column5: fierce results—but regardless
column6: they’ve never quite gained the audience they've so richly deserved over the years. They deserve recognition for their early-adapter approach to post-punk
column7: as well as for sticking with it until and after everyone finally came around. Most importantly
column8: though
column9: these albums just sound great
column10:
as this box set represents a band hearing something from somewhere else and doing something specific and unique with it.

"|18980.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18980-for-against-box-set/|7.8|Ned Raggett

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20388/homepage_large.ef119fed.jpg|Spiderland|5860.0|Slint|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Touch and Go']|2014-04-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:55.343069|"

“We’re from Louisville
column2: and we thought you needed to hear this.” These words are heard deep into the rarities portion of this 3xLP box set
column3: as the introduction to a live recording dating back to a 1989 Chicago show in support of Slint’s raucous debut album
column4: Tweez. And just what did Slint think their audience—who
column5: judging from the faint smattering of applause
column6: barely cracked the double digits—needed to hear at that moment? A freakin’ Neil Young cover
column7: and a wholly reverential
column8: note-for-note eight-minute reading of “Cortez the Killer”
column9: at that. But the moment is significant nonetheless
column10: and not just because “Cortez” proved to be the root DNA of the ominously methodical music they would go onto explore; that brief spoken introduction counts as an extremely rare document of Slint actually asserting their worth in public.

column1: In many respects
column2: the story of Slint is an exceedingly familiar one of influence accruing in absentia
column3: of mavericks who were ignored in their time and had to wait years to get their due. Except unlike other members of the criminally neglected alt-rock trailblazer club—from the Stooges and Big Star to Pixies and My Bloody Valentine—Slint didn’t just fail at becoming the world-beating superstars that their record labels and music-critic boosters alike hoped they would be. Through their initial 1986-1991 existence
column4: Slint were obscure outsiders even within the subterranean confines of the American indie-rock underground.

column1: Compared to the get-in-the-van
column2: play-anywhere ethic practised by fellow 1980s-hardcore students
column3: Slint rarely performed live
column4: and when they did
column5: it was rarely as a headliner. Interviews were scarce; band photos all the more so. Spiderland—their second
column6: final
column7: and ultimately most revered album—wasn’t some painstaking
column8: Loveless-scaled masterwork belabored over in the studio for months on end; it was a collection of six pared-down basement jams recorded over a single weekend
column9: with many of the lyrics rush-written at the last minute. And Slint were so uncertain of their purpose upon the album’s completion
column10: they actually included a call-out for female-vocalist auditions on record’s back cover
column11: before just deciding to disband altogether prior to its official release. With Spiderland’s chilling
column12: dead-of-night ambience
column13: its predatory rhythmic gait
column14: spine-tingling guitar plucks
column15: and short-story narratives recited in unnervingly hushed tones
column16: Slint had essentially crafted the mysterious soundtrack to their own disappearance. Even that seemingly innocuous
column17: Will Oldham-shot album cover of the band members playfully swimming in a quarry looks just like the sort of photo you see on an 11 o’clock news bulletin about four local teens who went missing on a camping trip.

column1: It wasn’t until their friends—in bands as stylistically divergent but spiritually connected as the Jesus Lizard and Palace Brothers—achieved some degree of national renown in the mid-90s that Slint began its transformation from footnote to boldface; to read interviews with these and other affiliated groups in magazines such as RayGun
column2: Alternative Press
column3: and Option was to play a game of Spot the Spiderland Namedrop. By 1995
column4: Slint started turning up on major-label-issued movie soundtracks; by ’96
column5: Gavin Rossdale was dialing up Steve Albini—who recorded Tweez—to bring some of that corrosive crunch to Bush’s Razorblade Suitcase. And with the similarly atmospheric
column6: equally explosive likes of Mogwai and Godspeed You! Black Emperor dominating the late-90s indie-rock conversation
column7: Slint ceased to be just some band that had broken up too soon and became an entire subgenre of music unto itself.

column1: But well after they ascended to sainthood status
column2: Slint’s sense of timing remained as curiously off-kilter as the tempos of their signature songs. In 2005 the band reunited
column3: a good five years after the post-rock they’re credited with spawning had peaked in popularity. And now
column4: after a few years of intermittent touring
column5: we have the 23rd-anniversary box-set reissue of Spiderland
column6: featuring a much-needed remaster courtesy of Shellac’s Bob Weston
column7: 14 previously unreleased outtakes
column8: a handsome 104-page photographic history of the band (with a foreword from Oldham)
column9: and director Lance Bangs’ thorough and intimate feature-length documentary
column10: Breadcrumb Trail. On the surface
column11: it’s the sort of hefty package that adheres to the standard process of classic-rock-level canonization. But true to the band’s spirit
column12: the set is ultimately a grandiose act of self-effacement. Because for all the mystique Slint have acquired over the past two decades
column13: no one has been more mystified by the band’s rising posthumous reputation than Slint themselves. (I mean
column14: just look at the cover of the box set—notice something missing?)

column1: Rather than trumpet the album’s immense influence on subsequent generations of indie rockers
column2: emo kids
column3: and doom-metalheads alike
column4: everything about this set works the other way to disassemble a quote-unquote classic into its basic raw materials. The demos practically break down Spiderland on a riff-by-riff basis
column5: as we hear the songs devolve from pre-production dress rehearsals to rudimentary acoustic sketches recorded on cassette. The visual materials
column6: meanwhile
column7: trace Spiderland’s genesis back through the unheralded but highly fertile 80s Louisville post-hardcore community (which served as a sister scene to the Touch & Go/Drag City stables in Chicago)
column8: all the way to the formative relationship struck by band principals Britt Walford and Brian McMahan when they were kids attending a downtown alternative elementary school.

column1: Early in Bangs’ film
column2: Walford claims he was bored with rock‘n’roll by the time he was 11; by the time they were teenagers
column3: he and McMahan were already bored with hardcore
column4: having served time in horror-punk torchbearers (and certified Friends of Danzig) Maurice and Hüsker Dü-styled thrashers Squirrel Bait. When the duo formed Slint with Maurice guitarist David Pajo and bassist Ethan Buckler
column5: there was little to suggest the band would amount to anything more than another of Walford and McMahan’s impulsive extracurricular projects
column6: which at that point had included everything from videotaped improv comedy routines to cassettes featuring nothing but the sound of their flatulence
column7: samples of which reportedly seeped into the mix of Tweez. Though obviously indebted to the caustic
column8: caterwauling post-punk of their producer’s former band
column9: Tweez also gleefully subverted underground orthodoxies: In contrast to hardcore’s stern
column10: anti-authority-figure rhetoric
column11: the band named each of the album’s songs after their parents
column12: while Pajo’s avant-Halen squeals and Buckler’s muscular but dextrous basslines meant Tweez wound up not too many slam pits removed from late-80s funk-metal phenoms like Faith No More and Jane’s Addiction. (Dissatisfied with Albini’s recordings
column13: Buckler left the band shortly after Tweez’s release
column14: and was replaced by Todd Brashear.)

column1: When Slint began working on the songs that would form Spiderland in 1989
column2: the initial wave of post-hardcore indie rock was on the wane
column3: with scene stalwarts either trading up (the major label-bound Sonic Youth and Dinosaur Jr.) or breaking up (Black Flag
column4: Mission of Burma) or both (Hüsker Dü). Recorded by their friend Brian Paulson
column5: Spiderland would forge a new indie-rock lexicon by applying hardcore’s emotional intensity to music that
column6: formalistically speaking
column7: was its complete inverse. Even in its heaviest moments
column8: Spiderland wasn’t so much about rocking as stalking: Songs prowled instead of pummeled
column9: with clean
column10: glistening guitar lines (inspired by Pajo’s obsession with Minutemen’s D. Boon) accentuating lyrics that were muttered rather than screamed
column11: all enhanced by a strategic use of space that meant the silences between the notes accumulated their own crushing weight. The album’s definitive bookend tracks—“Breadcrumb Trail” and “Good Morning
column12: Captain”—don’t so much shift from quiet to loud as from bleak to blinding
column13: with McMahan and Pajo emitting the sort of frequencies that make you cover your eyes instead of your ears. And when the band do encroach on something resembling conventional rock—like with the meaty
column14: metallic
column15: morse-code riffage of “Nosferatu Man”—it’s to a sadistic
column16: merciless degree of excess
column17: until you feel like the poor bastard in the movie Se7en whose stomach explodes after being force-fed too much spaghetti.

column1: Spiderland’s volcanic outbursts naturally count as the album’s most bracing
column2: memorable moments. The one drawback is that they occasionally obscured and overshadowed McMahan’s monologues
column3: which remain eminently unnerving for both their delivery (not so much “spoken word” as melody-averse singing imbued with cold-blooded
column4: dead-eyed dread) and their amazingly immersive economy. Even a simple opening line like “Don stepped outside” (from the distorto-folk centerpiece “Don
column5: Aman”) instantly sets a vivid scene of simmering unease
column6: of needing to escape from some stifling
column7: suffocating situation; the devastatingly melancholic “Washer” scans as a break-up ballad
column8: but could also very well be the prelude to a murder-suicide. (Fortunately
column9: Weston’s new master gives McMahan’s voice a greater clarity
column10: while the amplified-vocal demos of “Good Morning
column11: Captain” and “Nosferatu Man”—not to mention the supplied lyric sheets—allow you to follow the words more closely.) Back on Tweez’s “Carol
column12: ” Slint hinted at the darkness lurking in the backwoods of suburbia “past where they paint the houses”; forsaking its predecessor’s inside jokes for outsized drama
column13: Spiderland ventures past that point of no return where the mundane turns horrific
column14: with songs of vampiric lust and county-fair roller-coaster rides and boat trips gone terribly wrong. When Slint do inevitably unleash the noise
column15: it’s less a sonic device than a narrative one
column16: to mark the moment after which
column17: for the songs’ protagonists
column18: nothing will ever be the same again.

column1: And that seemed to be the case for the band itself. The one Slint legend Bangs’ film does confirm is that
column2: after recording the harrowing vocal climax on “Good Morning
column3: Captain
column4: ” McMahan checked himself into a hospital. And the fact that nothing more is said of his stay supports the theory that for Slint
column5: Spiderland was something of a transformative
column6: Deliverance-type experience for the band members—what began as a casual amusement among friends unwittingly lead them into somewhere very dark and disturbing
column7: the details of which are never to be discussed publicly. (The box set reveals a couple of instrumental bed tracks from heretofore unpublicized
column8: eventually aborted post-Spiderland sessions—the fragmented “Todd’s Song” and the drum-machine-ticked “Brian’s Song”. Their drifting
column9: meandering nature suggests returning to the same headspace was too daunting a proposition.) Where Pajo would go on to enjoy some success with Tortoise
column10: as Aerial/Papa M
column11: and as an alt-rock ringer for Interpol and Yeah Yeah Yeahs
column12: McMahan's post-Slint outfit
column13: the For Carnation
column14: has been dormant since 2000. Brashear—who wasn't involved in the reunion tours—now runs a video store. And Walford
column15: once the galvanizing wünderkind of the Louisville scene (and
column16: briefly
column17: a Breeder)
column18: likewise receded into the sidelines as a supporting player for various Drag City acts and old blues-circuit singers alike
column19: while sporadically working on music in private. (It's only now that he's reemerging with his first proper band in two decades
column20: Watter
column21: whose debut album comes out next month on Temporary Residence.)

column1: However
column2: the album’s shadowy aftermath doesn’t necessarily make Spiderland a more intriguing artifact; likewise
column3: the fact its creators were actually a bunch of goofball pranksters from loving
column4: supportive
column5: well-to-do families in no way diminishes the album’s grim majesty and visceral potency. If anything
column6: the elucidating peek behind the curtain that Bangs’ documentary provides makes the album feel like an even more singular
column7: remarkable achievement. Spiderland has always felt like the work of old
column8: wizened souls who had endured great physical and psychological trauma and barely survived to impart their cautionary tales. But even with the visual evidence presented here
column9: it’s still hard to fathom that music this visionary
column10: disciplined
column11: and emotionally resonant was being made by a bunch of guys still in their teens. (Slint may have a great band
column12:
but they were even better actors.)  Spiderland’s greatest legacy is not that it motivated a cluster of semi-popular bands in the late-90s and early 2000s to adopt its whisper-to-scream schematic. It’s the boundless inspiration it perpetually provides for all the bands that have yet to emerge from the basement. 

"|19182.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19182-slint-spiderland-remastered-box-set/|10.0|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20405/homepage_large.35f7ddaa.jpg|So It Goes|30729.0|Ratking|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2014-04-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:56.793869|"

At a time when so many young
column2: emerging New York City rappers are eagerly presenting themselves as a sum of their classic New York rap influences
column3: Ratking have generated attention by trying to represent something different. Bursting onto the scene with rabble-rousing gusto and a reputation for wild live shows
column4: teenage MCs Wiki and Hak (of the Upper West Side and Harlem
column5: respectively) and Harlem-based producer Sporting Life aim to revitalize the reckless spirit of classic New York rap.

column1: From the title of their full-length debut So It Goes—a Kurt Vonnegut reference that doubles as commentary on whether hip-hop is dead—to the album's nearly-exclusive focus on New York as a muse
column2: it's impossible to misinterpret Ratking's stance on the constant conversation that runs through hip-hop culture. “This ain't 90s revival/ It's earlier
column3: it's tribal revival
column4: ” Wiki raps on “Protein”
column5: a disorienting song with an insistent MIDI tone driving the beat
column6: a lengthy instrumental break in the middle
column7: some understated singing
column8: and a lot of disembodied yelling. Above all
column9: Ratking's palette is restless
column10: chaotic
column11: and cluttered
column12: and accordingly So It Goes sounds like it exists in its own world.

column1: It's an album tied inescapably to its urban setting
column2: with snippets of voices and the dings of closing subway doors drifting around under the clanging instrumentation. Sporting Life's instrumentation crackles with energetic drum-machine patterns and digital washes of noise
column3: but the sound of So It Goes is never too harsh
column4: with soulful backing vocals and meandering horns that offer an underlying warmth
column5: particularly on the languorous highlight “Snow Beach”. The contributions of engineer and Jay-Z associate Young Guru (again
column6: the New York lineage here is solid) are valuable
column7: too: while previous Ratking recordings occasionally sounded claustrophobic because of the chaos' collision with the dense jumble of lyrics
column8: So It Goes sounds spacious and clear.

column1: The increase in clarity includes Wiki and Hak's rapping. Wiki first attracted attention as an MC due to his dense
column2: rapid-fire delivery
column3: and both rappers have a gift for freewheeling
column4: tangled flows. However
column5: their presence is satisfying on a basic level
column6: too
column7: breaking from the anti-expressiveness that often comes with such lyrical recitations. Hak often gives his rhymes a physical depth
column8: creating a percussive effect through heavy alliteration
column9: while the more ebullient Wiki yells and repeats short phrases like the singer of a hardcore band. These phrases echo and ring out like proclamations: “The earth is fucked
column10: the city is gone!”
column11: “The city implodes with the prettiest prose!” “20 degrees outside! We're toasted in the tunnel!” Much of So It Goes isn't as concerned with following traditional rap structures as it is with creating rich panoramas.

column1: There isn't anything here that's trying for pop accessibility (unless you count King Krule's singing on the excellent downer anthem “So Sick Stories”)
column2: and So It Goes drags a little toward the end
column3: especially with regards to the title track's new-agey ramblings
column4: so the constant noise and loose structure can feel oppressive. Where Ratking dives deepest
column5: then—the police harassment protest song “Remove Ya” and “Snow Beach”
column6: which addresses NYU's gradual takeover of New York's downtown and paints a rich lyrical portrait—the payoff is greatest
column7: proving that Wiki and Hak are perceptive observers. There's a pulsing
column8: lived-in energy to So It Goes that captures what New York feels like and pushes at the boundaries of lyrically-driven rap. Beyond conversations about their city or genre
column9:
Ratking's greatest success is confidently offering a sound that feels untethered from expectations and bristles with the exhilarating energy of trying something new.

"|19201.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19201-ratking-so-it-goes/|7.5|Kyle Kramer

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20380/homepage_large.4b043302.jpg|Make My Head Sing...|11622.0|Jessica Lea Mayfield|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2014-04-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:57.179398|"

Jessica Lea Mayfield’s third album opens with the loud
column2: percussive crunch and grind of an electric guitar
column3: thudding loudly and precipitously—definitely the most intrusive sound to creep its way into any of her songs. That opening volley of “Oblivious” sounds like a school bus falling into a ravine
column4: or perhaps a piece of rusted machinery designed to cleave and separate this album from its predecessors in Mayfield’s small catalog. For eight years now
column5: the Ohio singer/songwriter has proved one of the more intriguing artists on the fringes of alt-country
column6: with a blurry
column7: slurry vocal delivery and a wry lyrical style that allows for a very frank cataloging of romantic regrets and bad decisions. Yet
column8: she slams her fingers against the strings on “Oblivious” so hard that she effectively unmoors herself from the confines and concerns of country-based songwriting. She is entering new territory that is perhaps a bit more idiosyncratic
column9: a bit more extreme
column10: a bit less well behaved.

column1: This is the only dramatic addition to her sound on her new album
column2: Make My Head Sing.... Otherwise
column3: the record represents a careful subtraction of instruments and elements until only the basics remain: voice and guitar
column4: drums and bass. It's her first without Dan Auerbach at the helm
column5: but ironically it’s the album that best captures the minimalist rock ethos of the Black Keys. Co-producing with her bass player and husband Jesse Newport
column6: Mayfield keeps the sound loose and roomy
column7: preserving the effect of three musicians huddled in a cramped practice space. There’s something certainly compelling about this raw
column8: minimalist sound
column9: even if it buffs away the wry twang in her vocals and shifts the focus away from her songwriting.

column1: In fact
column2: the difference between Make My Head Sing... and Mayfield’s previous records may be as simple as the difference between a guitar album and a singer/songwriter album. The focus here is squarely on the guitar
column3: and there’s an intriguing messiness to her playing
column4: a sculptural approach that favors rough surfaces and sharp edges. After the gangly metal crunch of opener “Oblivious” comes the murky “I Wanna Love You”; “Pure Stuff” stumbles and surges like an early Nirvana b-side
column5: while the postpunk riff on “Do I Have the Time” shimmers like the sequins on the album cover. Elsewhere
column6: she summons Explosions in the Sky and Dinosaur Jr. Make My Head Sing... can be scattershot and unfocused
column7: but especially after two albums dominated by very distinctive guitarists—Auerbach on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/12398-with-blasphemy-so-heartfelt/""><i>With Blasphemy
column8: So Heartfelt and her brother David Mayfield on Tell Me—it’s good to hear her emerge as a resourceful and compelling player herself.

column1: This new musical direction of course informs her lyrical approach
column2: twisting her reverbed psychodrama into something like a variation on the blues. Mayfield favors skeletal song structures and delirious repetition
column3: as though she’s trying to say as much as possible with a few words as possible. On “Standing in the Sun
column4: ” that approach conjures a sense of queasy
column5: heatsick regret
column6: especially as Mayfield layers her vocals like she’s going out of focus. But concise does not always mean weighty or evocative. For all its insistence
column7: Make My Head Sing... is strangely slight and ephemeral. These aren’t short songs
column8: but even “Pure Stuff” and “Unknown Big Secret”
column9: both of which lurch past the five-minute mark
column10: sound like they’re over before Mayfield has a chance to unspool her ideas adequately.

column1: Perhaps that’s a consequence of this new sound: She emphasizes the guitar parts to the neglect of every other element. And yet
column2: Mayfield remains an incisive lyricist with a sharp humor that gets underplayed by her deadpan delivery. “I could kill her with the power in my mind
column3: but I’m a good humanitarian
column4: ” she sings on “Oblivious
column5: ” dismembering that unwieldy word at the joints as she shoots daggers at the other female corner in a love triangle. On closer “Seein* Starz”
column6: she tells a man
column7: “You’ve got a stranglehold on my heart.” Mayfield has insisted for years that love is treacherous and obliterating
column8: and on Make My Head Sing... her guitar enacts that romantic violence. It provides an intriguing counterpart to her vocals
column9:
turning her inner monologues into something like an argument. 

"|19173.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19173-jessica-lea-mayfield-make-my-head-sing/|6.9|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20423/homepage_large.7244e42b.jpg|Ineffable|30199.0|DJ Q|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Local Action']|2014-04-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:57.883862|"

Over the past several years
column2: DJ Q has leaped into the void created by the undefined narrative of UK’s black inner-urban dance scene to claim the territory as his own. It may seem like an exaggeration to say that the majority of contemporary populist dance music emanating from England—from Disclosure to Deckstar
column3: and from 2-step to deep house
column4: from jackin’ to grime—exists primarily as raw material for the former star of North England’s bassline scene to work with
column5: but when sampling some of his recent sets
column6: the statement carries more weight.

column1: Apart from stellar mixing
column2: Q’s key skill as a DJ is his ability to present his eclecticism as purism
column3: weaving together the loose ends of a series of disparate sub-genres into a unified sound which both exists beyond him and because of him. His ultimate mission is to locate and lionize the essential quality of UK urban dance music that is expressed through myriad combinations of shifting stylistic signifiers
column4: helping the listener to follow the music’s pathways from set to set.

column1: His debut album
column2: Ineffable
column3: is a collection of Q’s productions that attempts to capture the broader canvasses he typically works with<i>
column4: offering a neat
column5: carefully pruned cross-section of the more familiar vibes the producer has promulgated: Todd Edwards-esque vocal tapestries over stuttering house beats and turgid basslines
column6: preternaturally sweet R&B divas singing over syncopated 2-step percussion
column7: cavernous half-step rhythms and aggressive synth riffs offering moments of tension. Those sonic collisions define Q’s best production work: as a grime cut
column8: “Lassie” is so-so
column9: but its queasily harmonizing synth patterns prove both alluring and ominous. “Every Time” is a bass-driven UK Garage track that sounds trapped by its own slinkiness
column10: lost in a purgatory of svelte sensuality that never finds release.

column1: Q’s productions function as a microcosm of the broader sonic parameters he plays with
column2: but the typically bright
column3: shiny precision of Ineffable's tracks
column4: while bewitching in the midst of a DJ set
column5: can sound incongruous in isolation. That said
column6: there’s at least a few anthems here that point to Q’s skill as a pop craftsman: the simultaneously chirpy and glowering “Notice Me” is begging for a full-fledged UK Garage revival
column7:
while winsome closer “Be Mine” scales and almost reaches the heights of Sweet Female Attitude’s “Flowers”. It's a sound that trembles with joy and possibility.

"|19218.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19218-dj-q-ineffable/|7.5|Tim Finney

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20415/homepage_large.ef0b850d.jpg|Half-Eaten Guitar|23380.0|Wyrd Visions|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['P.W. Elverum & Sun']|2014-04-16 00:00:00|2006|2016-06-11 16:38:58.464741|"

The first sound on Wyrd Visions' Half-Eaten Guitar feels old and broken beneath the surface. A neglected-sounding acoustic guitar plays an irregular figure in octaves—two bars of three followed by one bar of five
column2: a waltz doubling over repeatedly with a pierced side. It repeats ceaselessly while a boyish voice chants what might be Swedish (the liner notes give no indication). Each time
column3: a different ""off"" note pokes up
column4: offering itself for study like a tongue running obsessively over a molar. You're given no more information
column5: or much of anything else to focus on
column6: while this incantation spreads out for what feels like half an hour
column7: at least three LP sides. When it's over
column8: you might have forgotten what day it is.

column1: Wyrd Visions is slippery with time this way: Peer into it too deeply and you could fall in. That's what happened to Phil Elverum
column2: who became transfixed by the project's initial limited-print run on the Blue Fog label. Elverum's in-house label
column3: P.W. Elverum & Sun
column4: has taken to re-releasing it
column5: dubbing it a ""long lost artifact""
column6: and while the facts don't line up that neatly with this claim—the album came out in 2006
column7: and has therefore been ""lost"" since roughly the second season of ""Lost""—the sound suggests they're right in a larger sense. Wyrd Visions is one Toronto man
column8: Colin Bergh
column9: making imagined Nordic music that intentionally has an ancient
column10: dredged-up feel
column11: as if Bergh simply transcribed what Druids hummed to themselves to warm up their caves.

column1: Colin Bergh is not a Druid (he runs a karaoke night in Toronto) but his solo music has a mystical chilliness that makes it easy to see what drew Elverum to him. Both celebrate the pagan naturalism at the root of black metal while rejecting the noise: Half-Eaten Guitar's six-track
column2: forty-minute run-time makes room for an acoustic cover of Mayhem's ""Freezing Moon"". Bergh's voice is similarly frail and quiet
column3: as if he were standing reverently aside his music rather than making it. And both Bergh and Elverum seem to be trying to paint the same picture with their music—the outline of a stone church in the forest
column4: maybe
column5: or the figures moving dimly outside it—using similar tools.

column1: Bergh's music is ineffably stranger than Elverum's
column2: though—incantatory
column3: acoustic
column4: built in strange meters and rhythms. ""Sigill"" looms over the rest of the album like a great archway
column5: leading to the smaller and quieter sensations offered on its other side. ""Ceremony"" hangs on a simple
column6: tolling perfect fifth
column7: the dried-out framework of a power chord. Almost nothing happens inside of it—nothing describable
column8: anyway. Uncanny sensations pour into the cavernous space Bergh leaves for them in his arrangements. Owen Pallett and members of Grizzly Bear contributed to the recording
column9: but nowhere on the album do you get the warm sense of neighbors popping in. The album feels entirely desolate
column10: a procession of ghosts.

column1: The name for the project comes from Orson Welles' blood-soaked adaptation of Macbeth
column2: but there is no ""toil and trouble"" hokum on Half-Eaten Guitar. Bergh takes his task seriously
column3: and demands that you do
column4: too. So while ""Bog Lord"" might be a potentially ripe
column5: funny song title (and does contain a lyric about ""dancing and be necromancing"")
column6: there is nothing to snort about in the song. It begins with Bergh humming an ear-troubling
column7: tritone-filled melody. Oddly jaunty whistling crosses over him. A guitar plays a high
column8: winding staircase of a melody. In the end
column9: Bergh begins chanting --""W-Y-R-D V-I-S-I-O-N-S across the sky."" It becomes clear: For Bergh
column10:
this is holy music. 

"|19211.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19211-wyrd-visions-half-eaten-guitar/|7.8|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20418/homepage_large.42c455c7.jpg|Do to the Beast|31.0|The Afghan Whigs|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-04-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:38:59.098046|"

The most satisfying moments on the Afghan Whigs’ first album in 16 years aren’t the soaring choruses
column2: or the runaway guitar solos
column3: or the thinly veiled R&B references—not even Van Hunt doing a truly killer Bobby Womack impersonation on “It Kills”. Rather
column4: Do to the Beast is best right before all hell breaks loose. On “Royal Cream”
column5: Greg Dulli and the band draw out the verse for an extra beat or two
column6: ratcheting up the suspense before surging into the swaggering chorus. You brace yourself for the impact
column7: as you would in a car crash. Occasionally
column8: Dulli veers away from that brick wall at the last second; rather than burst into the expected minor-key chorus
column9: “Lost in the Woods” upshifts into a major key
column10: making the song sound like a pivotal and distinctive plot point in the album’s larger narrative of sinners redeemed
column11: saints brought low
column12: and Dulli just barely surviving.

column1: It's a sensation similar to watching a Hitchcock film
column2: and perhaps Dulli picked up the trick as a film student at the University of Cincinnati in his pre-Afghan days. (When the band signed with Elektra in the early 1990s
column3: the label agreed to fund his feature-length directorial debut
column4: which he sadly never found the time to make.) He deployed the suspense-building technique during his tenure with that band
column5: but didn’t really master it until well into the Twilight Singers’ catalog. That latter outfit never had a set lineup
column6: so it could expand or contract in accordance with Dulli’s creative whims
column7: often giving him a larger orchestral palette to work with. In that regard
column8: it’s tempting to call Beast a Singers record rather than an Afghan joint: It’s carefully and richly arranged
column9: less a rock album than a rock soundtrack.

column1: On Do to the Beast
column2: Dulli seems less interested in rehashing the raw rock-quartet attack the Afghan Whigs mastered in the 90s than he is in building on it. The pummeling math-rock riff of “Matamoros” and the impossible breakneck pace of “The Lottery” recall the band in spirit if not precisely in sound
column3: and opener “Parked Outside” may be the heaviest thing he’s ever committed to tape. These songs are orchestrated grandly to draw out the dark drama of Dulli’s lyrics
column4: which continue to plumb the deteriorating effects of drugs
column5: crime
column6: and love
column7: but overall there’s less groove than you might expect from an Afghan Whigs album.

column1: The shift in aesthetic is owed to the logistics of this reunion. In addition to Dulli
column2: only one of the founding Whigs members
column3: bassist John Curley
column4: shows up. Guitarist Rick McCollum is MIA
column5: and the Afghan Whigs never even had a semi-permanent drummer to reunite with
column6: so there's fewer charter members playing on this album than there were on the two new songs from their 2007 retrospective
column7: Unbreakable. Dulli and Curley filled out the roster with Joseph Arthur
column8: Mark McGuire
column9: and Johnny “Natural” Najera (Usher’s musical director)
column10: along with members of the Italian indie-rock group Afterhours
column11: Queens of the Stone Age
column12: Chavez
column13: and others.

column1: In other words
column2: no one involved this album seems terribly concerned with picking up where the Afghan Whigs left off more than a decade and a half ago
column3: and nor should they be: the last thing we need from the Afghan Whigs is 90s nostalgia. Dulli has always been unapologetic about his influences
column4: which have famously leaned toward classic R&B
column5: soul
column6: and funk. That made him something of an outsider in the 90s alt-rock scene—he was dismissed almost as passionately as he was embraced—but it also means that Afghan Whigs albums were motivated by personal vision rather than scene aesthetics and therefore have aged remarkably well.

column1: If 1965 drew from mid-to-late-60s soul and Black Love was about early-70s Blaxploitation soundtracks
column2: then Beast might be set just a few years before
column3: when the rhythm and blues industry was housed in a few independent labels on Broadway and acts like Solomon Burke
column4: the Drifters
column5: and the Shirelles sang out-in-the-street pop epics with ambitious arrangements and insoluble heartbreak. Dulli knows his history
column6: so when he opens “Algiers” opens with a drumbeat practically quoted from the Ronettes’ “Be My Baby”
column7: he’s using that girl-group staple as a slight-of-hand trick: Instead of bursting into a towering wall of sound
column8: the song settles into a bleak acoustic strum accentuated with castanets and handclaps. Rather than declaring love or promising commitment
column9: “Algiers” evokes a bereft loneliness
column10: his only company “the heavenly demons waiting outside my window.”

column1: Throughout the album
column2: Dulli seems to be treating the band’s own career in the same way he treats an old R&B record: as raw material for his current obsessions. As he nears 50
column3: he’s able not only to play up the rough grain in his voice as he grasps for high notes on “Lost in the Woods”
column4: but also to take in the breadth of his career to date. If his catalog is a car
column5: he’s stripping it of its parts and refashioning something newer
column6: more streetworthy. So Do to the Beast may not always sound like an Afghan Whigs album
column7: but it operates like one
column8: scavenging the darker corners of pop history to create something personal
column9: vital
column10:
and urgent.

"|19214.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19214-the-afghan-whigs-do-to-the-beast/|7.6|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20408/homepage_large.35423b51.jpg|Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah|349.0|Bikini Kill|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Bikini Kill']|2014-04-15 00:00:00|1993|2016-06-11 16:38:59.565837|"

Tobi Vail opened her diary. It was October 21
column4: and the 21-year-old drummer set out to pen a Statement of Intent for her brand new punk rock band
column5: Bikini Kill
column6: the one that would fuel thirdwave feminism and create watershed moments. She had dreamt of starting a world-ruling all-girl band since her teen years. The writings in her zine
column7: Jigsaw
column8: archived last year at Harvard
column9: helped steer what we know as the DIY punk-feminist movement
column10: Riot Grrrl. Vail’s diary entry was likewise laced with ideology. She was philosophizing a future feminism by describing her own inquisitive evolution
column11: politicizing punk by charging it with the conditions of her life as a woman. Bikini Kill
column12: she wrote
column13: would fight sexism and homophobia
column14: legitimize girl-rock
column15: reclaim the punk domain. For the time being
column16: they ruled their own tiny universe. “I can already feel the power of it and the band is fast becoming the most important thing in my life
column17: ” Vail wrote. “I think we will be like thee most misunderstood band ever.” The truth of her vision would soon be revealed—loudly
column18: with serious tunes
column19: and music that was straight fire.

column1: Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah
column2: out in March 1993
column3: was their second record
column4: a split with British riot grrrl spokespeople Huggy Bear. Bikini Kill’s half was tracked a year prior in the basement of D.C. punk house the Embassy
column5: where they practiced
column6: and released for their tour with Huggy Bear
column7: which spawned a short doc titled literally: It Changed My Life. Yeah was more crudely recorded than the EP that preceded it
column8: or the Joan Jett-produced “New Radio” single that followed
column9: but these tightly-wound anthems and reprimands were the essence of early Bikini Kill. More than any formal Bikini Kill release
column10: Yeah bears a proud and defiant aesthetic of lo-fi amateurism learned from Olympia’s K Records. The rage of their irreverent sneers and power chord slashes were explosive
column11: and their presence was tough
column12: pissed.

column1: Bikini Kill followed a lineage of angry women in rock—the physical surge of X-Ray Spex
column2: the gruff roar of Babes in Toyland. But no band actively created a counterculture for marginalized groups quite like them. To write protest songs that are as intellectually sharp as they are searingly cool and dryly witty—this is one of music culture’s enduring challenges
column3: and Yeah remains a model of the form
column4: a record with a cause and also real edge. The riffs were hard
column5: the pace was breakneck
column6: the drumming was anarchic
column7: but Yeah was as hellishly catchy as it was raw. Kathleen Hanna
column8: the trailblazing singer
column9: said that in Bikini Kill she embodied 1
column10: 000 voices
column11: and you can hear this on any of these songs. She pivots between radically contorted stylings—from a childish sing-song playground rhyme to a savage
column12: lion’s roar—in order to show how things like masculinity and femininity were performed constructs
column13: how those qualities are inside of us all. Despite these somewhat pointed concerns
column14: Yeah rarely comes off as topical—Bikini Kill’s mantras are primarily inclusive and therefore timeless. Visceral empathy for the oppressed among us never goes out of style.

column1: Hanna had a unique past
column2: an artist and stripper who worked at a domestic violence shelter. Her mission was fueled with empirical evidence
column3: which she clearly desired to share: Yeah’s opening sample finds a bro-moron suggesting that assault happens “because most of the girls ask for it.” The album is all fight songs
column4: but “White Boy” takes no prisoners; it is pure opposition art
column5: with Hanna appropriating a Rollins-like stalwart stance for her war. “I’m so sorry if I’m alienating some of you!” she screams
column6: a mocking taunt. “Your whole fucking culture alienates me!” It is sad that this central line
column7: a Bikini Kill thesis
column8: feels pertinent in 2014—a world where hashtags must explain that rape culture exists (#RapeCultureIsWhen) and we struggle to eradicate the vicious prevalence of haphazard rape jokes. Hanna’s gritty missives used an uncomfortable erotics to illustrate imbalances of power ingrained everywhere. “It’s hard to talk with your dick in my mouth!” she wails. “I will try to scream in pain a little nicer next time!” The sarcasm is ruthless.

column1: Bikini Kill’s early lyrics cut straight to the point
column2: aphoristic truisms that worked as effectively in song as in the zine manifestos where they also appeared. The vocal escapades of “Don’t Need You” reject outward validation
column3: and its anti-production aesthetic insures it. “This Is Not a Test” succinctly shows how society is flawed
column4: not the girls that suffer because of it: a brutally grunted “YOU’RE FUCKED!” followed by an elastic
column5: playful
column6: and performative
column7: “I’m naahhhht!” “Jigsaw Youth”
column8: the fiery centerpiece
column9: brings unity to their generation of grrrls
column10: instilling the idea of a real social movement. But it underscores multiplicity therein—the many kinds of feminism
column11: or the wide-open nature of riot grrrl. “We know there’s not one way/ One light/ One stupid truth!” Hanna shouts
column12: a classic Bikini Kill line. “Don’t fit your definitions! Won’t meet your demands!” The subsequent track
column13: “Resist Psychic Death”
column14: drives the point that resisting definition (and
column15: like
column16: reading) is the punkest thing you can do.

column1: The propulsive throb of “Rebel Girl” is Bikini Kill’s signature anthem and one of the most distinctive moments in American punk. Yeah marked the first release of this iconic song
column2: a  canonical rallying-call of female friendship and girl solidarity. “That girl thinks she’s the queen of the neighborhood!” Hanna shouts
column3: signaling a floodgate of notes all coded with consciousness. “I’ve got news for you/ SHE IS!” This is spiritual music for feminist punks
column4: yes
column5: but also for outsiders of all stripes. The later Joan Jett-produced version broadened “Rebel Girl”s appeal—faster
column6: tighter
column7: slicker—but the sing-song chants and blurry-erotic “Uhhh”s here are animated
column8: unnerving
column9: provocative
column10: showing cracks and nuance. Hanna’s nonconformist dream-grrrl steamrolled over female stereotypes in rock and the world
column11: evoking revolution with every step.

column1: The word “radical” should not be taken lightly here. This band aimed to fundamentally change how people thought about all manner of hierarchy. It also meant Bikini Kill would do things like climb the roof of a house screening “Twin Peaks”
column2: disconnecting the antenna cable in order to sabotage the party. Bikini Kill were horrified by this show
column3: which they felt had a sexist premise—the mystery of a beautiful dead girl. “We had a vendetta against ‘Twin Peaks’
column4: ” guitarist Billy Karren comically writes in the Yeah liner notes
column5: offering context for their early track
column6: “Fuck Twin Peaks”. It’s one of seven newly added early recordings that comprise Side B of this reissue—each purposefully added to illuminate something relevant about the band’s roots. “[‘Twin Peaks’] became the focal point of our initial anger in the band [laughs] which we thought was justified
column7: ” bassist Kathi Wilcox told Rookie.

column1: The song highlights Bikini Kill’s biting sense of humor
column2: no small feat in the realm of politicized music. As does “George Bush Is a Pig”
column3: in which Karren grunts the title over a Sonic Youth-type freakout. The bloodcurdling shrieks of the Vail-sung “Not Right Now” prove
column4: again
column5: why she put the “grr” in “grrrl”
column6: but its caterwauling rage is also terribly funny: “I’m not the kind of girl who’s gonna sit around and make you treats!” “I Busted in Your Chevy Window” is a powerful piece of spoken-word
column7: performed live with terrifying
column8: blood-boiling intensity
column9: offering a tangible window into these legendary early shows. “Why”
column10: Hanna writes in the notes
column11: was her first go at songwriting
column12: a piercing and raw ballad in the vein of her 1997 solo record Julie Ruin. The best of Side B is “Girl Soldier”
column13: a chilling military march regarding the U.S. government’s ceaseless war on women—they used it to open a 1992 gig outside the Capitol with Fugazi
column14: where they protested the rightward swing of the Supreme Court.

column1: “I believe with my whole heartmindbody that girls constitute a revolutionary soul force that can
column2: and will
column3: change the world for real
column4: ” Hanna once wrote. It was only a matter of time. In 2011
column5: before leading a guerrilla art collective that has effectively revealed the bitter truths of modern Russian life
column6: Pussy Riot’s Nadya Tolokonnikova lectured at a conference on the history of feminist art; Bikini Kill was her first slide. In 2014
column7: on the cover of the latest ELLE
column8: teen publishing mogul Tavi Gevinson has interviewed pop’s reigning star
column9: Miley Cyrus—discussing such topics as feminism and gender equality. Conversations in music have expanded and Bikini Kill and comrades pried them open. The dominant Y-chromosomes of punk’s DNA would not change on their own—the canon of Black Flag and Ramones
column10: the degenerate gigs of macho-ritual where dudes went to get spat on. Imagine the air sucked from a room. The window has no handle. The door has no knob. The only option is to smash through and breathe. That was Bikini Kill
column11: busting barriers in a way no one had. They staked out new territory in rock and now it belongs to them
column12:
and us.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20430/homepage_large.15aef27b.jpg|Built on Glass|31903.0|Chet Faker|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Downtown'

Given Chet Faker's profile in his homeland over the past few years
column3: it's easy to forget the Melbourne producer had only put out a single solo EP before Built on Glass. Since his cover of ""No Diggity"" and 2012's Thinking In Textures
column4: Faker has been the Australian poster boy for the nebulous intersection of R&B and soul-influenced electronic music. Either somewhere between James Blake and Tom Krell or a leader of the ignominious ""Australian sound"" depending on who you ask
column5: Faker's standard-bearing might seem a little premature. <i>Built on Glass
column6: as his first full-length
column7: is therefore his case to the world.

column1: There's some premeditation to this statement of his. Faker reportedly scrapped his album twice in pursuit of refining what Chet Faker is supposed to sound like. The result is some inconsistency as Faker tries to reconcile every avenue of his interest with his existing identity
column2: and almost certain disappointment for anyone who expected 52 minutes of Chet as soft-spoken sex facilitator. In the confusion
column3: though
column4: is the chance for surprise
column5: and Faker capitalizes with a hint of just how far his horizons can expand beyond the flaccid cracker-crooning of his previous work.

column1: The first half of the record is where Faker satisfies his obligations. Opening with his trademark Rhodes piano and soupy vocals with ""Release Your Problems""
column2: he then runs through the beat- and sample-chopping singles ""Talk Is Cheap"" and ""Melt"" and the woozy R&B of ""Gold"". The first indication that not everything is as it seems comes on ""No Advice (Airport Version)"": splitting up the two singles
column3: it occupies half its duration with electroacoustic burbling before allowing Faker to sing a few short bars over nothing but a low
column4: vibrating hum.

column1: It's necessary to talk about Built on Glass in sides as it makes a point of distinguishing between them. The record pivots with the interlude ""/""
column2: a gravelly Southern accent speaking through vinyl pops and cracks: ""That was the other side of the record. Now relax still more and drift a little deeper as you listen."" This second half is where Faker becomes more adventurous
column3: enough to venture beyond the borders set for him by his first record. With the blueprint reaffirmed by the first side
column4: the back load feels like he's consciously leaving behind familiar ground to investigate his other influences further. Faker plays with depth
column5: allowing each element room to move between the back and foreground. Booming drums shatter the cavernous atmosphere of ""Blush""
column6: broken shards of glass tumble over each other
column7: and Faker's pitch-shifted vocals clash from high and low
column8: finally uniting harmoniously in the middle.

column1: The album's climax is in the coupling of the betrayal-house of ""1998"" and the rhythmic textures of ""Cigarettes & Loneliness"". On ""1998""
column2: Faker's mumblemouth drawl works in his favor
column3: sounding too numb in parts to even motivate his lips
column4: but at least finding the strength to croak ""We used to be friends."" A chattering beat leads it into ""Cigarettes & Loneliness"" and Faker's voice strengthens into a Van Morrison-like lilt
column5: dancing over syllables.

column1: Maybe it's no coincidence that between the whirring synths and the beat
column2: like metal wheels clanking over tracks
column3: it sounds like the siren of a level railway crossing; the kind of place desperate folks all too often wander in their final moments. The track itself conjures a similar
column4: overbearing futility. Again
column5: Faker explores the space
column6: disrupting the stability of its plucked central riff with cascading elements both percussive and melodic
column7: sucking it all up into its weeping choruses as Faker pleads helplessly for understanding.

column1: Faker placed a keyboard on the cover of Thinking In Textures
column2: nodding towards his greatest tool. On Built on Glass
column3: it's replaced by a human hand; possibly a nod towards Faker's adoption of what we still anachronistically refer to as ""real instruments."" While the core of Built on Glass is still drum machines and synthesizers
column4: Faker's expansion into the organic and electroacoustic has given him a wider territory to roam. And while the introduction of those elements into his work might leave some wondering what happened to the bedroom producer who took over Australia with a dashed-off Blackstreet cover
column5:
Chet Faker's first full-length album proves that the artist is eager to explore new frontiers.

"|19224.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19224-chet-faker-built-on-glass/|7.3|Jake Cleland

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20395/homepage_large.7d4053da.jpg|Sound Houses|32191.0|WALLS/ORAM|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ecstatic']|2014-04-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:00.892144|"

The career of Daphne Oram
column2: a pioneer in electronic composition who worked at the hallowed BBC Radiophonic Workshop in its heyday
column3: remains tangled up in tiny mysteries. A 2007 compilation titled Oramics—named after her studio and the Oramics Machine she created
column4: in which sound could be manipulated by drawing on 35mm film strips—pulled together some of Oram’s post-BBC commercial work
column5: her ventures into musique concrète
column6: and a number of studio experiments. But the exhaustive 2012 compilation of her material
column7: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16262-the-oram-tapes-vol-1/""><i>The Oram Tapes
column9: had the odd effect of making her work harder to read
column10: largely because it showed how Oram had funnelled her work in a near infinite number of directions. It’s a thrillingly heterogeneous listen
column11: full of moments that can make you think
column12: laugh
column13: and occasionally jump out of your skin when great slabs of avant garde noise rupture from the surface.

column1: If The Oram Tapes thrived on a sense of cheery disorder
column2: Sound Houses heads in the opposite direction. This project
column3: commissioned by Oram’s former employers at the BBC
column4: takes elements of her extensive sound library and throws a frame around them with the involvement of Alessio Natalizia and Sam Willis
column5: who make thoughtful electronic pieces as the Kompakt-signed Walls. Here
column6: they test how Oram’s forward-thinking sound pallette holds up when knotted together with contemporary equipment. At times
column7: it’s easy to spot Oram’s hand ghosting behind them—”Rendering the Voice I” begins with a sample from her “Fanfare of Graphs” that’s situated at the same place in the track and remains largely unmanipulated. In those moments
column8: where Walls directly skingraft the 1960s onto the 2010s
column9: the timelessness of Oram’s pieces are thrown into stark relief
column10: with her work immediately feeling at one with the present day.

column1: Most of Sound Houses blurs the lines further than “Rendering the Voice I”
column2: with the sounds of Natalizia
column3: Willis
column4: and Oram entering into an uneasy symbiosis. Walls are careful to make sure there’s some conflict involved
column5: often letting the tension simmer just below the surface as it occasionally does in Oram’s own compositions. “Some Shriller
column6: and Some Deeper” bristles with unease as it slothfully lumbers on its path
column7: while “Rendering the Voice II” perfectly works off the earsplitting electronics Oram would often use. Natalizia and Willis have dialed down the playfulness a touch
column8: perhaps to keep it routed in a world they feel more comfortable in
column9: although elements of humor do emerge; the lumbering drone that’s twisted through the center of “A Very Large Metal Box” is just the right side of clumsy
column10: bringing with it an oafish weight and sense of imbalance that’s positively Beefheartian in outlook.

column1: Pete Kember
column2: aka Sonic Boom
column3: mastered Sound Houses
column4: helping lift it away from the degraded atmosphere of some of The Oram Tapes
column5: which was largely due to the fact that much of the material had languished in dusty boxes for years. His part here forms a loop back to his work with Oram’s fellow Radiophonic Workshop colleague Delia Derbyshire
column6: who contributed to his EAR project and was memorably interviewed by him. It feels like Kember and Oram’s contributions were key at this stage in Walls’ career
column7: whose second album
column8: Coracle
column9: showed plenty of promise without ever feeling like they’d fully inhabited the world they were trying to create. Here
column10: their curatorial skills guide them in relation to the sound sources
column11: helping fill in the blanks when they hit them
column12: causing them to get lost in inspiration instead of scrabbling around for it. It’s also another fascinating twist to Oram’s story
column13:
adding a touch more weight to her legend by making this music breathe once again.

"|19190.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19190-wallsoram-sound-houses/|7.0|Nick Neyland

Between breathless early accolades
column3: inking a deal with Rough Trade on the strength of a five-song EP
column4: and frontman Jordan Gatesmith’s not-so-advanced age
column5: you could spend a lot of time talking about Minneapolis’ Howler before ever getting around to their music. In the two years since America Give Up—their slack-inflected
column6: Strokes-damaged debut LP—the young Gatesmith’s grown even more grizzled-beyond-his-years
column7: and the band’s gone looser
column8: more ramshackle
column9: cleaving most of the taut turn-of-the-millenium NYC from their sound. World of Joy
column10: Howler’s sophomore set
column11: arrives with hardly a fraction of America Give Up’s hype. This time around
column12: without all the focus on Howler’s extramusical hooks
column13: it’s easier to hear a record like World of Joy for what it really is: half-an-hour of antic
column14: raucous rock’n’roll
column15: no more
column16: no less.

column1: Cheap cigs
column2: cheaper gin
column3: mornings in bed and afternoons on the couch: this is Howler country. But while just a few years have passed since Gatesmith’s golden boy phase
column4: the guy’s aged rapidly: much of World of Joy finds him looking askance at
column5: y’know
column6: “society
column7: maaan
column8: ” and he’s not so sure he likes what he sees. Ramonesy yearner “Don’t Wanna” finds Gatesmith rattling off a list of things he urges you to opt out of
column9: if you’re so inclined: “you don’t have to listen to the Smiths if you don’t want to
column10: ” he moans
column11: unleashing raspberries at his onetime-labelmates minutes after a none-too-subtle reminder that “we’re being sold.” Jittery opener “Al’s Corral” is similarly indifferent
column12: as Gatesmith rattles off a long list of things he doesn’t want to do. And World of Joy’s title track plays like one long shrug; over a dour
column13: intensifying buzz
column14: Gatesmith repeatedly mutters “world of joy” with as much apparent glee as the counter guy at Panera talking your mom through her You-Pick-Two. For most of the album Gatesmith’s slumped-shouldered
column15: “oh
column16: great
column17: this again” outlook permeates like bongsmoke in a work shirt. But his sour streak isn’t quite caustic enough to overrun these songs with pure cynicism
column18: and there’s enough tenderness in the balladry here to suggest some genuine sincerity behind the smokescreen of sarcasm.

column1: Musically
column2: World of Joy’s exuberant slop is a far cry from Gatesmith’s lyrical listlessness. A Cheap Trick riff here
column3: a Raspberries hook there
column4: a warbly Westerbergian weeper or two: Howler know from power-pop
column5: and while their influences aren’t hard to pick out
column6: their nervy playing and easy way with hook craft mostly gets them past mere imitation. “Here’s the Itch That Creeps Through My Skull” is a Dion song misted in Ocean Rain; closer “Aphorismic Wasteland Blues” is
column7: for all intents and purposes
column8: a skiffle song. Even on the slower numbers
column9: World of Joy manages to maintain a certain wildness. But
column10: for a bunch of guys who do a bang-up job projecting “over it
column11: ” Howler certainly seem to take some care in their craft; the rickety playing’s not without its charms
column12: but these songs lose their shape when they start to streak past too quickly. These guys
column13: power-poppers that they are
column14: certainly know their way around a hook. But whenever they let the power overtake the pop
column15: they load said hooks into a canon and light the fuse
column16: leaving you with little else but a trail of smoke.

column1: The trouble with World of Joy isn’t that it’s bad
column2: but that it seems perfectly content to stop short at “pretty good.” These hooks are plenty catchy
column3: but not world-conqueringly so; these performances are lively
column4: but they’re not exactly primed to set the world on fire. And Gatesmith
column5: even with the uptick in aggravation
column6: still isn’t the easiest guy to get a read on: one minute he’s in a swoon
column7: and the next
column8: he’s grousing like a part-time punk. Sometimes rollicking
column9: sometimes righteous
column10: World of Joy is a spiny
column11: strident rock record. But one can’t help but think pushing any one of these elements even further forward—the lyrical insouciance
column12: the four-beers-deep playing
column13: the clattering hookcraft—might help push them closer to the forefront of a crowded field. Still
column14: even if they never quite achieve the greatness promised in those early notices
column15: the world needs pretty good bands
column16:
and Howler fit that bill better than most.

"|19249.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19249-howler-world-of-joy/|5.9|Paul Thompson

Combine their rustic
column2: throwback image and prodigious work ethic and Woods is about as literal as the term “cottage industry” gets in indie rock—not only do they run a label
column3: they also throw an annual get-together in Big Sur consisting of “two days of mellow music and celebration.” And it's possible that attending the Woodsist Festival is the only way to find people who engage in heated debate about how one would rank Woods’ discography. By 2012’s Bend Beyond
column4: they’d released five proper LPs in as many years
column5: all just about equally good. Their impeccable consistency can make you wonder if Woods have the impulses or incentive to truly go for it. The result of a relatively lengthy two-year process
column6: their new album With Light and With Love might not be a bold reinvention
column7: but there's an unmistakable focus and determination that can serve as a proper substitute for overt
column8: bar-raising ambition.

column1: Similar to the Men’s Tomorrow’s Hits and Future Islands’ Singles
column2: other 2014 albums by respected ""lo-fi"" bands recording in a “real studio”
column3: With Light and With Love is a reminder that while Woods' hard-touring
column4: road-dog reputation has solidifed their fanbase
column5: people show up in the first place because the band can write great songs. This isn’t a jamband who occasionally stumbles onto golden tunes: Jeremy Earl’s high
column6: distinct voice is predisposed to melodies that quickly corkscrew their way into your memory. The differences between the classicist pop-rock of “Only the Lonely” and early Shins mostly come down to the vocal effects being used.

column1: ""Only the Lonely"" is one of the many times where the relatively sparkly production of With Light and With Love shortens the distance between Woods and quasi-indie acts that fill much bigger festival bills. “Moving to the Left” isn’t their first shot at a crossover
column2: but it's their best; they emphasize their rhythm section with caricatured
column3: bulging bass and a snappy
column4: near-synthetic drum track that typifies Yoshimi-era Flaming Lips. Earl sings
column5: “It feels strange/ It feels the same”
column6: and that’s really With Light and With Love summed up
column7: since nothing Woods do here will alienate anyone other than the most hardcore 4-track enthusiasts. “Moving to the Left” still slowly unravels into a coda filled with wah-wah guitars
column8: and it’s preceded by the requisite Woods woodshedder that takes up an inordinate amount of the LP’s space. The title track is over 9 minutes
column9: yet it never feels improvisatory or exploratory or tacked on—the wigged-out soloing isn’t meant to show Woods’ considerable chops
column10: only to serve the masterful return to its forceful chorus.

column1: Still
column2: With Light and With Lovenever makes much of a fuss about its aims. Earl’s lyrics are inquisitive in nature without giving you much to chew on
column3: taking on the form of homilies about self-discovery and existential doubt. No matter how many times I’ve heard him sing “Are we floating by and by/ Are we moving to the left?”
column4: the question never sounds particularly answerable
column5: let alone urgent. And towards the back half
column6: Woods occasionally revert to a genial folk-rock band that can anonymously blend into ""indie BBQ"" playlists.

column1: But the versatility of Woods becomes more evident throughout the album
column2: as they spread outwards rather than building upward: you get B3-infused soul (“Leaves Like Glass”)
column3: breezy psychedelia (“New Light”) and darker shades of American Beauty (“Shining”)
column4: giving jamband types
column5: roots fans
column6: folkies
column7: indie kids and DIY fetishists a place to link up. “Breakthrough”
column8: “masterpiece”
column9: “bold leap”—those aren’t words that really seem applicable to With Light and With Love
column10: or Woods for that matter
column11:
but they’re allowing themselves to be extremely likable for a larger crowd.

"|19205.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19205-woods-with-light-and-with-love/|7.9|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20440/homepage_large.f0bd3e5d.jpg|The Both|32020.0|The Both|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Superego']|2014-04-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:02.709072|"

At the tops of their respective games
column2: Aimee Mann and Ted Leo provide such a study in contrasts that a partnership between the two is as intriguing as it is unlikely. Mann
column3: whose “Voices Carry” turns 30 next year
column4: is so wry and reserved that she can crack a joke that you won’t get until a verse or two later. Writing with an acerbic precision
column5: she hides her world-weariness in that shirk of a voice
column6: simultaneously jaded yet still vulnerable.

column1: At the opposite end of the spectrum
column2: Leo is a former hardcore punk with a vocal style whose excitability reinforces
column3: rather than undercuts
column4: his smarts. On Hearts of Oak and The Brutalist Bricks
column5: he laid out sociopolitical platforms with such nonchalant specificity that it took a while to realize the darker implications of songs like “Bottled in Cork” and “Me and Mia”. In addition to their predeliction for tongue-in-cheek videos
column6: both he and Mann are fiercely intelligent songwriters
column7: but perhaps the greatest difference between them is that he plays the extrovert and she the introvert. His songs reach out into the world
column8: while hers look more deeply inside herself.

column1: The duo joined forces as the Both
column2: and you’d expect that they’d each bring the other out of their respective comfort zones on their debut album. On a few songs
column3: when the tempos surge
column4: they do: On “Milwaukee”
column5: they devise a witty hook and bolster it with handclaps
column6: a growling guitar outro
column7: and lyrics that offer a from-the-stage perspective on their lives as performers. Similarly
column8: the New Pornographic “Volunteers of America” conjures the 1970s pop energy that informed Mann’s last album
column9: 2012's Charmer. Unfortunately
column10: much of the Both is a rocky
column11: frustrating collection of plodding tempos
column12: lackluster hooks
column13: and a pervasive air of mild-mannered gravity. Their insistent emphasis on craft can strangle their songs
column14: as these too-tidy structures and restrained performances undercut the messy emotions of “Pay For It” and the dour “You Can’t Help Me Now”.

column1: The Both mostly serves to highlight the duo’s limitations. Mann's voice has never possessed much expressive range
column2: but she's managed to turn that into a strength. She sounds relatively raw and unrehearsed on “Honesty Is No Excuse”
column3: one of her best moments on the album—but the song descends into a cop-out chorus of yeah-yeah-yeahs
column4: a predictable guitar solo
column5: and some of the mopiest handclaps put to tape. It’s a weird mess. Leo
column6: on the other hand
column7: tends to pen melodies that fit his vocal delivery
column8: often favoring breathless surges of syllables that underscore the urgency of his lyrics. When Mann expertly navigates the snaky folk melody of “Hummingbird”
column9: he can only phrase it awkwardly and sound out of place in that setting.

column1: Despite the lows outnumbering the highs
column2: there remains some promise in this pairing
column3: if only because it can potentially uproot both Mann and Leo from their respective sounds. There are just enough intriguing moments on this debut to point out a viable future for The Both
column4: one where they make music that sounds nothing like their solo material yet still bears the DNA of each parent. At heart
column5: this is an enthusiastic debut that can’t quite live up to its own billing
column6:
but at least it shows two veterans who have bravely embraced the neophyte’s challenge of figuring out their sound. 

"|19235.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19235-the-both-the-both/|5.4|Stephen M. Deusner

For a long time it’s been fine to think of Amps for Christ as an oddity. The project’s creative core
column3: Henry Barnes
column4: first became known as a member of legendary noise-crust band Man is the Bastard
column5: and his turn toward Amps’ form of cracked
column6: rustic art-folk—one that dug Jesus
column7: no less—added an undertone of novelty compared to his MITB’s heaviness. Not that his new album
column8: Canyons Cars and Crows
column9: can be dismissed as an ex-punk’s cranky religious rambling
column10: any more than his prior work comfortably can. As Barnes’ spirituality has receded to a dull
column11: mellow glow
column12: so has his music ripened
column13: deepened
column14: and opened.

column1: Accordingly
column2: Canyons is a burst fruit of an album. The elements of Amps past—feathery jangle
column3: queasily harmonized leads
column4: modulated organ
column5: stomp-box daisy-chains—splay out in all directions
column6: both sweeter and messier. But seeing as how Canyons is Barnes’ first full-length since 2006’s Every Eleven Seconds
column7: there’s a deliberateness and refinement to the project’s otherwise chronic lack of sharp focus. The stubborn fuzziness of Barnes’ vision makes for a halo effect: On the instrumental “Hills of Padua”
column8: keyboards are treated and smeared until they bleat like bagpipes
column9: even as Barnes feeds them through a distortion pedal that might have been built out of a Geiger counter. That tattered
column10: mutated
column11: yet undeniably traditional folk air assumes a more solid shape on “Scottish Country Dance”
column12: another vocal-free track that balances chiming delicacy with an earth-scraping underbelly glacial enough to have carved out the Great Glen. Even the Celtic lilt of “Chieftains I” and “Chieftains II” coheres into something more otherworldly than Old World. Still
column13: these instrumentals brush the skin of the album’s dimensionality rather than dive into it.

column1: When Barnes finds his voice

column3: where he sings with gentle

column7: the drumming perfectly balances skill and savagery

column4: though

column7: repetition is more strongly emphasized than those bands

column1: There are elements that break up the blackened torrent—the bells on “Metastasis
column2: ” some disjointed guitar solos here and there
column3: the occasional doom-stomp—but otherwise the mood on Congregation is relentless and impossible to escape. In Portal
column4: Omenous Fugue plays bass and Ignis Fatuus plays drums
column5: so the fact that these guys can play a similar form of death metal in different roles makes you admire their skill in a way that triggers a fear for their well-being. Same goes for<span style=""font-style: normal;""> Ingnis Fatuus' vocals; mostly
column6: he goes for a indecipherable growl
column7: but on “Inservitude of Asynchronous Duality” he reaches piercing highs reminiscent of Absu's Proscriptor.

column1: It's difficult to experience Congregation as anything but a full meditative experience. The vibe is so oppressive that it's not unreasonable to think that this record really does not give a fuck about any of your feelings. Is it oppression through freedom
column2: or freedom through oppression? Congregation concludes with the nearly 15-minute “Blight
column3: ” and it's the most warlike in an album littered with doves' corpses. The song represents everything essential about Impetous Ritual pushed further and further into the breaking points of comprehension and endurance. If you made it through “Blight
column4: ” then congratulations. Your taste in death metal is superb
column5:
and you're probably a little imbalanced.
