Downliners Sekt have taken their time establishing a trademark sound. Barcelona duo Fabrizio Rizzin and Pere Solé's first LP
column2: Statement of Purpose
column3: was released nearly a decade ago
column4: and it sounded like mildly pleasant table scraps from the waning days of IDM's glitchy heyday; 2008's The Saltire Wave ditched the ones and zeroes for shoegazey textures and patient post-rock instrumentals. They were decent records without much staying power
column5: so it wasn't surprising when Rizzin and Solé took the top of this current decade to follow The Saltire Wave's drifting tendencies with a series of more rhythmically focused EPs turning to dance music's nocturnal charms.

column1: Rizzin and Solé's early attempts at straightforward club music resembled artists at a creative crossroads
column2: as elements from their past—twitchy glitch motifs
column3: pastoral melodic lines—yelped and wiggled under the pair's skipping
column4: low-slung beats and foggy atmosphere. Their work since The Saltire Wave has felt more like creative workshopping and less about presentation of fully-formed ideas; on their third album
column5: Silent Ascent
column6: a point of comfort is reached. The record is Downliners Sekt's most sonically uniform statement to date
column7: a steady-handed execution of a specific sound—that is
column8: garage-leaning rhythms coated in aromatic vocal samples and drizzled in rain—that suggests a newfound confidence after a decade of trying to find their way.

column1: It's beyond cliché in 2014 to suggest that a given dance record has taken cues from Burial's Untrue—as I recently bemoaned
column2: the sound has been in the air since that record's release. But it's impossible to talk about Silent Ascent without mentioning that landmark record's sound. Rizzin and Solé work in the same muted grays and purples that Burial's built his name on
column3: mostly steering clear of plagiarism by liberally applying dub textures while embracing the ruddy emerald-green textures of John Talabot's work. The primary difference between Silent Ascent and Untrue is that Downliners Sekt are more concerned with atmosphere
column4: with tracks that double the length of Burial's comparatively concise works; regardless
column5: the blink-and-you'll-miss-it similarities between a buried vocal sample in the first third of ""Eiger Dreams"" and the central figure of Burial's ""Ghost Hardware"" are proof that working in such a universally familiar style yields the danger of coming off as mere copyists.

column1: Silent Ascent is often a spotless execution of one specific style—the title track's warm organs and ricocheting vocal samples represent the peak of their compositional powers—so the record's most engaging moments come when Downliners Sekt stretch their legs. ""Balt Shakt I""
column2: taken from a 12"" for Infiné from last year
column3: switches things up with sultry vocals
column4: a bed of rolling static
column5: and aqueous synth blurps that sound ripped from ambient techno veteran Thomas Fehlmann's catalog. ""Junior High"" represents the record's ecstatic peak
column6: as a pulsing house rhythm and an ecstatic vocal sample call back to Talabot's psychedelic club creations.

column1: Downliners Sekt excel when it comes to detail
column2: and Silent Ascent's most surprising moments are the little things—a stray synth arpeggio here and there
column3: the music-hall piano on album closer ""Give Him Your Heart"". Beyond that
column4: this 64-minute album too often sounds samey
column5: as its melancholic fog sometimes threatens to suffocate where it should merely hang above the landscape. It's good that Rizzin and Solé have finally found a sound that
column6: if not especially original
column7: at least feels like a good fit; the challenge they face in the future is expanding on that style without getting too distracted. For now
column8:
Silent Ascent shows great promise from a project that was once a minor concern.

column7: remains a despised record amongst metal diehards. (In retrospect
column8: had it been released under a different moniker
column9: Lake would be considered a fine glam record.) Fischer quit music altogether following the first dissolution of Celtic Frost and moved to the States for a brief time; in the mid-'90s
column10: he formed Apollyon Sun
column11: a group whose limp industrial metal sounded like it was trying too hard to sound current. Fischer placed himself in a tough position to bounce back from
column12: but somehow
column13: he did it: around the turn of the century
column14: he rebooted Celtic Frost and invited Martin Ain
column15: the band's longtime on-and-off bassist
column16: back into the fold. 2006's Monotheist sounded different from Celtic Frost's previous records
column17: and for a minute it seemed like the reformed Celtic Frost actually had something to say—but that all fell apart.

column1: So Fischer's rocky history lent a drive to push himself that's evident in Triptykon's music. As with Daimones
column2: Chasmata is a series of dense compositions filled with the dark crunch of Fischer's and V. Santura's guitars
column3: set to changing currents from outright malestrom to creeping death fog. “Tree of Suffocating Souls” wastes no time in getting into action
column4: immediately blasting where “Goetia
column5: ” the leadoff track from Daimones
column6: took two minutes to speed up. Chasmata features faster songs than its predicessor
column7: but the close-haning gloom is still prevalent
column8: as Triptykon give special focus to Vanja Šlajh's bass
column9: which lingers in “Boleskin House” and “Demon Pact” to the point where you feel tension in your skin. When I interviewed Fischer three years ago following Triptykon's first American tour
column10: he said that the low end is vital to the band
column11: citing his disappointment with amateur concert recordings: “If you record it with some cheap microphone on a cell phone...you will lose a lot of the heaviness and darkness that is experienced when you stand in the crowd.” Nothing is taken lightly in this group
column12: and they've got the chops to carry the weight of such seriousness.

column1: Fischer's dedication to Triptykon is also evident in Chasmata's liner notes
column2: which feature his commentary on each of the album's songs
column3: giving a glimpse into Fischer's thought process and outside inspirations. “In The Sleep of Death” is a tribute to Emily Brontë
column4: and Fischer says the following about ""Breathing"": ""Much of what we experienced and created was dominated by a solemn
column5: at times even despondent mood."" Offering an in-depth look into the creative process is not something a lot of metal musicians would do
column6: and it's more evidence that even after three decades
column7: Fischer feels he's still got something to prove.

column1: Fischer is one of the few on his level who can write compelling mid-tempo parts
column2: and that carries over into Chasmata: “Breathing” is straight Celtic Frost-esque thrash
column3: and around the three minute mark the whole band becomes slave to the primitive lockstep of Fischer's riffing. His avant-garde tendencies also live on in Triptykon
column4: but thankfully
column5: they're more streamlined and fitting with the atmosphere on Chasmata. “Pact”'s layered noise is not unlike a digital Penderecki string section
column6: while “Sleep” sees Fischer taking on a more theatrically pained tone in his voice.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Chasmata is slightly inferior to its predecessor due to a sequencing issue near the record's end. The sprawling “Black Snow” transitions to “Waiting”
column3: a lovely track but maybe not the best song to close out the record
column4: making Chasmata a record that doesn't quite have the ending to tie everything together. Fischer has managed to stay relevant
column5: and he should be commended for that. The moving Chasmata is a mark of longevity
column6: then
column7: but lacks the bombastic “We're back” quality that Triptykon's debut had—fitting
column8:
since first impressions are usually the most lasting.

"|19155.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19155-triptykon-melana-chasmata/|7.7|Andy O'Connor

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20412/homepage_large.fd63d767.jpg|The Future's Void|29348.0|EMA|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2014-04-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:09.328758|"

A line on a short a capella song called “Coda”
column2: from EMA’s 2011 album Past Life Martyred Saints
column3: goes like this: “I looked on the computer/ And it just was an emptiness that/ Made me want to throw up on the spot.” On Past Life
column4: Erika M. Anderson sings noise-drenched songs about grey ships and blue scars and red pants that hide menstrual blood and drugs that make her so sad that she can’t stop taking them
column5: but that brief moment is slightly jarring because you don't necessarily picture the narrator in these visceral and harrowing scenes sitting in front of a computer. But the line is that much more striking because of the contrast; in hidden bedrooms where goth kids cut their arms with butterfly knives
column6: there’s also
column7: of course
column8: a laptop. And even an act as banal as cracking it open and browsing the web might lead you to confront loss and take stock
column9: and that moment could actually make you ill. On an album with many great images
column10: “Coda”’s moment of digitally-invoked despair stood out
column11: and that anomalous line effectively serves as a portal into another world
column12: the one of EMA’s second album
column13: The Future’s Void.

column1: The key track on Past Life Martyred Saints
column2: and the one that gave the album its name
column3: was its first single
column4: “California”. On it
column5: Anderson sang-spoke lines about splitting from her home in South Dakota and leaving behind friends
column6: who we assume are still there
column7: in order to make her mark as an artist out West. However much of the impressionistic “California” was literally true
column8: it certainly felt like autobiography
column9: and it was emblematic of a record packed with details both personal and universal. The Future’s Void is presented as a different kind of record
column10: one that’s about things and issues instead of people. One of those things is the state of our lives as lived online
column11: with thoughts about Big Data
column12: and
column13: yes
column14: the spiritual vacuum of media-saturated culture. There’s more to the record than that
column15: but given the title
column16: the Oculus Rift headset on the cover
column17: and the content of the two lead singles
column18: “Satellites” and “3Jane”
column19: the initial encounter with it happens within this framework.

column1: Digital culture is tricky to write about
column2: because so much of what we’re used to hearing is delivered as a polemic without complexity. On one side you have people talking about disconnect and loneliness and the deterioration of human interaction
column3: basically saying we’ve changed for the worse
column4: and it’s hopeless. On the other
column5: you have the digital utopians—most of whom make their living from the online world
column6: not coincidentally—and they’re telling us that people are more connected because of technology. Writing about what is almost certainly the truth—that contemporary life is a messy
column7: ever-shifting mix of good and bad
column8: and that generalizations about large groups of people are impossible—is hard enough to do in an essay
column9: never mind a four-minute pop song. So you have to hand it to Anderson for addressing such a difficult subject.

column1: Even the songs here that are not about the media per se have it lurking somewhere in the background. There are lines like “when you click on the link” and “makin a living off of takin selfies” and “feel like I blew my soul out across the interwebs and streams
column2: ” and it’s hard not to cringe just a little
column3: because they seem so on-the-nose. I sense judgement in these lyrics
column4: and even if the judgement feels accurate
column5: it’s a point of view we're bombarded with every day
column6: one that is hard to say something new about. Anderson has indicated in interviews that she's aware that she was taking a risk writing about technology
column7: knowingly using phrases that could seem clumsy as a way to push against limtations. But for me
column8: when the record falters
column9: it’s often because these moments take me out of it; they come over as too easy.

column1: Which is not to say that they aren't also used in songs that resonate. “3Jane” is the perfect representation how the album’s awkwardly delivered details can take on serious power when considered whole
column2: and it also seems like the successor to the pairing of “Coda” and “Marked” on Past Life Martyred Saints. The first thing to note about “3Jane” is that the arrangement and melody are absolutely gorgeous
column3: the delicate piano and ghosted synths and thumping tom-toms and shimmering cymbals combine into a ballad that moves with tremendously emotional force. And while lyrics like “it’s all just a big advertising campaign” and “it doesn’t seem like it was only yesterday when you wandered out on superhighway” are iffy
column4: the song ultimately comes over as honest and moving. “It left a hole so big inside of me
column5: ” recalls the fantasy of trepanation from “Marked”
column6: and the way Anderson sells it
column7: you feel what she’s feeling.

column1: The aching beauty of “3Jane” is found elsewhere on The Future’s Void
column2: on the sing-song organ that half-quotes the melody from “Taps” (Anderson is a genius at making obvious musical references sound strange) in “Dead Celebrity” and on the mid-tempo acoustic lilt of “When She Comes”—the easiest song on the album
column3: catchy and instantly appealing
column4: with lyrics that feel like an evocative puzzle you don’t need to solve. “100 Years”
column5: a song about history and industrialization
column6: is striking most because of the nakedness of Anderson’s vocal
column7: both fragile and strong; after years of being subjected to Auto-Tune and processing and reverb
column8: hearing a flawed human voice this close to the microphone
column9: outlining a melody and cracking subtly here and there
column10: is so real it’s an almost psychedelic experience. “So Blonde”
column11: the album’s most obviously personal song
column12: crackles with memorably imagery (“her pills are shakin in her bag”) and evokes the alt-rock 90s and the era’s interrogation of cultural iconography
column13: with Anderson’s Courtney Love-like scream on the title refrain driving it home. There are moments of brilliance here.

column1: There are also songs that are easy to skip. Anderson in industrial rock mode just doesn’t work for me this time
column2: and some of that might be up to the production. The album was recorded simply
column3: in her basement
column4: often alone
column5: and sometimes
column6: especially during its quieter moments
column7: that works to its advantage. But the noisy “Cthulu”
column8: “Smoulder”
column9: and “Neuromancer” never hit the intensity they’re going for
column10: and these three songs in sequence in the middle of the record drag it down big time. There are no memorable hooks during this run
column11: and the pinched filter applied to Anderson’s voice wants to evoke a Nine Inch Nails-style blown-out intensity
column12: but it never reaches that pitch.

column1: Still
column2: despite the lyrical clunkers and ill-advised production choices
column3: The Future’s Void has the feel of a real statement
column4: of an artist trying for something new even if she doesn’t always get there. And the EMA project is antithetical to the idea of perfection anyway
column5:
so combing through the messy whole to find the places of clarity and insight feels somehow appropriate.

"|19208.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19208-ema-the-futures-void/|7.4|Mark Richardson

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20174/homepage_large.a97a36fa.jpg|Convertibles|31995.0|Chuck Inglish|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Federal Prism'
column2:
'Sounds Like Fun']|2014-04-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:09.863542|"

Urgency has never been much of a concern for Chuck Inglish. The music he and Mikey Rocks put out as the Cool Kids relies on nonchalance rather than a burning desire to impress—it's the kind of rap that works because they're committed to it and have clearly done their homework when it comes to the brand of 1980s revivalism they trade in
column3: understanding the power of negative space and artful simplicity. On the best Cool Kids songs
column4: the less effort it appears they're expending
column5: the better the results. There's a fine line between drowsy charm and inducing sleep
column6: and when the Cool Kids have run into trouble
column7: it's because they've chosen to play the long game rather than strike quickly and get out before fatigue hits. 30 minutes of stripped-down minimalism is refreshing; an hour of it can be a chore.

column1: This is something that Chuck Inglish's first solo album
column2: Convertibles
column3: smartly avoids. It clocks in at a lean 13 tracks
column4: with only two stretching longer than four minutes. Unsurprisingly
column5: the few songs that flirt with the five-minute mark lack the kind of propulsion needed to make it to the finish line; when he has to make space for extended hooks—like on ""P.R.I.S.M.""
column6: which finds him adopting a flow more melodic than usual—his songs spit fumes and sputter out of control
column7: unable to regain enough forward motion to correct course.

column1: Then there are the tracks that play up the fact that Inglish is joined by Incubus guitarist and sometimes producer Mike Einziger
column2: whose role on the album seems to be to inject color to Inglish's default monochromatic setting. Einziger manages to add some warmth to the concrete-in-the-shade snap that Inglish favors. While Inglish's production has always paired well with sticky July afternoons
column3: now it often sounds just like one. ""Elevators"" packs a Cali-certified hydraulic bounce to its considerable punch
column4: and even the most retro-leaning beats feature more elements that they would have in the past
column5: approaching a retro-futurism that fits in 2014 quite well.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: while the guests that drop by Convertibles sound at home on Inglish's updated production
column3: the album leans a little too hard on them. At this point
column4: there are no secrets left with Inglish as a rapper. He continues to focus on his holy trinity of topics: how he's hanging out with your girl
column5: how strong his wardrobe is
column6: and how much cooler he is than you. He pulls this off with an effortless professionalism
column7: but rarely manages to spit something that will perk your ears. His raps have never sounded more like wallpaper than they do here
column8: and this is only amplified when rappers like Action Bronson pop up and drops more quotables in one verse than Inglish does on the entire album. Of course
column9: you don't listen to Chuck Inglish for the kind of raps that you try to cram into 140 characters
column10: but because his music sounds great while driving around in the summer and shooting the shit with friends. Because of this inherent charm
column11: Convertibles ends up a low-stakes affair without being a low-quality one. And when you think about it
column12:
that's a pretty fair description of Inglish as an artist.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20428/homepage_large.1e0f199d.jpg|Spiritual|32209.0|Cute Heels|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dark Entries']|2014-04-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:10.374273|"

Victor Lenis
column2: the Brussels-based electronic musician who records under the name Cute Heels
column3: grew up in the punk scene around Bogotá
column4: Colombia. Although his music doesn’t have much sonically in common with punk rock—it has no guitars
column5: no vocals
column6: and generally moderate tempos—you can hear its influence clearly throughout his new album Spiritual.

column1: It comes through loudest in its strictly defined palette of vintage synthesizer and drum machine sounds. Spiritual consists largely of monophonic parts played either with punchy
column2: percussive analog synths or first-generation digital gear that produces low-res tones enveloped in hazily pixelated auras
column3: with little in the way of obvious filters or effects. In synthesizer terms
column4: it’s about the closest thing possible to the bare-bones live-wire rawness of a guitar plugged straight into an overdriven amp
column5: and a compelling expression of punk’s fundamental keep-it-simple-stupid immediacy.

column1: Lenis is similarly direct when it comes to putting those tones together. His compositions are lean
column2: unfolding mostly around sparse handfuls of notes arranged into uncluttered grooves. The songs on Spiritual build up a little momentum and then mutate subtly
column3: moving the emphasis between looping melodies and insistent rhythms that change shape over their pop-friendly running times
column4: and as a result the listener is kept slightly off balance for most of the album’s duration. This constantly shifting center of gravity keeps us on our toes
column5: and as a result the songs far more absorbing than the typical instrumental synthesizer album.

column1: Stylistically
column2: Spiritual is all over the place. Much of it resembles the hard-edged dance music that Lenis’ adopted homeland was a leading exporter of back during the 80s
column3: reviving the vaguely totalitarian drum programming and black-latex funk of Belgian electronic body music group Front 242. (The syncopation-heavy “Watch the Neon” specifically recalls Trent Reznor’s own early-career attempts at emulating them.) Elsewhere the grooves deepen and harden and start to resemble the synth-based action movie scores from around the same time
column4: like the ominous but strangely pop-compatible scores that John Carpenter composed for his own films.

column1: Elsewhere they go deeper and harder still until they turn into something like early house and techno but a jagged aggressive streak—Lenis’ punk background showing through again—that wasn’t actually present in early house and techno. It’s a raw
column2: primitivist version of proto-dance music
column3: sort of like the way that punk innovators in the 70s who were eager to return rock to a pre-psychedelic state of grace overreached and ended up with something nastier and noisier than rock ‘n’ roll had ever really been.

column1: Spiritual’s most straightforward moment
column2: and possibly its finest (not to mention the most likely to end up in DJ sets) is its penultimate track
column3: “Calibre 2000."" It combines a Chicago house beat
column4: a Detroit techno synth sequence
column5: and an electro melody line
column6: all genres that overlapped in their early days but rarely ever reached this kind of balance within one song. It pays thorough tribute to old styles without being overly reverential
column7: and updates them for a contemporary audience without sounding particularly modern. It’s not just timeless
column8: but causes the time since those sounds first came into the world to collapse around it
column9:
with Lenis as the singularity in the center.

"|19223.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19223-cute-heels-spiritual/|7.2|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20431/homepage_large.792e0fb1.jpg|Seer|32164.0|Golden Retriever|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2014-04-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:10.930386|"

Jonathan Sielaff and Matt Carlson of Golden Retriever look toward the cosmic and the karmic
column2: favoring set-it-and-forget-it synth jams that seem ripped from 1970s Germany; they’re scientific and mechanical in their construction
column3: but they still imbue their work with emotion. Perhaps because they come from free improv backgrounds
column4: Golden Retriever’s early cassette and CD-R releases leaned toward steady-state
column5: circuitous instrumental pieces rather than the dramatic engagement of their recent work. Seer
column6: their second record for Thrill Jockey and third LP overall
column7: seems particularly laser-guided in its looping and loping melodies. It continues the careful editing that they practiced on 2012’s Occupied With the Unspoken: synth and bass clarinet lines pop in and splatter the void
column8: and tracks are given room to breathe and unfurl
column9: but they’re never lackadaisical or laborious. Sielaff and Carlson may cop the aesthetics of Klaus Schulze
column10: but on Seer they’re content working on a smaller canvas.

column1: The duo’s increased discipline is most readily identifiable on the interlocking and overlapping instrumentation on “Flight Song”. Carlson sets up an asteroid field of pinging synth parts that Sielaff casually weaves through and around
column2: embracing the reedy squeals of his instrument instead of obscuring them with a mountain of effects. On “Superposition”
column3: Seer’s lengthy closer
column4: the duo wrangle serious timbral diversity out of their creaky gear
column5: as Sielaff’s processed clarinet peals make conversational counterpoint to Carlson’s crystalline atmospherics. Before Carlson launches into the sweeping arpeggiation that gives the song its dramatic momentum
column6: it’s the most relaxed moment on the record
column7: but even when the duo stretches out—on “Superposition” and “Sharp Stones”— it never feels like they’re padding time or wasting space. When Carlson slows down the tempo and Sielaff’s work becomes more protracted
column8: these spacier segments set up the more propulsive sections.

column1: Golden Retriever has carved a niche that’s not strictly indebted to post-Berlin School ambient or to the more organic work of new age composers but rather snags details from both aesthetics. It’s transportive stuff when it’s done well
column2: and on Seer they’ve distilled each of the five tracks down to its basest parts
column3: making each feel like a succinct and potent journey in its own right. Albums in this vein can seem like an argument for sprawl
column4:
but Seer makes a case that a wondrous interstellar trip can still be focused.

"|19225.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19225-golden-retriever-seer/|7.4|Colin Joyce

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20393/homepage_large.8f186912.jpg|Tweens|31996.0|Tweens|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Frenchkiss']|2014-04-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:11.590439|"

Cincinnati has given us the Afghan Whigs and the National
column2: two prominent voices for brooding
column3: sexually frustrated
column4: 30-something masculinity—or
column5: basically everything that Tweens aren’t. The Queen City trio’s perpetually sneering brat-punk most likely isn’t a direct response to their city’s recent musical legacy
column6: but you can imagine some Greg Dulli or Matt Berninger type on the receiving end of lead singer Bridget Battle’s taunts on “McMicken”<i>
column7: from the ""trash pop"" band's self-titled debut: “Your old lady can’t get it up no more/ Or are you just a freak and want some more?” Taking its name from a section of Cincinnati notorious for prostitution
column8: ""McMicken"" is told from the perspective of a young woman “Surviving in the streets that the men destroyed
column9: ” and though everyone involved is compromised
column10: it’s clear who has the power in this situation: “We’re tough little bitches ‘cause we’re self-employed.”

column1: Not every song on Tweens is that overt about its relationship dynamics
column2: but it’s damn close: the majority of the record focuses directly on boys who fuck up because they don’t know any better. “Be Mean"" scolds the well-mannered type of male that bores the absolute life out of Battle: “I wish I liked nice
column3: nice boys/ There must be something wrong with me.” The subject of “Hardcore Boy”
column4: the most self-explanatory of Tweens’ eleven tracks
column5: is too caught up in doing hardcore boy things—wearing serious T-shirts
column6: seriously standing alone with a deadly serious expression—to realize that Battle just wants to be taken home already.

column1: Tweens is ostensibly meant to be listened to and identified with by people outside of the demographic responsible for making it (none of the band are actually tweens
column2: although Battle skews young at 21)
column3: and it’s fun for the whole family (except the parents). Battle and her bandmates actually were tweens at the release of the first Be Your Own Pet album
column4: which represents the high water mark for the band's aesthetic (they dutifully cite glammier predecessors like the Donnas as well).

column1: But Battle doesn’t have Jemina Pearl’s charisma
column2: and Tweens aren't as adept or distinct as BYOP in terms of their P.O.V. “Bored in This City” boasts a surprising modulation in its hook and a depth that cuts against the generality of its lyricism (“Getting drunk
column3: it ain’t a choice anymore/ I’m wasting away in this midwest hope”)
column4: but otherwise Tweens rely on attitude and a mutual understanding of the low stakes to carry them through the album's second half. Even if songs like “Hardcore Boy” and “Girlfriend” follow form lyrically
column5: the actual hooks become something of an afterthought.

column1: Then again
column2: attitude’s gotten them this far—they’ve only been around for two years
column3: and even if the Breeders were often a disinterested and dispiriting live presence during their more recent tour dates
column4: it was still an honor for Tweens to be tagged as their opener during an East Coast run. On the closing “Star Studder”
column5: all of this finally dawns on Battle
column6: who offers a respite from the insistent tropes and reveals the fear underlying their brash behavior: “Can’t stand all these faces looking straight at me/ ‘Cuz if I lose my cool they’ll see vulnerability.” Tweens will almost certainly be better off if and when Battle loses her cool
column7: but until then
column8:
the final line of Tweens embodies the strengths and weaknesses of its staunch commitment to derivative sounds: “All I know is what feels good.”

"|19188.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19188-tweens-tweens/|6.3|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20446/homepage_large.217a88ce.jpg|The Infamous|4755.0|Mobb Deep|['Rap']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['self-released']|2014-04-09 00:00:00|1995|2016-06-11 16:39:12.938381|"

The foreboding
column2: faraway skree announcing Mobb Deep's ""Shook Ones Pt. II"" is one of rap's most perfect sounds—but what is it? It might be a horn. But it also might be an exploding steam pipe
column3: or a car alarm
column4: or a laser-jet printer. An even stranger sound follows it: four notes played on either a guitar imitating a piano or a piano imitating a guitar. The line is so disorienting that it inspired a sixteen-year long hunt for its source
column5: which only ended in 2011 when producer Havoc confessed that sample snitches had finally pinpointed their target – a three-second piece of a Herbie Hancock instrumental
column6: sped up and then slowed down. Playing the sample back to back with its source does absolutely nothing to resolve the mystery of ""Shook Ones Pt II.""

column1: For the kids who made it—Albert ""Prodigy"" Johnson
column2: from Hempstead
column3: and Kejuan ""Havoc"" Muchita
column4: from Queensbridge—""Shook Ones Pt. II"" was half war cry
column5: half last gasp. It announced The Infamous
column6: Mobb Deep's second album and their first classic
column7: and in the canon of career-revitalizing rap singles—Kool Moe Dee's ""How Ya Like Me Now""
column8: LL Cool J's ""Mama Said Knock You Out""
column9: Dre's ""Still D.R.E.""—""Shook Ones Pt. II"" is maybe the most effective
column10: and certainly the most devastating.  The song was a rebirth
column11: and the album that it foreshadowed would rewrite their legacy entirely.

column1: The Infamous was not supposed to happen. Johnson and Muchita had already gotten their shot
column2: releasing a corny
column3: forgettable debut called Juvenile Hell in 1993 that sold 20
column4: 000 copies before being dwarfed by Illmatic
column5: which had already traveled the world as a demo before its official release in April of '94. At every radio interview
column6: Havoc and P found themselves answering questions about Havoc's Queensbridge neighbor Nas. In his 2011 memoir My Infamous Life
column7: Prodigy recalls ""Halftime"" pumping out of the speakers at what was supposed to be a Mobb Deep in-store in D.C. Shortly afterward
column8: Mobb Deep were dropped from their label.

column1: They retreated
column2: licking their wounds
column3: to Havoc's mother's house. In New York
column4: things were getting increasingly serious–Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)
column5: also released in '93
column6: had already shipped platinum by May of '94. A revolution was brewing in their own city
column7: and the authors of puerile kiddie sex raps like ""Hit it From the Back"" were in danger of getting left behind forever. It was out of this brew of desperation and determination that The Infamous began to take shape. Their music took on a grimmer
column8: darker tone.

column1: A few key people took notice. One was Schott Free
column2: an A&R at Loud Records and former member of the short-lived rap group Legion of D.U.M.E.; another was Matteo ""Matty C"" Capoluongo
column3: who ran The Source's News section and wrote its venerated Unsigned Hype column. Capoluongo and Free occasionally worked together on behalf raw
column4: roughneck rap
column5: the kind of stuff the industry required occasional nudging to embrace. It was Jacobs
column6: for instance
column7: who initially brought Wu-Tang's ""Protect Ya Neck"" into The Source offices. He and Matty C slipped Mobb Deep's new single
column8: the fierce and focused ""Patty Shop""
column9: to influential DJs Stretch and Bobbito. Word spread
column10: albeit faintly
column11: that the duo might yet have new life in them.

column1: The third important figure behind The Infamous is Q-Tip

Tom Jenkinson’s work as Squarepusher lacks any real center
column2: instead firing off in multiple directions to dizzying effect. His best tracks are vibrant in their nutty
column3: wild-eyed ways
column4: such as Go Plastic's ultra-precise “My Red Hot Car”
column5: or when they sound like a refined version of his rubbery
column6: bass-driven puzzles (Just a Souvenir's “The Coathanger”). Sometimes
column7: his work seems designed to provoke fatigue
column8: with the sheer density of sound violently throwing up multiple barriers to entry
column9: to the point where his listeners are left skirting on an infinite loop somewhere outside the process. Pitchfork’s Jess Harvell described Squarepusher’s last full-length album
column10: Ufabulum
column11: as having an “angry-jazz-droids-run-amok” feel—a useful summation of his sound that now reads as oddly prescient: on <i>Music for Robots
column12: Jenkinson hands the keys to the car to some actual droids.

column1: This five-track EP was conceived after Jenkinson and a number of Japanese composers received an invite to develop music for a group of music-playing robots collectively named Z-Machines. The robots are programmed to play somewhere beyond the human realm—there's a guitarist with 78 fingers
column2: and a drummer with 22 arms. Naturally
column3: the corporate world quickly zoomed in on this phenomenon
column4: as Coors’ alcopop offshoot Zima sponsored a rather dispiriting-looking debut show by Z-Robots in 2013. “When [the robots] see the audience raise up their bottles of Zima
column5: they jam harder
column6: ” reads a caption in this YouTube clip.

column1: Watching a dreadlocked robot shredding in proportion to how enthusiastic an audience is about promoting a drinks company—with its eyes lit up in a message from its sponsor
column2: no less—may put a damper on any “New robot overlords” thoughts. But enlisting Jenkinson to see just how far out they can push the concept means that at least someone in the Z-Robots team has been dreaming creatively. Regardless
column3: for anyone with a cursory knowledge of the Squarepusher back catalog
column4: the results on Music for Robots are unsurprising. This is no brave new world Jenkinson is entering; instead
column5: it sounds like he schooled a group of robots in his familiar musical motifs
column6: dragging them down with him into the mix of jazz fusion and electronics he’s been peddling for the past 20 years.

column1: Although Jenkinson seems like an adventurous choice to test out this type of composition
column2: in a sense he’s not the right guy for the job. His bass playing—so fluid
column3: so knotty
column4: but so often a triumph of technique over feeling—already has an un-human remove to it. So when EP highlight “Sad Robot Goes Funny” enters into the realm of blur-of-fingers playing
column5: it doesn’t feel like there’s much going on that we haven’t heard in prior Squarepusher records
column6: especially as it’s tied to berserk drum patterns that carry a whiff of jazz. Anyone wondering whether genuine machine music can provoke an emotional response won’t find any answers here because it’s all wrapped up in the work of someone who has spent much of his career retreating from feeling. There’s no combat to this music—as strange as it sounds
column7: this feels like a collaboration between like-minded peers.

column1: That Jenkinson's involved in work of this type shouldn’t be a surprise
column2: and to criticize it for being something it was never trying to be is an easy stumbling block to encounter when discussing Squarepusher. But there's still questions about the validity of Music for Robots beyond its status as a musical exercise. Most of it dips into detached terrain; the manic piano runs of “World Three” are rendered without drums
column3: and the layered buildup on “Dissolver” is executed in such a precise manner that it’s positively suffocating in its rigidity. It leaves Z-Robots feeling somewhat pointless beyond the novelty status afforded to a group of machines performing on stage. But this is an album released on Warp with a notable contributor on board
column4: which triggers wider questions about what it brings to the conversation—that is
column5:
a daring vision of the future that turns into a humdrum training session at the office.

Daniel Higgs has served as post-hardcore’s devotional core in secret and for so long that many don’t even realize it. His tenure as the shamanic
column3: enigmatic frontman of Lungfish—Dischord's  most arcane band
column4: and one that appears to be as unofficially defunct as close contemporaries Fugazi—saw the bearded
column5: glowering
column6: knuckle-tattooed enigma evolve from a growling poet into a mantra-chanting ritualist before finally falling off the face of reality and into the realm of outsider solo albums (some made exclusively with improvised Jew’s harp).

column1: Lately
column2: Higgs has returned to more rocking territory as a frequent guest vocalist for the Swedish group the Skull Defekts
column3: and Dances in the Dreams of the Known Unknown is Higgs’ third album with the band. On previous releases such as 2011’s Peer Amid
column4: the collaboration has yielded hypnotic wonders and grueling drone-gluts alike. Dances has a lighter
column5: more porous touch
column6: as aggression and angularity still dominate the group’s noise-born compositions
column7: but they’ve been honeycombed with pockets of atmospheres and cells of relative silence.

column1: The most striking example is album cut “Awaking Dream”
column2: a hollow
column3: ghostly echo of a Higgs-plus-Defekts song as the band shivers in a sequence of controlled
column4: krautrock spasms
column5: Higgs hovering over synths and drums like a crucified prophet. “Expanding
column6: oh oh oh
column7: contracting/ Spiral arms curving out and streaming in
column8: ” he sings
column9: not-so-subtly conflating orgasms with the horror of cosmic realization. If Wilhelm Reich had worshipped Cthulhu
column10: he might have written like Higgs.

column1: Compared to his vocals in Lungfish
column2: though
column3: Higgs’ contribution is hushed and muted. The roar is gone
column4: and it’s missed
column5: since Higgs barely registers on Dreams at all. He's not featured on the much of the album
column6: and that will be a drawback for almost anyone who engages with the album while hoping to engage with Higgs. Granted
column7: the Skull Defekts make fine music on their own
column8: but they sound more alluring and entrancing when their wagon is hitched to Higgs. “Patterns of Thought” and “The Known Unknown”
column9: two of Dreams’ best tracks
column10: fuse abrasive circularity with numbing oblivion
column11: but “Venom” and “King of Misinformation” come across as pseudo-industrial self-parodies. Higgs has been cited as a the band’s “spiritual ringleader”
column12: and his status as the Skull Defekts’ official fifth member has been officially cemented. But Dreams could have used a lot more of his voice
column13: verse
column14:
and devilry.

The Vienna-based
column2: London-born producer SOHN is one of the more high profile examples of new artists whose vocabulary of R&B was formed almost entirely during the few months between the release of James Blake and House of Balloons—Blake’s vocal abstractions and hiccuping rhythms
column3: the inelegantly wasted atmosphere of the Weeknd
column4: with just enough outside that frame to foster a “nature vs. nurture” argument: Bon Iver’s subtle tweaking of Auto-tune
column5: the monastic purity of How to Dress Well
column6: and the vague appreciation of Sade. Just about the only thing sourced from more than five years ago is the occasional Timbaland beat as heard from the PBR&B O.G.
column7: Junior Boys’ Last Exit. Give Christopher Taylor this
column8: he probably made a few good mixes back in the day.

column1: But good taste is a crucial quality for music supervisors and owners of clothing boutiques
column2: not necessarily songwriters. Which is just as well
column3: since Tremors seems desperately wanting for the approval of the former two groups. As producer
column4: Taylor only grasps the superficial aspects that made his influences timely
column5: as opposed to what made them timeless—melody
column6: rhythm
column7: atmosphere
column8: texture
column9: just to name a few. As such
column10: Tremors is nu-nu-indie R&B
column11: cluttered
column12: painfully stylized
column13: and overaccessorized with baubles.

column1: Rather than trusting a groove
column2: triplet beats are bent out of shape for no reason and bump like a broken bicycle wheel. Chopped up and humidified vocal harmonies lend “The Wheel” an intriguing introduction
column3: but what was once a subversion of R&B tropes has become a trope itself
column4: lending an unintentional irony to the title’s usage in chorus (as in “reniventing…”). As those samples just stammer on throughout its entirety
column5: the drum programming is the sound of James Blake endlessly rummaging through a bag of Tinkertoys. Even when “Artifice” becomes the first time that Tremors wisely settles into a steady rhythm
column6: the soggy hook feels pulled from the depths of Infinity Pool
column7: the last record from the similar
column8: unfashionably late When Saints Go Machine.

column1: Presumably
column2: the songs with a less obtrusive production touch would fare better and they do in the sense that SOHN is trying to make music for commercials rather than “commercial music."" As a vocalist
column3: Taylor’s no showstopper
column4: but he is capable
column5: able to nimbly swoop from a blanched moan to falsetto when the situation calls for it. But for an album where every song is documenting some letting of blood
column6: sweat
column7: and tears
column8: Taylor’s inability to generate grit or grain makes his earnest pleadings incapable of provoking any emotion other than the vague sense you could stand to buy more expensive shoes. He cries “it’s called home video” during “The Wheel”
column9: Abel Tesfaye minus the all-in conviction in his debaucherous anti-seduction. And then you have the half-hearted metaphor of “Veto”
column10: either Tom Krell or Arthur Ashin without their demonstrative
column11: fearless emoting. During “Paralysed”
column12: he rends his clothes while bemoaning his tangled intestines and being left dead on the roadside; it's meant as Tremors' centerpiece and can only muster the emotional resonance of a series of Mozz-bot Tweets.

column1: That said
column2: Tremors is actually kinda intriguing in a “canary in the coalmine” sort of way. It’s going to be framed as an “indie” record and in closing
column3: take some time to thank yourself because Taylor couldn’t have done it without you. Think of what had to be overcome for this happen: literally decades worth of antipathy towards synthesizers
column4: mistrust of acts incorporating R&B and pop
column5: a side-eye towards vocal technical prowess
column6: good old American provincialism. It does represent a weird kind of progress in establishing equality
column7:
almost heartening that all of these exciting fusions can result in “indie” albums based in pop and R&B and electronic music that are every bit as dull as your average Pavement or Yo La Tengo derivative from 1996.

The union of Man Forever and So Percussion is so natural
column2: it could have been caused by gravity. Both acts seek new sounds and ideas via percussion
column3: and both embrace devout repetition as a tool for finding unbeaten paths. Granted
column4: they’ve arrived at that task from different angles: Man Forever is Oneida drummer Kid Millions alongside many partners from the underground rock world
column5: while So Percussion is a quartet of former Yale grad students who perform works by heavyweights like Steve Reich and David Lang. But both share a vision of percussion as exploratory and expansive rather than supplementary.

column1: In fact
column2: their visions are so expansive that combining them could be too much of a good thing. There’s already a lot to absorb in the respective work of Man Forever and So Percussion
column3: so their big
column4: active sounds might crowd each other
column5: perhaps even cancel each other out. Neither happens on Ryonen
column6: which spreads 30 minutes of music across two tracks. There’s clarity throughout
column7: even when drums overlap and rhythms blur
column8: as well as a precision that gives a sense of purpose to every move. The whole isn’t greater than the sum of its parts; that’d be too much to expect of two entities with such high-quality individual track records. But Ryonen is an engaging first strike.

column1: What makes it engaging is its continual forward motion. Both pieces are loop-based
column2: their cores formed by cycles of percussion that repeat for long stretches. Yet both also make progress
column3: rarely dragged down by the weight of their over-and-over beats. Part of this progress comes from sonic variety: multiple types of drums and cymbals are employed
column4: and one piece requires that each instrument be played ""in a different time signature at the same tempo.” But progress also comes in the way participants use energy to create kinetic waves. They’re able to make the same figure sound different through the intensity and force of their playing.

column1: Those waves are most obvious on opener “The Clear Realization
column2: ” since the percussion recedes to let in a dreamy voice that sounds uncannily like HEALTH’s Jake Duzsik. Adding singing is an interesting move—I wouldn’t have guessed vocals would have anything to do with this collaboration—and the choice gives dramatic tint to a piece that’s otherwise about physicality. But it also makes “The Clear Realization” oddly light. It’s as if the musicians felt compelled to filter their ideas through something literal like speech
column3: rather than letting the drumming do the talking. The song might be more broadly communicative as a result
column4: but it’s also more generic.

column1: Vocals emerge on Ryonen’s closing title track too
column2: but they come much later in the game
column3: and they’re more about adding texture than taking the lead. The percussion in turn is also more complex and subtle. It begins like a collection of offset drumrolls
column4: but gradually masses into a growling drone
column5: then returns even more pointed and hypnotic than it began. As hummed voices rise with the final percussion climax
column6: “Ryonen” scales heights despite few overt
column7: attention-grabbing changes. In doing so
column8: it gives the collection an ideal ending point: it's both the album's peak and a ramp Man Forever and So Percussion could use to shoot higher
column9:
if we’re lucky enough to get a second meeting of these skillful minds.

Centipede Hz may have been Animal Collective’s response to unwittingly becoming a Top 20-charting act
column2: but the subsequent tours behind the record revealed there was
column3: in fact
column4: a limit to their perpetual game of playing hard-to-get. Where the quartet has traditionally treated concerts as public practice sessions to air out works-in-progress
column5: their 2012-13 setlists charitably balanced out the Hz with the hits (meaning that the band’s newer fans no longer had to dial up YouTube clips from 2007 to experience “My Girls” in a live setting). This generous spirit seems to have carried over to primary vocalist Dave “Avey Tare” Portner’s current interim pursuit
column6: which offers a glimpse of the kind of band Animal Collective could be if they gave into populist demand more often.

column1: To date
column2: Portner’s projects outside of Animal Collective have leaned toward the intensely introspective
column3: whether he was making blissed-out
column4: backward-looped soundscapes with then-wife Kría Brekkan (2007’s Pullhair Rubeye) or fractious
column5: click ‘n’ cut digi-dirges to address their subsequent separation
column6: the death of his grandmother
column7: and his sister’s struggles with cancer (2010’s Down There). His new band
column8: Avey Tare’s Slasher Flicks
column9: was born of a similarly stressful circumstance—Portner was sidelined by strep throat for a long stretch last year—but it also serves as a therapeutic
column10: adrenalized antidote.

column1: Supported by ex-Dirty Projector Angel Deradoorian and former Ponytail drummer Jeremy Hyman
column2: Avey Tare’s Slasher Flicks effectively resemble Animal Collective in stripped-down
column3: garage-band
column4: power-trio formation. They're not quite as densely textured and sonically adventurous
column5: but more than capable of generating the same sense of euphoric abandon: the bouncing-ball momentum of opening track “A Sender” follows in the foot-stomps of two totemic AC openers—Feels’ “Did You See the Words” and Strawberry Jam’s “Peacebone”—while “Duplex Trip” packs the woozy tropical punch of Centipede Hz's more mango-flavored material. (The sporadic flashes of high-beam harmonies from Deradoorian likewise yield a potent I-can’t-believe-it’s-not-Panda Bear effect.) But Slasher Flicks gradually develop their own peculiar personality
column6: most notably on “Little Fang”

column1: In contrast to the rhythmic clatter and electro squiggles that usually accompany Portner’s voice
column2: the Slasher Flicks position ""Little Fang""’s engaging call-and-response hook atop a silken 70s soft-rock groove that resembles a bygone ELO hit refracted through a funhouse mirror (while also betraying Portner’s debt to the phantasmagoric pop of Pure Guava-era Ween). And in their most concise
column3: frenetically funky moments— “Blind Babe”
column4: “Modern Days E”
column5: “Strange Colores”—Slasher Flicks pump out better Jane’s Addiction songs than anything that band has come up since reuniting (an outcome that doesn’t seem so ridiculous when you consider Portner and Perry Farrell’s mutual appreciation of tribal-percussion
column6: rapid-fire wordplay
column7: and the Grateful Dead—heck
column8: the Jane’s cover of “Ripple” could practically pass for a dry run for ""Fireworks"").

column1: As Portner admitted in a recent Pitchfork interview
column2: the Slasher Flicks concept was born of a desire to mess around with the sort of 60s garage-rock and horror-movie tropes that yielded novelty hits like “Monster Mash.” (For more on this phenomenon
column3: watch this disturbing documentary.) On Enter the Slasher House
column4: that influence proves to be mostly implicit. You won’t find any ditties here about ghouls and ghosts hosting graveyard soirees
column5: but the songs craftily split the difference between cheeky and creepy
column6: pitting innocent nursery-rhyme-like melodies against mutating
column7: hallucinogenic backdrops. (The ecstatic Afro-pop of “Catchy (Was Contagious)” even serves as a reminder of how the terminology used to describe a song’s likability factor can also be applied to communicable diseases.)

column1: Slasher House actually becomes a lot less inviting in those moments where it lays on the carnivalistic clamor and shock tactics too thick; when would-be centerpiece tracks like “That It Won’t Grow” and “The Outlaw” start bashing their half-baked choruses into submission with all the subtlety of an oversized cartoon mallet

column3: it’s a bit wearying to hear Portner revert to an esophagus-shredding yelp as his default mechanism whenever the songs seem to be running out of gas. Perhaps the act of screaming himself hoarse is Portner’s way of saying “fuck you” to strep throat
column4:
but Enter works best when it's not begging for an ENT.

column9: children

column1: Because of its pop-punk trappings

In early 2012
column2: the music director of a Norwegian state-funded radio station called P3 declined to add a song called ""Inspector Norse"" by disco producer Todd Terje to its rotation
column3: saying it sounded like ""background music at a beach bar."" When an interviewer asked him what he thought about the radio station's description
column4: Terje said he agreed with it. ""It sounds like elevator music. Good
column5: danceable elevator music."" Then
column6: in a pun fit only for hypothetical dads
column7: he added
column8: ""Elevate your body!"" In Terje's world
column9: there is no distinction made between beating and joining—it's all join
column10: join
column11: join.

column1: It's Album Time is
column2: as advertised
column3: his first full-length album. The title sets the tone: Casual
column4: confident
column5: and unburdened by the imagined need for significance that scares so many good dance producers into losing their cool when given a bigger platform. Most of the music on it could be classified as disco
column6: with shades of cocktail lounge
column7: exotica
column8: surf instrumentals
column9: and other styles that favor whimsy and novelty over sober artistic expression. Not that Terje isn't an artist—he is
column10: and a careful one
column11: fluent in history
column12: expert with texture
column13: and with a grasp on composition more akin to a 1960s film composer than a contemporary techno producer. But for as much ground as he covers on It's Album Time
column14: the music feels effortless
column15: gliding from Henry Mancini-esque detective jazz to bouncy
column16: Stevie Wonder funk like breeze blowing through the waffle weave of a leisure suit. Conventional wisdom bears out: The looser the grip
column17: the tighter the hold.

column1: Despite recycling four of its twelve tracks from previously released singles and EPs
column2: It's Album Time has a linear
column3: cohesive feel. Instead of trying to top ""Strandbar"" or ""Inspector Norse""
column4: Terje ties them together with short interstitial tracks—valleys that give perspective to the mountains. If he ever capitulates to the conventions of making a full-length album
column5: it's in structure
column6: which here is less redolent of disco than classic-rock pranksters like Paul McCartney or Frank Zappa: an introduction that features men whispering the words ""It's album time"" repeatedly
column7: peaking with a ballad halfway through; closing with the joyous ""Inspector Norse""
column8: and dying away to the sound of distant applause.

column1: Terje is
column2: at heart
column3: a comedian. ""I like my music very fruity
column4: he told Resident Advisor in 2007. ""Lots of percussion
column5: lots of silly effects."" When I interviewed the illustrator Bendik Kaltenborn
column6: who has drawn the covers for most of Terje's releases including It's Album Time
column7: he told me that the two first bonded over what Kaltenborn called a ""Stupid"" sense of humor. Everything about It's Album Time and Terje's self-presentation—whether it's the fart-like synth sounds
column8: the conga-line enthusiasm
column9: or the promo photos of him flexing his minor biceps with a pout on his face—is so studiously carefree that he sometimes seems less like a human being than an all-night party incarnate.

column1: But like all comedy
column2: Terje's act is held together by a taut thread of sadness. The beauty of his music is the beauty of a neon sign outside a cheap motel: It's kitschy but it knows it
column3: and in its kitsch conveys both loneliness (it's dark outside and you've been driving for hours) and its easy resolution (it's warm inside and happy hour never ends
column4: pink paper umbrella gratis). In the mockumentary-style video for Terje's ""Inspector Norse"" (which is excerpted from a Norwegian short film called Whateverest)
column5: a failed electronic musician living with his elderly father in a small town spends a day bowling and cooking drugs from household chemicals before turning out the lights and dancing to ""Inspector Norse""
column6: alone. Afterwards
column7: he wanders the streets in facepaint
column8: confused
column9: crying. He survives mostly on illusions
column10: and without happy music
column11: he'd be lost.

column1: The album's least representative song is the one that sticks with me the most: A cover of the Robert Palmer ballad ""Johnny and Mary
column2: sung by Roxy Music singer Bryan Ferry. The song is heavy
column3: melancholic
column4: and almost oppressively romantic—moods that the rest of It's Album Time feel designed to make you forget about. The lyrics tell the story of a couple who know they're alienated from each other but have hung on for so long they struggle with whether or not to break up. ""Johnny's always running around
column5: trying to find certainty
column6: the opening line goes. ""He needs all the world to confirm that he ain't lonely/ Mary counts the walls
column7: knows he tires easily.""

column1: Ferry has spent his entire career crying crocodile tears
column2: exploring the ways a seemingly insincere performance can ring with more feeling and pathos than something we recognize as ""real"". His voice—once a dazzling
column3: cartoonish instrument
column4: like Elvis with his finger in a wall socket—sounds hollowed-out and whispery
column5: an old man whose wisdom brings him no comfort. In the original song
column6: Palmer seems to hover above the characters
column7: observing them
column8: maybe even judging. Ferry sounds like he's in the next room
column9: suffering troubles of his own.

column1: As the song crests and the rippling arpeggios of Terje's synths reach their climax
column2: you might wonder: What is a song so sad doing on an album so relentlessly upbeat? Not to ruin the mood
column3: I think—only as a reminder that sadness is a choice. You could be ""Inspector Norse"" if you wanted to
column4: peacocking wild across the dancefloor
column5: spilling drinks on a stranger
column6: recognizing the brevity of life by enjoying it. From an artist like Terje
column7:
it's proof that he could go deep if he wanted to. He'd just rather have fun.

column1: On their follow-up
column2: Under Color of Official Right

column7: but the more subtle approach comes with more tonal and emotional nuance. Greg Ahee's ringing
column8: hollow guitar clack on ""Bad Advice"" gives weight and urgency to a narrative about Detroit Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick
column9: while the tenderness of Scott Davidson's slow-burning bass intro on ""What the Wall Said"" is a perfect counterbalance to an imminent and overwhelming barrage of guitars. ""Come & See"" begins with guitar chords that are given space to ring before being enveloped by huge
column10: oppressive waves of guitars
column11: and the effect is oddly uplifting. The hooks are diverse in mood—dark
column12: subtle

column1: As they did with No Passion
column2: Protomartyr seal the deal with Casey's lyrics. Often inspired by books and news stories and filtered through the band's deadpan abstractions
column3: they don't always make perfect sense right away. Album opener ""Maidenhead"" is directly influenced by Patrick Hamilton's black comedy novel Hangover Square. It's about George Harvey Bone
column4: a lonely alcoholic who suffers from spells where he feels no pleasure or pain. Casey sings about a ""clack"" in his brain
column5: which triggers ""dead moods"". At the chorus
column6: drummer Alex Leonard and Ahee ramp up their attack
column7: and when things cool down again
column8: Casey sings
column9: ""Maidenhead
column10: here I come
column11: referring to the happy place where Bone longs to return—where he can finally find respite from the darkness. ""I have arrived.""

column1: But here's the hitch: When Bone reaches Maidenhead in the book
column2: he isn't peaceful there—he's just as tortured as he always was. And as Protomartyr push out into the rest of their album
column3: they're still mired in darkness. They outline betrayal
column4: treason
column5: extortion
column6: corruption
column7: bad dads
column8: insufferable randos
column9: and of course
column10: violence. It's tempting to comb through the album to find clues that reveal Casey's initial inspirations
column11: but going line by line and decoding its ""secrets"" is about as arbitrary a practice as naming every sample on a Girl Talk album: it's nice to know the details
column12: but look at the big picture instead. The overall strength of Under Color of Official Right doesn't come from its big words
column13: Detroit cred
column14: or works-cited page; it's from lyrics that
column15: while fraught with symbolism
column16: feel emotionally resonant and
column17: sometimes
column18: viscerally unpleasant. If you listen carefully to Casey's voice
column19: this stuff can hit hard.

column1: Perhaps it's the seething
column2: self-assured vocals

column5: he casually croons on ""What the Wall Said"". A vengeful son kills off a pack of barfly dads in <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/16482-protomartyr-scum-rise/"">""Scum
column6: Rise!""

It's unclear who's to blame

column3: some smooth R&B

column5: jazz syncopation
column6: or acoustic guitar. The results of this formula are
column7: more often than not
column8: broadly appealing; at the least
column9: it makes good background music for parties or cocktail bars.

column1: There's a host of new acts that fit this format
column2: but only one comes with a cartoon world full of characters such as the Grateful Bat (that is
column3: a sardonic-looking hippie bat). Self-described as a “music and art project”

column6: Maroon 5
column7: and Robin Thicke. As a visual artist

column2: Young & Sick is a remarkably polished debut
column3: with each song boasting careful
column4: painstaking arrangements and adept uses of space. It's charming

column2: sweet nothings. Regardless

column4: romantic number over a taut syncopated that represents the album's strongest moment

column2: Nelly Furtado's ""Say It Right""

music is a reliable balm.

It wouldn’t be technically inaccurate to call Dalhous’s new EP Visibility Is A Trap an ambient music record—it’s full of lush
column2: slowly shifting sounds. In general
column3: it’s far more concerned with texture than rhythm or tune
column4: so it meets the genre’s main requirements. But the description doesn’t completely fit. By definition an ambient record
column5: even a great one
column6: is supposed to be able to function as aural wallpaper (and be “as ignorable as it is interesting
column7: ” according to Brian Eno)
column8: but even at its most tranquil moments Visibility refuses to fade into the background. While it has some genuinely blissful passages
column9: it’s mostly just unsettling in a way that’s difficult to pin down—if it was actually wallpaper
column10: you’d swear you could catch its patterns shifting in your peripheral vision.

column1: “Unsettling” has been the duo’s default mode ever since releasing the 2012 EP Mitchell Heisman
column2: named after a man who committed suicide in 2010 and left behind a 1
column3: 900 page exposition on the nature of human existence as way of a suicide note. Visibility is a subtler work
column4: from its titular reference—a line from Michel Foucault’s Discipline and Punish in a passage regarding Jeremy Bentham’s Panopticon
column5: a prison where inmates are never out of their supervisors’ view—on down.

column1: The Foucault reference establishes a paranoid dread that Alex Ander and Marc Dall spend four songs probing and building on with a palette of druggy synth pads and woozy sub-bass deep enough that it might actually be capable of messing with your inner ear. (There’s also a remix by Regis of “He Was Human And Belonged With Humans""
column2: from last year’s An Ambassador For Laing LP.) Ander and Dall are so good at setting an ominous mood that when they shatter the tension on track three
column3: “Sight of Hirta""
column4: by dropping in the EP’s only real beat—a stuttering
column5: stroboscopic thing that slides around a straight dance rhythm but never sticks—almost a traumatic experience.

column1: Visibility is supposed to be inspired by Dall’s interest in the self-help and anti-psychiatry movement
column2: particularly in the Scottish psychiatrist R.D. Laing
column3: whose views on the nature of mental illness—and his insistence that the emotional and mental experiences of the mentally ill shouldn’t be treated simply as pathologies—made him an outcast in his profession but a hero to anti-psychiatry activists. Laing
column4: anti-psychiatry
column5: and self-help all figured into the '70s New Age movement
column6: and
column7: with its plentiful pads and lack of drums
column8: Visibility often evokes New Age music
column9: as well as a general macrame-encrusted hippie-dippy vibe—The burbly synths on “Active Discovering” sound like they could have been pulled from an especially out-there block of programming on PBS during my childhood in the Me Decade’s afterglow. But Dall and Ander like to subvert that feeling as soon as they establish it
column10: and by its halfway point the song’s dissonant elements have accumulated into a sinister edge.

column1: Like David Lynch or Stanley Kubrick
column2: Ander and Dall are happy to present their audience with a bunch of ambiguities that they leave hanging in the air at the end. Their refusal to let the record resolve itself into something that can be easily sorted or explained makes it easy to play it on repeat
column3:
trying to find a new angle to approach it from.

Jon Langford's a Wales native who made his first mark in the late 1970s with the eminently British post-punk of the Mekons
column3: but he's lived in America for decades and has been paying homage to American roots music even longer. Starting with the Mekons’ 1985 album Fear and Whiskey
column4: folk and country have played large parts in almost all of Langford’s releases
column5: both with the Mekons and on his many side projects such as Waco Brothers and the Pine Valley Cosmonauts. It’s his solo albums
column6: though
column7: that have been the most intimate showcases of Langford’s fascination with Americana. From the cantankerous
column8: country-sucks-today rabblerousing of 2004’s All the Fame of Lofty Deeds to the honky-tonk-infused frolic of 2010’s Old Devils
column9: Langford keeps a taut leash on tradition.

column1: So “Summer Stars
column2: ” a song from Here Be Monsters
column3: Langford’s new solo album with his backing band Skull Orchard (a revolving ensemble named after his 1998 solo debut)
column4: comes as a surprise. It begins with an eerie science-fiction monologue—calling to mind that Langford’s older brother David is a renowned sci-fi author specializing in satire and pastiche—that lovingly taps into the space-glam wondrousness of T. Rex and David Bowie. Langford’s voice remains gruff and gregarious
column5: a tattered flag still happily flapping over a landscape littered with the bones of his contemporaries who didn’t make it.

column1: He later covers “Don’t Believe”
column2: a sparse and frostbitten meditation on faithlessness from the Slits member Viv Albertine's 2012 solo debut The Vermilion Border. As a show of post-punk solidarity

column6: practically rollicking pub-pop anthem straight out of Billy Bragg’s playbook. Elsewhere
column7: genre distinctions melt in the simmering melancholy of “Mars”
column8: the album’s slowest and most tension-riddled track. The song's a bookend to “Summer Stars” that subtracts gravity from the proceedings and lets Langford’s hoarse whispers
column9: his plaintive guitar twang
column10: and Jean Cook’s mournful violin hang in midair
column11: harrowingly unresolved.

column1: Still
column2: Americana has not lost its grip on Langford
column3: nor vice versa. A thread of ragged
column4: country-rock glory runs through “Sugar on Your Tongue”
column5: a tender paean to bittersweet regret
column6: and—in what seems to be Langford’s fixation on g-forces (or the lack thereof)—the dusty
column7: tumbleweed-like drift of “Weightless.” The subject matter represents a loose theme in Langford’s work that stretches all the way back to the Mekons’ Sally Timms-sung ballad “Ghosts of American Astronauts”; even on “Summer Stars
column8: ” the song’s Major Tom-esque narrator cites not Bowie
column9: but one of Langford’s more obvious Stateside heroes: “From the North down to the South/ Hank Williams' mouth will fill the sky”. Williams’ voice has certainly loomed large in Langford’s horizons for a long time now
column10: along with those of Johnny Cash
column11: Bob Wills
column12: and many of the other country legends that he's absorbed and digested over the decades. The dilution of purist fidelity makes Here Be Monsters one of Langford’s least focused albums in recent memory
column13:
but it also ends up as one of his richest.

When De La Soul released Stakes Is High in 1996
column2: the MCs were at a significant crossroads—and so was James Yancey
column3: whose work as J Dilla helped define their transition from the Prince Paul-produced lightheartedness of their first three albums. The producer's credited on that album's stirring title track
column4: which flipped jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal's early '70s cut “Swahililand” in ways unheard of since DJ Premier turned the first few bars of “Misdemeanor” into the pacing tension of Gang Starr's “Soliloquy of Chaos”. But the relationship between De La and Dilla went deeper than that: when Posdnuos declared that “The Native Tongues have officially been reinstated
column5: ” he might as well have been predicting the Dilla-heavy braintrust of the Soulquarians that the alt-rap baton would be passed to.

column1: 2004's The Grind Date featured the Dilla-produced single “Shoomp”
column2: but after a year and a half passed
column3: De La's future was uncertain and James Yancey passed away. In the eight years since
column4: it's easy to wonder what might have been. De La Soul's maturing
column5: grown-wiser Art Official Intelligence years and Dilla's early '00s expansions into avant-funk brilliance should've overlapped more than they actually did; it's possible that such an affiliation would've provided a stable identity for a group that was already rejecting pigeonholes and preconceptions by their death-declaring sophomore album. So the new mixtape featuring unreleased Dilla beats and reworked lyrics from De La Soul's catalog
column6: Smell the D.A.I.S.Y.—the acronym retrofitting their '89 iconography to stand for “DA Inner Soul of Yancey”—provides an alternate-history look into a meaningful partnership.

column1: ""Alternate history
column2: ” in this case
column3: means alternate takes on material that fans have already long since familiarized themselves with—a scenario that's less enticing than all-new lyrics over super-obscure Dilla beats. It's disorienting to hear the much-loved verses from “Plug Tunin'” or “Fanatic of the B Word” rattled off by the gruffer
column4: heavier voices of '00s-and-later Pos and Dove
column5: especially when they've been tweaked with switched-up flows
column6: altered lyrics
column7: and even shifted sentiments. So it makes more sense to think of Smell the D.A.I.S.Y. as a studio-bound tribute show-slash-remix album; cast in this light
column8: the reinterpretations are refreshing
column9: proving that even lyrics written a quarter-century ago hold up without too much rewritten interference.

column1: The classic material sounds simultaneously tougher and more reflective
column2: less hyped-up but no less smartassed. De La Soul Is Dead's leadoff cut “Oodles of O's” feels leaner and more tense over Dilla's sparse
column3: deceptively simple minor-key bass-and-drums beat
column4: while “Leave Your Cares Behind” is a sly
column5: airy
column6: neo-soulful parallel of the Chic-interpolating “A Roller Skating Jam Named 'Saturdays'” that switches its mood from low-lit free-skate session to sunny barbecue vibes
column7: closing on a preposterous flip of the ""Spongebob Squarepants"" theme song.

column1: After this year's minor debacle that was De La Soul's 25-hour free-album giveaway—filled with filesharing timeouts and the revelation that the downloads were sourced from an MP3 pirate blog—it's tempting to pick this package apart for flaws as well. You could gripe that Dilla's family name is misspelled “Yancy” in some of the promotional material
column2: but that's the limit of skepticism this project deserves. Along with the album itself

column4: sincere tribute (“Dilla didn't just produce for us
column5: he was an inspiration
column6: and often a kickstart to many De La albums”). A 39-minute 2006 documentary project Still Shining
column7: largely assembled with footage made around and shortly after Dilla's funeral service
column8: is included in better-than-YouTube quality and serves as an important time capsule where friends
column9: family
column10: and collaborators pay tribute and come to terms with where his legacy was headed. The only money-making enterprise involved with Smell the D.A.I.S.Y. is a web bookmark directing people to a PayPal link for a donation to De La's fundraising efforts towards that legacy.

column1: As a record
column2: Smell the D.A.I.S.Y. is a fine diversion—a brisk 29 minutes
column3:
none of which feels superfluous—and a good stopgap in a busy-looking 2014 for De La that promises a Pete Rock/Premier-produced EP and their first full-length in ten years. But as an effort to keep the spirit of a good friend and musical inspiration alive? That's where this is made to last.

When the Faint released their debut album Sine Sierra

column4: and if that makes you feel old

column6: the Faint's angsty
column7: political electro-punk could've seemed like the most exciting shit imaginable
column8: and by the time they reunited to play festivals in 2012

column10: but if we’re going to get one anyway

column1: Of course
column2: that means the Faint still have to make Faint-like music
column3: and they can’t claim any new insight to our political and socioeconomic problems. Regardless if Todd Fink has opinions on the NSA and the Crimea
column4: as far as he’s concerned
column5: 2014 might as well be 2004—or 1994
column6: or 1984. During the anti-everything recitation of “Animal Needs”
column7: Fink nasally intones
column8: “We don’t need soap/ We don’t need straws/ We don’t need software to tell us we’re lost.” He also tells us we don’t need toilets
column9: so...shots fired
column10: American Standard?

column1: The level of discourse on Doom Abuse will hit the spot for people who still think Desaparecidos’ political views are a little too nuanced. Who knows if Fink even believes half the shit he says
column2: but his functional nihilism is an accessory not all that different than pleather pants or Commie-chic album covers: disaffection is sexy
column3: so whether you’re batting your guyliner or rolling your eyes
column4: it’s all part of the same outfit. As he sings at one point
column5: “Evil voices lie when they say you’re in love!”
column6: proving that even coupling is inextricable from shadow-government involvement.

column1: To the Faint’s eternal credit
column2: their sacrifice of any modicum of ""cool"" means the songs on Doom Abuse more fun-silly than flat-out dumb. It’s even more Faint-like than the exceedingly sui generis Fasciination
column3: so at the least they can be forgiven for giving the people what they want. Even if they’re subject to fairly brazen ripoffs—there’s at least twenty different Cure riffs that are similar to the one that drives “Mental Radio”
column4: and the XTRMNTR JR industrial agit-prop of “Animal Needs” is pretty much a verbatim copy of Primal Scream's “Swastika Eyes.”

column1: Doom Abuse is most enjoyable when its superficial slapstick is at its most pronounced
column2: which is most of the time—it’s uptempo
column3: it’s unashamedly hooky
column4: Fink shouts a lot
column5: and it’s over before you can take the time to pick apart study hall manifestos like “Unseen Hand” or “Dress Code”
column6: a 100-second shoutdown against
column7: uh
column8:
dress codes. Doom Abuse isn’t so much an argument for the Faint’s continued relevancy as it is for the potency of their real-time nostalgia.
