In case you were wondering
column2: Ardour still sounds immersively gorgeous three and a half years later. Teebs' debut had a way of flooding your ears with greenery
column3: lush environments seeping out of speakers and making it feel like the ambient temperature was 68 degrees no matter where you were. As low-intensity and mellow as it was
column4: the warped instrumenation and crackling undercurrents of static and accelerated-aging decay seemed immediately tactile
column5: doing for your ears what a look up into sunlight filtered through a canopy of leaves does for your eyes. After the fatigue of the most endless-seeming winter in ages
column6: a followup feels sorely needed.

column1: And yet it seems like something's been lost in the intervening years
column2: considering how concise and relatively unadventurous E S T A R A has turned out to be. Unadventurous in this case doesn't necessarily mean derivative
column3: least of all derivative of himself; the departure from the sprawling warmth of Ardour into more straightforward beats is at least transitional. And it's not necessarily boring
column4: either—it's appealingly pretty music that's still a bit too attention-getting to recede into the background. But this is one of those cases where little manages to stick after repeated listens: slow builds
column5: subtle shifts and clever juxtapositions reward close listening
column6: but it doesn't do much to actually pull listeners in.

column1: Meeting the music more than halfway isn't that strenuous
column2: thankfully
column3: and the early advance singles are enough to get a sense of the album's strong points. Jonti collaboration “Holiday” has the neat trick of smearing and smothering its notes to the point that there's little distinction between where the melodic progressions end and the sustained drones begin
column4: thickly layered walls of percussive melody and melodic percussion concocting a blurry haze for bird chirps and sun-bleached vocals to stream through. “View Point” is more upfront in its structure—a beat that sounds like a muted
column5: underwater tabla
column6: offset with distorted ringing-bell chords that oscillate between sharp chimes and dissipating waves—and
column7: with its parallel senses of deep rhythm and medidative drone
column8: does a lot to advance Teebs' strengths as someone who can put together a dance track with the nuance and delicacy of an ambient composition.

column1: There are other moments of arresting beauty
column2: like the bossa-tinged beat on Prefuse 73 collab “NY pt. 2” that pairs airy woodblock and heavy-elastic kicks with crystalline acoustic guitar notes
column3: or the sustain-drenched keys that make “Piano Days”/”Piano Months” feel like Overlook Hotel muzak if the ghosts were more Miyazaki than Kubrick. But there are just as many songs that slip through your ears. “Shoouss Lullaby” is little more than windchimes over foot-dragging bass rumbles that eventually drag themselves out of bed to join a woozy-headed beat
column4: and “SOTM” runs off the jittery momentum of a gathering-steam burble of rapidfire click-boom-cymbal percussion. But even at opposite ends of the energy-level spectrum
column5: they're both too gauzy and vague to resonate much further than the last moment of fading reverb.

column1: E S T A R A is almost hypnotic in its tendency to make each individual track blur itself into an indistinct piece of a loosely memorable whole
column2: one with little impression actually retained even if it jumps from mood to mood. Melancholy
column3: bucolic relaxation
column4: and agitated giddiness all run through this record
column5: but its emotionally calming effect comes at the expense of anything truly revelatory or exciting. It's only when the clarinet of Jaga Jazzist's Lars Horntveth wafts its way into an almost snarky song- and album-ending moment at the conclusion of “Wavxxes”. There the sustained momentum finally all winds down in a flurry of missed notes and stray chuckles— the humanity finally piercing the surface. The mood is broken
column6: the past 40 minutes vanish into the ether
column7: and the loose sense of having just experiencing something fairly pleasant is all that's really left. Still
column8:
that elusive moment's worth trying to recapture with each listen.

White Hinterland
column2: the solo project of vocalist Casey Dienel
column3: is a study in texture
column4: space
column5: and expanse
column6: stretching R&B-laced pop to emotional extremes. Her last record
column7: 2010’s Kairos
column8: was woozy both instrumentally and conceptually
column9: leaning toward gossamer dream pop. Baby
column10: her newest
column11: sheds the downtempo beats of Kairos
column12: experimenting with more jagged percussion and orchestral flourishes
column13: notably horns. Dienel learned Protools and built a studio in the basement of her parents’ house
column14: and the methodical approach to the recording
column15: arrangement and production yields a work that feels homegrown (Pitchfork contributor Matt LeMay mixed the record). But for all the sonic change-ups
column16: her idiosyncratic voice remains the music’s signature.

column1: Dienel is in a line of vocalists who subvert traditional diction—Fiona Apple with her asymmetrical couplets
column2: Björk’s ability to contort syllables. She tucks whelps and cries between verses
column3: moving from opera-worthy falsettos to pained whimpers
column4: at times recalling Zola Jesus’s blackened folk and even the indie pop falsetto crawl of Portugal. The Man frontman John Gourley. Baby’s opener
column5: “Wait Until Dark
column6: ” features nearly a minute of tense near-silence
column7: with Dienel spitting irregular verbs in the dark
column8: creating an effect that’s uncomfortably intimate—not to mention riveting. “Show me respect
column9: maybe then I’ll let you ride with me
column10: ” she growls and howls
column11: curling the words behind the acid-keys of the record’s grooviest number
column12: “Metronome.” Dienel can also belt with a diva’s range
column13: especially on the Saturday night club-ready tracks such as “White Noise”. But the album also presents an interesting paradox: Dienel’s voice
column14: the record’s most gripping element
column15: can also be alienating. Occasionally
column16: her ambitious approach lead in over-singing
column17: such as on “Ring the Bell
column18: ” where her background vocals get in the way.

column1: On the whole
column2: Baby is an exceptionally cautious work and is
column3: at times an uncomfortable listen; it’s an account of a woman wrestling with and tackling self-doubt and insecurity
column4: exploring how it feels to lose control. “Is this my weakness?” Dienel asks as the instruments fade to black in the record’s title track. Over the song’s duration
column5: the question evolves from an admission to a mantra
column6: as Dienel’s voice gains traction and grows in power. Corrosive lyrics also make it an exceptionally heavy listen
column7: when she delivers likes like
column8: “Pushed your head under the water till all your breath gave out” on the title track. But even though it’s filled with stark admissions
column9:
Baby is ultimately an unflinchingly hopeful record that sees an already talented artist finding finding new ways to grow.

With YG and DJ Mustard referring to themselves as millennial analogues to Snoop and Dre
column2: and artists both prudent (Drake
column3: Trey Songz) and floundering (Chris Brown
column4: Jennifer Lopez) inching westward for a piece of Mustard’s sound
column5: it’s easy to mistake L.A. for the center of the current West Coast rap resurgence. But further up the Pacific Coast Highway
column6: Sage the Gemini and Iamsu! of the Bay area’s Heartbreak Gang collective have refined a sound that draws influence from frenetic dance-informed NorCal hyphy music and L.A. jerk music
column7: with hints of the sleek “crunk&B” of Jazze Pha and Ciara. In 2014
column8: both artists are at a peculiar stage of fame: Iamsu!’s found success playing wingman to other artists
column9: and Sage is sitting on gold and platinum viral hits that the average listener might not be able to recognize as his.

column1: Sage’s debut single “Red Nose” worked its way into the Billboard Hot 100 thanks to its association with the Bay area’s yiking dance movement; its chorus likens the dance’s signature lateral twerking motion to that of a wet dog shaking its head dry
column2: and the use of “Red Nose” as a soundtrack to scores of yiking-focused Vines and Youtube videos lent it chart traction. Follow-up single “Gas Pedal” further advanced Sage’s star
column3: bowing out in the lower rungs of the Top 40 and moving over a million units in the process; third single “College Drop” tried to wrangle “Red Nose” and “Gas Pedal”’s successes and achieved modest success on the hip-hop songs chart. Sage’s instructional dance floor drills are presently his livelihood
column4: but he’s a smart kid who knows he can’t spend the remainder of his career telling women how and where to shake their asses. So his debut album Remember Me arrives with a mission: keep listeners on their feet
column5: but show some range.

column1: Remember Me marks a respectable attempt at achieving that goal; its opening title track matches sped-up mobb-music sonics to autobiographical nerd-makes-good testimonials
column2: and the rest of the album peppers a parade of carefree party music with pathos. A lot of the album is kiddie-pool deep and full of pith for jealous onlookers
column3: pep talks for struggling rappers
column4: boasts about girls wooed out from under lames
column5: celebrations of new money
column6: and a healthy shock of incredulity that any of this is happening. Closer “Second Hand Smoke” pushes its luck on a foggy anti-drug metaphor never quite comes together
column7: but Sage’s affable aw-shucks charm and sparingly busy delivery draw attention off the goofiness of the premise. Remember Me is short on hard-fought insights and heavy on Sage and Su’s goofball wordplay and sharp hook construction
column8: but it radiates the confident cool of studio rats perfectly at ease rhyming with friends over homemade beats.

column1: Sage the Gemini’s greatest strengths are compositional. He produced six of Remember Me’s twelve songs
column2: and those cuts showcase both a mercenary efficiency with post-hyphy club bangers and a questing desire to turn them inside out. Sage knocks out all the curt uptempo numbers early on “Bad Girls” and “Go Somewhere”
column3: both built around martial drum patterns and brash synths that oscillate in and out of key. By the album’s midway point
column4: all the strip club-friendly dance tutorials are spent as Sage comes with the change-up in “Put Me On”
column5: a bit of clownish
column6: spectral video game boss lair music with disorienting drum construction.

column1: Remember Me’s back half committedly illuminates the frayed edges of Sage’s sound: the brusque 808 infused trap excursion “Down on Your Luck” trades Migos-esque flow missives with singer August Alsina
column2: “Mad at Me” pops collars over jazzy guitar and pulsing cymbals care of HBK associate Jay Ant
column3: and “Don’t You” works wonders with a one-chord hook. “Second Hand Smoke” possesses a brittle lyrical conceit and is garbled in concept
column4: but its ornately layered melodies make for an authoritative closer.

column1: As an exercise in showcasing Sage the Gemini’s capabilities beyond booty music
column2: Remember Me succeeds by keeping its sights reasonable and coasting past them on Sage’s garrulous charm and studio know-how. Periodically
column3: he trips
column4: and we end up with a dancefloor sargeant clunkily fishing out of his depth. But the writing here is always affable and occasionally gratifyingly personal
column5: and barring a few cuts
column6: the production is never less than engaging. Sage modulates from partied-out excess to spoils-of-newfound-fame reflection rather well
column7: steering mercifully clear of lofty ideas and tough-guy posturing he’d look out of place assuming. Remember Me keeps its mood light and its stakes low
column8: and in the process delivers a much needed breezy counterpoint to all the knotty
column9:
fatalistic shit coming out of HBK’s downstate peers that’s every bit as true to Cali as the gangsters and the thinkers.

column3: Sisyphus appear incongruent. Anticon rapper Serengeti functions as the deadpan narrator
column4: Sufjan as the whisper-drive balladeer
column5: and Ryan Lott under his Son Lux guise as the anxious
column6: industrial beatsmith. These three distinct talents are
column7: in a sense
column8: insoluble
column9: but their electro-focused sound works when their synapses fire off of each other and the ideas dovetail and blend together. Their first release
column10: 2012's Beak & Claw EP
column11: was a scattered lark that featured an abundance of Auto-Tune; on their self-titled debut LP
column12: that element's been scrubbed from the group's formula
column13: and the three of them have improved on their ability to create fractured-sounding music together—even if the results prove a little frustrating.

column1: Inspired by Jim Hodges’ art installation “Untitled”
column2: as well as the artist's body of work
column3: Sisyphus was co-commissioned by Minneapolis’ Walker Art Center and St. Paul Chamber Orchestra’s SPCO’s Liquid Music series. There's high-minded artistic ambitions at work here
column4: then
column5: as Sisyphus can be classified as something executed with the aim of being displayed and sold in a museum. To wit: the record's most simplistically fun moment is a six-and-a-half minute
column6: multi-section song called “Calm It Down”
column7: featuring positive-thinking musings from Serengeti and the type of balladry that Stevens executed so well on 2010's Age of Adz.  Other engaging moments are located in the slow-building noise of album closer “Alcohol”
column8: as well as the vocoder'd pomp of “Rhythm of Devotion”
column9: which finds ‘Geti aping Kanye West’s ""New Slaves"" cadence throughout.

column1: Sometimes
column2: though
column3: the trio's cleverness can get the best of them. Serengeti occasionally values sticking to a rhyme scheme over telling a narrative (""Booty Call"")
column4: while Lott can't focus on honing one good idea (the shapeshifting ""Flying Ace"")
column5: and Stevens issues one too many utterances of the word “booty”. Then there's the untangleable mess of ""My Oh My""
column6: which unwisely merges skittery trap synths
column7: ill-fitting sitcom references (""Drink a lot of milk like my name was Ted Cleaver"")
column8: and Stevens' now-trademark flute runs on the song's chorus.

column1: However
column2: much of Sisyphus is bogged down in malaise. In an interview about the album
column3: Stevens stated the group's artistic intent: “We wanted to make ear candy—catchy raps
column4: pop songs
column5: and sad ballads. But if you inspect some of the content
column6: you’ll uncover some bleak events.” You don't have to dig deep
column7: though
column8: to find the bleakness: witness Stevens singing in his teary-eyed voice ""I'm prepared for death/ I will tear clothes” on the dirge-like ""I Won't Be Afraid."" On the sparse ""Dishes in the Sink""
column9: Serengeti raps from the perspective of a blue-collar
column10: acerbic character whose sardonic attitude is reflected in the rapper's delivery: ""I was happy once when I went to a real brunch/ It was special."" These dour elements are tied together by Son Lux’s production
column11: whose classical-electro beats are so spiny and unsteady they inspire more squinting than head-nodding.

column1: More often than not
column2: Sisyphus misses its mark
column3: but the album's dense
column4: melancholy back half represents its strongest moments. On ""Lion's Share""
column5: Serengeti tells a ripped-from-the-headlines story about a Chicago jail break in a straight-forward chilled out '80s throwback rap
column6: while “Dishes in the Sink” and its companion ballad “Hardly Hanging On” tell a genuinely affecting story of squalor and depression. Despite these peaks
column7:
Sisyphus is more fun to ponder than it is to listen to.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20386/homepage_large.5329e1d6.jpg|I Shall Die Here|10726.0|The Body|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2014-04-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:25.827768|"

Genre boundaries mean nothing to the Body
column2: who celebrate 15 years in the business with their most audacious statement to date in I Shall Die Here. The band
column3: now based in Portland
column4: Oregon after years spent in Providence
column5: Rhode Island
column6: take doom metal as their core template and shred it to pieces until it's completely unrecognizable. The band
column7: a two-piece of drummer Lee Buford and guitarist/singer Chip King
column8: plus longstanding studio collaborators Seth Manchester and Keith Souza
column9: clearly felt something needed to change after their 2013 album
column10: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18630-the-body-christs-redeemers/""><i>Christs
column11: Redeemers. That album felt like a retreat
column12: a surrender
column13: a settling into type
column14: where prior form and function was repeated
column15: not forwarded. Enter Bobby Krlic
column16: the British musician who records jaundiced electronic works under his Haxan Cloak moniker
column17: who comes on board as producer
column18: helping Buford and King rip the guts out of their sound to achieve maximal brutality.

column1: Something that's evolved over time with the Body's work is their use of space
column2: not just in their choral collaborations on prior records
column3: but also in their other material. On I Shall Die Here it's their most potent weapon
column4: giving the sound a greater sense of suggestion than ever before. The dips into near-silence
column5: where machine noise is allowed to trail quietly in the mix
column6: effectively work as cues to pry open the imagination. At times they even function like a scene in a horror movie
column7: where you just know something bad is coming around the corner
column8: but the sense of anticipation is so expertly orchestrated that the fear is only heightened when the moment finally hits. ""Our Souls Were Clean"" is the best example of that here—it's all echoing electronics that resemble a machine repeating on itself long after any human hand has touched it
column9: ultimately turning into a convulsing swirl of noise that feels like being trapped in a constant spray of vomit over the two-minute close of the song.

column1: It's not always clear who did what here
column2: or how much Krlic overhauled the sound of the Body. In a sense it's better going into I Shall Die Here without knowing whether samples changed hands
column3: or how strips of guitar were pulled out and inserted elsewhere. A strong air of album-as-standoff results
column4: with musicians from different disciplines throwing daggers into each other's work
column5: making it feel like everyone was eyeing each other uneasily across the studio floor. Such working methods could turn into a mess
column6: but here it results in a great weight of tension sinking into the material. It's hard not to feel suffocated by it all when the death march beat of ""To Carry the Seeds of Death Within Me"" pulls in layer upon layer of oppression. But there are also strong dynamics at work in ""Seeds""
column7: especially when the song gets stripped down to the bare bones and a great sweep of noise jolts it back to life—a trick mirrored on the opening ""Consumed"" from Krlic’s Excavation. It makes it feel like ten tons of electricity are suddenly pulsing through the track.

column1: An unrelentingly bleak worldview is presented throughout the Body's work
column2: and often in their interviews as well. Occasionally they substitute desolation for ghoulish thrills
column3: which is marginally less successful. The pitch-shifted spoken word intro to ""Alone All the Way"" adds an unwelcome touch of schlocky horrorcore
column4: although the subsequent track—all air raid distress calls and isolated screeches in the dark—brings the murky air of pessimism that curls up around the album firmly back into view. At its strongest
column5: on the standout ""Hail to Thee
column6: Everlasting Pain""
column7: it's an album that takes a mazy journey through styles
column8: not so much seeking common ground between them
column9: but actively looking for the point of agitation that arises as they brashley bruise up against one another. So ""Hail"" takes in a great lattice of sound
column10: bringing samples on board that resemble the compact structures of Autechre's Amber
column11: along with treated industrial drums
column12: great slabs of drone-y guitar
column13: and King's blood-curdling shriek.

column1: The collective work on I Shall Die Here makes it feel like all involved were searching for illogical endpoints
column2: driving strains of metal and electronic music to some kind of brink of extremes that the Body and the Haxan Cloak's individual output had never taken them before. There's certainly an end-of-all-things atmosphere
column3: but perhaps more importantly a strong sense of unlearning everything they knew in an attempt to push music into a totally new space. Not that this is music without precedent; there are shades of Demdike Stare
column4: Prurient
column5: Earth
column6: and Sunn O))) at various times. But the execution of I Shall Die Here is so full-blooded
column7: so committed to forcing your head underwater to the point of blackout
column8: that it's hard not to view this as a singular piece
column9: out there on its own
column10: in a place most people wouldn't want to go anywhere near. It adds a chillingly lonely air to the work
column11: making it morbidly fascinating to see its participants head out on a road pointed eternally downward
column12:
landing in a place wracked by torment and lost hopes.

column18: in returning

column1: It will be a relief to some and a disappointment to others
column2: then
column3: that Drop the Vowels
column4: the project's debut LP
column5: is not a trap record
column6: despite what its trend-baiting title suggests. Whittaker and Stott are still exploring familiar territory—hollow dub techno
column7: into-the-red noise
column8: breakbeats that hiss and spit with static—but they're still fond of coloring outside of the lines as they did on 2009's ecstatic ""Ever Since You Came Down"". ""Stay Ugly"" feeds a colorful synth line through distortion
column9: as a drum break cyclically contracts and expands in nastiness; ""Corrosive""
column10: the album's most easily apprehensible cut
column11: takes clicking footwork patterns and slathers them in fog
column12: arpeggiated tones rippling endlessly in the distance before another chaotic break crashes through to disrupt the proceedings. For those familiar with Whittaker and Stott's individual output
column13: the firmament backing these sounds are unmistakably their creators'—but the extra flourishes are what prove most surprising.

column1: Amidst Drop the Vowels' pleasing left-turns—the clipped vocal sample that kicks open ""Spectral Source""
column2: a track originally released in Millie & Andrea's first run of 12""s
column3: carries a sugared swing while also sounding like someone being slowly choked to death—Whittaker and Stott excel when zeroing in on texture. The layers of echo and frizzy static applied throughout are done to create a 3D effect—essentially
column4: this is body music
column5: in that the crashing noise feels so uncomfortably close-range that it can resemble someone scraping your eardrums with a knife. Whittaker and Stott possess a gentle side
column6: too: the chaotic tumble of ""Temper Tantrum"" occasionally peels back to reveal a chipmunk'd vocal sample before emptying its cargo bay to reveal a lush backdrop of drone. Stick around until the track's very end
column7: too
column8: when Whittaker and Stott let loose a single
column9: satisfying bass hit possessing a brown-sound subtlety.

column1: Up to this point
column2: Stott's Luxury Problems stood as the best entry point to his and Modern Love's harsh
column3: uninviting world of razed sonics; while Drop the Vowels doesn't carry the game-changing nature of that album
column4: the relative sonic variety it provides compared to Luxury Problems' expressively singular mindset makes for a solid introduction to one of contemporary techno's most consistently exciting collectives. When working together
column5: Whittaker and Stott pull off an enviable trick of retaining specific stylistic tics they possess separately while creating something that sounds not quite like anything either of the artists have made before
column6:
and hopefully they won't wait so long to execute their collaborative talents again.

column1: Range of Light is the first album Carey's recorded in Bon Iver bandmate Justin Vernon's April Base studio in Fall Creek
column2: Wis.; he cobbled together his 2010 debut All We Grow while on tour with Bon Iver and built 2012's electro-folk Hoyas EP on mostly just a laptop. The warmth

column5: but his real talent lies in making these songs seem tiny set against the world around him.

column1: Even though Carey’s canvas is large
column2: Range of Light is all detail—including his voice
column3: which remains whisper-quiet and occasionally climbs to a hushed tenor akin to Sufjan Stevens. His voice is more up front than before
column4: which gives these songs more shape as he interacts with the ceaselessly beautiful soundscapes
column5: breaking up the serenity with songcraft. The syncopated “Crown the Pines” uses Justin Vernon’s falsetto as another background texture

column1: A trained percussionist in both jazz and classical music

column3: spoons on thighs

column1: Paradoxically
column2: Range of Light can sound a little too on-the-nose about embodying the majesty of nature and its meditative properties; there are greyscale cuts that possess cautious wonder and tumble-dry jazz tones
column3: like Talk Talk left out in the cold for too long. Carey's destinations and recollections can retreat to a sleepy
column4: melancholy safe zone. Regardless
column5: Range Of Light is the first album that defines Carey apart from his bandmates and contemporaries
column6: as his developed
column7: earnest
column8:
Midwestern glow bursts through the album's cracks.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20370/homepage_large.68d4ad4f.jpg|Nux Vomica|32176.0|Nux Vomica|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-04-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:27.942375|"

Nux Vomica are a band in perpetual motion. Several years ago

column3: they'd been experimenting with dynamics and genres
column4: slowly outgrowing their crust punk roots. They're quite good at it: The quintet's possessed with the uncanny ability to swirl together crust
column5: melodic death metal
column6: black metal
column7: metallic hardcore
column8: doom
column9: noise
column10: and ambient music into a cohesive
column11: engaging whole. Here
column12: they join the likes of Agrimonia
column13: Downfall of Gaia
column14: Fall of Efrafa
column15: and even their clear inspirations in Neurosis and Tragedy as examples of crust bands who reached for something more
column16: and ended up with something greater. Their 2009 LP Asleep in the Ashes is still one of the best examples of cross-genre pollination in regards to extreme metal
column17: and with their third full-length (and debut for Relapse)
column18: they’ve provided more firepower for the argument. Given the high quality of their past work
column19: Nux Vomica have continued to refine their sound in truly impressive fashion
column20: and on this self-titled
column21: three-song opus
column22: they’ve hit upon an ideal balance of beauty and brutality.

column1: The presence of melody is more pronounced and well-developed
column2: and the dark
column3: heavy moments hit harder. Just Dave’s ragged vocal approach is pure crust punk fury
column4: and undoubtedly the most straightforward aspect of the band’s sound. Nux Vomica are otherwise happy to play with genres and dynamics
column5: cherrypicking buzzing
column6: icy tremolo picking
column7: and rising melodic chords (a shining example of which lies midway through “Sanity Is for the Passive”) and applying them to their foundation of crusty metallic hardcore. Slow-burning buildups and ecstatic melodic crescendos keep the album moving
column8: and even a 20-minute track like “Choked at the Roots” refuses to drag. It’s an impressive feat
column9: but Nux Vomica have been working towards this moment for more than a decade. Their alliance with Relapse marks what may very well be their “big break
column10: ” or at least
column11: go a long way towards introducing them to the uninitiated. It’s good timing
column12: because this is their best effort to date.

column1: Opening track “Sanity Is for the Passive” rushes in with urgency
column2: framed by Dave’s frantic barks that rail against the media’s culture of misinformation. “We cannot live this way
column3: we must resist!
column4: ” he howls
column5: frustration and desperate rage informing every syllable. Nux Vomica’s politicized bent has formed the bedrock of the band’s philosophy since its inception in 2003
column6: and this latest effort sees them dial it up even further. On “Sanity Is for the Passive”
column7: they place the onus to improve conditions on the oppressed
column8: snarling “Why do we participate so willingly?” Here
column9: drummer Zacrilege leans heavily on his toms to create a huge rolls of tribal-influenced
column10: Neurosis-style thunder
column11: and the song itself roils atop the skeleton of a Swedish melodic death metal riff and blasts of furious metallic hardcore. Over the course of nearly 13 minutes
column12: that intensity dissolves into a turbid ambient dirge
column13: punctuated only by nearly indecipherable guttural spoken-word samples and snippets of sharp political prose. “Reeling” follows prettily
column14: climbing an almost shoegazy melodic riff to great heights and riding the positive energy for a good few minutes. That opening salvo parallels the gentle gloom of “Corpses With Egos” on their last full-length
column15: adding a nice sense of continuity. Of course
column16: being who they are
column17: the song quickly shifts into eclectic territory
column18: running Danny’s doomy
column19: ultra-distorted bassline beneath strokes of dreamy post-rock before picking up the pace and punching in desperate vocals and crashing cymbals.

column1: Closer “Choked at the Roots” takes its time
column2: grooving through a moody buildup before exploding. The Swedish death metal influence is strongest in this tune; some sections are full-on Gothenburg melodeath
column3: while others jib closer with dark d-beaten hardcore. But it always sounds like Nux Vomica. The guitar work on this track is spectacularly creative and never gets away from itself; whenever they seems close to veering off course
column4: guitarists Tim Messing and Chris Control turn on a dime and dive into a new riff or idea. The mid-song interlude cycles back to a haunting feedback-driven instrumental and ends on a triumphant note of hardcore euphoria. For a band that concerns itself so deeply with society’s ills and the sins of man
column5:
this is an incredibly joyful record. Perhaps they can tell they’ve made a difference.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20061/homepage_large.2bedb218.jpg|Memoryhouse|3641.0|Max Richter|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['130701']|2014-04-02 00:00:00|2002|2016-06-11 16:39:28.408029|"

In January
column2: the German-born composer Max Richter completed a task that had long felt like a dream: He heard the music of Memoryhouse
column3: his first album under his own name
column4: played in front of an audience in a proper auditorium. What’s more
column5: the show in London’s large Barbican Hall was not only sold out but an event important enough to necessitate the second vinyl reissue of the album. Since its release in 2002
column6: Memoryhouse has become a landmark of the amorphous scene that would eventually earn the tags “post-classical” or “indie classical.” Memoryhouse remains audacious but careful
column7: intimate but vivid
column8: innovative but reverent. In 2002
column9: Richter’s ability to weave subtle electronics against the grand BBC Philharmonic Orchestra helped suggest new possibilities and locate fresh audiences that composers such as Nico Muhly and Michał Jacaszek have since pursued. As you listen to new work by Julianna Barwick or Jóhann Jóhannson
column10: thank Richter; just as Sigur Rós did with its widescreen rock
column11: Richter showed that crossover wasn’t necessarily an artistic curse. Nearly a dozen years later
column12: the material finally got its due.

column1: When Richter began composing what became Memoryhouse in the late 90s
column2: he had no idea if any ensemble would ever record the work
column3: let alone play it live: “I just wrote the work for my own peace of mind—to just get it out of my system
column4: ” he recounted earlier this year. “This was my first time recording my ‘real’ music with an orchestra... It seemed like a crazy thing to happen.” In many ways
column5: this is simply the sound to which his three decades of life had directed him. He’d written music as early as a pre-teen
column6: then fallen for Kratfwerk and the Beatles. He’d considered becoming a poet by trade. Eventually
column7: Richter rigorously studied music
column8: training as a classical pianist and composer and working under the auspices of experimental innovator Luciano Berio. Richter went on to help form the minimalist-focused group Piano Circus and
column9: during their popular mid-90s run
column10: collaborated closely with the electronic duo the Future Sound of London. Funded by a short-lived record label wing of the wonderfully eclectic BBC3 show Late Junction
column11: Memoryhouse arrived as the post-modern nexus of it all—the piano and the strings
column12: the bass and the static
column13: the poems and the samples
column14: set against a rather solemn view of worldwide political struggle.

column1: A few relatively straightforward pieces for strings and sometimes horns help anchor Memoryhouse. For instance
column2: “Last Days” works as a symphonic crescendo
column3: with incisive strings providing the tension against a march of low brass and concert percussion. The piano sonata “Andras” presses into an unseen ceiling
column4: a melody growing only so loud and busy before quieting down again and again. But much of Memoryhouse threads those standard maneuvers against risky production choices and rather unexpected textures. “Garden (1973)/Interior” builds a glorious drone behind the voice of John Cage reading his poems; eventually
column5: the long tone yields to a sobbing violin line that winds through a harpsichord lace. And during the brazen “Untitled (Figures)""
column6: Richter accents a beat that might’ve been lifted from Aphex Twin with twinkling bells and sighing strings. “Laika’s Journey” takes the sonic structure of an orchestra and inverts it
column7: string-based splendor becoming the basis of notes that fade in and out like ghostlights.

column1: Some of the gambles are subtler. Above field recordings and a reading from political refugee and poet Edmond Jabès
column2: opener “Europe
column3: After the Rain” plays a disappearing game with its piano and string sections. Each separate element sometimes sounds as though it were being transmitted through a radio or piped in from the next room. Richter is undermining the orchestra he never thought he’d have. “Landscape with Figure (1922)” initially moves with the drama and grace of Arvo Pärt’s Tabula Rasa
column4: but Richter fights the impulse to stay polite. By piece’s end
column5: the (acoustic) bass seems swollen enough to accompany Sunn O)))
column6: the higher notes piercing and loud enough to galvanize most any post-rock climax. But it's the remarkable “Lines on a Page (One Hundred) Violins” that does it all: Richter crafts a wonderful moment of chamber ensemble beauty
column7: then pits it against a background noise of spoken word signals and the kind of blissful electroacoustic haze Fennesz helped make famous. The track only lasts 83 seconds
column8: but it’s a revelation of the possibilities that Richter would continue to explore on the more restrained and more thoroughly realized follow-up
column9: 2004’s The Blue Notebooks. Memoryhouse was an essential starting point
column10: not the peak of Richter’s aesthetic. That was yet to come.

column1: Richter often talks about art as a sort of personal synthesis
column2: where all the inspirations
column3: influences and experiences of his life funnel into a particular project. That’s especially true for Memoryhouse
column4: an album that took only two years to write but took most of his life to ponder. And the composer
column5: now 46
column6: first fell in love with recorded music not through shiny discs or tiny files but through slabs of vinyl. “Our sense of what is beautiful in music is always shaped by what we listened to as a kid
column7: and when I think of great music
column8: I think of vinyl music
column9: ” he said in an interview not long before the Barbican performance. “The Beatles
column10: the Beach Boys—they are an anchor to how I think
column11: and they were made on tape
column12: for vinyl.”

column1: Apart from mere coronation of that January show
column2: Richter’s preference is perhaps the best explanation for this latest reissue of Memoryhouse. Fat Cat imprint 130701 offered the album on both CD and LP when it initially re-released Memoryhouse in 2009
column3: but this version puts the content on two white LPs
column4: with a gatefold cover and additional art. If that sounds like a slim update of such an important album on such an auspicious date
column5: it is. Richter tends to discuss music as a conversation between composer
column6: subject and audience
column7: but this feels a little like a monologue. Perhaps a set of essays that gets to the heart of why Memoryhouse mattered then and now
column8: or even a batch of the musical sketches that led to these meticulous 65 minutes
column9: could provide that sort of communicative context. Richter
column10: after all
column11: has never been shy about what this set meant to his career or for the subsequent rise of a particular “indie classical” cadre with which he’s often associated.

column1: Still
column2: hearing Memoryhouse again through any avenue for the first time in years provides a jolting reminder of just how much classical music has broken outside of its shell and into other realms during the last decade. Lost in the Trees
column3: a band writing Baroque-influence song cycles about childhood trauma
column4: can thrive on the rock label ANTI- alongside Tom Waits and Neko Case. Rock musicians like Bryce Dessner
column5: Jonny Greenwood and Glenn Kotche can get legitimate attention and substantive interpretations of their classical sidelines with groups like So Percussion
column6: yMusic and Kronos Quartet. The Ecstatic Music Festival can thrive to the point it reaches Carnegie Hall and launches marquee premieres of major works. And in London
column7: Max Richter can hear Memoryhouse live for the first time
column8: played by the orchestra that recorded it
column9:
in a very sold-out Barbican. 

"|18864.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18864-max-richter-memoryhouse/|8.7|Grayson Haver Currin

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20382/homepage_large.7f51717b.jpg|Inventions|32028.0|Inventions|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2014-04-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:28.889807|"

Some collaborations feel inevitable. Matthew Cooper
column2: the producer behind the multifaceted ambient project Eluvium
column3: shares a label and a sensibility with post-rock juggernaut Explosions in the Sky—both craft towering edifices of sound that aren’t afraid to go for the emotional jugular. Inventions

column5: sounds much like you might expect
column6: with a mix of Smith’s shimmering guitars and Cooper’s placid drones. But the familiarity works in the record’s favor—by laying aside the idea of making music outside of their comfort zones

column1: About those feelings: early in their career
column2: Explosions in the Sky could have been just another band in the crowded field of post-Mogwai instrumental rock. On a quick spin in 2001
column3: you wouldn’t necessarily have guessed that in a decade they would be roughly 1
column4: 000 times bigger than
column5: say
column6: Mono. But if you listened more closely
column7: it was clear that EITS had zeroed in on a small handful of emotions and mastered the means to evoke them. Anticipation
column8: yearning
column9: hope
column10: and catharsis: this is more or less the totality of the band’s mental universe. Even their loudest and most crushing climaxes are imbued with hope. Rather than dissolving your ego
column11: the way the most intense noise-saturated shoegaze can

column16: like working a muscle. It may not be a particularly deep or complicated experience
column17: but it is a powerful one
column18: and also quite relatable. And this slice of feeling
column19: which EITS have down completely
column20: turned out to be perfect for soundtracking dramatic film and television of a certain stripe
column21: where their music isn’t used as contrast or shading

column1: I’m focusing on Explosions in the Sky because Inventions ultimately seems closer to their aesthetic. Eluvium is harder to pin down
column2: anyway
column3: because Cooper has released everything from light piano instrumentals to thick drones that verge on noise; his music has never been just one thing. But here he’s working with Smith to make something that plays like low key EITS
column4: capturing the flickering
column5: starry-eyed parts before they grow. You can hear the thread in the light beats
column6: chiming guitar
column7: trails of feedback
column8: and major chord synths drones running through the opening triptych of “Echo Tropism”
column9: “Flood Poems”
column10: and “Entity”.

column1: There are also some new wrinkles. “Entity” has what sound like gurgling voices echoing in the distance
column2: and the atmosphere is watery
column3: amniotic
column4: evoking early 90s ambient in the vein of the Orb. Relative to what surrounds it
column5: it’s a detached and comparatively static track that keeps the focus on texture. “Peaceable Child” has a flittering strobe effect slicing the drone into tiny pieces
column6: bringing to mind circa–2001 glitch
column7: with dubby accents to match; it’s one of the few places where you hear the music and think
column8: “computer
column9: ” but the change-up is welcome. Lack of variety aside
column10: Eluvium and Smith couldn’t be a better match
column11: and the record as a whole possesses an uncommon beauty.

column1: Two tracks on Inventions outline both the power and the limitations of the project. “Sun Locations / Sun Coda” has a kind of queasy clatter going on in the middle of it
column2: so it almost feels frightening but then never quite does
column3: while the closing “Psychic Automation” shows how even when the music gets “heavy” with a massive beat in its final half it never shades to “dark.” The immaculate construction of both is undeniable and the tracks bring with them a rush of feelings
column4:
but there’s no escaping that at their core they still touch on that small handful of sensations that usually circle back around to yearning and wonder. But that’s not a bad thing. There are times when you know exactly where you want to go and this is the music to take you there.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20379/homepage_large.77131672.jpg|Crystal Cult 2080|29894.0|Legowelt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Crème']|2014-04-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:29.352682|"

If ""The X-Files"" ever chose to explore the early-1990s rave scene—truly
column2: a bunch of kids wiggling around to alien noises in rural fields would've proven fertile ground—Danny Wolfers might have served as the episode's comic reveal: a harmless longhair making old machines whoosh and pump in his den. This is part of the fun of Wolfers' Legowelt alias: he's the rare producer whose personal mythology enriches his music instead of distracts from it (see also: Omar S). Crystal Cult 2080 is Wolfers' latest album
column3: and it's a lot like his last album
column4: 2012's Paranormal Soul
column5: as well as the dozen or so singles and EPs he released in the interim: richly melodic
column6: forested techno and house erected with vintage gear both fetishized and pulled from the scrap heap.

column1: Crystal Cult 2080 takes its title from Roland's somewhat obscure JV-2080 synthesizer and
column2: more interestingly
column3: a ""germanium crystal compressor"" of Wolfers' own making. Crystal Cult 2080's particular blend of swampy synth pads and shaman-y samples lends the album a rave-y feel
column4: as if all the hokum of early-90s techno-gypsies like Spiral Tribe has been distilled so that you can experience a crusty field rave while browsing Twitter. Indeed
column5: Wolfers seems to be injecting his persona into his music more so than on past albums. On Crystal Cult's best tracks—""Excalibur R8MK2""
column6: ""Psychotic Endurance""
column7: ""Cyberspace Is Still Happenin' for Real""—his fake occultism seeps in. When
column8: on ""Excalibur""
column9: he turns a manic's chant (presumably sampled from the 1981 flick) into a mantra—""Drink from the chalice / And you will be reborn!""—he finds an earworm worthy of his fantastic
column10: mystical bullshit.

column1: Legowelt is unique amongst house producers in that he invariably cares more about melody than rhythm. Most of his tracks feature a bog-standard 4/4 beat
column2: with all of the sternum-popping compressed kicks and ticklish hi-hats we've come to expect. It's a very Detroit way of constructing tracks
column3: and Wolfers owes plenty to early techno stalwarts like Anthony Shakir and Derrick May. Wolfers' melodies are luxe and abundant
column4: and he stretches them over his simple rhythms with the fastidiousness of someone cinching sheets over a made bed. Wolfers definitely makes dance music
column5: employing all of the proper idioms and tempos and textures necessary for inclusion in that sphere
column6: but the balance of melody and rhythm in his work—especially on his albums—can make it seem like he merely chose the most socially acceptable forum in which to generate spaceship noises. Which is great: a man this adept at spaceship noises should not be stifled.

column1: Wolfers' greatest talent is the ability to conjure a bunch of distinctly early-'90s feelings—barely disguised cheese
column2: plasticine futurism—without peddling nostalgia. His music has plenty of antecedents
column3: but Wolfers is just
column4: like
column5: in it for the tunes
column6: man. ""I am just recording tracks all the time
column7: he says. Crystal Cult 2080 offers 10 more of them
column8:
replete with all of this frills we've come to expect from Wolfers. Crystal Cult 2080 isn't weirder than Wolfers' previous albums; it's just better at being weird.

"|19172.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19172-legowelt-crystal-cult-2080/|7.7|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20378/homepage_large.5b499bf7.jpg|Yearling|29408.0|Orcas|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Morr']|2014-04-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:29.836942|"

On his own
column2: Thomas Meluch records cloudy electro-acoustic songs as Benoît Pioulard that sound hand-cobbled
column3: while Rafael Anton Irisarri drapes brooding ostinatos with dusky delay and reverb (he also makes ambient techno as the Sight Below). Though their individual styles are different
column4: both of them decompress lacy
column5: yearning melodies into slow oceans of melancholy

column7: their styles combined naturally
column8: with small acoustic guitar songs drowned in gritty quasi-choral harmony.

column1: Their second album
column2: Yearling
column3: retains the debut's vast scale
column4: glacial pace
column5: and visual splendor; the distortion of ""Petrichor"" dramatically unveils the kind of sweet motif
column6: clasped in drones
column7: that anchors the album. But Orcas fill in their abysses more fully than before
column8: bringing the human presence closer to the surface. Contributions from Efterklang's Martyn Heyne and Telekinesis' Michael Lerner on drums bring prior inklings of shoegaze
column9: post-rock
column10: and analog garage pop to the foreground

column12: electric and acoustic guitars ride over the gray swirls of atmosphere rather than vanishing into them.

column1: Where Orcas was mostly spun out from guitar and vocal improvisations
column2: Yearling is said to be more specifically composed

column4: the songs are more crisply structured
column5: with the terse
column6: arid groove of ""An Absolute"" smoothly hinging on controlled cymbal crashes. Meluch's voice is sometimes drawn out in somnolent lines and sounding downright bouncy elsewhere; it's striking how peppy and soulful he sounds
column7: far from his typical distant
column8: affectless moan. Though he slips in and out of focus

column1: ""Filament"" recalls the vaguer portions of Orcas' debut

Australian indie pop collective Architecture in Helsinki have spent the last decade refining their lineup and their sound: while slimming down from eight members to five
column2: the group has moved from cluttered
column3: colourful
column4: hyper-active twee to a sleeker
column5: more focused brand of pop. 2011 full-length Moment Bends was their largest step yet in that direction
column6: a record that paid homage to the sound of the 80s with bubbly synth tones
column7: drum machine backbones
column8: and extensive use of vocal processing. The band’s new record
column9: the cheekily titled NOW + 4EVA
column10: finds them continuing to embrace simple
column11: radio-friendly sounds
column12: with one foot newly planted in the realm of contemporary synth-pop songwriting.

column1: It’s to the band’s credit that their gradual shift towards a mainstream pop tradition feels devoid of cynicism or condescension
column2: qualities that tend to loom over indie bands making a push for commercial glory. In fact
column3: NOW + 4EVA rings with a genuine enthusiasm for pop music
column4: something that should be recognized and appreciated. Unfortunately
column5: the group’s reverence for the form doesn’t directly translate into successful or memorable songwriting; instead
column6: their tepid compositions invite listeners to seek out contemporaries and sonic ancestors with superior material.

column1: The problem’s neatly encapsulated by the band’s cover of Jackie DeShannon’s 1963 standard “When You Walk in the Room”
column2: a song that’s been tackled by everyone from Merseybeat bit players to ABBA alumni. Architecture in Helsinki’s admiration for the song is seemingly sincere—in a recent interview with Australian music site Moshtix
column3: vocalist Cameron Bird mentioned their love for the original recording and its presence as a staple of their live shows—but their version is missing the subliminal sexual charge that renders the original so indelible. DeShannon makes it clear with the intensity of her delivery that this is an adult fantasy
column4: one that’s dominating her brain and making it hard for her to focus on anything else; in the hands of Kellie Sutherland
column5: the song’s stripped of that latent energy
column6: and her take isn’t helped by an arrangement that’s saccharine to the point of cavity creation.

column1: That slip-up aside
column2: NOW + 4EVA’s finest moments coincide with Sutherland’s turns at the forefront: she has an airy
column3: light vocal tone that’s reminiscent of compatriot Kylie Minogue
column4: and helps shimmering pop-disco tracks like the funky “I Might Survive” and “2 Time” to achieve an easy
column5: frictionless glide. Bird is less successful
column6: struggling to sell a handful of goopy ballads (“Born to Convince You”
column7: “April”) scattered throughout the album’s back half; ultimately
column8: the weight of the failure falls on the group’s songwriting
column9: rather than his takes on the material.

column1: Looking at this album in the context of Architecture in Helsinki’s discography sheds light on a hidden strength of the band’s earlier hyperactive approach to composition: by jamming several discrete ideas into standard-length songs and moving between them with abandon
column2: the group made it harder to isolate weak passages
column3: and ensured the strongest bits rose to the front of listeners’ minds. The band has sharpened their focus on their most recent records
column4:
but in doing so has placed a spotlight on their songwriting and performance. It’s a shame that NOW + 4EVA can’t withstand this greater level of scrutiny.

“Ode to Viceroy”
column2: Mac DeMarco’s sun-dappled tribute to cheap cigs from his 2012 album 2
column3: hasn’t lost its smolder. It’s probably the Brooklyn-via-Montreal singer and songwriter’s best-known tune—a laid-back guitar-pop daydream
column4: as wobbly and welcoming as a backyard hammock—and it captures a lot of his music’s appeal. “Viceroy” is about taking pleasure in something that could kill you
column5: and the lethal paradox is part of the draw. Somewhere in retirement
column6: Joe Camel must be kicking himself.

column1: This alluring ambivalence is one of DeMarco’s defining traits. He’s the gap-toothed prankster who sings the sighing love ballad. He’s the guy everybody assumes is a stoner
column2: though he claims he never
column3: as they say
column4: touches the stuff. You can’t read about him without seeing the word “slacker
column5: ” but in two short years
column6: he’s gone from opening at New York’s 550-capacity Bowery Ballroom to headlining at the 1
column7: 500-capacity Webster Hall (could he have done better if he’d tried?). The fact DeMarco isn’t even his real name—he was born Vernor Winfield McBriare Smith IV—captures the duality almost too perfectly.

column1: Whichever Mac is the better-behaved one has been taking over more and more
column2: as the creepy detours of 2012’s Rock and Roll Night Club EP gave way to the more direct 2. His second full-length
column3: Salad Days
column4: isn’t a departure from its predecessor so much as a richer
column5: increasingly assured refinement. For all its internal contradictions
column6: Salad Days is no more or less than a great album in a tradition of no-big-deal great albums.

column1: There’s little here to justify DeMarco’s reputation for divisiveness (“Detractors
column2: ” as Steven Hyden put it for Wondering Sound
column3: “tend to regard him as some kind of bullshit artist
column4: a quintessential hipster doofus slumming it under the ironic guise of a hippie dirtbag who gleefully covers Limp Bizkit in concert”). The loping “Blue Boy”
column5: which shares its title with an indie-pop classic by Orange Juice
column6: amiably advises against acting so tough and worrying so much about your haircut. The warm
column7: watery groove of “Brother” recalls the Beatles’ “Don’t Let Me Down”
column8: though its moony lyrical sentiment (“You’re no better off living your life than dreaming at night”) might be more “I’m Only Sleeping”. You’re unlikely to hear a supposedly hip album this year with so many mentions of people’s mothers.

column1: As with Real Estate’s Atlas
column2: DeMarco’s new album is also ostensibly one where the chill bro gets all mature and stuff
column3: and here his inner conflicts return with a suitably nonchalant vengeance. The title track undercuts its narrator’s worries about aging by alluding to the inconvenient truth that the worrier is only 23—not exactly ready for that condo in Florida. Relatedly
column4: anyone hoping for a pot anthem in organ-thick “Passing Out the Pieces” will instead find a koan-like complaint about the artist life’s crummy trade-offs. Penultimate “Go Easy” suggests concern for the girlfriend left behind while on tour
column5: but its lyrical non sequitur—“You built it up
column6: just to knock it down”—is a common criticism of the music press that has received DeMarco so favorably and could speak to his uneasy relationship with success. Et tu
column7: Vernor?

column1: It’s telling that Salad Days' most immediate song
column2: the one with biggest chance of transcending DeMarco’s cult
column3: is one he says he didn’t want to do. “Let Her Go” was apparently the answer to label Captured Tracks’ demands for “an upbeat single” suitable for late-night TV
column4: and DeMarco is still upset about it. He shouldn’t be: It’s an outstanding crystallization of his gifts
column5: the real-talk advice of Jonathan Richman with a far more accessible poetic dreaminess. Of course
column6: even this reversal of the hoary “if you love her
column7: let her go” chestnut undermines its own advice—“Or you can keep her
column8: it’s OK
column9: it’s up to you
column10: ” DeMarco counters in a speak-singing outro. It’s only fitting that stick-with-the-girl songs “Let My Baby Stay” and “Treat Her Better” are almost as tunefully plush.

column1: In this context
column2: DeMarco’s non-album antics start to look like another defense mechanism
column3: another way of cutting himself off at the legs before someone else does it for him. That Limp Bizkit rendition showed up as part of a jokey 2013 live release; DeMarco has been vocal about how tiresome that novelty-cover setlist (Metallica
column4: the Police
column5: blah blah blah) became. And he previewed Salad Days with a video for a puckish perv-pop outtake centering on a refrain of “give me pussy.” So while his slack-not-slack aesthetic may point toward rising peers like Australia’s Courtney Barnett
column6: there’s also ample reason Odd Future lightning rod Tyler
column7: the Creator
column8: who cited this album’s synth-dripping “Chamber of Reflections” as DeMarco’s best song
column9: is a fan.

column1: ""Chamber of Reflections"" is something like Beach House's “Heart of Chambers”
column2: but evoking a bare
column3: cell-like apartment rather than a misty opium-den boudoir. It’s DeMarco’s most atmospherically exploratory track yet
column4: and it’s also painfully lonely and quietly eloquent about the experience. So when
column5: at the end of Salad Days' airy instrumental finale
column6: “Jonny’s Odyssey”
column7: he remarks
column8: “Thanks for joining me
column9: see you again soon
column10: buh-bye
column11: ” you don’t wonder if you’re missing some April Fool’s joke. You want to offer the guy a light
column12:
and then you realize he already has plenty.

Angel
column2: the third album by Austin’s Pure X
column3: is lackadaisical in its tempos and moods
column4: coming on at an almost laughably leisurely pace. A chiming electric guitar chord
column5: as well as some actual chimes
column6: make for a half minute of aural sage-burning to introduce the opening track “Starlight”. From there
column7: the album is an intricate but not overwrought construction of clean
column8: twinkly tones that distills George Harrison’s All Things Must Pass
column9: the more gently decadent moments of the T. Rex catalogue
column10: and other high points of rock’s early-70s post-hippie chill-out phase. All along
column11: Angel just sort of cruises on with tempos pegged to double-digit BPMs and the mood locked on “as mellow as humanly possible.”

column1: That doesn’t mean it’s a boring record
column2: though—it has a healthy pulse
column3: even if it never really climbs above an exceptionally relaxed state. There’s a lot of emphasis on mood and texture
column4: but they never get in the way of the songwriting
column5: which is consistent and generous with its hooks. The album’s surprisingly broad spectrum of influences seem to include a decent amount of Big Star—the melody lines on songs like “Valley of Tears” and “Every Tomorrow” have some of the zero-gravity quality of some of Chilton and Bell’s more pop-perfect moments. (And if the more brooding
column6: swoony “Livin’ the Dream” is any indication
column7: Big Star acolyte Elliott Smith’s probably well represented too.)

column1: Angel’s promotional material emphasizes the fact that the album was written and recorded in a hundred-year-old dance hall in a remote corner of central Texas over the span of just five days
column2: but that aspect of its creation doesn’t come through in the recording in an obvious way. A modern studio offers musicians interested in texture and atmosphere a more or less limitless range of options
column3: but Pure X wisely keep things simple here. Beyond layering gentle acoustic guitars
column4: ethereal multi-part vocals
column5: and the occasional subtle flourish of analog synthesizer
column6: they stick to a basic four-piece rock setup; the songs never fall victim to their own ambition and the music remains appealingly and accessibly human-scaled.

column1: Pure X draw heavily from the past—not only Harrison
column2: Bolan
column3: Chilton
column4: and Bell
column5: but from the troves of vintage private press psychedelic folk records that in recent years have been uncovered and rescued from terminal obscurity. Their forbears offered a personal
column6: pastoral cosmic transcendence that made sense in its own time
column7: when Summer of Love naiveté was eroding into Nixon-era cynicism. Angel serves as a balm in another era defined by mass pessimism and doubt. It’s easy to criticize it for its escapism and refusal to grapple with a reality that extends outside the listener’s personal space. But on “Heaven”
column8: when vocalist Nate Grace promises that
column9: “heaven is a feeling
column10: ” it sounds believable
column11:
an offer to find shelter and peace in Pure X’s blissed-out cloud that’s almost too appealing to pass up.

Tracks by Torn Hawk draw on various strains of nostalgia
column2: chopping up thoughts and feelings into a mazy whole that inhabits a ground somewhere between sincerity and amusement. Luke Wyatt

column5: some of it beat-oriented
column6: some of it edging close to the VHS nostalgia feel of chillwave. L.I.E.S.
column7: Rush Hour
column8: and now Not Not Fun are among the many labels to have released his work. Film plays an important part in Wyatt's world—a recent Rising feature noted how his stepmother operated a movie theater
column9: his music is often complemented by a mish-mash of grainy YouTube clips heavy on collage
column10: and his song titles frequently reference the silver screen (""Born to Win (Life After Ghostbusters)""
column11: ""Damage with Jeremy Irons"").

column1: Wyatt calls his experiments in the visual realm ""video mulching
column2: most of which consist of a barrage of imagery of an 80s hue. Those clips fall somewhere between the late-night disorientation of John C. Reilly's Steve Brule character and Daniel Lopatin's experiments with sound and vision under his SunsetCorp moniker. Lopatin took tiny loops of 80s music and set them to fuzzed-out visuals
column3: drawing on two fascinations he undoubtedly shares with the Torn Hawk project. Dire Straits
column4: Don Henley
column5: and Christopher Cross have all been sampled by Wyatt
column6: and his off-the-wall work includes <a href=""https://soundcloud.com/lukewyatt/sundayscdskipping"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Sundays CD
column7: Skipping"" (based around a glitched CD by indie pop icons the Sundays) and a track titled ""The Music You Hear at Sea World and Never Forget"".

column1: The humor has been dialed down a notch on Through Force of Will
column2: the latest Torn Hawk transmission
column3: although the feeling of looking back to utopian visions of the past is firmly intact. What sets this apart from most chillwave is the strong sweep of romantic feeling that flows through Wyatt's mesh of guitar and electronics—there's palpable emotion here amid the tinny drum machines and twists of industrial synth. It doesn't all come out that way
column4: especially when ""Streets on Fire"" begins with a hollowed-out drum sound that could have been ripped from a peak Jam & Lewis production. But Wyatt frequently uses his guitar tone
column5: aligned somewhere between the dreamy strum of Mark McGuire and the type of squelchy soloing found on longer Spacemen 3 tracks
column6: to give his music a vital sense of yearn.

column1: Torn Hawk's emotional impact is offset by the visual package
column2: which is all rugged photos of Wyatt
column3: who looks more stud-like than his tender playing might suggest
column4: especially when he's deep into the intricate picking on a track like ""To Overthrow"". But Through Force of Will partly works because of its intentional signal jamming
column5: where things don't lead where you expect them to on first glance
column6: with Wyatt guiding his audience through the drone-y ambiance of ""Hutchison"" and ending up in the altered-states pop of ""Blindsided"". The VHS aesthetics may have a touch of over-familiarity about them
column7: but there's just enough in Wyatt’s beefcake poses to suggest another twist being wrung out of the template
column8: giving his persona the air of an alien outsider invited to the drugs party.

column1: It's in the parameters Wyatt throws around this project that he breaks away from the vagaries of chillwave
column2: substituting ambiguity with personality. Or
column3: as he put it himself in an interview: ""I'm not going to restrict my impulses and make stuff in an anonymous fashion with some sort of minimal cover and numbered track titles."" The only counterpoint to that is in the sheer weight of material being released
column4: which can make it hard to get a handle on who he is and where he's going. There's already a follow-up to this record due imminently
column5: and doubtless more will surface. But Wyatt clearly delights in setting things up in contrast to one another
column6: particularly when polar opposites are involved
column7: which gives him an incredibly broad field in which to play around. Somehow he's able to retain a sense of self even when looping his material over the blandest strains of 80s rock
column8: and that's where he really succeeds
column9:
in defining a pallett that's recognizably his that concurrently allows him to go wandering in boundless directions.

If you’re stoked that indie rock no longer has to remotely resemble “rock”
column3: Manchester Orchestra’s fourth LP

column5: is probably like nothing else you’ve heard all year. ""Top Notch"" sets the tone immediately and it's that of a fire alarm—the drums loudly stutter-stomp
column6: the guitars strain in harmony at an even higher volume
column7: and Andy Hull’s rebel yell is even louder. This is the sort of thing that used to be called “alternative rock” out of habit

column9: it’s actually earned that name.

column1: And yet
column2: Cope once again finds Manchester Orchestra in the netherworld they’ve long occupied: not quite as cerebral as they aspire to be
column3: nowhere near as lunkheaded as they could allow themselves to be
column4: making radio-friendly rock too leaden and static to make reciprocity a foregone conclusion. That’s a shame

column8: workmanlike rock with Michael Kamen-level bombast.

column1: Cope doesn’t frame Simple Math as a misstep-in-hindsight
column2: although it doesn't try to top it
column3: either; this time around
column4: it's 11 bullshit-free rock songs about getting past the bullshit in your life. Essentially

column1: Even if Cope never manages the undeniable wallop of Manchester Orchestra's S&M-friendly “Virgin”

column6: lonesome harmonies

column8: sound like digital clipping. Hull also fails to muster warmth and empathy

column1: Look
column2: if you’re anything like me and strive to find at least five real-deal alt-rock bangers per calendar year
column3: it’s easy to pull for these guys—they are underdogs within an extremely unique context. Because this stuff can be potent in three-minute shifts
column4: there’s an undeniable thrill in the way “Top Notch” thrashes in place
column5: similar to watching the fight scenes from Iron Man 3 and knowing you’re not going to get that from an arthouse flick. And even if the verses rarely check out

column10: if you think you can just dial this stuff up by turning on your local “alt-rock” station
column11: well
column12: there goes the Neighbourhood. But four albums in
column13:
it's becoming pretty clear that the genre in which Manchester Orchestra resides has more untapped potential than the band itself.

The title of Ausmuteants' ""No Motivation"" isn't a figure of speech. The inert narrator says he looks for jobs every day
column3: then admits that he's lying. ""I sit at home and my friends get stoned."" Note that he's not even the one getting stoned—he's not doing anything at all
column4: really. That void of activity is a common theme in Amusements; the Geelong
column5: Australia band aren't making punk songs that are politically militant or socially conscious. Actually
column6: they belong more in the punk tradition of bands that write lyrics that are dumb. Take the Freeze's 1980 single ""I Hate Tourists""
column7: a catchily aggressive song about wanting to run sightseers off the road because they ""suck."" Or Dead Boys' ""Caught With the Meat in Your Mouth""
column8: or the King Khan & BBQ Show's ""Tastebuds"". They're delinquents who are all too ready to indulge in low-hanging fruit
column9: writing songs about urine and feces.

column1: But really
column2: a rundown of their most base
column3: lower-self lyrics makes Amusements sound much more puerile and expendable than it truly is. Jake Robertson
column4: Billy Gardener
column5: Shaun Connor
column6: and Marc Dean certainly aren't the most mature band out there
column7: but they're students of Devo
column8: the Screamers
column9: and Chrome. It's 12 tracks of ripping
column10: captivating
column11: fun synth-punk. As they shift from a deep buzzing synth to a trembling high end
column12: Ausmuteants consistently veer far away from anything resembling Computer World. Instead
column13: they invoke the kinetic
column14: trashy attack of the essential Killed By Death punk compilations. ""Bad Day"" has a persistent synth churn that's bolstered by Gardener's primitive
column15: hi-hat led stomp. Then there's ""Daylight Robbery""
column16: which features a melody that seems appropriately urgent for a song about breaking a window in order to commit a crime in plain view of the afternoon sun.

column1: As an impressive show of versatility
column2: they kick off the B-side by briefly abandoning synthesizers altogether. The plot presented on ""Kicked in the Head By a Horse"" is given away by its title: ""He acts oh so dull/ a hoof cracked his skull."" It's the perfect premise for a pit-ready song. They've done this sort of thing before—making an exciting punk song about a violent observation—with their single ""Felix Tried to Kill Himself""
column3: for example. These sorts of songs work along the same lines as ""Gimme Gimme Shock Treatment""
column4: ""Chain Saw""
column5: and most video games—violence used for ""laugh at the macabre"" means. So with material like this
column6: it's all about delivery
column7: and since they're adept with hooks
column8: handclaps
column9: and guitar solos
column10: they can often pull it off.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Amusements' juvenile posture makes it an entirely divisive record. Their primitive rhymes and nasal vocals are enough to turn people away out the gate. But then consider the basic ideas of their songs. There's one about stepping in shit and wiping it off; one song is about peeing in two streams. When you consider the song's inspiration
column3: ""Fran Drescher's Alien Abduction"" is reprehensible. Then comes the album's dramatic apex: ""Pissed Myself Twice"". A paced
column4: morose track where Robertson details exactly what went down: he was 6
column5: the other kids were laughing at him
column6: the teacher found a fresh pair of shorts in the lost-and-found box
column7: and so on. The gravity given to that track
column8: which makes it sound like the most heavy
column9: awful thing that's ever happened
column10: also makes it really funny. Obviously
column11: they ride a fine line.

column1: If anything
column2: Amusements is a touch formulaic
column3: as nearly every song finishes with a long instrumental stretch. But in those moments
column4: they're playing to their strengths—hooks
column5: grooves
column6: and attack over lyrical prowess and vocal performance. What's undeniable
column7: though
column8: is that Ausmuteants create a specific
column9: slovenly universe with their music
column10: and while they don't move too far past the couch or the toilet
column11:
they create an exciting synth barrage from where they sit.
