'Legacy']|2014-03-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:35.572327|"

Miles Davis hated stasis. In the 30-year period between the time he first gained notice playing bebop with Charlie Parker to when he retired for five years in 1975
column3: his music was usually in a state of transformation
column4: with steady but noticeable changes occasionally interrupted by moments of what
column5: in another context
column6: paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould called “punctuated equilibrium.” The shifts were not linear and could never be understood in terms of “progression.” Explorations into impressionist harmony
column7: modal improvisation
column8: pastoral sound-painting
column9: neoclassical orchestration
column10: abstract funk
column11: and sheets of electronic noise weren’t experienced as one music building on top of another
column12: but rather a constant search for the possibilities lurking in the unknown. As the years wore on
column13: Miles’ own fear of irrelevance kept him working with players many years younger than himself so he was being exposed to new ideas without feeling the need to chase trends (most major jazz figures with an interest in experimentation made some overtures toward free jazz in the 1960s but Miles never did). All of which is to say that when you contemplate a single
column14: narrow segment of Miles’ brilliant and varied career
column15: there’s no telling what the music is going to give you until you immerse yourself in it. You have to look at where it came from and where it would go next.

column1: Miles at the Fillmore
column2: the latest entry in Columbia’s revelatory bootleg series collecting unreleased Miles Davis live material
column3: finds the trumpeter departing one musical world and entering a new one. In the previous five years
column4: he’d taken the music of the Second Great Quintet (Wayne Shorter
column5: Herbie Hancock
column6: Ron Carter
column7: and Tony Williams) as far as it could go; hearing new music in his head
column8: music that had never been made before
column9: Miles fully embraced electric instruments on the dual landmarks In a Silent Way and
column10: a year later
column11: in April 1970
column12: Bitches Brew; most of this set was recorded in June of that year. By this point in a very busy year of live performances
column13: Bitches Brew was in stores and selling well and making waves
column14: and Miles and his band were playing large rock venues
column15: landing on the same bills as the Grateful Dead and Neil Young.

column1: Some of this material has been released in a different form. These four discs each contain an evening’s set
column2: recorded on four consecutive nights in New York at the Fillmore East (live albums during this time can get confusing—Miles also recorded in April 1970 at the Fillmore West in San Francisco
column3: and some of that material
column4: in far poorer sound quality
column5: is included as bonus tracks). On the 1970 2xLP Miles Davis at Fillmore
column6: each night was condensed and edited by Teo Macero into an approximately 25-minute collage to fit a single album side and given an overarching title without identifying individual pieces (“Wednesday Miles”
column7: “Thursday Miles”
column8: etc.) That decision foreshadowed what was to come with Miles’ live sets through the rest of the 1970s
column9: as written compositions and themes were considered only as additional elements to be swirled into process-oriented whole
column10: and needn’t necessarily be identified.

column1: Compared to where his music would take in the ensuing four years
column2: Miles’ sound in mid–1970 was still loosely tethered to jazz tradition. There are distinct compositions that unfold with a set arc
column3: there are recognizable themes
column4: there’s still a standard in regular rotation. And unlike his music in 1974 and ’75
column5: Miles Davis’ trumpet is very much the focus
column6: and his tone was strong and forceful and could easily cut through the electronic din. There are two keyboard players here
column7: both of whom would go on to become hugely popular in the 1970s: Keith Jarrett (organ) and Chick Corea (electric piano). With no guitarist in the band
column8: Jarrett and Corea are responsible for the electronics
column9: and each plays his instrument in ways that go well beyond its intended use; Jarrett’s squawking solos are often harsh and noisy
column10: reminiscent of electric guitar
column11: while Corea’s electric piano gives the music a sense of disembodied drift. Dave Holland’s basslines are simple ostinatos but feel more connected to jazz proper than the minimal funk Michael Henderson would bring a short time later. Saxophonist Steve Grossman serves a more functional role
column12: with solid workmanlike solos that mostly serve to make Miles’ time out front that much more exciting. And Jack DeJohnette’s drumming alternates between forward-driving and hard-hitting funk/rock and pure texture during more abstract passages. DeJohnette’s contributions underscore the defining quality of the music here: it’s relentless energy.

column1: The opener for each night
column2: the Joe Zawinul composition “Directions”
column3: sets the bar very high in this department. It’s built around a brilliantly simple bassline and has a classic theme that only shows up later in the piece
column4: signaling when to pass the soloing baton to the next player. Miles would lose interest in this sort of structure over the next couple of years
column5: but “Directions” is the perfect tune for him at this moment
column6: and hearing the four show kick-offs in one place provides an opportunity to see how pieces varied from night to night. Wednesday night absolutely rips
column7: as Holland’s bass refrain drives the song forward almost faster than the band wants to go. Thursday is comparatively mellow and exploratory
column8: allowing for more space. On Friday DeJohnette takes a less polyrhythmic approach to drums and Miles is more fluid and less intense in his soloing. And then Saturday is lighter and trickier
column9: with more quick rhythmic interplay. The set lists each night were almost identical—“The Mask”
column10: “It’s About That Time”
column11: “I Fall in Love Too Easily”
column12: and “Bitches Brew” are all heard in multiple versions—but jumping to different takes from disc-to-disc never feels redundant
column13: such is the invention and variation with each performance.

column1: Each phase of Miles Davis’ development calls for a different kind of listening. Both 1969 and 1970
column2: to my ears
column3: are more accessible than the late-period material with the second quintet
column4: with its unusual harmonies and deceptive structure. Nefertiti from 1967 truly feels like a puzzle
column5: something I’ll be working to understand forever
column6: but the appeal of the Miles at the Fillmore material is obvious: This is an amazing band and they rip
column7: but they never leave traditional ideas of rhythm and melody behind. There are extended soundscape passages in “Bitches Brew” and “The Mask” that are more about experiments in timbre
column8: exploring how jazz improvisation can become the furthest-out space music possible
column9: but the best of this set comes in hearing these players creating a new sound that remains immediate. You’re hearing jazz form straining against its enclosure
column10: and soon enough
column11: it would be abandoned—by 1974
column12: another key era
column13: musicality would not be a priority
column14: as black-hole-level density took over completely. Any notion of mainstream acceptance was pretty much gone by then
column15: and Miles and his band were doing brilliant things with that freedom. Here they’re doing equally brilliant things within certain strictures
column16:
making up a few rules and bending a few others to the breaking point.

From their early adoption of chillwave to the lush indie-R&B of last year's Limits of Desire
column2: Small Black's laid-back vibe has often masked a certain sonic perfectionism. Even when the songwriting's not quite there
column3: their records always sound fizzy yet full-bodied
column4: every element floating just where it should be. They are decidedly liquid-y
column5: capable of taking the shape of whatever container they pour themselves into. Real People

column9: best thought"" spontaneity into the mix.

column1: Comprised of four originals and a cover of Scottish sophisti-poppers the Blue Nile

the songcraft is a little hit-or-miss.

Opener ""Real People"" tells the story of Colton Harris-Moore
column8: Washington State's infamous teenaged ""Barefoot Bandit"" currently serving a six-and-a-half year federal sentence for (among other things) breaking into hundreds of houses and stealing several planes. Over the plink of steel drum-like synths

column10: examining the paintings on the wall of his latest conquest and pondering just how ""real people""—the kind who don't steal planes before they hit drinking age
column11: I suppose—live. It's a dense
column12: pulsating mix
column13: cut through with swirling harmonies courtesy of Frankie Rose
column14: but as a song
column15: it's a bit vaporous. Kolenik's voice
column16: as ever
column17: stops short at ""pleasant-sounding""
column18: and considering he's singing about an infamous child criminal
column19: his detached vocal turn is an odd fit for the subject at hand.

column1: ""Lines of Latitude
column2: Rose's other guest turn
column3: is Real People's finest moment. The sumptuous
column4: gauzy ballad floats in the air
column5: held aloft by gossamer synths and Rose and Kolenik's conjoined sighs. Kolenik's low-impact vocals are especially well-suited for a song like ""Latitude
column6: a track just misty enough not to envelop him like a fog. Unfortunately
column7: ""Consequences"" takes the opposite tack
column8: casting him against a thick array of ominous drones
column9: squelchy synths
column10: and rippling bass. The chorus blares like old neon
column11: but Kolenik gets swallowed up around the prechorus
column12:
stuck with a barely-there melody he can't quite sing his way out of.

The EP ends with their cover of the Blue Nile's 1989 hit ""The Downtown Lights
column13: and Small Black keep the melody in tact while piling on the sonic flourishes: a relatively upbeat tempo
column14: a few sci-fi synths swirling about
column15: and a murky spoken-word sample. However
column16: Kolenik's simply no match for Paul Buchanan's rich
column17: expressive tenor

column19: you find yourself how things might've gone if Kolenik would just throw himself into his performance a touch more
column20: and with the original ""Lights"" just a few clicks away
column21: there's no real need to guess. The slight
column22: somewhat spotty Real People is a lot like every Small Black record before it:  impossible to dislike

Bart Davenport’s latest album
column2: Physical World
column3: has a song called “Fuck Fame.” Bart Davenport has never really gotten within distance of fame
column4: but the songwriter spits at it with convincing disgust regardless: “Fame? What fame? I never wanted it
column5: I never needed it/ Fame
column6: what fame? I can be creative from behind the scenes.” The guitar tone is pure Joe Jackson

column10: “But we could talk about money
column11: ” harmonizing in a way that recalls Simply Red’s “Money’s Too Tight (To Mention).” It occurs to you: Hey
column12: actually
column13: maybe those guitars are more reminiscent of Simply Red’s jazzy synth chords
column14: after all. Is that intentional?

column1: The answer
column2: from a scan of Bart Davenport’s discography
column3: is an overwhelming “yes.” His catalog is a series of nested quotations brilliantly lifted and folded into power-pop confections that he's mastered
column4: down to the lemon zest and sea-salt sprinkles on top. Listening to “Fuck Fame
column5: ” it's not even clear if we’re hearing Bart Davenport’s thoughts or just a roundup of “fuck fame” songs strung together like a Sudoku puzzle in three dimensions.

column1: Davenport’s Physical World is a world of record sleeves
column2: thumbed through masterfully. The album opens with “Wearing The Changes”
column3: a fond and affectionate tribute to a woman who is “Wearing the changes well
column4: ” which is an elegant way to phrase aging gracefully. It’s a lion-in-winter flirtation

column6: while Davenport slides in the clincher line: “Don’t stop doing whatever you’re doing something so right”. Again
column7: you think: didn’t Daryl Hall say something like this?

column1: This sense of constant
column2: nagging nostalgia is kind of the point for songwriters like Davenport
column3: who keenly understands his place in the wider universe. However
column4: he plays too many games on Physical World to sustain a listener’s interest: he affects a British accent on “Dust in the Circuits
column5: ” although it’s less of a specific accent and more of an All-Purpose Morrissey.  “Pamela” traces a chord progression distractingly similar to “Wearing the Changes”
column6: but with twice the glucose.

column1: What he lacks is a presence that feels definitely Bart Davenport
column2: and after a while
column3: it begins to feel like an album full of someone else’s songs—or
column4: rather
column5: anyone else’s songs. His best moments are breezy and autumnal
column6: where a five'o'clock shadow of soulfulness shades the proceedings. “We rely on the physical world for love/ See me cry when invisible things still hurt
column7: ” he croons gently on the title track

column9: the melody is the focal point
column10: coasting up and breezing down with a reassuring ease. “Keep it light and keep it loose
column11: ” he sings

column13: but too much so
column14:
and it doesn’t take much for the entire album to float gently from your notice.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20366/homepage_large.fc88bb82.jpg|Important Picnic|32171.0|Gang Wizard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['MIE']|2014-03-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:37.217818|"

The history of American underground rock in the past 25 years is as messy and hard to track as the music. But ask any aficionado to cite stalwarts—groups who’ve stuck it out without bending their sound toward the mainstream—and a few immediately come to mind: No-Neck Blues Band
column2: Bardo Pond
column3: Pelt
column4: Oneida. One outtfit not as commonly thought of
column5: but whose unique body of work has certainly earned them a spot in this loose canon
column6: is Los Angeles noise-rock trawlers Gang Wizard.

column1: Part of the reason they’re less frequently cited is that their existence has been sporadic. Where all the aformentioned bands can claim mutliple members who’ve been involved from day one
column2: Gang Wizard’s lineup morphs frequently
column3: such that no single individual has participated in every stage of their career. But the group does have a core in the trio of Michael Landucci
column4: Christopher Breedon
column5: and Jacob Anderson
column6: all of whom have welcomed anyone they like—including most recently Landucci’s teenage sons—into the fray.

column1: Gang Wizard’s sound has a core
column2: too. Though they come off as shambling and impulsive
column3: they always offer a beat
column4: riff
column5: chant
column6: or some other solid element to latch onto. Each song takes on a degree of shape and direction
column7: then tears and fractures
column8: darting around like a dog off its leash. Nothing is ever completely chaotic
column9: but every moment trembles with fall-apart potential
column10: which is why their music is so blood-filled and—for those who like their rock risky—so fun.

column1: 19 years of hammering away at this resolutely-untamed approach have made Gang Wizard pretty sharp at imprecision
column2: and as a result Important Picnic might be the best of their 40 or so releases. On previous efforts
column3: their boundlessness has sometimes drifted into tedium
column4: but there's no downtime on Important Picnic. Guitar noise spits around as if shot from water guns; shards of hardcore punk and grumbling bass pass through like cars running a red light; and drums get so throroughly punched
column5: slapped
column6: and punctured
column7: one wonders if the band believes kits have to be broken to work right.

column1: Throughout
column2: there’s a sense that Gang Wizard are always in the midst of working things out
column3: with the process serving as the goal. In that sense
column4: they recall throw-it-all-out-there scramblers like Sun City Girls
column5: Trumans Water
column6: and Harry Pussy—groups whose releases obliterate the lines between jamming
column7: practicing
column8: and “properly” recording
column9: if they even imagined such a thing: there’s something thrilling about music whose embryonic stage is so apparent in the final result that it’s unclear if there’s even a difference between the two.

column1: Examples of such pulse-quickening sonic phenomena abound throughout Important Picnic
column2: but one that seems to capture every dimension of what makes this band special is a stunning ramble called “Dog’s Share”. It starts low-key
column3: with a few shards of bass fuzz and guitar cluck. But less than a minute in
column4: strings explode into dementia
column5: chopping the song’s weighty rhythm into a kind of musical flambé. The band not only maintains this manic pitch
column6: but escalates it; every time you think they’ve hit their heads on the ceiling
column7: they find a another hole to break through.

column1: Such untethered imagination gives Important Picnic a freshness that transcends the mid-90s era in which Gang Wizard began. In fact
column2: if this music says anything about time periods
column3: it’s that the group’s elemental take on rock—their thirst for building it up and blowing it apart—is somewhat missing in today’s underground. More bands should be flailing away in basements and garages
column4: treating rock like a huge water balloon to pop and drown in. If anyone out there feels so inclined
column5:
I can’t think of a better role model than Gang Wizard.

"|19159.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19159-gang-wizard-important-picnic/|7.7|Marc Masters

""I heard the Cityscape Skins are kinda kicking it again
column2: Craig Finn blurts out at the beginning of Teeth Dreams
column3: the sixth LP from the Hold Steady. Over the years
column4: the Cityscape Skins—a fictional coterie of tattoo-emblazoned Twin Cities street toughs—have darkened the doorways of many a Hold Steady song. But
column5: beyond a fleeting reference to a Skins-stocked Youth of Today show on ""Barely Breathing""—from the faintly disastrous Heaven Is Whenever—it's been some time since Finn got the gang together. Teeth Dreams' opening line is a callback
column6: a homing beacon to wayward fans left cold by the overblown
column7: undercooked Heaven. That beautiful shit Finn used to talk? Those beer-battered barroom floors and sloppy upper-Midwestern hagiographies? That neurons-blazing
column8: every line-better-than-the-last Minneapolis mythos? The gang's all here.

column1: After four good-to-fantastic records in five short years
column2: the Hold Steady took their sweet time and returned with 2010's Heaven
column3: a too-sleek
column4: saccharine
column5: cliché-mottled shrug of a record. Heaven's music felt bland and tentative
column6: but its real crimes were strictly lyrical: Finn swapped out the character-defining specifics for faceless generalities and an all-too-sweet sincerity that effectively transplanted his lived-in Minneapolis-St. Paul mythologies to Anyplace USA. At his best
column7: Finn wouldn't just set a scene
column8: he'd introduce you around to the regulars. Those first few Hold Steady records still feel like a gathering of familiars
column9: speaking a shared language. Heaven
column10: then
column11: was clearly the Hold Steady's attempt to cram a few more people into to the party. But
column12: by swinging for the back rows

column14: the very ones who'd helped make their singalong songs into scriptures.

column1: From its opening line on

column4: and the familiar scenery starts to take shape: the nitrous tanks under the overpasses
column5: the Michelin in Bay City where Gideon's been working. ""I Hope This Whole Thing Didn't Frighten You"" finds Finn offering a new love a guided tour of some old haunts; ""The Ambassador"" swings around a chorus of ""you came back to us/ South Minneapolis."" Even when they're not ticking off the hours in 3.2 bars
column6: the people of Teeth Dreams are very recognizably denizens of the Hold Steady universe: ""I'm pretty sure you recognize these guys
column7: Finn shares on ""The Ambassador"". They're a little older now
column8: but wiser? Well
column9: they're still sorta working on that. They have their good days
column10: their bad months
column11: their off years. Oh
column12: and they drink. Just maybe not quite so much as they used to.

column1: Produced by Nick Raskulinecz (Rush
column2: Evanescence)
column3: Teeth Dreams is handily the Hold Steady's worst-sounding album. The muddy
column4: hyperbolically compressed mix dies a thousand deaths through a couple of halfway decent speakers; it opens up a smidge in headphones
column5: but it strangles most of Finn's exhortations and grounds Tad Kubler's skyscraping solos
column6: casting everything in an ugly
column7: nuance-deadening grey. Musically
column8: Teeth Dreams is pretty much your standard-issue late-era Hold Steady LP: a post-Replacements hard-charger here
column9: a swaying
column10: Schlitzed-up ballad there
column11: all of it sturdy
column12: none of it remotely surprising. The hard edges of Separation Sunday have been sanded down; the soaring expanses of Boys & Girls in America have been dulled under Raskulinecz's heavy hand. Finn's delivery
column13: in particular
column14: gets swallowed up here: Raskulinecz buried his way back in the mix
column15: forcing him to fight his way out of Kubler and new axeman Steve Selvidge's six-string entanglements. With so much of the music taking the path of least resistance—and without Finn up front

After a decade-plus toiling in the shadows
column4: Travis Stewart finally struck gold in 2011—twice
column5: no less. As one-half of Sepalcure
column6: he and Praveen Sharma released a confident self-titled debut that refracted bass music in a soft
column7: pink-hued light without losing any creative edge. Stewart’s crowning achievement in that year
column8: however
column9: was his Planet Mu LP as Machinedrum
column10: Room(s). An embarrassment of riches that fused footwork’s 3D rhythmic patterns
column11: bass’ double-time gait
column12: and emotive vocal samples
column13: Room(s) stands as one of the strongest electronic full-lengths of the decade so far. It was a true crossover album that discarded notions of innovation and originality in favor of delivering a rich
column14: almost overwhelming listening experience.

column1: Room(s) represented a creative ideal for Stewart. He spent the previous decade hopping from sound to sound—glitchy IDM
column2: low-slung Dilla-influenced hip-hop instrumentals—while mostly staying anonymous. Room(s) caused many to sit up and take notice
column3: though

column8: Vapor City
column9: an album that found him smoothing out the terrain of its predecessor. The record didn’t pack the same thrilling punch of Room(s)’ finest moments
column10: coming over more as a the sound of an artist sticking with the sound that gained him notice—which
column11: in Stewart’s case
column12: isn’t a bad thing.

column1: On the outset
column2: his new EP as Machinedrum
column3: Fenris District
column4: resembles a victory lap after Vapor City’s modest successes
column5: but its content suggests that Stewart’s ear is wandering yet again—this time
column6: towards the bounce-heavy motifs and that make up the increasingly jocular spin on trap popularized by artists such as TNGHT and Dillon Francis. The release contains three new cuts
column7: two of which make make the shift clear: “On My Mind” opens with a high-frequency whine and clipped snares before sinking into dubby synth stabs and sensory-depriving bass frequencies
column8: while “Neujack” samples an utterance of its title’s second syllable and subjects it to a series of pitch-warped filters
column9: filling the resulting space with piled-up claps and
column10: yes
column11: more deep bass. Those coming to hear Stewart in his lane are rewarded early with the EP’s highlight
column12: “Back Seat Ho”
column13: which takes the ear-blasting sonics of its counterparts and throws in soft synth pads and pleasingly emotive textures in its back half. It’s the strongest representation of Stewart’s successful aesthetic since Vapor City’s evocative opener “Gunshotta”.

column1: Fenris District is rounded out by two remixes: Adrian Sherwood and bass mainstay Pinch offer a take on Vapor City’s downcast first single “Eyesdontlie”
column2: adding pitch-black vibes to the tune with broken piano lines and occasional ragga vocal samples. It’s an intriguing take
column3: if not an especially engaging one. Glasgow wünderkind Rustie does them one better on his remix of “Back Seat Ho”. Rustie is exploring new territory yet again
column4: attacking “Back Seat Ho”’s endlessly sampled vocal with nasty buzzsaw sounds before clearing the arena for city-leveling drums possessing a nihilistic brutality.

column1: Contrasted with Glass Swords’ penchant for wild-eyed optimism
column2: Rustie’s “Back Seat Ho” remix scans darker and represents a great artist trying (and succeeding) to chart his own path; his self-assured sense of originality presented here makes Stewart look inferior by comparison and presents a strange conundrum regarding where he takes the Machinedrum project next. After two albums of the same sound
column3: it certainly wouldn’t hurt for Stewart to branch out
column4: but that would risk losing the attention that he spent over 10 years trying to attain. Both history and the originals on Fenris District suggest that
column5: for Stewart
column6: trying something new doesn’t so much mean embracing originality as much as it does trying on other people’s clothes. Which leaves the Machinedrum project at a crossroads
column7:
and it’ll be interesting to see which path he takes going forward.

column1: As one could imagine

While the instinct to position the versatile CL in the front of 2NE1 is right on
column7: her compositions fall a hair short of Crush’s standouts

column9: pretty G-Dragon-penned ballad “Good to You”. But it’s not a “sore thumb” situation: CL stacks up to the more experienced hands of the YG factory
column10: and thus seems primed for a huge solo career. Crush represents a sleeker
column11: more refined vision for the group; if nothing else
column12: the well-balanced record serves as a capsule of the outfit’s pop instincts and versatility. Though the soulful
column13: organ-spiked R&B take “Baby I Miss You” might be the most natural fit for the group
column14: they generally make a breeze of it
column15: bolstering strong performances by the ensemble of Dara
column16: Minzy and Park Bom.

column1: In his K-Pop primer from 2011
column2: James Brooks made much of 2NE1's brash
column3: attention-grabbing ethos; Crush finds them wisely dialing back the assault. And
column4: unlike G-Dragon’s strained crossover attempt Coup d’Etat
column5: YG’s team—primarily the producers Teddy
column6: DEE.P and CHOICE 37—create something fairly universal on Crush. Like a number of records in this vein
column7: there are a handful of moments that push the sound’s signature maximalism too far—I would argue that “Come Back Home” holds up plenty well without the skizz-skizz-WOMP-WOMP-WOMP breakdown stapled to the bridge—but maybe that’s a little like penalizing a Swans album for having too many guitars. With Crush
column8:
2NE1 succeed on their inlaid mission statement—they've made music for anyone.

The young Rhode Island doom revivalists Pilgrim spent the first four minutes of their 2012 debut building a sort of altar for the voice of the Wizard
column2: their vibrato-emboldened frontman. With clattering drums and crackling amplifiers
column3: the trio wound again and again through one sticky riff
column4: alternately stretching and strengthening it; at one point
column5: a ghoulish choir even harmonized with it. When the band paused briefly

column7: ” the Wizard sang
column8: his theatrical tone arching above the volume to play his required role and address his suppliants. “I know your name.” The six songs on Misery Wizard hinged on that voice
column9: registering Pilgrim as heirs apparent to a lineage that included Black Sabbath and Candlemass. They weren’t looking to break boundaries
column10: integrate extreme technicality
column11: or even be very grandiloquent
column12: like their peers of the moment
column13: Pallbearer. They seemed content to follow big riffs for long trips around fables concerning crystals and elders
column14: wizards and pariahs

column1: At least initially

column4: guitar-only intro sets up a sudden full-band bash

column6: the Wizard steps in again
column7: his voice deeper now but his authority intact: “In the master’s chamber/ I was turned to stone
column8: ” he sings in lockstep with his guitar. The Wizard sings two verses
column9: cresting in the second as he relays the peril of a spell (or fever dream?) that’s left his head spinning. And on the short
column10: stomping successor “The Paladin”
column11: the Wizard sounds again like a vintage frontman
column12: his story of vigilante justice cast in reverb and delivered like a battle cry. Between its build-up and payoff
column13: its terse verses and dense solo
column14: “The Paladin” is the automatic single of the first two Pilgrim albums
column15: an efficient encapsulation of all this band’s assets.

column1: But then the Wizard
column2: or at least his voice
column3: disappears for 10 minutes. Pilgrim lurks through the instrumental dirge “Arcane Sanctum” and then rips through its inverse
column4: an aggressive wordless lunge called “In the Process of Evil”. These brief
column5: complementary pieces offer a mid-album revelation for Void Worship
column6: because it’s here that Pilgrim’s biggest change between albums becomes clear: They don’t depend upon the Wizard’s retrofitted voice like they once did. Aside from the exasperated chant he leads at the end of “Master’s Chamber”
column7: he actually sings on only about a quarter of the album’s opening epic. Though his tale of demonic seduction serves as the centerpiece of closer “Away from Here”
column8: with his voice dipping into a bellow and peaking into a thespian’s falsetto
column9: the story only consumes a small sliver of the song. The rest goes to the riff and the rhythm
column10: advancing in perfectly deliberate unison and pushing into a void of variation. Last year
column11: Pilgrim’s bassist
column12: Count Elric the Soothsayer
column13: took his leave
column14: forcing the band to reconsider their approach and adjust to life as a duo. They seem to have taken this is an invitation not to thin their sound but rather to reinforce it; on drums
column15: the wonderfully named Krolg Splinterfist
column16: Slayer of Men moves with the Wizard’s guitar with a twin sense of economy and power. The Wizard also adds bass
column17: and his approach is more oriented to fortifying his own guitar melodies and tying them to the drums than necessarily developing a distinct voice. Void Worship sounds more relentless and loaded than its predecessor
column18: even though Pilgrim often forgoes the additional layer of vocals. Coupled with proper production in New Jersey’s Moonlight Mile studio
column19: Pilgrim sounds appropriately massive for its proper Metal Blade entrance.

column1: The Wizard’s relative restraint will no doubt disappoint some of Pilgrim’s early adopters
column2: as it was a calling card for the band’s 21st century anachronism. But the move also helps to fade Pilgrim’s timestamp
column3: or the sense that they champion an era so much that they could be a vestige of it. Their abiding sense of doom remains intact

Void Worship takes what was essential about Misery Wizard and compacts it while expanding Pilgrim’s overall scope—a fitting progression for a pair of genre loyalists.

Writing about Johnny Cash is a lot like writing about religion: It’s tough to know where to start
column3: and most folks have their own unshakable ideas on the subject and little interest in your interpretation. At the heart of the matter lies a simple truth: it's difficult to cast a critical eye over something you’ve grown up with
column4: a presence you've always taken as gospel. So it must be said that not everything Johnny Cash recorded was hewn from pure gold. We sometimes need reminding that despite his larger-than-life existence
column5: at the end of the day he was but a man
column6: one who made plenty of mistakes
column7: both personal and musical. Cash’s flawed humanity is one of the reasons why so very many people were drawn to him
column8: and why we remember him still. This newest addition to his ever-expanding body of posthumous work
column9: an album originally recorded 30 years ago but never released at the time
column10: provides additional context for one of the strangest and most flawed periods of his career
column11: and offers up a few damn good tunes in the bargain.

column1: Out Among the Stars dates to the 1980s
column2: which may as well have been Cash’s lost decade. Nashville was so enamored of its rhinestone cowboys and gritty outlaws that the Man in Black slipped between the cracks and
column3: in his own words
column4: became largely invisible. His rough-and-tumble persona had been softened by television appearances and married life
column5: and it didn’t help that his three decades with Columbia Records had left both Cash and the label sour on one another. The early 80s marked a high point in the chart battle between Bakersfield-influenced pop country and the burgeoning outlaw scene
column6: and it was during this uncertain period between 1981 and 1984 that the Out Among the Stars sessions took place. Cash showed his chameleon colors by electing to record a duet with notorious rabble-rouser Waylon Jennings called “I’m Moving On”
column7: and this move—not to mention his close ties with Jennings
column8: Willie Nelson and Kris Kristofferson thanks to their shared time as the Highwaymen—seemed to place his allegiance firmly in the outlaw camp. And yet
column9: the sessions were recorded with au courant countrypolitan hitmaker Billy Sherrill. The album was shelved and remained in the vault until Cash’s son John Carter Cash stumbled across the recordings in 2012 and
column10: joined by co-producer Steve Berkowitz and musicians Marty Stuart
column11: Buddy Miller
column12: and Carlene Carter
column13: restored the album for release.

column1: The thing about Johnny Cash has always been that when he’s on
column2: he’s great
column3: but when he’s not
column4: it can be jarring and almost uncomfortable
column5: like seeing a favorite uncle swig from a hip flask at Christmas. Out Among the Stars is strongest when it stays close to his roughshod roots and rock’n’roll spirit
column6: and it fumbles when it comes to the sappy stuff. There are only a few awkward moments
column7: but they’re hard to ignore. Still
column8: the good outweighs the bad
column9: and you couldn’t be faulted for picking and choosing your sips of poison here. Given its origins
column10: it’s no small wonder that the album comes off more as a collection of songs rather than a unified whole; listening to it all in one go dims a bit of the individual songs’ sparkle.

column1: But man
column2: do some of these cuts sparkle. The opening title track is classic Cash: straightforward and conversational
column3: with punchy Springsteen-gone-bad lyrics (“It’s midnight at a liquor store in Texas
column4: closing time and now the day is done/ When a boy walks in the door and points a pistol
column5: he can’t find a job
column6: but Lord
column7: he’s found a gun”) and a rollicking beat. The protagonist remains a sympathetic figure even as he turns to crime and
column8: as is his wont
column9: Cash puts a lot of himself into those words. It’s a reassuring way to open the album and it dovetails nicely with “Baby Ride Easy”
column10: the first and better of Johnny’s two duets with June; ""Easy"" is a homespun exchange with an easy twang and bouncy upbeat
column11: and third wheel Carlene Carter’s backing harmonies add a little extra fullness to June’s verses.

column1: On the downside
column2: “After All” is a gospel-tinged piano ballad about lost love that constitutes the album’s weakest three minutes. Cash’s warm baritone is the focal point
column3: but the track feels more schmaltzy than sincere. A few other ballads fair better. “Tennessee” is a nostalgic love note to his birthplace replete with weepy strings and a children’s chorus
column4: and “Don’t You Think Its Come Our Time” is another endearingly sweet duet with June backed by a gentle mix of acoustic guitar
column5: banjo
column6: mandolin
column7: and upright bass. Saccharine and earnest
column8: the pair sound more like a mooney-eyed young couple singing at a church social; with anyone else
column9: it would sound utterly hackneyed
column10: but their chemistry makes all the difference.

column1: Turns out Johnny the heartbreaker is ultimately a lot more fun to listen to than Johnny the loyal husband. The simple country traipse of “If I Told You Who It Was” sees Cash get nice and comfortable in his role as a storyteller with a wink and a grin
column2: spinning a yarn about a nameless country star with a figure that just won’t quit. “I Drove Her Out of My Mind” makes good use of his oaky baritone and just begs to be played in a dingy barroom full of jilted shadows
column3: while steel guitar swinger “Rock and Roll Shoes” sees Cash unapologetic as ever
column4: trucking along defiantly with a rockabilly strut. “She Used to Love Me A Lot” is best known as a David Allen Coe tune
column5: but as it turns out
column6: Cash beat him to it by a scant few weeks. Though Coe’s delivery is uncharacteristically somber on his rendition
column7: Cash’s version is an even quieter
column8: more staid affair that finds him accompanied by a muted choir and soberly plucked acoustic strings. Where Coe howls
column9: Cash mourns.

column1: Closing track “I Came to Believe”
column2: a Cash original
column3: offers an illuminating contrast to his late period
column4: since it also appeared on his 2006 album V: A Hundred Highways. While the modern version is sparse and fragile
column5: this piano-driven
column6: gospel-influenced number showcases his voice at its finest. He lacks the later gravitas
column7: but his strong
column8: pure baritone easily commands attention and
column9: wrapped around a song of hope and redemption
column10: it ends the album on a high note.

column1: Johnny Cash is an American archetype—Paul Bunyan with a battered acoustic or Davy Crockett with a dobro tucked under his famous cap. To many of us
column2: the low rumble of his voice is a comforting and familiar sound
column3: and while we’ll never get him back
column4: it’s nice to come across his ghost on recordings like this. Though it’s far from “essential
column5: ” Out Among the Stars is a boon for fans of country music history as well as those who just can’t get enough Cash. More importantly
column6:
it highlights a missing link between the often disparate eras of a long and complicated career.

Glenn Kotche is best known as the drummer of Wilco 2.0
column2: the rebel whose junk metal thwacks and snaking marimba lines on Yankee Hotel Foxtrot’s “I Am Trying to Break Your Heart” heralded the beginning of the band’s most creatively fertile period. He also once played the Four Tops on faucets in a Delta commercial. But even before his tenure with Tweedy in Wilco and Loose Fur
column3: Kotche wrote and performed contemporary classical music. His previous albums of original works foregrounded himself as a virtuoso performer
column4: but on Adventureland
column5: a new collection of pieces for chamber ensembles
column6: he’s a composer first and foremost.

column1: As a percussionist writing music based around the obsessive repetition of small
column2: pulsating melodic cells
column3: Kotche automatically puts himself in the shadow of Steve Reich
column4: even quoting the elder composer on “Clapping Music Variations” and “Individual Trains” from 2006’s Mobile. But though he constructs his work from similar building blocks to Reich’s
column5: the pivot points in Kotche’s pieces are more frequent and jarring. He roughens minimalism around the edges and speeds up its action
column6: forcing the listener to adapt quickly to constant metrical changes.

column1: “The Haunted Suite”
column2: the better of the two large works that make up the bulk of Adventureland
column3: is full of these unexpected turns of phrase. Kotche works in his area of greatest expertise
column4: writing for a horde of pitched and unpitched percussion instruments and two pianos. Each movement in “The Haunted Suite” focuses on a different eerie
column5: real-life location
column6: and the shifting scenery inspires radical musical contrasts. The acerbic “The Haunted Furnace” evokes the ruins of a steel mill in Alabama
column7: and takes a page out of the book of the early 20th-century American composer Henry Cowell’s uncanny
column8: tone-cluster-ridden piano music. Similarly herky-jerky rhythms and dissonances arise in the lively “The Haunted Dance”
column9: but the piece is much more restrained dynamically
column10: channeling Indonesian gamelan music. The “Haunted Hive” moment is a percussion-only piece which
column11: unlike the other sections
column12: deals entirely in ambient
column13: sometimes onomatopoeic sound.

column1: In “Anomaly”
column2: a larger-scale work originally written for and performed by the Kronos Quartet
column3: Kotche adopts a less diverse approach. His liner notes mention that some of the piece’s sections were composed on drum kit; it makes sense
column4: then
column5: that the metrical patterns are its most interesting elements. Unfortunately
column6: the actual pitched material often feels like an afterthought
column7: and it's certainly a bit too familiar
column8: coming across like movie-soundtrack-ready pseudo-minimalism with a pop harmonic sensibility. It’s also too bad that Kotche doesn’t further embrace the possibilities of his chosen instruments
column9: considering he has the world’s premier avant-garde string quartet at his disposal. Unusual string timbres arise only briefly
column10: elsewhere on the album
column11: in the muted middle section of the collage piece “Triple Fantasy”.

column1: So the most compelling section of “Anomaly” is the first
column2: one that Kotche realized electronically instead of with the quartet. The dizzying melodic counterpoint is rendered on what sounds like a water-damaged version of Thom Yorke’s Rhodes on “Everything in its Right Place”
column3: and fractured increasingly by electronic manipulation. This treatment provides the piece with the textural interest that its other sections lack; it’s the one moment where Kotche embraces the noise
column4: grit and incidental sounds which amplify his best work
column5:
from his free improvisational recordings to “Ashes of American Flags”.

We will never stop returning to Stravinsky's savage
column3: gleaming The Rite of Spring
column4: and enterprising (or foolhardy) musicians will never stop reimagining it. Whether it was the Pacific Symphony's 2013 ""ReRite""
column5: the Metropolis Ensemble's ""The Rite: Remixed""
column6: Darryl Brenzel's big band jazz version
column7: or Golem's death metal take
column8: new entrants regularly succumb to the impulse to fiddle with Stravinsky's era-shaping masterwork
column9: and now the Bad Plus are stepping up to the plate. The jazz trio won acclaim by twisting hard rock and punk songs into jazz language
column10: a trick riddled with steep hazards: cleverness on one side
column11: and terminal lameness on the other.  The trio
column12: sure-handed and steely
column13: evaded both traps
column14: folding Davie Bowie
column15: Queen
column16: and Rush covers alongside their own compositions.

column1: Tackling Stravinsky's Rite arises fresh hazards. They no longer risk accusations of novelty
column2: but they also enter
column3: for the first time
column4: a crowded field. And while no sane person would refer to the task of transposing the entirety of the orchestral Rite into jazz trio as ""easy""
column5: they also wander much closer to jazz-friendly language when engaging with Stravinsky's work. The composer was thrilled and enraptured by jazz rhythms and harmonies
column6: and jazz musicians worshiped Stravinsky. (Pretty much everyone worshiped Stravinsky.)  So what happens when the Bad Plus make the closest they've come to a ""conventional"" decision?

column1: The premonitory shudder of the opening woodwind line
column2: which bandleader Ethan Iverson brings under both hands of the piano
column3: is a promising beginning. The piano notes refract in the mix in the mix like light through a water glass
column4: and after a minute or so
column5: some tasteful
column6: if slightly dated
column7: electronics enter. They have an air-conditioned
column8: late-'90s trip-hop feel to them
column9: and they are the first sign of rocky waters ahead. It's not that there's anything inappropriate about electronics: Some of the Bad Plus's touches that might sound gimmicky on paper
column10: like a sampled female voice uttering a sharp intake of breath during the ""Introduction"" section
column11: are its most vivid moments. This is a ballet about the thrilling violence of young lust
column12: after all.

column1: The trouble is that the electronics feel pat
column2: and slightly obvious
column3: and they signal that for the first time in their career
column4: the Bad Plus are simply outgunned. The contemplative
column5: brooding sections of Stravinsky's ballet translate the best—the yearning tug of the chords in ""Spring Rounds"" translate into dark glowing left-hand work. Double bassist Reid Anderson creeps on cat feet during the ""Evocation of the Ancestors/Ritual Action of the Ancestors"" movement
column6: while drummer Dave King bows some effectively eerie whines on the cymbals.

column1: But the fiercest sections suggest that the Bad Plus just aren't a match for the full blast of Stravinsky's orchestra. ""The Augurs of Spring"" is one of the most menacing moments in 20th-century music
column2: in which the orchestra lands on a tendon-crunching composite chord dozens of times
column3: the thudding downbeat a throw rug constantly disappearing beneath your feet. In the Pierre Boulez recording with the Cleveland Orchestra from 1969
column4: these hits feel stunning
column5: inhuman
column6: like steel hammers hitting dead flesh. Banged on the low-end of the piano with Dave King's kick drum to support it
column7: the section sounds almost...dinky. The Rite can be all kinds of things—breathless
column8: lustful
column9: pitiless—but ""dinky"" can never be one of them.

column1: The feat is still impressive
column2: in an athletic way. The trio have been mapping out this version in concert for years
column3: and you could never accuse them of scaling this mountain without planning ahead of time.  But the Rite should elicit gasps
column4: not cock eyebrows—the latter of which is the most extreme reaction the Bad Plus manage to provoke. It's ironic that after tackling (and matching) Black Sabbath and Nirvana
column5:
it would be Stravinsky that would finally make the Bad Plus sound positively tame.

Sometimes exploitative impulses yield good art. Despite the way it's presented
column2: Dylan's Gospel
column3: the sole album by the Brothers and Sisters (aka the Brothers & Sisters of Los Angeles
column4: aka the Los Angeles Gospel Choir—it's been reissued a few times)
column5: did not arise from a group of L.A. area gospel singers deciding what they really wanted to do was record some Bob Dylan songs. The idea came from producer and Ode Records chief Lou Adler
column6: who can't help but have noticed that the Edwin Hawkins Singers' ""Oh Happy Day"" had recently become the first full-on black gospel choir recording to hit the Pop Top Five.

column1: Adler's choir and soloists had
column2: indeed
column3: mostly learned to sing in church. But the ""Brothers and Sisters"" were recruited from the L.A. backup-singer circuit—if you've seen 20 Feet from Stardom
column4: you've seen a lot of their names
column5: and if you've ever listened to classic-rock radio
column6: you've heard their voices on other people's records. Over two days in July
column8: the group recorded churchified versions of 10 familiar Dylan tunes
column9: including his then-current single ""Lay Lady Lay""
column10: a song that's about as secular as Bob has ever gotten. This is formally the same kind of record as
column11: say
column12: a set of Imagine Dragons songs arranged as lullabies
column13: rather than a direct antecedent to the terrific 2003 tribute-with-the-honoree's-input Gotta Serve Somebody: The Gospel Songs of Bob Dylan.

column1: That said
column2: it's way better than it has a right to be: it's always at least interesting
column3: and often pretty delightful. If you didn't catch the words
column4: Dylan's Gospel could pass as a solidly played
column5: splendidly sung ""contemporary gospel"" record
column6: and if you can overlook the choir keeping a straight face as they raise the roof about ""her fog
column7: her amphetamine
column8: and her pearls""
column9: it can pass as that even if you do catch the words. By the time Adler's choir assembled
column10: Dylan was still a decade away from writing overtly Christian songs
column11: but he'd internalized the whole gospel songbook by the time he started writing his own stuff: the language of ""Chimes of Freedom"" and ""The Times They Are A-Changin'"" makes the stylistic transition beautifully. His lyrics were also open wide enough to interpretation that it wasn't hard to come up with a reading of
column12: say
column13: ""The Mighty Quinn"" as an impassioned if slightly eccentric parable about Christ's return
column14: which is exactly how the great Merry Clayton delivers it here.

column1: A few iffy aspects of the project reveal its origins as a cash-in. The vocalists are credited in a list
column2: but the lead singers weren't initially identified as such—""because of contractual obligations
column3: Adler claimed to Rolling Stone at the time. (The new reissue's liner notes indicate that it's definitely Gloria Jones on ""I'll Be Your Baby Tonight""
column4: for what that's worth
column5: and Honey Cone's Edna Wright on ""Lay Lady Lay"".) Master session bassist Jerry Scheff
column6: who would play on Dylan's Street-Legal nine years later
column7: was identified on the original sleeve as ""Jerry O. Scheft."" Some of the singers also don't seem to have been too familiar with Dylan's material: whoever sings the ""My Back Pages"" verse containing ""mutiny from stern to bow"" makes that line rhyme with ""slow
column8: a mistake you'd only make if you were reading it off a lyric sheet and hadn't noticed how every verse ends.

column1: Still
column2: sometimes exploitative impulses eventually yield things nobody anticipates. One of the Sisters on Dylan's Gospel was Clydie King
column3: who'd been recording hither and thither since she'd made her first single as Little Clydie as a 12- or 13-year-old in 1956. (If that's not her ripping it up on ""Mr. Tambourine Man"" here
column4: it's somebody with a very similar voice.) King spent most of the 70s as a top-flight backup singer for rock bands: 11 years after she sang with Adler's ad-hoc group
column5: she started dating Dylan
column6: and became his creative collaborator for the next few years
column7: often singing solo during his gospel-era concerts and duetting with him on stage and on record. ""Clydie's one of the greatest singers ever
column8:
Dylan said. ""I get chills when I hear her just breathe.""

 As the mastermind behind shapeshifting experimental outfit Horseback
column3: North Carolina musician Jenks Miller has played many roles: ambient auteur
column4: doom-metal songwriter
column5: black metal howler
column6: producer
column7: folkie. But he's not exactly willing to use labels—and why should he? In a recent interview
column8: Miller avoids the slippery slope of compartmentalization by situating Horseback within a broader tradition of psychic exploration and visceral expression
column9: birthed by the blues and embedded within the musical DNA of John Cage
column10: Neil Young
column11: and Richard Thompson alike: ""As far as I'm concerned
column12: he says
column13: ""all esoteric music is bonded by blood. I love it all."" Indeed
column14: Miller's sanguine palette has shifted in tone at various points throughout Horseback's seven-year existence
column15: producing such disparate offspring as the serene
column16: spacious 2007 debut Impale Golden Horn and its snarling
column17: frostbitten descendent
column18: 2012's Half-Blood. The latest Horseback album
column19: Piedmont Apocrypha
column20: compacts this meandering trajectory into a five-song narrative that's inclusive
column21: intriguing

column1: That the overwhelming majority of Piedmont Apocrypha is comprised of labyrinthine soundscapes is to be expected. Horseback songs have always been dominated by Miller's repetitive
column2: circular structures
column3: be they're in the guise of ribbons of feedback or forlorn twang
column4: and his mantras are the compositional and thematic cornerstones of the structures that strengthen with every verse
column5: every repetition
column6: and every second. At the same time
column7: closer inspection reveals the din to be anything but static: the snakelike line of drone that runs through opening dirge ""Passing Through"" courses like an open wire
column8: threatening to swallow the entire song whole at a moment's notice
column9: while the tonal irregularity of the spindled arpeggios that drive ""Consecration Blues"" (created by running two amplifiers with different tonal qualities) grows more dire and unsettling by the second.

column1: Even the prettiest of pastorals—conjured by the warm acoustic guitar of the title track and insect rhythms of ""Milk and Honey""—decay the second they reach your ears
column2: fostering a sense of dread that never goes away completely. Not even the return of frequent Horseback collaborators Rich James
column3: Nick Petersen
column4: and John Crouch for the 18-minute closer
column5: ""Chanting Out The Low Shadow""
column6: proffers relief. Miller's mix subdues the intensity of his death growls
column7: and later
column8: his singing
column9: by shrouding them in the solemn boogie of his bandmates. As a result
column10: Piedmont Apocrypha offers little in the way of easy satisfaction or cathartic handouts—that is
column11: aside from the title track's combustive finale
column12: a hot
column13: shimmery mess that unfurls several minutes' worth of stored energy in one go.

column1: Miller's fascination with the dark side of the human psyche resonates strongly on Piedmont Apocrypha. Delivered in a creepy
column2: lilting tenor
column3: ""Passing Through""'s opening couplet of ""I was born to lose/ I won't have this form forever"" could scan as an occult-informed boast or a bleak statement of acceptance. And yet
column4:
that single memento mori soundbite embodies the strange optimism of the project as a whole: tucking into this album is kind of like taking a stroll through hell with a trusted friend.

Much ink has been spilled over the death of regionalism in rap: New York's A$AP Mob fusing Harlem rap with Memphis and Houston aesthetics
column2: Chief Keef and Chicago's drill kids building on the blueprint crafted by Waka Flocka and Lex Luger in Atlanta
column3: and Drake up in Toronto shrewdly cherry-picking styles from everyone. However
column4: a group of Cali savants are eking out a body of work that gives the lie to the current proclamations of post-regionalism. Up north
column5: the Bay area hyphy sound's morphed into something sleeker and poppier thanks to LoveRance and Heartbreak Gang’s Iamsu! and Sage the Gemini. Down in L.A.
column6: DJ Mustard’s elevated the profiles of third-tier YMCMB star Tyga
column7: singers TeeFlii and Ty Dolla $ign
column8: and Compton rapper YG.

column1: Mustard's sound peruses the common ground between the chunky low-end synths of seminal house hits like Robin S.’ “Show Me Love” and the orchestral pomp of g-funk-era Dre. He and YG have worked closely on mixtapes such as 2012's 4 Hunnid Degreez and the Just Re’d Up series
column2: forging a symbiotic producer-rapper bond the likes of which has scarcely been seen on a mainstream field of play since Drake and Noah ""40"" Shebib. YG’s major-label debut My Krazy Life marks a turning point for the duo; here
column3: Mustard’s production and YG’s songwriting have both gone deliciously widescreen.

column1: Mustard’s still working with the melodic economy that has drawn shrewd trend-watchers Drake
column2: Young Jeezy
column3: and 2 Chainz to his fold
column4: but here they’re lighter and brighter. The opening fanfares on My Krazy Life's tracks are gossamer but massive
column5: like a blindside smack from a pillow. Typically
column6: Mustard’s productions lay their wares out early and drive home simple hooks flanked by little else but 808 kicks and claps
column7: occasionally throwing in a weird embellishment or nod to his forefathers. Strip club anthem “Left
column8: Right” doubles down on its colossal three-note theme with a fiddle midway through each verse
column9: “BPT”’s air raid siren keys are accented with orchestra hits like Dre and 50 Cent’s “In Da Club”
column10: and “Do It to Ya” plunks out piano and Moog melodies on loan from Tha Dogg Pound’s “Let’s Play House”.

column1: But by and large
column2: Mustard’s game is achieving ecstasy through simplicity and repetition
column3: hooks and drums thundering through each measure with scarcely a note gone to waste. YG could’ve shit on a mic with Mustard as co-pilot and still turned out a halfway listenable hour of music
column4: but to his instead he’s used My Krazy Life to play with the gun-toting lothario rubric he pieced together on the earlier mixtapes. The album is very much an exercise in genre (gangsta rap
column5: natch) beholden to all the structural touchstones of a modern-day mainstream rap release
column6: but this time YG’s classicist read on Southern California gang life comes with a refined flair for storytelling.

column1: Stylistically
column2: YG says he was aiming for Snoop Dogg's Doggystyle
column3: and you can hear faint traces of that record on My Krazy Life
column4: especially in the way that songs that touch on his background as a convicted residential burglar (“1AM”
column5: “Meet the Flockers”) collide with decadent good life numbers like “I Just Wanna Party” and “Who Do You Love?” to paint a picture of a young gangster who works hard and plays harder. My Krazy Life periodically eases off its unsettlingly gleeful blueprinting of breaking-and-entering scenarios through YG’s ace hook construction and a selection of comical interstitial skits—and hang around for the deep cut “Really Be (Smokin N Drinkin)”
column6: which pulls the listener inside the loss and desperation that provides the impetus for such extralegal escapades.

column1: My Krazy Life also finds YG flexing a greater comfort in regards to songs about women. It might be unreasonable to expect a guy who rose to fame on “Toot It and Boot It”
column2: whose body of work is rife with vengeful pith like “Bitch Betta Have My Money” and “Youzza Flip”
column3: to care about his bedside manner—but he makes inroads. “Do It to Ya” is the requisite sex jam
column4: but this time the focus is on reciprocity instead of conquest. “Me and My Bitch” chronicles the souring of a relationship after a girlfriend cheats
column5: but he intimates that he still carries a torch for her when they slip into a nebulous friends with benefits arrangement after breaking up.

column1: My Krazy Life’s most engaging relationship song is familial: “Sorry Momma” closes the album with an apology to YG’s mom for a laundry list of petty misdeeds and a pledge to do better by her now that he’s rich and she’s not doing so well. On a certain level
column2: the softer touch of these songs ticks off the expected major label song-for-the-ladies pandering—they’re replete with syrupy hooks from ratch&B crooners Ty Dolla $ign and TeeFlii—but they also reveal a songwriter who remains captivating even when he pushes his trademark tough guy posturing to the side.

column1: From classic Compton set-repping rhymes
column2: to guest spots from TDE’s Jay Rock
column3: Kendrick Lamar
column4: and Schoolboy Q
column5: to production that boils g-funk down to its requisite elements
column6: My Krazy Life breathes new energy into West Coast gangsta rap. YG holds summits with out-of-towners throughout
column7: exchanging bars with Drake on “Who Do You Love?”
column8: taking a beat from ATL maestro Metro Boomin for “1AM”
column9: and celebrating friendship with Jeezy and Rich Homie Quan on the platinum-selling buddy anthem “My Nigga”.

column1: But this album’s sense of place and time isn’t amorphous and dependent on collaborators
column2: as it's been with YG’s peers: My Krazy Life is always kicking back under roadside palm trees or darting through back alleys
column3: shaking foes that give chase. It's a record that's always posted up in sunny SoCal
column4: and whether it's serving up carefree party anthems or dispensing crass advice on whose houses to knock over and what to take
column5: L.A. feels like the capital of the country when it’s playing. YG and DJ Mustard have been dress rehearsing for nationwide stardom all along
column6:
but My Krazy Life is ratchet music’s Technicolor reveal.

The Range’s tracks remind me of millipedes: Simple shapes in garish colors that bustle on crazy-legged gaits. “Washingtons”
column2: the last track on his new Panasonic EP
column3: exemplifies the electronic producer’s knack for texturing glossy tones with busy
column4: off-kilter rhythms. The synthetic harp melody unfurls neatly
column5: but the percussion beneath it scrambles and writhes
column6: providing an antic locomotion. It's the same kind of aural illusion that Providence producer James Hinton cultivated on last year's Nonfiction
column7: where he plumbed deep dynamics between soft
column8: easy melodies and jagged
column9: intricate drums

column1: Panasonic adds six more satisfying variations to the bright
column2: gently jostling terrain of that fine debut. There are a few callbacks to ""Metal Swing""
column3: a Nonfiction standout that combined zigzagging production and loose
column4: low-res grime vocals. On ""Two""
column5: piano tones and hats elevate homely rap refrains towards fervor; ""Ed Reed Jersey"" is built around a terse
column6: skipping boast
column7: and the hardness of the vocal is matched by deep
column8: implacable bass and a blocky snare

column1: On Panasonic opener ""Slow Build""
column2: Hinton slowly alchemizes minimal techno into rugged hip-hop
column3: looping R&B refrains and rap posse chants through a purposefully limping bass line. With one exception—the supple
column4: drilling ""Tricky Pose"" is almost straight-faced drum'n'bass—he continues to find rococo rhythmic seams between disparate substances. ""Sony"" is on-trend with its winsome chipmunk vocal samples but replaces the dubstep-lite backing that often accompanies them with steady
column5: thick-piled synth pop
column6: while ""Two"" approximates the sound of a classical piano trio before introducing a fleet
column7: strafing rhythmic undercarriage. Hinton restrains his melodies to dewy loops and airy progressions
column8: using plucked string and piano sounds to leave space for his pillowy basses and feathery drum programs. The music is always characterized by the sense of time coiling and swirling below smooth façades
column9: but on Panasonic
column10:
The Range uses this technical heft to achieve surprisingly accessible and emotive results.

If you've found a route to appreciating the style of Harlem's Smoke DZA
column2: there's a good chance it came from either (or both) of two particular releases. 2010's George Kush Da Button was the early breakthrough
column3: a dank-fumed breeze of a mixtape that his highly motivated voice cut through sharply. Two years later
column4: Rugby Thompson emerged
column5: taking some of the best sour-smoke soul beats of Harry Fraud's production career and revealing DZA to be nicer with the concepts and storytelling abilities than his earlier straight-talk lyrics had hinted at. He still sounded like someone whose most memorable and individualistic traits on the mic put him at the level of a somewhat less oddball
column6: more NYC-beholden version of Curren$y. But his strengths of grounded observation and a lack of out-and-out corniness outweighed the tendency for his lyrics to be less memorable than the beats he chose to spit them over.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Dream.ZONE.Achieve has a problem: it's roughly as long as George Kush Da Button and Rugby Thompson put together. For an MC whose lyrics don't typically allow much room for narrative scope
column3: easygoing humor
column4: or high-concept weirdness
column5: that's a good way to make a sporadically inventive but otherwise passable-at-best album feel like a total slog. The easiest way to get a handle on where DZA is now and how far he needs to go to get in the conversation of best MCs out of New York is to get a load of ""Ghost of Dipset""
column6: the album's second cut (third if you count the intro skit
column7: which features—here's a hell of an omen —a pseudo-freestyle interrupted by a car wreck). The ghost in question appears in the form of a Cam'ron verse where
column8: in a handful of bars
column9: Cam meets
column10: describes
column11: reminisces over
column12: worries about
column13: is briefly tempted by
column14: and then dismisses a longtime female acquaintance who wants to cheat on her husband with him. All that evocative detail follows two DZA verses that ricochet from comparing himself to ""Banksky"" [sic] to scattershot descriptions of his gear to a bloodless interpolation of Mobb Deep's ""Survival of the Fittest"". The goodwill amassed by each sharp line (""Broke hearts like when Ewing missed the finger roll"") is practically erased by a clunker soon after (""They call it showing love
column15: nah
column16: call it sucking dicks/Speaking of that
column17: face fucking my Cambodian bitch"").

column1: At least those are punchlines that make him sound like he tried. His voice is strong—think Pusha T with a little more snarl—his flow is usually fundamentally sound
column2: and every so often he shows he's got a way with taut internal rhymes. But where Dream.ZONE.Achieve stalls out is in the inability for DZA to take his initial spark of lyrical inspiration and build from it into something more evocative. The scenarios and sentiments he lays out are credible
column3: and there's little doubt that everything is said without pandering to an audience he doesn't truly connect with. But without a sustained attention-getting creativity
column4: the themes of Dream.ZONE.Achieve largely blur together in a haze of aimless defiance and frustration. You've heard tracks like ""City of Dreams"" (NYC-repping anti-swag call to realness)
column5: ""9eleven"" (neighborhood as war zone)
column6: and ""Jigga Flow"" (pick any Reasonable Doubt deep cut) before—and DZA hasn't come around to finding a way to make these popular
column7: often relatable
column8: and frankly well-worn themes uniquely his own. Considering how often the spotlight swings to personality-rich guests like Ab-Soul (""Hearses"")
column9: Wiz Khalifa & Curren$y (""Legends in the Making"")
column10: and BJ the Chicago Kid (""Robin Givens"")
column11: the contrast gets pretty stark.

column1: Still
column2: even DZA's detractors have to admit that the man can pick a production slate. Even if all you hear DZA as is the necessary vocal counterpart of a choice beat
column3: there's a lot that demands to be heard. His ear for bleary yet attention-getting midtempo slow-burn noir soul is hard to compete with
column4: and even if there's little here that tops the best moments from Ski Beatz or Harry Fraud on his previous releases
column5: it's remarkably cohesive considering the dozen-plus names involved. Ski's late-night skulk of fusion-jazz soul (""Jigga Flow"") and a couple elegaic prog-trap beats from Fraud (""I Don't Know""; ""Legends in the Making"") frame DZA's voice well. And qualitatively
column6: there's little separating up-and-comers like Cardo and vets like Sean C.

column1: But the last track
column2: and most promising pairing
column3: actually winds up as some kind of weird paradox. ""Achieve
column4: which marks the conclusion of the titular three-act arc of the album
column5: is where DZA finally gets to fulfill a stated dream of rhyming over a Pete Rock beat. He does this for two pretty capable
column6: enthusiastic-sounding minutes—and then spends another seven giving out dedications and shout-outs to the extent that it makes the coda of Jay-Z's ""My 1st Song"" sound like the concluding half a bar of ""Takeover"". In most other contexts
column7: that'd be a waste. Here
column8:
it's one of the only looks we get into a world that's bigger than just DZA himself.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20374/homepage_large.96a54a2b.jpg|Boy|7483.0|Carla Bozulich|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2014-03-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:47.092762|"

As with such well-traveled peers as Thalia Zedek or Michael Gira
column2: Carla Bozulich has spent decades navigating the art-rock underground through sheer tenacity and a fierce commitment to her own distinctive musical vision.  Throughout her career as a solo artist
column3: with her various groups (Ethyl Meatplow
column4: Geraldine Fibbers
column5: Evangelista)
column6: and with a motley assortment of collaborations and guest appearances
column7: she has charted a course that appears almost specifically designed to win a fervent cult following while keeping most others at arm’s length. Her recent albums with Evangelista have been delivered with such abrasive
column8: primal force and emotive intensity as to be genuinely intimidating for the unsuspecting listener.

column1: So even though Bozulich proclaims her latest solo album
column2: <i>Boy
column3: as her version of a “pop record
column4: ” a sense of perspective is important. It's true that Boy showcases a renewed focus on standard song construction and forward propulsion compared to such albums as Evangelista’s Hello
column5: Voyager or In Animal Tongue
column6: but there’s nothing here that's as immediate or pop-centered as Geraldine Fibbers at their most accessible; it's a safe bet to assume that the days of Bozulich performing relatively straight covers of Dolly Parton or Beck songs are a thing of the past. But Boy is filled with memorable songs that are full-muscled enough to withstand whatever level of barbed deconstruction that Bozulich throws at them
column7: making it her most approachable album in a while.

column1: On Evangelista’s 2011 brooding In Animal Tongue
column2: Bozulich followed one particular stream of inspiration all the way to its murky headwaters
column3: as she and her collaborators created a dense sonic atmosphere that abandoned conventional rock textures almost entirely. Several tracks on that album eliminated rhythmic momentum altogether
column4: so it comes as a mild relief when Bozulich immediately dispels any lingering sense of claustrophobia by kicking off Boy with ""Ain't No Grave""
column5: proclaiming “Ain’t no grave that can hold me down” over a dramatic stab of bass and Andrea Belfi’s fluid drumming.

column1: As with Bozulich’s past work
column2: Boy makes frequent reference to various country
column3: gospel
column4: and blues traditions
column5: and those influences are refracted in ways that surprise and unsettle. Such slow-simmering tracks as “Don’t Follow Me” or the hypnotic “What Is It Baby” sound like distant relations to standard country or folk-blues songs
column6: stretched and attenuated in a such a way that their punches never quite seem to land where you expect them.  Boy's most straightforward song
column7: “Lazy Crossbones”
column8: features an electric piano shuffle and downright catchy “Ba-da-da-da” chorus competing for space with hazy interjections of feedback and abstract layers of tape noise. Bozulich’s earthy voice remains a unique and malleable instrument
column9: and here she inhabits the shifting landscapes of her songs with authority and deceptive ease.

column1: Bozulich’s vocals are so forceful and transfixing
column2: in fact
column3: that it's easy to overlook her skill as an arranger and sound artist. Playing the majority of the instruments herself
column4: Bozulich specializes in creating combinations of sounds and textures that continually loosen the songs' moorings. The Tom Waits-like grind of the lusty “One Hard Man” is punctuated by vivid blasts of industrial noise
column5: while distant strings echo through “Drowned to the Light” like fading spirits. At her best
column6: Bozulich uses the vernacular song forms of country
column7: blues
column8: and yes
column9: even “pop”
column10: to tap into something that feels much more elemental
column11:
a vein of primitive emotion that feels like it could pre-date the notion of musical genres entirely. Her work on Boy should be sufficient to satisfy her longtime followers and perhaps draw some new onlookers into the fold.
