0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20327/homepage_large.03600940.jpg|III: Beneath Trident's Tomb|32153.0|Twilight|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Century Media']|2014-03-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:47.730592|"

Long before its release
column2: III: Beneath Trident’s Tomb became a punchline for both heavy metal and indie rock fans. Less than a year after news of his split with Kim Gordon (and the concomitant break-up of Sonic Youth) surfaced
column3: Thurston Moore joined Twilight
column4: an amorphous pan-American supergroup that had previously collected metalhead lifers such as Leviathan’s Wrest
column5: Nachtmystium’s Blake Judd
column6: and Krieg’s irascible leader Neill Jameson. Xasthur’s Malefic and Isis’ Aaron Turner had recorded with Twilight
column7: too. Moore wasn’t a stranger to black metal
column8: of course—he’d written about it in Arthur
column9: professed his rather nascent love for its hate to Decibel
column10: and had generally been part of the caustic form’s larger cultural uptick. His own vision of noise and volume had an undeniable impact on the evolution of heaviness during the last two decades
column11: evidenced simply by his admission into the band itself. Still
column12: it was hard not to feel a little embarrassed for the 55-year-old
column13: in the same way you might grin but worry when a newly single parent admits they’ve squandered a chunk of retirement change on a candy-apple sports car. An indie rock icon prepared for his corpsepaint makeover.

column1: Moore’s personal crisis wasn’t Twilight’s only moment of ignominy
column2: either: In 2011
column3: Jef Whitehead
column4: or Wrest
column5: had been charged with sexual assault and he was eventually convicted of aggravated domestic battery and sentenced to two years of probation. Though Judd doesn’t play on Beneath Trident’s Tomb
column6: he did appear in band photos with Moore after he broke the news of the guitarist’s inclusion. In the past year
column7: he’s been accused of ripping off fans and bandmates
column8: arrested for theft
column9: and ultimately revealed that he was retreating the scene with hopes of beating his substance-abuse problems. What’s more
column10: when the group finally announced its long-delayed third album
column11: it added a seemingly inevitable asterisk: III: Beneath Trident’s Tomb would be Twilight’s final album
column12: because
column13: effective immediately
column14: the band was finished. If it was drama and excitement Moore sought
column15: he had doubtlessly found it.

column1: This tale of turmoil could go two ways for Beneath Trident’s Tomb
column2: of course. It might provide an obstacle for Twilight to overcome
column3: adding a core of tension and urgency to their process. Twilight could create its own pre-emptive Behind the Music and counter with their most wrenching album to date. Or the fuss could simply become the ballyhoo before the album’s eventual bust. Really
column4: these six songs offer a little of both: The collective scrapes through a mess of black metal and sludge
column5: industrial accents and noise countercurrents
column6: post-punk switchbacks and atmospheric interludes. The music itself can be delightfully dense
column7: with Moore and the Atlas Moth vocalist/guitarist Stavros Giannopoulos providing layer upon layer of leading riffs and antagonistic din. Moore plays the part of noise addendum perfectly
column8: adding thin layers of dissonance and quick flashes of power when needed. Chicago producer Sanford Parker again adds electronic disarray
column9: retrenching the album’s pronounced industrial direction.

column1: Given the band’s new mass of guitars
column2: they’re able to ratchet volume and intensity constantly. On “Seek No Shelter Fevered Ones”
column3: for instance
column4: they add an additional damaged layer of vocals or sub-surface shot of feedback at seemingly every turnaround. That same strength-in-numbers strategy works for the album’s best song
column5: “Oh Wretched Son”. Twilight pinball from ghoulish lurch to bass-led sludge
column6: from claustrophobic black metal to hardcore upheaval in a matter of minutes. They render each part with the precision of a veteran squad and the energy of five players enthusiastically building a collective musical map. They’re questioning in real-time what this version of Twilight is
column7: and they’re answering rather loudly.

column1: But that is the exception to Tomb’s blasé rule. Most of these songs suffer from a lack of motion or a mere inability to edit the excess away from that motion. Opener “Lungs” certainly sounds mean
column2: but it lashes at the same theme at the same tempo for most of its four-minute runtime. It’s hard not to stare at the track time in anticipation of any change. As though acknowledging the tedium
column3: Twilight does speed up for a short-lived coda
column4: but even that feels like an afterthought
column5: a footnote of excitement meant to mask general ennui. “Swarming Funereal Mass” is a tormented mid-tempo march
column6: its doleful plod accented by drum machines and desperate vocals. There’s a riveting break toward the middle
column7: where a gale of guitar noise overruns everything and seems to send even the band into shivers. But they soon drift into the same rote clip
column8: extending one idea unnecessarily. That’s even true of the otherwise powerful “Seek No Shelter for the Fevered Ones”. At nine minutes
column9: it’s impossibly bloated
column10: a track whose placid introduction
column11: steady buildup
column12: and squall-infested midsection could have been condensed into a harrowing four minutes. As is
column13: though
column14: you’ll get too accustomed to the attack to be scared by it; Twilight’s apparent need to turn every little thought into very grand statements fosters a kind of sensory acclimation
column15: where you become so used to the maneuvers they fail to leave any lasting effect.

column1: Taken collectively
column2: Twilight’s three finished albums feel like a decision still waiting to be made: What did this band hope to accomplish musically
column3: other than to corral a handful of scene celebrities into a room every few years? Was their heart with the primal roar of their self-titled debut
column4: a blunderbuss of invective and torment? Or was their head with Monument to Time End
column5: a sophisticated sophomore album that seemed to take the talents of its members and apply them to more audacious structures than ever before? Given some refinement
column6: that approach could have made Twilight incredible
column7: a supergroup worth the noise that surrounds them. More than anything
column8: Beneath Trident’s Tomb seems like an attempt to avoid any such stepwise intentionality
column9: choosing instead to let a few aging dudes throw a fit in a recording studio behind a small set of underdeveloped songs. Beneath Trident’s Tomb shows flashes of brilliance. But those limited sparks add up to a disappointing final bow from a band whose sordid reputation and fable-like storyline will likely outlast the music it made.

column1:
Correction: an earlier version of this review misstated that Jef Whitehead was convicted of sexual assault; he was initially charged with sexual assault and ultimately convicted of aggravated domestic battery.

Future Islands frontman Samuel T. Herring has an energy
column2: a physical aura
column3: that moves along a single line. On one end is a hangdog character with tucked-in shirt and pleated khakis and on the other is an ursine man-monster wresting primordial sounds from his heart. Until recently
column4: we could find Herring only in the small clubs where Future Islands relentlessly toured. With Herring as ringleader
column5: these shows got pretty rowdy for a three-piece synth pop band. Everyone would push around to his metal vocals of “Tin Man” and sway along to “Inch of Dust” — their former marquee song from 2010’s In Evening Air — all while Herring waved his arms like a man conducting a symphony of giants.

column1: When Future Islands recently performed their new marquee song on “Letterman”
column2: the stunning “Seasons (Waiting On You)”
column3: the secret was out: Here’s this guy
column4: this dude with a tucked-in shirt
column5: khakis
column6: and a receding hairline bobbing and weaving
column7: grinding gears in his throat
column8: giving a “fuck yeah” gesture before a perfect pop modulation takes him to the chorus. He had that kind of uninhibited spirit the internet loves to protect and preserve. If he had a more garrulous social media brand
column9: no doubt he could take this moment and amass an army of fans
column10: the hashtag Herring Task Force
column11: retweeting Vines of people wearing tucked-in shirts and khakis doing “The Herring”.

column1: The landmark performance was far and away the most viewed musical segment on “Late Show With David Letterman” and it was certainly the most surprising moment of Future Islands’ career. And now
column2: following the storied live shows
column3: the memes
column4: and their move from Thrill Jockey to 4AD comes their fourth and possibly best album
column5: Singles. These songs finally invite us to participate in Herring’s world
column6: one shaped by geological heartbreak events and their epochal reflection periods
column7: told with nothing more than the simple truth. It’s pop music distilled
column8: something Future Islands have been working at since their earliest lo-fi electro-punk recordings.

column1: Singles is a great balance of pop and melodrama. It’s built around the sturdy new wave beat
column2: almost always four on the floor
column3: giving Herring a comfortable frame in which to sing. Its themes are also symmetrical
column4: as Herring plays with antithesis like an eager English student: day and night
column5: sun and moon
column6: summer and winter
column7: man and woman. His words are the sort of thing that would tumble out of your mouth if you were told to write a love poem right now in eight seconds. “She looks like the moon/ So close and yet so far” or “My sun every morning/ My star of the evening” are just two couplets that look goopy on the page but sound so impulsively romantic when he sings them. Which is to say that the setting for these songs is nothing fancy
column8: but if they were any busier than cool nights in the tall grass with the moon hanging just so
column9: it would ruin the music’s delicate relationship with Herring.

column1: Herring’s presence draws from Wham City’s theatrical charm
column2: but Future Islands also work on a much grander scale. From their debut up to 2011’s On The Water
column3: bassist William Cashion was the group’s Peter Hook
column4: as he offered distinctive lines with an actual personality behind it. But on Singles
column5: Cashion and the band nod toward the stadium-ready anthems of early U2. The moody synth drones have been replaced with ergonomic melody and the band has tightened up accordingly. On songs like “Spirit” and the parting words of “A Dream Of You And Me”
column6: when Herring’s passionate delivery carries him into those heavenly choruses
column7: you can all but see the flood lights flash in the arena when he gets there. He sings with his eyes open
column8: still searching
column9: still trying to reconcile love
column10: and still a little pissed off.

column1: The album isn’t as taut as it could be in the back half—“Like the Moon”
column2: for example
column3: is a predictable and rather long four-and-a-half minutes. But Future Islands compensate for the occasional dull patch. Just after “Like the Moon” comes the album’s highpoint
column4: the post-mortem ballad “Fall From Grace”. It could be a Beach House song with its below-freezing tempo and a spotlight on Cashion’s guitars
column5: but then Herring gets to thinking about one of those heartbreak events and it all comes rushing back above this overdriven baritone guitar. He unknots all the emotion that has only bubbled up until now and asks one last question about their love and basically Hulks out: “was it ALL INSIDE OF ME?” The moment is arresting
column6: and in the context of the sometimes mushy poetry of the album
column7: these four words are blinding and absolutely unforgettable.

column1: If this all seems a bit much
column2: well
column3: it is. That’s the point of Future Islands
column4: to invite this impulsive and unfettered behavior into the lives of listeners
column5: both at home and at their shows. Singles is risky
column6: but the strength of the songwriting carries it over. It reminds me of that video from Sasquatch 2009 of the shirtless guy dancing to Santigold
column7: which has since gone mega viral. Herring acts on impulse—at no point does he sound calculated or clever—offering an open invitation to the uninhibited
column8: to the goofy
column9:
and the sentimental.

Some artifacts can only be referred to by themselves: A kidney bean is a kidney-shaped bean
column2: and Lavender Country is the best country record by an openly gay person released in 1973. It is an object singular enough in music history that the Country Music Hall of Fame officially recognized it in 1999. Patrick Haggerty
column3: the man who wrote and recorded it
column4: was raised on a dairy farm outside Seattle by a loving and accepting family before the twin shocks of the Stonewall riots and his ejection from the Peace Corps radicalized him. He responded with Lavender Country
column5: pressing about 1
column6: 000 copies with the help of a local gay community organization and selling them by word-of-mouth and in the back pages of gay magazines. Once those were gone
column7: that was more or less it—Haggerty remained a staunch advocate of gay rights
column8: and performed Lavender Country songs at pride events and community centers. But his record receded into history
column9: to a rumor perfuming the edges of record collector conversation.

column1: Now that the resourceful and adventurous North Carolina label Paradise of Bachelors is reissuing Lavender Country
column2: the enduring richness of Haggerty's achievement can be appreciated again. Haggerty didn't just write a ""gay country album"" for the political theatre. There are winking lyrics about tumbling in the hay and a rewrite of ""Back in the Saddle Again"" as ""Back in the Closet Again""
column3: but the country signifiers aren't just cheap hay-bale-and-tractor-bed props for a message. From the inexpertly sawed fiddle of Eve Morris to Michael Carr's saloon piano to Haggerty's reedy
column4: searching tenor
column5: it is a country album through and through. The sound is wobbly and amateurish
column6: but in a playful
column7: ""come on y'all"" sort of way
column8: and you can easily imagine a roomful of enthusiastic participants in folding chairs at a community-center basement
column9: singing along at Haggerty's encouragement.

column1: Like any good culture-clash project
column2: Lavender Country stops to have fun with sly subtext. ""There's milk and honey flowin' when you're blowin' Gabriel's horn""
column3: Haggerty leers on ""Come Out Singing"". On the title track
column4: he envisions a utopia where you wear your ""frilly blouse"" to ""The People's Outhouse"" and ""the folks will hang around and pee for days."" ""Cryin' These Cocksucking Tears"" claimed the FCC license of a DJ brave or foolhardy enough to play it on the air. On it
column5: Haggerty's backup vocalist Morris sings the words ""cock-sucking tears"" with a clarion earnestness
column6: like Joan Baez working blue. It is a fresh joy to hear every time it comes along.

column1: But Lavender Country is not a really a ""funny"" album. The songs address life inside the gay-rights struggle
column2: and the specifics hurt. On ""Waltzing Will Trilogy""
column3: Haggerty rails against the ""pack of straight white honky quacks"" administering shock treatment to homosexuals—""they call it mental hygiene but I call it psychic rape
column4: he barks. Young men are beaten to death by police and sodomized by prison guards. ""Back in the Closet"" and ""Straight White Patterns"" detail the quiet torture of living within a straight white regime. And ""I Can't Shake The Stranger Out of You"" is a lovelorn take on gay cruising
column5: a pickup song that doubles as a lament. ""I reckon you're lookin for some neckin
column6: yes I do
column7: Haggerty sings
column8: inviting the song's subject to ""climb right up on into my manger
column9: but let me warn you about one small danger
column10: babe/ I can't shake the stranger out of you."" The song's tone is masterful—sexy
column11: sad
column12: and tender all at once.

column1: This is why
column2: despite the references to the struggles of the era
column3: Lavender Country never feels like a footnote
column4: historical or otherwise. Haggerty's songs  are resonant and wonderful
column5: folding pain into jokes and vice versa and exuding heartbreak and anger and wry good humor. You could never switch the gender pronouns on a song like ""Georgie Pie""
column6: where Haggerty beseeches a would-be lover who remains closeted
column7: and yet the song speaks to anyone who has ever felt the sting of a rebuke. Haggerty's playfully frank ""Your body odor lingers in my toes and in my nose and in my head"" on ""Come Out Singing"" will make you grin with recognition if you've ever picked up and smelled someone's t-shirt.

column1: Haggerty kept moving after Lavender Country
column2: running for local office twice and working in anti-police brutality and anti-apartheid movements. He is 70 years old now
column3: and often plays to senior centers (he mostly sticks to Hank Williams and Loretta Lynn). Lavender Country is a piece of his past
column4: one moment in a busy life spent in social justice. But
column5: any way it is viewed
column6: it's a tremendous feat
column7: a remarkable act of bravery and honesty as well as a statement on the universality of love and lust and belonging. Pop songs are limited vessels for social justice
column8: but the good ones do a remarkable job of teaching empathy
column9: a few minutes at a time
column10: and Haggerty's songs build a better world to live in
column11:
for forty minutes or so. There aren't many achievements more exalted than that.

There's little chance that listeners unfamilar with Tim Kinsella's work would refer to the angular
column2: incomprehensible melodies of Owls’ self-titled 2001 LP as “pop”
column3: and it’s even less likely that his lyrics
column4: which are cryptic
column5: piecemeal
column6: and pointed as a ransom note
column7: would strike them as “emo”.  Owls is Kinsella’s most accessible project
column8: though
column9: and it’s proven massively influential for countless self-identifying emo groups. Regardless
column10: the funny thing about Two
column11: the project's first release in nearly 13 years

column13: it might actually appeal more to newcomers.

column1: Two does sound like a natural progression for the project—“Four Works of Art…” is almost raga-like in its call-and-response drone
column2: not too dissimilar from Owls' opener “What Whorse You Wrote Id On”—but this is not a case of Owls picking up where they left off. Tim Kinsella actually hits notes (even the high ones) and
column3: yes
column4: the unwieldy song titles of Owls have been ditched as well. Mike Kinsella’s drumming is intuitive and fluid rather than fractured
column5: which allows bassist Sam Zurick to actually groove rather than forcing himself within the gnarled arpeggios of guitarist Victor Villareal. A colleague mentioned Real Estate upon hearing “Ancient Stars Seed…”
column6: and there are parts of Two that qualify as “indie rock”—the amiable amble of “The Lion…”
column7: “I’m Surprised…” righting itself into a genuine chorus. Whereas Owls required the kind of sweep-picking mastery outlined in Guitar World columns
column8: a beginner could play some of these songs on guitar.

column1: Unlike Owls—or almost anything that Tim Kinsella has been involved with—Two doesn’t need a preemptive warning about its “challenging” nature
column2: which might disappoint diehards who relish the challenge. Two lacks the explosive
column3: uncanny chemistry of Owls—nothing matches the unbridled exuberance of “Everyone Is My Friend”
column4: the fragile beauty of “Anyone Can Have A Good Time”
column5: the frisky rhythmic interplay of “I Want the Quiet Moments of a Party Girl”
column6: and there's not a lyric that hits as squarely as “It’s not impossible to think of you thinking of me.” Two sounds comparatively normalized
column7: both due to Owls’ own aesthetic softening and the dozens of bands who have co-opted this sound wholesale. It doesn't clearly demonstrate why people follow Kinsella’s every whim
column8: or why he spent nearly two decades being despised.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Two is a showcase for Kinsella as a frontman rather than a bandleader. He’s always been a tough sell
column3: even from the days of the relatively revered-by-consensus Cap’n Jazz
column4: but if you tried to engage with Joan of Arc album titles like In Rape Fantasy and Terror Sex We Trust (let alone the contents therein) and immediately determined
column5: “Yeah
column6: this isn’t for me
column7: ” no one would blame you. But in the past few years
column8: he’s found rejuvenation in old age similar to Mark Kozelek: simultaneously emboldened and embittered by a life in music and a resultant
column9: unflappable fanbase
column10: they’ve pretty much stopped caring about public perception
column11: which has resulted in some of their most honest and direct music.

column1: Two is filled with dozens of obtuse word jumbles that only make sense to Tim Kinsella and others that only make sense if you live in Chicago
column2: but there's also very private thoughts that cloak their own profundity. Two can variously scan as a sly critique of internet culture
column3: or aging within the indie rock community
column4: or just aging in general as an artist of limited earning potential. On “Why Oh Why…”
column5: Kinsella casually doles a withering dismissal of thinkpiece culture: “It’s cute how you assume your experience of the world is the world.” But as a cult artist
column6: he understands the appeal of that cloistered mindset: “Haven’t you ever been new somewhere?/ Haven’t you been envious of membership’s endlessness?”

column1: Two practically demands listening along with the lyrics sheet; this is high-concept
column2: cerebral stuff that's difficult to wrench any kind of visceral thrill from. Opener “Four Works of Art…” is an ingeniously crafted song both musically and lyrically
column3: but it lays out “A way of understanding this historical period” by letting you consider the commonalities between a car filled with trash
column4: Christopher Kubasik
column5: David Petraeus
column6: and a CCR tape—and yet it all rattles around your head in a way that’s more unsettling than the prodding done by Owls’ progeny. Even though Owls serve as a touchstone in 2014
column7:
there's still little that quite sounds like Two.

“Please note that this album runs just under 12 minutes
column2: ” the promo page for Tony Molina’s 12-song Dissed and Dismissed warns. “Just so you know.” It’s a worthwhile heads up: Hearing a Tony Molina song for the first time can be a bit disorienting. We’re used to the kind of power-pop he makes abiding by certain rules and forms—three chords
column3: three minutes
column4: a chorus that repeats enough times for first-time listeners to be singing along by the end—but the songs on Dissed and Dismissed slyly toy with expectations. Take “Nowhere to Go”
column5: the crunching slacker anthem that opens the album: Two sing-songy verses followed by a harmonized
column6: Thin Lizzy-esque solo that feels like a build-up to something… but actually just turns out to be a finale. Most of the songs (which range from 26 seconds to an epic minute-and-a-half) on the album proceed similarly. And yet
column7: somehow
column8: ”album” is the right word here. Dissed and Dismissed is more fully realized—and packs more of a punch—than plenty of records five times its length. Call it a half-a-half-hour of power.

column1: Molina’s been a staple in the San Francisco hardcore scene for years now—he’s played in the bands Ovens
column2: Caged Animal
column3: Dystrophy
column4: and Lifetime Problems
column5: to name a few—but his solo work lets his sharp pop instincts shine. Initially released in early 2013 as a tape on the small Bay Area label Melters
column6: Dissed and Dismissed became an instant cult favorite
column7: quickly selling out its first pressing. (Later in the year
column8: he also released the taut
column9: self-explanatory Six Tracks E.P. as a part of Matador’s Singles Going Home Alone Series.) Now
column10: to bide the time while he records a new full-length for Slumberland and in hopes of reaching a larger audience
column11: the label has reissued Dissed and Dismissed.

column1: Molina’s music combines Ted Leo’s taste in riffs
column2: Rivers Cuomo’s record collection circa “In the Garage”
column3: and Robert Pollard’s attention span. In one of its most subdued moments
column4: Dissed and Dismissed includes an acoustic cover of the early Guided By Voices song “Wandering Boy Poet”
column5: and it feels like an obvious nod to the kindred spirits who believe that a song that exceeds two minutes has long overstayed its welcome. There’s a crucial difference in the ethos of these artists
column6: though. The brevity of early Guided By Voices tracks conveyed a certain shrug
column7: Pollard’s demeanor always seeming to say
column8: “I got bored with this one before I could write an ending or mix it properly.” Brief as they are
column9: though
column10: every one of Molina’s songs sounds finished—these are complete thoughts. The melancholy “Can’t Believe” moves through a whole sunset of tonal hues; it’s the shortest song Teenage Fanclub never wrote. Another highlight
column11: “Don’t Come Back”
column12: begins as a pop-punk song
column13: ramps up to a bubblegum-hardcore breakdown
column14: and then ends in a blaze of of signal flare riffage. It works because it’s confident
column15: polished
column16: and deftly executed—not in spite of any of these facts. Combining near-comic concision and hi-fi production lets Molina have the best of both worlds: These songs have a slacker sensibility
column17: but they’re not afraid of occasional brushes with virtuosity.

column1: Dissed and Dismissed ends just before it starts to feel formulaic. Molina’s not reinventing the wheel here
column2:
but a guy who’s clever and/or self-deprecating enough to screenprint photos of Thin Lizzy on his “Tony Molina Tour 2013” t-shirts is probably not bothered by that. These songs are too satisfying to make their limits feel like gimmicks. Only time will tell if Molina pushes beyond the stylistic boundaries he’s created for himself here. His next record comes out later this year. Maybe it’ll hit the 15-minute mark.

"|19081.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19081-tony-molina-dissed-and-dismissed/|7.5|Lindsay Zoladz

Ire for the Seattle rapper Macklemore has obscured the thrift shopper’s pedigree. Before Macklemore was the poster boy for mainstream rap’s identity crisis
column2: he was just another inoffensive
column3: independent rapper
column4: with a facile flow
column5: a pleasant attitude and a real love for the genre of music he had chosen to work within. But give the guy a couple of catchy beats and suddenly he’s sprung to life as the vanilla oppressor of rap’s traditionalists
column6: too approachable by half and more than willing to lecture hip-hop on everything it’s doing wrong.

column1: Those irritated by Macklemore will probably not think any better of his fellow Seattle resident Grieves
column2: the cosmetic similarities between the two former collaborators actually doing a disservice to the former’s skills as a rapper. Both artists do share a jones for sentimental subject matter
column3: rhyming with a down-to-earth demeanor that can border on self-congratulatory. Grieves
column4: born Benjamin Laub
column5: also sings his own hooks
column6: and the piano-heavy beats he’s particular to place him somewhere between Slug and Jason Mraz on the musical spectrum.

column1: Winter and the Wolves is Grieves’ fourth album
column2: promoted
column3: like a kind of musical companion to the Liam Neeson movie <i>The Gray
column4: as being “about the instinctual fight for survival.” That struggle mostly makes itself known through reflective songs about the rapper’s life
column5: including a batch concerned with the events of childhood and a now-defunct relationship. Laub is an intensely honest songwriter and the album is shot through with raw emotion
column6: even when the subject in question seems innocuous.

column1: Grieves has a gift for melody and his best songs rise above their subject matter with catchy hooks and amiable
column2: keyboard and guitar-laden production courtesy of San Jose’s B. Lewis.  “Astronauts""
column3: a song about the losses that come with maturity
column4: has a very sticky chorus. “Kidding Me""
column5: while it has many of the self-pitying qualities that hurt Laub’s songs about relationships
column6: has a soulful beat and a syrupy Mayer Hawthorne-esque hook.  But both songs are plagued by the unshakeable self-importance that dogs the record
column7: with lines like “you don’t have to be a kid to believe or see potential in a pile of leaves.” There’s no doubt that Grieves believes in the things that he’s rapping about; the problem is that he doesn’t seem to have any kind of self-awareness or sense of humor in doing so.

column1: What is it about earnestness that can seem so irksome? To start
column2: in a genre built on coded language and slang
column3: the relative approachability of Grieves’ music feels facile
column4: his lyrics and production simple in a genre that has historically prized complexity.  Add that to the fact that Grieves is a passable technical rapper
column5: rather than a particularly compelling one
column6: prone to rattling off lines like “I’ve been a bad seed ever since the ovaries” and you’re not left with much to sink your teeth into. The album is straightforward
column7: but often so much so that it can seem as if there’s nothing below the surface.

column1: Grieves can be tough to bear when he’s cheerful
column2: but he’s far worse when upset.  The break-up song “Over You” is the prototypical lament of the nice guy done wrong. I couldn’t help but compare the song to Fiona Apple’s “Werewolf""
column3: a track that also uses a series of metaphors to explore a break-up; each comparison Apple makes seems representative of the actual complexity of a real relationship. By contrast
column4: Laub’s most interesting move is the final line
column5: “I just don’t know how to get over you
column6: ” presented like a Shyamalan twist
column7: as if we weren’t expected to recognize the bitterness that the song is basted in.

column1: The blandness of the subject matter with which Grieves works makes his songs broadly relatable: it’s easy to imagine listeners identifying with the feelings he expresses on Winter and the Wolves
column2: especially given that a large percentage of the songs are legitimately catchy. Rap like this has always existed and
column3: again
column4: it's largely inoffensive—but when it becomes popular
column5: it threatens to dislodge more complicated music. Macklemore’s success sets a precedent: it will not be shocking if one of Grieves’ new songs makes it to radio playlists. Hip-hop has traditionally been a forward-thinking space
column6: where either lyricists or producers can explore difficult musical territory. The success of music that does not make use of the genre in this way
column7:
threatens rap’s progressive identity above anything else.

Liars have been one of the 21st century’s most confounding and consistent bands because they make two kinds of albums: ones where they don’t know what they’re doing
column4: and ones where they’ve figured it out. Since arriving in 2001 as inside operatives bent on dance-punk’s destruction
column5: their career has alternated bizarre and divisive left turns with records that vindicated their artistic vision. This risk/reward dynamic is even more pronounced with the release of their seventh album
column6: Mess. The sleek contours of 2012’s WIXIW betrayed Liars’ self-admission that they were learning how to use computers and sequencers on the fly
column7: downplaying the extreme shift from the caveman garage rock and scabrous art-punk of Liars and Sisterworld. And now Mess feels like Liars getting their driver’s license after fumbling with a learner’s permit—you can have a lot more fun with this machinery once you stop worrying about totaling the thing.

column1: If you didn’t care for WIXIW’s muted introspection
column2: Mess is a welcome counterpoint; the dance-punk throwback “Brats” was tacked onto WIXIW seemingly as a random addendum
column3: but Liars have a way of using late-album cuts as foreshadowing. And in fact Mess is the first Liars album that could be given a “dance-” hyphenate since their debut. As with They Threw Us All in a Trench and Stuck a Monument on Top
column4: it’s physical
column5: bodymoving music for people who don’t have much interest in proper dance music. A pitch-shifted Angus Andrew begins Mess demanding to be depantsed (as well as “eat my socks”)
column6: and after the pummeling beat of “Mask Maker” drops
column7: it could be heard as an alternate history
column8: one in which Liars continued on the path of electroclash subversives.

column1: Liars have never been futurists
column2: and a curious byproduct of their electronic shift is how it’s made them strangely retro. Their previous record’s clicks and whirs hearkened back to early 2000s IDM and lap-pop such as the Notwist and Dntel
column3: where the first half of Mess takes its cues from the festival-EDM that was thoroughly trendpieced around the time of WIXIW—Hoovering bass
column4: crowd-pleasing drops
column5: air raid synth lines. Mess bangs from the start
column6: albeit in a way that tends to flatten out the dynamics
column7: as the introductory duo of “Mask Masker” and “Vox Tuned D.E.D.” could be mistaken for an eight-minute suite
column8: a fairly predictable means of expressing their past physicality in an electronic setting. The relatively quieter moments are where Liars show their newfound confidence and instrumental facility: an organ break reminiscent of OutKast’s
column9: d.cGU"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Ghettomusick” pierces through “Pro Anti Anti”
column10: while the frazzled
column11: free-time “Can’t Hear Well” hints towards the second half’s turn towards more abstract composition.

column1: Mess turns out to be an admirably diverse album that foregrounds the big-beat material: “Darkslide” and “Boyzone” find Liars imposing their will on electronic music rather than the other way around
column2: the tribal rhythms and perverted vocals of Drum’s Not Dead updated with fancier software. The closers “Perpetual Village” and “Left Speaker Blown” actually revisit the unsettling atmosphere of They Were Wrong So We Drowned and contain some of Andrew’s most evocative lyrics if you can manage to suss them out. But at a combined 16 minutes of slow-moving murk and half-illegible
column3: half-inaudible vocals
column4: they’re more exciting as clues towards speculating Liars’ next move than they are in the present moment.

column1: Which at least cuts against the narrative that Mess is a fully-realized mission statement; Andrew confessed to being riddled with spiritual and artistic doubt throughout WIXIW
column2: but Mess is far more dilettantish and can register as being every bit as cynical as the murderous
column3: anti-Los Angeles screed Sisterworld. At points
column4: Andrew confesses “I am old/ Endless monotony dulls all alternatives/ Life is long
column5: way too long” and “I heard the wild world is wicked/ And the modern one is out for blood.”

column1: Seven albums in
column2: the respectable qualities of Liars’ music have been well-documented
column3: but it’s worth asking: do they make moving
column4: ingratiating music or simply admirable art? Does anything on Mess have the capacity to inspire emotional investment?  Does any of it stick with you? Or
column5: more importantly
column6: where is the Liars-ness in Mess? Mostly
column7: it comes from Andrew’s voice
column8: still intimidating in its lowest registers and frightening when given to wraith-like moans; we get both modes during obvious highlight “Mess On a Mission”.  But it’s been 10 years since Liars were notoriously and short-sightedly called “unlistenable” by major publications. In 2014
column9: Mess might be called ""challenging"" out of habit
column10: but is anything here capable of scaring off the squares?

column1: In fact
column2: Mess can sound pretty tame compared to electronic acts which can be linked to their ultra-percussive
column3: post-punk aesthetics such as Factory Floor or Fuck Buttons. As enjoyable as it can be
column4: Mess is a centrist record from a band without a lot of centrist strengths and appreciating it can feel like a symbolic gesture: it’s easy to support a band who’s achieved their level of success while making conceivably challenging music. In other words
column5:
it’s easy to admire because Liars are easy to admire.

After the kind of year Kevin Gates had in 2013—finally signing with a major label when he inked a deal with Atlantic Records
column2: releasing two critically-acclaimed mixtapes
column3: becoming a father for the second time—you might think that he'd be in a better mood. This
column4: however
column5: would be a fundamental misunderstanding of the Baton Rouge rapper. Although his unflinching
column6: often brutal dope-boy tales can find him struggling against his naturally pessimistic impulses
column7: Gates' default mode is one of squinty-eyed suspicion
column8: and the world he inhabits in his music is one where human connection only leads to betrayal and trust is something that gets you killed. But even with his Atlantic debut looming somewhere on the horizon and a higher profile than he's ever enjoyed
column9: Gates sounds unsatisfied and more than a little paranoid on By Any Means
column10: his third release in just over a year.

column1: This isn't to say his latest project—or Gates's music in general—is a bummer. As with his previous two releases
column2: By Any Means is packed with uptempo anthems and chest-pumping bravado
column3: the only difference being that here the beats are both a little bigger and have more of a sheen to them. The album splits the difference between the radio-friendly melodicism of The Luca Brasi Story and the technical experimentation of Stranger Than Fiction
column4: inching closer to the mainstream rap radio that one imagines is Gates' ultimate goal. The production still prioritizes the kind of lower frequencies that could level buildings
column5: and it's not afraid to take the sounds usually found at the fringes of trap beats and make them the focus. Whether it's the cathedral organs of ""Arm and Hammer"" courtesy of the Runners and the Monarch or the eerie MIDI blues backdrop that Dun Deal provides for bitter kiss-off ""Stop Lyin'""
column6: Gates tends to select tracks just to the left of the kind of beats other rappers would typically choose from the same producers
column7: and it gives his music the advantage of sounding familiar but fresh at the same time.

column1: That said
column2: Gates could rap over boilerplate trap beats and he'd still manage to put his personal spin on them. Few rappers today as using their voices as well as Gates does; he's got an instinctive grasp on when to slip from his usual melodic cadence into a balled-fist croak that sounds like he took a cheese grater to his vocal chords. He pulls out this trick on ""Homicide""
column3: a harrowing tale in which he exacts revenge after a botched job leaves his friend murdered and Gates in the hospital.

column1: Gates' ability to say one thing with his lyrics and another with his voice has always been one of his greatest strengths. He can puff his chest out while simultaneously undercutting a boast
column2: and this works especially well on an album that finds him ostensibly closer to his goals but somehow even more paranoid and isolated
column3: caught somewhere between sheer disbelief that he's even made it this far (""Can't Make This Up"") and an overwhelming suspicion it's too good to be true
column4: especially for someone who knows himself well enough to know that the man he used to be is always lurking around the corner. ""Be cool
column5: you must want to see me incarcerated"" he raps on ""Keep Fucking With Me""
column6: but over the course of By Any Means
column7: you get the feeling that Gates' is as worried about his own self-destructive tendencies as he is any external forces out to get him. With the exception of ""Movie""
column8: an absolutely heartwarming account of the birth of his children
column9: Gates rarely sounds as if he's enjoying his recent success
column10: even while boasting about driving around in cars he once only saw on the big screen; you can tell he's trying
column11: but relaxing is still foreign to someone like him.

column1: On the flip side of ""Movie"" is ""Posed to Be in Love""
column2: in which Gates narrates beating his girlfriend after discovering that she cheated on him while he was in prison. At best
column3: the track can be viewed as an ""All of the Lights""-style exploration of male rage and domestic violence; at worst
column4: it comes across like a frightening glimpse into Gates' misogynist attitude towards women
column5: which has reared its head before but never as brazenly as it does here. It's the kind of track that makes it obvious that an Atlantic sign-off wasn't required
column6: as it's the kind of song they'd be terrified that an artist of theirs—one who sells himself as much the lothario as he does the hustler—was recording. Then again
column7: Gates has never been one shy away from exposing the worst parts of his psyche
column8: even if it's as disturbing as it is on ""Posed to Be in Love"".

column1: There's also a sense that Gates is holding back somewhat. There are only a few guests
column2: the biggest being 2 Chainz
column3: who sounds like he's glancing at his watch while contributing a verse and the chorus to ""Bet I'm on It"". It's likely that Gates is saving them for the future rather than using up that major label budget now
column4: but he doesn't really need them anyways—he's a fascinating persona all on his own. With By All Means he completes a three-release run that's as solid as any in recent memory
column5:
even if the answer to the question of whether he has another gear in him remains unanswered for the time being.

Constraints of time and place are integral to the music made by Pan Sonic
column3: the Finnish noise duo who split in 2010. In 2001
column4: following the release of Aaltopiiri
column5: the pair encouraged people to write and suggest tour locations to them
column6: with the most appealing and/or unusual destinations chosen for a subsequent set of dates. This album for the Kvitnu label
column7: a live effort recorded in 2009 in Kyiv in the Ukraine
column8: is impossible to frame without thinking about the impending meltdown of both band and country
column9: cloaking Oksastus in an apocalyptic backdrop. It's not clear yet if this marks a return to active duty by Pan Sonic
column10: but this is more than a mere curio released to mark the final days of the band. Instead
column11: it's a meticulously recorded document
column12: laced with all the brutality and turmoil of their prior recordings
column13: and an anything-could-happen looseness that flows out of their improvisatory approach.

column1: Oksastus straddles a rich divide—its title is a Finnish word that can either mean the process of grafting or the cultivation of plants. Pan Sonic music never really feels like a graft
column2: but it does take work to get inside it
column3: to dig through the overlapping walls of noise to get to its cold heart. There's no sense of journey involved; instead it can be like peering into a cement mixer and watching new shapes appear and vanish inside its churn. Stand there long enough and even the smallest of movements can take on a significance greater than the infinitesimal change seen by the naked eye. On ""5'31"" (titles are replaced by runtimes throughout) a great loop of noise turns lethargically through its center as familiarly piercing electronics vye with a leaden undertow. Even as it approaches the point of white-out there's a strong sense of being trapped in time
column4: lost in its mechanical engulf.

column1: Where Pan Sonic succeed in their work
column2: both here and elsewhere
column3: is in the subtle bridging of discipline and the impromptu. They're somewhere between chaos and order
column4: setting out rigid backbones to tracks
column5: some of which harken back to mechanized sounds that mirror the earliest drum machines or synthesized drums. From there it resembles a battle between ship and wave
column6: with both sides winning out at various junctures. Their use of repetition was chiseled down to a fine art by this point
column7: and listening to them use it on a track such as the sprawling ""11'03"" is a fascinating experience—this isn't repetition to get lost in
column8: to transport you away. It's there to drag you in
column9: to keep you alert. It's the direct opposite of krautrock dreams or techno fantasias
column10: even though roots of those genres can be found across Pan Sonic's output. Instead this is a nightmarish vision of the everyday
column11: a stark and arresting vision of existence that spews out humanity's ugliness across a mixing board and a mesh of wires.

column1: It's when control bears down a little too hard that this collection loses focus. On ""5'42"" they're phoning in darkness
column2: sometimes resembling the hordes of John Carpenter clones that would thunder through the gates a year or two after this show was recorded. Occasionally a super-high frequency cuts through the gloom
column3: such as on the opening of ""17'28"" or on the close of the final track
column4: the almost comically clonk-like Sweet Exorcist clone ""5'41"". It's something Pan Sonic were known for—wrapping piercing textures in a maelstrom of noise. But here
column5: in a work that bears an air of finality
column6: even becoming definitive at times
column7: it adds an air of sentimentality to Oksastus
column8: especially when that singular tone trails off into silence at the record's close. Affection isn't an emotion usually attached to this band
column9: but here
column10: engulfed by thoughts that they might not return again
column11:
there's something moving in hearing that eardrum-shattering note unspool for one last time.

column6: and grime into its sound
column7: Dutch E Germ almost entirely removes rock from the equation
column8: with DeWit applying his psychedelic filter directly to various forms of bass music. And where his work with GGD was often masked behind a thick sonic haze
column9: IN.RAK.DUST has a bracing hi-fi clarity to its booms and crackles.

column1: What hasn’t changed is DeWit’s ambitious range of influences—IN.RAK.DUST is rooted in hip-hop and house but incorporates everything from trap rap to something that sounds like a Bollywood ballad with dozens of stops in between—and his gift for assembling them into pleasingly weird and intensely trippy new forms. Losing the blurry analog noise elements of GGD’s sound hasn’t affected DeWit’s ability to impart his recordings with a shimmering
column2: mushroomy aura
column3: and he’s become a master of transforming electronic glitches into 21st century psychedelia
column4: as he did with the flickering
column5: stroboscopic meltdown of a vocal sample from “IntroXXXWar” (originally released as “HBA War”) that Kanye lifted for the intro to “New Slaves”. He also remains conscientious about maintaining an impressively accessible vibe even when he goes far out
column6: and the album’s danceable even at its most experimental moments.

column1: With IN.RAK.DUST
column2: DeWit’s accomplished what seems to have been his goal for years: the creation of a new kind of dub
column3: a worthy spiritual descendent to the music that emanated out of Studio One and the Black Ark back in the day while sounding almost nothing like it. Too many of dub’s progeny have borrowed its sonic palette but not its philosophy of mad technological experimentation
column4: which was the whole point of the style. Even when he’s creating a track from scratch it still feels like an assemblage put together from disparate parts—a house beat
column5: a reggae bassline
column6: a synth lead picked up from a Southern rap song—that just happen to fit together perfectly. He also knows that gear sometimes sounds best when used in unintended ways
column7: and IN.RAK.DUST is full of off-label programming
column8: and electronics pushed into glitchy places they weren’t designed for. It’s easily one of the most technically daring and impressively produced albums of the year so far.

column1: One other crucial thing that DeWit’s music has in common with dub is that even at its most haywire it remains spiritually centered
column2: although that’s not necessarily apparent. The album doesn’t have any one obviously prescribed use—you can dance to it as easily as you can choreograph a runway show to it
column3: or you could just use it as a soundtrack for getting high. My favorite way to listen to IN.RAK.DUST is to put on my best and bassiest headphones and experience it while I travel around the city. In DeWit’s hands
column4: even the most crowded subway becomes serene and blissful
column5:
and the most mundane task deeply cosmic.

Ohio has produced so many good garage and post-punk bands in the past few decades
column2: picking a list of the best would be close to impossible. But one thing’s certain: Lamont “Bim” Thomas would show up a lot. He’s played drums in V-3
column3: Bassholes
column4: the Unholy Two
column5: This Moment in Black History
column6: and Puffy Aerolas; the latter two still enlist his services regularly. But his most important project is turning out to be one he does on his own. In just three years he’s cranked out three albums and a bunch of EPs and singles as Obnox
column7: pouring his experiences
column8: influences
column9: and considerable energies into burning-red noise-punk blasts.

column1: Obnox has been prolific because Thomas works quickly. His 2011 debut I’m Bleeding Now was recorded on his own four-track in a week
column2: and subsequent releasess have followed suit. (""I just bang it out fast
column3: like the record business used to be
column4: ” he once said.) I’d bet it didn’t take him a ton of time to put together Louder Space either
column5: but there was one significant difference in the way it was made: as the title implies
column6: Thomas recorded for the first time in a studio
column7: Columbus’ legendary Musicol.

column1: The timing of this move was perfect
column2: as Thomas’ songs have gotten wider and deeper
column3: and thus ripe for being rendered in finer detail. In other words
column4: he was ready for his close-up. But sharper clarity <span>doesn’t lessen the abrasive thrust of Obnox’s attack. He’s still painting in
column5: as he describes it
column6: “sheets of rhythm
column7: ” and Louder Space is piled high with them. Those layers are even more powerful when you can sift through them carefully. Part of the fun of listening to Obnox in higher-res is how easy it is to focus on a blazing guitar line here or a detonating drum beat there
column8: without losing sight of Thomas’ forest-sized din.

column1: That din is more surprise-filled than before
column2: due to Thomas exploring more of his musical obsessions. Louder Space is based in punk rock
column3: but he continually leaps from that center toward less expected modes. So on “Red I”
column4: soulful horns are buried under guitar fuzz; on “Molecule”
column5: chopped-up metal chords buttress a chant; and on “Raindrops”
column6: grunge riffs slide under sugared vocals. Most noticeably
column7: Thomas’ love for hip-hop and R&B shines through all the buzzing churn. The wiry guitar loop of “How to Rob (The Punk Years)” could circle a Public Enemy tune
column8: while “Bitch! Get Money!” hides a funk saunter inside its frantic amp-bleed. There’s even a gospel tint to the album’s only slow song
column9: a near-ballad bluntly titled “Feeling Real Black Today.”

column1: Thomas’ style-melding is so smooth
column2: it gives Louder Space a sheen of confidence. His music has never exactly been shy
column3: but here he sounds like he knows he’s reached a new plane and isn’t afraid to say so. “You never find a fuckin’ ounce of fat on me!” he insists at one point; later
column4: he chants posi-mantras in “Mecca Son Shine”—“Gotta chase my own glory/ Gotta write my own story/ Gotta grind my own dollars/ Gotta solve my own problems”—as if his brain is pumping iron. His throat does calisthenics too: Thomas jumps his voice through hoops
column5: crooning
column6: rapping
column7: and ranting in perpetual call-and-response with himself.

column1: All of this may make Louder Space sound like brazen boasting
column2: and at times it is. But Thomas’ boldness is more about assured self-confidence—more about belief in his own sonic mission—than vain puffing of feathers. And besides
column3: he's earned the right to stick out his chest a bit. Louder Space transcends not only his previous work
column4:
but much of the scene that he’s ensconced in. That makes it something worth bragging about.

He’s a festival-circuit megastar who’s already put an indelible sonic imprint on the early stretch of this decade
column4: but it still feels like Sonny Moore got a raw deal. Sure
column5: the fact Skrillex became the face of dubstep did plenty to rile the “purists
column6: ” but the Tempa–12“-hoarder set wasn’t responsible for reducing an unsubtle but genuinely adventurous and accessibly weird artist to a living meme. Outlets that eyerolled at first-wave dubstep as too niche belatedly rushed to hail Skrillex as the person who could—hallelujah!—finally make electronic music that you could mosh to and glibly compare to punk-fuckin’-rawk. By the beginning of this year
column7: it was starting to feel like the reduction of his music’s endorphin-explosion dynamics to a ”wait for the drop"" punchline would drain all the giddiness out of Skrillex’s catalogue before he even got around to a full-length debut.

column1: But at the end of the day
column2: all the thinkpieces about corporate rave and pop crossover and subgenre snobbery weren’t enough to obscure just how open Skrillex has been to switching his game up. You could call it from the word go: 2010’s My Name Is Skrillex delivered sugar-high jolts of French Touch that integrated Todd Edwards-style chopped-vocal fusillades into Justice-style snarl-house. And while the trademark mechano-industrial shivers and alarms in his subsequent work sound like chaotic ADD noise on the surface
column3: it’s also frenetically unpredictable and musically fun in a way not commonly heard since the crab-scratch heyday of super-advanced turntablism. (Listen to Mix Master Mike’s Napalm Rockets—released a few months before My Name Is Skrillex—for a great if probably unexpected precedent.) No matter that he learned about IDM when Korn gave Aphex Twin props on TRL; the point is that Skrillex decided he wouldn’t stop learning. And yet that’s why Recess is confounding: it hints at places Skrillex could take his sound
column4: but doesn’t feel ready to commit to any of them.

column1: What expectation-meeting wub-wub stuff there is on this album is diverting and enjoyable
column2: even if it feels obligatory in the context of this album's attempt at breadth. I mean
column3: the leadoff cut is called “All Is Fair in Love and Brostep”—the man clearly knows the joke and is savvy enough to turn it into a “yes
column4: and” improv sketch. That he gives the opening-track spotlight to a guest spot by the Ragga Twins—the MCs whose early 1990s singles made them connoisseur go-tos and pivotal figures in the early UK rave and jungle scene—points to a lineage that his detractors rarely gave him credit for. And the track is fittingly rugged—nothing that’ll have dubstep aficionados forgetting the Bug anytime soon
column5: but it’s easy to hear the fundamental strength of his basslines and the nuanced timing of percussion. Between “All Is Fair”
column6: the more explicitly dancehall-informed Ragga Twins teamup “Ragga Bomb”
column7: and the crowdpleasing “Try It Out” (built alongside Owsla signee Alvin Risk)
column8: Skrillex proves adept at going beyond the build-drop-build-drop Pavlov response to something a bit more dynamic and playful.

column1: But the broader sound is also pretty familiar at this point
column2: an issue that he’s aimed to confront with the album’s forays into whatever-works eclecticism. Sometimes the results are at least fascinatingly off-kilter. “Doompy Poomp” is the biggest wait-what? moment on the album
column3: a galumphing kind of schaffel/wonky/IDM hydra that’s all candy-colored grotesque. “Fuck That” dials back the bass a bit to something more in line with the distant swells of circa-02 Horsepower Productions sides
column4: wraps his sensibilities around a beat more befitting of contemporary bass music
column5: and builds the big ramp-up moment towards a switched-up version of the rhythm that bristles with negative space. And “Fire Away” returns to the shallow-Burial shot at spacious UK garage that he tried out on ""Leaving""
column6: a tolerable effort that’s upended by jarringly twee melodic accents and the grating wail of singer Kid Harpoon.

column1: What’s worrying is the stuff that seems to sidestep his oddball ADD energy completely. Even if brostep is pop these days
column2: it’s at least pop in a polarizingly abrasive sense; his maneuvers towards other more accessible sounds not only sound less bracing but feel pulled out of his hands. Teaming up with Diplo and getting K-pop superstars G-Dragon (Big Bang) and CL (2NE1) is an inspired move in theory
column3: but “Dirty Vibe” sounds so dominated by familiar Southern bounce and trap tropes that it feels like Skrillex is taking a smoke break and letting Mad Decent take over for a bit. The title track is even more confused—Fatman Scoop and Passion Pit’s Michael Angelakos together at… last?—with pseudo-Sleigh Bells pep rally bluster and bang-on-a-PVC-pipe moombahton that plays like decline-era big beat. And “Coast Is Clear” is jazzed-up d’n’b that keeps tripping over its own snares
column4: with Chance the Rapper’s voice the closest there is to an element of wavering chaos; shame his appearance is little more than a repeated if extended hook. (At least the machine-gun “doyouwannafuck
column5: doyouwannafuck
column6: doyouwannafuck” refrain has staying power.)

column1: The progression from early singles to first album isn’t nearly the same arc as it was just 10 years ago
column2: but it’s still weird that the first full-length showcase for Skrillex as self-contained album artist feels more like a transitional record than a debut that plays to his strengths. It’s tempting to suggest he’s ahead of the curve when it comes to the eventuality of the sound he popularized getting stale
column3: but he probably has his own reasons for tweaking
column4: sanding down
column5: subduing
column6: or otherwise retooling the parameters for what could be considered his signature aesthetic. If it points his fanbase towards another set of sounds to appreciate
column7: it could be at least somewhat worth it. But more of these half measures
column8:
and they might just wind up deciding to listening to someone else entirely.

In late 2011
column2: a handful of instrumental tracks under the account name Evian Christ showed up on YouTube. A random
column3: anonymous person putting music online is something that happens thousands of times a day
column4: but Evian Christ’s productions got around
column5: quickly
column6: on the strength of “Who is this?” raves from publications like Dummy and a number of blogs. Returning to them more than two years later
column7: these early tracks
column8: especially the startling and forceful “Fuck It None of Y’all Don’t Rap”
column9: hinted at serious potential
column10: even if they didn’t quite congeal into a distinctive voice. But one important person heard something in them: Kanye West used some of Evian Christ’s music to construct “I’m in It” from Yeezus
column11: and suddenly
column12: the kid who posted beats to YouTube had a hand in one of the most sonically adventurous records of the year.

column1: Shortly after that initial burst of interest
column2: Evian Christ (real name: Joshua Leary) signed to Tri Angle
column3: who assembled his early tracks onto an EP. The label was the logical home for his music in part because his path was similar to that of Tri Angle’s Clams Casino. But while Clams Casino sent his tracks to rappers and only later presented himself as an instrumental auteur
column4: Evian Christ
column5: despite the contribution to Yeezus
column6: has been perceived more as producer of standalone electronic tracks. The Waterfall EP
column7: his first release of new music constructed while people actually know who he is
column8: finds him straddling the worlds of the functional collaborative production and discrete statement.

column1: What’s most striking about Waterfall
column2: hearing it next to those earliest tracks
column3: is how much bigger his music has become. The early tracks eventually collected on the Kings and Them were nimble and spacious
column4: touching on genres like two-step that allow for tricky stop-start programming. From Waterfall’s opening “Salt Carousel” forward
column5: it’s clear that Leary is trying to rattle all the way back to the cheap seats. The is essentially big-stage EDM
column6: with colossal surges of bass and thick
column7: serrated synth lines evocative of the maximalism of TNGHT and Hudson Mohawke. It’s the type of music that makes most sense at massive volume
column8: with builds and drops whose meaning becomes clear only when the sound is completely overwhelming. And in terms of sound design and construction
column9: Waterfall has much to admire. The music is bursting with color and the surges are palpable
column10: and you can almost see the legions of head-banging festival-goers whenever tracks hit a big peak.

column1: The problem is that the four tracks here have a total of about three ideas. Three well executed ideas
column2: no doubt
column3: but it’s still not enough to make the record feel like a complete experience. Once you’ve heard one track—and each is in its own way a banger—you’ve heard all four. So when experienced outside of the massive soundsystem and communal experience of a live event
column4: Waterfall comes over as something closer to a beat tape—when listening to it
column5: I even find myself unconsciously inserting the ghost of a Danny Brown verse
column6: something to transform the Grade-A sonics into a track with an arc and some tension
column7: a piece of music with a few surprises or twists. Impressive as it can be in small doses
column8: Waterfall as a whole plows ahead like a WWI-era tank
column9:
heavy and lumbering and powerful but pretty much limited to a single direction.

Orchestral works by rock stars were once accorded the same level of basic dignity as Baby Mozart compilations or ""Classical Relaxation"" checkout counter CDs: They were the classical-music industry's green-mile walks
column2: grist for the mill. This handsomely appointed Deutsche Grammophon release of recordings by Bryce Dessner
column3: guitarist for the National
column4: and Jonny Greenwood
column5: guitarist for Radiohead
column6: is one sign
column7: among many
column8: of shifting cultural tides. ""Rock star"" is an altogether more genteel occupation in this century than it was in the last—Dessner and Greenwood in particular enjoy a middlebrow cultural cachet somewhere between ""TED Fellow"" and ""HBO show runner."" And the classical music industry is relieved to have modern cultural ambassadors that won't make them feel foolish or craven.

column1: Dessner and Greenwood have thus built up enviable composing careers for themselves. Their works are programmed by tony
column2: first-class institutions
column3: and positioned next to other contemporary composers
column4: not consigned to the Friday-night concert that serves drinks. Greenwood has a head start on Dessner—his suite for There Will Be Blood
column5: from 2007
column6: enjoys a robust performance life and Popcorn Superhet Receiver
column7: from which portions of this work were taken has been recorded already. Dessner
column8: however
column9: is catching up; last year
column10: none other than the Kronos Quartet devoted a full album to his compositions. Now
column11: whenever a prominent contemporary music festival is scheduled—such as this spring's Big Ears Festival in Knoxville
column12: which also features Wilco drummer Glenn Kotche—Dessner and Greenwood are included.

column1: It helps that their compositions do as much work as their names. Greenwood's There Will Be Blood suite is foreboding and inky-black
column2: a work whose extended quotes of Penderecki and Ligeti do nothing to obscure the thumbprint of Greenwood's sensibility. The leaping
column3: fiendish
column4: cello line will forever be associated with Daniel Plainview
column5: and the glinting blue eyes in Daniel Day-Lewis's soot-covered face as he proclaims his disgust for  ""these...people."" The slow-fall-in-free-space glissandi that punctuate the ""Henry Plainview"" movement
column6: the most obvious Ligeti touch
column7: break open into plangent
column8: lovely string writing
column9: a push-pull between furtive remorse and throbbing evil keeps the piece from curdling.

column1: Dessner's surprisingly mordant sensibility is a match for Greenwood's. On his ""St. Carolyn By the Sea""
column2: moaning tremolos pass like a fever chill through the orchestra and show up in the guitars a few minutes later
column3: goose flesh prickling the music's surface. There are guitars in the work
column4: but they are twinkling and demure
column5: and often feel like they are murmuring to quiet the upheaval of the shuddering beast that is the full orchestra. The work builds to a martial tattoo of an ending and cuts off
column6: leaving its sharp outline visible in our minds.

column1: Dessner's ear for string writing is particularly rich. The chords that move through the beginning of ""Lachrimae"" carry some Barber in their DNA
column2: an impression that gets upset later when a cello bows out hoarse-voiced harmonics high up near the bridge. ""Raphael""
column3: builds from wispy tendrils of sound into a super-saturated moment of full orchestral color
column4: a blazing sunrise burning fog off of a river. The work stretches majestically over 17 minutes
column5: maintaining a slow build that might feel familiar to the muscle-memories of post-rock fans. It is glacial
column6: patiently ecstatic
column7:
and further evidence that Dessner's vision could support some large-scale works. Whoever wants to commission his first symphony would probably be rewarded with something fantastic.

David Monks rarely sees further than his next crush
column3: and the four years since Tokyo Police Club's last album have given their frontman ample time to wonder if there’s anyone out there for him. “Enough to fill a room? Enough to fill a mall?” he asks rhetorically on “Argentina (Pts.
column4: I
column5: II
column6: III)”
column7: the leadoff track from the Canadian quartet’s third LP Forcefield. Well
column8: we can start out by narrowing it down to an estimate of 300
column9: 000. That’s the maximum number of people who could own both the Strokes’ First Impressions of Earth and Weezer’s The Green Album. Monks joked about how the much-maligned “Juicebox” and “Hash Pipe” were spiritual guides for the band during the creation of Forcefield
column10: where they’d play “rock riffs” that would previously be laughed out of the room. Only this time
column11: they admitted “wait a minute
column12: these are good and fun.” His point seems to be that you don’t even have to like those much-maligned songs. You just have to believe that it's not necessarily a bad idea when bands known for taut
column13: hooky laments about girl problems grab the Gibson SG from the Guitar Center wall and let it rip. Forcefield is very much good and fun when it sticks to the theoretical appeal of Monks’ concept. There are just as many times when it hits the unfortunate
column14: actual mark.

column1: The title of Forcefield makes Tokyo Police Club’s intentions abundantly clear; Monks says it reflects the band shutting out the countless microtrends that came and went during the curious
column2: long silence following 2010’s light heavyweight Champ. Kudos to Tokyo Police Club for giving up any sort of notion that they represent “cool” indie rock
column3: but it’s unnecessary; though they were viewed as a bridge from the New Rock Revolution into the crapshoot of mid-00s blog-rock
column4: neither Elephant Shell nor Champ sounded of a particular moment
column5: which made them easy to overlook.

column1: But it’s also a misleading title. In actuality
column2: Forcefield is the only Tokyo Police Club album that appears to be in tune with prevailing trends. In case you haven’t realized it yet
column3: indie rock is basically pop now and Tokyo Police Club seem energized by not having to pretend like their candy hearts don’t pump Kool-Aid. The bubblegum alt-glam of “Hot Tonight” should be blasting out of Stacy’s mom’s minivan. “Toy Guns” outsources the shrugging
column4: shuffling beat of its chiming chorus from Avril Lavigne’s “Complicated.” “Through the Wire” bears no similarity whatsoever to the Kanye West classic
column5: but its rhythm swings to the same beat as that other song about the wire.

column1: Befitting its mostly compact-disc era influences
column2: the sound of Forcefield is flat
column3: shiny
column4: spotless and unyielding—a naturally artificial production shift as recording duties were passed from Chris Zane (who helmed similarly snappy records from Passion Pit and Friendly Fires) to Doug Boehm
column5: an engineer on Miley Cyrus and Fall Out Boy LPs. Tokyo Police Club’s commitment is admirable—this a pop album
column6: produced like pop and structured to grant instant gratification. And yet
column7: this presentation throws the flaws of Tokyo Police Club’s dullest songs into sharp relief.

column1: As Monks promised
column2: there are rock riffs—the one from “Tunnel Vision” is situated somewhere between Angus Young and Satch’s “Summer Song”
column3: while the windmilled power of “Gonna Be Ready” is a surprising show of brute force. And there are choruses
column4: good ones too
column5: absolute wonders in isolation. But whereas previous Tokyo Police Club albums were economical
column6: cramming the greatest number of melodies into the smallest spaces
column7: the craftsmanship of Forcefield is kinda shoddy and cheap. “Gonna Be Ready” and “Miserable” in particular are done in by dawdling
column8: underwritten verses that make the hooks feel like prizes buried in stale
column9: glazed Cracker Jack. Yeah
column10: “don’t bore us
column11: get to the chorus” and all
column12: but within the context of three-minute pop songs
column13: 30 seconds is a lot of time to waste on lyrics like “I wanna live in the Bahamas/ Ah ha...I heard about it from a friend of a friend”.

column1: Or maybe the biggest problem is that Forcefield has to be judged relative to “Argentina (Pts. I
column2: II
column3: III)”
column4: a total outlier that also takes up nearly 30% of its total runtime. To put things into perspective
column5: Tokyo Police Club have never written a song longer than four minutes. This one is nearly nine
column6: but its tripartite structure simply means it’s the three best songs on Forcefield all at once rather than some prog odyssey. It’s a grand
column7: large-scale display of everything that makes Tokyo Police Club likeable in the first place—Monks’ weedy vocals and wry lyrics (“If I was a lighthouse/ I would look all over the place/ If I was an asshole/ Thank you for keeping a smile on your face”)
column8: a knack for making verse melodies as catchy of those of the chorus
column9: and yes
column10: there’s some showboat riffing cribbed from post-Green Album Weezer. So Tokyo Police Club were in the right frame of mind when they called this thing Forcefield: they didn’t need to look outside themselves to make a truly great record. But after “Argentina”
column11:
you just wish they took their own advice more often.

However sleepy its synthesizers may sometimes seem or however distant its electronic drums might occasionally become
column2: Light Divide thrives on an energetic restlessness. Throughout the five tracks of his short fourth solo album

column10: with Caminiti projecting guitar themes toward the unending horizon and Porras slowly transitioning from six strings to electronic-oriented abstraction. To that end
column11: Light Divide is his most definitive statement by himself
column12: even if its sense of mercury raises questions about the future stamp of his individual pursuits.

column1: The sounds on Light Divide will suggest a litany of electronic referents: Tim Hecker and Laurie Spiegel
column2: Andy Stott and John Carpenter
column3: Christian Fennesz and Keith Rowe
column4: to sample. But if it feels occasionally like Porras is only plundering the familiar
column5: know that the trick of Light Divide comes with context. With the attention Porras has paid to layers
column6: this album works well as low-volume headphones music. You can catch mesmerizing details in the descent toward silence at the middle of “New Monument” and notice the graceful
column7: shy melody behind the static din near the end of “Recollection”. It’s easier to hear the four-on-the-floor beat of opener “Apeiron” disintegrate from such a short distance
column8: especially since it falls apart only after falling under the attack of several subtle contrasting rhythms. But for all of its intricacy
column9: Light Divide often operates behind a forward curtain of volume and power; many of those more slight maneuvers occur behind commanding tones or around bulging rhythms. During “Divide”
column10: for instance
column11: airy tones whorl through throbbing bass and pressing organ. And though “Pleiades” tunnels through a set of thin static scrims and microscopic pops
column12: it moves laterally between a Tim Hecker-sized hum
column13: an ascendant keyboard melody and
column14: at its end
column15: a martial house clip that demands loud speakers and a hard right turn of the volume knob. Light Divide functions as a sort of palimpsest
column16: then
column17: where different settings reveal contrasting components within the whole
column18: aspects that might have been overlooked through either headphones or a living room stereo alone.

column1: Both the restlessness and wide toolkit that make Light Divide a compelling
column2: rather brief listen do suggest a potential problem for Porras’ solo work: He shamelessly evokes those who have long charted similar territory
column3: and Porras’ music
column4: both in idea and execution
column5: can feel somewhat indistinguishable from those antecedents. At the very least
column6: he’s yet to show how he’s separate from or superior to a median or mean of those people whose music his suggests. That is
column7: admittedly
column8: part of the intrigue with Light Divide—hearing how a musician known for his distant guitar pontification digests and then delivers the sound of a very active and au courant electronic subset. But how can Jon Porras go from making very good records that read like strings of Recommended if You Like references to making records that belong in a list of RIYL standbys? That is a long-term worry for Porras
column9: anyway. For now
column10: he’s made the most efficient and best-directed solo album of his career. No matter how much it wades through established styles or sources
column11:
it sorts and stacks them in unfamiliar patterns that depend upon and demand careful listening—out loud and in isolation.
