Black Lips defined themselves early on with riveting music that breathed new life into garage rock. So let’s just get this out of the way: 2005’s Let It Bloom is still their best album. That’s not meant as a slight to their later work
column2: but rather an acknowledgement of just how thrilling the early
column3: ragged material could be: the way they screamed just after the intro of “Not a Problem”; their hypnotizing
column4: fluid cover of Jacques Dutronc’s “Hippie
column5: Hippie
column6: Hoorah”; the swooning
column7: filth-caked ballad “Dirty Hands”. Everything on that LP was well-written and performed in a way that was exciting and distinctive. Before they had crowds freaking out to “Bad Kids” and “O Katrina!”
column8: these songs anchored their shows (as captured on their great live album Los Valientes del Mundo Nuevo).

column1: Even as they cleaned up their sound
column2: Black Lips’ best records since have kept the same grit
column3: glam
column4: and grime they had at the beginning. Mark Ronson’s production on Arabia Mountain‘s “Family Tree”
column5: for example
column6: had a vintage
column7: musty record store atmosphere to it
column8: with saxophones and arrangements that made them sound like they were auditioning to be Rufus Thomas’ backing band. With Ronson
column9: they proved that their unrefined songs could still hit with an A-list producer. So the fact that they recorded in Nashville with the Black Keys’ Patrick Carney on seven of Underneath the Rainbow’s 12 tracks isn’t something to dismiss out of hand.

column1: But another producer is responsible for the album’s best songs. Four tracks were recorded in New York with Tom Brenneck
column2: who worked with the band on Arabia Mountain and played guitar for Sharon Jones
column3: Amy Winehouse
column4: Cee-Lo Green
column5: and others. “Smiling”
column6: a song about spending the night in jail
column7: is the first in a run of Brenneck-recorded highlights. It was originally intended to be about Gucci Mane
column8: but
column9: thankfully
column10: Jared Swilley had the sense to to base it on his own experience behind bars. He sings about pissing in a cup
column11: not being able to sleep because of the fluorescent lights
column12: and sharing old Newports
column13: and the details
column14: when added to the song’s sunny and catchy melody
column15: lend a grinning
column16: toothless charm
column17: not unlike what they exuded on “Dirty Hands”. Brenneck also oversees “Make You Mine”
column18: the expertly crafted power pop song co-written with Mastodon’s Brent Hinds
column19: and “Funny”
column20: which features what are probably the album’s dumbest lyrics (“come suck some milk from my titties”) and a careeningly tenuous vocal performance from Cole Alexander. Here
column21: the band find their old fire

column1: The Carney material
column2: by contrast
column3: is hit and miss
column4: to say the least. The twee romp “I Don’t Wanna Go Home”
column5: co-written by soul singer Curtis Harding
column6: and “Dog Years”
column7: which was penned with Bradford Cox
column8: are highlights. But other Carney-helmed tracks are utterly faceless
column9: which
column10: for a band with Black Lips’ reputation
column11: is unacceptable. The vocals in “Dorner Party”
column12: “Justice After All”
column13: and “Waiting” are stiff and generic
column14: aiming for a sort of new wave affectation that doesn’t work. Individuality has been sanded away. Since the the lyrics are uncharacteristically tepid
column15: blame can't be solely attributed to Carney
column16: but it is worth noting that until the Lips’ vocals come in
column17: the stomp of “Dandelion Dust” could easily be mistaken for a Keys track.

column1: The album’s centerpiece “Boys in the Wood”
column2: a slow
column3: Southern-rock-tinged song recorded with Brenneck
column4: was the record’s first single. Heard in isolation
column5: it didn’t work
column6: but it sounds great in the context of Underneath the Rainbow. Coming after a dull patch
column7: it’s a sudden injection of life
column8: with a thoughtful and well-paced arrangement. Unlike the Steve Mackay-style sax on Arabia Mountain’s “Mad Dog”
column9: the Budos Band’s horns on this one recall Allen Toussaint’s arrangements for the Band’s Rock of Ages—Southern rock songs emboldened by soulful brass. Counter to the album as a whole
column10: it’s proof that Black Lips can step outside their comfort zone
column11: craft an ambitious song
column12:
and still sound like themselves.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20347/homepage_large.eef24440.jpg|Catch the Throne: The Mixtape|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Launch Point']|2014-03-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:39:58.897762|"

Race has long been a sore spot for speculative fiction: check the latent color consciousness of Tolkien (dark skinned orcs = savages
column2: fair skinned elves = enlightened)
column3: the whitewashed galaxies of the early Star Wars films
column4: and The Last Airbender
column5: a silver screen take on a series about Asian people that somehow managed to bleach them out in casting. HBO’s popular adaptation of George R. R. Martin’s swords and sorcery drama Game of Thrones is the latest to weather criticism for its dealings with race
column6: from the noted absence of people of color in early seasons to their depiction in later seasons as uncivilized masses in need of white guidance. With the show returning for a fourth season of blood-soaked castle keep intrigue next month
column7: the network is determined to make inroads to a more diverse viewership. Apparently “attract more minorities” means “pander to urban audiences with rap music” because HBO’s power play for multicultural patronage looks a lot like a mixtape.

column1: Catch the Throne drafts the production team from New York’s Launch Point Records to fashion hip-hop beats out of the show’s rich
column2: dramatic orchestral score and select swatches of dialogue from key characters. The result is a collection of rousing aspirational stompers interspersed with Eastern scales and instrumentation
column3: tasked both with honoring the show’s musical accompaniment and holding the attention of casual onlookers. Launch Point makes a noble go at it
column4: but the source material is too stuffy to allow them to shine. The same could be said of the cadre of rap
column5: reggaeton and dancehall artists featured throughout Catch the Throne
column6: who do their best to skirt the patent absurdity of the mixtape’s premise but invariably end up falling on their own swords.

column1: When these rappers aren’t struggling to explain Martin’s tangled plot and reveling in veiled references to Westeros lore
column2: they’re puking up bored motivational boilerplate. Opener “Mother of Dragons” finds Big Boi unfurling plot intensive lines like “Targaryen
column3: the rightful bloodline/ So don’t you worry about the Red Wedding
column4: that made it crunch time” and “Fuck the Lannisters and everybody that ride with ‘em”. Bodega Bamz spends “Win or Die” tripping on platitudes about life during wartime (“You lose if you break the rules/ Kings do what they have to do”). Nobody can resist a pat joke about dragon taming queen Khaleesi: Bamz “spits fire like Khaleesi”
column5: Wale brings us “that Khaleesi heat” and “The Parallel” sees Dee Goodz in search of a “female species with physical features of the girl Khaleesi”. Barring dancehall star Magazeen’s “Iron Throne”
column6: which succeeds by avoiding show specifics in favor of a fatalistic world-weariness
column7: and “Magical Reality”
column8: Kilo Kish’s fetching mining of Game of Thrones’ undercurrent of sensual mysticism
column9: Catch the Throne is clunker after cringeworthy clunker. Rampant spoilers and the high learning curve for the languages and lore that riddle the lyrics ensure that these songs won’t make any sense to anyone that doesn’t already know the material.

column1: Ideas that look terrible on paper are quite often terrible in practice
column2: and Catch the Throne’s ace conceit
column3: to lure people of color to Game of Thrones with rap music
column4: is executed about as poorly as one could expect. The writing is leagues beneath everyone involved
column5: and the sequencing is nonsensical to a hilarious degree. But beyond that
column6: the notion that a mixtape is a sensible means to boost Game of Thrones’ sinking black and Latin viewership is misguided
column7: if not insulting. If HBO is really interested in expanding into different households it might want to consider presenting people of color in a more complimentary light on the show. Fishing for diversity with a mixtape when the desired audiences are only seen in the series as slaves
column8: savages
column9: thieves and bargaining chips is covering a stab wound with a band-aid. Game of Thrones has problems no amount of hip-hop star power can fix
column10:
and Catch the Throne has given back very little in return for the urban cred it’s been loaned here. One can only hope everyone involved caught a princely check for their troubles.

"|19140.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19140-catch-the-throne-the-mixtape/|4.0|Craig Jenkins

For the last three decades
column2: Current 93 have been not so much a band as an ever-evolving collective anchored around the complicated vision and curdling voice of David Tibet. To scan the liner notes of Current 93’s past is to see a roster of remarkable talents and controversial figures
column3: each worthy of their own lengthy explorations: Crass’ Steve Ignorant and Coil’s Jhonn Balance
column4: folk queen Shirley Collins and ambient demigod William Basinski
column5: regulars Steven Stapleton and Andrew Liles
column6: the mesmeric singers Antony Hegarty and Rickie Lee Jones. Tibet has been an unapologetic Svengali
column7: bending these incredible casts to his alternating will of atmospheric neo-folk or apocalyptic rock symphonies
column8: refined industrial cacophony or delicate chamber maneuvers.

column1: There’s endemic payoff and peril with such an arrangement
column2: of course. That rotation has long seemed to energize Tibet
column3: forcing him to reconfigure his explorations of ancient religion and modern life with for nearly every new outing. Tibet’s music remains intriguingly unpredictable
column4: then
column5: a wide catalog bound mostly by the thread of his serpent’s tongue and high-minded conceits. On the other hand
column6: some crews of Current 93 have simply worked better than others. Many have afforded his material surprising depth
column7: while others have seemed shallow when pitted against his idiosyncratic charge. So it goes for the capable assemblage of I Am the Last of All the Field that Fell
column8: an 11-song album that not only re-taps Hegarty
column9: Liles
column10: Nick Cave
column11: and guitarist James Blackshaw (relegated to bass this time) but adds John Zorn and boundary-pressing Dutch classical pianist Reinier van Houdt. And that’s but a partial sample. There are flutes and poetry readings
column12: floods of noise and wisps of bass clarinet. Still
column13: such an astounding lineup only serves to reinforce the disappointment of the flat and oftentimes gangly Field.

column1: Tibet’s voice does not easily fit many definitions. It is a sharp
column2: brittle instrument that works best in starts and stops
column3: when it can leap beneath and through musical phrases with the authority reserved only for a bandleader. But on Field
column4: Tibet’s only consistent accompaniment is van Houdt’s versatile piano playing. Together
column5: they navigate peppy burlesque numbers and lurking acid rock
column6: demented freak-jazz and drooping torch songs
column7: various members joining in or dropping out. He attempts to slip his uniquely shaped vocals into too many unyielding holes. These torrents of words—references to Akkadian grammar and forgotten gods
column8: cigarettes and hipsters
column9: delivered no less in several languages—lash against the sides of the songs van Houdt attempts to shape. The most awkward fits even become unintentionally hilarious. Late during “Kings and Things”
column10: Tibet steps sprightly over piano and a distortion-pedal din
column11: his voice chased by the fair air of Comus’ Bobbie Watson. He offers phrases like “Announcing Japanese beheading
column12: ” and she stays in his thrall. It sounds like an action scene from Cats
column13: while its successor—the piano-and-voice soliloquy ""With the Dromedaries""—sounds like the dark-night confessional that might chase it on a Broadway stage. “Let’s discuss denim/ or the weather/ of my dead friends
column14: ” he sings
column15: doing his best to constrain himself to the small valleys between van Houdt’s cresting-and-collapsing notes. Above the tightly scripted full-jazz-band motion of “Spring Sandy Dream Larks”
column16: Tibet seems truly lost for one of the first times in his career. It’s as if he’s wandered uninvited into a rehearsal by the Bad Plus and tried to shoehorn his voice—shouts of Aleph and all—into a tune written without him. Dejected
column17: he takes his leave nearly a minute before they’re done.

column1: But the band isn’t so much the problem as the directions they generally take
column2: a point epitomized by the brazen and vitriolic “And Onto NickPick Magick”. The outfit starts in a pre-lit smolder
column3: with snarling electric guitar and teasing flute lashing out against van Houdt’s dissonant piano and Tibet’s deep speak-sing. The group suggests a conflagration spiraling upward through space: The piano lines pile high. The guitar tone grows more reckless. The bass maintains its constant thump but gets louder and more anxious
column4: a pulse quickened by the knowledge of impending doom. By the song’s paroxysmal end
column5: Tibet cries every line
column6: his stentorian tone now liquefied into terror. “I could not find your lips in the songs of bees
column7: in ForgetMeNot Fields
column8: ” he screams during one of the album’s most lucid
column9: poignant
column10: and harrowing moments. That sensation emerges toward the end of “Those Flowers Grow”
column11: too
column12: when Tibet’s clinched screams
column13: Zorn’s saxophone squawks
column14: and Tony McPhee’s guitar lock into a three-way war. It’s one of Field’s few moments of full-band power that still finds Tibet in rightful control.

column1: Paradoxically
column2: Tibet also succeeds when he sets up a system and lets it advance without him. On 2006’s Black Ships Ate the Sky
column3: for instance
column4: he gave his nightmares ballast and balance by allowing a set of premier singers—Hegarty
column5: Bonnie “Prince” Billy
column6: Marc Almond—to deliver the 18th century hymn “Idumæa” separately. It stunned. And he wrote the lyrics for the 2007 Michael Cashmore EP The Snow Abides
column7: again voiced by Hegarty; it’s one of the most remarkable moments in any of their careers. On Field
column8: a choir of monastic hums backs Hegarty
column9: gliding through Tibet’s interconnected lyrics with ease. Tibet tries the same thing by himself two songs later
column10: and the contrast crystallizes their differing skill sets. At least the record ends with “I Could Not Shift the Shadow”
column11: a perfect duet between Cave's husky voice and fluttering harmonies
column12: sunlight and shadow
column13: fire and ash. “And bare your naked church into my mouth
column14: ” he repeats at the end
column15: pushing off with the sort of steady resolve that so much of Field misses. It’s a parting reminder that this is Current 93
column16: and to date
column17:
the magic has always returned.

“He had a high tolerance for pain
column2: ” said drummer Pat Doyle in 2012 when eulogizing his former guitarist Anthony “Tony Offender” Johnson
column3: who had just died of lung cancer. To play in Offenders
column4: he would have had to. Rounded out by bassist Mikey Offender (née Donaldson
column5: who died in 2007) and singer J.J. Jacobson
column6: the lineup of Offenders during its 80s prime was as anguish-trawling as any in hardcore. Of all the historic punk and HC bands based in Austin in the early 80s—MDC
column7: D.R.I.
column8: the Big Boys
column9: and the Dicks foremost among them—Offenders remain the least celebrated or even recognized
column10: despite the fact that Johnson was a founding member of MDC (when they were still called the Stains) and Donaldson played on D.R.I.’s seminal 1985 album Dealing With It. Offenders have always belonged on that top tier. No amount of revisionist oversight can blunt the brute impact of their discography
column11: particularly their two full-lengths
column12: 1983’s We Must Rebel and 1985’s Endless Struggle
column13: as well as their 1984 7” “I Hate Myself”/“Bad Times”. In an effort to help rectify this blind spot
column14: these three releases have been collected in full by Southern Lord as a double-LP anthology including beefed-up fidelity. Not that these songs have ever sounded less than staggeringly savage.

column1: The discography of Offenders has never been that difficult to find. Copies of Endless Struggle abounded in used bins of the 90s
column2: and over the years
column3: various CD anthologies have surfaced
column4: both domestically and as imports. With hardcore hitting another upswing in its perennial cycle
column5: though
column6: the timing of We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle couldn’t be better. Yet it underscore that Offenders’ music is more timeless than many of its better-known contemporaries. After a strong if derivative debut 7”—1981’s “Lost Causes / Rockin’ the Town”
column7: which is not included here
column8: features an A-side that sounds like an homage to Orange County punk and a B-side that’s a fun but out-of-place Clash pastiche—We Must Rebel ditched the past and went after the future with fangs bared. That future included a plan of attack that
column9: up to that point
column10: had been antithetical to hardcore: heavy metal. On the album’s first track
column11: “Fight Back”
column12: a new tone is instantly set with a shadow-steeped arpeggio that would have sounded at home on another record released that year
column13: Metallica’s Kill ’Em All. But unlike the proto-crossover of Void’s half of the 1982’s The Faith/Void split album
column14: We Must Rebel isn’t sloppy or chaotic. It’s tightly wound and inhumanly focused
column15: even when Doyle’s drumming on “No Chance” feels like it’s about to catapult itself into insensibility
column16: or when Johnson’s riffs on “New Militia” are applied like surgical implements.

column1: The between-albums single
column2: “I Hate Myself / Bad Times”
column3: is rawer than either full-length
column4: which only renders the abusive self-loathing of the former into a hackle-raising cry of elemental hurt. Jacobson’s vocals hint at another D.C. hardcore influence besides Void—namely Minor Threat’s Ian MacKaye—but in Jacobson’s throat that barking roar is less accusatory than confessional. Along with Offenders as a whole
column5: he hits his personal best on Endless Struggle. “On the Crooked Edge” jabs gaping holes in itself
column6: leaving space for Johnson and Jacobson to hang in—that is
column7: before Johnson’s plugs the holes with squealing snarls of guitar-solo anarchy worthy of Void’s Bubba Dupree. “Endless Struggle” earnestly sports an epic
column8: organ-laden
column9: Deep Purple-esque intro at a time when Day Glo Abortions were making fun of that exact same sound. But it’s the opening salvo of “You Got a Right” and “Face Down in the Dirt” that marks the anthology’s peak. Less than three minutes combined
column10: the pair of tracks spans the band’s own spectrum: The latter is a scathing rebuke of abuse that pukes up battery acid and a palpable stench of degradation
column11: while the former is a glacial
column12: churning
column13: bleakly anthemic grind that sounds like a primitive ancestor of “Owner’s Lament”
column14: the legendary Scratch Acid song that appeared a year later on Rabid Cat
column15: the same Austin label that released Endless Struggle. Slow and choked with sludge
column16: “You Got a Right” marks a turning point in hardcore—a song-length breakdown that offers no respite
column17: and a omen of the grunge and pigfuck crawl that was just around the corner. As if to punctuate that pivotal nature
column18: Offenders’ cover of the Supremes’ “You Keep Me Hangin’ On”—or rather
column19: Offenders’ cover of Vanilla Fudge’s version of the song—concludes Endless Struggle on a bitter
column20: bludgeoning note that carves a straight line between the proto-metal of the past and the shape of post-hardcore to come.

column2: an infamous episode of CHiPs (on par with an equally infamous Quincy M.E. episode that year) featured a fictional band called Pain performing its signature song
column3: “I Dig Pain”. It was meant to be a true-to-life portrayal of hardcore circa the early 80s
column4: although its hopelessly square depiction of musical sadomasochism looks as cartoonish now as it did then. But there is something perversely real at the heart of Pain’s otherwise laughable “I Dig Pain”—namely
column5: the idea that hardcore
column6: unlike the punk that preceded it
column7: dived deeper into the realm of inner turmoil
column8: confusion
column9: and agony with less mercy than any music before it. It wasn’t a celebration of pain
column10: but a stark acknowledgement of it
column11: especially necessary during a decade when a new conservatism stifled not only political policy and social convention
column12: but the way kids were expected to just absorb all the pent-up shit that ate away at their souls. Calling We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle catharsis is too pat. Offenders weren’t purging. They were conducting
column13: in a Morse code of twinges and flinches
column14:
all the hate and pain that was being forced through them.

Along with Offenders as a whole
column5: he hits his personal best on Endless Struggle. “On the Crooked Edge” jabs gaping holes in itself
column6: leaving space for Johnson and Jacobson to hang in—that is
column7: before Johnson’s plugs the holes with squealing snarls of guitar-solo anarchy worthy of Void’s Bubba Dupree. “Endless Struggle” earnestly sports an epic
column8: organ-laden
column9: Deep Purple-esque intro at a time when Day Glo Abortions were making fun of that exact same sound. But it’s the opening salvo of “You Got a Right” and “Face Down in the Dirt” that marks the anthology’s peak. Less than three minutes combined
column10: the pair of tracks spans the band’s own spectrum: The latter is a scathing rebuke of abuse that pukes up battery acid and a palpable stench of degradation
column11: while the former is a glacial
column12: churning
column13: bleakly anthemic grind that sounds like a primitive ancestor of “Owner’s Lament”
column14: the legendary Scratch Acid song that appeared a year later on Rabid Cat
column15: the same Austin label that released Endless Struggle. Slow and choked with sludge

column17: and a omen of the grunge and pigfuck crawl that was just around the corner. As if to punctuate that pivotal nature

column20: bludgeoning note that carves a straight line between the proto-metal of the past and the shape of post-hardcore to come.

column2: an infamous episode of CHiPs (on par with an equally infamous Quincy M.E. episode that year) featured a fictional band called Pain performing its signature song
column3: “I Dig Pain”. It was meant to be a true-to-life portrayal of hardcore circa the early 80s

column5: the idea that hardcore
column6: unlike the punk that preceded it
column7: dived deeper into the realm of inner turmoil
column8: confusion
column9: and agony with less mercy than any music before it. It wasn’t a celebration of pain
column10: but a stark acknowledgement of it
column11: especially necessary during a decade when a new conservatism stifled not only political policy and social convention
column12: but the way kids were expected to just absorb all the pent-up shit that ate away at their souls. Calling We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle catharsis is too pat. Offenders weren’t purging. They were conducting

column14:
all the hate and pain that was being forced through them.

The 20-year career of John Schmersal has been one of alternately ceding and seizing the spotlight. In the mid-90s
column2: the guitarist first appeared as a Keith Richardsian foil to the jacked-up Jaggerisms of vocalist Timmy Taylor in Dayton
column3: Ohio berserkers Brainiac. After Taylor’s death in a car crash in 1997 brought that band to a sudden end just as they were about to record their big-league debut for Interscope
column4: Schmersal resurfaced as a charismatic frontman in his own right with Enon
column5: the Brooklyn-based outfit that released four inspired but unheralded albums of electro-shocked pop before dissolving in 2010. Around the same time
column6: Schmersal settled into the steadiest gig a 90s freak-scene vet could hope for this side of the Seth Meyers Band
column7: as a touring guitarist for Caribou. But even though it’s a gig that's allowed him to tour further afield and play for larger crowds than he’s ever experienced before
column8: Schmersal is too restless an artist to remain completely beholden to someone else’s vision and timetable.

column1: Since moving to L.A. in 2010
column2: he’s put together two new
column3: very different bands that isolate each half of the pop/slop symbiosis that’s always fuelled his work. To satisfy his penchant for bizarro psych-funk
column4: he’s got Crooks on Tape
column5: a reunion with former Enonite/Skeleton Key clanger Rick Lee. And to unleash his inner melody-maker
column6: he has Vertical Scratchers
column7: a house party­-forged partnership with drummer Christian Beaulieu of San Fran prog-punk mutants Triclops! and collaborative psych-folk project Anywhere. Given the divergent interests and ping-ponging aesthetics of both parties involved
column8: what’s most remarkable about Vertical Scratchers is its determinedly narrow ethos. Though it has an antecedent in Schermsal’s one-off lo-fi 1998 solo release as John Stuart Mill
column9: it’s by far the most classicist band either principal has been involved in to date. Over the course of this 15-song
column10: 30-minute blur of a debut record
column11: the duo mine a post-Beatles power-pop lineage that connects the byzantine logic of the Lilys (“Turn Me Out”)
column12: the hazy harmonies and easy-going groove of early Sloan (“Someone”)
column13: and the Vaselines-smeared side of pre-Nevermind Nirvana (“Wait No Longer”)
column14: yielding a bounty of jagged
column15: 120-second song shards that would make Schmersal’s old Dayton pal Bob Pollard proud. And when Pollard actually turns up for a guest vocal turn on the zippy “Get Along With U
column16: ” the fit is so natural you almost don’t notice his appearance at first.

column1: But appropriately enough for a record that was recorded in L.A. punk pit The Smell
column2: Daughter of Everything doesn’t so much recapture a golden age of pop as exhume it
column3: presenting pretty melodies beset by dust
column4: decay
column5: and stinking rot. The name Vertical Scratchers isn’t some random
column6: cheeky nod to infomercial-hawked itch-relieving implements
column7: but a vivid descriptor of Daughter of Everything’s rusted-out sound: Many of the songs feature Schmersal scraping away on an unplugged electric guitar
column8: and on tumbling tracks like the Kinks-kicked “Way Out”
column9: the clipped effect of his speedy strums is so pronounced
column10: it’s almost as if the band has two percussionists. It’s an approach than can grow a little wearing
column11: particularly in those moments (see: “Chambermaids
column12: ” “Kingdom Come”) when Schmersal’s silly-putty voice loses its grip on his ceaselessly shifting melodies and gets lost in the clamor. But Vertical Scratchers are wise to trip the album’s breakneck pace with strategically placed balladic breathers
column13: and these slow-motion anomalies—like the beautifully woozy “Pretend U Are Free
column14: ” the subtly anthemic “U Dug Us All
column15: ” or the stoner-folk reverie “Rainbows”—result in the album’s most illuminating
column16: savoury moments
column17: showcasing the duo’s savvy songcraft while resisting the urge to scuff it up. Daughters of Everything is rock‘n’roll rendered on Etch A Sketch: imperfect and monochromatic to be sure
column18: but infectiously playful
column19: and liable to spin off into any direction at any moment. And
column20: occasionally
column21:
you find yourself marveling at an accidental masterpiece.

Kevin Drew would make a great poet laureate under Toronto’s current regime
column3: but unfortunately the guy in charge seems like more of a hip-hop fan. For the past decade

column5: drugs
column6: politics

column4: and prone to slow-burning torch songs—never feels like a “band” record. That’s partly due to the synth-heavy arrangements

column7: Devendra Banhart

column1: Still
column2: you wouldn’t call it “synth-pop
column3: ” any more than you would Bruce Springsteen’s Tunnel of Love

column5: but four years after Forgiveness Rock Record
column6: it’s striking how instantly familiar Drew can sound even in this newly sleek context
column7: thanks to a cadence that riffs on ragged melodies just a little behind the beat.

column1: This works in Darlings’ favor
column2: particularly when Drew’s voice is all you can hang onto. He has a knack for lyrics that are both explicit and obtuse
column3: words that are overly blunt and vague at the same time. “You Gotta Feel It” and “You Got Caught” both repeat a stock phrase ad nauseam to bind ambiguous lines
column4: while “Bullshit Ballad” is every bit the empty salvo it criticizes. The latter’s steady chug bears a striking resemblance to Arcade Fire’s “Keep the Car Running”
column5: though I doubt it’s aimed in their direction. More likely
column6: it’s aimed at no one in particular
column7: and the non-specificity of lines like “Your soul was distracted/ And your vocals were too high…your horrible whining” renders it the only time where Darlings is well
column8: pretty limp.

column1: But “Bullshit Ballad” is more of a curious fit than a weak song; the rest of Darlings lays out what Drew considers to be ballads free of bullshit. The album is often just as expansive as Broken Social Scene
column2: though spreading outwards rather than shooting upwards and collapsing—its struggles are wholly internal rather than external. On “Body Butter”
column3: Drew wants to party all alone
column4: and yet he allows his date to the Mexican aftershow party to claim him as hers only because “I don’t wanna fight with the man that I am.” You get a good sense of just what kind of man Drew is on Darlings
column5: reconciling monogamy with promiscuity
column6:
Broken Social Scene’s cheap-seats bombast with love-seat confidentiality.

A few years ago
column2: New York City’s Other Music came across dead stock of a two-albums-on-one-CD from two British brothers dressed in dashikis who went by the name of Woo. The release combined two obscure albums from the prior decade
column3: 1982’s <i>Whichever Way You Are Going

column6: relics of a bygone era

column8: Woo are also are relics of another time
column9: or perhaps just displaced from spacetime.

column1: In the past few years
column2: Woo’s obscurity has lessened slightly
column3: with Drag City reissuing It’s Cosy Inside and the UK imprint Emotional Rescue last year reissuing Whichever (they'll also reissue Into the Heart of Love later this year). Hearing When the Past Arrives as a “new” Woo album or a collection of previously unheard archival material feels beside the point

column2: like the acoustic guitar-led “Acting Like a Lover”. The charming “1001 Decisions” has a cello that sounds like it’s submerged in a children’s pool
column3: the bowed melody broken up by what could be little bits of a ringing toy telephone
column4: theremin
column5: and tiny xylophone. Elsewhere
column6: there’s a little ditty wherein the brothers and a lady friend coo the question: “How far will you go today/ Up the garden path?” Woo do merit comparison to the likes of Cluster and Durutti Column but it’s easy to imagine that those are not the Ives’ brothers exact reference points. They sound like Durutti Column as rendered on ukulele
column7: or Cluster if instead of amassing early synthesizers they instead collected clarinets
column8: kazoos and other woodwinds. (In one interview
column9: they talk about growing up with Dixieland jazz.)

column1: When the Past Arrives’ centerpiece is the elegant nine-minute piece
column2: “Satya”. What sounds like gentle bits of electronic fuzz reveals itself to be buzzing clarinets and curlicues of guitar. There’s also a drone as gentle as a rubbed wineglass. It’s vintage Woo. Or perhaps it’s recent Woo? Or maybe it’s just the sonic embodiment of that Sanskrit word “satya
column3: ” which loosely translates as “unchangeable” and “that which is beyond distinctions of time

column5:
and person.”

Vermont is a new project from Germans Danilo Plessow and Marcus Worgull. For Plessow
column2: better known as Motor City Drum Ensemble
column3: it represents the first significant dump of new material since his wildly popular Raw Cuts series—dusty
column4: sample-based house ravers—put him on the map at the end of last decade. The album
column5: a collection of percolating synthesizer landscapes
column6: represents a new direction for both
column7: one that borrows from Germany's storied history of outre music in both form—the influence of artists like Popol Vuh and Hans-Joachim Roedelius is undeniable—and function: Can's Jaki Liebezeit guests on drums.

column1: Despite its relative obscurity in the canon of western music
column2: instrumental synthesizer music is plentiful. Analog circuitry is enormously fun to fiddle with and gear obsessives have a tendency to hit ""record"" and do just that. Artists such as Steve Moore
column3: Norm Chambers (Jürgen Müller
column4: Panabrite)
column5: Steve Hauschildt
column6: and Jorge Velez (Professor Genius) are just a handful of artists who've released exciting works in the genre recently. This is music that sits in the middle of a venn diagram that brings together ambient
column7: improvisatory
column8: and generative musics
column9: which is to say that it's music that can often seem more edifying and enriching for its creators than for its audience. Vermont's careful
column10: patient compositions don't feel particularly generative or improvisatory
column11: but the instruments still do a lot of the heavy lifting: anyone not predisposed to enveloping pads and wispy filigrees of melody will find little else to sink their teeth into.

column1: If Plessow and Worgull distinguish themselves
column2: it's via clarity and execution. Because its creators are often using finicky gear three and four decades old
column3: lots of synthesizer music tends to sound as worn and fractured as the tools used to make it. Vermont
column4: though
column5: is focused and luminous; its high is similar to that of waking up early
column6: totally sober
column7: and gathering oneself. There's discipline and fidelity in this music
column8: which is a fancy way of saying it has its shit together. Vermont is never less than agreeable and pretty: if you get off on hearing a bunch of volts and circuits evoke mountains and fog
column9: Vermont might be for you.

column1: Evoking those landscapes
column2: though
column3: is all Vermont does. It's polite music that
column4: unlike proper ambient music
column5: has pretensions that extend beyond politeness. It's here where Vermont's balance hurts it. Something foggier or more random would open more avenues to explore
column6: but Vermont feels complete
column7: without mystery or intrigue. It lacks the psychedelia and stoned otherness of its inspirations. ""Macchina""'s puddled rhythms and ""Ruckzug""'s graceful plumes are lovely
column8: but oddity and intrigue are beyond their grasp. ""Cocos"" is a moody
column9: minor-key sea of texture
column10: but it never stirs up any real tension.

column1: To its credit
column2: Vermont stares its self-imposed limits in the face and walks away with plenty of elegant moments. Its slightness makes it nothing more than a diversion: for listeners
column3: sure
column4: but also for its creators. Vermont is a side project that sounds like one
column5: a pastime for Plessow and Worgull
column6:
a minor curiosity for their fans.

To record her first full-length
column2: Mirrors the Sky
column3: London singer-songwriter-producer Lyla Foy had to leave the city. She hauled her instruments and equipment out into the English countryside
column4: where she recorded herself performing songs on overcast beaches
column5: in deep woods
column6: or in sunny fields. As she told the 405 recently
column7: “One of my trips took me up to the Lake District
column8: and another to the blustery coast of Cornwall
column9: during a storm. There are birds and goats to be heard all over the recordings
column10: if you listen closely.” Returning to London
column11: she convened with her bandmates to touch up the recordings with keyboards
column12: drums
column13: and vocals
column14: working to complement the rustic demos while preserving their airy minimalism.

column1: The result might be best described as a digital pastoral: sequences and synthesizers blending with live instruments to create the kind of introverted
column2: outdoorsy reverie most commonly associated with acoustic folk. Foy’s songs are both lush and low-key
column3: intimate and surprisingly intricate. She layers beats generously but carefully
column4: alternating between buoyant (“I Only”
column5: with its percolating intro) and bittersweet (“Only Human”
column6: with its insistent snare tap). Except on the relatively aerodynamic “Feather Tongue”
column7: which could easily be remixed into a throbbing dance number suitable for a meadow rave
column8: Foy’s concern isn’t rhythm but texture and tapestry. The tempos are generally slow and rigid
column9: which  fits the general atmosphere of the record and gives you a better opportunity to admire her craft.

column1: Given the various geographies that contributed to these songs
column2: the mood on Mirrors the Sky can be too narrow. When it changes
column3: it moves from gloomy to gloomier
column4: especially on “Rumour”
column5: which trudges along on the glummest reggae-dirge beat imaginable. And yet
column6: Foy peppers these songs with enough flourishes to prevent the album from becoming too predictable or claustrophobic. She has an ear for ambient noise: It sounds like someone’s rubbing a balloon on “Only I” and who knows what that din is on “No Secrets”? Car keys nervously jangled in a coat pocket? Billiard balls being ground into dust? That the source of the sound is never clear only makes it more ominous.

column1: Over this burbling electronic folk music
column2: Foy writes impressionistic lyrics that prove more inquisitive than confessional
column3: and she sings in a robust and expressive whisper
column4: as though she’s letting the listener eavesdrop on a private
column5: unself-conscious moment. Yet
column6: her truest gift may be for writing dreamy
column7: shimmery
column8: extremely catchy hooks that lift these songs out of their depths. Her songs measure the distance between lovers and document her attempts to either erase or create that space. “Am I allowed to love you yet?” she asks on “No Secrets"". She doesn’t sound angry or hurt; that line isn’t rhetorical or accusatory. Instead
column9: she sounds like she’s lamenting so many lost opportunities for happiness.

column1: Mirrors the Sky is actually Foy’s first release under her own name
column2: after playing for a few years under the pseudonym WALL. Under that guise she was routinely compared to the xx for her downcast gothicisms
column3: but these new songs have more in common with Nick Drake
column4: Vashti Bunyan
column5: Sibylle Baier
column6: and other otherworldly folk artists. (Foy even covered Karen Dalton’s “Something on Your Mind” during her WALL days.) It’s apt that she tore down the WALL
column7: with all its misleading Pink Floyd associations
column8: for this album: Mirrors the Sky reflects a subtle yet effective refinement of her sound
column9:
as she tweaks these elements and influences to create music that is both familiar and idiosyncratic.

column6: however
column7: presents no easy remedy for his inner turmoil. If the mesmerizing motorik hum of Slave Ambient gave Granduciel an outlet to escape his problems
column8: Lost in the Dream is where he pulls a U to survey the emotional wreckage. While his former War on Drugs compadre Kurt Vile is forever Waking on a Pretty Daze
column9: Granduciel has been sleepless through some ugly nights.

column1: As detailed in a recent Grantland feature
column2: Lost In the Dream was the product of a grueling
column3: year-long recording process. Though Granduciel involved his touring band more so than any previous War on Drugs record
column4: his perfectionist tendencies still held sway
column5: resulting in endless cycles of recording
column6: revising
column7: and scrapping. And such self-doubt wasn’t helped by the fact that Granduciel was recovering from the flame-out of a long-term relationship
column8: the ashes of which are scattered all over his lyric sheet here. But the obsessiveness and insecurity pay off massively on Lost in the Dream—this is the War on Drugs’ most lustrous
column9: intricately detailed
column10: and beautifully rendered record to date. In essence
column11: the War on Drugs have evolved as a band on an album-to-album basis in precisely the same fashion as so many of their songs: what at first seemed like a fairly straightforward
column12: traditionalist roots-rock exercise has very gradually
column13: very subtly blossomed into something wondrous and profound.

column1: Lost in the Dream continues down the Slave Ambient route of bridging polar-opposite strains of 1980s rock—namely
column2: the tremulous haze of late-era Spacemen 3 and the sort of flyover-state Americana anthems used to sell pick-up trucks. But even in the album’s opening seconds
column3: the new album asserts itself as a more urgent affair—overtop the blurry
column4: break-of-dawn guitar ripples of “Under the Pressure”
column5: a stuttering drum machine sounds off like an alarm clock coaxing you out of bed and prodding you out the door. And if the steady-pulsed melody that emerges initially positions “Under the Pressure” as the most placid song about anxiety ever
column6: by the third chorus run—at which point it’s amassed a swirl of dueling guitar solos
column7: starburst synths
column8: and brown-note saxophone swells—you feel the full weight of this nine-minute track bearing down on your chest.

column1: This tension is inescapable. Whether it’s the hair-raising
column2: Autobahn-blazing charge of “An Ocean In Between the Waves” or the Positively South Street sway of “Eyes of the Wind”
column3: Granduciel’s litany of worries are laid bare here
column4: free of any textural interference or obfuscation. And the comparatively direct lyrics mirror the new approach to incorporating some of Granduciel’s more unfashionable influences. As ever
column5: totemic figures like Dylan and Springsteen cast a long shadow over the War on Drugs’ terrain
column6: but Granduciel is the sort of classic-rock purist who wore out the grooves of those artists’ most canonical albums so long ago that he now finds fresher inspiration in their less lauded 80s discography.

column1: Period sounds abound: “Red Eyes” is what would happen if Springteen’s simmering “I’m on Fire” was actually set aflame; “Burning” finds its fuse in the buoyant keyboard riff to Rod Stewart’s 1981 new-wave novelty “Young Turks”; the melancholic mid-album meditation “Disappearing” sounds like the synth-powered rhythm track of Tears for Fears’ “Pale Shelter” on a codeine drip. And the preponderance of glistening piano chords on this record suggests Granduciel is not one to touch his dial whenever Bruce Hornsby’s “The Way It Is” pops up on his local oldies station.
But if Lost in the Dream is unapologetic in its dad-rock reverence
column2: it’s dad-rock for people who are too fucked up and broken to even think of having kids. (As he sings on “The Ocean In Between the Waves”: “I’m in my finest hour/ Can I be more than just a fool?”) In sharp contrast to
column3: say
column4: recent efforts to liberate Dylan’s 80s output from its dated production
column5: Granduciel’s songs are left to fidget and squirm within the claustrophobic sonic confines and synthetic sheen. In his hands
column6: these echoes of the past ultimately emphasize the uncertainty of his future
column7: those shiny surfaces representing the good life that seems forever out of reach.

column1: And besides
column2: on Lost in the Dream
column3: the most crucial details are found in its structural mutations. The album is loaded with songs whose greatness is revealed slowly
column4: where the simplest
column5: most understated chord change can blow a track wide open and elevate it from simply pretty to absolutely devastating. Note the shift that occurs two minutes and 50 seconds into “Suffering”
column6: where the pent-up despondency heard in Granduciel’s state-of-his-union address (“Why we here when we’re both gonna fake it?”) is unleashed in a crying jag of drizzling piano chords and gently weeping White Album-like guitar slides. Or in the midst of the album’s epic break-up-ballad finale
column7: “In Reverse”
column8: ­ you realize that all of the angst and ache that went into the song
column9: and the album’s creation as a whole
column10: is just building to the moment of release provided by the big
column11:
shoulder rub of an acoustic-guitar riff that appears out of nowhere at the 5:13 mark. They’re the sort of perfect little touches that effectively translate Granduciel’s private hurt into communal catharsis—and reify Lost in the Dream as an immaculately assembled portrait of a man falling apart.

column9: inevitably

column1: The moment is the Kid CuDi catalog in miniature: A vast
column2: serene

column1: Of all these issues

column5: but Cudi defaces it
column6: stuttering and tum-de-tum-tumming all over it
column7: like an eighth-grader who wondered into the unattended studio and left his own vocal track just for laughs. Pick any track: on ""Internal Bleeding""
column8: he assumes a mush-mouth delivery that might be a stab at dramatizing the condition in the song title. Maybe we're supposed to imagine this guy singing on the floor with a mouth full of broken teeth? At any rate
column9: the music tumbles down around him like a drunk grabbing onto a curtain rod.

column1: To navigate successfully around a Kid Cudi album
column2: then

column4: a sonar blip traveling through the mix there. Mercifully

column6: and they are

column9: while Imperial March horns—notably similar to Yeezus's ""Blood on the Leaves"" —blare overhead. It could almost have snuck onto the last Fuck Buttons album and gone unspotted. ""Copernicus Landing"" is a calm

column5: modestly
column6: and in tune—over nothing but some guitar
column7: finger-picked with athe level of skill that suggests a deep study of Green Day's ""All By Myself"". The song is just two chords

or both.

Awake is the album where Scott Hansen
column2: the San Francisco-based visual artist and musician who records as Tycho
column3: expands into a far-reaching space. He's made gorgeously constructed techno under this name for over a decade
column4: ultimately gaining traction with the sunny Dive in 2011. In the context of Awake—the first Tycho record recorded as a three-piece band—his previous albums now sound like mere dreams of the luminous world he was trying so hard to connect to. Here
column5: Hansen gains a skip in his step and strides right into that place
column6: largely due to a shedding of the muddied beats and wistful synth tones that positioned him a little too close to Boards of Canada's retro-futuristic notions. There's more air here
column7: lending a greater expanse of room to move around in than before
column8: like travelling from a rundown seaside resort to vast scoops of desert plane. It's still recognizable as a Tycho recording
column9: with a familiar sense of melancholy and the embers of sundown burning through it
column10: but with the ambition clearly heightened right from the first few notes.

column1: Not for nothing does the echoey guitar clang that opens a couple of these tracks (notably ""Awake"" and ""See"") sound like the Edge's long-familiar tones in U2. It's not exactly stadium-leaning
column2: but if what came before felt more like bedroom creations
column3: then here the Tycho sound is taken into a different area entirely
column4: where everything glistens so brightly it feels like the work of someone who thinks the Beatles' career began and ended with the ultra clean lines of ""Here Comes the Sun"". Something it shares with Dive is the feeling of journey
column5: where tracks heard in isolation won’t make as much sense as picking up the long thread from beginning to end. ""Montana"" may reach a greater point of euphoria than the moodier ""Dye""
column6: but watching how Hansen and his band arrive there is part of the thrill
column7: with disparate moods slowly slotting into one another in a perfectly natural flow.

column1: The sense of build Hansen possesses—knowing when to add and subtract
column2: when to fade and zoom right back into focus—was a central tenet of the Dive sound
column3: and it's a sensibility he retains here
column4: although it doesn't always stop his work from circling perilously close to redundancy. ""Apogee"" is clearly supposed to be born from a moment of discordance
column5: but it's an all-too brief divergence that makes it feel like the ideas are running dry when he returns to his tastefully constructed loops for the bulk of the track. Fortunately
column6: Hansen keeps things brief
column7: cutting Awake dead around the 35-minute mark after eight tracks. A common problem with bringing live instrumentation into techno is the heavy handedness that can set in—a dilemma the Field's live-band incarnation often grapples with—although that's rarely an issue here. Only on ""Spectre"" does the subtlety loosen
column8: but even there it offers release from the strong sense of control that can feel suffocating when the Tycho sound is so thoroughly pinned down.

column1: Where all this leads Hansen and his creation is into a great pool of reflective thought
column2: typified by the introspective guitar strum of ""Plains"". It feels like this is Tycho mining an older strain of music than the more contemporary references of Dive. There are nods to post-rock
column3: but this feels like it's reaching further toward the sources of that genre than the acts themselves
column4: with Tortoise's aping of Mike Oldfield's Tubular Bells on TNT emerging as a strong reference point. Lessons have been learned from Dive here—this is a much leaner record that feels skillfully edited
column5: with less use for indulgence and circular routes that don't lead anywhere. It could use a break from the pensive train of thought at times
column6: and the tentative branches away from that mode suggest it's under consideration
column7: if still not quite there yet. But the strong feeling of movement Hansen creates
column8: as he quietly creeps through shades of orangey color
column9:
comes packed with dualling strains of sorrow and empathy.

column1: What's at once frustrating and captivating about Dental Denial is how it undersells so many of its best moments. They'll write a phrase that's fascinating or funny only to have it buried in the mix beneath other instruments. They'll establish an undeniable earworm

it certainly rewards repeat visits. Like Tommy Boy.

Pay close attention to the order in which the two members of the new Long Island/Queens duo Psalm Zero are introduced: If what you’re reading about their excellent debut LP The Drain is intended for a metal-minded audience
column2: chances are you’ll first meet Andrew Hock—the pair’s screaming half
column3: a former member of tech squad Biolich and the current frontman of the beguiling Castevet. The member with the mid-range monotone
column4: though
column5: is Charlie Looker. He played guitar on the Dirty Projectors’ Rise Above
column6: worked as an early member of exploratory compositional collective Zs
column7: and seemingly explored the borders of classical music
column8: math-rock
column9: and pop in the intriguing but woefully short-lived Extra Life. If you’re browsing an indie rock or experimental emporium
column10: then

column1: But The Drain pays less attention to the divide between Hock and Looker’s pasts and instead thrives on the tension between the union of their résumés. This is a gyre of metal aggression and industrial wallop
column2: synthpop filigree and rock hooks

column4: ‘Oh
column5: it’s like this band

column7: ’” Hock told Andy O’Connor in an interview earlier this year. “It feels totally honest and an actual synergy of all my influences

column10: the gloom of Christian Death
column11: the same twisted post-punk structures Hock works in Castavet—without overemphasizing such disparities. At their best
column12: these songs are powered by the strain of those separate elements
column13: not controlled by them.

column1: Psalm Zero link those interests immediately and obviously. In fact
column2: the opener is also the title cut
column3: an appropriate gambit given how much its music feels like the album’s thesis. It begins with a looming
column4: Godflesh-like guitar theme
column5: chased by dead-eyed bass and a plodding
column6: heavy drum machine. But Looker’s voice is famously staid
column7: delivering the first verse with a droll tone that springs melodies from the slightest rises and dives. When he’s done
column8: the rhythm and riff suddenly shift
column9: with the beat doubling over itself and the guitar twisting into knots. Hock enters
column10: his voice a vitriolic rasp delivering bad news: “No words/ Don’t touch me/ Mouth shut/ Dumb fuck.” But the arrival of a wobbling
column11: sliding synthesizer line becomes the velvet glove that doesn’t let the moment glower with purely metal aggression. “Force My Hand”
column12: revisited here after it served as the A-side to the pair’s debut single
column13: turns similar tricks
column14: blurring the dividing lines of a back-and-forth volley between Looker and Hock. It’s as if the music was written to dovetail to their voices—the heavier bits for Hock
column15: the more rock-oriented moments for Looker—and then transposed by half. At one point
column16: Looker sings above spiraling
column17: steely guitar lines; at another
column18: Hock shouts above tones so bright they sparkle.

column2: especially after the first two tracks bridge the divide with such obvious intent: Looker delivers “Chaos Body” with some help from Hock. Looker drops his monotone to yell a Prurient-like tirade about unease and torment over arrows of feedback and stuttering drums. Between those moments
column3: though
column4: the music is surging and vaguely triumphant

column6: when his harangue about what hell is and will forever be becomes backlit by music so tumescent and bright it could pass for a symphony’s grand reveal
column7: albeit backed by flailing industrial rock. Hock doesn’t sing at all during “In the Dead”. Despite the especially macabre mood
column8: Looker’s hook is alluring enough that it could belong to Depeche Mode’s Violator. But the drum machine pushes the turnarounds between the verses and chorus toward blast beats

column7: issued The Drain

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20292/homepage_large.fc67552e.jpg|Say Yes to Love|31732.0|Perfect Pussy|[]|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2014-03-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:09.319811|"

Syracuse five-piece Perfect Pussy sound like a hardcore band fronted by Joan of Arc: A swirling maelstrom of fire engulfs a singer who shouts with the ecstatic conviction of someone who would rather die than apologize. Following a searing
column2: four-song demo tape released last year
column3: their proper full-length debut Say Yes to Love is an unrelentingly intense experience—23 minutes of five people pushing themselves to their absolute limit. Frontwoman Meredith Graves has called the band's songs ""happy revelations about incendiary events
column4: and this remains the most fitting description of their music. It doesn’t feel corny or hyperbolic to call this record life-affirming
column5: so perfectly does it capture the flashes of gratitude
column6: self-knowledge
column7: and inexplicable joy that often follow an experience of great pain.

column1: A Perfect Pussy song comes together in layers
column2: and the group’s writing process is a kind of sonic avalanche. Graves has said that her bandmates Ray McAndrew (guitar)
column3: Garrett Koloski (drums)
column4: and Greg Ambler (bass) usually record a totally clean track first
column5: and then she and keyboardist Shaun Sutkus come in and ""make noise on purpose."" That approach gives these songs an energy that is both chaotic and collaborative—the instruments sound like they're wrestling each other for space instead of working in harmony. And the textures of the eight songs on Say Yes to Love are damaged but also luminous; even at its most assaultive moments
column6: like the gale-force ripper ""Advance Upon the Real""
column7: jangly chords and a bright melody shine defiantly somewhere below the surface.

column1: Say Yes to Love is so relentlessly pummeling that it's almost meditative
column2: and its songs are caked in so much sludge it's often hard to make out what Graves is saying. Until
column3: very suddenly
column4: it's not. You know the feeling when you're in a place that's so loud and crowded that you have to scream into the ear of the person next to you
column5: and then suddenly the room goes quiet and now everyone can hear you? And how this always seems to happen when you're saying the most private and potentially embarrassing thing? In a Perfect Pussy song
column6: this happens to Graves constantly—""AND I WANT TO FUCK MYSELF/ AND I WANT TO EAT MYSELF
column7: she is caught saying in one of these moments of jolting clarity. But a great power emerges as she delivers even her most vulnerable lines without a twinge of shame. She sounds emboldened by silence
column8: her presence growing to fill it
column9: like a person whose voice has been stifled and is now overjoyed by the chance to be heard.

column1: It's easy to be overtaken by the primal force of this music but there's also an incentive to dig deeper. Say Yes to Love is a convincing argument for reviving that practice of reading along with the lyrics while listening. Graves' lines are full of vivid
column2: visceral
column3: and often unsettling images (""You can read the story of my last six weeks/ In little black bruises and marks from boys' teeth"") and the sort of bold confessions plenty of people wouldn't tell their best friends. And her delivery is at once shit-kickingly tough and childlike
column4: sometimes reminiscent of Life Without Buildings vocalist Sue Tompkins' wide-eyed swagger.

column1: Perfect Pussy have been criticized for the buried vocals and often unintelligible lyrics
column2: but the approach serves a purpose. There's tension in this music between vulnerability and defenses
column3: between the things we tell each other and the things we feel the need to keep hidden. The lyrics to songs like ""Interference Fits"" and ""Dig"" (which meditates on sex and violence) are so intense that hearing every word could almost be a distraction—it'd be hard to pay attention to anything else. So you're given a choice of how to experience these songs: You can lose yourself in the rush
column4: or you can follow along and think more closely about what they're trying to say.

column1: There are a few moments in ""Big Stars"" when the feedback squall sounds like it's bleeping out something Graves is saying. If it's intentional
column2: it's a pretty good joke about arbitrary censorship—a topic Perfect Pussy know well as they've quickly gone from being evangelized in limited-run underground zines to being covered in publications too refined to print their name. But an irony that we're just starting to understand as a culture is that
column3: for women in particular
column4: the first word in Perfect Pussy's name is much more obscene than the second. If you're female
column5: it's far more socially acceptable to express self-deprecation than self-love
column6: and it's more acceptable for anybody to express numbly detached nihilism than Perfect Pussy's particular brand of hard-won
column7: audaciously blazing joy. Something about Say Yes to Love—the way Graves' bright
column8: confidently optimistic vocals are threatened to be drowned out at every turn—speaks to the forces that make women in our society feel like they must exist in a constant state of perceived inadequacy. And fuck all that
column9: says Graves at the end of the careening ""Dig"": ""If I'm anything less than perfection/ Well shit
column10: nobody told me!"" Say Yes to Love is one of the hardest and most jarring records I've heard in a long time
column11: not because it's trying to shock you with darkness
column12:
but because it's unafraid to stare directly into the light.

column2:
'Terrible']|2014-03-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:09.931972|"

""Ask a gay question/ Here's a black answer"" is a bomb of a line hidden in the opening track of Khalif Diouf's—aka Le1f—big indie label debut
column3: a refutation of the uninvited politics that seem to follow him wherever he goes. It's a hefty moment on an otherwise lighthearted five-tracker that serves to introduce the New York rapper to a new audience on what could be the biggest release of his career so far
column4: his first for Terrible Records (and jointly put out by XL). In an alternate universe
column5: it'd be the first transmission from some plucky pop artist being groomed for stardom. Instead
column6: the short EP is both an announcement and a confident distillation
column7: the essence of what makes Diouf so captivating
column8:
packaged up into something mass consumable and effortlessly fun.

""I’m pretty much always leaning toward futuristic
column9: progressive beats
column10: so if something sounds even a couple months dated to me then I’m already over it
column11: Diouf recently told Vogue in an interview surrounding his signing to Terrible/XL. For this one he's still aligned with his longtime collaborators—underground producers like Matrixxman
column12: Boody and Dubbel Dutch—but the beats are pared down and utilitarian
column13: skeletal backdrops that contrast his wordplay rather than wrap around it. Compare that to Fly Zone or last year's Tree House
column14: brilliant mixtapes where Le1f took on weirder and more ambient beats as an implicit challenge to write odd flows that dove and soared across the wide contours. ""Hey""
column15: on the other hand
column16: is a mere whistle and some horns
column17: which makes the music feel timeless instead of trendy. More importantly
column18:
it gives Le1f's venomous slither center stage. 

And he's more ornery than ever; or maybe determined is a better word. Hey is aimed pointedly at its prospective audience: latecomers
column19: hangers-on and fawning journalists alike. Diouf sounds both hungry and content
column20: like he's trying to persuade you of his skills but confident enough to know that he will succeed. Hey is all about identity—about reclaiming
column21: defining and reinforcing it—and he snarls like the leader of a pack. ""Sup"" is the the kind of autotuned bragging-about-your-crew number that could centrepiece a drill tape out of Chicago
column22: and on ""Boom"" he spits ""new world order/ LGBT cuties all over the world are diamonds and pearls"" like he's leading a march out into the open. He's still a fiercely sexual lyricist too
column23:
even directly referencing his own penchant for frank and decadent fantasies (""he wanna hanky panky but he can't handle how otherworldly I am""). 

As slimmed-down as the beats might be
column24: Diouf still finds ways to instil them with personality. On ""Buzz
column25: he embellishes the chorus with buzzing bee vocalizations and layers his voice deliriously through the verses
column26: creating a surrealist smear of vocal fry and processing artefacts that feels truly alien without being alienating. A string of Pokémon mentions on ""Hey"" and a pileup of Starbucks references on ""Sup"" are humorous and witty
column27:
the kind of densely packed writing we take for granted from Le1f that make him such a fascinating lyricist beneath all the surface dazzle.

There's a newly mastered version of 2012's ""Wut""
column28: Le1f's biggest hit so far. It's an opportunist move that makes the EP feel more like a marketing tool than a statement
column29: but Hey is most likely a stopgap on the way to something bigger. It's still impressive how Diouf takes to the song's knotty twists and turns with ease
column30: motoring through its virtuosic second verse with pure finesse. Taking on a new resonance in light of Macklemore's moral hijacking of gay issues in rap and (alleged) direct hijacking of 5kinandbone5's original beat
column31: ""Wut"" now sounds like a veteran doing his thing like a pro. So maybe Hey isn't the cry of a scrappy newcomer—rather
column32: a reminder that he's an incredible rapper and wordsmith regardless of the bullshit. Ask him a gay question
column33:
and he'll give you a rap answer.

column3: the Irish producer who records as Shit Robot
column4: is part of a lineage that runs through James Murphy's DFA empire. The pair met when Murphy was setting up a studio in a New York building where Lambkin had an office
column5: and the latter has released music as Shit Robot sporadically in the years since. The title of his first full-length
column6: 2010's From the Cradle to the Rave
column7: hinted at his status as a lifer at this game
column8: but few of his musical fascinations venture outside a small set of dance music influences. Lambkin's not necessarily interested in being current but he is interested in getting back to that moment of complete white-out on the dancefloor
column9: where the future and past cease to matter and all that's left is to get lost in the present.

column1: We Got a Love reads like an exercise in DFA box-ticking on the surface
column2: and digging deeper doesn't reveal much depth beyond that. Tropes from house
column3: rave
column4: and disco are all present
column5: along with a familiar switch-up between wailing and monotone vocals from an array of guests. But depth is probably something Lambkin never intended to be there in the first place. As a club record to zone out to
column6: this doesn't reach the euphoria of Todd Terje at his best
column7: or even the Juan MacLean's excellent ""Feel Like Movin'""
column8: which was released last year on the flipside of Shit Robot's Reggie Watts-featuring single ""We Got a Love"". But it works for what it is—a solid set of impeccably produced club jams
column9: all rinsed through an atmosphere that's never less than jubilant.

column1: Watts has a couple of features here
column2: bookending an album that includes appearances from LCD Soundsystem's Nancy Whang and Luke Jenner from the Rapture. Despite the array of approaches—Watts can go deadpan or diva
column3: Whang is ultra flat
column4: Jenner goes the full Barry Gibb—there's a firm hand guiding it all
column5: bringing in piano stabs at just the right moment along with carefully programmed mechanical loops and clattering percussion and handclaps. The vintage house feel and ""jack your body"" refrain of ""Do It (Right)"" is as nostalgic and backward-looking as Kings of Leon or Mumford & Sons
column6: but it's filtered through a set of influences that will remain forever impeccable. This is a world where Darryl Pandy and Anita Ward simply never grow old
column7: remaining forever locked down in their finest moments.

column1: Music that borrows heavily from dance music's past and post-punk is common
column2: but Shit Robot sees little worth plundering beyond 1991 or 1992. The cut-off point here
column3: and arguably across the DFA spectrum
column4: appears to be the introduction of jungle and drum'n'bass
column5: at which point a stern barrier to entry comes clattering down. An artist needn't enter that space
column6: of course
column7: but We Got a Love feels like a place we've visited countless times before
column8: which raises questions about going back yet again. Even though the record is irresistible at times
column9:
it's also a feedback loop of nostalgia that's creaking as it turns.

The Nocando narrative seems pretty easy to write at first. He's a Scribble Jam champ and Project Blowed vet
column2: so he's versed in battle rap and its tendency to thrive on a heady blend of lyrical intricacy and haymaker punchlines. And if that's not enough
column3: his presence as co-host of the hip-hop podcast Shots Fired (which
column4: for the sake of full disclosure
column5: is a joint production with Pitchfork contributor Jeff Weiss) reveals him as a relentless smartass whose depth of knowledge and easy rapport are only matched by his ability to tell a hilarious anecdote or six. Tie that into the precedence of his more recent albums—2010's Jimmy the Lock (where every other line was a clever piece of a swagnostic manifesto) and last year's mixtape Tits 'n Explosions (which is
column6: well
column7: called Tits 'n Explosions)—and it's hard not to go into one of his tracks without expecting at least some kind of slick joke to turn up.

column1: Jimmy the Burnout isn't all that different in that respect. Nocando's casually perceptive voice drops cliche-inverting quips and irreverent punchlines on the regular (from ""Little Green Monsters"": ""I'm just another dick and this rap game is a glory hole""). And he sneaks in a pair of skits featuring comedians Jermaine Fowler (a meta-skit where he tries to pitch a skit idea) and Eric Andre. But throughout Jimmy the Burnout
column2: weaved in through the punchlines and the witty turns of phrase
column3: are deeper things. Nocando is a grown-ass man with a family
column4: fresh into his thirties with plenty to look back on
column5: and it's clear that through maturation and experience his sense of humor can trend towards the dark—not always edgy
column6: but often on edge.

column1: Intricate metaphors and shit-talk alone don't put you in a class with Aceyalone and Murs
column2: so it's fortunate that Nocando rarely if ever just focuses on spitting for its own sake here. Once you get past the diabolical vibe and halfway-horrorcore minor-key g-funk skulk of ""Little Green Monsters""
column3: you can catch a rapper whose confidence and ambivalence are regularly at odds (""It's funny how stupid we feel the more we know/ Baby we ate off the same plate
column4: how come all the porcelain broke"")
column5: even if he finds a way to make it sound like confidence is just one unguarded shot away from rallying towards a blowout. He raps about relationships in a way that sidesteps the potential corniness in being vulnerable
column6: like when he sees an old flame and realizes ""you never looked better/ until the day I saw you hanging off another nigga's arm"" (""Never Looked Better"") or tries to reconcile a tense
column7: guarded moment between himself and his partner (""Too Much to Ask""). And whether he's pulling double-overtime in the shadow of his cousin locked in Chino (""3rd World Hustle"") or standing up for people who're treated like they'll never amount to anything (the Mono/Poly remix of ""Zero Hour"")
column8: he makes his stories of day-to-day struggles and striving to overcome bullshit ring as true as the best conscious-rap message tracks without a bitter aftertaste.

column1: The fluidity of Nocando's voice deserves crediting for that. The way he works with the beats on Jimmy the Burnout is borderline chameleonic
column2: able to snap tight to the mood of the track and jump right in with a crucial hook. That stands out clearly early on after a three-track run—the piano-and-horns throwback pop-soul of ""Break Even""
column3: the cloudy chopped-vox-and-snare rumblings on ""Did You Know That???""
column4: and the buttery slow-jam homage ""Too Much to Ask"" (all produced by Caleb Stone)—where he flips from knotty
column5: assonant internal rhymes to straight-ahead choruses like the seasoned pro he is. Sometimes
column6: production-by-committee results in a scattershot album where the identity and the vibe never really cohere. But here
column7: it's just a good excuse for him to stretch out and put all his facets out there
column8:
whether he's amped up on Djemba Djemba's gospel-gothic boom-bap (""Hellfyre Club Anthem"") or floating through some of Dâm-Funk's emotionally (and bodily) moving ""smile with a tear"" space-boogie (""Lucid Dream""). That he's showing this kind of range might be Nocando's slickest joke of all: his name just keeps getting more ironic with each record.

The music Bo Anders Persson made in the late 1960s and early 70s may not have spread wide
column2: but its influence went deep. While his Swedish groups Pärson Sound
column3: International Harvester
column4: and <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tr%C3%A4d
column5: _Gr%C3%A4s_%26_Stenar"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Träd
column6: Gräs Och Stenar didn’t sell tons of records
column7: for a certain cross-section of the underground
column8: their sprawling swirl of psych
column9: folk
column10: noise
column11: and abstraction was a sound ripe for worship. Bardo Pond
column12: Acid Mothers Temple
column13: and Sunburned Hand of the Man all owe their smoky trails in part to the paths that Persson’s bands blazed.

column1: Persson’s solo music might have made as much impact over the past five decades
column2: if anyone had actually heard it. One piece did make a small dent: the 1967 tape-loop protest “Proteinimperialism
column3: ” released in 1970 on a split LP with fellow countryman Folke Rabe. But it turns out Persson had a lot more going on before he formed his avant-rock groups with fellow students at Stockholm’s Royal College of Music. Inspired to “play music the way I myself imagined that it should sound
column4: ” he crafted tape-based experiments and ensemble compositions that rival his pioneering later work.

column1: As heard on the archival compilation Love Is Here to Stay
column2: these early Persson pieces reflect their times and predict later advances
column3: yet ultimately stand as the unique work of a singular vision. Granted
column4: Persson was influenced by Terry Riley
column5: whom he met when his mentor
column6: the composer Jan Bark
column7: brought him to Sweden to lead a version of In C in which Persson played electric organ. You can hear Riley’s musical voice echoing through Persson’s tape experiments
column8: which build and expand the way Riley’s did. But there’s a simplicity to Persson’s approach that makes his work more primal
column9: and more personal. Most of his pieces use just a few sonic elements
column10: and are clear about where they are and what they’re doing. Their power comes not from overwhelming your ears but focusing them
column11: directing concentration to detail rather than density.

column1: They also make a fascinating study in combining tapes with other instruments
column2: in ways that end up like collaborative duets. On “Invention” parts I and II
column3: Persson intersects his recorders with the flute of Björn J:son Lindh
column4: creating what at times sound like embryonic versions of Phill Niblock’s rock-solid drones. Even more intriguing is Persson’s use of Maylen Bergström’s singing. On “Piece I”
column5: her free-form vocalizing evokes Patty Waters’ height-scaling and Yoko Ono’s quiver. Persson grounds those flights with loops both rhythmic and responsive
column6: supporting Bergström without blocking her. Later
column7: on “Piece II”
column8: tape repetitions move forward
column9: soaking the vocals until they become pure waves.

column1: Persson’s ensemble compositions also feature interlocked partnership. “Små toner mer eller mindre
column2: ” from a 1967 Swedish radio broadcast
column3: uses five players
column4: yet it’s still thoroughly
column5: calmly minimalist. No individual element dominates; at times it seems as if everyone is playing one instrument together
column6: lending intimacy to something that could have sounded crowded. “Love Is Here to Stay”
column7: by contrast
column8: has moments of clutter
column9: and is the clearest foreshadow of Persson’s group work
column10: as his conga rhythms turn it into a kind of rock meditation. But even this piece feels personal
column11: more the echoes of a mind than the rumblings of a collective.

column1: Love Is Here To Stay ends with its only previously-released track
column2: the aforementioned “Proteinimperialism”. Its overt political slant
column3: based on a repeated phrase signifying the environmental dominance of the Western World
column4: is also unique among these pieces. In fact
column5: were you to listen to the rest ofthe album without further context
column6: you might think Persson’s solo work was significant primarily for its formal experimentation
column7: at a time when minimalism was just starting to gel and infect genres outside of academic composition.

column1: That wouldn’t be wrong
column2: but there’s more going on here than aesthetic progress. Persson was particularly concerned about the environment—he took up music after abandoning engineering because of machines’ impact on nature—and a love of surroundings
column3: an appreciation of the organic
column4: is evident throughout the album. (Not coincidentally
column5: Persson now devotes most of his waking hours to farming his own food). The music develops with little restriction and
column6: even at its most tape-manipulative
column7:
doesn't sound artificial. Perhaps the loudest message of Love Is Here to Stay is that complex ideas are sometimes best expressed in the most uncomplicated ways.
