Shortly after the release of TRST—the debut LP from Canadian coldwavers Trust—Maya Postepski said her goodbyes
column2: leaving Robert Alfons to go it alone while she refocused her energies on Toronto dream-poppers Austra. Postepski and Alfons shared both songwriting and vocal duties on TRST
column3: making her exit not just sudden
column4: but potentially drastic. Yet there's something strangely fitting about Alfons carrying on as a solo project: Trust
column5: after all
column6: are precisely the kind of band that seems to thrive on alienation and solitude. Even the clubbier tracks on TRST had a a dark
column7: dissociative
column8: alone-in-a-crowd feel
column9: better suited for a 4 AM freakout in a windowless room than any kind of communal catharsis. Joyland
column10: the Alfons-only Trust's second effort
column11: is a couple notches sleeker than its predecessor
column12: but that lurching
column13: sweating-off-the-pancake-makeup smear of TRST continues unabated on the scowling
column14: subterranean release. Perhaps unsurprisingly
column15:
Alfons makes a pretty good loner.

Opener ""Slightly Floating"" eases you into Joyland slowly
column16: its twinkling keyboards and choral swirl getting you good and acclimated to the darkness ahead. By the time ""Geryon"" rolls around
column17: you're in deep: the bass throbs
column18: synths sputter and shriek
column19: while Alfons' sleep-deprived

column21: where the velvet rope's blood-spattered and the VIP section's a bathroom stall. Even when the tempos unclench
column25: breath-catching chorus of ""Are We Arc?"" would be plainly gorgeous. To get there
column27: you'll have to wade through a good minute of Alfons' perilous mumble. Joyland never flinches; you can almost picture Alfons sizing you up with a glazed stare
column28:
making sure you're ready to see some things you can't easily unsee.

Whether left unadorned or taffy-pulled into the upper registers
column30: self-serious vocal tone is given even more room to slither throughout Joyland. In his review of TRST
column31: Larry Fitzmaurice compared Alfons to a ""goth Eeyore""; point being
column32: the guy's not exactly the type to light up a room. With Postepski gone
column33: Alfons is responsible for every voice on Joyland
column34: from the pip squeaking chorus of ""Lost Souls/Eelings"" to his gravelly
column36: Alfons slathers his voice with effects
column39: and reshaping syllables into not-always-comprehensible shapes. As with TRST
column42: riveting the next—is certainly Trust's most distinguishing characteristic. But
column44:
these oft-garbled exhortations—coupled with Joyland's icy synths and weaponized rhythms—have a distancing effect.

Throughout Joyland
column45: the dingy hues introduced on TRST have deepened; Alfons has somehow managed to open up more space in his sound without sacrificing that twitchy
column48: Joyland's just not quite at the same level. The emotional range throughout Joyland is fairly narrow—you've got your dark greys
column49: and your pitch blacks—and memorable hooks often seem to take a backseat to tone and texture. Verses often seem rushed
column50: with Alfons barreling through in that stern monotone
column51: only to come alive around the choruses. Joyland's surface pleasures—fizzling synths
column52: dry-heave rhythms—often seem to take precedence over its songcraft: the moaning
column55: but the pulsing tempos of all but a couple of these songs often seem to blot out everything else around them
column56: and the more patient numbers often feel a bit shapeless
column57: little more than excuses to test out another new effect on Alfons' malleable voice. The oily
column58: immersive Joyland's very nearly the equal of its predecessor. But with so many similarities—and so little growth—between the two records
column59: it's a little like spending another night at the same club: once you've gotten the lay of the land
column60:
the thrills are never quite so thrilling.

In 2010
column2: the New Orleans rapper Curren$y scored the two biggest hits of his career. The rapper
column3: born Shante Franklin
column4: had once been a gangster rapper
column5: one of the semi-anonymous weed carriers that populated Lil Wayne’s Young Money Entertainment imprint. Like so many of his fellows
column6: Curren$y
column7: who frequently refers to himself as Spitta
column8: wasn’t promoted properly while on YME
column9: but he also was an ill fit for the label’s gangster-lite subject matter at the time.

column1: After leaving Young Money
column2: he hit upon a formula that worked better: rapping about his smoked-out lifestyle
column3: an aspirational
column4: unpretentious
column5: working man’s fantasy of fast cars
column6: fast women and copious amounts of THC. Curren$y found his trademark style
column7: discussing that subject matter with a flow which didn’t so much find a beats’ pockets as create creases of its own. Pairing those raps with the lush boom-bap of the producer Ski Beats on the Pilot Talk records yielded two near-perfect albums of stoner fantasia.

column1: He has not made a project with the same kind of impact since. That has a lot to with artistic inertia—like many prolific musicians
column2: Curren$y can seem more interested in the present
column3: cranking out song after song
column4: than he does in making specific creative statements. The closest he gets is warmed-over concepts like the one that powers his new mixtape <i>The Drive In Theatre
column5: a tired tribute to the Godfather that’s ostensibly supposed to double as a paean to movies in general.

column1: But the Pilot Talks weren’t great because they provided an insider’s look into the aviating life—Curren$y’s concepts have traditionally been smoked-out deviations more than anything else.  Instead
column2: they functioned as mood albums
column3: the lush beats creating a perfect atmosphere for Spitta’s offbeat flow to come in and make itself at home.  And the new mixtape is the first since that 2010 duo to create a similar atmosphere
column4: making it the rapper’s strongest project in nearly four years.

column1: A lot of that has to do with the guiding hand of Thelonius Martin
column2: who produced just under half the songs here and who keeps it orchestral
column3: with brass-happy
column4: atmospheric boom bap that provides the perfect backdrop to Curren$y’s diaristic scribbling.  “Vintage Vinyard” is a great example of the intimacy on display. It’s a jazzy

column6: opulent
column7: but also filled with paranoia
column8: reflections on one’s place in the artistic hierarchy and quiet moments with the wife. “Hi-Top Whites” keys in on a single detail about a woman
column9: but in the course of getting to the shoe-talk
column10: gives an absorbing account of a day in the life. Curren$y is smoothest over beats like these
column11: where his leaping from one topic to another feels less unfocused and more in sync with the improvisational jazz providing a foundation below him.

column1: Even when Martin is not in charge
column2: the album’s producers do a good job at keeping the vibe consistent. The production team of Cardo and Young Exclusive contribute a blown out bass to “$ Sign Migraine” buts it’s the floating mid-tempo tones that help the song to vibe with the rest of the album. Cooking Soul
column3: who fans will recall from their late-aughts remix albums

column5: the mellow backdrop of “Stove Top"".

column1: If there is a uniting theme on The Drive In Theatre
column2: it’s that Curren$y seems more reflective than usual
column3: a rap veteran reconciling himself with his place in the music business. The posse cut “Grew Up In This” includes a hook that could be interpreted as an assertion of gangster authenticity (“I grew up in this shit”) but it seems to double as a contemplation of being a working man’s rapper
column4: tirelessly grinding out songs and navigating a perilous industry with finesse. “Grew Up In This” also features excellent verses from both Young Roddy and Freddie Gibbs
column5: the former a Curren$y protege who seems to finally have found his own voice
column6: the latter a rapper with a career path similar to and a record of making great songs with Curren$y.

column1: Curren$y has always had good taste in collaborators and the other features on the album are equally effective. Fiend and Smoke DZA both sound great over the handclaps and sax that power “The Usual Suspects.” And Action Bronson saves what might otherwise be a weak opening track
column2: “Godfather Four.” (The beat loops The Godfather’s theme music
column3: which sounds great
column4: but is awfully gimmicky.)

column1: That beat is just one of the many ways in which The Drive In Theatre is studded with the trappings of a much weaker concept album—there are also plenty of unnecessary snippets of dialogue from Coppola’s movies. But just as Pilot Talk became a euphemism for the kind of lifestyle rap that Curren$y excels at
column2: the movie theater signifiers mostly evaporate to reveal a reflective rapper with a keen eye for detail and a true gift for beat selection: the atmosphere is cinematic
column3: in scope if nothing else. Curren$y puts out a lot of music
column4: and fans could be forgiven for missing a mixtape here and there. But <i>The Drive In Theatre
column5: premiered on Datpiff with next-to-no promotion
column6: proves once again
column7:
that Curren$y is one of a certain group of artists that it pays to keep your eye on.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20309/homepage_large.7b992b12.jpg|Fabric 74|22045.0|Move D|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2014-03-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:13.320918|"

David Moufang has built a sizable career from making something out of almostnothing. The German producer's spent the last 20 years and change pushing at the edges of ambient techno as Move D
column2: slipping snatches of jazz and Tropicália into the genre's squishy confines. His many collaborative efforts have resulted in a deep and varied catalog reflecting a wide emotive range not always easy to pull off in the squishy sub-genre of dance music he works in
column3: embodying darkness and light in equal measure.

column1: His reputation for versatility is impressive; in the last five years
column2: he scored a direct hit with his jittery 2008 LP with Hamburg auteur Benjamin Brunn
column3: Songs From the Beehive
column4: while toiling away on his own with releases for reputed labels such as Workshop and Modern Love. At the end of last year
column5: he dropped his latest solo LP
column6: The Silent Orbiter
column7: a largely beatless
column8: elegiac excursion that mourned the death of frequent collaborator Pete Namlook.

column1: A seasoned veteran whose versatility is as much owed to his natural talent as it is to the general adventurousness possessed by his peers who similarly came up in the 90s
column2: Moufang has proved impressively hard to pin down on record—not so when it comes to his reputation as a DJ
column3: though. Despite his restless penchant for experimentation
column4: he understands well that when it comes to the dancefloor
column5: you simply can't fuck around with the audience's idea of a good time. He frequently delivers compelling sets of warm
column6: lush house and techno that is far removed from the electronic abstractions he's known for
column7: and the 74th entry in London superclub Fabric's long-running mix series is an excellent direct reflection of Moufang's explicitly crowd-pleasing side.

column1: Judging alone by the mere proliferation of the artform
column2: it would appear that the latest iteration of the digital age has brought with it a golden age of the mix; in truth
column3: the sheer ease that new technology provides (not to mention the hands it often lands in) has made for a glut of mixes from both professionals and amateurs that eschew such important building blocks as patience and build in favor of simply filling the air with sound. Fabric 74
column4: then
column5: is the type of professional
column6: elegant effort that only pops up a few times a year; instead of offering an intentional survey of a scene or a reflection of an artist's vision
column7: though
column8: it's clear that Moufang is intent on bringing his own party-starting side to the home-listening audience. An hour-plus of lovely
column9: classic-sounding house music partially comprised of tunes he's snuck into recent sets
column10: it's taken the crown of being the most endlessly listenable mix released in this young year thus far.

column1: Many mixes possess a general rising and falling action
column2: with a few peaks dotted along the way; with Fabric 74
column3: Moufang draws a straight line placed at a high altitude
column4: maintaining an impossibly consistent level of energy that speaks to the subtlety demanded in crafting ambient techno as peerless as the type that makes up the Move D catalog. His selections are impressive and as much ripped from house's past as they are from its present: there's Chicago vet Roy Davis Jr.'s radiant ""Under Tha Sun""
column5: the winding garage-infused sounds of Dom 877's 2013 roiler ""Do It Right""
column6: and Chi house mainstay DJ Pierre's 1992 single as Darkman
column7: the Grace Jones-sampling ""Annihilating Rhythm"". Moufang creates a uniform vibe that rejects sameness through subtle variation
column8: as Amsterdam jazzy-techno auteurs and frequent collaborators Juju & Jordash's rippling ""Loosey Goosey""
column9: taken from their excellent 2012 LP Techno Primitivism
column10: slips in to add different textures without disrupting the general flow.

column1: For a genre that possesses such potential for emotional transcendence
column2: dance fans are a notoriously cranky bunch—but the one complaint I've seen mentioned regarding Fabric 74 has some merit: Willow's ""Feel Me""
column3: a deconstructed web of filtered vocals and distant
column4: bleeping tones
column5: inarguably kills the mood with its needless abstractions. The tune sounds like it'd do better on one of Moufang's many creative endeavors
column6: but placed near the end of Fabric 74
column7: the tune serves as a minor buzzkill supported by an impressively consistent
column8: peerlessly mixed series of tunes. House music's gotten a lot of burn in the last 18 months
column9: breaking into international pop charts and triggering a wave of new-jacks and also-rans that have likely spent more time focusing on the form's general structure than the many subtleties buried deep within its past. Fabric 74
column10: then
column11: is a blast of a history lesson from a certifiable old soul
column12: a reverent document that never loses sight of the fact that
column13: as dance fans
column14:
we're all here to have a good time in the end.

It’s easy imagining that a collaboration between members of Einstürzende Neubauten and the Jesus Lizard might fall somewhere on the harrowing end of the spectrum. Each of those outfits
column2: in its own way
column3: made a name for itself by pulverizing the syntax of rock—Neubauten using brain and sinew
column4: the Lizard using gonad and intestine—and constructing something singularly unsettling in its place. But The Unsemble
column5: the eponymous debut album by a trio comprising Alexander Hacke of Einstürzende Neubauten and Duane Denison of the Jesus Lizard (along with past Silver Jews drummer Brian Kotzur)
column6: is not the logical output of such an equation. Neither industrial nor pigfuck
column7: it’s a refined
column8: even contemplative assemblage of instrumental art-rock with a marked lack of shit getting bashed.

column1: Not that The Unsemble is strictly background music—or rather
column2: it is background music
column3: even though it wallpapers a speculative tableau in which nebulous perception and queasy surreality are the norm. In spite of Hacke and Denison being the big names here
column4: the album feels more like a collaboration between Hacke and Kotzur
column5: seeing as how they’ve each done film work before (Hacke as a soundtrack composer for Uli M Schueppel and Kotzur as an actor in Harmony Korine’s Trash Humpers). That cinematic envisioning of the Unsemble’s essential mission—which otherwise appears to be little more than an ad hoc
column6: let’s-book-two-weeks-in-the-studio-and-see-what-happens arrangement—is most vivid on the track “Act 3"". Hacke’s boiled-in-oil bass line actually sounds more like the Jesus Lizard’s low-end from the axe of David Wm. Sims
column7: all grease and grunts and grated knuckles—but in Hacke’s hands the twang is rolled off the top
column8: leaving just the raspy
column9: prog-punk chug. Kotzur subdivides the syncopation
column10: leaving Denison to bob above that tight helix of rhythm
column11: towing a wispy chemtrail of guitar.

column1: As imagistic as much of The Unsemble is
column2: it’s short on emotion—which in this case is preferable
column3: seeing as how the album’s mix of composition and improvisation gives these visceral players a welcome cerebral pretext. The drawback being
column4: it’s also short on mood. A vague aura of detachment is about the only atmosphere it can muster
column5: and even that
column6: maybe aptly
column7: never fully coheres. These guys are listening to each other
column8: but they’re not exactly vibing. “Chaingang”—another score in search of a scene—shoots for menace but ends up almost comical
column9: as its literal chain-rattling not only makes a self-parody of the title
column10: but a self-parody of Hacke’s found-object legacy with Neubauten. In one sense it’s a welcome nod to an approach that Hacke
column11: of all people
column12: can lay almost full claim to; on the other
column13: it partly defeats the purpose of seeing what new directions this convocation can yank itself in. And the five improvised tracks—“Improv 1”
column14: “Improv 2”
column15: etc.—don’t congeal until “4”
column16: where a tentative
column17: chamber-jazz crawl turns simultaneously skeletal and sinuous
column18: leaving an afterimage of weird worlds in the distance while tapping into an earthy
column19: nearly shamanic pulse.

column1: The most rewarding
column2: yet most frustrating
column3: experiments on The Unsemble are the songs that rock hardest. Along with “Act 3”
column4: the tracks “Shadows” and “Circles Revisited” feature teeming
column5: lurching bass-and-guitar paired with an intricate percussive thump. They move
column6: but they also leave little to the imagination—which is where the strength of “Waves” and “Voices”
column7: in all their empty
column8: drifting prettiness
column9: lies. “Neon”
column10: however
column11: is the album’s head-and-shoulders highlight—a Goblin-esque throb of spectral
column12:
synthetic delicacy laced with cascading arpeggios and a gentle gravitas—that once again accentuates the cinematic nature of the collaboration. But it’s telling that the Unsemble grip hardest when they’re hewing closely to their inspirations—as well as the bands from which they sprang.

In 1993
column2: Cleveland's Ringworm released their debut record
column3: <i>The Promise
column4: whose influence would really be felt once the 2000s came about. When metalcore became the sound on the mid-00s thanks to Uranium and the rebirth of Headbangers Ball
column5: bands that didn't rip off At the Gates took a lot from Ringworm and their NYHC-meets-thrash sound. They've influenced so many bands on the Baltimore metal/hardcore label A389 that the label may as well be called The House Ringworm Built. While bands like D.R.I.
column6: Cryptic Slaughter
column7: and S.O.D. served in breaking down the boundaries between punk and metal
column8: Ringworm brought that dedication into the 90s onward. Given their legacy
column9: they haven't been that prolific. Their second album
column10: Birth is Pain
column11: came out in 2001
column12: after the band had broken up for some time. Hammer of the Witch
column13: their sixth overall and first for Relapse
column14: shows the quintet remaining as consistent as ever.

column1: Most Ringworm songs are have the same ingredients: thrashy riffs
column2: breakdowns
column3: and a total absence of pretension. They're all to the point
column4: much like the harshness of living in an Ohio town where the factory isn't ever coming back. Still
column5: there's a certain precision that these songs have— no coincidence
column6: since guitarists John Comprix and Matt Sorg have also played in Charred Walls of the Damned (who feature Richard Christy from The Howard Stern Show and formerly of Iced Earth and Death) and former Judas Priest vocalist Ripper Owens' group Beyond Fear. Most hardcore bands don't have solo passages that sound like they could be lifted from K.K. Downing's playbook
column7: and this is especially true on “Psychic Vampire” and “I Recommend Amputation"". Even if they're tight
column8: they're not stiff. Ringworm's hardcore side comes out most on “Exit Life""
column9: the shortest song on the record at 1:44. There's no break in the intensity
column10: especially in the blastbeats that follow the intro.

column1: Like other NYHC influenced groups
column2: Ringworm place emphasis on the breakdown. “One of Us Is Going to Die” in particular will make you visualize a battle scene at This is Hardcore or Chaos in Tejas
column3: limbs flying without actually being torn off. “Leave Your Skin at the Door” has a breakdown that is a bit doomier
column4: but no less ripe for mayhem. You can see where Power Trip got some of their cues from. While Ringworm have remained steady over the years
column5: their one true constant is vocalist James “Human Furnace” Bulloch
column6: the group's sole original member. Even given the group's break in the late 90s
column7: it's astonishing he's held on his voice this long. Most new jack Southern Lord hardcore dudes try to sound mad; Bulloch actually is pissed. You can hear him spit at the end of “We'll Always Have The End""
column8: a small bit of personality on the record.

column1: Witch is a solid record throughout
column2: but it is one of those records that feels like a collection of songs—good songs!—rather than an actual album. It doesn't have an appropriate bookend
column3: an appropriate closing. The record just kind of... stops. However
column4:
that might not matter when you're practicing freelance dentistry with a stage and a floor at a Ringworm show.

The appreciation of Madlib and Freddie Gibbs' new collaboration Piñata depends on the range of your hip-hop tastes and your familiarity with both artists' deep cuts. Madlib's Remixes albums put his beats in a street-rap context
column2: giving his esoteric
column3: dusty-sample imprint to cuts like Kurupt's ""Who Ride Wit Us"" and the Noreaga verse on ""Misery Loves Company"". And while Gibbs has thrived when his voice cuts through updated G-funk or soul-chromed Southern bounce
column4: he's also sounded at home on the boom-bap-leaning East Coast beats of Statik Selektah (Lord Giveth
column5: Lord Taketh Away) and the more blunted second half of Baby Face Killa. The team unofficially known as MadGibbs is a somewhat unexpected pairing
column6: maybe a bit outside the usual
column7: but the notion of Gibbs spitting over Madlib's dank obscuro-soul breaks became easier to understand before Piñata even came out.

column1: The question
column2: then
column3: isn't whether Gibbs and Madlib make a compatible match
column4: but what that match winds up motivating Gibbs to say. Piñata isn't a major lyrical departure from the last-real-gangsta-standing attitude that's kept Gibbs defiantly his own unfiltered self over the last five years. But his tendency to let the beat inspire certain facets of his writing has resulted in a record that
column5: true to the underheard yet memory-stirring undercurrents of Madlib's production source material
column6: is fueled by a certain kind of grown-man reflection. There's a deep awareness of how the embattled dealer from Gary has and hasn't changed on the way to becoming an L.A.-based enthusiast's favorite—renowned enough to get Scarface and Raekwon on his record
column7: but for reasons that run deeper than just having famous co-signs. Many of Gibbs' lyrics on Piñata ride a line between pride in his own resilient hustle and ambivalence about what he did to succeed—maybe not guilt
column8: but at least a concerted effort to confront his colder impulses. His stories of a talented man making his way in a bleak environment are brought up without either glamorization or moralizing
column9: but they still feel human. Funk-fusion and soul jazz breaks bubble and blister in the heat
column10: throbbing like a running man's pulse
column11: and Gibbs states the facts as he sees them.

column1: Gibbs is nothing if not an anti-bullshit activist
column2: even if it means casting the occasional doubt upon himself or staring down his own contradictions. There's a great line on ""Deeper"" where he abruptly gets introspective after he confronts a woman who got pregnant by another man while Gibbs was in jail—""Maybe you's a stank ho
column3: maybe that's a bit mean/ Maybe you grew up and I'm still livin' like I'm sixteen""—and a taut verse on ""Broken"" that address the supposed irony of having a cop for a father (""I'm a crook and you crooked
column4: that's all we had in common""). Those are just a couple highlights; so many of Piñata's best moments are fueled by this sense that Gibbs knows he did wrong but also knows that letting any remorse slip would've potentially made him look weak. There's also a bit of triumph in there somewhere
column5: not in the fact of what he's done and seen
column6: but in the basic fact of his still being around to relay these things. This is a record that sounds really lived-in
column7: in both the sense that it's been steadily labored over and the sense that it's focused on the personal details that come with years of weighted memories.

column1: There are other cuts that focus more on the man Gibbs is now than the situation that made him
column2: and they don't lack for urgency
column3: either. ""Real"" is Gibbs' Young Jeezy dis track
column4: which stands out as razor's-edge wrath in a hip-hop world that mostly sticks to subtweeting and passive-aggressive maneuvers; that it's based in actual creative grievances and personal fallout instead of just hearsay and general disrespect only makes the lacerations deeper. Paired together
column5: ""Lakers"" and ""Knicks"" draws a straight line from his current pilgrimage-paying L.A. transplant status back to the early-days nickel-bag hustle that first proved his motivation. Even when he's doing a smoker's anthem—the blissed-out ""High
column6: featuring a characteristically hyperactive Danny Brown—there's an efficiently punchy energy that makes him sound ready to take on all comers. It's the same kind of energy that puts him on the same level as Chef (""Bomb"") and Mr. Scarface (""Broken"") when it comes to vivid crime-life narrative
column7: lets him play virtuoso shit-talk mentor to Domo Genesis and Earl Sweatshirt (""Robes"")
column8: and has him leave such a dominant impression that it makes the otherwise-solid title-track closer seem like a mood-breaking outlier simply because it goes too many bars without his voice.

column1: The way Gibbs uses that voice in the context of the production that deserves special attention here. Gibbs' acknowledged debt to 2Pac is paid back with a versatile
column2: musical flow that seeps into and builds up the structure of the Madlib beats beneath it; his tendency to use the same intonation for both intricately tight-knit verses and simple
column3: to-the-point hooks highlights just how skilled he is at both. He went in and challenged himself to rap fluidly over under-quantized drums and succeeds to the point where it feels like he snaps them into place himself. And that'd be noteworthy enough if this didn't double as some of Madlib's most inspired production since his Beat Konducta 00s—with Gibbs' deep resonance sinking into spaced-out synth-prog (""Bomb""; ""Uno"")
column4: air-suspension glide R&B (""Robes""; ""Shame"")
column5: and butterfly-knife-wielding splatter-flick funk (""Scarface""; ""Real""). He even gets in the spirit of the comedic interstitial skits that're Madlib's stock in trade; while the blaxploitation dialogue and trailer snippets are fitting enough (and add some faded film-grain quality to the proceedings)
column6: the goofy kazoo-synth tag at the end of ""Robes"" where Gibbs mutters barbs aimed at industry-dependent fools is its own justification for the teamup on just about every level. It doesn't matter if Gibbs and Madlib were once considered artists playing to different audiences -- united in their uncompromising
column7: independent-as-fuck visions
column8:
they put together something hardcore hip-hop heads on both sides should feel.

There were dead rats in the walls of Steve Fisk’s Avast! Studios in Seattle
column2: recounts the liner notes of the new Unwound box set Rat Conspiracy
column3: when the trio of drummer Sara Lund
column4: bassist Vern Rumsey
column5: and singer-guitarist Justin Trosper convened there in March of 1994 to mix their album New Plastic Ideas. After hours upon hours at the board
column6: it got to be too much. Mingling with the perpetual pall of stale cigarette smoke in the studio
column7: the stench of decomposing rodent was so bad that Lund had to run outside just to catch her breath.

column1: Murky
column2: anxious
column3: asphyxiating: That’s the atmosphere New Plastic Ideas—and its 1993 predecessor Fake Train—conveys. The Olympia-based band had recorded and aborted what would have been their debut 12” in 1992
column4: originally slated for the new local label Kill Rock Stars
column5: but drummer Brandt Sandeno had quit before it could come out. The album was shelved (later to be released as Unwound
column6: included in the recent Kid Is Gone box set) and Lund was brought aboard. Her liquid
column7: unhurried drumming only added to the group’s gooey undertow. Old songs were scrapped and new ones written to accommodate this uncharted chemistry. It seemed to seep everywhere at once—grunge
column8: pigfuck
column9: indie-rock
column10: post-hardcore
column11: punk—collecting residue as it went along. In a decade where anti-packaging was the ultimate irony
column12: Unwound cloaked itself in the dirty earnestness of necessity.

column1: Rat Conspiracy collects Fake Train and New Plastic Ideas along with a third album of 7” singles
column2: radio sessions
column3: compilation appearances
column4: and unreleased tracks from 1993 and 1994. Together they comprise Unwound’s first true statement. It’s a garbled one. From the lazily sadistic whiplash of “Dragnalus” to strangulated stasis of “Feeling$ Real”
column5: Fake Train lurches
column6: twists
column7: and turns in on itself
column8: as if manifesting some perverse
column9: extended metaphor for the feedback that laces nearly ever track. “I don’t feel strange/ I don’t feel at all”
column10: Trosper mumbles on “Dragnalus” like a kid made to stand in the corner. Then he screams his fucking face off.

column1: That drift between hesitance and horror underscores “Lucky Acid
column2: ” in which Trosper’s vocals wander in as if the mic got turned on too late; soon the muted jangle of his guitar swells into a Morse-code distress call banged out on naked nerve endings. And the trilogy of “Valentine Card”
column3: “Kantina”
column4: and “Were
column5: Are and Was or Is”—Fake Train’s own “The Wonder”
column6: “Hyperstation”
column7: and “Eliminator Jr.”—not only mimic Sonic Youth in structure
column8: but in the delicate
column9: dissonant
column10: Daydream Nation-esque instrumental “Were
column11: Are and Was or Is”. But Rumsey’s blood-chugging bass line on “Valentine Card” is pure Jesus Lizard
column12: even as Lund’s impressionistic percussion dots the rhythm.

column1: There’s sausage being made here
column2: but gristle keep clogging up the grinder. “Ratbite”
column3: the album’s lone hardcore song
column4: comes on like an homage to Wire’s “1 2 X U” as filtered through Minor Threat and a broken bottle of Robitussin. Vintage punk gets more directly referenced on the bonus track “Census
column5: ” a cavernous noise spasm from 1994’s “Negated” 7” that ends with a sample of Billy Idol’s goofy line “A heavy heavy dub
column6: punk rockers!” from the throwaway Generation X song “Wild Dub
column7: ” a dub version of their 1978 song “Wild Youth.” Echoes of echoes of echoes—yet with Unwound they congeal into a fugue of fucked-up signifiers as thick with collagist subversion as Fake Train’s Tom Jones-on-Sun Ra cover art.

column1: Of the remaining bonus tracks
column2: “Unsympathetica”
column3: “Untitled 1”
column4: and “Untitled 2” are previously unreleased. All three are napkin-drawn blueprints for songs that never were. Together they shed light on Unwound’s shambolic writing process
column5: a jam-based unraveling of knots of ideas rather than an act of construction. “Untitled 2” goes so far as to verge on start-stop
column6: hard-rock swagger
column7: more the area of expertise of Unwound’s close friends and contemporaries Karp. The sludge-shoveling “Mkultra”
column8: from the 7” of the same name
column9: could have even been a Karp cover. Rat Conspiracy’s only actual cover
column10: though
column11: is of the Minutemen’s “Plight”—and its throbbing atmospherics
column12: entwined voices
column13: and elegant spirals of abrasion are treated as both tribute and birthright.

column1: New Plastic Ideas is less a product of its input and more of a refinement of its lack thereof—a process of weeding out
column2: as it were
column3: regarding Unwound’s blatant inspirations (Black Flag very much among them). There’s a huge leap in articulation here
column4: both in gesture and enunciation
column5: from Fake Train. “Entirely Different Matters” masters one of Trosper’s guitar trademarks
column6: a layered
column7: symphonic squeal of opening feedback
column8: while “Usual Dosage” does the same for another
column9: the crystalline dissonance of harmonics. But the dynamics refuse to lapse into patterns
column10: as the pinpoint noise-squibs made predictable by Fugazi are deployed with counterintuitive chaos. On “Envelope”—one of Unwound’s most indelible songs
column11: a study in inverted
column12: charred-hearted near-pop—melody morphs into menace and is never resolved. By the time the seven-minute sprawl of “Abstraktions” (which features Fisk on keyboards) veers down a harrowing
column13: Side-Two-of-Joy-Division’s-Closer corridor
column14: the shape of Unwound to come has been all but sketched out.

column1: Seeing Unwound in a freezing warehouse in the mid-90s was glimpse into that future. Wrapped in ratty scarves
column2: playing with fingerless gloves
column3: their breaths curling like smog in the frigid cold
column4: they lugged around with them a miasma of sourness. Their music didn’t move the air in the room so much as curdle it. Their records to date—meticulously overdubbed
column5: immaculately raw—had not been ample warning. What the hell was going on? This was a DIY punk show; it was supposed to feel in some way collective and cathartic. Instead—like Lund in the mixing room during the New Plastic Ideas sessions—those of us in the sparse audience were struck numb and left gasping for oxygen. Unwound had sucked it all in
column6: stunk it all up
column7: fed it back to us as a sad
column8: blackened racket.

column1: Fake Train and New Plastic Ideas hold important places in the history of 90s music
column2: not to mention those of punk and indie as a whole. And they set the tone for unimagined Unwound greatness to come (which will be chronicled in subsequent volumes of the box-set series). But those two albums
column3: and the tracks that accompany them on Rat Conspiracy
column4: transcend time
column5: place
column6: attitude
column7: and even the sprawling continuum of influence. More than any other records of their generation
column8: they embody a paradox that disaffected youth has been stabbing at since the advent of rock ’n’ roll: how it feels to be cocooned among strangers in utter alienation
column9:
yet stand as one.

column2: Garvey’s symbology has gotten that much more sodden and heavy-handed
column3: even as Take Off steadfastly sheds mass. On “Fly Boy Blue/ Lunette”
column4: he’s traded in his rockets for the drudgery of commercial flight with all its degradation of wonder. Garvey’s in-flight movie may have been Up in the Air one too many times. Singing “I’m reaching the age where decisions are made on the life and the liver
column5: he falls back on the bottle as a totem of existential boredom. His voice itself—numb
column6: null
column7: narcotic—spreads its warmth around that imagistic mixology. “So bring your faces/ Home to my sweet trampoline/ And acres of crash site love
column8: he waxes later in “Fly Boy Blue/ Lunette”
column9: and only the song’s bittersweet orchestral swells save it from falling out of the sky.

column1: Moments of greatness come
column2: just not often enough. The contorted syncopation and signature-twiddling of “Charge”—as well as its thick keys and dehydrated guitar—establish some real counterpoint and tension
column3: elements the album otherwise mostly lacks. And Garvey’s in-character narrative summons pathos
column4: tangible rage
column5: and the entitled bitterness of old age and memory. He bites off words
column6: chews them
column7: spits; Roger Waters circa The Final Cut might have been proud. It complements Take Off’s other standout
column8: its title track
column9: a wash of throbbing
column10: “Tomorrow Never Knows”-esque psychedelia that also channels Garvey’s most open inspiration of late
column11: Peter Gabriel.

column1: Those gains are almost entirely erased by lusterless lumps like “Honey Sun”
column2: a song that begins promisingly with a clip of off-the-cuff studio hijinks before devolving into Elbow’s longtime default setting: a discrete if uninentional reimagining of Blur’s “Tender
column3: ” in all its crowd-baiting
column4: platitudinous blankness. “Can I jump in the gun/ And fly/ Over the ocean” goes Garvey’s obligatory air-travel reference as he lands his 747-sized sentimentalism right on the nose. Perhaps it’s deliberate that throughout The Take Off and Landing of Everything
column5: hardly anything truly takes off. Instead the album dangles there
column6: an effortlessly leaden exhibition of glum triumphalism—and an example of what makes Elbow
column7: at its least potent
column8:
so subtly unsubtle.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20301/homepage_large.28b2cfc6.jpg|The Aquaplano Sessions|23550.0|Donato Dozzy|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Spectrum Spools']|2014-03-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:18.327454|"

For the last decade
column2: Italian electronic maestro Donato “Dozzy” Scaramuzzi’s been regaled as a leading light of his home country’s unheralded electronic music scene
column3: but he only started garnering greater acclaim in 2012 with the sumptuous project Voices From the Lake. A collaboration with one of his Italian progeny
column4: producer Giuseppe Tillieci (a.k.a. Neel)
column5: Voices From the Lake’s eponymous debut was an instant classic in electronic music circles
column6: a hallmark of ambient techno to be slotted alongside the likes of Manuel Göttsching’s E2-E4
column7: Aphex Twin’s Selected Ambient Works Volume II
column8: the KLF's Chill Out
column9: and Gas’ Pop.

column1: Voices From the Lake was a masterwork of the organic and the electronic: choirs
column2: bells
column3: frogs
column4: and field recordings all melded with Dozzy and Neel's hardware to form an evocative
column5: ethereal whole. It was a biosphere that doubled as a symphony
column6: a lagoon as a minimal godhead
column7: Berghain from a submerged Atlantis. That sound wasn’t without precedent: in 2008
column8: Dozzy collaborated with another producer whose moniker differed from Neel’s by one letter: Nuel
column9: a.k.a. Italian producer Manuel Fogliata. On a series of 12”s released on the short-lived Aquaplano imprint
column10: the duo set the table for Voices From the Lake’s successes. Since the price range for those 12”s have reached triple-digits on Discogs
column11: the Spectrum Spools label have thankfully compiled those four transmissions into one heavy package.

column1: When the earliest Aquaplano 12”s appeared in Berlin’s Hardwax record shop
column2: minimal techno was at a cul-de-sac. Sandwell District’s early singles pointed towards a way out
column3: utilizing slightly slower BPMs and abrasive tones to revive the form; in contrast
column4: Dozzy and Nuel’s efforts were decidedly out of fashion. Their first Aquaplano single revealed a love of hazy ambient washes
column5: as well as tribal drum programming that
column6: at a certain meter
column7: could be tagged as trance.

column1: Like a centuries-dormant giant virus that scientists resuscitate in the 21st century
column2: “tribal trance” is not the sort of '90s electronic music genre to be revived lightly. Yet
column3: on “Aquaplano 4”
column4: Dozzy and Nuel reveal an artisanal touch and sense of craft that belies any concern of worldwide aesthetic cataclysm
column5: while “Aquaplano 1” makes minimal techno as rendered by an amoeba
column6: metallic and fleshy. Some tracks find Dozzy & Nuel gnashing like an early Drexciya outing
column7: salt water sloshing around their circuitry
column8: while the shakers and hi-hats of “Aquaplano 2” flutter like a butterfly
column9: the bass hits echoing through Basic Channel’s supercollider. Functional though these tracks may be
column10: they hint at the grandiose direction Dozzy would later take.

column1: In the years that followed
column2: Dozzy refined that aesthetic
column3: leading up to the glorious career peak of Voices From the Lake; on the new Velo di Maya EP on NYC dance party-cum-imprint the Bunker
column4: Voices From the Lake trawl into darker
column5: more sinister soundworlds not too far from the likes of Demdike Stare. Listen to the title track on headphones while waiting for the subway
column6: and the low-level
column7: distant metallic scraping it opens with might have you leaning over repeatedly to see if a train is approaching. In the dark
column8: that sound might also be breathing
column9: the aural hallucinations of Voices From the Lake already at work; the track's ethereal opening minutes darkens about three minutes in
column10: as the bass turns sinister.

column1: “Sentiero” foregrounds the beat moreso than on previous Voices From the Lake tracks
column2: with high frequencies howling at a tribal throb. The eight-minute “Respiro” comprises the entire B-side
column3: throbbing
column4: creaking
column5: and as noisy as cicadas come nightfall. The EP moves at a velocity decidedly faster than anything on their debut
column6:
suggesting that Voices From the Lake might not be so ambient after all.

"|19095.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19095-donato-dozzy-nuel-voices-from-the-lake-the-aquaplano-sessions-velo-di-maya-ep/|8.0|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20338/homepage_large.ef0f458d.jpg|Soft Opening|32128.0|Posse|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Beating A Dead Horse']|2014-03-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:19.045454|"
Posse does not have some kind of marvelous origin story
column2: there is no blood oath or volatile
column3: undeniable chemistry. The songwriting duo of Paul Wittmann-Todd and Sacha Maxim met during a show at a Seattle lesbian bar and decided to collaborate because the former ""didn't have a lot of other options."" On their sophomore album Soft Opening
column4: Wittmann-Todd and Maxim exhibit that same kind of non-committal camaraderie
column5: as their vocals do not harmonize or intertwine or do battle; most of the time
column6: they exchange one-sided conversations
column7: acknowledging each other and going about their business. Every instrument is given enough space to do whatever it wants as long as it cleans up after itself. It's the musical equivalent of roommates who randomly linked up on Craigslist and totally worked things out. Whatever qualities this might suggest in Posse as people lend a lived-in bumminess to Soft Opening
column8: imbuing its no-frills
column9: rumpled indie rock with a discernible point of view and more importantly
column10: a personality.

column1: That’s important
column2: because this is really no-frills indie rock. The most notable studio tricks Posse employ are a fuzz pedal
column3: a tambourine
column4: and the occasional echo on Maxim’s vocals. Either Wittmann-Todd is playing an extremely avant-garde solo during a portion of “Jon” or they simply didn’t feel like overdubbing a flubbed take. On the up-tempo numbers
column5: Posse recall a rainy day Real Estate
column6: a less bookish Galaxie 500
column7: or Yo La Tengo driven by a equivocal
column8: platonic friendship. On slower-than-slowcore “Talk""
column9: they’re all but mesmerized by their own torpor
column10: situated somewhere in between Pavement’s “Stop Breathing” and Built to Spill’s “Cleo” in terms of uncomfortably numb guitar heroism. Similar to those bands
column11: Posse make music that is lo-fi without sounding cheap
column12: purposeful minimalism that can sound strangely expansive: Maxim and Wittmann-Todd’s vocals are barely projected without being off-key
column13: and the guitar leads have an effortless melodicism whenever they take over. Even if most of these songs could be strummed out from a beanbag chair
column14: Posse always add a chord that fancies things up just enough.

column1: Posse describe their sound as “delay pedals and 27 years of disappointment”
column2: which may not be factually correct; you hear a lot more of the latter than the former
column3: and the second line of opener “Interesting Thing No. 2” is “You turned 25
column4: so many things you haven’t tried.” It’s theoretically sound all the same
column5: since Soft Opening’s self-deprecation is a big part of its appeal. For all of its invocations of 80s and 90s A-listers
column6: Soft Opening is an of-the-moment record in the way it aligns with the sort of sitcoms that dominate the viewing habits of people Posse’s age: the actors involved are presented as friends
column7: yet they don’t really seem to like each other all that much.

column1: In the case of Soft Opening
column2: nearly every song is a subtly hilarious metacommentary on some sort of communication breakdown. Maxim sings
column3: “I know you’re gonna talk through this and not care
column4: ” and you can easily visualize the shoulder shrug
column5: the eye-rolling
column6: the internal defeat she anticipates with this interaction. With every repetition
column7: it cuts deeper and deeper as an insult: you are someone who simply can’t handle sitting in silence with their own feelings. A song later on “Shut Up”
column8: a drunk and bored Wittmann-Todd fantasizes about a time when he’s going to work up the nerve to tell someone to shut their yap
column9: even if it’s himself: “I’m gonna watch you go outside now/ And make a stupid face/ And shut up.""

column1: And yet
column2: none of this venting comes off as mean-spirited. In fact
column3: most of Soft Opening unwinds with the casual bonhomie of three post-work beers over darts; the deleterious effects are minimal compared to the necessary release and bonding. And hell
column4: if Posse seem to have a strange enjoyment for each other’s company in spite of it all
column5: well
column6: it’s because the outside world doesn’t have that much more to offer. “Cassandra B.” relates a date between overeducated
column7: underfunded Seattlites as they down too much vodka
column8: go to an “intelligent rap” show (“A bald white guy/ With a mumu onstage”) and lie about reading Willa Cather books that were bought at college and promptly shelved. As with every dryly hysterical line on Soft Opening
column9: there’s never any “pitchiness”; it’s never trying to be any more droll and absurd than life itself.

column1: Despite the litany of disappointments
column2: misunderstandings
column3: and aimlessness befalling the narrators in these songs
column4: Soft Opening is a record of oddly stoic presence. For one thing
column5: the austere sonics and plainspoken lyrics ensure that nothing gets glossed overso it's a tough record to tune out. But also
column6: Posse sound exactly like the band they want to be—you don’t sense any musical ambition unmet
column7: any word misplaced. It’s a modest record done confidently
column8: enough to end with a six-minute guitar workout based around the lyric that perfectly encapsulates Soft Opening’s comforting sadness
column9:
its satisfied misanthropy: “Don’t touch me/ I’m in my zone.”

"|19132.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19132-posse-soft-opening/|7.9|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20305/homepage_large.bc5bee30.jpg|Dean Wareham|13962.0|Dean Wareham|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Double Feature']|2014-03-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:19.725548|"

Dean Wareham has always presented himself as a music fan as much as a musician
column2: the sort of artist for whom it’s not uncommon to devote at least 20% of an album to cover songs. But whether he was reinterpreting George Harrison with Galaxie 500 or Guns 'N Roses with Luna
column3: it never felt like Wareham was just showing off his record collection for the sake of it
column4: or worse
column5: being ironic. Rather
column6: he was asserting his platonic ideal of pop music
column7: separating iconic artists from their historical baggage
column8: and distilling the songs down to the intimate
column9: personal connection and details that made him an enthusiast in the first place. It’s an approach that went into overdrive with Dean & Britta
column10: Wareham’s mid-2000s collaboration with ex-Luna-bassist-turned-wife Britta Phillips; the couple’s covers-stacked releases captured the sound of newlyweds rolling around on the living-room floor amid piles of their favorite 45s during a red wine-fueled all-nighter. But
column11: naturally
column12: every nocturnal reverie must be followed by a moment when you have to face the day again.

column1: It’s tempting to read into the fact that
column2: following that seemingly successful musical and matrimonial partnership
column3: Wareham is now releasing records under his own name for the first time in his nearly three-decade career. While Phillips is still in the picture
column4: she’s reverted from star-player status to a background role amid Wareham’s mise en scene. Her presence as a muse
column5: however
column6: is as powerful as ever: Like last year’s Emancipated Hearts EP
column7: Wareham’s new self-titled full-length is less Dean & Britta than Dean to Britta. It’s an album that humorously but honestly explores the tensions that arise in any long-term relationship
column8: however in this case
column9: the pressures—financial
column10: political
column11: or otherwise—seem to be coming more from without than within. “I’m living in a holding pattern
column12: ” Wareham confesses on the album’s deceptively sprightly centerpiece “Holding Pattern”
column13: but it’s not the proverbial seven-year itch that’s nagging at him so much as the humdrum
column14: 9-to-5 uniformity of modern American life
column15: where even in an era of “drop-down menus
column16: ” it can be hard to distinguish sports-ticker reports from the 1970s arena-rock dinosaurs still clogging up the FM airwaves (“Kansas
column17: Boston
column18: Toto
column19: Journey
column20: Foreigner
column21: and Styx/ San Diego over Denver 17 to 6”).

column1: In the face of such demoralizing conditions
column2: it can be hard to keep one’s spirits up even in a happy coupling
column3: but the standout tracks here suggest that
column4: while it may be unsentimental to think of relationship as work
column5: it’s the sort of labor that yields rewards: “We’ll love you in the lean times
column6: ” Wareham assures on “My Eyes Are Blue”
column7: a song whose title evokes a classic track by his beloved Velvet Underground
column8: but whose winsome jangle sounds more like the sort of early-60s pop confections Lou Reed would’ve cranked out in his pre-VU song-factory stint. And as Wareham observes
column9: in a world dominated by “Heartless People”
column10: romanticism becomes akin to radicalism—when he sings
column11: “You and I/ Hate to see a flower die
column12: ” it’s less an expression of twee-as-fuck sensitivity than a defiant assertion of one’s humanity even as the bastards try to get you down.

column1: Once again
column2: Wareham’s turned to his record collection for emotional guidance
column3: though instead of simply covering some of his favorite artists
column4: he’s taken to enlisting younger contemporaries as collaborators. On Emancipated Hearts
column5: he ceded the console to Jason Quever
column6: aka Sub Pop indie-pop savant Papercuts
column7: and for this more sonically elaborate recording
column8: he's given himself over to My Morning Jacket’s Jim James
column9: a relationship that dates back to Wareham’s obsession with MMJ’s 1999 debut
column10: The Tennessee Fire. Though James’ aesthetic has obviously evolved greatly from the rustic simplicity of that album
column11: his name is still synonymous with a certain strain of cosmic Americana
column12: and the sparkling
column13: synth-washed productions of “Beat the Devil” and “Love Is Not a Roof Against the Rain” balance the retro and futurist in a fashion reminiscent of post-Deserter’s Songs Mercury Rev
column14: providing Wareham with the cocoon-like insulation from the outside world he seeks.

column1: But
column2: perhaps owing to Wareham’s recent acts of self-reflection—penning an autobiography
column3: dusting off Galaxie 500 standards in concert—this album functions firmly within the various comfort zones he's inhabited over the years
column4: spanning the dreamy drone of his first band (see: “Babes in the Woods”
column5: featuring a rare showing of Wareham’s long-dormant falsetto) to the sort of electronic-inflected pop he toyed with in Dean & Britta. Given the dichotomy between Wareham’s dry
column6: plainspoken demeanor and James’ shoot-for-the-stratosphere tendencies
column7: this album is an epic of modest proportions
column8: a Pocketbook Dean Wareham to go with your Portable Galaxie 500. In more calculated hands
column9: the pulsating groove of the closing “Happy & Free” could be elevated into a “With Or Without You”-sized anthem
column10: but Wareham is content to just calmly ride it out at his patient pace
column11: and enjoy the moment of peace—because he knows it won’t last. He may claim he’s “happy and free
column12: ” but he adds
column13: with typically understated sardonicism
column14: “for a while.” And
column15: as ever
column16:
the least his songs can do is make those short whiles feel like they could last forever. 

"|19098.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19098-dean-wareham-dean-wareham/|7.5|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20278/homepage_large.e1382aa6.jpg|Young Money: Rise of an Empire|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young Money Entertainment']|2014-03-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:20.532752|"

Young Money
column2: 2009: Lil Wayne lands on slightly wobbly legs following one of the greatest runs in rap history and extends each arm
column3: for support
column4: to a couple of ascendant stars he’s helped discover
column5: recruit
column6: and mold. To his left is Drake
column7: a kid climbing the ranks and finding chart success despite—or with the help of—his soft Canadian heart and stint as a television actor. To his right is Nicki Minaj
column8: the Queens-bred Trinidadian princess with a handful of dextrous features and a couple of fireball mixtapes behind her
column9: the “Monster” verse still to come. Supervised by Birdman
column10: they’re surrounded by a gaggle of hyperactive oddballs
column11: a motley crew that compensates for its lack of raw skill and starpower with versatility
column12: sheer enthusiasm
column13: and tiger-print pants. They post up in a mansion like it’s summer camp
column14: playing foosball and squirting each other with water guns. Morale and camaraderie is high
column15: and they sound as though they’re having a ton of fun.

column1: Young Money
column2: 2014: Lil Wayne
column3: for all intents and purposes
column4: is a fallen hero after a long string of unrecognizably weak projects. His duo of star underlings
column5: however
column6: have scaled the heights of both rap and pop and helped build powerful bridges between the two. Their supporting motley crew is still essentially the same supporting motley crew
column7: if a bit thinned out and dramatically less excitable. Whereas 2009’s compilation We Are Young Money found Wayne and his cohort proudly kicking open doors and announcing their plans for world domination with jester-like sneers and grins
column8: Rise of an Empire positions Young Money as a collective unsmilingly guarding its moneyed perch. “Long as we living right/ Then we alright/ Long as it’s high life/ Then we alright
column9: ” goes the bridge of “We Alright”
column10: a lead single tinged with the paranoia of a pack of artists taking stock of exactly what they’ve still got in their collective grasp.

column1: If Rise of an Empire is meant to read like some kind of State of the Union address
column2: it paints Young Money as a fractured team that’s lost its compass. Minaj and Drake have fallen so far out of the orbit of Young Money’s pedestrian rings that their contributions almost feel like charity—Drake’s “Trophies” appears on the project months after he released the song for free on SoundCloud through his own OVO imprint. Nicki Minaj’s “Lookin’ Ass”
column3: which she released along with a brutal
column4: artfully shot black-and-white video last month
column5: feels similarly detached from the rest of the compilation
column6: and reads more like a promotion for her forthcoming studio album. Both tracks are highlights and sonic outliers on Rise of an Empire
column7: and they stand in sharp contrast to the rest of the compilation
column8: which—beyond the typical unevenness of any crew album—is largely joyless and anonymous.

column1: The group’s youngest rapper
column2: Lil Twist—who’s gained more of a reputation through his misadventures with Justin Bieber than anything else he’s done in recent years—boasts about hanging with Atlanta’s Rich Homie Quan and 2 Chainz rather than Lil Wayne on a song “Bang”. Yes
column3: “Bang”
column4: a hollow retooling of the song that put drill kingpin Chief Keef on the map. Even Tyga
column5: who created a legitimate ripple in the rap pond a couple of years ago with “Rack City” and followed through with a decent album
column6: sounds bored. The only figure with real energy is new Young Money signee Euro
column7: a rapper with an unfortunate name but an imperious presence. But on his boastful coming-out statement “Induction Speech
column8: ” he sounds aware of his diminished surroundings: “I flew afternoon and made it by night/ I landed/ The flight was amazing/ I just stayed up and write
column9: ” he raps about his arrival
column10: before confessing: “Chauffeur was waiting with a sign/ Except my name wasn’t right.” He goes on to crack about forgetting to text Mack Maine
column11: Young Money’s effective director of operations
column12: once he’s gotten in town.

column1: Lil Wayne
column2: who's allegedly gearing up to release the fifth installment of Tha Carter
column3: sums up Rise of an Empire pretty tidily on ""Moment"": ""Lately all I been doing is celebrating/ Don't even know why I'm celebrating."" But he certainly has one reason to celebrate: Drake and Minaj
column4: despite their evident drift from the day-to-day operations of Young Money
column5: remain deeply loyal to he and Birdman. A DVD released along with the deluxe edition of Nicki Minaj’s last album pictures her alongside Wayne
column6: presenting him with a brand new car for his birthday and faithfully referring to him as the President. She and Drake clearly remember the days when they were lucky to have Young Money. Rise of an Empire paints a different picture
column7:
one that emphasizes exactly how lucky Young Money is to still have them. 

"|19072.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19072-young-money-rise-of-an-empire/|4.9|Carrie Battan

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20267/homepage_large.df4d0748.jpg|"“Second Poem To Karmela"" Or Gypsies Are Important"|4967.0|Peter Walker|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-03-12 00:00:00|1968|2016-06-11 16:40:21.306486|"

The albums of guitarist Peter Walker and songwriter Bob Frank don’t have a lot in common. Walker emerged in the mid-60s as an adventurous multi-instrumentalist
column2: a peripatetic polyglot whose enthusiasms would ultimately make him a student of both Ali Akbar Khan and
column3: d.dmQ"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">flamenco guitar
column4: plus the musical pied piper to Timothy Leary’s lysergic Millbrook hideaway. His tunes epitomize late-60s psychedelic experimentation
column5: with tufts of notes from his nylon-string guitar or sarod blooming into ecstatic bliss. But Bob Frank was a Tennessee kid who liked the blues and country music
column6: Bob Dylan and Gordon Lightfoot. He’d tried to write commercial hits in Nashville
column7: but his sharp-penned historical ruminations and lyrical snapshots never climbed any charts
column8: due in part to his own obstinacy about them. One seemed to be the Okie From Muskogee
column9: the other the dope-smoking California hippy who would’ve been arrested on his way through town.

column1: But Walker’s second album
column2: “<i>Second Poem to Karmela
column3: ” or Gypsies Are Important
column4: and Frank’s self-titled debut are the first two titles of an exciting new series from the resurrection-prone imprint Light in the Attic
column5: in which they will raid the deepest vaults of Vanguard Records. Established in 1947
column6: Vanguard served as an essential syndicate for the folk music of the world
column7: with albums from The Weavers and Doc Watson and Joan Baez countered by recordings from Israel and Norway and Asia. It’s one of the most intimidating catalogues in American music history
column8: a story as rich as those of Paramount or Okeh.

column1: Something that Walker and Frank did share was a deep disinterest in playing their record label’s commercial games. As they both recount in the extensive first-person liner notes included in each reissue
column2: they made decisions after the release of their respective albums they knew would get them blacklisted. At an album release concert in New York
column3: Vanguard co-founder Maynard Solomon told Frank to play something from the new record. “If anybody wants to hear the songs off the album
column4: let ’em go buy the fucking album!” he said. Not long before Walker recorded Second Poem
column5: he canceled a string of gigs to study with Khan
column6: a move that dismayed the label but gave him the technical abilities necessary to make the album at all. “You’ll never work again!” they told him. In both cases
column7: these LPs were the last that either musician released for the next 30 years
column8: as both retreated into the private lives of raising their families and quietly building their craft. During the last decade
column9: both Walker and Frank have released more music than in the previous half-century combined
column10: meaning these two albums at least share something else: Though they seemed to be endpoints
column11: they are both now unlikely new beginnings.

column1: Bob Frank was an outlaw songwriter’s outlaw songwriter
column2: a Vietnam veteran and graduate school dropout who had been too stubborn to make it as part of the Nashville music machine. He was tougher than Kristofferson and more spry than Cash
column3: an often-jolly light in typically dark corners. He delighted in trouble
column4: did every drug
column5: wasted most weekends. “Memphis Jail""
column6: which closes this debut
column7: might start like a blues
column8: with the protagonist waiting to be released from his jail cell. But the despair is a feint
column9: as the police have only arrested the rebel for public inebriation. They have no idea he stole a car
column10: too. “I got off light
column11: ” he whoops
column12: a smile evident in his voice
column13: “considering how bad I am.” The quest for a little more weed leads to stringband delight during “She Pawned Her Diamond for Some Gold""
column14: an ode to any partner willing to sell jewelry for a joint. And “Layin’ Around” extends the bucolic vision of escape that infiltrated American and European roots music of the moment—a modicum of success that allows for family
column15: some comfort
column16: “a place of my own.” It’s a portrait of the wild one
column17: coming home to roost. “I circled around and I wound up here
column18: ” he croons. “A good place to be this time of the year.”

column1: The record lasts just longer than 30 minutes
column2: but if it feels lengthier and weightier than that
column3: it’s because Frank relates his characters with such strength and poignancy. Some of these sketches are autobiographical and some observational
column4: but all are rich with the annals of real life
column5: little details that pull these people off of the page or out of the record’s black groove. You know what “Wino” drinks and how he smells
column6: where he sleeps and what rodents can’t scare him. “Jones and Me” is a snapshot of a catch-up conversation Frank once had with a friend. In less than two minutes
column7: you learn about their boredom and their anxieties
column8: their preference for booze and their predilections for distraction. It’s as though you’re barside
column9: sitting between the two. Even “Judas Iscariot""
column10: an allegory of Jesus and the disciple who betrayed him
column11: feels like an account of yesterday; Frank recasts the Biblical pair as booze-and-weed buddies
column12: drunk at a party and given to the sort of philosophically deep conversations that tend to happen when all the wine is gone. Judas wasn’t a traitor
column13: Frank suggests
column14: but simply misunderstood by a friend too buzzed to listen. You want to stop and ponder these people
column15: to consider them as they might have been.

column1: Unlike Frank
column2: Walker enjoyed some of the perks of being a Vanguard artist before mostly disappearing. His debut
column3: Rainy Day Raga
column4: emerged in 1966
column5: just as John Fahey’s Takoma Records was gaining momentum and as the Beatles began to slip under the thrall of Indian music. He flirted with the zeitgeist; in fact
column6: Walker—for that part of his life
column7: a fortuitous friend of the famous—studied under Ravi Shankar alongside Beatle George Harrison. “It was like a bull by the tail
column8: like a rocket ride
column9: and all you could do was hang on
column10: ” he says of the period following Rainy Day’s release in an extensive interview by Glenn Jones that’s included with this reissue. Only two years passed between Rainy Day and its follow-up
column11: Second Poem
column12: but they are worlds apart in source and intention. Despite the Raga reference of his debut’s title
column13: Walker was just learning about Indian music
column14: a young white man from Massachusetts with a guitar. But he studied with Khan in the interim
column15: and Second Poem is delivered mostly with sarod
column16: the guitar showing up intermittently. Nearly half a century since its release
column17: the material remains intoxicatingly nebulous.

column1: Indeed
column2: these 10 pieces often feel as though they’re about to burst
column3: to split the seams of the gathered ensemble wide open. During “Circus Day
column4: ” Walker works through a patient sarod circuit
column5: trading lines with Jim Pepper’s flute. When the rhythm arrives
column6: they charge ahead
column7: their melodies wrapping constantly around one another. At one point toward the song’s midsection
column8: it feels as if they’ve all lost the plot and are just playing for the thrill of the sound
column9: not unlike Albert Ayler with his two-bass-and-violin band. They pull it together
column10: though
column11: winding slowly toward the song’s fading end. “Blake Street""
column12: which follows
column13: is a short
column14: ascendant piece for guitar
column15: a salve after a storm. Indeed
column16: such shifts in momentum and dynamics are a hallmark of Second Poem. The group smolders over the tamboura drone of “I & Thou” but leaps briefly into hyperkinetic passages. “Southwind” cycles from a lonely sarod meditation into a tense duel with the violin of John Blair.

column1: Throughout Second Poem
column2: you can hear Walker test the bounds of his own experimental realm
column3: his instruments pressing against the possibilities of the moment.  The closing “Mixture” is an ominous and enigmatic improvisation for keyboards
column4: violin
column5: tabla
column6: sarod and sitar
column7: where the various players puzzle out in real-time how these elements might work with one another. Remember
column8: this was 1968. Walker made another album after Second Poem
column9: 1970’s Has Anybody Seen Our Freedoms?
column10: though it was only released last year. But it’s more in line with his folk-singer antecedents and solo-guitar contemporaries
column11: not the alien abstraction of Second Poem. Had Walker pursued this path
column12: where might he have arrived?

column1: Light in the Attic’s continued tunneling of Vanguard vaults likely won’t answer those sort of questions
column2: but it will continue to raise them. What’s more
column3: these albums went out of print almost instantly
column4: meaning that they’ve been consistently expensive collector’s items for years. (Despite his seemingly encyclopedic knowledge of this broad school of guitarists
column5: even Jones didn’t know about Second Poem until 2004.) How might music sound if these albums had broken through cult obscurity
column6: if Frank or Walker had behaved? That doesn’t matter: For Frank’s humble documents of the commoner
column7: and for Walker’s willful exploration of the fringes
column8: this material demands to be heard by wider audiences. Now
column9:
they share that chance.
