column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20290/homepage_large.64d673dd.jpg|Untitled EP|32122.0|Benedek|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Peoples Potential Unlimited']|2014-03-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:21.841073|"

At the very end of 2013
column2: a white label 12” with only the name “Benedek” written on it came through the mail
column3: bereft of any other information whatsoever. And when the full-length album began arriving in shops last month
column4: it had about the same amount of info on it. There are eight tracks in total
column5: all of them untitled
column6: released by the Washington
column7: D.C. imprint Peoples Potential Unlimited.

column1: For the PPU label
column2: this is par for the course. Since 2008
column3: PPU’s catalog makes for strange
column4: eclectic listening
column5: primarily reissuing demo recordings from the early 80s of African-American acts hoping to be the next Earth Wind and Fire or Marvin Gaye. The bizarro world of boogie and R&B that PPU unearths—far from the upper echelons of kings like Michael Jackson and Prince— is fascinating stuff and almost any toe dip into the PPU catalog will reward listeners. But the label also releases music from acts similarly informed by such lost musics
column6: be it Tom Noble
column7: Psychic Mirrors or Benedek.

column1: A bit of research revealed that Nicholas Benedek hails from Los Angeles and while he’s had a few cassette-only comp appearances
column2: his only other release available to date is a collaboration with Dâm-Funk. Much like his peer Ariel Pink and how his hypnagogic pop vision influenced an entire generation of indie-rockers
column3: Dâm-Funk’s aesthetic seems to have had a similar effect on a new generation of post-Dilla producers
column4: drawing on obscure boogie
column5: funk
column6: freestyle
column7: house music
column8: modern soul and lost R&B to create a strange yet danceable new world of sound.

column1: There’s something uncanny and familiar about Benedek’s sound palette across these eight instrumentals: the bubbly synths
column2: the popping basslines
column3: the crisp drum machine hits
column4: the canned handclaps
column5: all of which evoke the production tropes of a bygone era. The first track has this sliver of sound that makes me think of Mr. Mister’s “Broken Wings""
column6: which may just be a trick of the mind akin to Ariel Pink’s
column7: in that it attaches itself to what you have stored in your own musical memory banks. Another section has the warm pads and chopped-up hand percussion reminiscent of a proto-house track
column8: interspersed with chimes. There are sounds that might bring to mind a workout video from the 80s
column9: unless you weren’t born in that decade
column10: in which case the bassline might instead sound like something from the early 90s. The third track features the sort of harmonica preset of an old synth and Jacuzzi-warm keyboard chords
column11: all set against the kind of boom-tick that my girlfriend would call “grown and sexy.”

column1: The fourth untitled track sticks out for me
column2: laced with the kind of hook that could either be from an obscure lite jazz album
column3: a rare modern soul 12
column4: ” or some sort of boogie track that might have gotten aired one night at the Paradise Garage
column5: full of airy guitar upstrokes. But perhaps it’s not a sample at all
column6: but rather from the mind and fingers of Benedek himself. His evocative debut
column7: while scrubbed of track titles
column8: vocals and eschewing easy genre categories from the past thirty years
column9:
nevertheless makes such blurred lines be part of its listening pleasure.

"|19084.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19084-benedek-untitled-ep/|7.6|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20291/homepage_large.174ed2f0.jpg|The Parasitic Survival of the Human Race|32123.0|Dodsferd|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Moribund']|2014-03-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:22.435190|"

Few love loathing as much as Wrath
column2: the evil mastermind behind Greece’s Dodsferd; in fact
column3: it’s all but certain that he actively hates you and me this very second. Asked by one interviewer what motivates him to keep pushing his devilish
column4: crusty strain of black metal
column5: Wrath offered a matter-of-fact reply: “My everlasting hate towards every living being!” And look how far that hate has taken him: what was once a one-man project has blossomed into a full quartet and spawned an impressive discography
column6: including eight full-length LPs (most notably
column7: 2007’s twin terrors
column8: Fucking Your Creation and Cursing Your Will to Live) and splits with Happy Days
column9: Necronoclast
column10: and others.

column1: Now we have The Parasitic Survival of the Human Race
column2: a blistering suite with a relentless hardcore heartbeat
column3: and a work surrounded on all sides by the sounds of humanity at its most delirious—specifically
column4: the screams and sirens that flooded the streets of Athens during the 2012 riots. A muffled gunshot
column5: the blood-curdling curses of protesters
column6: seas of white noise: chaos seeps into every square inch of interstitial tissue separating the album’s five tracks
column7: sustaining a mob scene for the album’s duration. The motif gets a bit tiresome by record's end
column8: but at least initially
column9: the confusion inherent in this aural overload lends itself well to gut-wrenching surprises like the jagged riff that crashes down a minute into the “Stupid Worthless Sheep”. Aside from providing plenty of thrills
column10: the The Parasitic Survival of the Human Race also boasts the clearest
column11: tightest production on a Dodsferd album to date
column12: continuing the sonic clean-up that began on 2008’s Death Set the Beginning of My Journey. Wrath’s once-garbled screams cut into the din a bit more now
column13: shaking with the organic intensity of a Jacob Bannon or Erlend Hjelvik.

column1: Those extra dashes of punk in the mix lend the album some welcome immediacy
column2: but neither the airtight mixing nor the catchy riffs can mitigate redundancy altogether. On opener “Breeding Chaos”
column3: Nadir seems content to carry meat-and-potatoes hardcore riffs past the point of disinterest
column4: dulling their sawtoothed impact; “Doubting Your Worth” suffers from the same water-treading
column5: spared at the last minute by a teeth-gnashing coda. At a lean
column6: mean three minutes
column7: you'd think the cover of the Misfits’ “We Are 138” that closes the record would be the perfect way to shake off the doldrums of the mammoth tracks that precede it and provide a satisfying
column8: succinct conclusion to the party. It’s a shame that the tribute morphs into a strange game of vocal showboating by the third verse
column9: only to disappear into the apocalyptic Athens soundscapes for good. It’s almost as though Wrath got bored.

column1: And there's the rub: The Parasitic Survival of the Human Race is the leanest Dodsferd LP to date
column2: packing all that misery into five tracks in thirty minutes
column3: but it still can’t shake off its bloat. Die-hard misanthropists will most likely be able to overlook the tedium and bask in the glory of the gospel of Wrath
column4: but for the rest of us
column5:
the album feels uninspired.

"|19085.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19085-dodsferd-the-parasitic-survival-of-the-human-race/|5.8|Zoe Camp

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20124/homepage_large.55ef39bd.jpg|Zentropy|31974.0|Frankie Cosmos|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Double Double Whammy']|2014-03-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:23.207339|"

Indie-pop has always privileged shy people who manage their world by making it feel as small as possible. Enter Greta Kline
column2: a 19-year-old who records under the name Frankie Cosmos. Her new album
column3: Zentropy
column4: is 10 songs and less than 20 minutes long
column5: opening with a complaint about art school and closing with the eulogy of a pet dog. In between are explorations of love
column6: aging
column7: and the other intricacies of private life
column8: all rendered with the simplicity of a stick-figure drawing.

column1: As its title suggests
column2: Zentropy is a playful but disciplined album. Most of it consists of pretty
column3: tuneful music in a tradition that connects Best Coast to Beat Happening to pared-down takes on 1960s girl-group pop
column4: anchored by a three-piece drum set and an electric guitar—the utility kit of a band that occasionally wants to get loud without ever having to leave the living room. Its longest song is two and a half minutes long
column5: and its best
column6: “Birthday Song”
column7: is just over a minute. “Just because I am a certain age
column8: doesn’t mean that I am any older/ Than I was yesterday
column9: ” it starts
column10: Kline’s voice as sweet as a child’s but firm as a board.

column1: Kline is not afraid of cute
column2: self-evident statements like this
column3: nor is she afraid of using them as a bait-and-switch for more complicated ones. “I think how repulsive to you it must be when I refuse to do the things you want me to
column4: ” she sings a few seconds later. Like every line on Zentropy
column5: it sounds innocuous when you hear it
column6: but conveys a feeling so rich it could fill a song five times as long. “Repulsive” alone has an almost atomic presence: Pry into it and something unexpectedly big might explode.

column1: Toward the end of the album
column2: Kline confesses
column3: “I do what I/ Have to do/ This is when I say my ‘I love you.’” For a 19-year-old
column4: she has an unusually good grip on the obligations and nuances of long-term relationships
column5: and an ability to relate them in ways that feel clever but direct. “I’m bitter like olives
column6: ” she jokes on “Leonie”
column7: but then pivots: “That’s why you like them and I don’t.” Her simplicity is her mask: It makes her seem like she doesn't have anything to say
column8: which is why it’s so surprising when she does.

column1: In the same way rappers exaggerate confidence to give listeners the thrill of feeling strong
column2: Kline—as is custom in our time of ironized over-sharing—exaggerates her sadness to make space for real vulnerability. “I’m the kind of girl buses splash with rain
column3: ” she sings. Not just a girl
column4: but a kind of girl: A cliché you’ve seen in movies and heard about in songs. And yet
column5: as soon as she sings it
column6: her sadness feels light and abstract—something playacted. There’s an argument here: The first step to feeling better is to let yourself feel bad; the second is to realize that whatever you’re feeling is probably somewhere on TV right now.

column1: For all its little-girl-lost poses
column2: Zentropy is a tight
column3: confident album. Kline—the daughter of actors Phoebe Cates and Kevin Kline—seems emblematic of the way culture is being re-zineified by shows like ""Girls"" or publications like Rookie: Examples of young female voices who can articulate intimacy in a way that feels savvy and clear. But she also belongs in a larger conversation about older things: the New York poet Frank O’Hara (of whom she is a fan)
column4: the sweeter moments of filmmaker Jean-Luc Godard
column5: or the sister group the Roches—clever
column6: funny writers who navigated the margins of urban life with heartache and whimsy. What Zentropy reminds me of most is Greta Gerwig and Noah Baumbach’s Frances Ha
column7: a movie that did less to capture the sociological particulars of Brooklyn in the 2010s than the archetypal triumphs and disappointments of young life in a big city.

column1: In the past few years
column2: Kline has released over 40 albums and EPs on Bandcamp. Had she wanted to
column3: she could have included 50 songs here
column4: maybe 60. But why muddle the point? She knows what she wants to say and she is saying it. If there are weak moments on the album
column5: it’s when she steps back into a bigger sonic picture: the girl-group chorus on “Dancing in the Public Eye”
column6: the distancing echo of “I Do Too”. Like any music whose strength lies in its intimacy
column7: the fewer reminders Zentropy gives us of the world outside
column8: the better.

column1: Is this music simple? Yes. Solipsistic? That too. But in Kline’s withdrawal
column2: there’s also a kind of humility: Never will she speak for anyone’s experience but her own. “He was just a dog/ Now his body’s gone
column3: ” she sings on ""Sad""
column4: the album's last song. “So what is left
column5: but me and my poem?” Nothing
column6: maybe
column7:
but that doesn’t matter: The poem is plenty.

"|19130.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19130-frankie-cosmos-zentropy/|8.0|Mike Powell

The back cover of Belomancie reads “COMPOSED
column2: PERFORMED
column3: & PRODUCED BY CAMERON STALLONES.” A few years ago
column4: that information would’ve been redundant
column5: as Sun Araw began in the late 00’s clearly as Stallones solo project. But lately it’s been an expanding universe
column6: incorporating various musicians into both studio and concert settings; he’s even referred to it as the Sun Araw Band. This ensemble has morphed so much that some iterations took on new names—Turban Chopsticks
column7: Duppy Gun
column8: The Celebrate Music Synthesizer Group—suggesting Stallones is increasingly interested in subsuming his personality into a larger collective. So
column9: suddenly
column10: it’s surprising that he would make a Sun Araw record by himself.

column1: This would all just be interesting trivia if it didn’t have discernible effects on the music. But the sonic minimalism of Belomancie makes it distinctly the expression of a single mind. This is easily the most sparse
column2: skeletal record Stallones has made. He’s explored stripped-down versions of his woozy psych-dub before
column3: and this double LP is too wide to be labelled with a single style. But the majority has a building-block feel. Frequently throughout its 80 minutes
column4: Stallones hones in on the most irreducible elements of Sun Araw—a single beat here
column5: a minute loop there—to see what might happen if they got to play alone for a while.

column1: The result hypnotizes as strongly as the murkier swirls of previous peaks—the glowing smoke of On Patrol
column2: the bleary humidity of Ancient Romans—but in a different way. In a sense
column3: listening to the album’s sharp
column4: pointillist beats and all the air in between them is like staring into space rather blinking into the fog. But there’s also something microscopic about the music that makes it like a nuclear laboratory. With so many layers stripped away—primarily the heavy reverb of Stallones’ guitar
column5: which usually drowns his songs in swampy dreams—what remains gets magnified
column6: meaning a single machine-drum hit can sound as big as a bomb. It’s as if Stallones zoomed so far into the essence of Sun Araw that you can see the molecules circling each other
column7: the neurons firing through synapses. And it’s pretty fun to just keep on staring.

column1: Part of that enjoyment comes from how Stallones can go minimal without losing a key Sun Araw effect—the sense that it’s all happening spontaneously. There may be a path in the crooked beats
column2: squeaking synths
column3: and three-note guitar loops
column4: but there’s certainly no forseeable destination. This open
column5: anything-could-happen vibe comes easier when music is bathed in echo or buried in haze; making sparser stuff feel so pregnant with potential is a trickier feat. But Stallones is so practiced at conjuring that magic that it’s almost impossible to imagine him not doing so. When the pin-pricks and string-slashes of “Scrim”
column6: or the snare punches and two-word lyrics of “Huff” (note those minimal titles) unfurl across their nine-minute journeys
column7: every moment feels like a step toward something new. By the end of each I’m thinking less about how long Stallones has been churning away than about how much longer he clearly could.

column1: Which points to the greater significance of Belomancie in the context of Sun Araw’s oeuvre. It shows Stallones has more moves in his aresnal
column2: more ways he can adjust or reimagine his approach without losing its essence—or in this instance
column3: actually enhancing it. The sounds may be comparatively shrunken
column4: but together they stretch his world
column5: suggesting its expanse may be boundless. If you’ve been fascinated by any of Stallones’ work
column6: Belomancie will get you stoked about not only what he’s done
column7:
but how much more he can do.

As Hauschka
column3: Volker Bertelmann writes fairly plain piano music that winds up sounding bewilderingly elaborate. What he plays matters less than what he does before playing it: shoving bits of junk (wood
column4: foil
column5: paper) in the harp or tacks in the hammers. He feeds this snaggletooth grin a diet of frantic minimalist ostinatos and sweetly lingering right-hand themes. Its digestion produces outlandish sounds
column6: not just percussive but also melodic
column7: thanks to live electronic effects. Even when he's playing alone
column8: as he is on Abandoned City
column9: we seem to hear everything from kick drums and rattles to synth arpeggios and violas. You'd swear there was a plucked lute on ""Sanzhi Pod City""
column10: a runny music box on ""Pripyat"". I still can't quite believe there aren't strings on ""Who Lived Here?"".

column1: Bertelmann says he was unaware of John Cage when he had the idea
column2: though someone must have clued him in after his first album
column3: as his second was dutifully titled The Prepared Piano. Coming from a techno background
column4: he basically wanted to make an acoustic synthesizer where each key could be programmed
column5: after a fashion
column6: with its own timbre. Quite different from the austerity of Cage
column7: his songs have a clumsy grace
column8: eagerly tripping over themselves as they rush between frolicsome and ominous moods. The latter gain ground on Abandoned City
column9: as though Bertelmann were glimpsing a desolate future in the discarded places for which the songs are named.

column1: After learning his way around solo prepared piano improvisations
column2: Bertelmann started branching out. Enlisting collaborators and adding electronics
column3: he enshrined his knack for pert chamber froth on Ferndorf
column4: perfected his acoustic house music concept on Salon des Amateurs
column5: and tried out bracing modern chamber music with a world-renowned young classical violinist on Silfra. Abandoned City brings him full circle to solo piano
column6: but with bits and pieces he's picked up along the way. It's often patterned like electronic dance music
column7: its busy syncopation redoubled by a small fleet of clean and filtered microphones.

column1: Within its limits
column2: the album is fairly diverse
column3: though after so many records
column4: the style might be wearing a bit thin. There's horror-movie buildup music like ""Elizabeth Bay""
column5: acoustic IDM like ""Pripyat""
column6: slowly sweeping melancholia like ""Craco""
column7: techno in homespun disguise like the exhilarating ""Agdam"". But no matter what Bertelmann puts in his piano
column8: every clever noise it makes necessarily deprives it of another
column9: expanding timbral range at the expense of harmonic. All the skittering pizzicato
column10: clenched syncopation and scudding bass overshadows distinctions in the compositions. When the convulsions relax on ""Who Lived Here?""
column11: where Bertelmann lets a beautiful melodic structure unfold
column12:
it's a nice change of pace to hear more of his voice than his piano's.

The first time I saw Thou play live
column4: it was an earlier incarnation of the band opening for Sunn 0))) at Philadelphia’s First Unitarian Church. Shaggy locks of hair obscured most of their faces
column5: and their skinny arms were clad in flannel and neutral t-shirts. There was nothing outwardly “metal” about their presentation
column6: as long as one ignored the ominous stacks of amplifiers looming behind them on the low chapel stage. They were unassuming
column7: and it was all very unremarkable
column8: until the first note rang out and the rafters shook and the stained glass rattled as Thou proceeded to browbeat the audience with their apocalyptic doom. The band has toured the world and racked up stacks of accolades since then
column9: but you’d never know it from speaking to any of its members.

column1: Within a genre that prides itself on theatricality
column2: Thou’s lack of pretension and their commitment to the DIY world from where they came is refreshing. The band refuses to hide behind elaborate stage shows or tour laminates
column3: releases boatloads of new material every year
column4: and still prefers to pile into their beat-up red van and play all-ages DIY spaces. They hail from Baton Rouge
column5: Louisiana
column6: but could seemingly care less about fulfilling anyone else’s “Southern sludge” stereotypes. Basically
column7: Thou have always been Thou
column8: and their stellar new album
column9: Heathen is a portrait of a band that is in complete harmony with itself
column10: if not the world it inhabits.

column1: It’s also their first full-length since 2010’s also stunning Summit
column2: though the band have released a cavalcade of splits
column3: EPs
column4: and covers since then. They’re nothing if not prolific
column5: and luckily
column6: everything they’ve released since their first 2005 demo easily stands up to the most rigorous standards (especially their penchant for recording brutalizing Nirvana covers). This album is no exception. Though Heathen stretches well past the hour mark
column7: the album must be digested as a whole.

column1: The bruising power these songs wield is great and terrible. This fourth full-length is undeniably the band’s most punishing work
column2: and yet is also their most beautiful. Thou explore their melodic potential to an almost startling extent
column3: and devote more than a few moments of the sprawling collection to gentle
column4: uplifting harmonies. The rivers of oppressive sludge are broken up by three short
column5: quiet instrumentals
column6: written around pastoral acoustic guitars that occasionally echo Earth’s dreamy recent output. For the first time
column7: they've allowed a faint glimmer of light to shine through the overbearing gloom.

column1: Not only that
column2: but for the first time
column3: the album also includes clean vocals courtesy of close band ally Emily McWilliams. Her warm
column4: clear tones lighten up the darkness
column5: and add an almost joyful element to Heathen’s shuddering dirges. McWilliams also played puppetmaster for all the strings and horns that pepper the album and add splashes of color to Thou’s usual dark sonic palette.

column1: The album’s first track
column2: “Free Will”
column3: is ominous and somber
column4: building in intensity over the course of nearly 15 minutes and neatly exemplifying what's so compelling about Thou’s trance-inducing chords and tense
column5: ultimately cathartic crescendos. Vocalist Bryan Funck’s near-feral howl commands and chastises
column6: laying out the album’s themes of power
column7: despair
column8: defiance
column9: and free will. His delivery may verge upon black metal in its throat-scraping mania
column10: but the words he speaks are grounded in crushing reality
column11: not fantasy. The demons he confronts are real.

column1: The aforementioned first track
column2: “Into the Marshlands”
column3: and “Immortality Dictates” stand out as album highlights
column4: with the latter sneaking up out of the gloam. In direct contrast to its stark title
column5: the third and longest interlude “Take Off Your Skin and Dance in Your Bones” follows one bright
column6: rippling melody before sinking deep into the mire with the next track’s explosive bait and switch. “Immortality Dictates” underscores McWilliams’ wispy vocals with a ghostly choir
column7: then plunges straight into a caustic dull roar. Other songs like “At the Foot of Mount Driskill” and mournful closer “Ode to Physical Pain” are more inclusive
column8: weaving strains of melody over and under abrasive
column9: fuzz-drenched doom riffs in more traditional Thou style.

column1: They may have lightened up a bit
column2: but Thou have definitely not lost their ability to shock and awe. Those who appreciate the electric frisson of the band’s lumbering doom riffs and Funck’s acerbic snarl will find much to appreciate here
column3: and it’s hard to see even a casual listener taking issue with the more experimental bent of the LP
column4: especially when it works so well. Consumed by struggle and steeped in agony
column5:
Thou have truly reached a summit.

Marco Niemerski's 2006 debut single was called ""Around the House"" and the title sums up the German producer's career as Tensnake. He's occasionally experimented with sounds from other genres—electro's searing synth lines
column4: beachy balearic tempos
column5: expansive space disco—but he's always returned to house's straightforward pulse
column6: both with his original productions and as a DJ. Reliability has been Niemerski's calling card but his best material comes when he steps out of his comfort zone. He had a minor blog-crossover hit with 2010's Soul II Soul-jacking remix of defunct Toronto house ragamuffins Azari & III's ""Reckless With Your Love"". That year also brought ""Coma Cat""
column7: a classic slice of 1980s-redolent house music on blissed-out dance hub Permanent Vacation that paired textural intensity with a melody that was a serious earworm.

column1: It's been nearly four years since ""Coma Cat"" and Niemerski has remained reliable
column2: so Glow seeks to both capitalize on that rep and introduce him to a larger audience—it's not only is it his debut album
column3: it's also his first time on a major. Successful dance full-lengths generally take one of two approaches: a statement of purpose separate from the creator’s established style or a collection of existing singles
column4: rounded up as a primer for newcomers. Glow goes in a different direction
column5: offering a streamlined
column6: sanitized version of the Tensnake sound. It's house music in miniature form
column7: heavily brushed with disco's steady-handed bounce and tempered with just enough potential pop-crossover appeal. Niemerski generally works best with room to stretch
column8: as his best productions typically land around the seven-minute mark. A brief glance at the running time of Glow's individual songs—only one pushes the six-minute mark
column9: while most clock in at three-and-a-half—suggests that he compromised his vision to accommodate a larger stage.

column1: Much of the album finds Niemerski collaborating with Berlin vocalist Fiora
column2: a capable singer whose unshowy qualities makes her both malleable and forgettable; save for ""See Right Through""
column3: a moody cut that's made the rounds over the past year
column4: Fiora's presence feels more like a placeholder
column5: a paperweight meant to anchor the barely-sketched house figures. Niemerski's collaborations with other artists fare worse; the stale ""Pressure""
column6: a disco workout featuring vocalist Thabo
column7: never capitalizes on its propulsive build
column8: while ""Feel of Love""
column9: a team-up with Jamie Lidell and space cadet Stuart Price in his Jacques Lu Cont alias
column10: is a jagged
column11: off-putting synth-pop tune that resembles the many low points of Lidell's self-titled LP from last year.

column1: Many of Glow's songs are just-there
column2: but a few manage to be engaging: ""No Relief""
column3: ""See Right Through""
column4: and ""No Colour"" are perfect examples of Niemerski's still-considerable talent with house form. The latter two tunes made memorable appearances on his Essential Mix
column5: confirming that he's most in his zone when dreaming of the dancefloor. The appropriately slow ""58 BPM"" is a lush
column6: swarming synth-pop tune that serves as the album's strongest vocal cut
column7: while album bookends ""First Song"" and ""Last Song"" play around with pop-focused drone while embracing the type of epic beams found in M83's music (or
column8: Random Access Memories' own jet-engine closer
column9: ""Horizon"").

column1: Both ""First Song"" and ""Last Song"" suggest that Niemerski may have had a more focused album experience in mind
column2: but it never had a chance given the record's scattershot approach. Given its release on a high-profile label
column3: as well as recent shifts in mainstream dance culture
column4: it's possible to look at Glow more cynically. Michaelangelo Matos recently described Niemerski's Astralwerks signing as the latest example of the EDM cash-grab still raging on in North America. But the album is so slight
column5:
it’ll be easy to forget it exists and hope that Tensnake's next full-length won't sound so uninspired.

Joseph Mount just can't stay tethered to a moment. Metronomy's 2008 LP Nights Out was the headlong dive into pop's peak-coke gloss
column3: archly tweaking disco
column4: new wave
column5: and all points in between. Three years later
column6: Mount dusted off some old vintage navy blazer and got yacht-rockish for The English Riviera
column7: trading California beaches for the boardwalks of English seaside resorts and almost pulling off the integration.

column1: With another three years passed
column2: Metronomy arrives with another rearview glance at pop and rock history
column3: aging backwards into a gray space between late psych and early glam with a bit of pastoral Kinks ennui mixed in to whatever's left of the old indie-dance pedigree. (He even booked Toe Rag Studios for that special analog-purist touch.) But there's a wide gulf between the idea of Love Letters as pleasant
column4: throwbackish pop-rock nugget and the vapor-thin nonentity it became. What worked for The English Riviera's mellow beachfront reveries—subdued instrumentation
column5: placid vocals
column6: clinical studio-band polish—doesn't stick as well when the tempo's edged back up a notch or two towards something a bit more trad-rock. And what simple-enough songwriting chops there are to this album's credit are delivered so flimsily it's less twee than just plain weak.

column1: If you're looking for a specific culprit
column2: pin that on Mount's voice. Ten seconds and twelve words into opener ""The Upsetter""
column3: Mount tries pushing his luck at the end of the phrase ""straight from the satellite"" and creaks out this whimpery Bowie affectation that's a pained balloon-squeak of a noise. It's viscerally grating
column4: and there's more where that came from: When he's not reducing his passionless mumbling to a caricature of a non-committal indie-slacker voice (at its slackest on lite-Kraut ""Call Me"" and the dozy quasi-waltz ""Never Wanted"")
column5: he's trying his hand at a fume-drunk midpoint between 60s UK pop and velvety R&B that creaks and shudders under the burden of a voice better built for flatness. Even through a number of permutations—Holiday Inn lounge Motown (""I'm Aquarius"")
column6: chirpy analog-organ dance-craze pop (""Reservoir"")
column7: drunk-dial Clientele (""The Most Immaculate Haircut"")—it sounds like he's holding back
column8: looking at his feet
column9: trying not to cause a scene.

column1: The big shame is that all these side-route trips into oddball drum-machine garage rock or motorik-a-go-go soul had the making of something daringly weird
column2: intentionally out of step with your typical Brit-indie fare
column3: yet still giddily catchy. After three NyQuilcore tracks that make the drum machine from Timmy Thomas' ""Why Can't We Live Together"" sound like a Clyde Stubblefield/Ginger Baker showdown
column4: the title track feints towards another woozy slog for a bit over a minute before breaking out in a big stomping piano-pounding number that actually shakes the needle. If only the rest of the record caught on to that out-front force—the words on Love Letters might scan as more than lonely fridge-magnet poetry
column5: the beats might feel like more than just placeholders
column6:
and the music could be something to dance to instead of just drift off to.

Eagulls are a four-piece band from Leeds who write revved-up post-punk songs combining the sound of a mannered Killing Joke
column2: who they've covered
column3: with a deep atmosphere reminiscent of early Misfits and guitars that bring to mind the Cure's ""Boys Don't' Cry"". Clean-cut vocalist George Mitchell
column4: who keeps his eyes closed when he sings

column6: explosive

column1: That said

column3: a letter that is still
column4: to a degree
column5: defining the band. In the screed
column6: they talked about ""beach bands sucking each others’ dicks and rubbing the press’ clit"" and made some comments about ""90s hairstyles
column7: people who dress like Disney characters
column8: ""disgusting Afro Beat sounds
column9: and groups that only get attention because they feature girls. The note wasn't as compelling
column10: or as offensive
column11: as people wanted it to be
column12: and the fact that they took it down
column13: replacing it with an image of a naked ass and ball sack
column14: suggested that it was all a sophomoric prank.

column1: Still

column7: talented group—this is not the stuff of GG Allin
column8: or the Sex Pistols (or even Jesus Lizard). Read the interviews: nice guys who talk about having shitty jobs and feeling depressed. Basic stuff. You can't make out all of the lyrics
column9: but when you hear Mitchell sing about ""soulless youth
column10: ""hollow visions

column12: you won't mistake his material or story for Richard Hell's Blank Generation. These songs cover heroin addicts and sexual assault

column14: complicated subjects
column15: but it doesn't feel dark

column1: And this isn't a problem. Eagulls have synthesized their influences well
column2: and have created an enjoyable rock record (they've been around since 2010
column3: which may account for why so many of these songs sounds accomplished as they do); so while Eagulls is not exactly life-changing music

column5:
and sometimes that's enough.

Dave Charles Shuford has called New York home since the early 90s
column2: when he emigrated from the South and joined up with likeminded experimentalists in the improvisation-driven No-Neck Blues Band. In the last several years Shuford has reclaimed his Georgia roots by inhabiting the alter ego of D. Charles Speer
column3: frontman of a band he calls the Helix. As No-Neck has grown quieter the past few years
column4: the Speer persona seems to be growing in its creative influence on Shuford. If D. Charles Speer and the Helix were relegated to side-project status in the past
column5:
NNCK is now in Speer’s shadow.   

D. Charles Speer and the Helix has always felt like Shuford’s way of giving his home state its due. His southern drawl is Georgia-specific
column6: bringing to mind a younger
column7: more-prone-to-slurring Larry Jon Wilson. No-Neck and the jammy psych of Rhyton (another Shuford side project with ex-Psychic Ills member Jimy Seitang) are boundless
column8: but the Helix is far more contained. That’s not to say the music of D. Charles Speer has ever been particularly easy to pin down or pigeonhole. Speer’s deep drawl and bandmate Marc Orleans’ weepy pedal steel give it an unmistakably Southern feel
column9: but calling it country-rock or Americana or anything like that would be woefully reductive. Outlaw country is closer
column10:
but that underplays the psychedelia. 

The thematic material on new album Doubled Exposure is similarly restless. “Is this exoskeleton your true identity?/ Eat some boric acid
column11: prove your love to me
column12: ” goes some of the barely discernible lyrics from leadoff track “Wallwalker""
column13: a Kafka-esque insect allegory set to a boogie beat. There’s “fabled bestiality” between a queen and a bull on “Cretan Lords""
column14: which sounds like Dick Dale sitting in with the house band at a Cretian bar (the bouzouki and baglamas recall Speer’s Mediterranean solo diversion Arghiledes). Speer casually sidesteps from the exotic to more traditional story songs like “Bootlegging Blues""
column15: which begins appropriately with a popped bottle and a gluggy pour as Speer woozily sings about corn whiskey like a man who’s been leaning against the saloon piano and hitting the bottle himself between takes. “Red Clay Road” is unmistakably Georgian
column16: with mentions of bacon fat
column17:
mustard greens and a Ford coupe gunning down Highway 9 “from Dawsonville to the ATL.”

The instrumental “Mandorla at Dawn” is Doubled Exposure’s outlier
column18: starting with an unassuming
column19: minor-key ascending guitar riff that bleeds into a 70s country-rock
column20: pedal-steel hook
column21: almost like a wordless Derek & the Dominos outtake. But after three minutes
column22: things start getting weird—courtesy of some live looping and staccato piano vamping. They get progressively weirder and No-Necky until the song ends close to the 10-minute mark. You could argue it’s out of place on an album of mostly structured songs
column23:
but I think it works the same way Yo La Tengo’s lengthy jams tend to open up albums of otherwise structured songs. It’s a dose of excitement and a good reminder of the far-out capabilities of these players.

Doubled Exposure is a fun
column25: but there’s also nothing too sticky about it. Like David Berman
column26: Speer’s oddball vocal delivery offers surprises that keep things engaging
column27: but Speer doesn’t have the same larger-than-life presence on this album that he has onstage (especially in a bar with low ceilings). The record ends on a sour note
column28: too. “Tough Soup” feels like a throwaway with its boilerplate blues-rock solo and lyrics that OD on cheeky drug references (“This recipe stands alone/ it guarantees a consistency of stone”; “cook it on high”). But the album is also further proof that D. Charles Speer and the Helix is a more-than-worthy NNCK diversion and a testament to the band’s ability to stretch out within a framework. D. Charles Speer is unmistakably Dave Charles Shuford

It’s hard not to listen to Ben Asbury
column2: the 23 year-old Atlanta native behind Axxa/Abraxas
column3: and not think about all of the sweet
column4: long-haired stoners who haunted record stores back in my college town. They were the guys with obsessive record collections and an extensive knowledge of zine culture
column5: dudes with the wherewithal to run their own mail order tape labels and put on all-ages shows in shitty makeshift venues while still finding time to pursue mostly unusable degrees. Maybe they also sold you weed. Ben Asbury definitely seems like one of those dudes.

column1: For a few years now
column2: Asbury has been working as Axxa/Abraxas
column3: turning out charmingly messy psych-pop and releasing it into the world via his own label
column4: RTA Arts Collective. Given the wily nature of his music and his visual art (he is also an accomplished silkscreen artist)
column5: the label’s official motto—""Archetypal artwork in reflection of the Cosmic Harmony""—makes perfect sense. On <i>Axxa/Abraxas
column6: Asbury’s first official full-length on Captured Tracks
column7: the songwriter takes a lifetime love of outré psych-pop and squeezes it into occasionally overstuffed but generally affable songs about night rides and mystical winds.

column1: For someone whose earlier work could often be so gloriously messy
column2: the 10 tracks on Axxa/Abraxas are surprisingly straightforward. “I Almost Fell” aims for an Apples in Stereo-like pop and is the record’s catchiest track
column3: and “Ryan Michalak (Is Coming to Town)” has the kind of Crystal Stilts swagger that sounds excellent blasting loudly out of a pair of vintage speakers. Still
column4: Asbury’s lyrics
column5: when considered outside of their trippy environs
column6: can be rough. Only someone with his powerful wail can get away with the likes of  “Close your eyes so your mind can see/ Try to find what’s your destiny/ Nothings free” and make it sound both convincingly metaphysical and absolutely sincere.

column1: Given Asbury’s claim to have discovered punk rock in the Third Grade
column2: it makes sense that his music feels so intentionally kaleidoscopic. Influences like Television Personalities
column3: Grateful Dead
column4: and Neil Young & Crazy Horse (with an emphasis on the Crazy Horse) are heard throughout. The most obvious precursors appear to be local. Given that he is a Georgia native
column5: and that most of Axxa/Abraxas was written during his time as a student in Athens
column6: one can’t help but hear the ghostly echoes of the prodigious Elephant 6 Recording Company
column7: particularly the Olivia Tremor Control.

column1: Axxa/Abraxas was mixed and engineered by Woods member Jarvis Taveniere
column2: and much of it sounds like it could actually be a Woods record. It's a charming album from an artist with an obsessive/compulsive love for writing shambolic
column3: vaguely psych-infused rock songs but it doesn’t distinguish itself from any number of similar records from this sphere over the past few years. Asbury’s personality and his charismatic voice save it from being completely generic
column4:
and one hopes they'll carry him into weirder landscapes on future releases.

Did Cynic really have to make a third album? In 2006
column3: the Florida progressive metal paragons returned to the stage after a decade away from both recording and performing (plus a short stint under another name). The first phase of Cynic’s existence had been short but crucial; in only five years
column4: they evolved from an atavistic thrash band to a frame-breaking alloy of technical death metal and thundering jazz fusion
column5: crystallized on their wonderfully vexing 1993 debut
column6: Focus. Two decades later
column7: Focus still sounds like future music
column8: an impossibly complex rush of disparate parts and unseen twists that maintains its momentum in spite of its bewildering mechanics. It’s righteous and affirming
column9: too
column10: and not just for its instrumental heroics; with his voice floating in a web of electronics and his head in a cloud of self-made mysticism
column11: Paul Masvidal extolled the infinity of the mind and the sovereignty of the individual.

column1: Their post-reunion LP
column2: 2008’s Traced in Air
column3: thrived on a similarly ambitious mix of power and prowess
column4: though the aging members Cynic had tempered the ambitious parts. The metal
column5: jazz
column6: and math seemed partly pulled apart
column7: strands that no longer held one another so closely. It was a worthy successor and proof that their legacy could live beyond one 15-year-old benchmark. It was also a chance for graceful closure. Instead
column8: Cynic have made Kindly Bent to Free Us
column9: a debacle that scraps not only that exit opportunity but also a chunk of what made them interesting at all.

column1: As if to prevent the perception that they
column2: after a quarter century
column3: simply became just another band aiming to issue a new record every several years
column4: Cynic drastically shift their approach for Kindly Bent to Free Us. In fact
column5: on album three
column6: they leave approximately half of their sound behind. Though Kindly Bent to Free Us does get dense and loud
column7: with the occasional viscous march and tempestuous drum burst
column8: they slough off much of their metal persona for eight tepid tracks. These pieces bend toward post-rock (mawkish closer “Endlessly Bountiful”) and prog (the swiveling “Moon Heart Sun Head”). Brighter production and fewer moving parts dovetail to give Masvidal’s computerized vocals a broader spotlight
column9: too. At their best
column10: that choice offers a pop-like gleam. At worst
column11: it shapes the songs into the unintentional comedy album of the year. Lyrics lifted from the cereal Rice Krispies float above ceremoniously solemn guitars. The plea “Oh mercy
column12: radiate your grace on me” lingers as the grand
column13: laughable conclusion of a particularly knotty span. And that’s just before Masvidal
column14: singing with a choir composed only of himself
column15: informs us repeatedly that “There will be holy fallout.” His tone is clear
column16: clean
column17: and garish. Without the frisson afforded by their more aggressive portion
column18: Cynic’s music becomes a string of unfortified punchlines.

column1: The mere deletion of Cynic’s metal side isn’t itself a satisfactory condition for the failure of Kindly Bent to Free Us; some of these hooks are among the most radiant moments in the band’s catalogue
column2: and some of the instrumental interplay ranks among their most fascinating. It’s not pedestrian
column3: either. These guitar solos remain knots of notes that seem to start and stop time. Cynic also relishes in the daunting task of dividing melodies across every instrument
column4: as they do at the start of the interesting “Gitanjali.”

column1: But the omitted ingredients make Cynic too predictable—not only for the rote order in which things happen here but also for the things that never have the chance to happen. Focus might be impossibly complex
column2: but at least on a structural level
column3: these new songs seem flatly simple
column4: as though the trio plugged parts into an algorithm and played to the resulting script. They favor short
column5: vaguely threatening intros followed by full-band bursts
column6: as that’s how three of the first four songs begin. By the time opener “True Hallucination Speak” reaches its second chorus
column7: its routine movement between quiet and loud
column8: full tempo and no tempo has already become a bore. “Moon Heart Sun Head” seesaws between marching
column9: drum-led verses and lulling
column10: bass-heavy impasses. Even a hyperkinetic solo and a lengthy sample of philosopher Alan Watts reading from his The Nature of Consciousness can’t excite that back and forth. If you get the feeling that you know what’s coming next while listening to Kindly Bent to Free Us
column11: your premonition is most likely correct. In losing a chunk of their identity
column12: Cynic also lost their ability to do the entirely unexpected. They once launched the listener into a sense of wonder and kept them there for minutes on end. Not here.

column1: In the past several years
column2: the bands of peoples’ dreams have reunited. Some have cashed in with high-profile gigs but (at least to date) recorded little else
column3: while others have dazzled with new material that made you mourn their initial hiatus once again. Still others have embarrassed themselves with endless cash grabs and new recordings that amounted to debacles
column4: and a few have made new material that sounds more or less like what they left behind. Cynic is a most peculiar case
column5: though: They got back together to play the old stuff and ended up enjoying the experience so much that they wrote a copacetic follow-up to the only album they’d ever made. And now
column6: after the reunion buzz has had time to dissipate
column7: they’ve embarrassed themselves with a record that fails because it divides their legacy in half. Kindly Bent to Free Us works as a sort of retroactive insult: It resurrects many of the misgivings people have always had about Cynic—the overindulgent vocals
column8: for instance
column9: or the ponderous new-age musings—and runs wild with them. In fact
column10: when I listened back to Focus after hearing Kindly Bent to Free Us
column11: those traits felt like strangely fresh faults
column12:
where they’d once been part of Cynic’s unlikely sui generis appeal. It’s a shame that the present now haunts this band’s peerless past.

The Neptunes were in the middle of an untouchable seven-year creative peak—beginning with Kelis' 1999 debut Kaleidoscope and tapering off shortly after the Clipse's 2006 comeback Hell Hath No Fury—when Pharrell dropped his debut solo single
column2: ""Frontin'""
column3: which eventually landed on the Neptunes' showcase LP The Neptunes Present...Clones. A lush
column4: airy slice of R&B
column5: ""Frontin'"" existed as a pleasurable curio until three years later
column6: when Pharrell released his first full-length
column7: In My Mind.

column1: In My Mind was a low-key record that favored cascading piano cadences and psychedelic soul touches as a backdrop for Pharrell's vacuous lyrics
column2: and it sounds a little better in 2014 than its reputation suggests. But at the time
column3: it cratered both commercially and critically
column4: and Pharrell's solo career faded in tandem with the Neptunes' own slow retreat from the spotlight. The fact that he continued to make music as part of N.E.R.D.
column5: his genre-melding
column6: notoriously inconsistent project with Neptunes partner Chad Hugo
column7: suggested that the chilly reception accompanied by striking out on his own was a blow to his self-confidence. ""I wrote those songs out of ego
column8: he told GQ in an interview earlier this year. ""What was good about that? There was no purpose.""

column1: If the materialistic bent of In My Mind was indicative of where Pharrell was in 2006
column2: then G I R L
column3: his second solo album
column4: points to what he's looking to achieve in 2014. The last eight years of the 40-going-on-23 years old auteur's career have been light on creative substance—there were a few key contributions to albums from Frank Ocean
column5: Usher
column6: and Kendrick Lamar
column7: as well as heavy involvement in the score for the 2010 animated film Despicable Me. But the success of Robin Thicke's ""Blurred Lines""
column8: along with Pharrell's work on Daft Punk's Random Access Memories
column9: propelled him into a new level of ubiquity. In a recent Pitchfork interview
column10: Pharrell explained that the idea for the album came from Columbia after they first heard the still-inescapable ""Get Lucky"" and saw dollar signs. ""They offered me a deal on the spot
column11: he said. ""If I was left to my own devices
column12: I would not have elected to do it.""

column1: On Random Access Memories
column2: Daft Punk created an expensive-sounding and grandiose monument to the music that shaped their personal histories; on G I R L
column3: Pharrell has done something similar
column4: but with a significantly narrower scope. A bright
column5: smooth demonstration of musical largesse that features a diverse cast of supporting players including Justin Timberlake
column6: Daft Punk
column7: composer Hans Zimmer
column8: Kelly Osborne
column9: and teen breakout-turned-internet R&B curiosity JoJo
column10: G I R L calls back to sounds that have shaped its creator's musical vision. There's the nervous sexuality of peak-era Michael Jackson
column11: bright-eyed 1970s soul
column12: funk's squishy right-angle riffs. But largely
column13: G I R L finds Pharrell taking inspiration from Pharrell. His past successes
column14: both solo and as part of the Neptunes
column15: echo throughout the album: the sweaty slink of Timberlake's ""Rock Your Body""
column16: N.E.R.D.'s yacht-rock fixations on 2002's so-nice-they-recorded-it-twice In Search Of…
column17: the gum-snapping percussion on Snoop Dogg's ""Drop It Like It's Hot""
column18: the lad's-mag R&B of ""Blurred Lines""
column19: and the undying jangle of ""Get Lucky"".

column1: The appeal of Pharrell's production has long been a push-and-pull between elegance and agitation. He's capable of sounds that can blow your eardrums and gently caress them into submission. G I R L also tempers its classic-pop approach with strident sonics
column2: as sharp edges poke through the record's overall smoothness—the airless riffs of ""Hunter""
column3: ""Come Get It Bae""'s cascading claps
column4: the ascendant horn figure that punctures ""Brand New""'s chorus. These are small hints that Pharrell has a knack for pop music that
column5: at its core
column6: sounds a little weird. But G I R L hedges its bets; its all-ages
column7: aisle-reaching attitude is ready for mass consumption
column8: and over the next year and maybe longer
column9: you'll probably be hearing these easy-to-please tunes anywhere you can find a room without a roof.

column1: ""Happy""
column2: originally conceived for the soundtrack to last year's <i>Despicable Me 2
column3: has already reached the point of mass saturation and currently sits atop the Billboard Hot 100. Accompanied by a celebrity-packed video that's impossible to watch without a grin on your face (as well as a 24-hour version that's impossible to watch without a nap and a few square meals)
column4: the walking-on-air retro-soul of ""Happy"" is
column5: arguably
column6: one of the most beatific and lovable pop singles in recent memory
column7: a bundle of New Age koans dipped in honey and left out to dry on a breezy spring day. If Cee-Lo's ""Fuck You"" was a declarative T-shirt of a single
column8: ""Happy"" is what you'd get if you turned that T-shirt inside-out
column9: its effortless just-keep-livin' attitude reflected in its presentation.

column1: In addition to being G I R L's highlight
column2: ""Happy"" also stands apart from the thinly-drawn concept spelled out in the album's title. ""Women and girls
column3: for the most part
column4: “have just been so loyal to me and supported me
column5: he told GQ when speaking to the album's thematic concerns
column6: unintentionally reflecting G I R L's shallow non-attempt at paying tribute to the opposite sex. Save for the hang-in-there-baby Alicia Keys duet ""Know Who You Are""
column7: nearly every woman on G I R L is the object of sexual pursuit
column8: with Pharrell reprising the horny-schoolboy routine he
column9: Thicke
column10: and T.I. embodied in the ""Blurred Lines"" video.

column1: In a recent London listening session
column2: Pharrell hinted that G I R L's female-centric focus was an attempt to rectify his association with the ""questionable lyrics"" that provoked accusations of sexism in ""Blurred Lines"". It misses the mark badly. On ""Hunter""
column3: over a jarringly limp funk motif
column4: Pharrell ditches his Dudley Do-Right hat for something more sinister
column5: comparing the objects of his affection to animal carcasses stuffed for sport and shoehorning in an awkward (and ill-timed) ""Duck Dynasty"" reference before laying it out in no unspecific terms: ""I'm a hunter.""

column1: The tone-deaf ""Hunter"" also happens to be G I R L's boldest moment. Other bits stand out—the come-hither hedonism of the Miley Cyrus-featuring ""Come Get It Bae"" and the bushy-tailed ebullience that Timberlake brings to ""Brand New""
column2: especially—but Pharrell leans a bit too hard on his Grammy-winning formula of tasteful
column3: everything-in-its-right-place retro-pop. ""Gust of Wind""
column4: featuring Daft Punk
column5: has all the relentless stair-climbing of Random Access Memories' ""Lose Yourself to Dance"" with none of that song's patient build; it jogs in place for five minutes that feel much longer. No one will deny Pharrell's place in shaping how pop music's sounded in the past 15 years
column6: and the lack of innovation found on G I R L is also inarguable.

column1: So while the immaculately blended pop smoothie that is G I R L goes down easy
column2: its complacency is disappointing. Which makes ""Lost Queen""
column3: the eight-minute stretcher placed on the record's back half
column4: so surprising. Over hand drums and sampled chants
column5: Pharrell unspools the type of corny pick-up lines and awkward pop-culture references (""Like Geico/ The time I'll save you/ Can get those motors runnin'"") that G I R L is lousy with; then
column6: the structure dissolves midway through
column7: washed away by the sound of crashing waves
column8: orchestral stabs
column9: and refreshing sighs
column10: reminiscent of Timberlake's The 20/20 Experience ballad ""Spaceship Coupe"". ""You gotta go inward/ To experience the outer space that was built for you
column11: Pharrell sings in a watery cadence
column12: offering advice that
column13: at G I R L's endpoint
column14:
you wish he took closer to heart.

Five years is a long time
column2: especially in your early 20s
column3: as you try on certain identities and cast off others in search of one you feel more or less comfortable in. Case in point: five years ago
column4: Karen Marie Ørsted was writing Peaches-aping novelty songs titled ""When I Saw His Cock""
column5: which included raps as trashy as her beats. Fast forward half of a decade
column6: and the only thing the music of the Copenhagen native
column7: now 25
column8: shares with her earliest demos is an omnivorous musical appetite
column9: one that synthesizes a number of of-the-moment sounds on her self-assured debut as MØ
column10: No Mythologies to Follow.

column1: The album finds MØ (pronounced somewhere between ""Muh"" and the sound a cow makes) ditching shock-rap for more mature but no less immediate electro-pop that explores the swirling confusion of young adulthood. Its sound is one that's equally as indebted to the forward-thinking Scandinavian pop scene she comes from as it is to the sounds of Southern rap and modern bass music. It's the kind of output you'd expect from an artist who's grown up with instant
column2: unlimited access to music from every corner of the globe. This melting-pot approach pervades No Mythologies to Follow
column3: which was produced almost entirely by Ronni Vindahl
column4: a fellow Dane who makes up one-half of No Wav.
column5: the production team that includes Robin Hannibal
column6: aka the dude responsible for the sensuous
column7: restrained arrangements found on last year's debut from Rhye
column8: Woman.

column1: MØ and Vindahl are a good pairing
column2: sharing an easy chemistry as collaborators; Vindahl's production keeps up with but never eclipses MØ
column3: and she doesn't bat an eyelash at his production
column4: which has some bite. Most of the album's twelve tracks are built on top of a sturdy bedrock of tick-tick-ticking 808s and swarms of pulsing synths; ""Maiden"" and ""Red in the Grey"" get the throb of post-dubstep right
column5: and glockenspiels and horns play nice with molasses-thick claps and a gurgling bassline on ""Pilgrim"". There's often a lot happening on these tracks
column6: and this is only compounded by the fact MØ loves her multi-tracked vocals and ad-libs. It has the effect of turning her into a one-woman girl group—the massive lurch of ""Fire Rides""
column7: for instance
column8: leaves plenty of space for MØ to harmonize with herself
column9: and she stuffs the track to the brim with ecstatic shouts and fists-in-the-air woops.

column1: At this point you're probably getting the impression that No Mythologies to Follow isn't exactly a study in minimalism; combined with her everything-is-a-hook style of songwriting
column2: MØ ends up building a rather outsized persona for herself over the course of the album. It's never of the one-note all-caps variety
column3: but it sometimes obscures nuanced performances and her ability to simultaneously nail a bunch of conflicting emotions
column4: often within the span of a single line. ""I never want to know the name of your new girlfriend"" she wails on ""Never Wanna Know""
column5: both because she's not sure she can handle the piece of information but also because she recognizes that knowing gives her another reason to obsess over her ex rather than move forward and on.

column1: At the heart of everything is MØ's voice
column2: a powerful and versatile tool comfortable expressing emotional turmoil as it is wearing a fuck-the-haters scowl. You can almost see her stretching on the tips of her toes as she soars into the clouds during the chorus of the aforementioned ""Never Wanna Know""
column3: and she plays a convincing house diva on ""Slow Love""
column4: a Balearic slinker that recalls John Talabot at his loosest. And although it makes no apologies for the bits and pieces it takes from her contemporaries
column5:
No Mythologies to Follow doesn't work because it assembles the right ingredients in the right amount—it works because a likable persona is something you just can't teach.
