0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20272/homepage_large.5c7dc67f.jpg|The Soul of All Natural Things|3422.0|Linda Perhacs|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Asthmatic Kitty']|2014-03-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:31.258814|"

Linda Perhacs is easily the most celebrated dental hygienist to ever have recorded a classic psychedelic folk album. That album
column2: 1970’s Parallelograms
column3: has persisted over decades
column4: even as Perhacs herself moved on with her life after the record failed and copies of it slowly disappeared from print. The people who heard it
column5: though
column6: did not move on. They made their own editions and passed the album to those they deemed worthy. One of those people was the leader of the prog-metal band Opeth
column7: who did as much as anyone to keep copies of Parallelograms circulating. A legend built. Eventually
column8: someone notified Perhacs.

column1: It’s the kind of tidy capsule story that makes for an excellent set of liner notes
column2: but it’s worth stepping back and reassessing the phenomenal unlikeliness of the tale now that we’re faced with its follow-up
column3: The Soul of All Natural Things. The gulf separating 1970 from now might be dizzying for some
column4: but Perhacs' sense of time is looser than ours
column5: and it doesn’t seem to phase her.

column1: The Soul Of All Natural Things was made with several of Perhacs' contemporary admirers helping her; Julia Holter appears on ""Prisms of Glass""
column2: and Ramona Gonzalez contributes backing vocals. The resulting album has a fluid
column3: communal energy to it that feels very different from Parallelograms. Perhacs' voice is duskier at 70 than it was at 27
column4: but her range is still surprising
column5: dipping into sultry contralto and leaping easily into higher registers. Her ear for multi-tracked harmonies remains the clearest link back to her first album
column6: and you can hear her quizzical and highly original musical mind operating through them. It's easy to find in them the sound that bewitched latter-day followers like Holter.

column1: What The Soul Of All Natural Things isn't
column2: though
column3: is personal
column4: or small-scale
column5: the way Parallelograms was. Perhacs’ first words on Parallelograms were “And it rains here every day since I came”—a conversational line
column6: right down to the way it begins with “And.” That song followed a series of abstracted thoughts like raindrops across a window pane—""It kinda gets inside you...the silences
column7: I mean. They kinda wrap around you and loosen everything."" The first words on the opening title track of The Soul of All Natural Things
column8: meanwhile
column9: are “See the waves that break upon the rocks and stones/ Hear the winds that play upon the ice and foam.” Same focus—the weather
column10: the elements—but the smallness of the human mind has been subtracted. There is no chit-chat to be had here.

column1: In other words
column2: The Soul Of All Natural Things is more purely new age than Perhacs' first record. God as a force
column3: as a character
column4: suffuses these songs
column5: whispering to wind and waves on the title track and carrying the world's ""river of souls"" on ""River of God"". ""Immunity"" is a plea to God to help listen for his love. There is no dogma
column6: just a gentle insistence on slowing down. “Where are you going and if you are going can you take some time for me
column7: just today?"" she inquires on ""Children"". The music is gorgeously recorded
column8: with strings and nylon-string guitar filitering through the mix like the sunlight through the trees in her Topanga Canyon home. But where Parallelograms basked in some cosmic energies
column9: it also offered you a series of conflicting thoughts to puzzle over. The Soul of All Natural Things mostly pats you on the head a little and tell you to calm down.

column1: The best moments are when the song forms fracture a little
column2: and Perhacs' multi-tracked voice is allowed to spiral free. “Prisms of Glass” and “Freely”
column3: two songs in the middle of the record
column4: capture more genuine spiritual feeling with the haunting sound of Perhacs’ interlocking vocals than anything else on the album. On “Song of the Planets”
column5: her voice blurs into a repetition of the words “one” and “sun
column6: ” creating the blissful synthesis that the lyrics can only point to. The Soul of All Natural Things is sumptuously recorded and often beautiful
column7: and honestly
column8: it’s wonderful to have it. If it's difficult to envision a 44-year cult of devotion arising from its songs
column9: well
column10:
once in this lifetime is probably enough for that kind of achievement.

"|19066.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19066-linda-perhacs-the-soul-of-all-natural-things/|6.8|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20266/homepage_large.2f08f8cb.jpg|The Drop Beneath|28243.0|Eternal Summers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kanine']|2014-03-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:31.782504|"

Eternal Summers began their life as a duo. Safely ensconced in something called the Magic Twig Community—a cache of like-minded musicians living in the mountains of Roanoke
column2: Virginia—the band’s first recorded efforts were a mixture jingle-jangle guitars and lo-fi minimalism. On their 2011 debut
column3: Silver
column4: Guitarist and vocalist Nicole Yun and drummer Daniel Cundiff tossed off anti-authority missives and swoony romantic paeans in equal measure
column5: managing to wring a surprising amount dynamic tension from a simple guitar and drums setup. On 2012’s Correct Behavior
column6: the inclusion of a new band member—bassist Jonathan Woods—helped to push the band’s sound forward. With the inclusion of some much-needed low end
column7: Eternal Summer’s sonic palette finally sounded big enough to match what appeared to be their own dream-punk goals: songs that range from emotional Marine Girls-like strummers to hyperdriven juggernauts that finally sounded as big and fuzzed out as the band’s own oversized ambitions.

column1: On their third proper full-length—the PledgeMusic-funded and generally excellent The Drop Beneath—the band takes another assured step forward. Having generally eschewed any outside producers in the past (Correct Behavior was mixed by Raveonettes’ frontman Sune Rose Wagner and producer Alonzo Vargas
column2: but recorded safely at home in Roanoke by the band themselves)
column3: this time the band opted to work elsewhere
column4: relocating to Austin
column5: Texas to record with producer Doug Gillard (Guided By Voice
column6: Nada Surf). The change of venue and a slight loosening of the reigns seem to have done the band a world of good.

column1: The Drop Beneath is the most pristine sounding thing that Eternal Summers have ever recorded. While smoothing away the rough edges seems slightly anathema considering the charm of the band’s early releases
column2: on Beneath the cleaner sound reveals what excellent songwriters Eternal Summers have become. On “Gouge” a galloping guitar melody plays counterpoint to some of Yun’s most arresting lyrics—“Gouge my eyes out/ Cut tongue from my mouth”—all of which are delivered with the sweetness and ardor of a love note. Such is the charm of the album’s best songs—“A Burial” and “Deep End” among them—in which seemingly moribund sentiments are optimistically splayed out against walls of shimmering guitar. And while The Drop Beneath will likely do very little to quell the band’s reputation as savvy 90s alt-rock revivalists—“Keep Me Away” could pass for an American Thighs-era Veruca Salt outtake
column3: not that that’s entirely a bad thing—the band’s frame of reference does appear to have grown. Yun’s voice and the band’s deftness with effects’ pedals might invite easy comparisons to the likes of Lush and pop-inflected shoegaze
column4: but they also make the kind of loopy art-pop that would fit nicely alongside anything Too Pure were releasing back in 1996.

column1: Judging by the overall sense of clarity on The Drop Beneath
column2: it would seem that bringing in an outside producer has mostly been a blessing for the band. Not only does one have a sense of what an excellent and rangy guitarist Yun actually is
column3: her voice is something of a revelation here. On tracks like “Until the Day I Have Won” (in which she sings “Thrill/ is more than a swill/ It's more than what you feel/ It's knowing you've finally got the knack”)
column4: she sings with a kind of calm assurance and that previous releases only hinted at. That being said
column5: the production polish can occasionally be a curse. The album’s prettiest songs benefit from the most from the more crystalline proceedings
column6: but the rockers often sound a little restrained. In a live setting there’s no doubt that “100” and “Make It New” would sufficiently shred
column7: but on record one can’t help but wish Yun’s voice would occupy a little less of the sonic real estate and that the guitars were allowed to rip a little harder. Also seemingly out of step on the record is “Not For This One”—a mellow
column8: Feelies-vibed mid-tempo track in which Daniel Cundiff takes over vocal duties. It’s undoubtedly one of the album’s loveliest songs
column9: but it sounds like it could/should appear on a different record altogether—one that perhaps Cundiff (who has a history of contributing vocals to interesting one-offs on previous records) should consider actually making.

column1: In a career that seems predicated on striking some kind of balance—a balance between whisper and roar
column2: messiness and finesse
column3: between articulating Heavenly-style twee bedroom musings versus whipping up walls of roiling melodic noise—Eternal Summers appear to have nearly hit their stride. While nothing here qualifies as any kind of radical reinvention of the indie-rock wheel per se
column4: the band manages to astutely put their own spin on it
column5:
seemingly figuring out their own sizable strengths in the process.  

"|19062.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19062-eternal-summers-the-drop-beneath/|7.8|T. Cole Rachel

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20256/homepage_large.6faaf182.jpg|Spectre|5100.0|Laibach|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute']|2014-03-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:32.317049|"

The Slovenian group Laibach are fundamentally a performance-art project
column2: with a single barbed joke they've been repeating for over 30 years: observing how art becomes a tool of totalitarianism
column3: and pushing it as far as it can go in that direction. Their work is deliberate kitsch—music for stomping around in jackboots
column4: slickly polished and martial
column5: drawing on imagery and slogans from both Communist and Fascist history. In that context
column6: the title of Spectre is very clearly an allusion to the opening line of The Communist Manifesto—but it's also a description of the current state of the band. Once dangerous political dissidents (they were banned in Yugoslavia for several years)
column7: they've gradually become grumpy subcultural fixtures.

column1: Laibach are also
column2: historically
column3: very cagey about who's in the band and who's not: they're a collective
column4: don'tcha know. Nonetheless
column5: it's reasonable to assume that these days they're basically stentorian lead mutterer Milan Fras and whoever else happens to be around. On Spectre
column6: there's a woman with a less prominent accent than Fras' who gets about as much microphone time as he does; is it the group's occasional vocalist Anja Rupel? Cease your impertinent questions
column7: cur. It's a member of Laibach.

column1: For those attuned to the joke
column2: Laibach's music (and the work of the Neue Slowenische Kunst collective with which they're affiliated) is a perpetually jabbing finger aimed at the aesthetic fetishes of military power. For anyone who's not paying attention as closely
column3: it just sounds fetish-y—hence their popularity in goth clubs in the late 80s and early 90s
column4: when they were recording Laibach-ized covers of songs like ""Sympathy for the Devil"" and ""The Final Countdown"". Covers
column5: in general
column6: have been Laibach's calling card—their previous non-soundtrack album was 2006's Volk
column7: for which their repertoire was national anthems.

column1: Spectre
column2: though
column3: is all new songs
column4: and nobody listens to Laibach for songs; their selling point is attitude
column5: the snarling demands and airbrushed electronic stomp they settled on several decades ago. (A stray name-drop of Occupy Wall Street in ""No History"" is nearly the only sign here that they've been paying attention to the past decade or so; ""Walk With Me"" and ""Resistance Is Futile"" both sound like musical ideas Depeche Mode would have left on the outtake reel circa 1986.) There are some clever arrangements here
column6: like the ""Colonel Bogey March""-ish whistle that opens the album (the song's called ""The Whistleblowers""
column7: and yes
column8: that's an elbow jabbing your ribs)
column9: or the chants of ""liver liver liver liver liver"" in ""Eat Liver!""
column10: which otherwise comes off like what would happen if the Russian Police Choir followed up ""Get Lucky"" with a rendition of Suicide's ""Rocket USA"".

column1: Still
column2: the stiffly prefabricated industrial-dance grooves that Laibach habitually fall back on don't quite cut it any more
column3: and without a monolithic state to serve as the object of their satire
column4: they're reduced to mocking political fatuity. The result is sometimes all but indistinguishable from what they're mocking. A lot of Spectre's lyrics are meaningless up-with-the-people sentiments like ""We're rising higher/ Come don't look back now/ Let's reach the stars"" or ""If you wanna change the world/ You'd better do it with a thrill/ 'Cause if you don't no one else will
column5: or equally meaningless intimations of disaster
column6: as when Fras and a synth choir declare ""Europe is falling apart"" in ""Eurovision"" (there's that elbow again).

column1: When Spectre plays its vocalists against each other—Laibach are wise to dialectic if any band is—it sometimes manages to work up a bit of the band's old dissonant dissidence. ""Koran"" contrasts Laibach Woman intoning platitudes (""I believe in a better world... I believe in brotherhood
column2: equality
column3: and freedom"") with Fras growling ""Words are nice/ Words are memories of pain."" The group clearly has plenty of painful memories
column4:
but they haven't found new battles they can fight.

"|19052.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19052-laibach-spectre/|4.9|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20304/homepage_large.0502375e.jpg|Mastermind|4880.0|Rick Ross|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Maybach']|2014-03-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:33.737092|"

Think back on all we’ve learned about Rick Ross since his 2006 debut album Port of Miami. He sells dope off the iPhone. His girls look like money bags. He wakes up to lobster bisque and reclines to the finest crab meats. Ross has pushed pomp at the expense of disclosure ever since he teased a serviceable personal style out of the paint-by-numbers Miami-Dade pimp chronicles of his early career. But what kept these impersonal missives afloat was a theatrical kingpin flair that seemed to expand in relation to attacks on his dominance. In 2009
column2: when 50 Cent unearthed evidence of Ross’ history as a corrections officer
column3: he brushed it off and struck back with the deliciously plush and cartoonishly prideful Deeper Than Rap and Teflon Don. After a health scare on an airplane in 2011
column4: he puffed his plume further with the Miami Vice villainy of 2012’s Rich Forever and God Forgives
column5: I Don’t. Ross has spent much of his career running defense against claims he’s lost his touch
column6: even as his kingly seafood diet has been usurped by diced pineapples
column7: but he’s had a tougher time than usual in the past year
column8: as threats from gangs
column9: show cancellations
column10: and a drive-by after a birthday celebration raised salient concerns about his wellbeing. A flippant line about spiking a girl’s drink on trap baron Rocko’s hit “U.O.E.N.O.” reportedly cost him a lucrative promotional deal with Reebok. His Maybach Music Group’s Self Made Vol. 3 struggled to connect with a national audience
column11: while a series of fiery solo singles skirted the Billboard Hot 100 entirely. A proposed release date for his sixth studio album Mastermind came and went this past December
column12: and while Ross assured fans he was just “putting final touches on the album
column13: ” it looked like the untouchable Maybach Music empire had hit a rough patch.

column1: Mastermind finally lands this week tasked with saving face after a bad year. But God Forgives rode fans’ willful suspension of disbelief raw as Ross anointed himself a pirate
column2: a king
column3: and a president over an album adorned in the gaudiest of embellishments. It doesn’t help that Mastermind finds him slipping from character into caricature. Many of the song concepts here are wan
column4: and much of the wordplay is spent. On “Sanctified”
column5: he’s the “fresh David Koresh
column6: ” soliciting grilled cheeses and fellatio from concubines. “BLK & WHT” houses Ross’ third joke about the George Zimmerman trial (“Trayvon Martin
column7: I’m never missing my target”)
column8: and the same song’s chorus drably quips that “a nigga black but he sellin’ white.” “Walking on Air” is fashioned entirely out of biblical airballs like “I’m into fashion
column9: nigga
column10: John the Baptist” (whose signature outfit is said to be the hair of whatever wilderness animal he managed to skin) and “Half you niggas Judas
column11: I’m the son of Moses” (whose progeny were passed up as his successors in the priesthood in favor of his nephews). When he’s not falling flat on bad puns
column12: he’s busy hawking his Wingstop restaurants’ lemon pepper chicken wings.

column1: With Ross’ hammy tendencies fading from strength to liability
column2: it’s up to label money and collaborators to save this thing
column3: and bless them all
column4: they tried. Mastermind shines when guest raps from Ross regulars Meek Mill
column5: Lil Wayne
column6: and Jay-Z light a fire under his ass. Wayne and Jay’s great chemistry with Ross proves mutually inspiring for both; “The Devil Is a Lie” nets a better Jay verse than can be found on the majority of Magna Carta Holy Grail
column7: and Wayne’s attack closer “Thug Cry” delivers an intensity recent releases have lacked. Kanye rolls a fixation on Chicago drill and Atlanta swag rap cadences
column8: a rousing vocal from soul great Betty Wright
column9: spectral synths and sinewy lows from ratchet maestro DJ Mustard
column10: and Ross’ trademark overindulgence into the regal pomp of “Sanctified” for the album’s high watermark. “Sanctified” is an outstanding entry into Ross and Kanye’s catalogue of stunners
column11: but it never feels like Ross’ song. The same can be said for deep cut “In Vein”
column12: where Ross cedes the reins to the Weeknd’s promethazine noir
column13: showing face more than halfway in and skating after a quick verse like a guest on his own record. Similarly
column14: “War Ready”’s bloodless
column15: overlong summit with erstwhile Rozay nemesis Jeezy only takes off when the snowman touches the mic.

column1: When Mastermind’s not clinging to famous friends
column2: it’s thrashing at 90s classics for direction. Early on
column3: following a skit playing 911 call audio from the scene of Ross’ shooting
column4: “Nobody” remakes the Notorious B.I.G.’s unsettlingly fatalistic “You’re Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You)”. Given a shot at breaking kayfabe and speaking on the incident
column5: Ross largely opts out
column6: spitting street rap boilerplate in a Biggie cadence he can never quite pull off. “What a Shame” references both Wu-Tang Clan’s “Shame on a Nigga” and Camp Lo’s “Luchini (AKA This Is It)” but brings little to the table beyond French Montana’s bratty “Hanh!” ad lib. “Thug Cry” fares better employing the Billy Cobham sample that provided the backdrop for NorCal alt-rap veterans Souls of Mischief’s “‘93 til Infinity” but damn near drowns under a melodramatic sung hook and more lemon pepper wing talk. Mastermind’s sporadic 90s flair feels cursory
column7: but it actually saves the album from a glut of productions all too often beholden to the bleating synths of mid-2000s DJ Toomp and the moody
column8: intricate sounds of Mannie Fresh. The album could’ve used a few more J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League burners and a trap house brawler or two to lift up the sluggish pace. It wraps in just over an hour
column9: but you’ll feel like you’ve been through much more
column10: listening from end to end.

column1: Mastermind finds Rick Ross in the same predicament his mortal enemy 50 Cent experienced when they squared off in 2009. He’s badly in need of reinvention after running out of recipes for his gangster shtick
column2: but he’s too set in his ways to change direction six albums in. Mastermind gestures at Ross inviting us inside his thought process on “Nobody”
column3: where he intimates that he sends a decoy tour bus around the on tour while traveling via private jet
column4: and “Rich Is Gangsta”
column5: which doubles down on the story that his stint as a corrections officer was an intentional ruse. But the moments where Mastermind gives us William Roberts the man instead of Rick Ross the gangster flick composite character with the borrowed name are scarce
column6: and he remains committed to dialing in good life platitudes that increasingly ring hollow. Mastermind finds Ross at a Truman Show moment: his character’s reached the logical end of its universe. Going forward
column7:
he can either break out or keep up a jig he knows that we know is way past expired.

"|19097.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19097-rick-ross-mastermind/|5.8|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20277/homepage_large.46f542f1.jpg|Guilty of Everything|31634.0|Nothing|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-03-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:34.341470|"

Relapse Records is a metal label. You know that. I know that. I only bring it up because it’s going to frame a great deal of the discussion surrounding recent signee Nothing’s debut LP Guilty of Everything
column2: which might be unusually heavy dream-pop
column3: billowy alt-rock
column4: or blustery shoegaze
column5: but it is definitely not metal. There’s probably never been a time when wimp panic wasn’t a pressing concern in the metal community
column6: but these are more fraught times than ever judging by the two most controversial records of recent months—countless hours in 2013 were spent debating whether Deafheaven were too soft to be “real metal
column7: ” while doomgaze progenitors Alcest dropped the “doom” part entirely on the antiseptic Shelter. Situated almost exactly between the sound of those two records
column8: Guilty of Everything walks right into the ongoing crossfire
column9: which might actually make it the ballsiest metal album in recent memory.

column1: Whatever guff they get from headbangers
column2: this kind of projected audacity certainly works in favor of a record that doesn’t really have much itself. Guilty of Everything is loud
column3: it’s distorted and it’s heavy
column4: but it’s not aggressive. It’s actually quite comforting. No matter how softly Domenic Palermo sings during the first minute of “Hymn to the Pillory” and no matter how pretty those clean
column5: 8th-note guitar chords are
column6: you’re conditioned to know the tidal crash is coming. And when it does
column7: it’s warm and enveloping
column8: soothing almost. Even the moments of dissonance on Guilty of Everything have an aqueous rather than an abrasive feel; on the stirring single “Dig”
column9: Palermo’s vocals have a steadying effect amidst the seasick
column10: melodic leads while “Endlessly” swoons in the manner of a wave pool
column11: contained
column12: just immersive enough and somewhat menacing if you let your attention slip.

column1: Of course
column2: Guilty of Everything is comforting because it’s familiar as well—25 years of indie rock have been supported by the idea that bludgeoning guitars and vaporous vocals are somehow incompatible and for the first 15 minutes or so
column3: having the opposite once again confirmed can even be kinda thrilling. But after that point
column4: Nothing have pretty much told you all they have to say. That’s in a figurative sense
column5: as Guilty on Everything seems to fold back on itself
column6: its second half repeating certain modes on the first—the “uptempo one”
column7: the “quasi-ambient” one
column8: the waltz. The guitars remain gorgeous throughout
column9: though lacking tonal or dynamic variety and Palermo’s vocals start to take the effect of stale taffy
column10: soft and still retaining its sweetness
column11: but inflexible.

column1: But in a literal sense
column2: you haven’t really heard anything Palermo has to say. Even when pitted against the quietest moments of Guilty of Everything
column3: Palermo’s words are nearly impossible to make out. To be fair
column4: this applies to 99% of all vocalists in this realm. But otherwise
column5: it actually made the lack of specificity even more frustrating. Because you sense there is some kind of personality Nothing can’t quite convey in their music just yet.

column1: I listened to Guilty of Everything without the lyrics sheet and not much more was revealed after listening with it. Same goes for finding out that the songs were inspired by Palermo’s coming of age in Philadelphia’s extremely shitty Kensington section and serving a two-year bid for aggravated assault and attempted murder. It gives some kind of perspective to typically generalized lyrics like “I’m on my knees...I’m guilty of everything
column2: ” and can make this record something of a conceptual piece about the will to live and a death wish somehow converging. But otherwise
column3:
a solid debut can’t help but feel just a little disappointing after realizing you could’ve had the doomgaze answer to The B. Coming.

"|19071.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19071-nothing-guilty-of-everything/|6.9|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20275/homepage_large.aadc0eda.jpg|Yung Archetype EP|32121.0|Tunde Olaniran|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Quite Scientific']|2014-03-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:34.855902|"

On “Highway""
column2: the second song on his Yung Archetype EP
column3: Tunde Olaniran matter-of-factly lays out a winking indictment that seems to double as a mission statement: “We off punk
column4: we on trap
column5: ” he intones. Coming in a long rap about fracking
column6: incarceration trends
column7: and
column8: especially
column9: people who shop at Whole Foods while frowning on dudes with sagging pants (“they're white but still like rap”)
column10: it's a sharp observation—made sharper by the fact that thematically it's basically a punk song delivered over a skittering trap beat that samples a parrot. This type of witty confusion interlaced with a broader social message is pretty much par for the course for Olaniran. If the winking
column11: Carl-Jung-goes-hip-hop title of the project or its cover showing Olaniran with a grill and a jacket tailored out of traditional Nigerian lace fabric weren't clear enough indicators
column12: let's just say it outright: He's ready to fuck with your expectations.

column1: Part of this approach is simply something that's been thrust on Olaniran
column2: whose music would rather explore identity than adhere to strict
column3: conventional ideas of it. In interviews
column4: he's talked about getting dismissed by blogs that say they don't cover hip-hop based on his picture while at the same time making music that didn't seem to belong on rap blogs. But he's also been a champion of the diversity of the music scene in his home of Flint
column5: Michigan—a city
column6: that
column7: despite a rich musical history
column8: is more commonly associated with industrial decline and crime—and he's vocal about making art from a place as an ally to marginalized groups. A Nigerian-American raised in London
column9: Germany
column10: and Flint whose formative musical experience was touring Europe with Berlin-based producer Phon.o after the two met on MySpace and collaborated
column11: Olaniran's frame of reference is unsurprisingly broad. To further contextualize: He's collaborated extensively with the band Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr.
column12: and he's also known to keep a fog machine in the trunk of his car.

column1: Even in this brief five-song offering
column2: Olaniran tries on a lot of different ideas. His approach probably most closely resembles the kitchen-sink genre pastiche and loosely political brio of M.I.A. or
column3: to some extent
column4: the silly perceptiveness and electronic experimentation of rap acts like Das Racist and Le1f. The product is a pitch-perfect mashup of where pop-leaning underground music
column5: or perhaps underground-aware pop music
column6: stands in 2014
column7: incorporating the rattling percussion of trap and dance music with a presentational
column8: genre-spanning glam sensibility. “The Raven”
column9: for instance
column10: feels a little bit like what would happen if Ellie Goulding and A$AP Rocky teamed up to make a song about magic
column11: pairing Olaniran's grandiose
column12: swooping sung vocals with screwed-down raps about “witches in Williamsburg.” “Critical” finds Olaniran doing a solid James Blake impression shot through with Yeezus-style bursts of distortion.

column1: The two-year-old “Brown Boy” might still be Olaniran's most vital offering
column2: though
column3: a thunderous
column4: clattering four-alarm fire of a song. On ""Brown Boy""
column5: Olaniran calmly cuts through by rapping lines like “And then these questions/ they can really trip me up/ Especially when they prove/ to be real tough/ Like can I be a man?/ Can I not love?” with a sardonic flair that seems increasingly profound on repeated listens. The hook offers a pithy look at racial prejudice that somehow manages to not feel reductive.

column1: Not every moment of Yung Archetype is quite as lyrically smooth. Olaniran sometimes namechecks ideas where it might be useful to explore them
column2: and he also has a tendency toward simple
column3: clever similes like “go hard like Thanksgiving for vegans” that are funny but don't necessarily do much beyond fill space on repeated listens. “The Internet""
column4: while catchy and funny
column5: can feel a little bit circular
column6: since it's a song that will likely be talked about on the Internet that's in part about promoting music on the Internet (on the other hand
column7: that's probably the appropriate feeling for it to have). But these issues are minor qualms that don't necessarily take away from the music and only stand out because of the brevity of the project. For the most part
column8: Yung Archetype is an explosive
column9: dynamic offering from what is clearly a restlessly creative talent. Olaniran's ideas could have massive reach—anyone who seems to gunning for David Bowie
column10:
Kanye West and Missy Elliott right out of the gate is clearly poised for some big stuff—and this is a great look at that process beginning to happen. 

"|19069.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19069-tunde-olaniran-yung-archetype-ep/|7.3|Kyle Kramer

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20274/homepage_large.0c6aa8f8.jpg|Aqonis|32120.0|Eadonmm|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Day Tripper']|2014-03-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:35.415214|"

Eadonmm has a knack for being out of place. The solo project of Osaka’s Shinya Wada emerged in 2011 during a boom period for Japanese electronic music in the city
column2: but while his counterparts dabbled in Brainfeeder-inspired cosmic beats or maximalist dance sounds
column3: he crafted spacious tracks focused on inducing shivers rather than getting people moving. Other producers around him performed in front of colorful geometric visuals
column4: while Eadonmm plays in front of projections of flames. With his debut
column5: Aqonis
column6: he’s made a shadowy
column7: captivating album that would have easily been lumped in with the micro genre witch house—if it hadn’t become a punch line.

column1: Despite sharing a love of pitched vocal samples and goth-leaning visuals
column2: Aqonis stands out  because Eadonmm establishes a genuinely unsettling mood
column3: something most of the bigger names in witch house never did. He avoids the sonic suffocation and aggression of Salem
column4: instead leaning toward the sparse structures of Balam Acab and oOoOO. Moments of beauty emerged from the dark corners of those artists' best songs
column5: bits that were often built from warped R&B vocals or YouTube-ripped audio. With Eadonmm
column6: the space only hides more mysteries
column7: each layer revealing a creepier detail nudged forward by skittering beats. He has a specific
column8: very dark sound in mind
column9: and maintains it throughout the album’s run time.

column1: Wada manages this by making sure the music never settles for one loop
column2: letting new sounds creep in whenever possible. “Oblivio Throb” pulses forward
column3: but several vocal whines swirl about and a carnival-appropriate synth line pops up underneath
column4: adding a woozy charm. “Gothic Anamnesis” achieves a similar vibe with rat-a-tat drum programming and water splashes
column5: while lurching centerpiece “If You Melted” unnerves with extended
column6: muffled dialogue and the occasional throaty whisper. These aren’t sonic jump scares
column7: but a bunch of small details creating a larger
column8: unsettling mood.

column1: It's easy to overdo this sort of thing
column2: but Eadonmm paces the album well. Several brief
column3: drumless passages offer space between tracks
column4: allowing for breathing room without sacrificing the ominous feel. Then there are the reminders that
column5: for all the darkness
column6: this project has roots in the club (Wada himself started his own party around Osaka in 2011). Shuffling numbers such as “Tide Up” and “Dim” sound like a more disorienting Holy Other
column7: and they have enough of a bounce to offer a break from the brooding.

column1: Wada only falters when his work comes too close to pure loop music. Ironically
column2: “Perpetual Goes” fails to go anywhere beyond the hiccuping vocal sample at its core. He fares better on “Alder”
column3: which is also built around a wisp of a voice
column4: though it could've been trimmed down without surrendering any of the otherworldly atmosphere. The one time he pulls off this sort of repetition is on closer
column5: “Post Obit”
column6: a surging noise cut that hits harder thanks to its sudden loudness appearing after the subtler tracks. It's moments like this that showcase the overall strength of Eadonmm's work—he's a producer with an unnerving approach
column7:
one where the smallest details come together to form a larger whole that lingers.

Read anything about Washington Heights-bred MC and Das Racist (R.I.P.) affiliate Lakutis (Aleksey Weintraub)
column2: and one word seems to pop up with alarming regularity: Dirtbag. Known more for his party animal persona than this rapping
column3: he certainly looks the part
column4: like the gold-toothed
column5: frequently shirtless offspring of Ted Nugent. Dirtbag or no
column6: he's an eccentric for sure
column7: evidenced on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14662-sit-down-man/"" target=""_blank""><i>Sit Down
column8: Man-era features like ""Amazing""
column9: which showcased his heavy-lidded but zealous flow. Though his appearances alongside the DR boys felt a bit like charity (or maybe it was because he just felt like one smartass too many)
column10: he fared a little better on his own. His 2012 I'm in the Forest EP found him trying to find his voice in the New York weirdo party rap community
column11: druggily reinterpreting Ja Rule and Ashanti's ""Put It On Me""
column12: dropping smart-dumb non-sequiters (""Chilean with miners but I'm major"")
column13: and even offering a few choice tracks (""Lakutis in the House""). Two years later
column14: Lakutis is back with his pay-what-you-want full-length debut 3 Seashells. Still prone to fits of bizarre leftfield humor
column15: 3 Seashells reigns the focus in and unveils a darker
column16: more unhinged version of a man who now compulsively refers to himself as ""skeleton"" (he pronounces it ""skell-a-tawn"").

column1: A few months ago
column2: Lakutis offered up the single ""Jesus Piece""
column3: accompanied by a Tarsem-esque video that found him fighting through a nosebleed and getting covered in gold paint. Nothing too original in the visual department
column4: but the track itself—dystopic
column5: sludge-y
column6: and queasy to the point of needing a Dramamine—felt ahead of the curve. And it's a good way into 3 Seashells
column7: which feels like its been informed by horrorcore and Wu-Tang in equal measure. It's a record that suggests the person who made it spends more time listening to rap music than actually making it
column8: a paranoid loner with a baggie of bad acid trying to translate a stack of classic 90s New York hip-hop records in his basement. Save for a feature from DVS
column9: Lakutis is on his own here
column10: making an unsubtle statement of independence. Instead
column11: it just sounds like he's scared all of his friends away. Tracks are short and punchy
column12: operating like mini exorcisms or kooky freestyle templates. And while he's still prone to boneheaded provocation—""Skeleton"" sounds like a booty bass track whacked-out on PCP
column13: complete with howling and babbling; ""Mumra"" is a dirge-y black magic chant—3 Seashells reinvents the rapper without skimping on the details that made him oddly compelling in the first place.

column1: Part of this has to do with the production. Helmed by a stable of relative unknowns
column2: the beats on 3 Seashells feel cypher-ready but take on more experimental shapes
column3: favoring caustic sounds that give off an eerie
column4: unpredictable impression. SicksentZ's ""Black Swann"" sound like a washing machine with a cinderblock in it trying to recreate the drums on ""Loser""; Bill Ding's ""Dope As Fuck"" (which feels like a companion piece to A$AP Ferg's ""Dump Dump"") is draped in haunted moans; a creeped out Eastern mystic vibe undercuts Spvce's ""Mumra"". More traditional compositions fit in nicely as well
column5: like previous Lakutis collaborator Steel Tipped Dove's opening two contributions
column6: like the smoker-friendly ""Animal"" or the headknock throwback ""What the Fuck"". Even the goofy lover's rock of ""Body Scream"" manages to charm.

column1: But if you're coming to 3 Seashells looking for bars
column2: it's best to look elsewhere. Lakutis isn't big on coherent content
column3: favoring a sort of stream of consciousness approach to his rhyming. Granted
column4: 3 Seashells doesn't stray too far from your run of the mill rap hedonism. But his trademark wisecracking is also present
column5: referring to himself at one point as ""Tombstone Pizza Pierre"". Other times
column6: he waxes Rust Cohle
column7: like on ""Jesus Piece"" (""Look at the fuck have you done/ Made a world where father doesn't know his son/ But the drugs let the child know god if he want""). Lakutis' real strong suit is the way he raps
column8: punctuating words with a visceral intensity usually reserved for the frontman of a hardcore band
column9: his flow almost functioning as a percussive element.

column1: 3 Seashells was slated to come out late last year
column2: but was pushed back a couple times
column3: with Lakutis repeatedly promising on Twitter that it would be ready any minute. With this in mind
column4: the album feels a little rushed
column5: and for such a short ride (12 tracks
column6: only three of which scrape the three minute mark
column7: including two brief in-jokes masquerading as skits)
column8: there's one or two too many missed targets. Coupled with Lakutis' nagging need to freak out the squares at nearly every turn
column9:
3 Seashells is more promising than anything else.

The atmosphere that permeates Warfaring Strangers: Darkscorch Canticles seems straight out of someone’s incense-fumigated
column2: window-blackened basement circa 1975. As well it should. The 16-song collection is a murky snapshot of mid-1970s American proto-metal
column3: a loose confederation of groups working mostly in obscurity and isolation that drew on the supple yet thudding heft of Deep Purple
column4: Uriah Heep
column5: and Black Sabbath. But unlike the tape-trading metal culture that was just a few years away
column6: these bands had little to no DIY infrastructure through which to spread said sounds. A handful of American groups of that era such as Sir Lord Baltimore and Pentagram managed to persevere
column7: push though
column8: and become better known. Warfaring Strangers pays alms to those who didn’t.

column1: As altars go
column2: there’s plenty to worship. Drawn from 7” singles released throughout the 70s on tiny regional labels across the continent (Toronto’s Sir Lord Baltimore-esque Triton Warrior being the disc’s lone Canadian delegate)
column3: the band leading the charge is Medusa
column4: whose full-length
column5: circa-'75 document First Step Beyond surfaced in 2013 and helped bring about this set. “Black Wizard” appears both here and on First Step Beyond. It’s well chosen. Suffused with tape hiss and an almost orchestral gravitas
column6: the song captures occult vibes
column7: galloping dread
column8: and overreaching stabs at jazz-prog virtuosity that lend it an unhinged urgency. The sorcerous
column9: first-person narrative could have been sung from the perspective of Sabbath’s titular “The Wizard”
column10: and as with legions of doom bands to come
column11: Ozzy is held as chief druid. But Tolkien is the demigod: A love of The Lord of the Rings
column12: then recently popularized in rock thanks to Led Zeppelin
column13: bleeds through on “King of the Golden Hall”—courtesy of Iowa’s geographically displaced Stonehenge—and “Song of Sauron”
column14: a track by Michigan’s Sonaura
column15: who used to spread their harmonized sludge as openers for the Stooges and the MC5.

column1: What makes the bands on Warfaring Strangers so compelling
column2: though
column3: are their idiosyncratic visions of weird America. A decade before Mötley Crüe’s “Shout at the Devil” became the national anthem for would-be suburban warlocks
column4: Tampa’s Wizard—formed by survivors of the 60s teen-garage scene—sang “Séance”
column5: a tuneful
column6: alternately delicate and distorted paean to Satan as a metaphor for the druggy counterculture. In this same environment that their fellow Rosemary’s babies such as Arrogance and Inside (both
column7: miraculously
column8: from North Carolina) converted local bog-water and Heep-worthy organ riffs into the near-Lovecraftian hymns “Black Death” and “Wizzard King”
column9: respectively. Largely unaware of the metal tropes and conventions being carved in stone in the mid-70s—mostly in England
column10: where early metal connected
column11: codified
column12: and thrived—San Antonio’s Hellstorm let the fuzz drift and the funk unfurl. The only African-American group on Warfaring Strangers
column13: Hellstorm ends the anthology on a bloodcurdling note: The decade’s laidback haze is fed
column14: with sacrificial zeal
column15: back into itself.

column1: Numero Group
column2: the label behind both Darkscorch Canticles (as well as Medusa’s First Step Beyond)
column3: might have gone a little overboard with the supplemental release of a companion board game titled Cities of Darkscorch. Or maybe the gesture is exactly overboard enough. After all
column4: these bands were not going for realism or restraint
column5: choosing instead to champion an amped-up
column6: all-American arcana for a post-Manson decade in which hippie mysticism had turned ink-black. If True Detective had been conceived in the 70s and set from sea to shining sea instead of the Deep South
column7:
Warfaring Strangers might have made for a gloriously eerie score.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20176/homepage_large.3542898f.jpg|English Oceans|1183.0|Drive-By Truckers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2014-03-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:37.321276|"

Drive-By Truckers don’t owe us shit. They’ve never made a bad or even a mediocre album in their two decades
column2: even though they’ve given themselves many opportunities to do so. And considering their occasionally acrimonious lineup changes and bold conceptual gambits
column3: they’d have many valid excuses if that fate were to come to pass. But depending on your affinity for 2008’s generous-to-a-fault Brighter Than Creation’s Dark
column4: it’s either been six years or 10 since their last truly great album. English Oceans isn’t great
column5: but it’s not mediocre and certainly not bad—but its reception most likely will be predicated on whether or not you think Drive-By Truckers owe you anything more than a “Drive-By Truckers album.”

column1: They seemed due for a shake up
column2: particularly after the hiatus occurring following 2011’s Go-Go Boots. Bassist Shonna Tucker (who started contributing songs and vocals on Brighter) and pedal-steel specialist John Neff left the band
column3: while founding members Patterson Hood and Mike Cooley both made solo records. And in several aspects
column4: this is a return to form; English Oceans is much more of a “rock” record than the Muscle Shoals-influenced Go-Go Boots
column5: though DBT have retained enough groove to the point where there’s just as much Stones in their sound as there is Skynyrd
column6: probably more so. And that’s a good thing
column7: as they had the tendency to be a lumbering musical entity even during their peak days.

column1: It’s also the first time since their 2001 breakthrough Southern Rock Opera where the songwriting duties are split solely between Cooley and Hood. More pointedly
column2: it’s the first time the songwriting duties have been split equally. And that allows you to hear Drive-By Truckers in a completely different way
column3: because not only does Cooley reestablish himself after being relegated to a bit player on Go-Go Boots and The Big To-Do
column4: he actually puts this album on his back.

column1: In the past
column2: he hasn’t been underrated so much as overshadowed. Hood’s been often seen as DBT’s head and heart
column3: whereas Cooley operates more from the gut and groin
column4: the sidekick
column5: the comic relief. Cooley still comes up with some instantly quotable
column6: real-talk snark about the sad sex lives of white-collar supervisors (“Trophy tail wives taking boner pill rides for the price of a Happy Meal”) and a henpecked friend (“Said she only hollered when she'd stood as much as she could stand/ Jimmy's ego can take it ‘baby go on and fake it loud as you can’""). But he’s also developed a kind of redneck
column7: cosmic profundity to rival that of early Isaac Brock. While still spoken in plain language
column8: Cooley gets at the kind of accidental enlightenment available to intelligent
column9: if undereducated men given repetitive tasks and a lot of time to mull over things. The construction worker on the shit-hot “Shit Shots Count” notes “Meat’s just meat and it's all born dying.../ Somebody's gotta mop up the A-1 somebody's gotta mop up the blood
column10: ” while a tumultuous relationship on “Natural Light” is “As cold as a loveless embrace/ Or hot like a low seething rage.”

column1: Cooley’s superlative performance on English Oceans would be more worthy of celebration if it wasn’t negated by Hood’s most non-committal songwriting to date. “When He’s Gone”
column2: “Til He’s Dead or Rises”
column3: and “Pauline Hawkins” are all variations on the same inert gender dynamics
column4: pro forma Dixie rock with gawky choruses that I suppose one could applaud for being lyrically succinct: “She can't stand to have him around/ But she always misses him when he's gone
column5: ” “love is like cancer/ And I am immune
column6: ” “She’ll ride him until he’s dead/ Or rises to the occasion.” But Hood never uses these sturdy
column7: nondescript phrases to bear any additional detail or personality
column8: and that’s problematic for a songwriter of his nature: there’s never been a strong melody or a killer riff that’s saved a lyrically weak DBT song.

column1: The gap is even more clear when the duo delve into politics. Cooley’s “Made Up English Oceans” alternates the surreal and hyper-real in a manner similar to PJ Harvey’s Let England Shake
column2: invoking right-wing zealots and god-fearing religious factions while leaving worlds open to the interpretation. Conversely
column3: Hood’s “The Part of Him” recalls the strawmanning that marred The Dirty South
column4: leaning hard on stilted rhymes (“His integrity was phoning in/ Totally Nixonian”) and shrugged jokes about wingnuts and teabags. As with “Pauline Hawkins” and “When He’s Gone”
column5: there’s no sense of place or humanity; it’s something Hood could’ve cooked up after a jag of ""House of Cards""
column6: to say nothing of the likely inspiration for “When Walter Went Crazy”.

column1: Which is to say that the truly great Drive-By Truckers albums may have been unified by a concept
column2: but the great songs they’ve made throughout their career are inspired by real people
column3: whether it’s “The Living Bubba”
column4: George Wallace
column5: the only people in America imprisoned for consensual incest
column6: Buford Pusser
column7: or Craig Lieske. If you don’t know the last name
column8: he served as DBT’s merch guy
column9: was a fixture in Athens’ music scene
column10: and was remembered fondly by his community upon his death in January 2013. He’s the inspiration for English Oceans’ showstopping closer “Grand Canyon”
column11: and it’s DBT’s most musically rich and expansive song to date
column12: seven-minutes of acoustic guitars and vocals that positively gleam in waltz time. Hood’s lyrics are equally up to the task
column13: a meditation on their last great memories with Lieske
column14: the therapeutic value of the road and the supernatural. It’ll probably be their closer for the next decade
column15: and if Drive-By Truckers are still touring in 10 years
column16: that’s a good thing. For now
column17: English Oceans ensures they’ll back on the road
column18:
where they’re still one of the best things going and Drive-By Truckers probably don’t owe us much more than that.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20182/homepage_large.94baaf20.jpg|The Power and the Glory|32023.0|Perc|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Perc Trax']|2014-03-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:38.506723|"

UK techno has always occupied an odd space. It has little relation to the Hardcore Continuum—that line of distinctly British club music that encompasses Hardcore
column2: Drum and Bass
column3: and UK Garage—instead taking its cues from the rougher areas of Detroit and Berlin
column4: minus the former's futurist escapism and the latter's hedonism. Stern and un-funky by design
column5: UK techno is music for aesthetes
column6: hardscrabble bangers strung together to cleanse and exfoliate. It seems designed not to help clubgoers forget their troubles for a weekend but rather to inspire those clubgoers to bloody their troubles' noses. It's a style that's seen a resurgence in recent years
column7: beginning in part with techno high priest Karl O'Connor (Regis)'s involvement in Sandwell District—and Berlin's return to harsher clubbing realms—and growing more recently by acting as a refugee camp for dubstep orphans like Blawan and Untold.

column1: Ali Wells
column2: aka Perc
column3: is at the forefront of this resurgence largely because he's been making scraping techno bangers
column4: with little rest or deviation
column5: since 2002. His Perc Trax label has been a breeding ground for young producers like Truss and Forward Strategy Group
column6: serving as an inspiration to upstart labels like Avian
column7: just as O'Connor's Downwards served to Perc Trax. Wells' debut album
column8: 2011's Wicker and Steel
column9: crystallized this trend
column10: leading the Guardian to compare Wells' bleak soundscapes to contemporary Britain's flailing socio-political climate
column11: because sometimes hissy noise isn't allowed to be just hissy noise. Because of all of this
column12: Wells' second album
column13: The Power and the Glory
column14: is expected to be not just another industrial techno record
column15: but a totem release on which this style of music can lean.

column1: The record succeeds
column2: mostly
column3: inasmuch as it reconfirms that Wells is one of the style's most creative deviants. The Power and the Glory is a roiling album that feels looser and more chaotic than the rigid constructs Wells normally works within. Only a handful of the album's 10 tracks adhere to the four-to-the-floor overdriven kicks and unpitched ephemera that remain the backbone of UK techno. Like Surgeon before him
column4: Wells understands an album requires a defter touch than a standard 12"". The album starts slowly with ""Rotting Sound""
column5: one of two collaborations with Dethscalator's Dan Chandler. An unbound mix of speaker static
column6: sampled dialogue
column7: and Chandler's echoing yelps
column8: it's a terrible chore that mostly serves to prevent listeners from getting on with the mashing fun in a timely fashion.

column1: The rest of The Power and the Glory fares far better. It's less strict and formalist—and better—than Wicker and Steel
column2: making room for tracks like ""Speek""
column3: an eerie
column4: thrumming soundscape featuring Factory Floor's Nik Colk Void and ""Horse Gum""
column5: a dubby
column6: ambient collage. ""Galloper""
column7: a near-breakbeat infused with a sickly organ
column8: has enough space and pacing to spar with London's hipper house producers. Importantly
column9: Wells also finds new and creative ways to pummel. ""Dumpster""
column10: which opens with a wink—some birds chirping over seaside waves—relies
column11: typically
column12: on a monstrously overdriven kick drum
column13: but also features a warped carnival melody. ""David & George"" is a delirious house of mirrors
column14: featuring a nasty
column15: snare-led beat a maniacal cackle.

column1: Like Untold's Black Light Spiral
column2: The Power and the Glory is an album that uses techno's scrape and burn to bring a group of disparate ideas together. Long a purist
column3: The Power and the Glory stands as Wells' boldest and messiest work to date. It's still techno—best used for riling oneself and/or cleansing the palate—but it's techno that veers from its traditional purpose
column4: picking at its scabs and rending its garments. Long a scene steward
column5: Wells greatest contribution is bringing personality to a style that
column6: by its very nature
column7:
avoids it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20247/homepage_large.cf1fe9d4.jpg|The Air You Found|30723.0|Empty Flowers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Translation Loss']|2014-03-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:39.102755|"

It’s as fortunate as it is telling that Empty Flowers didn’t look to Kickstarter to fund their new remix album
column2: The Air You Found. Though the tense New England quartet is itself only two years old
column3: the music they make definitively harkens back at least two decades—when the term indie rock felt a lot less amorphous
column4: when rich regional scenes formed in the most surprising places
column5: when bands from Slint and Shellac to Girls Against Boys and Archers of Loaf shaped their own bleeding edge. On two short LP’s
column6: 2012’s SIX and last year’s FIVE
column7: they’ve taken those acts and their associates as chief inspirations
column8: retrenching those sounds with a little metal heaviness. Had Slint made it past Spiderland and tried to concoct a three-minute
column9: tough-guy radio single for the Alternative Nation set
column10: it might have sounded like Empty Flowers’ “Quit”. The knotty shape and recalcitrant delivery of “Police” suggest a songwriter with an affinity for Unsane and Unwound. Their music suits a crowd for which “remix” can be a dirty word—a gimmicky addition to MAXI CD singles or
column11: these days
column12: the source of an inane viral video hit. Asking such people even to listen to a full LP of such recastings might rightfully raise some questions and eyebrows. Would you really want to hear the house edit of “Breadcrumb Trail”
column13: let alone help pay for it?

column1: Against most odds
column2: The Air You Found is a wonderful seven-song set that delights on its own terms and suggests new possibilities for Empty Flowers
column3: a young band previously hidebound to the past. Empty Flowers’ original “Call a Priest” was a cocksure standoff
column4: with frontman Christian McKenna offering vague threats over flinty guitars and a distant din. But Kevin Hufnagel detects a core of despair in McKenna’s tone and isolates his voice
column5: building around it an ornate cathedral of acoustic guitar. Working as Crone
column6: former Isis member Jeff Caxide inverts the guitar-centric aggression of “Ice on Wings” entirely. He turns the songs into a funhouse mirror drone
column7: where Vocoder vocals pass above a static hum and between space-rock keyboards. There is a beat-machine-buffeted industrial rendering (from Dälek leader Will Brooks
column8: now working as iconAclass) and a collage that pulls a song’s pieces apart and reassembles them in purposely oblong shapes (courtesy of James Plotkin
column9: a nominal metal guy comfortable with infinite genre splices).

column1: But the most engaging pieces here are the ones that don’t subvert or collapse Empty Flowers’ own takes but instead treat them as starting points. Tombs frontman Michael Hill reinforces the anxiety of “Resonate” with massive drums and blanketing synthesizers. He tumbles McKenna’s shouts through a revolving wheel of distress
column2: turning a noise-rock song into a blackened noise span that would feel at home on Hospital Productions. Jesu and Godflesh founder Justin Broadrick keys on the presiding drama of and subtle organ peals beneath “Car Fires”
column3: one of Empty Flowers’ best songs. He lets the number plow ahead as intended
column4: but pads out the song beneath it
column5: using the organ as an invitation to place the tune over a bed of luminous choirs and keys. Where the original tune ends
column6: Broadrick marches ahead
column7: using the song’s melody and meter to create a radiant instrumental coda. Its simultaneous heaviness and heavenliness sound like a perfect marriage of Jesu and Sigur Rós. But the Empty Flowers’ song serves as the anchor
column8: preventing the remix from drifting away in its own ethereality.

column1: As compelling as the tracks on The Air You Found can be
column2: what’s most intriguing about the collection is what’s not there: new material from Empty Flowers. Despite their rather rigid songs
column3: they have occasionally shown traces of influences outside of canonical indie and math rock and metal. “Call a Priest”
column4: from SIX
column5: sounds like a missing link between Eric Bachmann’s work in Archers of Loaf and Crooked Fingers
column6: but Empty Flowers added a surprising filigree of digital bursts over its top. And the widescreen arc of “Trained Not to Worry”
column7: from FIVE
column8: suggests the filmic ambitions of the most efficient post-rock acts. But those are only passing moments in a catalogue of consistency. Might these collaborations
column9: however
column10: push Empty Flowers out of their to-date accomplished revivalism
column11: showing them just how far the source of their sounds can be stretched? Imagining them taking austere acoustic detours of their own accord (as Hufnagel has them do) or turning into a drone ensemble (as Crone reshapes them) is a daunting stretch. But perhaps they can borrow those accents from this experience and use the extra textures to finesse their attack. That’s the real brilliance of Broadrick’s rendition of “Car Fires”
column12: which preserves the idea and attitude of the original but shows that the song’s slow-march backbone is only that—an origin
column13:
or a central point from which the song and the band itself can spread. Empty Flowers could do well to follow that example.

column1: Though their songwriting may indicate otherwise

column4: which

column6:
again.

column3: New Moon

column5: and after years of sonic and personal instability
column6: the quintet pooled their energy into being a rock band—one that liked their Neil Young loud
column7: their beer plentiful
column8: and their guitars in threes. A year later
column9: the message on Tomorrow’s Hits is about the same for people who preferred to see them as they were on 2011’s Leave Home
column10: revivalists of nearly every iteration of ugly and abrasive NYC guitar perversion
column11: or as the comprehensive indie-rawkers of Open Your Heart: they’re a rock band and the roll continues.

column1: As with New Moon and Open Your Heart
column2: the Men’s accruing success lends to a welcome
column3: optimistic outlook. There is an element of wishful thinking to Tomorrow’s Hits
column4: from its self-deprecating title to the supposedly unintentional Big Star homage of the cover. This is the first Men record put together in a high-end studio

column7: cabin-tested New Moon. For all of their abrasive tendencies

column1: Regardless of the slight upgrade in fidelity

column3: with “the Men” serving as a fantasy camp construct for the record collectors making this record collector rock. “Get What You Give” has absolutely nothing to do with the New Radicals song
column4: although it does share a taste for bubblegummy riffs and enthusiasm for music making: Chiericozzi literally gets out of bed only to chase the songwriting muse (on several other songs

column8: weed-dealing brother and mom buying your first guitar. This story begins in 1974
column9: meaning that Chiericozzi would have to be nearly 50 for this song to be autobiographical.

column1: If you caught them live in 2013
column2: most of these songs should be familiar
column3: since they were all finished and tracked before New Moon was even released. But they’re also familiar in the more general sense
column4: wherein the influences are recognizable to both you
column5: your cooler older sibling
column6: and your dad. New Moon was defined by frayed acoustics and raw soloing
column7: very much in the lineage of Meat Puppets and Dinosaur
column8: Jr.
column9: bands that were descendents of Crazy Horse
column10: but unquestionably indie rock. This is the real-deal stuff
column11: BTO boogie
column12: Skynyrd
column13: and according to the band

column1: Say what you will about the Nuge and Grand Funk
column2: they wrote some catchy riffs and the Men are still working their way towards their “Stranglehold”
column3: their “We’re An American Band”. Which is to say that Tomorrow’s Hits hints at what New Moon also did—that the Men are great sonic emulators and merely good songwriters. And so
column4: the highlights on Tomorrow’s Hits are the ones that recall the velocity of their early work. It’s easy to get caught up in the breakneck pace of “Pearly Gates” and “Different Days” and think “I bet they kick ass live
column5: ” but knowing how the Men operate
column6: there’s a good chance that opportunity has already passed you by. Also
column7: some of these sound too familiar in the sense that they’re kinda like older Men songs: “Dark Waltz” is a continuation of Open Your Heart’s barstool-bound “Candy” (really the song that’s determined their path ever since) and “Sleepless” is barely distinguishable from New Moon’s “Bird Song”
column8: whereas closer “Going Down” sounds like “Half Angel Half Light” being workshopped before they found its bracing chorus.

column1: There’s one lyric that sticks out amongst all of this whiskey-slugging and road-dogging
column2: as Ben Greenberg sings on “Different Days”

column6: a time when doing this meant being centrist rather than on the indie rock fringe and having to explain yourself. Even before Open Your Heart dropped
column7: the Men wanted to stress that Leave Home wasn't ""them."" But the greatness of those two records lay in how it was impossible to tell who the Men really were; they sounded capable of doing anything. And hell

but Tomorrow’s Hits for now mostly succeeds in toeing the line between being on a roll and being in a rut.

You'd be excused for reading the descriptor ""tribute to the music of Chicago's South Side"" flown under the banner of a name like Thug Entrancer and
column2: I don't know
column3: shaking your head slowly and knitting your brow
column4: maybe letting out a huff of annoyance. That the musician born Ryan McRyhew started out on a more IDM tip
column5: moved to Chicago from Denver a couple years ago
column6: then moved back out a couple years later
column7: bringing an evangelical enthusiasm for old Trax Records 12"" classics back with him? That's the way a lot of super-suspect appropriation nightmares start.

column1: But that's also how a lot of engagingly weird cross-genre works happen
column2: and Thug Entrancer's full-length debut album Death After Life—his breakthrough release on Daniel Lopatin's Software label—is more definitively a bold experiment than a cheap jack move. McRyhew's context has always been that of the generation that grew up with the idea of digital music as a normalized way of making things
column3: from formative Mario Paint experiences onwards. So when Death After Life touches on a blend of styles
column4: it comes across less like a cultural lift and more like someone finding a new element to add to the periodic table of beats.

column1: It's tempting to call what Death After Life does ""microjuke
column2: at least in its more obvious moments. The focus cut
column3: ""Death After Life I"" (all eight non-bonus cuts follow the title + roman numeral format)
column4: fits that descriptor most readily
column5: spilling its footwork guts out with a stripped-down
column6: chromed-out flourish and making sure the drum patterns are as frantic and agitated as the synth washes that act as de facto melody are floaty and light (if occasionally distorted to subtly unnerving did-I-just-hear-that? effect). The way McRyhew builds a beat comes across like an overflow of ideas
column7: as if the opportunity to toy with the rapidfire snares
column8: claps
column9: and kicks of juke rhythms opens up so many variations he can't help but leap from one to another
column10: chopping the one into fractions and shuffling it around like a blackjack dealer's cards.

column1: Juke isn't the only ingredient in Death After Life
column2: though—McRyhew puts his work together like somebody who spent decades listening to Roland-powered music and
column3: finally given the chance to make some of his own
column4: goes all shopping spree with it. So there's a thread running through this record that actually does juxtapose some of Chicago's core styles—not just juke and footwork
column5: but ghetto and acid house
column6: bracingly put through the wringer on ""III"" and ""V"". Granted
column7: he's stripped out some of the crucial elements that make the material that inspired him so vital—with sparse exceptions
column8: it doesn't push the BPMs to the 150-160 mark
column9: and good luck finding an actual vocal sample anywhere on here—his ear for pitting the kind of slow-build chord progressions usually found in more ambient and minimalist works against that sort of dense rhythmic syncopation is well-tuned.

column1: Death After Life gets a little cute here and there (cf. the extended roboseizure freakout outro to ""III"")
column2: and it starts to lose a little steam near the end
column3: when the downtempo digression of ""VI"" and the hopped-up yet unsurprising ""VII"" roll towards the official conclusion. The QED of ""VIII"" pulls out every genre-Cuisinart trick in Thug Entrancer's book to strong effect
column4: and the bonus tracks of ""Ready to Live"" parts 1 and 2 show what he can do with his focus elsewhere—turns out he can get just as rhythmically berserk with neighbor-alienating bass hits as he can with drum elements. Whether this infatuation with the sounds of the South Side are a passing phase or a legitimate connection remains to be seen
column5: but it's clear there are plenty of places Thug Entrancer can take it. And if Ryan McRyhew is a dilettante
column6: then hey
column7:
looks like sometimes even dilettantes hit on something.

patten's music is all sharp edges

column4: at times

column2: the finicky beat set to a whistling motif on ""Winter Strobing"". But there's rarely a sense of direction

column5: processed

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20216/homepage_large.310c2884.jpg|Pulsing EP|30413.0|Tomas Barfod|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2014-03-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:43.027709|"

If you haven’t been paying close attention to the last decade of work by Danish producer Tomas Barfod
column2: you might find yourself stunned by his quiet prolificacy. Between his main gig as a drummer for off-kilter electro-pop trio WhoMadeWho
column3: his partnership with compatriot Kasper Bjørke as straightforward house duo Filur
column4: and his own burgeoning solo career
column5: Barfod’s had a major hand in nearly a dozen full-lengths since 2000. He’s not showing any signs of slowing
column6: either
column7: with two releases due in the first quarter of 2014 alone: WhoMadeWho’s fifth album
column8: Dreams (due out March 3 on the band’s own imprint)
column9: and his own Pulsing EP
column10:
which follows 2012’s solid debut solo LP Salton Sea. 

Though it borrows Salton Sea’s structure of alternating vocal and instrumental tracks
column11: Pulsing is a much leaner affair
column12: running its course in a brisk eighteen minutes while the former stretches over an hour. Barfod has cut down on the individual bloat
column13: too
column14: his average runtime having shifted from over five minutes on Salton Sea to well under four minutes on Pulsing. This newfound concision is accompanied by a parallel increase in focus: where Barfod once delivered a survey glance at electronic music—floaty vocal electro-pop
column15: playful house
column16: meandering headphone fodder—he now sticks to a rigid dichotomy: sharp
column17: finely sung pop in one hand
column18: and moody instrumental cuts in the other. You get the sense that Barfod digested the disproportionate praise given to Salton Sea standouts like “November Skies” and “Don’t Understand” and decided to double down
column19:
directing all of his straightforward compositional energy into a pair of stunners and using his instrumental tracks as a repository for stranger ideas. 

If there’s any legitimacy to that strategy
column20: then it certainly paid off. Pulsing’s title track finds Barfod reuniting with Swedish vocalist Nina K
column21: who guested on the aforementioned “November Skies” and one other selection from Salton Sea
column22: and their partnership continues to bear fruit: “Pulsing” takes a churning polyrhythm and uses it to anchor a bittersweet
column23: subtly sticky pop song. Barfod’s roots as a drummer snake through the song
column24:
presenting themselves in the way Nina crams impressive numbers of syllables into the verses with quasi-mechanistic precision; there’s a delicate balance between complexity and catchiness at play that belies Barfod’s talented hand for pace. 

“Happy” isn’t quite as successful
column26: downtempo melancholy is a neat change of pace from the brighter
column27: glossier sound of “Pulsing.” The song’s relatively obscure guest and unlikely backstory overshadow its musical merits: Barfod met Eddie Chacon
column28: of 90s R&B one-hit wonder Charles & Eddie
column30: and discovered their musical connection after a few drinks in a nearby bar. Chacon provided the lyrics to “Happy
column31: ” a reflection on the scores of his contemporaries who have passed away over the last few decades
column32:
and his contribution lends the song an emotional weight it would surely lack otherwise. 

Pulsing’s instrumental tracks are a little more hit and miss. “Tea Cup” is the better of the two: it’s buzzy
column34: and ripe with skittering layers of rhythm
column35: like the best B-side from The King of Limbs you’ve never heard. Barfod clearly has the ability to inject some vitality into the kind of electro-rock hybrid that’s rarely pulled off well
column36: and it would be fascinating to hear him delve deeper into that side of his potential on a future release. “Value of Feint” hews closer to his previous work
column37:
but lands in an anemic middle ground between grand instrumental balladry and chilled-out synth noodling that relegates it to secondary status on the EP.

While the remix of “Pulsing” by Boston producer J£zus Million that book-ends the EP doesn’t quite succeed on its own merits
column38: it ultimately sheds more light on Barfod’s strengths as a producer through its failure. Million recasts the song as a ghostly
column40: and though he knows his way around a pitch shifter
column41: he robs “Pulsing” of the twisting rhythmic core that works as the heart of Barfod’s original. Perhaps it isn’t a surprise that a drummer by trade peaks as a producer when playing with rhythms
column42:
but Pulsing makes it clear that Barfod’s assessment of his own skills is right on target.

Despite being on nearly opposite ends of the Earth
column2: New-York-based Sam Obey and Osaka’s Seiho Hayakawa share a lot of similarities. Both record sample-heavy
column3: hyperactive electronic music under projects named after parts of their name (Obey City and Seiho
column4: respectively). Obey helped organize the Astro Nautico collective label

column6: meanwhile

column10: as Obey City entered the LuckyMe fold and Seiho has attracted more attention domestically and even started working with more major-label acts. Seiho’s imprint and Astro Nautico teamed up for a release

column1: Of the two

column3: starting with last year’s Champagne Sounds and a promised Merlot Sounds—with “Wait

column1: Seiho’s contributions
column2: meanwhile
column3: can barely stay put. His earliest recordings tended to be spacey

column5: but he’s shined since he’s embraced a herky-jerky approach where he locks synth zig-zags and bursts of samples into a coherent track. “Double Bed” is a perfect example. Sounds zip in for brief stops before whirling out
column6: never to be heard again. At one point

column9: a jumble of start-stop vocals and electronics. It’s hyperactive
column10: but also playful

column12: “Koi""

column14: blurring classical Japanese instrumentation with digital noise.

column1: Shochu Sounds works as a solid introduction to each artist
column2: and can hopefully serve as a diving board into their 2014 outputs. Obey City’s Champagne Sounds shows off his range as a producer while also being built for booming sound systems

column5:
Shochu Sounds is still a good offering from two producers to keep tabs on.

Before their rich

column1: On Atlas
