column1: The result is at once their most forlorn album and their most beautiful. Producer and mixer Tom Schick dissolves the noncommittal haze of reverb that made it sound like you were hearing Days through a fisheye lens
column2: and the crispness that emerges on Atlas is gorgeous. Courtney’s tenor is soft and even
column3: and the room tone is bruised-ripe like an October sunset. In this soft light
column4: the band sounds like the platonic ideal of themselves
column5: and it’s difficult not to wish all their albums had been recorded this way.

column1: The clarity of Atlas underlines what an uncommonly graceful unit they are. Real Estate essentially has two lead vocalists—Courtney’s tenor on the one hand
column2: and Mondanile’s pearly guitar melodies on the other. The two voices enjoy a near-telepathic relationship
column3: and it’s almost impossible to imagine Courtney’s singing without Mondanile’s guitar twirling around it
column4: and vice versa. As the tabbed tutorial they posted for “Crime” underlines
column5: nothing anyone is playing would tax a first-year guitar student. But their two voices
column6: working modestly and in perfect sync
column7: key into a mysterious and powerful emotional calculus. When the bell-clear leads rise out of on ""The Bend"" and""Navigator""
column8: they feel like spontaneously welling tears.

column1: This simplicity and eloquence is the key to Atlas’ surprisingly profound ache. Courtney’s words tend to mention the same things over and over—the sky
column2: the horizon
column3: the sidewalk
column4: the houses on his block—but he’s not repeating himself. He’s shaping the contours of a world
column5: one that's built on a sense of cosmic gratitude matched by an equal and opposite sense of cosmic loss. “I don’t need the horizon/ To tell me where the sky ends/ And it’s a subtle landscape/ Where I come from
column6: ” he sings on “Had to Hear”. “Just over the horizon/ That’s where I always think you’ll be/ It’s always so surprising/ To find you right there next to me
column7: ” he sings tenderly on “Horizon”. The bittersweet disorientation of these two competing thoughts—I’ve lost more than I’ll ever know
column8: I have more than I ever imagined—mark out a very particular phase of life
column9: and it’s one Courtney is currently in the throes of: He’s about to have his first child.

column1: This is a life moment when you engage in a little less dreamy reverie about who you might be
column2: and begin assessing
column3: with some alarm
column4: who you have already become. If you’re lucky
column5: like Courtney
column6: you are roughly pleased with what you find
column7: even as you squint bewildered into the recent past to mark the notch where the transition happened. “I remember when/ This all felt like pretend/ And I still can’t believe
column8: ” he marvels on “Crime”. “I’m staring at the hands on the clock/ I’m still waiting for them to stop” he sings on “Navigator”
column9: the album’s final song and one of many bemused meditations on the passing of time. Real Estate have weathered some jam-band comparisons
column10: and Alex Bleeker is an avowed fan of the Grateful Dead
column11: so it feels like a permissible stretch to note that the shadow of a very particular Dead song—the wry
column12: valedictory “Touch of Grey”—seems to hover over Atlas. Like that song
column13: Atlas assesses the current moment
column14: and everything leading up to it
column15: with a puzzled head scratch and shit-eating grin.

column1: Real Estate are a deeply suburban band
column2: and the shade of long tree-lined streets
column3: the lonely symmetry of the houses
column4: rise up continually out of their music. If it has been too easy to underestimate Real Estate in the past
column5: it might be in part because of this: Suburbs are not often stages
column6: in the popular imagination
column7: for great existential drama. They are places of reverie
column8: of absence
column9: into which the drama of the real-world intrudes. But Atlas gazes calmly and wisely into the face of some troubling questions: Mortality
column10: the passing of time
column11: the problem of loneliness. With it
column12: Real Estate have made more than just their third excellent record in a row
column13: more than just their best-ever record. They’ve made the first record of their career that feels like it might teach you something over time. It is rare
column14: and special
column15:
for a band to be this effortlessly and completely themselves.

Despite a schedule packed with twerk wall evangelism
column4: Twitter explosions
column5: boat party planning
column6: and his usual full slate of remixes and production credits
column7: Diplo somehow found time for two separate longer-form releases last year. His sophomore effort behind the boards as cartoon commando/cyborg Major Lazer
column8: Free the Universe
column9: found the producer and partners Jillionaire and Walshy Fire spreading themselves too thin and sacrificing any chance at cohesiveness in the name of versatility. An autumn EP under his own name
column10: Revolution
column11: was stuffed to the gills with satisfying drops
column12: but felt more like a grab-bag of trend-riding cuts than a thematically sound articulation of his strengths. Never one to rest on his laurels
column13: he’s already back with another EP
column14: this one back in the guise of Major Lazer; Apocalypse Soon
column15: like its predecessors
column16: is rich in guest stars and attempts to bring nuclear-level energy to the world’s dance floors.

column1: While Major Lazer’s primary incarnation—one that included fellow DJ/producer Switch and hype man extraordinaire Skerrit Bwoy—was rooted in the export and steroidal electro-amplification of Jamaican dance music
column2: the purity of that concept has long since been diluted
column3: and Apocalypse Soon doesn’t mark a return to any such thematic consistency. Its opener
column4: “Aerosol Can""
column5: is less a representative statement than the equivalent of throwing your best pitch first: Diplo wisely capitalizes on the exploding star of Pharrell Williams
column6: currently hitting an unexpected peak as a mainstream musical force and experiencing a broader creative renaissance. While “Aerosol Can” is ripe with fascinating textural work—the hollow
column7: tinny spray and pressurized rattle of the titular can is ear-catching in the best way—it’s foolish to pretend that the song is anything other than the ultimate exercise in “your mileage may vary”: it hinges on how you feel about Pharrell
column8: both as a personality and a rapper. A useful heuristic already exists in the form of his batty
column9: scene-stealing verse on Future’s monstrous single “Move That Dope”: if you’re down with #GandalfHat
column10: “Aerosol Can” will tickle your fancy with lines like
column11:
“Make yourself bigger like mushroom/ Mario Kart.” Just don’t press play expecting anything resembling a traditional hook. 

At least “Aerosol Can
column12: ” for all its simplicity
column13: picks an idea and sticks with it; several of Apocalypse Soon’s other tracks jump from sound to sound with reckless abandon and remarkable volatility
column14: and suffer for it. It’s a relatively minor issue when the hyperactivity takes time away from worthwhile ideas that could use a bigger chance to shine: “Sound Bang
column15: ” featuring soca star Machel Montano
column16: leaps from a breezy
column17: lilting beach circle to a hard-charging
column18: strobe-lit club to some sort of hybrid atmosphere and back at whiplash-inducing speeds
column19: but the discrete sections are compelling enough on their own to warrant further exploration. But the excess kinetic energy is a bigger problem when it feels like a diversionary tactic
column20: a distraction from compositions lacking real hooks or momentum. “Lose Yourself” and “Dale Asi” are dense with the sort of drops
column21: rapid shifts
column22: and dynamic plays that need just a tiny substance-aided push to become interesting
column23:
but listening to them under normal circumstances is like watching a game of three-card monte once you’ve picked up the keys to the con: an eye on the tricks of the trade spoils the illusion. 

It’s disappointing that these songs don’t have the bones to stand on their own
column24: especially since a precedent for truly great Major Lazer songs exists: older cuts like “Keep It Goin’ Louder” (still one of Diplo’s finest musical moments
column25: bar none) and last year’s Amber Coffman collaboration “Get Free” work as both genre exercises and straightforward pop triumphs. Apocalypse Soon’s best song doesn’t quite scrape those heights
column26: but its relative coherence and catchiness places it a head above its counterparts on the EP. “Come On to Me” is anchored by a vintage performance from none other than Sean Paul
column27: whose thick-tongued patois and ability to navigate a hook remains intact even a decade removed from his Dutty Rock heyday. But the song’s merits extend past its vocalist’s charisma: it actually feels like a song with a structure and a fully realized mood
column28:
rather than a Frankenstein held together by drops or a sketch. It’s just too bad that “Come On to Me” is the exception on Apocalypse Soon and not the rule.

The first edition of Nguzunguzu's The Perfect Lullaby mix hit on an idea that was both kind of esoteric and remarkably effective: the fusion of contemporary top 40 R&B and the direct-source international sounds of Latin America
column3: the West Indies and Africa—which
column4: in turn
column5: had been both refracted in and inspired by that top 40 R&B in the first place. It was a blend that carried over from (and into) their own work
column6: a global-disco idealism more grounded in the universal pull of the emotions they could wring from these sounds than the ""exotic"" status of the locales they originated from. It doesn't take a lot of stretching to picture their blends booming out of cars in their homebase L.A. (or Miami or NYC)—it's American music for an America where what we take in means more than what we ship out.

column1: Like the first Perfect Lullaby
column2: it definitely helps on a source-quoting
column3: credit-due level to understand where the inspiration on The Perfect Lullaby II comes from. This is a mix where Afro-Portugese music spun by club DJs in Lisbon—DJ Fofuxo
column4: DJ Lil Thug
column5: DJ Dadifox—are snuck under Aaliyah classics (""Hot Tarraxa/Don't Think They Know"") or a Ciara remix of a Chris Brown track (""Tarraxo Deuces""). It's where reggaeton vets Nova & Jory (""La Noche Perfecta"") are slotted between a couple post-Moombahton Dutch house cuts—outfit M&N Pro's Cape Verdean flip of Usher's ""Let Me See"" and a Zouk remix of another Brown track
column6: ""Another Round""
column7: by DJ Phraze. It's where the two members of Nguzunguzu themselves—Asma Maroof credited on a few edits as ""MA""; Daniel Pineda as ""NA""—fit the pieces together with minimal tweaking while still hiding the seams expertly. The transitions hop continents without a hitch.

column1: But for those less curious about the specific nuances of zouk and kuduro and kizomba
column2: the appeal is still there in an immediate sense of style. The specific throughline on this mix is the less heavy
column3: more bucolic and dreamlike angles of this diasporic beat
column4: which opens with rainshowers and robin calls before layering a delicately resonant spacedrum solo by Yuki Koshimoto over the sparse but waist-winding zouk-bass of DJ Fofuxo & DJ Pausas's ""Tarracho Exxelentt"". And there's this juxtaposition throughout
column5: where these persistently churning drums and basslines are set alongside R&B divas and slow-jam loverman cuts—not quite softening the beats
column6:
but giving them this pulse of romanticism and intimacy that stands out just as strongly as the groove.

If you want to get a sense of why rocksteady is spectacular
column2: there’s an easy way to experience it. Each Sunday

column4: between the aptly named Paradise Street and less perfectly named Walter Street
column5: heaps of people of all ages will congregate in front of Brother Bunny and Sister Norma’s Capricorn Inn for an oldies session
column6: one that's been happening in Kingston since 1982. Red Stripe and white rum is available in copious amounts. Klassique's sound system will be strung up—with
column7: if you’re lucky
column8: two walls of speakers. Dancers will be spinning and stepping out on the road to a range of old disco
column9: soul
column10: funk
column11: pop and then
column12: suddenly
column13: the selector will announce that he’s going to turn the beat around. If you’re even luckier
column14: he’ll put on a tune like “Party Time” by the Heptones. The tell-tale alto sax line leading to Leroy Sibbles’ plaintive voice singing “Time is short so hear me man
column15: let’s live the life the best we can
column16: don’t try to work your soul away.” Members of the crowd will smile
column17: sway and slow dance. During their weekly rocksteady set

column1: Sure
column2: it may not be possible to jump on an airplane and get yourself to Rae Town in time for this Sunday’s dance
column3: but you could do much worse than Soul Jazz’s excellent collection of <i>Rocksteady
column4: Soul and Early Reggae from Studio One. This is music from the mid-60s—an in between era for Jamaican music that is often characterized by Duke Reid’s Treasure Isle label. But where Reid’s rocksteady really took its cue from US soul and R&B
column5: Studio One was
column6: as reggae historian and liner note writer Lloyd Bradley suggests
column7: more experimental. And
column8: perhaps
column9: as can be heard from the often love-laden tunes showcased on Rocksteady
column10: from Alton Ellis’s “Hurting Me” to “Me and You” by Carlton and the Shoes
column11: more soulful. As smooth as the vocals are
column12: the sounds of Sir Coxone Dodd’s label at this time is music easy to imagine on a soundsystem—and
column13: as Klassique demonstrates on a weekly basis
column14: was and is best heard loud and bass heavy.

column1: For those well steeped in the music of Jamaica
column2: this is not a set of rarities
column3: but rather a collection of tunes that can set a mood. The set contains the excellent “Stars” by the Eternals
column4: the original Cornell Campbell voicing of the now well-worn riddim. The keyboard virtuoso Jackie Mittoo is on show on the joyous “Our Thing” and there’s a taste of legendary Lee Perry’s early productions
column5: even at this time displaying his penchant for organic depth in his sound. A case in point is here next to the always spectacular vocals of the Crown Prince of reggae
column6: Dennis Brown
column7: on “Easy Take it Easy”
column8: and one of the tunes from one of Jamaica’s most well-loved vocalists
column9: Ken Boothe
column10: with his trademark enunciation and vibrato on “Home Home Home”.

column1: It’s near impossible to not nod one’s head to John Holt’s Perry-produced warning against “Fancy Make Up” girls who will “rob and cheat you
column2: make you wanna cry” and the Wailing Souls’s “Row Fisherman Row”—the title a metaphor for what you need to do when love just aint working out and not an original version of the Congo’s more literal version recorded in the heart of the reggae era of the late 1970s. But not every tune on this set deals with the trials and tribulations of romance. There’s Larry and Alvin’s “Throw Me Corn” that speaks to those fussing
column3: fighting
column4: stealing and killing as well as Marcia Griffith’s “My Ambition”
column5: communicating not only the striving of the singer

column1: Throughout Bradley’s extensive liner notes shines a passion for the music and the history—he situates this American-soul influenced sound sandwiched by the bounce of early-60s ska and the sway of the reggae to come
column2: pointing out the bits and pieces of each song that you should be paying attention to. He also makes an argument that Studio One

column5: the importance
column6: and the ins and outs
column7: this music isn’t as much of an intellectual pursuit as it is a pleasure in every note. As Bradley observes
column8: it really is smooth stuff; there are few horns
column9: and songs are driven by vocal prowess and bass groove. These are songs that demonstrate tremendously tight vocal arrangements and exude the ease of a growing music industry that is just chock full of creativity
column10:
developing a unique sound in every single.

There’s something to Joel Thibodeau’s music that makes it sound like it’s been pulled from a hermetically sealed terrarium
column2: where life has flourished untouched by the outside world over the course of a few decades. He makes instrumentally ornate folk music unafraid to bust out a pump organ or kalimba to locate an archaic emotion
column3: and sings with an idiosyncratic falsetto that gives credence to the description “God-given.” Recording as Death Vessel
column4: Thibodeau released two albums in 2005 (a year when the popularity of Devendra Banhart
column5: I’m Wide Awake
column6: It’s Morning Bright Eyes and half the Arts and Crafts roster made him an obvious debut) and 2008
column7: then fell off the radar. Six years later
column8: he’s returned with Island Intervals
column9: an album recorded in Reykjavik that invites us to tour his world.

column1: It’s impossible to discuss Death Vessel without mentioning Thibodeau’s voice
column2: which is piercing and shrill and whatever other pejoratives might’ve been thrown at Joanna Newsom circa “Peach
column3: Plum
column4: Pear”. It’s deeply committed to a particular feeling
column5: and might not evoke more sympathy from some beyond
column6: Dude sounds like a lady. But it’s perfectly suited for songs in which medieval worlds are conjured to contextualize fragile emotions that might be a little impenetrable were they rendered in a more modern cadence. Try to imagine the singer of any butt-rock band yelling
column7: “For the nonce I will dream of when we jointly preened triangulated heart.” The simplest way I can put it is that this is an album for people who wouldn’t have minded if the Lord of the Rings movies spent a little more time with the elves—for people who have been known to remark at parties
column8: “There’s actually a lot more to Tiny Tim than ‘Tiptoe Through the Tulips’.”

column1: The elves were cool
column2: though. They spent a lot of time in forests and were clearly too deep in the game for the dwarves to understand
column3: which is how you might feel listening to Thibodeau begin the album with a line like
column4: “Backing Blackrock dirt and other derring-do”. That’s from “Ejecta
column5: ” the album’s heaviest song (blame it on the pump organ)
column6: which opens up with the ease of a slow river. It gives way to comparatively lighter fare like the renaissance fair jaunt of “Mercury Dime” and the airy
column7: delicately plucked fantasy of “Ilsa Drown”
column8: which gets an assist from Sigur Rós singer Jónsi (who helped record in Reykjavik). The stakes get increasingly higher: Thibodeau isn’t only looking at what’s in front of him
column9: but imagining what’s up and beyond out of reach. “Velvet Antlers” adopts the form of a drum circle to pay tribute to the real or imagined power of the constellations; “We Agreed” uses the great openness of nature as a metaphor for the impossibility of knowing what comes next. (“We agreed that life keeps on going/ A reach we’ll never be knowing”).

column1: Such ambitious subject material could easily be mishandled by someone more precious or novel in his dedication to this aesthetic. But Thibodeau’s ear for richly pastoral arrangements and Chaucerian lyricism make him more than a high-voiced novelty—he’s a knight or a bard in search of truth
column2: heading along the path through places overgrown with life. This is passionate music
column3: delivered with searing honesty by a man who didn’t mind disappearing from the conversation if that’s what it took to articulate what he was trying to say. The hymnal refrain of the final song
column4: “Loom
column5: ” also ends up being the album’s final line: “I don’t want to owe you my only open road to goodbye”. Why bottle yourself in when there’s so much to explore? He sounds sad as he’s singing it
column6: like someone who wishes it was easier to merge his world with ours. For now
column7:
it's enough to be shown around. 

"|19053.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19053-death-vessel-island-intervals/|7.5|Jeremy Gordon

Two years into Black Hippy’s mainstream rap takeover the efficacy of TDE’s hit factory is still a marvel to watch. As a group
column3: pensive Compton good guy Kendrick Lamar
column4: gang-affiliated L.A. street rap classicist Jay Rock
column5: suburban psychotropic-loving conspiracy theorist Ab-Soul and drug dealing party animal Schoolboy Q unite to offer a panoramic view of Southern Californian inner city rot. In-house production teams Digi+Phonics and THC buoy the rhymes in excitingly quirky sonics
column6: while gifted recording engineer Mixed By Ali keeps it all sounding winningly crisp and plush. The team has crafted over half a dozen albums together in just four years
column7: and at this juncture
column8: you can almost tell ahead of time what you’re going to get coming into a new TDE project. Although Kendrick’s <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17253-good-kid-maad-city/"" target=""_blank""><i>good kid
column9: m.A.A.d city revealed a Dickensian eye for storytelling and a knack for radio-savvy singles that didn’t wander too far off the plot—and sold a million copies in the process—the mechanics of his sound didn’t change much. You could easily slide “Bitch
column10: Don’t Kill My Vibe” somewhere into Q’s Habits and Contradictions or Soul’s Control System without a bumpy transition. Consistency breeds familiarity
column11: but as Schoolboy Q releases his Interscope debut Oxymoron
column12: the precarious followup to his brother-in-arms’ mainstream windfall
column13: the axiom sometimes proves a liability.

column1: Schoolboy Q specializes in hairpin turns from cautionary street tales and remorseful reflection into wanton bacchanal
column2: and Oxymoron is essentially a volleyball match between his warring proclivities. Opener “Gangsta” kicks off with Q coldly admonishing a street worker for thinking pneumonia gets her the day off
column3: but after the raucous set-repping “Los Awesome”
column4: “Collard Greens” drags us to the club for elite liver putrefaction. Then it’s back to the block for a few until “Studio” pops up pining for affection after a stressful day of recording. Oxymoron punctuates its seriousness of purpose with stress-free jingles
column5: like a rap game The Who Sell Out
column6: but it skirts falling apart because Q has cut a figure that seems equally at home throwing back shots and bagging up rocks. His skill set is varied enough to sell a terse
column7: hypnotic vamp like “Collard Greens” off of personality alone
column8: effect a snarling menace bouncing crack dealer bromides off 2 Chainz on “What They Want”
column9: and then methodically juggle cadences and syllables relating the story of an uncle’s drug-addled downfall on “Hoover Street”. Q’s wildman delivery does most of the heavy lifting on the slighter material here
column10: but you see the true depth of his songwriting talents in detail obsessed verses on “Break the Bank”
column11: where he lets slip where the pills were stashed back when he sold
column12: and “Prescription/Oxymoron” where Q
column13: holed up at home munching prescription pills
column14: catalogs all the calls he ignores as he hurtles toward an overdose (“My phone rang
column15: rang and rang and rang/ If you ain’t sellin’ drugs
column16: then I don’t hear a thing”). Thing is
column17: these crack storytelling twists are occasionally drowned in formalist gangsta rap boilerplate.

column1: Oxymoron is painfully aware of its place in the pantheon of hardcore West Coast rap
column2: from the guest list
column3: which calls in vets like slick-tongued Oakland pimp Suga Free and Dogg Pound wordsmith Kurupt alongside Odd Future magnate <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"" target=""_blank"">Tyler
column4: the Creator
column5: New York mafioso rap architect Raekwon and Atlanta trap court jester 2 Chainz to accentuate the commonalities between two generations of drug trafficking goon rap
column6: to its struggle to imbue druggy levity and horned-up bedroom dispatches with a hardened
column7: streetwise edge. Q is never less than engaging in this juggling act (though the brattier numbers can grate
column8: like “Los Awesome”
column9: which sounds like mid-2000s T.I. getting his hands on some quality speed)
column10: but he can come off sounding more interested in ticking off his wiseguy bona fides than introducing the person underneath. His 2012 independent album Habits and Contradictions made a much better go of it
column11: from “My Homie”’s wounded story of a friend who turned out to be an embedded undercover cop to “My Hatin’ Joint”
column12: which pulled off the song-for-the-ladies trope with a comically petty air of vindictiveness
column13: to “Oxy Music”
column14: which blueprints Oxymoron’s drug using drug dealer conceit with much more gripping imagery. Oxymoron is gruff and goofy in all the right places
column15: and enticingly lush as one could expect from a TDE project (for instance: the pogoing drums and plinking keys of “Collard Greens”
column16: the perpetually melting synth Tyler suspends over Q and Kurupt on “The Purge”
column17: Pharrell’s keys on “Los Awesome”
column18: equal parts EDM debauchery and arcade overdrive). But a whiff of formula makes for an experience that coolly whisks along on rails where it should be bounding off them.

column1: Q shines the most when he’s able to reconcile his hustler past with his rap star present rather than mining each separately. “Hell of a Night” showcases a trap-house hybrid from DJ Dahi
column2: fresh off Drake’s “Worst Behaviour”
column3: and Q cuts loose
column4: partying hard because he’s lived hard enough to deserve it (“I ain’t minding if the world stops/ We been living up in hell’s shop”). “Break the Bank” and the Chromatics-sampling “Man of the Year” follow suit in affixing the happy ending to Oxymoron’s war stories while serving up the album’s most memorable hooks. The quality that sold the gangsta rap classics Q clearly studied in the process of making this album was an ability to tease triumph out of the mouth of adversity
column5: and Oxymoron really takes off when the streak of songs that close the album proper stumbles onto the equation. Small wonder that the majority of its singles are culled from there.

column1: Oxymoron is a victory in that Q’s sound has made the jump to the majors fully intact in an era where major label debuts often take a chop shop approach to assembly. Interscope’s trust in TDE saves the album from the awkward test tube collaborations that bog down many of its peers
column2: but Oxymoron’s doubling down on a reliable formula makes for a relatively risk-averse listen. We don’t find out much about Q’s character or capabilities that we didn’t already know coming in
column3: and a few of the tried and true song tropes here deliver diminishing returns. There isn’t a bad song in the bunch
column4: but you get the sense that three albums in
column5:
Q’s readymade sense of what a Schoolboy Q album should sound like is as much a safety net prohibiting outright failure as it is a hindrance to true progression.

column1: Home
column2: Like NoPlace Is There burns with the same five-alarm intensity throughout its nine songs
column3: and the few times where the Worcester band are at a loss for words
column4: they have no trouble expressing themselves. There isn’t a single moment of passive listening here because the relationships that fill Holden’s songs require 24/7-surveillance; they’re toxic and codependent
column5: with people who “try to make chaos external” and are “killing the self to protect it from harm.” If there isn’t an emergency intervention or a 3AM phone call that must be answered
column6: a funeral is likely to follow. The specifics are removed

column8: pills

column11: and people who are just plain fucked to give you an idea of what’s at stake.

column1: This all makes for common subject matter in rock music
column2: especially within the Hotelier’s emotive punk rock. Home derives its gut-wrenching power from Holden’s narrator being someone who’s barely escaped the same tragedies
column3: speaks the language of its victims
column4: and is pulled between knowing that his friends and family may be beyond help and the moral and spiritual drive to be the better man. In “The Scope of All of This Rebuilding”
column5: kinship and resentment are inseparable as Holden spits over barbed
column6: clashing guitars
column7: “you cut your ropes
column8: left the umbilical.” Not caring and caring too much hurt equally
column9: and these songs ache with guilt and real remorse. During “Your Deep Rest”
column10: Holden can’t bring himself to attend the subject’s funeral; in the first chorus he’s merely uncomfortable
column11: the second time around
column12: “the sight of your family made me feel responsible.”

column1: And yet
column2: if you ignore the lyrics
column3: “Your Deep Rest” is a shambling
column4: shuffling piece of soaring pop-rock that could sneak onto any Clear Channel playlist. <i>Home
column5: Like NoPlace Is There is emotionally relentless

column7: lacking the training and polish to hit them—though it’s malleable enough to fit within just about every variant of punk that’s gone overground. You get rousing group chants
column8: call-and-response hooks
column9: and collegiate jangle sliced and diced with Fugazi’s precision (“The Scope of All of This Rebuilding”) and an abrupt turn towards double-time

column1: For all of its song-by-song diversity
column2: <i>Home
column3: Like NoPlace Is There is constructed as a whole to mirror the endless cycle of abuse and relapse—a key lyric from “In Framing” puts it it right out there
column4: “you retraced the same shape/ cut up and resewn/ when you felt abandoned
column5: when you felt alone.” It’s not a narrative
column6: though each stylistic shift can serve as a plot twist. Holden manages some sense of composure during the stately first half of “An Introduction to the Album” and “In Framing”
column7: and loses it during “The Scope of All of This Rebuilding” and the impulsively raging “Life In Drag”. The most desperate choruses are the most anthemic
column8: as on near power-ballads “Discomfort Revisited’ and “Among the Wildflowers”
column9: Holden recognizes what his suffering friends never do: the futility of trying to get through this alone.

column1: Theatrical closer “Dendron” takes its title from the Greek word for “tree” and ties back to the arboreal imagery of “Your Deep Rest” as well as its chorus with a gut-wrenching admission (“part of your charm is the way you would push me from/ all of the traps that I just couldn’t see/ figures the one that would trip you up/ would be the one that was set there by me”). Home ends with a transposed version of the melody from “An Introduction to the Album”
column2: and it’s a brief respite
column3: not a happy ending or even an ending. It just puts you right back where you started
column4: prepared to fight another day.

column1: Home
column2: Like NoPlace Is There is very much an album that works its ass off; it can’t afford to do otherwise
column3: as the Hotelier battle addiction
column4: ignorance
column5: and their own past. The first line finds a flock of singing birds telling Holden to “tear the buildings down

column11: basement-show ethics and big-tent ambitions these days.

column1: But sonically

but they’re working towards something monumental.

Music that's ""as ignorable as it is interesting
column2: to use Brian Eno's famous phrase about the ambient genre
column3: can pack an emotional wallop
column4: too—what if the wallpaper reminds you of an ex? Or of a long-gone grandmother? The techno whizzes over at Germany's Kompakt label recently released their 14th annual Pop Ambient compilation
column5: but lower-case ""pop ambient"" still seems like a useful phrase to describe records that mix unobtrusive electronic drifts with the basic but intense #feels you might expect from more linear types of songwriting.

column1: The ghost of Drake hovers over the tune on Ricky Eat Acid's Three Love Songs that would be most likely to fit on one of those Pop Ambient comps. ""In my dreams we're almost touching"" flips the ""my only wish is I die real"" bit of the rapper's 2011 Take Care title track (via a cover version) and lofts it over percolating thumps and whirring synths. At once hypnotic
column2: triumphant
column3: and bittersweet
column4: it's something like Kompakt star the Field gone piano-house
column5: with dance-diva vocals reaching heavenward and then disintegrating as if you were listening to it on a tape player with a battery that's giving up the ghost. Nothing else on the album is quite like this
column6: and certainly nothing is as immediate.

column1: The rest of Three Love Songs is pop-ambient in more of a lower-case sense
column2: and that works
column3: too. Ricky Eat Acid is Sam Ray
column4: a Maryland-based musician who has his hand in a few other projects and was booked to open a late-February New York City show by R&B aesthetes Rhye; wonderfully (and tellingly)
column5: a recent mix Ray made for The Fader consists mostly of scruffy
column6: heart-on-sleeve indie guitar pop from bands like Go Sailor
column7: Joanna Gruesome
column8: and Rocketship. Though it takes this album until the eighth of 12 songs to reach its dying-real pinnacle—the LP title is a slight misnomer—how it gets there is a patient journey across nuanced
column9: digital-meets-organic soundscapes
column10: fraught with gnawing heartache and wistful reminiscence.

column1: Three Love Songs is Ricky Eat Acid's first album available on vinyl
column2: and the first vinyl release from Brooklyn's Orchid Tapes. Part of why it's so affecting comes down to an inspired and strategic use of the format. Side one is almost entirely drum-less
column3: but each flickering vignette
column4: heavy with found sounds
column5: is different enough from the last that by the time a preacher starts spewing fire and brimstone on the fifth (and first substantial) track
column6: the seven-minute ""In rural virginia; watching glowing lights crawl from the dark corners of the room""
column7: it's
column8: well—not quite a come-to-Jesus moment
column9: but pretty close. The slightly uncanny piano loops of fuzz-caked mid-album track ""Inside your house; it will swallow us too"" are in their own way almost as catchy as ""In my dreams we're almost touching""; piano carries over to Clams Casino-like side-A closer ""It will draw me over to it like it always does""
column10: which finally adds percussion and a sung vocal sample. Not a moment too soon

column2: magpie downtempo might be late
column3: great Swedish duo Air France's 2008 No Way Down EP. The sonic similarity is clearest on the second of Three Love Songs' two (one for each side) seven-minute opuses

column5: with its sumptuous viola next to IDM-bustling beats and opulent keys. But there's a bigger spiritual affinity: The choir-like vocals and shrill hum of Yo La Tengo-referencing hymn ""I can hear the heart breaking as one"" would be out of character from the Swedes
column6: but the<a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/staff-lists/7686-the-top-500-tracks-of-the-2000s-200-101/6/""> ""sort of like a dream
column7: no better"" quality
column8: that heart-in-throat sense of of being suspended between planes of existence. Finale ""Starting over""
column9: meanwhile
column10: ripples like Deerhunter man Bradford Cox's more esoteric blog-only Atlas Sound tracks.

column1: The ultimate forebear for Three Love Songs would have to be the KLF's 1990 ambient-house landmark Chill Out

column3: its free-flowing evocativeness

Three Love Songs might be the sound of music having a dream within a dream about music. And in those dreams
column8:
it's almost touching.

Ethan Bassford
column2: the fatefully named bassist of Brooklyn art-rock oddballs Ava Luna
column3: got into a few arguments with singer/guitarist Carlos Hernandez while they were writing their 2012 debut album
column4: Ice Level. Couldn't they at least try to write a song with a chorus?
column5: Bassford wondered. As the freewheeling
column6: compositionally adventurous Ice Level attests—the answer was a resounding no. But Bassford persisted. ""I was like
column7: 'Carlos
column8: don't worry
column9: '"" he recalled in a recent interview. ""'It's still gonna be weird. Having a chorus doesn't make it not weird.'""

column1: After hearing Ava Luna's taut and irresistibly fun new album Electric Balloon
column2: it's hard to disagree. Its 11 songs are as eccentric as anything this band of merry weirdos has ever done
column3: but they stick in your head in a way their earlier material did not. Ava Luna are a kitchen-sink band
column4: whose richly cluttered songs pull from a variety of influences: dance-punk
column5: funk
column6: doo-wop
column7: and R&B. (They've summed it up in a perfectly succinct Bandcamp tag: ""nervous soul."") They're one of very few current indie bands (in New York or anywhere else) reaching back to the lineage of no-wave; Hernandez often sings in a trembling falsetto but his acrobatic yelps sounds like nobody so much as James Chance. Because of their punchy and tightly arranged female backing vocals
column8: Ava Luna often get compared to Dirty Projectors
column9: but that parallel is more appropriate for the figures at the center of those bands. Like Dave Longstreth
column10: Hernandez is an intelligent
column11: almost-too-ambitious maestro who over time has learned how to embrace playfulness and shine a spotlight around his equally talented ensemble.

column1: Ava Luna wrote and recorded Electric Balloon over two different two-week-long working vacations sequestered in a house in upstate New York; every evening
column2: they'd cook
column3: crack jokes
column4: and then channel their energy into nightly after-dinner jam sessions. The result of this process—""more like culling than just writing
column5: as Bassford says—is a much looser album than Ice Level
column6: which was carefully arranged to the point of sometimes feeling stiff or aloof. But there's an inclusive
column7: kinetic vibe to the best songs on Electric Balloon (which was produced by Hernandez and drummer Julian Fader)
column8: like the spunky shout-along ""Sears Roebuck M&Ms""
column9: or ""Plain Speech""
column10: which morphs halfway through from jittery funk to dazzling AM radio gold. Ava Luna are an exhilarating live band
column11: and Electric Balloon is the first thing they've done that comes close to bottling that energy.

column1: Since Ice Level
column2: Ava Luna have shrunk from a seven-piece to a five-piece
column3: and this streamlining has cleared out some (though not all) of the clutter in their sound and benefited the band dynamic. Felicia Douglass (vocals/keyboards) and Becca Kauffman (vocals/guitar) are both more active presences on Electric Balloon—and this is a very good thing. Ava Luna are now a band with not one but three distinct lead singers
column4: each with unique but complementary personalities. Hernandez's songs
column5: like the opener ""Daydream""
column6: are often driven by a frayed
column7: manic intensity. (The ""nervous soul"" tag is definitely most apt when he's at the helm.) It's an enjoyably wild ride
column8: but it might be too much to take were it not balanced out by quieter moments like the ballad ""PRPL""
column9: Douglass's stunning and velvety lead vocal turn.

column1: But
column2: as long as you like your choruses weird
column3: the breakout star of Electric Balloon is Kauffman. She vamps and woooops! through ""Sears Roebuck M&Ms"" like a kid riding a sugar high
column4: and spews mesmerizing gibberish throughout the title track
column5: which channels the brief moment when the B-52s were too strange for the radio. That last song was written most spontaneously of all
column6: when Kauffman stepped up to the mic and started riffing on a vocal idea she had during one of the after-dinner jam sessions. The rest of the band tried to join in but they weren't quite sure what she was saying: ""Shock me with electrical uhh?"" ""Shopping with electric balloon?"" None of the guesses amount to much sense—but damn if that mysterious hook isn't stuck in your head for days. Ava Luna are still speaking in tongues
column7: as they always have been
column8:
but this time they're inviting you to sing along.

column3: Seth Haley's Com Truise couldn't have been more of-the-moment. A vintage-synth freak with a nostalgic moniker diving headlong into the sounds of 1983? In that long
column4: hazy comedown from 2009's summer of chillwave
column5: Haley was practically popping a wheelie on the zeitgeist. He took full advantage
column6: too
column7: offering up the superb Cyanide Sisters EP and the almost-as-good Galactic Melt LP in the same calendar year. But
column8: apart from 2012's soggy early-days comp In Decay
column9: we've heard next to nothing from him in the interim. Wave 1
column10: Com Truise's new seven-song EP
column11: is the first in a planned series that
column12: as Haley told DazedDigital
column13: concerns ""the world’s first Synthetic Astronaut on this journey to a planet—each release represents the next stage in his journey."" The chrome-plated
column14: pristine Wave 1 plants itself at the intersection of synth-funk
column15: electro
column16: and fussy 80s computer-pop. Haley
column17: returning from a two-year absence
column18: seems content to reemerge as a man out of time: unconcerned with the trends of the day
column19: blissfully mining Reagan-era pop at its most meticulous.

column1: Opener ""Wasat"" whirrs to a start like a spaceship preparing for hyperdrive. Just 15 seconds in
column2: and it's all systems go: a punctilious synth stutters like a long-lost Bambaataa track while a couple more streak past in a flash of light. The needly high-register synth and burbling bass at the center of ""Mind"" are almost conversant
column3: trading garbled interstellar transmissions atop the crackling of the drum machine. Haley's fastidious—forever searching for the perfect beat—and even his fizziest synth never seems to trail too far afield. In the past
column4: his exacting approach has occasionally tipped over into rigidity. But on Wave 1
column5: his chosen sonic touchstones—whether it's pre-Purple Rain Prince or Cupid and Psyche-era Scritti Politti—share his fondness for clean lines
column6: sharp edges
column7: and inorganic rhythms. Haley's fussiness persists
column8: but on Wave 1
column9: he comes by it honestly.

column1: Wave 1 peaks with ""Declination""
column2: a slick
column3: bright-as-the-sun pop deconstruction with vocals from Ford & Lopatin's Joel Ford. Haley's never quite known what to do with vocals
column4: but Ford's an ideal fit for the otherwise all-instrumental Wave 1
column5: his roboticized falsetto sliding its way into the nooks and crannies of the bustling track
column6: bringing some curious new shades to the all-pastel palette. Haley's never seemed particularly concerned with innovation; as Andrew Gaerig wrote in his review of In Decay
column7: he's a ""grid-worshipping…pure stylist
column8: more interested in playing within the lines than expanding on them. By injecting a little human warmth into this carefully delineated
column9: fiercely technical music
column10: Ford does as much to push Wave 1's sound forward as Haley himself.

column1: Apart from the the splattering ""I Would Die 4 U"" drum patterns sitting underneath ""Miserere Mei""
column2: Wave 1's post-""Declination"" tracks find Haley retreating into the tried-and-true: burbling bass
column3: squelchy zero-gravity synths
column4: blunt-ride rhythms. These songs are sleek and glorious-sounding
column5: each squiggle and thump given its own space. But
column6: by leaving no space for error
column7: Haley also doesn't allow much room for feeling
column8: and after a half an hour of vaccum-sealed rhythms
column9: a skipped beat or a flubbed intro never sounded so right. After a few years of silence
column10: Haley's still a stickler for detail
column11: still more concerned with perfection than innovation
column12: still mixing up ""crisp"" and ""mechanical."" But by burrowing down into a few key sounds rather than stiffly approximating a dozen-plus
column13: the intermittently funky
column14:
unshakably finicky Wave 1 is a mostly welcome return.

The Notwist do a good job of shrinking into the shadows
column3: making it feel like they could stop doing all this and drift away without any kind of announcement or farewell note. On hooking up with Sub Pop for their first full-length album since The Devil
column4: You + Me in 2008
column5: the label made such a big deal that it felt positively un-Notwistian. This is a band that operates without fanfare
column6: favoring the periphery over the spotlight. Even their brightest moment—the elevation in stature following the release of the gorgeous Neon Golden in 2002—led to more than half a decade of inactivity prior to its follow-up. The Notwist may feel like they know how to disappear completely
column7: but there's a weight of expectation when news of resumed activities comes through
column8: a sense that a return to the bittersweet sentiment of ""Chemicals"" or ""Pick Up the Phone"" could be careering around the bend.

column1: At their peak this is a band that can make disparate feelings feel positively orderly
column2: with singer Markus Acher's approach emotional yet strangely distant
column3: resembling someone trying to open up but keeping a handful of key thoughts to themselves. In theory the Notwist should be a big mess
column4: with nascent thrashings in hardcore circles
column5: attempts at bridging technology and indie-rock long before Thom Yorke tripped over a sampler
column6: and Acher's non-voice floating along on top of it all. Instead
column7: like all bands who've had at least one Neon Golden moment in their careers
column8: they have a way of making it seem remarkably uncomplicated
column9: establishing this as a space they inhabit alone despite the legions of laptop-tapping acts with an ear for pop melody
column10: some of whom seeped deeper into the public consciousness than the Notwist will presumably ever do at this point.

column1: Initially things seemed promising for Close to the Glass. Releasing the title track with its detuned beats underpinned by familiarly fussy electronics and Acher subsumed somewhere in the middle of it all was a smart move
column2: resembling the kind of dubbed-out pop structures Margaret Fielder was practicing with her band Laika circa their excellent Silver Apples of the Moon. Better still was the release of ""Kong""
column3: which comes stamped through with a forthright guitar clang
column4: irresistible organ drone
column5: and Acher hitting some wavering high notes not dissimilar to J Mascis' falsetto. It's this album’s equivalent of ""Day 7"" from Shrink—finding the spot where their brainiac approach merges perfectly with their fondness for abandon
column6: resulting in a catchy moment that's a far better realization of their anthemic tendencies than similar efforts from <i>The Devil
column7: You + Me.

column1: There's a sense of confidence installed by placing ""Close to the Glass"" and ""Kong"" early in the tracklisting
column2: although what follows never gets back there. The drop in quality isn't sharp—instead it's like watching a group of people kicking around a ball that's slowly deflating. There's an acoustic campfire misfire (""Casino"")
column3: Nick Drake wistfulness (""Steppin' In"")
column4: an attempt at Kevin Shields' glide-guitar sound that feels like it was regurgitated from a dusty old rehearsal tape from the mid-90s (""7-Hour-Drive"")
column5: and a go-nowhere instrumental that quickly crosses the line from Eno-esque beauty to boredom (""Lineri""). It would be a little cruel to hold up the title of ""From One Wrong Place to the Next"" as symbolic of where the second half of Close to the Glass ends up; instead
column6: there is no sense of place at all
column7: just a series of loose strands that never reach a point of cohesion.

column1: A version of Shrink was released on Stereolab's Duophonic label when it initially surfaced
column2: and it's easy to trace links between the approach and trajectory of both bands—both fascinated by the meeting point between pop and technology
column3: both keen to maintain an emotional distance from their audience
column4: both quietly working away with little regard for reception. Arguably Stereolab's later career produced more uneven results than their earlier work
column5: and it feels like the Notwist are in that phase now
column6: where change comes off as forced and unnecessary
column7: and the bigger picture of the band's identity becomes increasingly cloudy. There was always a tendency to divert into different styles on their prior albums (at least from 12 onward)
column8: but always with a feel of continuity underpinning it all
column9: as if each path they took was firmly routing off the same road. Here
column10:
their razor-sharp sense of direction feels strangely blunted.

After the rise of “The Belleville Three”—Detroit techno originators Derrick May

column4: Marcellus Pittman and Theo Parrish (the four intermittently collaborate as 3 Chairs). Since the 90s

column9: dusty vinyl grooves and—if the Popeye's inner sleeve is to believed—greasy fingers. Playful in juxtaposition to Theo’s seriousness
column10: the Dizzy Gillespie to Theo's Miles Davis
column11: Dixon might be best glimpsed through the prism of another Detroiter: J Dilla. Both men deconstructed and flipped old funk and soul to new ends
column12: Dilla’s focus towards hip-hop
column13: Moodymann's towards basement-deep house music.

column1: Take an album highlight like “Desire""
column2: which features Moodymann with uncredited Blue Note crooner José James. James does his deepest Gil Scott-Heron impersonation
column3: Moody deploys piano chords as judiciously as Bill Evans did
column4: all of it set against a beat that edges towards house only to dissipate just before settling into a steady pace. Old 33 1/3 soul gets spun at 45 on the ecstatic “Lyk U Use 2""
column5: the skittering snare pattern of fellow Detroiter Andrés then slowed all the way down to 45 BPM. It’s not only old soul vocals though: there’s an acid squirt over the Junior Boys’ Jeremy Greenspan on “IGuessuneverbeenlonely” and most peculiar of all
column6: has Lana Del Rey ask about death on “Born 2 Die"".

column1: But the most prominent voice on the album is Dixon’s own. In a close-mic’d croak
column2: Moodymann’s vocal delivery vacillates between late-night disc jockey and booty call from Sly Stone. He laments that “eight and a half is not enuff anymore
column3: ” that girls may not like 45s. One of the funniest call-and-responses of the year occurs on the too-brief “No”; KDJ heavy-breathes from a payphone to one of those bikini-clad nymphets draped across him on the front cover
column4: asks if she likes fried chicken without hot sauce. Also: “Y’all mad I’m a local Detroiter?”

column1: While almost every second of Moodymann’s oeuvre hearkens back to his hometown
column2: Moodymann is perhaps his most explicit ode yet. Snippets of movie dialogue
column3: murder statistics and tales of 70s heroin kingpins like Henry Marzette emerge between the spacious
column4: slack grooves. For all the insouciance that’s informed Moodymann’s work over the past two decades
column5: Moodymann feels downright serious at times. It comes to the fore on the sprawling twelve-minute version of Funkadelic’s “Cosmic Slop""
column6: which is part cover
column7: part edit
column8: part deconstruction
column9: part remix. Yet for a reason not altogether clear amid its haze is that these parts just don’t quite add up. Blame the news report samples or perhaps Dixon’s own croon
column10: but midway through
column11:
I fantasized what a sidelong KDJ edit circa 1998 might’ve sounded like instead.

“Sunspots”—the gentle
column2: two-minute instrumental that opens Bob Mould’s 1989 solo debut Workbook—may be the softest
column3: saddest “fuck you” in recorded history. Still stinging from the acrimonious breakup Hüsker Dü in 1988
column4: the singer/guitarist formed a new trio to replace the old
column5: this one with bassist Tony Maimone and drummer Anton Fier (who
column6: among other accomplishments
column7: served together briefly in Pere Ubu). That caliber of rhythm section had the potential to be at least as loud as Hüsker Dü’s. Instead
column8: Mould turned down and turn his back on punk. “I sensed there was a part of the punk audience that would feel betrayed
column9: ” Mould writes unapologetically in his autobiography See a Little Light
column10: “but it was important to move beyond the sound of the past eight years.” At the time
column11: Mould was living in rural Minnesota
column12: not far from an Amish settlement. Workbook isn’t exactly a work of entrenched technophobia—come the new millennium
column13: Mould would even go so far as to dabble in electronica—but its hushed tone and introspective air reflects a sense of isolation that’s bucolic if not exactly idyllic.

column1: Mould was an angry young man in Hüsker Dü
column2: and anger abounds on Workbook (which is getting an expanded reissue in honor of its 25th anniversary
column3: Workbook 25). Here
column4: though
column5: it’s dispersed among empty spaces and meandering melodies. There’s a honeycombed hollowness to tracks like “Heartbreak a Stranger” and “Sinners and Their Repentances""
column6: both of them overlaid with languid jangle and Mould’s newly naked moan. After years of straining to be heard over Hüsker’s din
column7: he sounds almost startled by the potency and range of his own voice; the same goes for the themes of his lyrics
column8: which don’t shy away from an encroaching spirituality that would eventuality lead to Mould’s religious awakening years later. But for every folky
column9: free-flowing rumination is a song such as “Dreaming
column10: I Am""
column11: which veers between a driving beat
column12: delicate guitar
column13: and a deceptively corrosive mood.

column1: “See a Little Light
column2: ” the song after which Mould named his book
column3: was Workbook’s lead single. Accordingly
column4: it’s the album’s brimming cup of pop hooks. Still
column5: it’s far more drifting and complex than it seems at first
column6: pivoting around tangles of chords while gliding frictionlessly across the glassy playing of cellist Jane Scarpantoni (who’d appeared on R.E.M.’s Green and would go on to play with everyone from Nirvana to Bruce Springsteen to Swans). The widespread use of cello throughout Workbook is one of its more striking tonal choices; Mould originally wrote those parts for synthesizer
column7: and their translation into chamber instrument threads the album with a haunting
column8: melancholy warmth—especially on “Sinners""
column9: where Scarpantoni duels with Mould like a demonic temptation.

column1: Hüsker Dü was
column2: in many ways
column3: a massively distorted folk band—but Workbook isn’t just acoustic Mould like “Too Far Down”
column4: Candy Apple Grey with the gunk scraped off. “Brasilia Crossed with Trenton”
column5: which Mould says came to him one morning as a “full realized dreamsong
column6: is seven minutes of imagistic
column7: shanty-like folk-rock
column8: but it’s hard to imagine its soul-spilling excess and sprawl ever fitting onto a Hüsker album
column9: even one as ambitious as Zen Arcade. The problem is
column10: Mould takes catharsis to a new dimension on Workbook
column11: but that leaves subtle cuts like “Brasilia” and “Lonely Afternoon” undefended by Mould’s most formidable weapon: a walloping chorus. He still wields them on “See a Little Light”—which boasts one of most searing choruses of his career—as well as on “Poison Years”
column12: which crams tender twang
column13: roiling angst
column14: anthemic stamina
column15: and squealing showmanship into a single song. All the elements of Mould’s songwriting are on parade on “Poison Years”
column16: but they’re lumped together in odd
column17: lopsided combinations.

column1: “Poison Years” also shows that Mould wasn’t entirely ready to strum gentle into that good night. Along with Workbook’s darkest track
column2: the venom-dripping “Wishing Well”
column3: it vengefully kicks on the distortion pedal as if it were an old toy that triggered memories of a troubled childhood. The shift is more than simply sonic
column4: as Mould himself seems equally electrified when he lets his amps to scream. One of the bonus tracks of Workbook 25 is the bouncy
column5: catchy “All Those People Know
column6: ” the B-side of the “See a Little Light Single”—and it makes perfect sense that it was omitted from the original album release
column7: seeing as how it could easily pass for latter-day Hüsker Dü.

column1: The rest of Workbook 25’s bonus tracks comprise a live set recorded at the Metro in Chicago in 1989. The live version of “Sunspots” is echoing and effected
column2: sounding in that regard almost like a John Martyn song. Mould’s affinity for vintage English folk-rock is also evident in his faithful yet fiery rendition of Richard and Linda Thompson’s “Shoot Out the Lights.” (He would eventually record Richard Thompson’s “Turning of the Tide” for the 1994 tribute album Beat the Retreat). But it’s “If You’re True” that’s the hidden gem of Workbook 25. A song that Mould has admitted to being a swipe at his former Hüsker Dü bandmates Grant Hart and Greg Norton—“No more friends that lie and hide / No more games to play to get to know the answer
column3: ” he rages—the Metro version of “If You’re True” is unleashed with riotous righteousness plus a clutch of country-rock licks that come together to sound uncannily like the formula Uncle Tupelo was about to make famous. It’s far more spirited than the drum-machine-backed 1988 demo version
column4: but Mould’s grudges didn’t fully carry over to his previous group’s music. He opens those fresh wounds long to encore with three Hüsker Dü songs: “Hardly Getting Over It”
column5: “Celebrated Summer”
column6: and “Makes No Sense at All”. As Mould states in See a Little Light
column7: when Workbook came out “there was a concerted effort not only to divorce myself from my past
column8: but also not to live off of my past accomplishments”. Yet he performs his Hüsker set reverently
column9: intimately
column10: almost in awe of the life they’ve taken on.

column1: While Mould seems liberated by his newfound quietude
column2: he also strains at it. In the video for “See a Little Light” he thrashes and hammers at his strings; at one point
column3: spit flies from his lips. It’s as though he alone can hear the noise behind his clean-toned
column4: cello-swaddled songs
column5: that theoretical roar that his old group would have brought to them. The pent-up force finally breaks free on Workbook’s final track
column6: “Whichever Way the Wind Blows""
column7: a lurching
column8: churning
column9: borderline grungy rager full of haywire guitar and Mould’s most unhinged vocal performance since his SST days. Sure enough
column10: Mould
column11: Maimone
column12: and Fier would quickly crank themselves up to paint-peeling levels on Black Sheets of Rain
column13: their 1990 follow-up to Workbook; from there
column14: Mould’s 90s group Sugar would return Mould triumphantly to his punchy
column15: distorted roots. But the urgency and vigor he packs into the unplugged punk of Workbook—the frequent knuckle-scraping attack of his strumming
column16:
his refusal to whisper or withhold—are what make the album a testament to tension rather than hesitance.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20228/homepage_large.35773ce6.jpg|Manhattan|32070.0|Skaters|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-02-27 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:53.452436|"

Last week
column2: the Village Voice published its list of the 50 Most NYC Albums Ever
column3: a feature that illustrated the myriad ways—from West Side Story to Ramones to On the 6—in which the five boroughs have been mythologized in song over the past 60-odd years. Coincidentally enough
column4: just days later
column5: New York quartet Skaters issued their own listicle of Big Apple rock-history signifiers—they just happened to do it in the form of their debut record.

column1: It’s an album about living in Manhattan titled Manhattan. There’s a song about what it’s like to be young in NYC called “To Be Young in NYC”. There are between-song snippets of young women complaining about sublets in uncannily Shosh-like voices. And it's no exaggeration to say this album—and its major-label patronage—would not exist without the modernized grot-rock of the Strokes’ Is This It. But in contrast to that unimpeachable document of pre-9/11
column2: Giuliani-era jollies
column3: Manhattan is the rock‘n’roll analogue to a post-Bloomberg New York
column4: where skyrocketing rents—and the big-box chains that can afford them—can make some city blocks look like Anytown USA. If the Strokes savvily refashioned NYC iconoclasts like the Velvet Underground and Television as dance-party pop music
column5: Manhattan is what’s become of your head-shop CBGB t-shirt after another 12 years of laundromat visits.

column1: Each of the 11 songs here are positioned at some point in an endless cycle of going out
column2: scoping girls
column3: getting drunk
column4: making out
column5: passing out
column6: and “waking up in [your] clothes.” But for Skaters
column7: such scenes are apparently so routine that they often sound disinterested in their own debauchery: On the opening track
column8: “One of Us”
column9: frontman Michael Ian Cummings sums up another messy night on the town by blithely repeating the words “fun and games” with an audible shrug that suggests he’d rather be at home catching up on House of Cards. It’s a blasé attitude that’s reflected in the band’s intensely streamlined sound
column10: which retains the fuzz and buzz of post-millennial mainstream garage-rock
column11: but is synth-smoothed and rhythmically processed to the point of sterlity. And the dabbles with electro blips (“I Wanna Dance But I Don't Know How”) and half-baked hardcore (“Nice Hat”) ultimately dilute rather than diversify the band’s personality; you’ll hear more credible reggae than “Bandbreaker” in your local karaoke bar’s backing track for “Underneath It All.”

column1: But if Skaters' version of Manhattan feels overly insular and one-dimensional
column2: they at least come by it honestly: Upon arriving from L.A. in 2012
column3: Cummings reportedly spent his first year in New York working as a bartender
column4: giving him a nightly front-row seat to a parade of self-indulgence. And in his more inspired moments
column5: he evinces the smarm and charm (if not the knockout lyricism) of another guy who's seen his fair share of last calls
column6: Paul Westerberg. Really
column7: if the reunited Replacements decided to make a new record in 2014
column8: they could do worse than crank out new-waved power-pop pick-me-ups like “Schemers” or the aforementioned “To Be Young in NYC”
column9: whose shout-out to “a generation of jerks
column10: directionless on our feet” scans as a post-millennial update of “Bastards of Young.”

column1: However
column2: it's the song dedicated to an unattainable rival-state beauty that
column3: ironically
column4: best fulfills Manhattan’s soundtrack-to-the-city mission: “Miss Teen Massachusetts”
column5: which boasts the album's most towering hook and convincingly restless performance. It just goes to show that it takes a lot more to capture the spirit of New York City in song than sampling conversations with cab drivers or rhyming “Harlem” with “problem”; with its churning groove and pleading
column6: stressed-out vocal
column7: “Miss Teen Massachusetts” counts as the rare moment where Skaters seem less concerned about describing what life in Manhattan looks and sounds like
column8:
and more into communicating how it really feels.

"|19023.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19023-skaters-manhattan/|4.8|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20237/homepage_large.4a7c3b33.jpg|Konstellaatio|32081.0|Ø|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sahko']|2014-02-27 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:54.041592|"

The Finnish musician Mika Vainio appears to have very little use for trends: For 30 years
column2: in a variety of collaborative contexts and with a panoply of solo guises
column3: Vainio has doggedly explored the outer edges of extreme electronics. In the 80s
column4: he tumbled found sounds into industrial onslaughts. In the 1990s and through much of the last decade
column5: his duo Pan Sonic worked as a sort of analogue revolver
column6: pushing between noise-heavy flotsam and graceful
column7: glitchy techno. Vainio follows that same swerving muse by himself; in the past two years
column8: he’s released a record that crunches and grinds (Kilo)
column9: one that sparkles only to roar (Magnetite)
column10: and another that hovers in a beautifully somber reverie (the impressive new Konstellaatio). What’s more
column11: in an age of composers and improvisers staring at MacBook screens both onstage and in the studio
column12: Vainio sticks to his longtime hardware kit of sequencers and synthesizers
column13: effects pedals
column14: and manipulated instruments. Speaking of computers
column15: he flatly told the Quietus last year
column16: “I have no problem resisting that.”

column1: But Konstellaatio
column2: Vainio’s first full-length in three years under his occasional mononym Ø
column3: shares several sonic and stylistic traits with the slow wave of doom-oriented electronic musicians that have grown out of darkwave
column4: shoegaze and heavy metal in recent years. Across these nine tracks
column5: Vainio juxtaposes blanketing drones with airy keyboards
column6: clipped beats and beeps with seemingly bottomless bass. These slow-motion spans treat the beautiful and the threatening as necessary complements
column7: as though he were a horror film director with an eye for both shock and cinematic elegance. For its overall aggression and bulk
column8: Vainio’s back catalogue can be intimidating
column9: even off-putting. But Konstellaatio is luminous and eerie
column10: the sort of liminal record where the pretty sounds elicit goose bumps and the grimmest tones feel like exhalations. Likely by little conscious design
column11: Vainio is the stylistic contemporary of acts such as Demdike Stare
column12: the Haxan Cloak and Andy Stott
column13: at least temporarily. If there’s a movement among such groups
column14: Konstellaatio merits more than mention with it.

column1: Vainio works with a rather limited set of sounds on Konstellaatio
column2: but he groups them into unexpected sets. He cycles constantly through low
column3: high
column4: and mid-range tones
column5: a strategy he sets in motion during the thesis-like opener “Otava”. Mellifluous keyboards lay like a lacy filigree atop bulbous bass
column6: with quick
column7: shivering clicks teasing a rhythm between them. “Neutronit” could rattle trunks
column8: with powerful concussions pounding beneath chirping circuits. But Vainio steadily corrodes his own system by fostering a rising tide of distortion beneath the beat. He’s the puppeteer
column9: balancing the thrills of propulsion with the threat of darkness. The revelatory closer “Takaisin” works in much the same manner
column10: pitting a corroded
column11: dub-like skitter and whorls of sampled mbira melodies against foreboding bass movements. Konstellaatio works best when Vainio makes each piece’s elements conspire against one another
column12: as when twinkling bells trickle their quiet hymns across the tectonic motion of “Elämän Puu” or when an unlikely rhythm emerges from a call-and-response between seraphic keyboards and hellish distortion during “Metsän Sydän”. These juxtapositions offer brief glimpses into Vainio’s past
column13: itself a springboard to contrast.

column1: If scope and restlessness are Vainio’s assets
column2: overall editing isn’t. Judicious
column3: non-grandiose projects have never really fit his approach. He releases a lot of records
column4: and he tends to overload them with material. (His last four albums run collectively for more than four hours.) Sähkö
column5: the label that Vainio co-founded in the 90s and has since issued much of his own music
column6: released Konstellaatio on CD. Listening to it
column7: though
column8: it’s hard not to wish that Vainio didn’t find some way to make this fit onto one slab of vinyl. Though some of Konstellaatio’s best moments arrive near the end
column9: these 66 minutes start to feel a touch oppressive long before the hour mark ticks near. As it floats from crackling static into sunwarped melody
column10: from drifting guitar into coruscant glockenspiel
column11: the 10-minute “Talvipäivä
column12: Vanha Motelli” begins to feel like the record’s musical sketchpad
column13: an organizational vestige accidentally left behind. And no matter how broad and compelling their sounds become
column14: no matter how monstrous the bass or florid the high tones
column15: the paired openers linger like redundant introductions. Konstellaatio fills a lot of room
column16: then
column17: with very little range. But what’s there is excellent and
column18: for Vainio
column19:
a striking and surprising contribution to a scene that’s watched him work for at least two decades.

Hayden Thorpe sneers ""Don't confuse with me someone who gives a fuck"" on the first track of Present Tense
column2: as if Wild Beasts could ever be the victims of mistaken identity. The inimitable interplay between Thorpe’s keening alto and Tom Fleming’s rich lower registers
column3: the sleek and supple rhythm section
column4: the immaculate production that provides quiet storm R&B’s high-thread count and funk’s pinpoint precision: you can’t really approach this sound without ripping them off outright
column5: so no one even tries. Much has been made about how Wild Beasts have drastically reduced the musical drama since their swashbuckling
column6: chandelier-swinging debut <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/12450-limbo-panto/"">Limbo
column7: Panto. Present Tense doesn’t reverse that trend
column8: but without much left to discard sonically
column9: Wild Beasts make their most radical and daring subtraction: emotional drama.

column1: As unique as they’ve been musically
column2: Wild Beasts' candid carnality has made them far more rare in the boy’s club of rock music than you’d been led to believe. Uncoupling masculinity from cartoon machismo
column3: indie slackerdom
column4: teenage neediness
column5: and brooding distance
column6: Wild Beasts presented modern man as a libidinous creature burdened by expectations and failed by his body
column7: both hunter-aggressor and prey to their own insecurities and embarrassments. Thorpe sang “I know I'm not any kind of heart-throb/ But at the same time
column8: I'm not any sort of slob” on Smother’s “Plaything” and that was about the size of it.

column1: Things are a lot healthier on Present Tense
column2: and Wild Beasts' dueling vocalists own up to past mistakes. Thorpe sums it up on “Past Perfect”: “Man did fuck up/ And then he learnt.” Lurid and obscenely limber
column3: “Mecca” presents sexual compatibility as nothing short of god’s will and eternal truth. The same goes for the “Sweet Spot”
column4: its title signifying “A godly state/ Where the real and the dream may consummate.” You’ve got the gist of it by the time “A Simple Beautiful Truth” comes around
column5: and it’s Wild Beasts’ most locked-in
column6: fluid performance
column7: barely two minutes of gorgeous and curvaceous R&B. These add ballast to the plainspoken and plainly pretty pop songs that define Wild Beasts’ new romantic fulfillment. “Palace” and “Pregnant Pause” come awfully close to treacle outside of context
column8: but balanced by the loinclothed swagger of “Nature Boy” and the apocalyptic retribution that “Daughters” foretells
column9: contentment feels earned rather than seen as entitlement.

column1: Still
column2: Present Tense is incrementally more dense and foreboding than Smother or Two Dancers. This is largely due to the implementation of synthesizers
column3: arranged by Leo Abrahams (amongst other things
column4: co-writer of David Byrne and Brian Eno’s “Strange Overtones”) and Lexxx
column5: whose previous
column6: blunt-force stadium-status charges (Arcade Fire
column7: the Killers
column8: Madonna and Keane amongst them) are about the exact opposite of Wild Beasts. And yet
column9: even with all of this expert musicianship and hired talent
column10: the added sounds are soft and welcoming. The lo-fi
column11: rigid beats of “Wanderlust” and “Daughters” and the Hounds of Love-style Linn rolls that ramp up the chorus of “Mecca” push against Chris Talbot
column12: a drummer who’s never played a standard rock beat and still hasn’t; he’s at his most emotive on Present Tense
column13: as “Nature Boy” skulks with primitive menace
column14: while the sadness of “A Dog’s Life” is conveyed by an inventive trick that makes his kit sound like it’s deflating.

column1: Though dealt with indirectly
column2: class struggle has always pervaded Wild Beasts' lyrics and they’ve always empathized with the outsider for good reason. They came on the scene at a time when the Arctic Monkeys ensured that lad-rock would continue to constitute the UK’s musical ruling class
column3: and so their early
column4: theatrical scene-chewing was seen as the epitome of drama club elitism. And while they’ve relocated from northern farming town Kendal to London and occupy their own sweet spot between the top of the pops and the basement
column5: Wild Beasts still side with the have-nots without condescending. “Nature Boy” plays off a common artistic trope—here’s a wild man that will do things to your woman that your white-collar
column6: Victorian ass can’t even imagine and she’s really into it. That sort of thing is right within Fleming’s wheelhouse
column7: but that dynamic seems a little too simplistic for Wild Beasts. You might miss the money quote courtesy of Jake “The Snake” Roberts (“A little fun for me/ And none for you”)
column8: but the title is indeed a Ric Flair reference
column9: and so the and so the caricatured imagery of “Nature Boy” makes the song as a whole a laugh at how complexities of class
column10: masculinity
column11: and sex can often be reduced to the heel/babyface duality of pro wrestling.

column1: A similar skewering occurs on “Wanderlust”
column2: which thankfully doesn’t aspire to be another pat
column3: “Common People”-style rant about the rich kids fetishizing artistic “authenticity.” Instead
column4: Thorpe questions the reductionism that goes on in both sides and the self-obsession that goes into any artistic pursuit. ""In the mother tongue/ What's the verb 'to suck?'""
column5: Thorpe taunts
column6: a subliminal at some fellow UK band getting a little too obvious in their Americanization. It also makes you wonder if “Nature Boy” might be a metaphor for how Wild Beasts compare to some of their more accommodating and popular peers. So what is “Wanderlust” doing as the opener on a record that focuses so much on domestic satisfaction? Get to the closer “Palace” and Thorpe bookends it by singing
column7: “Baby there’s have alls and there are have nots/ I’m happy with what I got”. Both songs speak on the futility of trying to attain any sort of real happiness trying to be someone else. Lucky for us
column8: there’s no one else like them and on <i>Present Tense
column9:
their success has allowed Wild Beasts to be even more like themselves.

Indoor Living is a moody outlier in Superchunk's great early run. It's a 4 pm kind of record
column3: a soundtrack for the moment when the sun hasn't set yet
column4: the day is more behind us than ahead of us
column5: and we're momentarily unsure of what to do with ourselves. Most people smooth over this unpleasant transition with a drink or three
column6: but Indoor Living spends 48 minutes lingering there. As a result
column7: it's a slightly odd Superchunk record
column8: neither tortured like Foolish nor desperate like No Pocky for Kitty nor delicate like Come Pick Me Up. It's just slightly tired and enervated-sounding
column9: and listening to it can occasionally feel that way.

column1: Some of that slightly cratered feeling probably came from its surrounding circumstances. After burning through five records and multiple EPs in six years
column2: Superchunk had reached a peak that suspiciously resembled a standstill. Their previous record
column3: 1995's Here's Where the Strings Come In
column4: brought them close as they would ever get to mass success
column5: which was
column6: in hard terms
column7: still ""nowhere near."" They had toured through Mac McCaughan and Laura Ballance's grisly breakup record Foolish
column8: during which Laura asked Mac's vocals to be removed from the monitors to keep her from crying onstage. Their fans were getting older and weren't coming to as many shows
column9: and there wasn't necessarily by a new batch of fervent twenty-something's clamoring to take their place. It was a moment
column10: if not to quit
column11: then to step back and take stock. What next?

column1: On the first song from Strings

They took the longest time between records in their history—two years—and spent more time working in mid tempo than they'd ever dared. On Come Pick Me Up
