0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20225/homepage_large.c14999ff.jpg|The Satanist|32003.0|Behemoth|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nuclear Blast']|2014-02-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:55.814508|"

Given that The Satanist is not only the first album by Polish firebrands Behemoth in five years but also their first since frontman Nergal was diagnosed with leukemia in 2010
column2: you might expect them to be restless at the start
column3: to burst open in a characteristic tangle of extreme metal. But they begin slowly
column4: a sinister riff cutting patiently through open air. The drums march rather than maraud
column5: while the bass pads the pocket. It feels like the preamble of a classic rock anthem
column6: perhaps the sequel to “Hells Bells”. But really
column7: Behemoth want to make sure you can hear Nergal and understand him when he opens with purely heretic invective: “I saw the virgin’s cunt spawning forth the snake
column8: ” he hisses
column9: clearly audible in his sibilance. “I witnessed tribes of Judah reduced to ruin.” Rather than emerge as though they have something to prove through speed and precision
column10: one of heavy metal’s most popular bands elects to return with something to say that’s as vile and startling as most any moment in their previously impious two decades. Even the precipice of death
column11: Nergal implies
column12: didn’t soften his sacrilege.

column1: The Satanist is Behemoth’s 10th album
column2: and in many ways
column3: it reflects a synthesis of their stepwise
column4: two-decade journey between atavistic black metal
column5: expert death metal and a mid-career hybrid of the two. During the last decade
column6: a bright studio gleam has often made their material feel cold and polished
column7: as though the execution had superseded the core. This didn’t necessarily make for bad albums as much as it did middling ones
column8: records that you could hear twice and move beyond. The Satanist doesn’t give up on high-end recording; in fact
column9: with its occasional exultant choirs
column10: horn fanfares
column11: and acoustic interludes
column12: it’s a complex and deliberate affair. This time
column13: the sheen only highlights what’s beneath the surface
column14: revealing these songs’ eccentricities and thrills rather than buffing them out. During “In the Absence ov Light”
column15: for instance
column16: Behemoth shift suddenly from a black metal raze into an impasse where acoustic guitar and soft jazz saxophone waft beneath a spoken passage from Polish writer Witold Gombrowicz. When the band returns
column17: though
column18: Nergal’s impatient voice and Inferno’s unsettled drums arrive with unexpected force
column19: like closed fists swinging through the dark. It’s the sort of thrilling confluence of structure and sound that Behemoth has lacked on recent records.

column1: What’s more
column2: these dynamic songs keenly balance the aggressive with the accessible
column3: so that even the most volatile tantrums open wide at some point. After a slow-building introduction
column4: “Ora Pro Nobis Lucifer” springs into a blast beat
column5: with a pick slide leading to riffs pulled taut beneath Nergal’s rasp. But the refrain
column6: a corruption of the Lord’s Prayer
column7: is instantly unforgettable; the guitars change their pattern so that their notes push upward beneath the tune
column8: countering the power with just a touch of pop. And wedged between a blues-like solo and an eruption of blast beats
column9: the closer “O Father O Satan O Sun!” crests in a chorus worthy of an Amon Amarth anthem. The Satanist is vividly rendered
column10: with bright moments that shine outward from the prevailing doom and themes that wind into dense knots and unravel into electrifying leads.

column1: Much as they’ve always done
column2: Behemoth state their intentions and ideals in hyperbole throughout The Satanist
column3: with polemics that pass beyond the threshold of mere anti-Christian antagonism. Nergal writes of massaging mold into pages of scripture and infecting the cross with woodworms. That’s presumably a rather steep barrier to entry for many
column4: but the rhetoric is meant to be a tad ridiculous
column5: something Nergal plainly admits. “I really hope that people can read between the lines
column6: ” he told Loudwire earlier this year. He’s long clashed with the Polish government over his expressed religious views. “I really hope they don’t take things in a very literal way.” And that is the real trick of The Satanist
column7: an album that
column8: in spite of its title and tone
column9: ultimately feels less about “bit[-ing] the withered hand of God” than besting the odds and avoiding the comfort of conformity. This is something that Behemoth’s recent albums have refused to do themselves
column10: after all.

column1: Nergal is careful to stretch his style sheet of references beyond the Devil and Christ; he folds Latin and Coptic concepts into these lines
column2: even nodding to John Milton in one passing moment. “Blow Your Trumpets Gabriel” might crib some of the Bible’s key concepts and phrases
column3: including Gabriel’s horns
column4: but it actually celebrates any collapse of absolute power. And near the middle of “Amen”
column5: Nergal falls out of the accelerating pace and yells the album’s most essential phrase in his lowest tone: “Credo undone”
column6: he bellows
column7: stretching that last syllable until it blurs into the record’s most delirious solo. That proclamation has less to do with the Devil and more to do with everything else in the world. There was some doubt
column8: after all
column9: if Nergal would even live long enough to make another album. And there was certainly more doubt than hope that
column10: if Behemoth did finish a tenth record
column11: it would stand somehow as a late-career renaissance. But The Satanist is a terrific coil of most everything Behemoth have ever done well
column12:
a strangely hopeful vision of hell wrested away from its very grip.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20270/homepage_large.7cfa06e3.jpg|No. 2|32117.0|Christina Vantzou|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2014-02-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:40:56.516365|"

Brussels-based composer Christina Vantzou has made a name for herself by being unassuming. In collaboration with Stars of the Lid’s Adam Wiltzie
column2: she made up half of the Dead Texan
column3: whose 2004 collection of noisy vignettes supposedly stemmed from aborted SotL pieces. These sketches were too aggressive to fit in with Wiltzie’s main project and Vantzou
column4: who was then best known as a maker of bleary short films
column5: stepped in. The Dead Texan’s music was all loops and whorls
column6: more intent on grabbing your attention than SotL’s work but still grounded in the monochromatic haze that Vantzou would go on to explore in her visual art and in solo material. Her new solo album
column8: underscores her commitment to subtle composition.

column1: No. 2 takes the gauzy
column2: filmic work that made up Vantzou’s first release and homes in on the emotionally engaging details. Even with its expanded instrumental palette and larger string section
column3: it’s small moments that give her music a new diversity. Vantzou’s bedtime symphonies have been fleshed out with the addition of woodwinds and a more dynamic use of her voice
column4: and “Sister” in particular stands out for its foreboding clarinet swells in the midst of an album heavily reliant on a glacial string section.

column1: Vantzou works well with the short form: No. 2 is only 35 minutes
column2: without any tracks breaching the five minute mark
column3: so her amorphous drones never overstay their welcome. And while there are no appreciable hooks
column4: Vantzou has a pop sense of timing and she’s intent on making this record a digestible whole. Each track carries its own emotional weight. Even “Strange Symptoms”
column5: which is little more than a minute-long keyboard drone
column6: functions as a placid comedown from the elemental movements that bookend it.

column1: Still
column2: No. 2 still holds onto that unassuming nature
column3: for better and for worse. When moments like the funereal horn lines on “Vostok” break into the open after several tracks of frigid drones
column4: the contrast is absolutely heart-rending. But these transcendent moments are few
column5:
and No. 2 could still use a little more of that drama.

In the mid-2000s
column2: Souljazz Orchestra emerged playing West African funk and highlife rife with propulsive horn hooks
column3: blown-out keyboards
column4: and call-and-response refrains full of political fervor. On Inner Fire
column5: the Ottawa collective sounds different. The program is once again curated by composer and bandleader Pierre Chrétien
column6: who brings a crate-digger’s thirst for obscure and offbeat musical idioms. Under his direction
column7: SJO patch together swatches of North American
column8: African
column9: and Latin styles to create hybrids that resist easy categorization.

column1: Much of Inner Fire consists of intricately arranged
column2: harmonically adventurous Afro-Latin jazz; this sound
column3: when paired with the lush piano and vibraphone backgrounds Chrétien favors
column4: creates resonances with Mulatu Astatke’s Ethio-jazz. The driving polyrhythms of Nigerian folk music that marked their earlier work are set aside in favor of more laid-back percussion indigenous to the Americas. The album’s highlights are its most culturally ambiguous selections
column5: like “One Life to Live”
column6: which mixes rhumba and reggaeton rhythms
column7: and “Sommet En Sommet”
column8: a dense
column9: three-against-four shuffle influenced partially by Guinean music. “As the Crow Flies”
column10: the single finest track

column1: Equally fundamental to the ethos of Inner Fire is the school of spiritual jazz that blossomed in the wake of John Coltrane’s Eastern-influenced explorations of the mid–1960s. The band has always claimed the style as a source of inspiration—their 2007 album Freedom No Go Die features a rendition of Pharoah Sanders’ hypnotic half-hour opus “The Creator Has a Master Plan”. Steve Patterson and Ray Murray
column2: the SJO’s tenor and baritone players
column3: often channel the legendary saxophonist in their solos
column4: and Chrétien frequently emulates the keyboard flourishes of McCoy Tyner and Alice Coltrane.

column1: Inner Fire falters when the ensemble attempts full pieces in the “spiritual” mold
column2: as on “Black Orchid""
column3: a slick piece of lite-funk. The spare
column4: blues-inflected dirge “East Flows the River” lacks some much-needed disruptive element or event to keep it from sounding like a jazzy piece of boom-bap rap production without an MC. “Celestial Blues”
column5: a cover of a Roland Kirk-styled piece of 70s avant-soul by Gary Bartz NTU Troop makes one curious about the original record
column6: but the SJO’s version itself ultimately comes off as inert.

column1: Inner Fire's biggest problem is a sporadic lack of energy. The band’s recent interest in more introspective and less tightly structured music doesn’t always play to their strengths
column2: namely
column3: their ability to devise and deliver taut and constantly mutating arrangements. But the group's impulse to dismantle and globalize their sound (or their refusal to settle on one) is admirable
column4:
and their efforts to do so result in some inventive moments.

""I won't be long
column2: sang Beck last year
column3: over and over
column4: on a song he quietly self-released. Lyrically
column5: the track was clouded by some of the songwriter's favorite themes: apocalypse
column6: disconnection
column7: death. But musically
column8: ""I Won't Be Long"" couldn't be more alive. Across 15 minutes
column9: it casually segued between alien synth oscillations
column10: atmospheric funk
column11: queasy reverb rock
column12: and squished punk
column13: effectively updating the post-modern glories of his 18-year-old Odelay. It was a fine piece of evidence showing that Beck was back—that the previous six years of producing excellent albums for Charlotte Gainsbourg and Stephen Malkmus
column14: covering the likes of INXS and Yanni with playful abandon
column15: and tossing out stunning one-offs like his 20-minute Philip Glass remix revived him after a string of less-than-great albums. But ""I Won't Be Long"" was a red herring. While he's apparently working on another genre-jumping LP

column1: Beck’s music didn’t used to be comfortable. Early on
column2: if he wasn't putting a modern twist on the blues tradition
column3: he was splicing styles that had never met before
column4: or paying tribute to his R&B heroes with unabashed glee. His entire ethos involved challenges: to history
column5: to authenticity

column7: Nick Drake
column8: and Gordon Lightfoot
column9: it was surprising because it was so straightforward—and emotive. It had the poster boy of irony looking straight into the camera and confessing his bitterness and desolation following a breakup. Morning Phase marks the first time since then that Beck has returned to this more forthright style
column10: partly due to the fact that a batch of tapes containing Sea Change-style demos were tragically lost in the years following that album. But while the new record is unequivocally related to its forebear—it features most of the same players and a strikingly similar sonic palette—there are differences that set it apart
column11: and bring it down.

column1: Rather than focussing on a resigned anger or ambiguous darkness
column2: Morning Phase is plagued by a frustrating in-between-ness that can also come off as flat and neutral. Many of the lyrics read like vague zen koans that perilously walk a tightrope above meaninglessness: wheels turn
column3: hearts beat
column4: skies fall. Without many concrete details to anchor the songs
column5: they can become too ethereal for their own good. Part of the idea behind Morning Phase involves renewal and maturation: If you live to be a married 43-year-old father of two
column6: Beck may be saying
column7: the peaks and valleys of youth eventually even out. The sense of loss on the album is more internalized and indirect
column8: which is interesting in theory
column9: but in practice it can dull things into oblivion. ""Say Goodbye"" strings together breakup scenes with Beck as the narrator who's seen it all before but can only muster sidelined commentary. ""These are the words we use to say goodbye
column10: he shrugs. You get an overall sense of wisdom from the lines on this album
column11: though that wisdom too rarely coalesces into something truly affecting.

column1: All of which is even more vexing due to the fact that most of Morning Phase sounds stunning; as the producer of the album
column2: Beck matches Sea Change studio guru Nigel Godrich tweak for tweak. But that raises another issue: While Beck's technical chops have grown impressively
column3: Morning Phase only proves that he can tackle Sea Change-style production
column4: like he's trying to redraw a masterpiece. Even so
column5: his singing has never felt stronger
column6: adding to the voice-of-god vibe (which plays through to his practically disembodied head on the album's cover). And every guitar pluck and string swipe is rendered with a warmth that backs up Beck's analog evangelicalism; on the gorgeous proper opener ""Morning""
column7: you can practically see the rays of California sun peek through the blinds before the light comes through full-force on the hook. ""Unforgiven""
column8: another highlight
column9: very well may be Beck's finest technical vocal performance as he milks every syllable while his composer father David Campbell provides a swirling symphony behind him. The similarly epic ""Wave""
column10: however
column11: falls into melodrama and ends up sounding like a lesser version of Radiohead's Godrich-produced ""Pyramid Song"". So while Morning Phase is remarkably easy to listen to
column12: the distinction isn't completely praiseworthy.

column1: Recalling his 1990s emergence in a Pitchfork interview from 2011
column2: Beck said
column3: ""Back then I had a feeling that we weren't quite measuring up to the music that had come before
column4: or it just wasn't as important somehow."" Of course
column5: for a generation of adventurous music fans who sang along with ""The New Pollution"" in the backseat
column6: artists like Beck and Pavement and Sonic Youth were indeed more important than the classic rockers who came before them
column7: even if it didn't seem so at the time. And the way that those artists dismantled the known canon and morphed new shapes from it made them exciting. Based on some of his recent work—a 30-minute track here
column8: a songbook album there—Beck does not seem through with trying to rearrange our musical synapses
column9: which is why Morning Phase ultimately is a disappointment. Not only does it uphold the myths of baby boomer greats like the Byrds
column10: Neil Young
column11: and Simon and Garfunkel with a staid type of reverence
column12:
but it also piggybacks on the legacy of one of Beck's best records. It's the sound of a rule-breaker dutifully coloring inside the lines.

The King is an album of moody indie rock that was partly funded via Kickstarter and soft-released through iTunes and Amazon. Buried like a time capsule beneath its very modern mode of release is the story of how things got here—through a turbulent transition into the artist-empowering internet age that left some casualties in its wake. One was Voxtrot
column2: an Austin-based band formerly led by the singer-songwriter now simply billed as Ramesh.

column1: Voxtrot wrote indie-pop songs you could dance to without drum machines or sequencers. Pairing spry
column2: zooming musicianship with the adorably wimpy vocals of Ramesh Srivastava
column3: they were like the Smiths for a world after the dance-punk revival. They came out swinging with a pair of self-released EPs in 2005 and 2006. With their winning blend of scrappiness
column4: conviction
column5: and smarts
column6: the EPs remain well worth your while: ""The Start of Something"" is particularly indelible
column7: though its title feels ironic in hindsight.

column1: No one guessed that Voxtrot's start would be so close to its end
column2: especially after they signed with Beggars Banquet. But on their self-titled 2007 LP
column3: their rambunctious energy crumpled under self-conscious arrangements
column4: and the band itself crumpled under the weight of the mixed reactions to it. They eked out a murky last EP in 2009 and kept performing until 2010
column5: but as of 2007 they were no longer part of the conversation.

column1: The mid-2000s were kind of crazy times. Our current dispensation
column2: where bands can use the internet to circumvent indie labels like their forebears did the majors
column3: was still taking shape. This was before Bandcamp and SoundCloud
column4: when one could still write about ""the promotional power of the mp3"" as something novel. The digital DIY narrative crystallized around Clap Your Hands Say Yeah in 2005
column5: in a cultural climate both drunk on and wary of hype.

column1: As the industry kept granulating
column2: so did critical influence. Blogs and websites
column3: figuring out how to wield newfound power
column4: often raced to greet anything promising with preemptive enthusiasm that could abruptly shift to disproportionate disappointment in a way that must have seemed capricious on the receiving end. Young bands now take immediate and overwhelming scrutiny for granted—or crave it. But they weren't used to it back then.

column1: ""The career path of Voxtrot was truly one of long
column2: simmering build
column3: explosion
column4: and almost instantaneous decay
column5: Srivastava wrote in a 2010 breakup note. ""Slowly
column6: I am learning to replace any feelings of regret with positive memories of how amazing the whole thing was
column7: and how it has
column8: in an unexpected way
column9: fortified my character."" The experience feels faintly scarred on this comeback LP
column10: where something new in his voice sounds shaky and proud.

column1: What hasn't changed is the sweetness of that voice
column2: with its delicate buoyancy that makes me want to hear him cover Paul Simon. And the songs
column3: which are mostly made with electric guitar
column4: piano
column5: bass
column6: drums
column7: and light synthesizers
column8: aren't terribly different from Voxtrot: There's aching chamber pop (""The King"")
column9: danceable indie rock (""1111"")
column10: and amalgams of them both (""Youth Trip""). An eclectic roster of backing musicians and producers (such as Jim Eno) includes Voxtrot alums Jason Chronis
column11: Mitch Calvert
column12: and Jared Van Fleet. But the tempos are generally slower
column13: the vocals more vulnerable
column14: the arrangements
column15: with a couple exceptions
column16: more cautious.

column1: String-and-piano ballads and bouncy disco-pop tracks are Srivastava’s strong suits
column2: and there are quite a few enjoyable ones here. Not everything works: The harp and trumpet on ""American Lust"" feel a bit aimless
column3: and the segue from whispered poetry to frantic noise rock on ""Lux"" is just strange. Some lyrics
column4: no longer glossed over in wordy gouts
column5: are distractingly sentimental (there are occasional rainbows
column6: angels
column7: ecstasies). But The King is a plainer
column8: more enjoyable album than the one Voxtrot finished with
column9: and feels like a foundation Srivastava could rebuild upon
column10:
a few years later and an age away.

If indie-rap heads weren't sure what to make of Homeboy Sandman as the calendar flipped over to 2012
column2: they've had so many opportunities to figure him out that anybody still left behind has just about lost. We're talking six releases of note in just over 24 months—<i>Subject: Matter
column3: Chimera
column4: First of a Living Breed
column5: Kool Herc: Fertile Crescent
column6: and All That I Hold Dear all dropped through 2013
column7: with White Sands
column8: his first release of 2014
column9: making it half a dozen. If you've ever tried to commit yourself to getting into Sandman's dryly incisive style—all scalpel-wielding deadpan and internally knotted wit and ha-ha-wait one-liners—there're more fresh entry points than Sonny Corleone post-tollbooth.

column1: But if you're not converted yet
column2: why not go for the EP produced by the man who helped get Danny Brown's “Wonderbread” permanently lodged in countless listener's brains? Paul White's contributions to Old authoritatively put White on the radar
column3: but his years' worth of previous work included a couple collaborations with Homeboy Sandman that already set a positive precedent. Sandman's White collabs on the Chimera EP breathed vividly through minor-key Michael Mann glow (“Look Out”) and VHS-fidelity late-summer soul murk (“They Can't Hang (Word to the Mother)”). And his spot the next year waxing anxious over a stargazing shuffle beat on White's Watch the Ants endcap “Find a Way” made it clear they had a mutually beneficial set of styles going.

column1: Hence White Sands—even the title's slick wordplay makes this team-up seem preordained. Sandman's clear-eyed
column2: clinical yet humane dissection of daily experience benefits from a similarly subdued production that holds just a few ripples of detectable tension beneath. White's sound here is the kind of thing worth conjuring up when attempting to figure out if there's such a thing as a Stones Throw house style: you get obscuro-soul beats filtered through quaver and hiss on some old-cassette shit
column3: sawn-off basslines and snares that sound like baseball bats against padded walls
column4: and vocals pitched up until they sound just the right side of bewildered. That
column5: plus there's a goofy streak somewhere in there. I'm sure there are slower fadeouts than the dying-battery nod-off of “Fat Belly""
column6: but none I can think of that're accompanied by enthusiastic food crunching noises.

column1: Granted
column2: those crunching noises come after a bunch of verses relating to Sandman's vegan/organic/health food diet
column3: which reclaims almond milk and lentils from hippie-dippie yuppie-shopper punchline status and flips it through his own eat-right lens in the tradition of A Tribe Called Quest's “Ham 'n' Eggs”. From there on out there's ample proof that Sandman's blend of straight-up rhyming
column4: conceptual thrust
column5: and worldbuilding storytelling is yet again on point. In doses of little interconnected one-liner details
column6: unspooling over “I Saw a World” or “Bad Meaning Good""
column7: his negative-space-heavy hard-stop flow lets the snapshots come into focus. Bigger-picture stories feel like they could go on for another half-dozen verses—there's devastating depth to the broken woman depicted at the core of “Echoes” (“Her mother once beside herself with worry/ Now she wander right beside her none the wiser/ She didn't recognize her”). Sure
column8: White Sands is something of a self-contained universe
column9:
another one-producer release in the tradition of ""EL RNTC"" collab Kool Herc: Fertile Crescent and the M. Slago-helmed All That I Hold Dear. But it's a universe with a lot to explore.

Is misandry a growing threat to our society? Catcalling women on the street: a socially acceptable form of flattery? Do you have an allergy to certain delicious herbal tea blends? If you said yes to any of these questions
column2: the members of Tacocat are not your friends
column3: but you might end up liking them anyway. Though they've been around since 2007
column4: the Seattle quartet are relatively new to a wider audience. Over the past few months
column5: they've been expanding upon their longtime underground reputation as a gutsy bubblegum surf-rock outfit bolstered by an adorable meme
column6: some goofy Y2K nostalgia
column7: and—above all—an unparalleled feminist wit that's hard to hate
column8: even if you're the target.

column1: It's born of practice: Tacocat's Hardly Art debut
column2: the ironically sunshiny NVM
column3: is hardly their first foray into the satire game. Back in 2012
column4: vocalist Emily Nokes and bassist Bree McKenna were the pair of masterminds behind <a href=""http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/men-who-rock/Content?oid=14913816"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Men Who Rock
column5: the now-legendary cover feature of local Seattle weekly The Stranger that brilliantly skewered the music media's objectification of female musicians. Two years later
column6: NVM—an abbreviation for ""nevermind"" coined by the post-Nirvana AOL generation—has become an extension of that tradition
column7: turning just the right cheerful screws on haters from all corners of their hegemonic hellscape.

column1: Whether it's the male gaze (""Hey Girl"") or menstruation (""Crimson Wave"")
column2: seasonal affective disorder (""Bridge to Hawaii"") or becoming a woman (""Psychedelic Quinceañera"")
column3: or even just hometowns that have a collective aneurysm every time it snows (""Snow Day"")—no vexation is safe from the sprightly melodies of Tacocat. ""In my experience
column4: making jokes about that kind of stupid stuff has made people check themselves more than when people yell at them about it
column5: Nokes said in a recent interview. So instead of a blistering indictment
column6: she and her friends made an album that throws a double-handful of confetti in the face of topics that might otherwise induce rage blackouts
column7: a light-hearted reminder that sometimes the best way to defeat an enemy is to make them sheepishly laugh.

column1: Like many of their compatriots
column2: Tacocat draw as heavily on 60s surf rock and girl-group radio hits as they do on 90s and 00s MTV alt-rock rotation (""Quinceañera"" is bolstered by horns worthy only of Cake)
column3: but where peers have settled for simple
column4: fest-ready party rock
column5: Tacocat use those influences to complement a musical comedy that's effortless and immediately justifies its existence: I didn't realize I needed a song about hating my bus line with an all-consuming passion
column6: yet ""FU #8"" delivers like a Sky Mall patent direct from heaven. Almost every track
column7: save the disappointing-only-by-comparison ""Alien Girl"" and opener ""You Never Came Back""
column8: serves a highly specific
column9: completely unromantic purpose
column10: especially in the lives of women: they're simple theme songs
column11: #realtalk jingles to tuck away in the personal artillery that gets you through a particularly dumb day.

column1: And though it seems downright insane when paired with the actual sounds contained on the album
column2: most of NVM
column3: despite its humor
column4: is still sincerely concerned with the bullshit inherent in power structures
column5: as much as a Bikini Kill or a Sleater-Kinney or even a White Lung. It lacks the sonic weight that so easily matches those feminist frustrations
column6: but it would be foolish to want such things of a band like Tacocat
column7: because there are so few places in which to find sentiments like these in such a refreshingly sunny musical context. The only anchor the album really needs is the certainty that one day your world will treat you like utter garbage
column8: and only the sarcastic irreverence of Tacocat can lift you out of your vortex of suckitude. Cheeky but not bratty
column9: NVM leaves a statement behind without preaching or scolding (save perhaps on ""This Is Anarchy
column10: a satirical
column11: natural mate to millennial eye-rollers like Bent Shapes' ""Brat Poison""). It's simple and approachable
column12: but its wit gives it longevity—at least
column13:
until a song about ""communists in the summer house"" is passé.

Annie Clark's bold and almost jarringly confident fourth record
column3: St. Vincent
column4: does not sound like it was recorded here on Earth. Its songs sprout with their own strange
column5: squiggly lifeforms and are governed by unfamiliar laws of gravity. Check out the first one
column6: ""Rattlesnake""
column7: a song that's bare
column8: Kraftwerky
column9: and full of imagery that is somehow both Edenic and post-apocalyptic. Clark glances around: ""Am I the only one in the only world?"" She spots the title creature
column10: gasps
column11: and then comes this song's idea of a chorus
column12: like melodic gagging
column13: or distress expressed in an 8-bit video game: ""AH-AH-AH-AH-AH-AH AHH AHH/ AH-AH-AH-AH-AH-AH AHH AHH."" You often get the sense in a St. Vincent song that Clark has touched down on a desolate
column14: previously unexplored planet without an air supply and is showing off the fact that—for the moment at least—she can still breathe.

column1: Given the fangs she bares on St. Vincent
column2: it seems like Clark could take that snake
column3: easily. Over the course of four albums
column4: many early-career guest spots
column5: and a 2012 collaboration with David Byrne
column6: Clark has been focusing her vision and sharpening her music's edges; were it not for Google image search
column7: it would be easy to convince yourself that you merely dreamed those days when she wore butterfly wings with Sufjan Stevens and blithely flowing robes with the Polyphonic Spree. With each release
column8: Clark sounds less like anybody but herself
column9: and more forcefully embraces a darkness that was quietly stirring in even her earliest songs. ""You don't mean that
column10: say you're sorry
column11: she chimed in a creepy
column12: Bride of Chucky voice on her still-magnificent debut single
column13: ""Now
column14: Now"". But the smirking overlord that stares out from the cover of St. Vincent does not apologize
column15: not for any of the unpleasantries she utters through gritted teeth
column16: nor the much nastier things she blurts out her fingers.

column1: St. Vincent continues Clark's run as one of the past decade's most distinct and innovative guitarists
column2: though she's never one to showboat. Her harmonic-filled style bears the influence of jazz (she picked up a lot of her signature tricks from her uncle
column3: the jazz guitarist Tuck Andress) and prog rock
column4: two genres known to embrace sprawl. But Clark's freak-outs are tidy
column5: modular and architecturally compact—like King Crimson rewritten by Le Corbusier. Even at its most spazzy
column6: there's always something efficient about St. Vincent. The stark
column7: spring-wound single ""Birth in Reverse"" doesn't waste a second on superfluous sounds
column8: and the same goes for the corrosive crunch of ""Regret""
column9: which sounds like a classic rock song pared down to its most essential elements. All the negative space in that last one makes Clark's riffs hit that much harder
column10: especially when—in one of the most thrilling moments on the album—a solo strikes down out of nowhere like a cartoon lightning bolt.

column1: Critics of St. Vincent call her pretentious. Fair enough—these are the sorts of songs that dare take themselves seriously and tack on easy suffixes like ""in America"" when they want to let you know they are Making a Statement. But there's an under-appreciated playfulness about Clark's music that balances this out. I can't think of much contemporary guitar-based music that has this much fun with texture—the rubbery whiplash percussion on ""Prince Johnny""
column2: the stretched-taffy vocals on ""Bring Me Your Loves""
column3: the gleefully synthetic-on-purpose sheen of ""Digital Witness"". At best
column4: St. Vincent has a mischievous curiosity about texture (and explosions) that feels almost childlike. Recently my 8 year-old cousin asked me
column5: with a wicked twinkle in his eye
column6: if I'd ever microwaved a banana. I'm terrified to try
column7: but I'm sure whatever happens—splattering
column8: abrupt
column9: radioactive—sounds exactly like an Annie Clark guitar solo.

column1: ""What's the point in even sleeping/ If I can't show
column2: if you can't see me?"" Clark asks on the single ""Digital Witness""
column3: a rather on-the-nose critique of our hyper-transparent
column4: Instagram-your-every-meal culture. It's tempting to label St. Vincent Clark's anti-internet album
column5: but that wouldn't be quite right—it knows too well what a life mediated through screens feels and sounds like to be sending it up entirely. (In fact
column6: digital life may have influenced her concise
column7: anti-jam style: ""I have some restless ears
column8: and I now have a fractured attention span because I'm like living in the modern world
column9: she said in a recent interview. ""So I'm like
column10: how do I make this sound interesting to myself?"") ""Huey Newton"" is maybe one of the best songs ever written about falling down a late-night
column11: vaguely depressive internet k-hole (""Pleasure dot loathing dot Huey dot Newton/ Oh
column12: it was a lonely
column13: lonely winter""); seemingly stream-of-conscious references to Black Panthers
column14: Byzantine architecture
column15: and the Heaven's Gate cult flicker by like puzzlingly connected Wikipedia pages. The common threads emerge if you look closely. From the self-coronated Prince Johnny to the ""near-future cult leader"" Clark has fashioned herself on the album cover
column16: there's a fascination with power
column17: faith
column18: and mind-control running through these songs—learning how to sell yourself your own lines well enough to sell them back to other people
column19: too.

column1: ""I was reading Miles Davis' biography
column2: Clark says of her Beyoncé-like decision to self-title a record this late in her career
column3: ""and he says that the hardest thing for a musician to do is sound like yourself."" In that sense
column4: it's a perfect title. St. Vincent is the Platonic ideal of a St. Vincent record
column5: executing with perfect poise everything we already know she can do. But this also is why it falls just short of being her best. That honor still goes to Strange Mercy
column6: which had a capacity to surprise and defy expectations in a way that this record does not. Strange Mercy was easier to connect to emotionally (""If I ever meet the dirty police man who roughed you up
column7: she cooed on the title track
column8: a line that was as jarring for its tenderness as it was for its violence) and gave Clark a little more room to stretch her legs in the grooves. The pixelated shredding on ""Huey Newton"" and ""Regret"" are great
column9: but nothing here feels as unhinged as the borealis chaos of at the end of ""Northern Lights"" or the razor-sharp coda of ""Surgeon"". The Bowie-esque metamorphosis suggested by the cover image doesn’t mean she’s reinvented her sound. Of course it's not the worst problem for an artist to have
column10: but Clark's become so good at being St. Vincent that
column11: on future releases
column12: she risks boxing herself in. You hope the next album finds her coloring outside the lines she's so meticulously drawn for herself.

column1: Still
column2: it’s hard to ask too much more from an album that boasts melodies as lovely as  ""Prince Johnny"" and ""Severed Crossed Fingers"". That last one is the best closing song on a St. Vincent album yet—a self-deprecating
column3: slow-motion parade of a ballad that sounds like if Lorrie Moore had written the non-existent lyrics to “Here Come the Warm Jets”. (This song and “Birth in Reverse” both take their wry titles from Moore’s great short story collection Birds of America.) It’s a moment of vulnerability and bleak hope rounding out Clark’s hardest
column4: tightest
column5: and most confident record to date—a vaguely ominous promise of better days ahead. ""We’ll be heroes on every bar stool
column6: she vows
column7:
sounding so sure of herself that you’re liable to follow her to whatever planet she’s headed.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20221/homepage_large.ac293b39.jpg|Blank Project|11116.0|Neneh Cherry|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2014-02-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:41:03.066861|"

The past 10 years of pop music have Neneh Cherry’s fingerprints all over them
column2: from the unruly conglomerations of genres that have come to define much of the Hot 100 to the uncountable number of female singers who’ve borrowed directly or indirectly from the club-diva-meets-art-school-b-girl playbook that made a smash out of her 1988 single “Buffalo Stance”. It’s become painfully obvious that her status as a one-hit wonder has far less to do with her talents than how far she was ahead of her time.

column1: Cherry’s early work has aged well. In 2012
column2: she returned from a hiatus initiated after the back to back flops of the alt-rock-leaning follow-ups to her 1989 debut Raw Like Sushi (1996’s Man didn’t even get a U.S. release) with an album-length collaboration with the Scandinavian experimental jazz outfit the Thing that leaned heavy on dissonant avant-funk and turned the cliche of the club diva’s late-career “jazzy” phase on its ear. A companion collection of remixes
column3: including one by Kieran Hebden of Four Tet
column4: followed. That crossing of paths has now led to Cherry album produced by Hebden that finally finds her returning to the basic—and hard to improve upon—combination of vocals and beats.

column1: Blank Project isn’t a roaring
column2: triumphant return to form. Instead it’s understated to the extreme
column3: a master class in the ways in which simple pleasures can become fascinatingly deep. The opening track
column4: “Across the Water”
column5: is simply Cherry singing over a bracingly austere drum arrangement
column6: with zero in the way of melodic accompaniment. Between her rich
column7: unembellished voice and emotional performance it’s somehow more overwhelming than most songs that have full orchestral backing.

column1: From that point
column2: things pick up a little
column3: although only by degrees. The rest of the songs have basslines
column4: but only about half go further to add lightly sketched synth parts on top. Some of the tracks push at the upper boundary of what’s normally considered mid-tempo
column5: but most fit comfortably within that range. There are no grand stylistic gestures or unnecessary moving parts or anything that qualifies as fussy.

column1: And yet within those parameters
column2: Cherry and Hebden find a wealth of moods and modes to play with. The title track takes the ricocheting rhythms of drum’n’bass and floods its normally icy aura with warmth and organic dirt that Cherry half-sings
column3: half-raps over; her delivery is forceful despite the fact that she barely raises her voice above a conversational level. “Spit Three Times” conjures up a woozy
column4: paranoid atmosphere and a slow-grinding trip-hop beat out of what seems like mostly negative space. “Out of the Black”
column5: featuring a vocal assist by Cherry acolyte Robyn
column6: feels like an ecstatic club-pop anthem played with the subdued confidence of someone well beyond the point of caring whether anyone else gets turned up over it or not.

column1: Minimalism is all the rage in the more hip-hop-aligned parts of the pop world
column2: making Blank Project feel modern and stylish without exactly sounding fashionable. The album
column3: and the woman steering it
column4: are not only comfortable with their eccentricities but strengthened by them
column5: and the effect is enthralling—not to mention a thorough schooling for the performers working in Cherry’s wake on how exactly to do the dead-cool
column6: stripped-down thing. As such
column7: it’s not hard at all to pick up some of her old “Buffalo Stance” cockiness in it. It’s a rare pleasure to see a musician who was under-appreciated during her heyday have a delayed influence a later generation of artists while she’s still in good working condition. It’s even rarer
column8: and even more pleasurable
column9:
to see her staying a few lengthy strides ahead of the game.

Even in a musical climate that prides itself on constant reinvention and change
column2: Mi Ami's artistic trajectory has been fascinating. At the top of this decade
column3: the bi-coastal noise outfit released their searing
column4: energizing second album
column5: Steal Your Face
column6: a heady swirl of dubby textures and throat-shredding vocals that sounded like a future-shocked take on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/23514-public-image-ltd/"" target=""_blank"">Public Image
column7: Ltd.'s paranoid wobble. The record delivered on the promise of the previous year's debut
column8: Watersports
column9: suggesting that Mi Ami's sound was rapidly crystallizing. Then they splintered from the inside. Bassist Jacob Long left the band
column10: and remaining members Damon Palermo and Daniel Martin-McCormick soldiered on with 2011's Dolphins
column11: a surprising left-turn that laid Martin-McCormick's panicked
column12: flailing vocals over thick
column13: clubby production.

column1: Mi Ami's turn towards the dancefloor was surprising
column2: but if you knew where to look
column3: Palermo and Martin-McCormick's side projects left clues. Martin-McCormick's Ital took a noisy
column4: chaotic approach to house
column5: with two full-lengths on Planet Mu and a smattering of releases on other labels that ran the gamut from abusive
column6: noisy body music to purple
column7: psychedelic swarm; meanwhile
column8: Palermo took a less circuitous path to club music as Magic Touch.

column1: His sole release from 2013
column2: the solid Nothing More EP
column3: carried a pristine sheen that sounded as if someone had taken a vacuum to the fuzzy detritus that surrounded his previous constructions for 100% Silk. Palermo's debut LP for the label
column4: Palermo House Gang
column5: still has plenty of dusty grit—one of the most endearing qualities of 100% Silk's output is how their releases sound as if you're hearing the music pumping out of speakers through thin walls in an adjacent room—but in its best moments
column6: the melodies are sharp and bright
column7: inching toward high-definition house.

column1: Over the past few years
column2: 100% Silk has overcome skepticism that their roster was mostly indie kids in dance music dress-up
column3: and the imprint is now one of the most consistently interesting underground dance labels in North America. Even when considering the increased reliability of the label's catalog
column4: though
column5: Palermo House Gang is impressively robust
column6: reverently embracing disco's sparkle and classic house music's sassy thump. The swaying saxophone of ""It's Love"" and ""Calabria""'s tropical humidity are not unlike something Frankie Knuckles would throw into one of his sets
column7: while the synth bleats that open album highlight ""You"" provide a tricky nod to Alice Deejay's trance classic ""Better Off Alone"" before unfolding into the type of skipping
column8: chopped-vocal body-mover evocative of New Jersey garage legend Todd Edwards.

column1: In addition to referencing house music
column2: the title Palermo House Gang suggests that
column3: keeping with Not Not Fun and 100% Silk's communal origins
column4: this is a group effort. And the album is in fact heavy on collaboration. Notably
column5: Brooklyn’s Octo Octa has his hand  in Palermo House Gang's two most notable highlights: ""You""
column6: which also features contributions from Body High-affiliated duo Newbody
column7: and the 13-minute ""House of Intuition""
column8: which accentuates dense drone and hypnotic hand-drum patterns with a cyclical
column9: sharp synth line that opens up beautifully in the track's final minutes.

column1: At its best
column2: Palermo House Gang is pure dance music candy
column3: smacking of familiar sounds done properly and with a little bit of roughness around the edges. Accordingly
column4: the record's minor structural hiccups—an unnecessary second mix of ""It's Love""
column5: the thin vocals laid atop opener ""I Need the Magic""
column6: a general lack of cohesion—suggest Palermo's best work is yet to come. His most well-known project has been marked by its perpetual change
column7:
but Palermo seems to have found sonic stability on his own.

column4: has built much of his career aesthetic on this paradox. Recall the video for the 2004 single ""I'd Rather Dance With You""
column5: which finds Øye in a red and white tracksuit
column6: navigating a throng of giggling girls in a ballet class and letting his limbs fly and droop in a series of choreographed moves. He's a master of leaning calmly into his gawkiness rather than attempting to mask it
column7: and he exudes an unassuming sort of confidence as a result. So it was no surprise to see him pop up alongside a young Bulgarian woman named DENA last summer in a video for a knowingly goofy but genuinely infectious rap single called <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r4CDc9yCAqE"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Cash
column8: Diamond Rings
column9: Swimming Pools"". There they were
column10: two peas in a pod: gangly
column11: welcoming
column12: unpretentious
column13: deeply European. ""If you're listening to this in a hot country/ Please come rescue me
column14: DENA raps in her thick Bulgarian accent in an assortment of clashing outfits
column15: ""If you got a swimming pool
column16: then we can be hanging.”

column1: Part M.I.A.-informed party rap
column2: part YouTube novelty
column3: part small-town Eastern European documentary
column4: “Cash
column5: Diamond Rings
column6: Swimming Pools” had all the hallmarks of a meme-y
column7: flash-in-the-pan internet rap hit. (DENA’s YouTube account name is ""denafromtheblock"".) But the kitsch of her style translates nicely across her debut album Flash
column8: a small and inviting record that is unfazed—delighted
column9: even—by its own rough edges and occasionally bumbling sensibilities. It’s an album that lifts from an almost comically basic hip-hop and social-media glossary to talk about young adult love and frustration and ambition in an endearing way: “Haters gonna hate/ Lovers gonna love/ If you mess with me/ You get a total ignore
column10: ” DENA raps bluntly on “Total Ignore”. “You can’t believe that my beats so banging/ Yeah
column11: I made it all while you were hanging
column12: ” she boasts. The production
column13: which DENA handled herself
column14: is a studied blend of clatter
column15: simple keyboard melodies
column16: and quiet boom-bap.

column1: Which isn’t to say that Flash is cartoon music. DENA strikes a delicate balance between sounding naive enough to pray to the altar of American rap flash and excess and savvy enough to recognize her own distance from it. “I haven’t been taking any planes today/ You’re the one who whisks away and I’m the one who stays
column2: ” she laments on “Jet Lag”. “I think I’m having jet lag without even having fun.” The record is more nuanced and knowing than simple white-girl gag rap; DENA’s charm buffers her from some of the pitfalls of her outsider-rap status. Flash carves her out a new space in a crowded sphere: She's a refreshing foil to the jaded slickness of an artist like Lorde
column3: the brutal tone-deafness of someone like the white Swedish rapper Yung Lean
column4: or the overbearing cutesiness of a Kitty Pryde.

column1: There’s a sense that DENA earned her sly stripes because she's a true music nerd
column2: and that she uses music as a means of escaping small-town claustrophobia. It’s evident on a song like “Cash
column3: Diamond Rings
column4: Swimming Pools”
column5: where she sings that she’s “hanging here and wishing to be there
column6: ending up with not really being anywhere.” Some of her best work came in the form of a SoundCloud mix called “High on Hi Hats”
column7: which blended together an unexpected list of contemporary remix obscurities with forgotten classics like Guru and Kelis’ “Supa Love”. Like the best kind of nerd
column8: she’s done her research. Now she just wants to participate and share
column9:
and doesn't mind showing off her imperfections in the process. 

"|18985.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18985-dena-flash/|6.7|Carrie Battan

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20222/homepage_large.3230763d.jpg|Interrupt|30610.0|Bleeding Rainbow|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kanine']|2014-02-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:41:05.092888|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1m65tipughs.1.6:0.1.0.$19018/=1$19018.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div>In 2009
column2: Bleeding Rainbow were called Reading Rainbow
column3: and their MySpace address
column4: lamentably
column5: was ""levarfuckingburton."" They changed their name shortly afterward
column6: because ""<a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&ved=0CCYQFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.brooklynvegan.com%2Farchives%2F2012%2F01%2Freading_rainbow.html&ei=n28GU4reFYujhgfY4oGwCw&usg=AFQjCNE9MA1-pKLGEMt8B1FBJqfPo-zA2Q&bvm=bv.61725948
column7: d.ZG4"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">we didn't want to get a cease and desist order from PBS
column8: and because ""we like the name Bleeding Rainbow better."" Making the hobbled-ankle leap from one dubious
column9: cutesy moniker to another in full view of your audience is
column10: to put it bluntly
column11: not a great way to ensure your future as a band.

column1: <div>They didn't break up
column2: however
column3: and over a few records
column4: they've slowly sorted out who they are. Their new album
column5: Interrupt
column6: is a zippy
column7: Superchunk-y set of buttoned-tight pop-rock songs that bounce nimbly on their heels for three or so minutes and then briskly exit. The album captures the band at a senior-year-in-high-school moment in their development: The fuckups and ill-fitting poses are all pretty fresh in the minds of everyone around them
column8: but they've located the beginnings of adult poise and their future looks brighter than their past.

column1: <div>For one
column2: Sarah Everton has found a powerful mid-register voice that she can belt with
column3: one she leans into enthusiastically on the real-deal big choruses of of ""Out of Line"" and ""Cut Up"". Robi Gonzalez
column4: the drummer for A Place to Bury Strangers
column5: recorded the album with them and was promptly replaced by another drummer (Ashley Arnwine)
column6: and his work is a stiff shot of adrenaline. The rhythm section is pulled as tight as hotel bedsheets
column7: Everton and Rob Garcia's vocals mesh neatly
column8: and the tempo stays brisk. Everything on the album is busily competent and in cheerful working order
column9: like a middle manager on their third cup of coffee making the late-morning rounds. The album is short and formulaic and bracing and
column10: while it's playing
column11: pretty great.

column1: <div>The band still doesn't have a distinct stamp
column2: though; on ""Monochrome
column3: they remain enraptured by My Bloody Valentine
column4: dripping distorted glimmers and pitch-bends all over song's edges. Being many things at once isn't a sin
column5: of course
column6: but Bleeding Rainbow aren't great at enough of those things to justify using up our time trying them out. The strained
column7: shouty ""Images"" recalls Foo Fighter's ""Monkey Wrench
column8: and while ""Monkey Wrench"" is an excellent power-pop tune
column9: the shouting does not flatter Garcia at all.""I fall all the time
column10: goes the chorus to ""Cut Up
column11: one of their punchiest and best songs. These guys may not be the most graceful outfit out there
column12: but they are surprisingly scrappy
column13: and they've picked themselves up from a couple of minor faceplants with aplomb. "|19018.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19018-bleeding-rainbow-interrupt/|6.4|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20203/homepage_large.e9dad183.jpg|Your Arsenal|2837.0|Morrissey|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Parlophone']|2014-02-21 00:00:00|1992|2016-06-11 16:41:05.751436|"

The title of Morrissey's third solo studio album is a sly triple-entendre. It can mean ""the power you command
column2: or it can be a pun on ""your arse an' all
column3: but it's also a joke about an association football club as subcultural identity. That suggests a song that might be a key to the record—a song that's not actually on it
column4: but one that Morrissey had used to end his 1990 videotape Hulmerist and would use as entrance music some years later.

column1: The specter of ""You'll Never Walk Alone""
column2: the king of all football-fan sing-alongs thanks to its association with Liverpool (and Pink Floyd)
column3: hovers over the whole album: the chopped-up football-kop voices in the middle of ""We'll Let You Know""
column4: the chord progression and sentiment of ""I Know It's Gonna Happen Someday""
column5: and most of all the relatively uncharacteristic first-person plural Morrissey uses and implies throughout Your Arsenal. Viewed in that light
column6: beginning the album with a song called ""You're Gonna Need Someone on Your Side"" seems formally appropriate.

column2: that's exactly what Morrissey needed; he had apparently realized that
column3: as Oscar Wilde might have put it
column4: the only thing worse than being in a rock band was not being in a rock band. Your Arsenal
column5: unlike the previous year's Kill Uncle
column6: sounded like the work of a real group—as indeed it was. He'd assembled guitarists Alain Whyte and Boz Boorer
column7: bassist Gary Day
column8: and drummer Spencer Cobrin for the extensive Kill Uncle tour
column9: and kept them around to record. (Boorer is still playing with Morrissey today
column10: and Whyte stayed with him until 2004.) Boorer had previously played with rockabilly revivalists the Polecats
column11: who'd had minor British hits with covers of David Bowie's <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GirgbG9GxoQ"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""John
column12: I'm Only Dancing"" and T. Rex's ""Jeepster"". And Morrissey roped in one of the former song's architects to produce Your Arsenal: Mick Ronson
column13: who'd been Bowie's guitarist and principal creative foil in the early 1970s.

column1: Morrissey has never been shy about paying homage to his favorite records
column2: but Your Arsenal comes off at first like an out-and-out glam rock pastiche—""glam rock"" defined
column3: for these purposes
column4: as ""Bowie plus T. Rex minus the strings"". ""Glamorous Glue"" stomps like ""The Jean Genie""
column5: ""Certain People I Know"" cops its guitar licks from ""Ride a White Swan""
column6: and ""I Know It's Gonna Happen Someday"" winks so hard at ""Rock 'n' Roll Suicide"" that Bowie winked back
column7: covering it a year later on Black Tie White Noise.

column1: The homage that eventually emerges from Your Arsenal
column2: though
column3: is closer to home: it often sounds like Morrissey and Whyte (who co-wrote eight of its 10 songs) doing their best approximation of the Smiths. It's odd to intimate that someone would be imitating his own band
column4: but really: there could have have been endless ways to arrange <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zv1zy-7-PgE"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Seasick
column5: Yet Still Docked"" that didn't sound quite so much like the Smiths' ""That Joke Isn't Funny Anymore""
column6: for instance. On Viva Hate and Kill Uncle
column7: Morrissey had been demonstrating what his voice and his oddball sense of tune could do with collaborators who distinctly weren't Johnny Marr; this time
column8: his band does their damnedest to recapture the old vibe.

column1: It was inevitable that someone would be disgruntled with whatever Morrissey decided to do
column2: and his habit of amplifying anything that annoys anyone means he's more Morrisseyesque than ever before here. That was great news for his singing—his tics are his glories—but it often blindsides his lyrics. Morrissey's commitment to ironizing everything including his own irony ends up undercutting any position he might be staking out. Hence ""You're the One for Me
column3: Fatty""
column4: whose hook's cleverness leaves him flailing for other utterances to follow it up with. Hence also the (more or less) trumped-up furor over ""The National Front Disco"": Morrissey is clearly declaring ""England for the English"" in great big quotation marks
column5: especially considering that at the end of the previous track he's announced that ""we are the last truly British people you'll ever know""—nationalism pumped up until it disintegrates into meaninglessness—but all the kisses he's blown to creeps and thugs make it harder to swallow.

column1: Morrissey can't resist ironizing his own team spirit
column2: either
column3: which leads straight to the album's best song and his solo career's best joke
column4: ""We Hate It When Our Friends Become Successful"". (Egotists are always funnier when they can mock their own egotism.) Its ""we"" is a delicious bit of rhetoric—it presumes the listener's agreement—and so is the whiplash sequence of perspective shifts at the end: ""You see
column5: it should've been me... Everybody says so."" And what is it that makes Morrissey's work <a href=""http://sisii2011.blogspot.com/2011/06/richard-hamilton-just-what-is-it-that.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">so different
column6: so appealing? He spells it out: ""Loads of songs/ So many songs... Verse/ Chorus/ Middle eight/ Break
column7: fade."" Nobody else is doing that!

column1: Naturally
column2: Morrissey has now doubled down on the annoyance factor of his last few reissues by tinkering with the track listing of Your Arsenal a bit—""Tomorrow"" has been replaced by its American single mix. In lieu of a tacky badge
column3: this edition comes with a slightly muddy but passable live DVD filmed at California's Shoreline Amphitheatre in October
column5: four months or so after the concert that became the Live in Dallas video. The only song it's got in common with the album is ""We Hate It...""
column6: which was then still six months away from its appearance as Your Arsenal's first single. The new band is solid
column7: and they even work up a bit of rockabilly heat here and there
column8: but nobody's threatening Morrissey's position as the captain of the team
column9:
so he's not particularly fighting for it.

"|18999.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18999-morrissey-your-arsenal/|7.3|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20212/homepage_large.5a0fa63f.jpg|Voices in a Rented Room|32059.0|New Bums|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-02-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:41:06.191218|"

For many musicians
column2: the act of picking out a tune on an acoustic guitar and singing along is the easiest
column3: most pleasurable
column4: and therapeutic thing in the world. And
column5: not coincidentally
column6: it’s also the most tired and clichéd mode of performance
column7: one forever associated with egregiously earnest
column8: coffeehouse-scented singer-songwriter hokum. As products of the post-millennial West Coast acid-folk insurgence
column9: Ben Chasny and Donovan Quinn have spent a great deal of the past decade reinstating the acoustic guitar as an agent of experimentalism rather than sentimentalism: Under his nom de psych
column10: Six Organs of Admittance
column11: Chasny has amassed a formidable catalogue of string-and-mind-bending ragas
column12: while Quinn has used his unplugged instrument as a springboard into more fantastical realms with the Skygreen Leopards. But now that they’re cracking open their guitar cases side-by-side as New Bums
column13: the two present themselves with their most formidable challenge yet: to make something familiar—i.e.
column14: a low-key
column15: classic-rock-inspired record—uniquely their own.

column1: According to Chasny’s blog
column2: New Bums’ debut album has been in the works on-and-off for roughly five years
column3: but Voices in a Rented Room sounds like it was written and recorded in about five hours
column4: with one set of eyes on a watch and the other on the wallet. But that’s as much a comment on the album’s purity of vision and effortless execution as its scrappy
column5: off-the-cuff vibe. Melodically
column6: these 12 songs would fit more comfortably in Quinn’s canon than Chasny’s
column7: though the latter’s experience covering old Gary Higgins obscurities prepares him well for the sweet serenading required here. Rather than contrast their voices and personalities
column8: Voices in a Rented Room presents its participants as a united front and
column9: luckily
column10: their harmonizing sounds a lot like a double-tracked Marc Bolan vocal. (The opening “Black Bough” will immediately endear itself to anyone whose favorite T. Rex song is “Ballrooms of Mars.”)

column1: True to its title
column2: Voices in a Rented Room is modestly scaled and simply structured; the tone and form established in a song’s first verse don’t change by the time we reach the third. But even within these confines
column3: New Bums rarely retrace their steps: the beautifully dazed “Sometimes You Crash” sounds like something a strung-out Alex Chilton would have strummed out during a late-night session for Big Star’s Third/Sister Lovers
column4: whereas the busker boogie of “Your Bullshit” imagines an alternate 1990s where Royal Trux sold enough records for Virgin to get their own MTV Unplugged episode. But what makes this album special—and a highlight amid both principals’ sprawling discographies—is the way Chasny and Quinn offset their idyllic
column5: campfire-ready accessibility with mellow-harshing irreverence. New Bums are ultimately a harmony duo that thrives on mischief and discord: pretty songs laden with cuss words
column6: absurdist expressions of modern-bromance (“Your Girlfriend Might Be a Cop”)
column7: oblique references to those poor heshers who shot themselves in the head after listening to Judas Priest. On Voices in a Rented Room
column8:
Chasny and Quinn resemble not so much folk singers as punk pranksters who couldn’t afford to pay their electricity bill. Just call ’em Simon & Garfuckoff. 

"|19008.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19008-new-bums-voices-in-a-rented-room/|7.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20263/homepage_large.27a700b6.jpg|I Am Back To Blow Your Mind Once Again|11611.0|Peter Buck|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mississippi']|2014-02-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:41:06.869227|"

In the late 1970s and early 80s
column2: the members of the newly-formed R.E.M. cut their teeth on typical bar-band fare. They gigged around Athens playing a range rock'n'roll standards
column3: from the Velvet Underground’s “There She Goes Again” to Johnny Kidd & the Pirates’ “Shakin’ All Over”. As Tony Fletcher writes in his exhaustive band bio Perfect Circle
column4: “People danced
column5: drank
column6: and sang along when they recognized a Sixties’ pop classic like [the Monkees’] ‘Stepping Stone’… Others frowned upon the proliferation of cover songs; in a community with such a strong reputation for art
column7: innovation was a prerequisite for performing.” Eventually
column8: the quartet seeded their sets with more and more originals
column9: including early versions of “Radio Free Europe” and “Sitting Still”
column10: but those early covers held sway over the band for years
column11: informing the ramshackle charms of Dead Letter Office and their infamous cover of the Clique’s “Superman” on Lifes Rich Pageant.

column1: After R.E.M. dissolved in 2011
column2: guitarist Peter Buck was quick out of the gate with his first solo album
column3: which returned to those early influences to find fresh inspiration. He covered old bluesmen and wrote songs that sounded like they could have been pounded out in somebody’s garage ca. 1966. Rather than derivative
column4: that album sounded loose and nervy
column5: as thought he’d finally broken free of the best-band-in-the-world expectations that quashed so many of R.E.M.’s eccentricities in the 2000s. That he returns to this general sound for his follow-up
column6: the immodestly titled I Am Back to Blow Your Mind Once Again
column7: is no surprise at all. Nor is it unwelcome: Songs like the jittery rave-up “Monkey Mask” and the gangly jangle “My Slobbering Decline” bristle with the excitement of a kid staying up late to watch black-and-white monster movies on cable.

column1: As a solo artist Buck has repeatedly signaled his willingness to indulge some of his weirder impulses
column2: both musical and commercial. As with his debut
column3: I Am Back will be released exclusively on vinyl
column4: via Portland indie Mississippi Records. Again
column5: he enlisted a small core of friends as his backing band: Adam Selzer
column6: Scott McCaughey
column7: and Bill Rieflin. Corin Tucker returns for the murky country-goth ballad “Drown with Me”
column8: while Drive-By Trucker Patterson Hood narrates “Southerner” as Buck unleashes squalls of Monster-era feedback behind him. Both the solemnity of the piece and its  reliance on real-world details contrast the fantastical nature of much of Buck’s songwriting
column9: with its nods to apes and aliens and parties
column10: yet Hood’s sense of personal reminiscence reinforces the nostalgia that clearly motivates Buck’s solo material.

column1: I Am Back not only picks up where Peter Buck left off
column2: but sounds like an extension of that album’s sessions and sensibility. Except that it’s better: more focused and funnier
column3: although not so much better that it sounds polished or loses its DIY grit. Still wooly and weird
column4: I Am Back shows a slightly stronger sense of the sideman’s strengths and weaknesses as a frontman. Buck does
column5: in fact
column6: seem like a creditable bandleader
column7: almost like a newly zombified Sam the Sham. Rather than write a bridge for “Monkey Mask”
column8: he simply yells
column9: “Sun Ra!” and lets his band burst into some slapstick noise-rock. On the outro
column10: he calls out Mighty Joe Young as “nothing but a fat man in an antiquated monkey suit. I’ll kick his ass.” In addition to making better use of the grit and grime in his bizarre voice
column11: which is the definition of “acquired taste
column12: ” Buck enlarges his musical palette
column13: not just writing lowdown blues-pop numbers that sound like covers but also driving the Ramones to the beach on “Gotta Get Outta the House” and chasing two-headed dogs with Roky Erickson on “West of Sunset”.

column1: Buck’s return to these early sounds as the template for future experiments is something of a—forgive the pun—perfect circle. I Am Back gives the impression of a man approaching everything with the enthusiasm of an adolescent
column2: as though he had just heard Ramones and the Nightcrawlers’ “Little Black Egg” (which is all but quoteed in ""Fall on My Own Sword"") for the very first time. The album itself is far too loose
column3: too modest
column4: too personal
column5: too fans-only to live up to its grandiose title
column6:
but perhaps it’s not Buck’s intention. Perhaps that’s only the music talking: old songs cropping up to blow Buck’s mind once again.

"|19059.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19059-peter-buck-i-am-back-to-blow-your-mind-once-again/|7.1|Stephen M. Deusner
